IREIT Global Group acquired a Berlin property for $217.2 million, while Keppel Infrastructure Trust acquired a 51% stake in Keppel Merlimau Cogen Pte Ltd for $510 million. Keppel Corp appointed Veronica Eng as an independent director, and Sembcorp Development secured rights to develop a 750-hectare industrial park in Vietnam. SingHaiyi Group will invest up to $134.4 million in a joint venture to acquire Park Mall. China Sky Chemical Fibre posted a net profit of $15.8 million for FY2014, up 5% from the previous year. These deals mark significant investments in real estate and infrastructure.

site_title: Athens requests 2-year rescue deal with EU to cover financing needs
summary: Greece has requested a 2-year rescue deal with the European Union to cover its financing needs, amid an impending crisis that could trigger a eurozone exit. The deal, proposed by Prime Minister Alexis Tsipras, would involve restructuring debt and accepting creditors' reform proposals. The EU had offered a last-minute deal, but Greek Finance Minister Yanis Varoufakis has rejected it, and a referendum on the proposals is set for Sunday. Failure to pay a key IMF repayment would see Greece default on the IMF since 2001, and European leaders warn that a "yes" vote in the referendum would allow creditors to negotiate with a new government.

site_title: Currency traders want clarity as bloopers stoke volatility
summary: Currency traders are seeking clarity on policy direction from world leaders and central bankers, as recent gaffes have caused volatility in currency markets. The euro tumbled after a reported rejection of Greece's reform proposal, but rallied after it was clarified. Traders want fewer surprises and more transparency, particularly as the second half of the year approaches.

site_title: Novo's Q4 loss widens to US$11.3 million
summary: Novo Group, a Chinese steel company, reported a widened net loss of US$11.32 million in its Q4 2015, down from US$6.52 million a year ago, due to slashed selling prices to clear inventories and maintain market share. Revenue plummeted 69.9% to US$22.27 million, and the company's net loss for the full year deepened to US$20.58 million. Despite the downturn, Novo Group remains optimistic about its medium-term prospects, citing improved market conditions and opportunities in the steel and raw materials trading business in Asia.

site_title: A family business for tomorrow
summary: A family business for tomorrow is a question for entrepreneurs and small-business owners nearing retirement, as they consider their future. Meanwhile, Japan's Sojitz plans to open a specialist centre in Tokyo or Osaka, while NUS researchers aim to halve the price of sustainable marine fuel. OCBC targets S$5 billion in loans for serial entrepreneurs by 2028. Businesses like Shatec and Hao Mart are facing challenges, with Shatec shutting its campus and training restaurant, and Hao Mart's Taste Orchard experiencing poor footfall and vacant units. Rebranding efforts are also underway in the food industry, such as Munchi Pancakes modernizing traditional min jiang kueh.

site_title: Oil rout puts smaller drillers at advantage as big players cut back
summary: Smaller oil drillers are gaining ground as major energy companies cut back on spending and idle drilling rigs due to the decline in crude oil prices. Smaller explorers are seizing the opportunity to explore fields in Africa, Latin America, and other regions, taking advantage of declining costs and increased availability of rigs. Smaller companies can now drill wells for significantly lower costs, making them more attractive to investors.

site_title: SGX woos Israeli startups for IPOs
summary: The Singapore Exchange (SGX) is targeting Israeli startups for initial public offerings (IPOs) as the bourse seeks to expand its presence in the region. SGX officials have made visits to Israel in recent months to court Israeli listing hopefuls, particularly in the medical and telecom sectors. This move aims to capitalize on the growing demand for capital and visibility among Israeli startups looking to expand their business propositions in Asia.

images.alt_text: Anita Gabriel

site_title: PM Lee makes fresh plug on raising productivity
summary: Singapore Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong emphasized the need for the country to boost productivity by 2% annually to achieve its economic growth forecast of 2-4% per year. Despite poor progress, he acknowledged that it will be a "hard slog" requiring transformation in society, economy, and businesses. The government aims to reach 2-3% annual productivity growth by 2020, with a focus on education and training to prepare workers for the future economy, as automation and technology may displace jobs. Lee also highlighted the challenges of an aging population and the importance of maintaining Singapore's unique identity.

images.alt_text: Lee U-Wen

Mr Lee says improving productivity and maintaining economic growth are the only way for Singaporeans to continue finding good jobs and creating opportunities, as Singapore has only its human capital to speak of.

site_title: Artivision clinches several Israeli deals
summary: Artivision Technologies, a Singapore-listed company, has clinched several deals with Israeli entities, including managing programmatic video campaigns for Lapam, Israel's government advertising agency. Artimedia, a wholly owned unit, will provide full campaign management services through its automated video buying platform, Advision. This deal was secured through a competitive process, marking Artivision's expansion into the Israeli market. The company's move aims to capitalize on the growing demand for digital advertising solutions in the region.

site_title: Petrobras to slash spending, restore confidence
summary: Brazil's state-run oil company Petrobras has cut its long-term spending plan to US$130.3 billion for 2015-2019, the lowest level in eight years, in an effort to reduce its massive debt burden and restore confidence after a devastating corruption scandal. The plan is 41% lower than its previous five-year plan and includes a reduced forecast for global production to 3.7 million barrels per day. Despite the cuts, Petrobras does not expect to pay off its US$120 billion debt within six years, and the plan's lack of specifics has raised concerns about the company's ability to resolve its debt issues.

site_title: S'pore unlikely to go Scandinavian way to up fertility rate
summary: Singapore is unlikely to adopt generous policies like Scandinavian countries to boost its fertility rate. Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong said the country's society is different and it's a balance between career progression and family life. The PM noted that Scandinavian countries have achieved a higher total fertility rate (TFR) due to strong government measures and industrial support for parental leave. Lee suggested that Singapore could consider similar measures, but it would require a higher goods and services tax to fund the policies.

images.alt_text: Lee U-Wen

site_title: Design Studio Group names new CEO
summary: Design Studio Group has named Ku Wei Siong as its new CEO, effective September 1, replacing Bernard Lim Leng Foo. Lim's departure was announced on March 4, citing personal interests. Ku brings strong credentials and experience, having previously served as senior vice-president at CapitaLand GCC Holdings. The group's non-executive chairman, Tan Siok Chin, praised Lim's tenure, saying he left the group in a strong position with a capable management team. A management committee has been formed to oversee day-to-day operations during the transition period.

images.alt_text: Nisha Ramchandani

site_title: Rolls-Royce to get S$60m Leng Kee showroom
summary: Eurokars Group, owned by motor magnate Karsono Kwee, plans to invest S$60 million to build a new Rolls-Royce showroom in Singapore, located in an 8-storey building with 40,000 sq ft of space, set to begin construction in Q1 2016. The new facility will also serve as Eurokars' flagship headquarters, replacing the current showroom at 29 Leng Kee Road, which is congested due to the growing model line-up. The move is seen as a strategic investment to support the brand's growth in the market, despite current sales challenges due to loan curbs and progressive taxes.

images.alt_text: Rolls-Royce currently shares the premises at 29 Leng Kee Road with the Porsche brand. Mr Kwee says it is congested and the situation will be further exacerbated with a growing line-up of models.

site_title: US Ex-Im Bank unable to approve loans as charter lapses
summary: The US Export-Import Bank (Ex-Im) charter has lapsed due to a lack of Congressional action, affecting financing for US exporters such as Boeing and General Electric. The lapse is temporary, with Congress potentially re-authorizing the institution next month. Pending applications total over $9 billion, and Ex-Im will continue to work on existing agreements but cannot approve new loans or guarantees. Proponents argue the bank supports US jobs, while opponents see it as cronyism, citing unfair favoritism towards certain companies. Ex-Im supporters plan to meet with President Obama to push for legislation to revive the institution.

site_title: Manila developers expanding into industrial estates
summary: Manila developers are expanding into industrial estates as the government aims to make the Philippines a car manufacturing hub, attracting Japanese carmakers and other companies. The industrial sector is expected to get a boost, with average annual rent in Philippine industrial estates at US$5 per square metre, compared to China's US$7. Builders such as Ayala Land and Megaworld Corp are developing industrial properties to diversify their portfolios, while the government offers tax incentives to support car production.

site_title: A staunch ally from the start
summary: Singapore and Canada mark the 50th anniversary of their diplomatic ties, with Canada being one of the first countries to acknowledge Singapore's independence in 1965. Canada's Prime Minister Lester Pearson recognized Singapore's independence in a letter to then Prime Minister Lee Kuan Yew, establishing diplomatic relations later that year. Over the past 50 years, the bilateral relationship has grown considerably, with Canada's High Commissioner to Singapore stating that the relationship has evolved in line with changes and developments in both countries.

images.alt_text: "Canada is recognised as one of the most innovative and competitive economies in the world . . . in this respect, I suspect we are not unlike Singapore. Canada generates over 4 per cent of global knowledge despite accounting for only 0.5 per cent of the world's population."- High Commissioner Heather Grant
Since 2011, Canadian and Singapore volunteers have organised Terry Fox runs at East Coast Parkway, raising close to S$800,000 for cancer research here.
Thousands of Singaporeans have studied in Canada, taking advantage of its affordable world-class education.
Singapore was admitted as an accredited observer to the Arctic Council during Canada's chairmanship of the organisation from 2013 to 2015.

site_title: Tender deadline pushed back for Choa Chu Kang EC plot
summary: The tender deadline for the Choa Chu Kang EC plot has been pushed back to July 28 due to a new condition requiring the development to be set back at least 15 meters from the line of road reserve. The 99-year leasehold site can yield about 490 residential units. Analysts had previously expressed concerns about the site's limited amenities and distance from the MRT station, with forecasts suggesting it would fetch between three and seven bids, with a top bid in the S$250 to S$330 per square foot per plot ratio range.

images.alt_text: Mindy Tan

site_title: Brokers' take
summary: ComfortDelGro's subsidiary, Metroline Rail Ltd, has been shortlisted as one of four potential operators for London Overground. This development is seen as a positive for the company, with a potential 3% impact on net profit in FY17F if it wins the tender. Ho Bee has sold its Forte industrial building for S$66 million, generating a net gain of S$6.9 million. The company plans to deploy the cash proceeds to reduce bank borrowings and working capital.

site_title: Greece referendum may well be a political gamble to buy more time
summary: Greek Prime Minister Alexis Tsipras's decision to hold a national referendum on July 5 may be a calculated move to buy time, rather than an impulsive one. The referendum aims to gauge support for austerity measures, with a "no" vote potentially allowing Tsipras to decide the next course of action. A default on July 20, when Greece must pay 3.5 billion euros to the European Central Bank, would have significant consequences, including the potential derailment of the Greek banking system. Markets will closely watch the outcome, with a Greek default potentially having limited macroeconomic impact but posing risks to weaker EU countries.

images.alt_text: Greek Prime Minister Alexis Tsipras's decision to call for a national referendum on July 5 may not have been an impulsive move.

site_title: JetBlue poised to add luggage charge in fare revamp
summary: JetBlue Airways is set to introduce a new fare scale with a three-tiered pricing system, eliminating its complimentary luggage policy for coach passengers. The airline aims to boost revenue by at least $200 million annually by 2017. The change will leave Southwest Airlines as the only major US carrier with no checked bag fee. JetBlue plans to offer lower base fares and a new online booking tool, with options to purchase additional luggage or perks like loyalty points and refundability.

site_title: Conditions for 2nd Woodlands Square commercial site unveiled
summary: Singapore has unveiled conditions for the second commercial site in Woodlands Square, open for application under the government land sales (GLS) programme. Two industrial sites in Ubi and Tampines are also released for sale, while a Reserve List site in Tuas Bay Close is open for application. These sites are part of the first-half 2015 industrial GLS (iGLS) programme, offering developers the opportunity to build in strategic locations. The conditions and sites are now available for interested developers to apply.

site_title: Mobile phone makers hit by consumers extending upgrade cycles
summary: US consumers are extending their mobile phone upgrade cycles, holding onto their devices for 20-24 months instead of 15 months, leading to declining sales for manufacturers like Samsung and HTC. Phone financing, popularized by T-Mobile in 2013, has become widespread, with almost two-thirds of AT&T subscribers opting for financing plans. This shift is expected to contribute to a slowdown in smartphone sales, with shipments rising only 5.3% a year until 2018. As a result, handset makers like Samsung and HTC are facing increased competition and financial challenges.

site_title: IMF may take back seat in Greek talks with missed payment
summary: The International Monetary Fund (IMF) may lose its prominent role in Greek debt talks after Greece's anticipated failure to pay $1.7 billion, cutting off further IMF funds. This would limit the IMF to providing technical advice and training, a shift from its current role in providing financial assistance. The missed payment would be the largest in the fund's history and the first time an advanced economy has fallen into arrears.

site_title: International buyers snap up German stores
summary: International buyers are rapidly snapping up German retail properties, with almost 6 billion euros invested in the first half of 2015, a threefold increase from the same period in 2014. Despite declining footfall and falling shop sales, investors are drawn to Germany's stable economy, cheap financing, and high yields of over 3.5%. The market may be peaking, with prime leases losing momentum, but investors are buying supermarkets and DIY retail parks, which are more resistant to online shopping.

site_title: Monetary stance likely to stay easy for a while: RBA chief
summary: Australian Reserve Bank Governor Glenn Stevens stated that global monetary policy will remain "very accommodative" for a while, relying on regulatory measures to address potential financial excesses. He noted that inflation is low globally and that central banks' primary objective may shift from price stability to financial stability. Stevens also expressed concerns about the underlying liquidity of financial markets, which could be a challenge when interest rates turn. The RBA's view on the Australian dollar remains unchanged, with Stevens predicting further depreciation.

site_title: Restaurant booking startup Chope raises US$8m
summary: Restaurant booking startup Chope has raised US$8 million in Series C funding, its third round of financing, led by F&H Fund Management, NSI Ventures, and existing investor Singapore Press Holdings. This follows previous funding rounds of US$3.5 million since Chope's launch in 2011.

site_title: Against all odds
summary: A specialist healthcare centre is set to open in Tokyo or Osaka, Japan, following Sojitz's acquisition. Researchers at NUS aim to halve the price of sustainable marine fuel. Meanwhile, Hao Mart's Taste Orchard faces poor footfall and vacant units, prompting tenant concerns. OCBC targets S$5 billion in loans to serial entrepreneurs by 2028. Shatec shuts its Orchard campus, cuts staff, and puts the building up for sale. An otah business is rebranding heritage for the younger generation, while Munchi Pancakes modernizes traditional min jiang kueh as a 'national snack'.

summary:

OCBC targets serial entrepreneurs for S$5 billion in loans by 2028. Shatec shuts down its Orchard campus and cuts staff, putting the building up for sale. Meanwhile, businesses like an otah business and Munchi Pancakes modernize traditional snacks to appeal to younger generations.

site_title: Study suggests Google skews search results
summary: A study led by Harvard and Columbia researchers found that Google sometimes alters search results to promote its own content, despite user preferences. In a test of 2,690 users, those who saw search results including links from rival sites like Yelp were 45% more likely to click on links. The study's findings could renew calls for government regulators to reopen an investigation into Google for antitrust violations, and may also provide new ammunition for officials in Europe who have accused the company of unfair practices. Google questioned the results, saying the methodology was flawed and the study was a public relations exercise.

images.alt_text: Google entices people to search by promising links to the best that the Web has to offer.

site_title: Tennis player manager IMG makes bold strokes to reassert its marketing magic
summary: IMG, the tennis player management company, has reasserted its marketing magic after a tumultuous year, signing or reaching agreements with top players including Maria Sharapova, Novak Djokovic, and Nick Kyrgios. Despite early setbacks with rising star Eugenie Bouchard, IMG remains committed to accumulating talent, prioritizing its focus on attracting top players. The company's executives, Ari Emanuel and Patrick Whitesell, reject concerns about their influence over the industry, citing their ability to represent clients in multiple fields and their commitment to treating clients properly. As IMG builds towards a possible initial public offering, it faces competition from boutique agencies and must navigate its debt load and limited event holdings.

images.alt_text: Some of the stars IMG Tennis represents are Kei Nishikori of Japan (above), Maria Sharapova, Li Na, Novak Djokovic, Petra Kvitova, Jo-Wilfried Tsonga and Nick Kyrgios.

Eugenie Bouchard arriving for the WTA pre-Wimbledon party on June 25. Bouchard has been the biggest disappointment for IMG. She has won only four of 16 matches since a quarterfinal run at the Australian Open this year. But at age 21, her commercial prospects and chances of rebounding remain strong.

site_title: UOB helping clients invest in Myanmar
summary: UOB is ramping up its activities in Myanmar, with clients investing US$300 million over the next 12 months in projects such as factories, hotels, and commercial properties. The bank will provide working capital and term loans for these projects, focusing on infrastructure, manufacturing, and hospitality sectors. UOB forecasts Myanmar's economy to grow at a 8% annual rate, with US$163 billion in foreign direct investment expected over the next 15 years. The bank has established a dedicated FDI Advisory unit in Myanmar to help businesses identify opportunities in the country.

images.alt_text: UOB - one of nine foreign banks awarded a banking licence in Myanmar last year - will officially open its Yangon branch on Thursday. Although the branch began business in May, the bank has been engaging clients interested in Myanmar for the last couple of years.
Mr Wong said that the bank's differentiator is its ability to help clients understand regulations as they evolved in Myanmar.

site_title: New Deutsche Bank chief under pressure to reverse fortunes fast
summary: Deutsche Bank's new CEO, John Cryan, faces pressure to reverse the bank's fortunes after the departure of two co-CEOs. Investors want him to tackle issues including regulatory run-ins, high operating costs, and a sprawling investment bank. Cryan has set a self-imposed deadline to publish the bank's strategic plan by July 30, with a focus on cost-cutting, restructuring, and increasing competence. Shareholders expect him to improve execution and tighten governance, while accelerating reforms to modernize technology and restructure the bank.

site_title: Euro slips back as Greek default looms
summary: The euro slipped back in Asian trade on Tuesday, hours before Greece's debt repayment deadline, potentially leading to a default and eurozone exit. Greek Prime Minister Alexis Tsipras announced a July 5 referendum on austerity measures, sparking fears of a crisis escalation. The euro eased to 136.90 yen, down from 137.82 yen, and the US dollar inched down to 122.33 yen. A Capital Economics analysis suggested the risk of a near-term Grexit has risen above 50%.

site_title: Chicago business activity index rose to 49.4 in June from 46.2
summary: Chicago's business activity index rose to 49.4 in June, a slower contraction than the previous month, from 46.2. Orders grew, but factory employment contracted at a faster pace. Economists had forecast a rise to 50. The national factory index is expected to show a slight increase to 53.1 in June, indicating continued manufacturing growth.

site_title: Wealthy people still prefer shopping the old-fashioned way
summary: Wealthy individuals, defined as those earning at least $150,000 and having a net worth of $2.9 million, prefer traditional shopping methods, such as visiting stores and receiving guidance from salespeople. A survey of 1,600 affluent shoppers found that nearly half of women don't research jewelry before buying, and 60% of women opt to avoid online research for fashion accessories. Luxury retailers must adapt by training workers to build human relationships and providing knowledge, rather than simply trying to "sell" products.

site_title: US consumer confidence improves in June
summary: US consumer confidence rose to 101.4 in June, matching March's level and surpassing a downwardly revised May reading of 94.6. The improving jobs market contributed to the increase, contrary to economists' forecasts of a 97.3 reading. The jobs index fell to 25.7 in June from May's adjusted 27.2.

site_title: Grexit will be the staggering cost of a non-independent central bank
summary: The European Central Bank (ECB) has frozen emergency liquidity assistance to Greece, effectively pushing the country towards leaving the eurozone. This decision, made despite the ECB's deep politicization and lack of independence, is seen as a failure in its core responsibility to maintain financial stability. The ECB's refusal to provide liquidity is attributed to its fear of losses, despite the fact that the Greek central bank and people would bear the costs. The move is also criticized for undermining the eurozone's governance and the ECB's own independence, raising concerns about the long-term consequences of Grexit.

images.alt_text: On paper, the European Central Bank enjoys full independence. Its board members cannot be revoked and their long eight-year mandate cannot be renewed. So they do not have to please member governments. Yet they reluctantly violated the no-bailout clause to please member governments.

site_title: MAS to cut distinction between int'l, domestic banking ops
summary: The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) plans to remove the distinction between domestic and international banking operations by cutting the distinction between the domestic banking unit (DBU) and the Asian currency unit (ACU). This move aims to simplify banking operations and align with global regulatory standards. Deputy Prime Minister Tharman said the DBU-ACU divide has lost relevance due to increased global regulatory requirements and the blurring of lines between domestic and offshore banking activities.

site_title: As they see it
summary: A Singapore startup, Viddsee, is building a video empire by curating an online library of Asian short films, available for free. Founded in 2013, the platform aims to promote Asian cinema globally.

site_title: Singapore to ease banks' local and offshore regulations
summary: Singapore is relaxing rules requiring banks to segregate domestic and international operations into separate accounting entities. The move aims to simplify regulations and reduce administrative burdens. Deputy Prime Minister Tharman Shanmugaratnam stated that the current division, introduced in the late 1960s, has become less relevant due to enhanced global and domestic regulatory standards. The Monetary Authority of Singapore will provide details of the new regulations in a consultation paper by August, with the changes to be implemented in close consultation with the banking community over time.

site_title: More large apartments put up for mortgagee sale in H1
summary: There was a 38% increase in total auction listings in Singapore's property market in the first six months of 2015, with 378 listings, compared to the second half of 2014. Large apartments above 1,500 sq ft saw a spike in mortgagee sales, while strata-titled industrial properties also saw an increase. However, most owners can continue servicing their mortgage loans, and the market is expected to remain challenging due to stringent loan curbs and affordability concerns. Colliers International expects this trend to continue, with high demand for affordable properties priced below S$1.5 million.

site_title: Eurozone to discuss new Greece request
summary: Eurozone finance ministers are set to discuss Greece's last-minute proposal for a two-year rescue deal, just hours before its current bailout expires. Greek Prime Minister Alexis Tsipras requested the deal to avoid a "technical default" and a 1.5 billion euro payment to the IMF. The proposal comes after the Eurogroup rejected an extension to Greece's bailout program and a referendum on reform demands by creditors. European Commission chief Jean-Claude Juncker has proposed a "last-minute" solution involving Tsipras accepting creditor demands and backing a "yes" vote in the referendum.

site_title: At least 116 dead in Indonesia military plane crash: officials
summary: At least 116 people were killed in a military plane crash in Medan, Indonesia, on Tuesday. The Hercules C-130 plane, carrying 113 people, crashed into a residential area shortly after take-off and exploded in a fireball. The cause of the crash is unclear, but officials suspect engine trouble. The disaster has raised concerns about Indonesia's poor aviation safety record, with the country experiencing its sixth fatal air force plane crash in the past decade. The Indonesian military has grounded some of its Hercules planes following the incident.

site_title: SMEs urged to adopt strong financial management
summary: Singapore's deputy chairman of Spring Singapore, Piyush Gupta, emphasized the importance of strong financial management for small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) to survive and prosper in the market. At a seminar co-organized by the Singapore Exchange (SGX), Gupta highlighted the benefits of adopting robust financial management frameworks, including increased profit margins, higher internal efficiency, and improved ability to handle market volatility. Spring Singapore is providing consultancy services and financial support to SMEs, including a Capability Development Grant and micro loan programs, to help them establish strong financial management systems.

site_title: Inflation in eurozone softens in June on dip in energy
summary: Eurozone inflation softened in June, moving away from the European Central Bank's target, with consumer prices rising 0.2% year-on-year. Energy costs weakened, and prices for food and services eased after a spike in May. Excluding energy and unprocessed food, core inflation rose 0.8%. The European Central Bank's quantitative easing scheme is intended to lift inflation towards its target rate of just under 2%. Eurozone inflation remains below 0.5% for a year, suggesting the ECB still has work to do to hit its target.

site_title: Understanding our neighbours
summary: The SME Magazine (July/August 2015) discussed the Asean Economic Community (AEC) as Singapore businesses invest in neighboring countries. Recent articles covered various topics, including a specialist healthcare center opening in Japan, a startup aiming to halve the price of sustainable marine fuel, and the struggles of tenants at Hao Mart's Taste Orchard due to poor footfall. Additionally, OCBC aims to provide $5 billion in loans to serial entrepreneurs by 2028, while Shatec cuts staff and puts its building up for sale. Chinatown Business Association seeks compensation from Nanyang Old Coffee over outdoor area use.

site_title: Property data
summary: A specialist healthcare centre is set to open in Tokyo or Osaka after Japan's Sojitz takes control of Royal Healthcare. Researchers at NUS have developed a startup aiming to halve the price of sustainable marine fuel. Tenants at Hao Mart's Taste Orchard are struggling due to poor footfall, resulting in vacant units. OCBC targets S$5 billion in loans to serial entrepreneurs by 2028. Shatec has shut its Orchard campus, laid off 42 staff, and put its building up for sale. A rebranding initiative has revitalized an otah business, while Munchi Pancakes modernizes traditional min jiang kueh as a 'national snack'.

site_title: Opec crude production surges as Iraq pumps at record pace
summary: Opec crude production surged to a 13-month high in June, reaching 32.134 million barrels a day, driven by Iraq's record-breaking 4.388 million barrels a day. The increase was largely due to Iraq's surge in production, which more than doubled from May, and Saudi Arabia's 150,000 barrel daily increase to 10.45 million barrels a day. Despite this, Opec agreed to maintain its collective output target of 30 million barrels a day.

site_title: Tsipras asks euro region for a new bailout as meltdown looms
summary: Greece, on the brink of a financial meltdown, asked for a new bailout program from the euro region, seeking to cover all its financial needs for the next two years and a debt-restructuring plan. The request was made by Prime Minister Alexis Tsipras hours before the country's existing aid agreement expires. The proposal doesn't include economic-reform measures sought by European negotiators, and its validity is uncertain. A referendum on austerity measures tied to rescue money is set for July 5, which could determine Greece's fate in the eurozone.

site_title: Trillions spent but financial crises like Greece's still plague the world
summary: Global financial markets experienced significant declines on Monday, driven by announcements in Greece and Puerto Rico, and China's stock market. Despite trillions of dollars in central bank stimulus, debt loads remain a major issue, stifling economies in countries like Greece, Puerto Rico, Brazil, Turkey, and China. Economists say monetary policy can only be a palliative, not a cure, and that debt forgiveness is another option to alleviate the burden. The Dow Jones and Standard & Poor's 500-stock index fell, while investors sought the safety of US government bonds.

site_title: Hyflux unit enters into agreement to set up investment holding company
summary: Hyflux's wholly owned subsidiary, Hyflux Capital, has entered into a shareholders' agreement with Tuspark Technology Services Investment to set up an investment holding company focused on water projects in China. Hyflux Capital will hold a 25% stake in the company. Additionally, Hyflux's subsidiaries, Spring China Utility, have entered into sale and purchase agreements to divest their equity interests in five water plants in China for 890 million yuan (S$195 million).

images.alt_text: Nisha Ramchandani

site_title: Nurturing growth
summary: Singapore's startup scene is experiencing increased competition due to growing entrepreneurs and recognition of the community's capabilities. Innovative startups with unique technologies are creating new markets. Meanwhile, Royal Healthcare is set to open a specialist centre in Tokyo or Osaka after being acquired by Sojitz. NUS researchers are working on a project to halve the price of sustainable marine fuel. In other news, Hao Mart's Taste Orchard is facing poor footfall and vacant units, while OCBC aims to provide S$5 billion in loans to serial entrepreneurs by 2028.

site_title: Sembcorp Development joint venture obtains rights to develop township, industrial park in Vietnam
summary: SEMBCorp Development's joint venture, Vietnam Singapore Industrial Park Joint Venture Co, has secured exclusive rights to develop a 750 ha integrated township and industrial park in Nghe An Province, Vietnam. The project, comprising 198 ha of industrial land and 81 ha of commercial and residential land, will be funded with US$15.2 million in equity and external borrowings. The 49-51 joint venture between Vietnam's Becamex IDC Corporation and a Singapore consortium holds a 92.9% stake in the project, with SEMBCorp Development holding a majority stake.

images.alt_text: Nisha Ramchandani

site_title: Cisco to buy OpenDNS for US$635m to boost security business
summary: Cisco Systems Inc announced the acquisition of OpenDNS, a cloud-based security company, for US$635 million in cash and equity awards. This move aims to boost Cisco's security business in the face of growing, sophisticated cyber attacks. Cisco had previously invested US$35 million in OpenDNS in May last year. The OpenDNS team will join Cisco's security business group, enhancing its security offerings.

images.alt_text: Cisco Systems Inc said on Tuesday it would buy OpenDNS, a privately held cloud-based security company, for US$635 million in cash and equity awards.

site_title: Singapore Wrap Tuesday
summary: Singapore's total bank lending grew in May for the first time in four months, driven by stronger demand for credit for general commerce and financial institutions. Electricity tariffs in Singapore are set to increase by 7.5% in the third quarter. The Singapore Exchange and Spring Singapore are collaborating to support small and medium enterprises in building their financial management capabilities. Meanwhile, the STI rebounded on Tuesday, with investors betting on a potential reversal in China's economic trends or a Greece eurozone exit.

site_title: No movement from Greece after EU bids for last-minute deal: EU Commission
summary: Greece has not responded to a last-minute EU bid to broker a deal to end a deadlock over its debt crisis, despite a call from European Commission President Jean-Claude Juncker. The deadline was midnight on Monday, and contacts with the Greek government are underway. The EU Commission expressed concern that time is narrowing, and a deal remains uncertain.

site_title: Apple conspired to fix e-book prices: US appeals court
summary: A US appeals court ruled that Apple conspired with five publishers to fix e-book prices, violating federal antitrust law. The 2-1 decision upheld a lower court's injunction to prevent a recurrence of the price-fixing. The court found that Apple organized the conspiracy, which led to marketwide prices rising to a desired level. The ruling is a significant victory for the US Department of Justice, which had sued Apple over the e-book price-fixing scandal in 2012.

site_title: Get an early start
summary: A specialist healthcare centre, Royal Healthcare, is set to open in Tokyo or Osaka, Japan, after Sojitz takes control. NUS researchers aim to halve the price of sustainable marine fuel. Tenants of Hao Mart's Taste Orchard lament poor footfall and vacant units. OCBC targets S$5 billion in loans for serial entrepreneurs by 2028. Shatec has shut its Orchard campus and training restaurant, cutting 42 staff and selling the building. An otah business is rebranding heritage for the younger generation, while Munchi Pancakes modernises traditional min jiang kueh as a 'national snack'.

site_title: Economy, population and identity are key challenges for S'pore in next 50 years: PM Lee
summary: Singapore faces three key challenges in the next 50 years, according to Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong. The challenges are maintaining economic growth, raising its total fertility rate, and forging a common identity among Singaporeans. Lee emphasized the importance of addressing these issues to improve lives in the short-term, medium-term, and long-term. The prime minister's comments come as the country navigates a rapidly changing global landscape.

site_title: Merkel sees no new developments on Greece on Tuesday: sources
summary: German Chancellor Angela Merkel expressed no new developments on Greece, contradicting hopes of a last-minute deal before the bailout program expires at midnight. She said the crisis' consequences could be cushioned and eurozone countries should stand together without compromising for its own sake. Merkel's comments appeared to dash last-minute hopes for a deal, potentially leading to economic instability in the eurozone.

site_title: Design Studio appoints new chief executive
summary: Design Studio Group appoints Ku Wei Siong as new chief executive, replacing Bernard Lim Leng Foo, effective Sept 1. Lim stepped down due to personal interests. Ku brings experience in the real estate sector, having worked at CapitaLand GCC Holdings, and is expected to lead the group's growth. The company also announced changes to its board committees. Tan Siok Chin, non-executive chairman, praised Lim's tenure, citing a strong position and capable management team.

images.alt_text: Nisha Ramchandani

site_title: Greece makes new aid proposal, seeks debt restructuring
summary: Greece has submitted a new two-year aid proposal to creditors, seeking debt restructuring and financial support through the European Stability Mechanism (ESM). The proposal aims to resolve an impasse with lenders, which was exacerbated by an impending default on a loan to the International Monetary Fund. The Greek government's statement did not specify how creditors would respond to the proposal, which came as Athens faced a financial crisis.

site_title: Bill Gross warns mutual funds, hedge funds, ETFs vulnerable in liquidity pullback
summary: Bill Gross warns that mutual funds, hedge funds, and ETFs are vulnerable in a liquidity pullback due to their reliance on central bank liquidity. Gross, a bond investing guru, notes that these funds are part of the "shadow banking system" and could experience sharp price moves if liquidity dries up. He advises investors to hold cash to avoid panic selling, citing potential triggers such as interest rate hikes, emerging market crises, and geopolitical risks.

images.alt_text: Bond investing guru Bill Gross on Tuesday warned investors and markets that mutual funds, hedge funds and exchange-traded funds are most vulnerable when liquidity becomes scarce.

site_title: Germanwings offers emotional damage payments to crash victims' families
summary: Germanwings is offering 25,000 euros in emotional damage payments to the families of the 150 victims of the March 24 plane crash. The payments, on top of 50,000 euros already provided, are intended to compensate for pain and suffering. Relatives can receive an additional 10,000 euros if they experience health problems without needing formal proof. However, a lawyer described the offer as "completely inadequate," citing the airline's significant financial losses last year.

site_title: Home prices in 20 US cities grew at slower pace through April
summary: Home prices in 20 US cities rose 4.9% in April, slower than the median estimate of 5.5% from economists surveyed. Nationally, prices rose 4.2%. The slower growth indicates an uneven market as it enters the busier selling season, with demand outpacing supply. Economists expect gains to accelerate as the job market improves and more Americans venture out on their own, boosting spending and investment.

site_title: Grexit should not cause alarm: DPM Tharman
summary: Deputy Prime Minister Tharman Shanmugaratnam said a potential "Grexit" should not cause alarm as the direct impact of a Greek economy collapse is not significant. Eurozone governments and financial institutions have been preparing for such a scenario. The European Central Bank and EU are likely to take necessary steps to safeguard the eurozone financial system. It is too early to determine if Grexit will become a reality, but contingency planning is underway.

site_title: Capital controls mean Greeks can click, but not buy
summary: Capital controls in Greece have disrupted online transactions, making it impossible for Greeks to purchase goods and services from international online suppliers like Google, Apple, and Facebook. The controls, imposed to prevent a banking system collapse, ban transfers of funds out of Greece and payments via debit or credit cards to accounts outside the country. Many businesses, including online retailers and airlines, are affected, with some, like Google, working to find a solution. The restrictions are causing problems for businesses that rely on international online services.

images.alt_text: Monday was the day the music died for thousands of song downloaders and music streamers in Greece.

site_title: US: Wall St opens higher on Greek deal hopes
summary: US stocks opened higher on Tuesday, driven by hopes of a last-minute deal to avoid Greece's exit from the euro zone. The Dow Jones industrial average rose 83.46 points, the S&P 500 gained 12.25 points, and the Nasdaq Composite added 38.84 points. The positive market sentiment was attributed to improved expectations of a Greek deal, despite ongoing US-EU trade talks and tariff uncertainty.

site_title: Greece will not pay IMF debt on Tuesday: finance minister
summary: Greece will not pay a 1.6 billion euro debt installment to the International Monetary Fund due on Tuesday, according to Finance Minister Yanis Varoufakis. Despite this, Athens still hopes for a last-minute deal with creditors on an aid package, with the current program expiring on Tuesday.

site_title: Back to the drachma? Greek lawmaker touches a nerve
summary: Greek opposition lawmaker Haris Theoharis claims a team within the prime minister's office is preparing to return to the drachma, sparking fears of economic chaos. The claim was dismissed by Prime Minister Alexis Tsipras as "fantasy." European partners warn that a "No" vote in a referendum on Sunday could lead to a Greek exit from the euro. Greece is facing a potential default on a 1.6 billion euro loan repayment and is poised to run out of cash to pay pensions and wages.

site_title: Shanghai CO2 market flounders as supply glut hits prices, trading
summary: Shanghai's carbon market ended its compliance year with a subdued note, as a supply glut and lack of investor confidence led to record-low permit prices. Not a single transaction occurred on the last day, with prices near 15.5 yuan, 61% lower than 2014's end-of-year price. The glut was caused by firms in economic distress dumping permits, eroding confidence in China's nascent CO2 markets. The market's liquidity struggles persist, with few speculative traders taking advantage of a new borrowing permit policy.

site_title: Market Capitalisation
summary: NTT DC Reit's Singapore public offer was 9.8 times oversubscribed. US stocks opened lower due to President Trump's fresh tariff salvo on Canada. Creative Technology warned of potentially lower-than-target H2 revenue and similar operating loss to H1. London's Heathrow plans to increase fees for a £10 billion upgrade. Indonesia detained a Trafigura employee in a 285 trillion rupiah graft case. OCBC announced Tan Teck Long as its incoming CEO. MAS and PBOC agreed to deepen cooperation in green and transition finance, ahead of Singapore's GDP data release.

site_title: China Sky Chemical Fibre Co swings into the black for FY14
summary: China Sky Chemical Fibre Co reported a net profit of 72.8 million yuan (S$15.8 million) for FY2014, swinging into the black from a loss of 68.05 million yuan the previous year. Revenue rose 5% to 2.08 billion yuan, driven by higher sales volumes. Earnings per share improved to 8.94 fen, versus a loss of 8.35 fen previously. The company expects raw material prices and selling prices to increase gradually as the Chinese economy improves, but demand and prices for its products remain low.

images.alt_text: Nisha Ramchandani

site_title: Avoid 'bad history' in Greece, top economists warn
summary: World-renowned economists, including Joseph Stiglitz and Thomas Piketty, have warned EU leaders against "creating bad history" in their standoff with Greece, urging a "fresh start" for the country. Greece's bailout programme expires, and the country is at risk of default due to its inability to make a 1.5 billion euro payment to the IMF. The economists call into question the effectiveness of the contractionary austerity policy demanded of Greece and suggest that Syriza's leaders should be given the latitude to implement reforms.

site_title: IREIT Global to acquire Berlin property for 144.2 million euros
summary: IREIT Global has agreed to acquire a property in Berlin for 144.2 million euros (S$217.7 million), its largest asset to date. The 21-storey building will add 79,097 sq m to IREIT's portfolio, with a net property income yield of 7.1%. The acquisition is expected to be funded through a mix of equity and debt, with IREIT's total portfolio value growing to 438 million euros. The property is leased to a principal tenant, Deutsche Rentenversicherung Bund, with a lease expiring in 2024.

images.alt_text: Nisha Ramchandani

site_title: China new home prices rise in June: survey
summary: China's new home prices rose 0.56% in June, marking the second consecutive month of increases, according to a survey by the China Index Academy. The average price per square meter reached 10,628 yuan (US$1,714). Authorities have implemented stimulus policies, including interest rate cuts and eased mortgage policies, which are believed to have boosted demand and accelerated market recovery. This comes after eight consecutive months of price declines from December last year, and a 2.70% year-on-year decline in June.

site_title: Indonesia keeps palm oil, cocoa bean export tax unchanged in July
summary: Indonesia has maintained its export tax for crude palm oil at zero percent and for cocoa beans at 10 percent for July, according to a trade ministry statement. This decision aims to support the country's palm oil and cocoa industries. The unchanged tax rates are a continuation of the existing policies, which were previously extended for the month of July.

site_title: JetBlue's free checked bag disappears with new pricing system
summary: JetBlue Airways Corp is introducing a new, three-tiered "Fare Options" system, ending its free checked-bag policy starting Tuesday. The airline will offer passengers more ticket options, with prices varying between "Blue," "Blue Plus," and "Blue Flex" tiers. Passengers who select Blue will pay for checked bags, while Blue Plus and Blue Flex offer one and two checked bags at no cost, respectively. The move aims to provide at least $200 million in annual operating income by 2017, driven by increased revenue from fuller planes and retrofitted seats.

site_title: India bans oil trade with Islamic State-linked organisations
summary: India has banned trade with Islamic State-linked organizations in oil and other products, complying with a UN resolution. The ban includes oil and refined oil products, modular refineries, and related materials, as well as items of cultural, scientific, and religious importance. This move aims to prevent the militant group from profiting from oil smuggling. The decision follows Iraq's Prime Minister Haider al-Abadi's call for international assistance to prevent the group from exploiting oil resources.

site_title: Euro heads for quarterly gain as Greek standoff clouds outlook
summary: The euro is poised for its first quarterly gain since early 2014, driven by month-end and quarter-end flows despite a Greek standoff. The euro has gained 2.2% this month and 4.7% this quarter, with volatility increasing due to a possible Greek exit from the eurozone. European Commission President Jean-Claude Juncker has contacted Greek Prime Minister Alexis Tsipras, and investors are looking to European Central Bank President Mario Draghi for guidance. The euro's resilience is attributed to a lack of a clear exit strategy for Greece, with the country's potential need to print its own currency to stay in the monetary union.

site_title: EU's Juncker proposed 'last-minute' solution to Greece's Tsipras: source
summary: European Commission chief Jean-Claude Juncker proposed a "last-minute" solution to Greece's debt crisis, which could involve accepting reform proposals and backing a "yes" vote in the upcoming referendum. This solution was discussed with Greek Prime Minister Alexis Tsipras, according to a Commission source. The proposal aims to reach a debt deal before the referendum, which is set to take place on July 5, 2015.

site_title: World's markets brace for Wednesday's leap second
summary: Global financial markets will open on Wednesday with a one-second adjustment to synchronize atomic time with the Earth's rotation, a decision by the International Telecommunication Union. This is the first time a leap second is added on a working day in a high-speed electronic trading environment, potentially testing sensitive trading systems. Markets in Asia, including Singapore, will adjust their systems between midnight and 5 a.m. on July 2, while exchanges in other regions, such as the US, will delay market openings by varying amounts of time. The impact is expected to be minimal, with tolerance limits allowing for some flexibility.

site_title: Greek retail sales drop 1.9% year-on-year in April
summary: Greek retail sales declined 1.9% year-on-year in April, driven by a standoff over reforms with EU/IMF lenders. This marks a reversal of a five-month rise in sales, which had previously shown signs of improvement. The decline is attributed to a turbulent political climate and the country's ongoing economic slump, which has led to record unemployment and a 40% drop in retail sales from 2009-2013.

site_title: Central banks find limits, risks in monetary policy: RBA
summary: Central banks worldwide are finding that monetary policy has limited power to boost demand and poses a risk to financial stability. Reserve Bank of Australia Governor Glenn Stevens stated that super-easy policies have led to increased risk-taking in financial markets but not in the real economy. Corporations are holding onto cash, and households are reluctant to borrow more due to high levels of leverage. Stevens warned that easy monetary policies could create new imbalances in the financial sector and questioned whether rate cuts can fully revive sluggish economies. The RBA has already trimmed rates to a record low of 2%.

images.alt_text: Central banks globally are finding monetary policy has less power to boost demand than could be wished, while also posing a risk to financial stability, the head of Australia's central bank said on Tuesday.

site_title: Greek official says "initiatives" underway on last-minute deal
summary: Greek officials reported that last-minute contacts were underway between Athens and Brussels to reach a deal on bailout terms for Greece, just hours before the package expired. European Commission President Jean-Claude Juncker made an 11th-hour offer to Athens, but there has been no official response from the left-wing government. The outcome of these talks is uncertain, with Greece's future in the euro hanging in the balance.

site_title: Oil bounces off 3-week lows as Greek debt default looms
summary: Oil prices rebounded from three-week lows on Tuesday, rising 60 cents to $62.61 a barrel, amid concerns over a potential Greek debt default. Investors sought safer assets, putting Brent crude on track for a second month of losses. The contract is heading for a decline of over 5% for June, its weakest since April. The looming debt default has raised concerns about global economic stability and the impact on oil prices.

site_title: Liberia announces return of Ebola, with one new death
summary: Liberia has announced the return of the Ebola virus, more than six weeks after the country eradicated the disease. A new case was reported in Margibi County, resulting in one death. The individual was confirmed positive before death and has been buried. Authorities have traced and quarantined anyone who may have had contact with the victim, but details remain unknown.

images.alt_text: Liberia announced the return of the deadly Ebola virus on Tuesday, more than six weeks after the country eradicated the disease.

site_title: Climate, economic ties top agenda as Chinese PM visits France
summary: Chinese Prime Minister Li Keqiang began a three-day visit to France, focusing on climate talks and economic accords. China is expected to announce its national pledges to reduce carbon emissions, potentially influencing global climate negotiations. The visit also aims to seal 53 commercial and industrial accords worth tens of billions of euros, including significant contracts with Airbus and Alstom. France hopes the visit will give impetus to climate talks and encourage India to set a clear target to reduce emissions.

site_title: Thai May consumption index up 1.3% m-o-m
summary: Thailand's current account surplus increased to $2.13 billion in May, nearly doubling the previous month's surplus. The private consumption index rose 1.3% and the investment index fell 0.5%. Exports slipped 5.5% from the previous year, following a 1.7% decline in April. These data come as the country navigates economic challenges, including a slowdown in China's GDP growth and the ongoing UK economic contraction.

site_title: Greek PM Tsipras considering latest offer from creditors: report
summary: Greek Prime Minister Alexis Tsipras is considering a last-minute bailout proposal by the European Commission, which includes debt relief in October and changes to a supplement for low-income Greeks. The proposal comes as the bailout program is set to expire, raising concerns about Greece's financial stability. Tsipras' office has told Brussels that it is evaluating the proposal, but no further details have been disclosed. The decision could have significant implications for Greece's economy and its relationship with the European Union.

site_title: Baidu to invest US$3.2b in online-to-offline services within 3 yrs
summary: Baidu Inc, China's dominant internet search engine, plans to invest 20 billion yuan (approximately US$3.2 billion) over the next three years in online-to-offline services, including group-buying platform Nuomi. This move aims to compete with rivals Alibaba and Tencent, and to enhance its online-to-offline services, such as taxi-booking and restaurant deals. Baidu's CEO Robin Li stated that the investment will focus on improving user retention rates and consumption frequency.

site_title: South Korea picks Airbus for US$1.3b air-tanker deal
summary: South Korea has chosen Airbus for a $1.81 billion contract to supply air-refuelling tankers, beating Boeing and Israel Aerospace Industries. The A-330 Multi-Role Tanker Transport will support South Korea's air defenses against North Korea, with the capability to increase surveillance and bolster defense of disputed islets. The deal is part of a larger effort to bolster air defenses, with plans to acquire four air tankers by 2019. The acquisition will provide fighter jets with more ammunition and increase operating hours and range by 50%.

site_title: Greece teeters on brink of default
summary: Greece is poised to default on an IMF repayment, potentially becoming the first country to do so since 2001. The country's international bailout is set to expire, and Prime Minister Alexis Tsipras is urging Greeks to reject creditors' reform demands in a referendum. Failure to pay would severely impact Greece's economy and standards of living, making it the wealthiest in terms of living standards. Tsipras has also requested an extension of the bailout to keep Athens afloat.

site_title: China IPO funds threatened as regulators mull share sale ban
summary: China is considering suspending initial public offerings (IPOs) to stabilize its stock market, which could threaten hybrid funds that rely on them for returns. These funds, which buy short-term debt and equity, have seen annualized returns of over 10% in the first half of the year. If IPOs are suspended, returns on these funds would likely decrease, potentially leading to large withdrawals from the funds and a shift towards fixed-income assets. Regulators are also considering delaying the IPO of China Nuclear Engineering Corp, with over 500 companies waiting for approval.

site_title: UOB helping clients invest in Myanmar
summary: United Overseas Bank (UOB) is ramping up its activities in Myanmar, with clients investing US$300 million in projects such as factories, hotels, and commercial properties over the next 12 months. The bank will focus on infrastructure, manufacturing, and hospitality sectors, and has already provided financing for several projects, including a thermal power plant and a combined cycle gas-fired power plant. UOB forecasts Myanmar's economy will grow at a compounded annual growth rate of 8% per annum, taking its GDP from US$54 billion to US$176 billion by 2030.

site_title: Greek banks could be solvent for days after default: supervisor
summary: Greek banks may not be declared insolvent for several days after a default, according to European Central Bank supervisor Felix Hufeld. This temporary breathing room offers some relief before a referendum on a potential bailout. Hufeld's comments suggest the ECB may not immediately cut off banks' access to central bank funding, which could ease the financial strain on Greece's banks. The remarks come as Greece's banks face significant challenges after a missed payment to the International Monetary Fund and the end of its bailout program.

site_title: Automakers are in for more pain as China sales slide, LMC says
summary: China's auto sales continue to decline, with production exceeding sales by 140,000 units in the first five months of the year, according to LMC Automotive. This marks the widest gap in at least eight years, posing a risk to profit margins for automakers building factories in China. To combat slowing demand, carmakers have slashed prices, with the gap between production and sales expected to remain significant for a prolonged period.

images.alt_text: Carmakers are in for a prolonged "painful adjustment" in China, with production set to exceed sales by the widest margin in at least eight years, according to industry researcher LMC Automotive.

site_title: Renzi says Italy 'out of firing line' of Greek crisis fallout
summary: Italian Prime Minister Matteo Renzi stated that Italy is "out of the firing line" of the Greek debt crisis fallout, thanks to the country's structural reforms. He attributed this to the European Central Bank's protection and Italy's economic recovery. Renzi expressed concerns over global difficulties, rather than the crisis itself, and criticized Germany's hardline position in the Eurogroup negotiations, calling it a "convenient alibi." The Italian prime minister also warned that a Greek referendum could become a "mistake" and a distraction from finding a solution.

site_title: HSBC cut by Goldman after falling short on investment bank cuts
summary: HSBC Holdings Plc was downgraded to neutral by Goldman Sachs due to its decision to restructure its investment bank without exiting underperforming businesses, reducing revenue more than costs. The bank plans to cut 25,000 jobs and sell operations in Turkey and Brazil to restore profit growth. Goldman analysts led by Martin Leitgeb stated that the cuts are focused on capital optimization rather than exiting specific sub-scale businesses, posing a risk to earnings. The bank's shares fell 0.4% to 575 pence, extending this year's decline to 5.5%.

site_title: Retail investors stampede into Toyota's new class of shares
summary: Japanese retail investors are flooding stock brokers with orders for Toyota's new class of shares, known as "Model AA," with 10 times more applications than the planned retail-only issue. The shares pay an annual dividend starting at 0.5% and rising to 2.5% in the fifth year, attracting investors seeking stable long-term returns. Toyota plans to sell up to 500 billion yen of Model AA shares, priced 26-30% above the closing price of common stock, with the goal of selling 150 million shares, or 5% of its outstanding shares.

images.alt_text: Japanese retail investors are flooding stock brokers with orders for a new class of Toyota Motor Corp shares, indicating the carmaker can fetch a good price for the issue and secure a new group of long-term investors.

site_title: Indonesia military plane crash kills at least 30: govt official
summary: An Indonesian military transport plane crashed into a hotel and houses in Medan, northern Sumatra, killing at least 30 people. The plane was on its way to the Natuna islands when it crashed a few minutes after takeoff. The number of victims could increase.

site_title: From the sidelines, Chinese companies start to eye Greek deals
summary: Chinese companies are cautiously scouting potential buying opportunities in Greece amid the country's escalating debt crisis and risk of leaving the eurozone. With a 20% drop in the euro against the dollar in the past year, Chinese firms are looking at attractive targets such as airports, ports, and power utilities. Chinese companies have largely stayed away from Greek assets until now, but some, like Friedmann Pacific Asset Management, are exploring opportunities, with COSCO Group in advanced discussions about buying a majority stake in Greece's largest port Piraeus.

site_title: Eurozone inflation slows to 0.2%, unemployment stable
summary: Eurozone inflation slowed to 0.2% in June, down from 0.3% in May, due to plummeting energy costs. Unemployment remained stable at 11.1% in May. These figures come despite the European Central Bank's unprecedented stimulus measures. The data provides a slight respite for the eurozone economy, which has been struggling with low inflation and high unemployment.

site_title: China's Q1 2015 current account surplus US$75.6b: regulator
summary: China reported a Q1 2015 current account surplus of US$75.6 billion, with a US$17.9 billion deficit on its capital and financial accounts. Preliminary data had shown a slightly larger surplus. This data was released by the State Administration of Foreign Exchange.

site_title: French consumer spending stable in May: INSEE
summary: French consumer spending rose 0.1% in May, following a flat April, driven by a 0.3% increase in energy expenses and a 0.2% gain in car purchases. Producer prices fell 0.5% in May and 1.7% over the year.

site_title: Airbus sued by AirAsia crash families over defective systems
summary: Airbus Group SE has been sued by the families of 10 AirAsia passengers who died in the 2014 crash of AirAsia Flight 8501. The families claim the plane's systems were "defectively and unreasonably dangerous" and failed to provide accurate weather, air speed, and ice-accumulation information. The crash occurred on December 28, 2014, resulting in the deaths of all 162 people on board.

site_title: Singapore shares close on a rebound that pushes up STI
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) rebounded 37.15 points to 3,317.33 on Tuesday, recovering almost all the 41 points lost on Monday. The index's gain was driven by a large bounce in the three banks and Singtel, as well as speculation about the impact of Greece exiting the eurozone and China's reversal in volatility. The Shanghai Composite Index gained 5.5% on Tuesday, while the Hang Seng Index jumped one percent.

site_title: Philiippines' First Gen seeks partners for US$2.7b of energy projects
summary: First Gen Corp, the Philippines' largest gas-fired power plant operator, is seeking partners for three plants and a liquefied gas terminal worth $2.7 billion. The company plans to line up partners by the end of the year, with majority control of the assets. Talks are underway with potential partners from Japan, Europe, and the Philippines, with a focus on operating and maintaining the liquefied natural gas terminal. The company's shares rose the most in six years following the announcement.

site_title: Greece's closed banks at ECB mercy in week of saver suspense
summary: Greece's banks remain closed due to a deposit run, with lenders relying on the European Central Bank (ECB) for liquidity assistance. The ECB's 89 billion euro emergency funding line will be assessed on July 1, and a deal between the Greek government and creditors is crucial to the banks' survival. A Greek exit from the euro area and a "no" vote in the July 5 referendum on creditor proposals could lead to stricter capital controls, potentially forcing the ECB to curb emergency aid, plunging banks into crisis.

images.alt_text: Anyone hoping for Greek banks to reopen on July 7 has a troubling week ahead of them.

site_title: India said to consider combining lender to women with state bank
summary: India is considering merging state-run Bharatiya Mahila Bank with State Bank of India, the country's largest lender. The proposal, to be discussed by Prime Minister Narendra Modi's cabinet, aims to consolidate state-run banks and avoid large capital infusions. Bharatiya Mahila Bank, founded in 2013 to focus on lending to women, would be combined with State Bank, which has over 16,000 outlets and $211 billion in loans. The move aims to address India's fragmented banking system, where over 90 lenders compete for $1.3 trillion in deposits.

site_title: Sugary drinks may cause 184,000 global deaths a year: study
summary: A study published in the journal Circulation estimates that sugary drinks cause up to 184,000 deaths annually worldwide, primarily due to diabetes, cardiovascular diseases, and cancers. The highest death rates were found in Mexico and the US, with 450 and 125 deaths per million adults, respectively. The study also found that 76% of these deaths occurred in low to middle-income countries, and the quantity of sugar available in a nation correlated with the country's frequency of diabetes, cardiovascular disease, and cancer. Reducing or eliminating sugary beverages from diets is considered a global priority.

site_title: South Korea June housing prices rise for 22nd month: bank
summary: South Korea's housing prices rose 0.46% in June from May, marking the 22nd consecutive monthly gain, according to data from Kookmin Bank. The annual growth pace reached its highest in over three years, with a 3.33% increase from the previous year, the fastest since May 2012. This marks the longest period of consecutive price gains in the country's housing market.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks close 1.09% higher
summary: Hong Kong stocks rose 1.09% on Tuesday, recovering from previous day's losses, despite Greece's potential default that could lead to it leaving the eurozone. The Hang Seng Index increased 283.05 points to 26,250.03 on HK$155.87 billion in turnover.

site_title: UK economic growth revised up, household real incomes surge
summary: Britain's economy grew 0.4% in the first quarter of 2015, revised up from an initial estimate of 0.3%, and households' disposable income rose at the fastest annual pace since 2001. The year-on-year growth rate was also revised up to 2.9%, from 2.5%, and the overall growth for 2014 was revised to 3.0%, its fastest rate since 2006.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares end higher
summary: Malaysian shares ended higher on Tuesday, with the Kuala Lumpur Composite Index increasing 14.72 points to close at 1,706.64. The index saw 1.75 billion lots traded, with 495 gainers and 309 losers.

site_title: IndiGo said to plan US$500m IPO filing as early as Tuesday
summary: InterGlobe Aviation Pvt, the owner of India's largest carrier IndiGo, plans to file a draft prospectus as early as Tuesday for an initial public offering (IPO) valued at around $4 billion. The $500 million offering will be used to raise $200 million through new stock and $300 million from existing investors. This would make it India's biggest IPO since 2012. The airline's low fares and economic growth have contributed to its success, and it is a rare bright spot in India's competitive aviation sector.

images.alt_text: InterGlobe Aviation Pvt, owner of India's biggest carrier IndiGo, plans to file a draft prospectus as early as Tuesday for an initial public offering of about US$500 million, people with knowledge of the matter said.

site_title: Greece not yet lost as Europe awaits voters to rule on euro
summary: Greece's future in the eurozone remains uncertain as the country's bailout deal expires and a referendum on austerity measures is set for July 5. Despite initial market calm, European leaders are holding out hope for a "yes" vote, which could allow Greece to secure fresh aid and continued eurozone membership. A rejection of the deal could lead to Greece's departure from the eurozone, but some economists suggest that a "yes" vote could reopen negotiations and provide a temporary reprieve.

site_title: Chinese funnel 25% of global property investment into Australia
summary: China attracted over 25% of global commercial property investment in Australia in the first quarter of 2015, with US$4 billion invested, according to CBRE Group. This is a significant increase from 2014, with Australia previously attracting 15% of Chinese investment. The Reserve Bank of Australia warns that rising risks in commercial real estate, driven by offshore investors seeking yield, may lead to higher prices and lower yields. Chinese investors are focusing on inner city development sites in Sydney, Melbourne, and Brisbane.

site_title: Greece: Equities decline or don't find buyers outside Athens
summary: Greek stocks outside Athens declined sharply after talks between Greece and its creditors broke down. American depositary receipts of National Bank of Greece SA fell 24% in New York, while Coca-Cola HBC AG dropped 3.4%. The nation's banks and stock exchange were shut down ahead of a July 5 referendum on bailout aid. Economists say the markets are cautious, with concerns over a potential "yes" deal driving Greek assets down. The current euro-area bailout expires on Tuesday, and the European Central Bank froze emergency liquidity assistance to Greek lenders.

site_title: Rex International unit terminates existing lease for two rigs with Loyz Energy
summary: Rex International Holding has terminated its existing five-year lease for two rigs with Loyz Energy, a Singapore-listed oil company. The termination fee is US$13.8 million, which will be paid in a combination of US$2.5 million in cash and US$11.3 million in new shares. The new shares come with a nine-month lock-up period.

site_title: German unemployment steady at historic low in June
summary: German unemployment remained at a historic low of 2.786 million in June, with a seasonally-adjusted decline of 1,000. The unemployment rate stood at 6.4%, unchanged from May. This is the lowest level since December 1991. The labor market trend remains favorable, despite a slowdown in German domestic product growth in the first quarter. Economic expectations have clouded over, but labor market conditions are expected to remain favorable in the second half of 2015.

site_title: Europe: Shares extend slide, with Greece set to default on IMF loan
summary: European shares fell 0.5% on Tuesday, extending a two-day slump, amid a conflict between Greece and its lenders. Greece is set to default on a 1.6 billion euro IMF loan, with tens of thousands of Greeks rallying to support their leftwing government. European Commission President Jean-Claude Juncker made a last-minute offer, but Greek Prime Minister Alexis Tsipras refused to drop his repeated rejections of the bailout offer. The default is expected to push Greece close to financial chaos, forcing a shutdown of its banking system.

site_title: Empty Greek ATMs force tourists to stiff Santorini cab drivers
summary: A cash crunch in Greece has forced tourists to rely on cash, with many struggling to access ATMs due to limited withdrawals. The crisis has already resulted in cancellations of tourist bookings, with 1,500 cancellations reported this week, and small business owners, such as souvenir shops, fearing the loss of revenue. The tourism industry, a significant contributor to Greece's economy, is being severely impacted, with some worrying that the crisis may scare tourists away.

site_title: Malaysia's Felda says to rely on debt to fund Eagle High stake purchase
summary: Malaysia's Felda Global Ventures Holdings Bhd plans to fund its $680 million purchase of a 37% stake in Indonesia's PT Eagle High Plantations using mostly debt, despite concerns over the proposed price. CEO Mohd Emir Mavani Abdullah believes debt is "cheap at the moment" and notes the deal's debt-to-equity ratio will remain reasonable for a growing company. Felda will keep its cash reserves intact and issue new shares to acquire the remaining stake. The deal has sparked concern among analysts and opposition lawmakers over the high price.

site_title: Sony plunges 8.25% on massive share sale plan
summary: Sony shares plummeted 8.25% on Tuesday after announcing a massive share sale plan to raise $3.6 billion. The company plans to issue new shares and bonds, totaling 441 billion yen, to finance image sensors for cameras. The financing is considered unusual, leading to concerns over dilution of per-share value. Analysts attribute the stock's decline to the timing, which coincided with market volatility caused by Greece's debt crisis.

site_title: Europe: Stock markets fall at open
summary: Europe's main stock markets fell at the start of trading on Tuesday, with London's FTSE 100 index dropping 0.40% to 6,593.78 points. Frankfurt's DAX 30 and Paris' CAC 40 also declined, with losses less acute than on Monday due to concerns about Greece's potential eurozone exit. Greece is set to default on a payment owed to the International Monetary Fund, despite Athens' defiance over creditors' demands for reforms. Thousands protested in Greece's streets on Monday, opposing the debt proposals and warning of a chaotic Greek exit from the eurozone.

site_title: Euro gives up gains as clock ticks before Greece's likely default
summary: The euro fell 0.4% to $1.1188, near a four-week low, as traders braced for Greece's likely default on a repayment to the International Monetary Fund, potentially disrupting the eurozone. Despite some buying on dips, few investors are willing to buy the euro, citing uncertainty over the outcome. The yen rose 0.7% to 136.90 yen against the euro, while the Swiss franc held steady against the euro. A Greek referendum on bailout terms is expected, with Prime Minister Alexis Tsipras suggesting he would resign if voters accept the deal.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks close up 0.63% recovering from fall on Greece fears
summary: Tokyo stocks rose 0.63% on Tuesday, rebounding from a 2.88% fall on Monday, as investors awaited a Greek default. The benchmark index increased 125.78 points to 20,235.73, while the Topix index rose 0.34% to 1,630.40. The gains followed a sharp decline on Monday, which was attributed to concerns over Greece's economic situation.

site_title: Hong Kong ETF market braces for competition from China's giants
summary: Hong Kong's exchange-traded funds (ETFs) are expected to lose market share to Chinese fund managers as a mutual trading scheme starts on July 1. The initial quota is 300 billion yuan each way, allowing funds domiciled in Hong Kong and China to be sold in each other's markets. This will increase competition for Hong Kong-based ETF managers, who have established a track record in providing access to the mainland. Global investors are also watching Beijing's management of investor sentiment amid volatility in the Shanghai index, which has tumbled over 20% from its peak in mid-June.

site_title: Asia markets rebound, Shanghai sees more volatility
summary: Asian markets rebounded on Tuesday after a day of routs, with Tokyo, Hong Kong, and Seoul rising. Shanghai surged, bouncing back from a 5.1% drop in the morning, while Shenzhen rose 2.0%. The euro edged down despite analysts warning of sharp movements this week due to Greece's impending default. European leaders called on Greeks to vote for creditors' proposals, but Standard & Poor's downgraded Greece's credit rating to junk territory. China's markets remain volatile, with Shanghai's index up 3.22% after a recent sell-off, and analysts predict further wild swings.

images.alt_text: Asian markets rebounded on Tuesday after the previous day's rout, despite Greece being just hours away from default, while Shanghai surged in volatile trading that saw swings of more than eight percent.

site_title: German conservative says "Grexit" best solution for all
summary: German conservative Markus Soeder has called for an "orderly" exit of Greece from the eurozone, describing it as the best option for all parties involved. The comments, made after Greece's Prime Minister Alexis Tsipras broke off bailout talks, underscore the growing frustration with Greece in Merkel's conservative camp. Soeder sharply criticized Tsipras for playing with Europe and his own people, saying a "Grexit" appears unavoidable, even if Greeks vote in favor of a bailout in the scheduled referendum on Sunday.

site_title: Suzuki to name president's son as his successor, Nikkei says
summary: Osamu Suzuki, 85, will step down as Suzuki Motor Corp president, handing the role to his son Toshihiro Suzuki, 56. Suzuki will remain chairman and CEO, while his son will take over as president. The announcement aims to ease uncertainty about management succession, which has been a topic of discussion since Suzuki's father took over the company in 1978. Suzuki's stock rose 5.5% in Tokyo trading following the news.
