site_title: Ghost Rider
summary: The Rolls-Royce Ghost Series II has been updated with refined ride quality, thanks to new air suspension and rear hydraulic axle bearings. The car's new seats provide a more body-hugging design, with firmer seat squabs and extendable lower thigh support. The updated model also features improved body control, smoother steering and throttle response, and a recalibrated eight-speed automatic transmission. The Ghost Series II boasts a 6.592cc V12 turbocharged engine, producing 570 hp, and has a top speed of 250 km/h.

site_title: FedEx says has requested EU approval for US$4.9b TNT bid
summary: FedEx has requested EU approval for its $6.6 billion bid to acquire Dutch rival TNT Express, combining FedEx's air fleet with TNT's European road network. The deal aims to create a strong third player in Europe to counter UPS and Deutsche Post. FedEx submitted its request to the European Commission on June 26, 2015, with a preliminary review expected to take 25 working days. This is FedEx's second attempt at acquiring TNT, following a rejected takeover bid in 2013.

site_title: Facebook staff diversity little changed over past year
summary: Facebook's new diversity data shows little change in the past year, with women increasing from 31% to 32% and minorities remaining at 2%, 4%, and 3%. Tech workers are more evenly distributed, but senior leadership remains overwhelmingly white and male. Facebook has introduced initiatives, such as a diversity training program and a course on stereotypes and bias, to increase diversity. Despite progress, the company still has work to do to address its diversity gap.

site_title: Initial optimism over Greek bailout fizzles out
summary: Initial optimism over a Greek bailout proposal dissipated as eurozone officials struggled to break a deadlock, leading to a 0.9% decline in the Straits Times Index (STI) on Friday. Bank stocks were dragged down ahead of Greece's last-ditch negotiations, despite a 5-day rally in Singapore stocks earlier in the week. The market correction was also influenced by a continued correction in Chinese stocks.

site_title: US: Wall St ends lower but health stocks rally
summary: US stocks closed flat on Friday but fell 0.4% for the week, with investors cautious ahead of a European meeting on Greece's loans. The Dow Jones rose 0.32%, while the S&P 500 and Nasdaq fell 0.03% and 0.62%, respectively. Investors are watching the European meeting, which could decide Greece's default on critical loans, and US-EU trade talks.

site_title: US buyout firms eye apartment Reits
summary: US buyout firms are targeting apartment real estate investment trusts (Reits), with Lone Star Funds agreeing to acquire Home Properties Inc for $7.6 billion, the largest US apartment Reit takeover since 2007. The trend is driven by the booming rental market, with younger tenants delaying home ownership and driving near-record occupancy and rising rents. Smaller, local operators are seen as potential targets, with companies like Post Properties and Mid-America Apartment Communities also on the radar.

site_title: HSBC ends 5-year collaboration with Markit
summary: HSBC has ended its 5-year marketing collaboration with financial information firm Markit Ltd, winding up a partnership that included sponsorship of the China Purchasing Managers Index (PMI). Neither company gave a specific reason for the end of the arrangement. Markit will announce replacement sponsors soon, amid reports that the firm was seeking other sponsors in Asia due to the potential high cost.

site_title: US Ex-Im Bank faces closure as Congress doesn't renew charter
summary: The US Export-Import Bank (Ex-Im) is set to expire its charter at midnight on June 30, 2015, due to Congress's failure to renew it. The bank, which has been in operation for 81 years, will no longer be able to make new loans or write new credit and trade guarantees. Ex-Im's chairman, Fred Hochberg, expressed disappointment, while conservative Republicans and think tanks have long campaigned to shut down the bank, citing it as "welfare" for giant corporations. The bank's employees will continue to work, but their ability to review new applications will be limited.

site_title: Obama delivers 'Amazing Grace' at funeral of slain pastor
summary: President Barack Obama delivered a memorable eulogy at the funeral of slain pastor Reverend Clementa Pinckney in Charleston, South Carolina, urging Americans to eliminate symbols of racism and oppression. He called the Confederate battle flag "a reminder of systemic oppression and racial subjugation," and led thousands in singing "Amazing Grace." The shootings sparked a national dialogue on racism and gun control, with the Department of Justice opening a hate crime investigation. Obama's speech was a poignant tribute to the nine victims, and a call to action for Americans to bridge the racial divide.

site_title: Detox demystified
summary: Detox programs are being tested for their effectiveness, with three options reviewed: the Nutrition Clinic's 10-Day RESET Detox, Punch Detox's Level 3 Juice Cleanse, and HICJUICE's 5:2 Juice Plan. The RESET Detox, which involves protein shakes and supplements, is said to be more effective in promoting healthy eating habits and weight loss. In contrast, juice cleanses, such as Punch Detox's Level 3, can lead to nutrient deficiencies and weight regain. The 5:2 Juice Plan, which involves drinking three bottles of cold juices on fasting days, may be a more accessible alternative to traditional dieting.

site_title: Japan consumption rebounds, but rising food costs complicate BOJ's task
summary: Japan's household spending rose 4.8% in May, the first increase in over a year, driven by a robust jobs market. However, core consumer inflation remained steady at 0.1% due to rising food prices, driven by higher import costs from a weak yen. The Bank of Japan faces a dilemma as it tries to accelerate demand-side inflation without scaring consumers away from shopping. Analysts warn that modest pay rises are not enough to make up for rising living costs, and policymakers are reluctant to expand stimulus measures unless the economy worsens.

site_title: Apple suppliers said to start making Iphones with Force Touch
summary: Apple has started early production of new iPhone models with Force Touch, a feature that senses how hard users are pressing down on a screen. The new iPhones, in 4.7-inch and 5.5-inch versions, will have a similar exterior design to the current iPhone 6 and 6 Plus models. Production is expected to ramp up next month, with Apple aiming to stay ahead of rivals such as Samsung Electronics. The release of Force Touch follows the success of last year's iPhone models with bigger displays, which helped Apple reclaim the top spot in the global smartphone market.

images.alt_text: Apple Inc has started early production of new iPhone models with a feature called Force Touch, which senses how hard users are pressing down on a screen, people with knowledge of the matter said.

site_title: A deal is the best way out for both Greece and EU
summary: Greece and EU negotiators are nearing a deal to release 7.2 billion euros of funds under the current bailout program, potentially avoiding a default and economic chaos. A deal is likely as it benefits both sides, with Greece avoiding a banking crisis and the EU preserving its roughly 300 billion euro exposure to Greece. However, a lack of deal could lead to a credit crunch and increased pressure on the Greek government to sign up to a deal. The risk of contagion to other peripheral countries is low, but a Greek default could prompt investors to look for other countries that may follow suit.

site_title: His open championship regrets
summary: Taiwanese golfer Liang-huan, known as "Mr. Lu," came close to winning the Asian's first Major championship in 1971, but ultimately fell short. He remains a significant figure in Asian golf, putting the sport on the world map before live television coverage and international superstars.

site_title: US compares China's South China Sea moves to Russia's in Ukraine
summary: The US State Department's Deputy Secretary Antony Blinken compared China's South China Sea reclamation projects to Russia's actions in eastern Ukraine, calling them a threat to peace and stability. Blinken urged China to freeze its reclamation activities and resolve disputes according to the rule of law. China claims nearly all of the South China Sea, building up reefs and asserting its right to do so, while the US prioritizes freedom of navigation through the sea, which passes $5 trillion in ship-borne trade annually. The US and its allies stand united against unilateral changes to the status quo.

site_title: Jordan v Rory
summary: Rory McIlroy and Jordan Spieth, the current world No 1 and No 2, engaged in a high-stakes golf rivalry. McIlroy, 26, and Spieth, 21, were also the joint holders of all four major golf championships.

site_title: Tianfang said to plan S$500m S'pore IPO for hotel trust
summary: Tianfang Hospitality Management Pte plans to list a Singapore Initial Public Offering (IPO) trust backed by three Chinese hotels, raising approximately S$500 million. The trust consists of the Ritz-Carlton Hotel, Tianmu Hot Spring Resort Hotel, and InterContinental Sanya Haitang Bay Resort Hotel. This could bring a boost to the Singapore stock exchange, which has seen a decline in first-time share sales and property trusts.

site_title: SEA Games success for Poh and Koh
summary: Two Malaysian golfers, Johnson Poh and Koh Sock Hwee, achieved success at the SEA Games, earning medals and helping their teams secure podium spots. This marks one of the best results for the home teams at the Games in recent years. Poh and Koh's performances demonstrate the growth and potential of Malaysian golf talent.

site_title: Time to review SGX's wearing of two hats
summary: Market stakeholders in Singapore are calling for a review of the dual role of Singapore Exchange (SGX) as a regulator and commercial business, following a comment from the Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) that there could be scope to reduce oversight overlaps. The Securities Investors Association of Singapore (SIAS) and other stakeholders have expressed concerns about potential conflicts of interest and the need for efficiency in regulation. A possible solution is to shift regulation of exchange members to independent, self-regulated organizations, similar to the Financial Industry Regulatory Authority (Finra) in the US.

site_title: More millennials entering US real estate market
summary: Millennials are increasingly entering the US real estate market, with 65% of those aged 25-34 planning to buy a home within the next three months, up from 54% in January. This surge is driven by improving economic conditions, rising rents, and the prospect of higher mortgage rates. Millennials now account for 32% of existing-home sales, surpassing Generation X as the largest segment of purchasers. Student debt remains a limiting factor, but other life-cycle issues such as marriages and births are also driving them into the market.

site_title: Warner Bros, Affleck said planning film about Fifa
summary: Warner Bros. has acquired the rights to "Houses of Deceit," a film about the Fifa scandal, with Ben Affleck's production company, Pearl Street, on board. The film is based on the writing of Ken Bensinger and tells the story of Chuck Blazer, a former Fifa executive who became a whistleblower. The movie will focus on Blazer's role in the scandal, including his acceptance of bribes to influence World Cup voting. This move comes after Fifa's own film, "United Passions," underperformed at the box office, earning less than $200,000 in worldwide ticket sales.

images.alt_text: Warner Bros and Oscar winner Ben Affleck will make a movie about the Fifa scandal, people familiar with the situation said.

site_title: China seen winning IMF's reserve-currency endorsement for yuan
summary: China is predicted to win the IMF's endorsement of the yuan as a reserve currency, with 11 out of 16 economists surveyed expecting the yuan to be added to the SDR basket at a review in October. This could lead to $1 trillion in inflows into yuan assets and challenge the US dollar's dominance in global trade and finance. The move comes as China gradually opens up its domestic capital market and expands its network of lenders that clear trades in the yuan.

site_title: German regulator says Deutsche Bank CEO misled Bundesbank: FT
summary: German regulator BaFin alleges Deutsche Bank's co-CEO Anshu Jain made "knowingly inaccurate statements" to Bundesbank during an investigation into manipulating the inter-bank rate setting process. The allegations claim Jain misled the Bundesbank in a 2012 interview about his knowledge of rumors of possible rigging in 2008. Deutsche Bank disputes the allegations, stating Jain understood the question to refer to rigging at the bank itself, not the market. BaFin recommends special banking supervisory measures for Deutsche Bank, which is under investigation for its role in the financial crisis.

site_title: Brokers' take
summary: Ascott Residence Trust (ART) acquired three serviced residences and four rental housing properties in Australia and Japan for S$298 million, funded by S$150 million from perpetual securities and yen debt. The acquisition provides exposure to growing Melbourne and Japanese hospitality markets, with estimated FY15 Ebitda yield of 5.5%. SATS secured a 30 billion yen contract from Delta Air Lines, expected to boost profits. These deals are seen as positive for ART and SATS, with ART maintaining its DPU forecasts and SATS raising its FY16-18 EPS.

site_title: Business, golf, cars
summary: Emerio, a global IT services provider, has been a key supporter of the Business Times Corporate Golf League. Its CEO, Harish Nim, 56, founded the company in 1997 and has grown it to over 1,600 employees. Nim is an avid golfer with a handicap index of 13.1 and shares his passion for business, golf, and cars.

site_title: Giving his fans their money's worth
summary: WWE superstar Kane, whose real name is Glenn Jacobs, is set to perform in Singapore on July 2 as part of a three-hour show at the Singapore Indoor Stadium. With 20 years of experience in the ring, Kane says he's far from retiring and credits his first WWE championship win in 1998 as a defining moment in his career, where he defeated Stone Cold Steve Austin. Kane, 48, will be joined by other big WWE stars, including John Cena, Dolph Ziggler, and Nikki Bella, and is looking forward to performing for fans in Singapore.

images.alt_text: Lee U-Wen

site_title: Independent auditors for banks' outsourcing vendors
summary: Singapore-based banks' outsourcing vendors must hire independent auditors to review their internal controls annually, meeting guidelines set by the Association of Banks in Singapore. The move aims to address security breaches, such as data theft and system failures. Vendors will pay tens of thousands of dollars annually for audits, which will be submitted to banking clients. The requirement is expected to increase costs for vendors, which could be passed on to banks, and may force smaller players to exit the outsourcing sector.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: CapitaLand's consortium has satisfied conditions to acquire land parcels on A2 Island in Iskandar Malaysia, with plans to develop a premier waterfront residential community over 10-12 years. Frasers Hospitality Trust sold S$123 million in new stapled securities to finance the acquisition of Sofitel Sydney Wentworth. SIA Engineering renewed its services contract with SilkAir for five years, while StarHub hired Dennis Chia as CFO and Howie Lau as chief marketing officer. MS Holdings reported a 36.5% decline in full-year net profit to S$2.04 million.

site_title: UN chief says attacks only strengthen fight against extremists
summary: UN Secretary-General Ban Ki-moon condemned attacks in Tunisia, Kuwait, and France, stating they strengthened the world's resolve to fight extremism. The attacks, which included a hotel shooting, beheading, and mosque bombing, killed over 60 people. The UN Security Council called for justice and condemned the acts of terrorism, emphasizing the need to bring perpetrators to justice. The UN reaffirmed its commitment to combating extremism, with Ban Ki-moon saying the attacks only strengthened the international community's resolve to defeat those bent on destruction and human annihilation.

site_title: Driven by a passion to innovate
summary: MobiQuest, an enterprise mobile enabler, is driven by innovation and perseverance. Founded by Rakesh Sabharwal, the company provides end-to-end mobile and IoT solutions for smart cities, aiming to double revenues in two years. MobiQuest has received numerous awards, including the SME 100 Award, for its projects such as smart waste management and indoor positioning systems. The company continues to focus on mobility and IoT, with a strong passion for innovation, to achieve its goals and increase customer confidence.

site_title: Tuck in all you want - for a hefty price
summary: The 2015 US Dietary Guidelines Advisory Committee (DGAC) report has dropped the recommended daily limit on cholesterol intake, citing no appreciable relationship between consumption of dietary cholesterol and serum cholesterol. A healthy diet can reduce heart attacks, strokes, and death by 20-50% through increased consumption of vegetables, fruits, whole grains, and low-fat dairy, and decreased consumption of red and processed meat, refined grains, and sugar-sweetened foods and beverages. Diets such as the DASH and Mediterranean diets have shown favorable effects on blood pressure, cholesterol, and cardiovascular disease outcomes.

site_title: Competing on a jewel of a course
summary: The Business Times Corporate Golf League 2015 is set to tee off at Sentosa Golf Club's Tanjong Course on July 6. The league, which brings together top executives and decision-makers, will feature familiar faces and new teams, including Citi and Team Walton. Participants can expect good playing surfaces and respectful green-speeds, with the Tanjong Course set to undergo redevelopment in November. The event aims to promote networking, competition, and entertainment, with many firms competing in both the competition and social categories.

site_title: Golf's new $25 million man
summary: Golf superstar Brooks Koepka has secured his third consecutive Masters title, solidifying his position as the sport's new top player. Koepka's dominant performance earned him a reported $25 million in prize money and endorsement deals. Industry analysts, such as Casey Alexander, consider this win as the start of a new era in golf, with Koepka's success potentially leading to increased investment and interest in the sport.

site_title: Europe condemns attacks in France, Tunisia, Kuwait
summary: European leaders condemned multiple attacks in France, Tunisia, and Kuwait, including a suspected Islamist attack on a gas factory and massacres in beach resorts and a mosque. At least 61 people were killed, with French President Francois Hollande and Tunisian counterpart Beji Caid Essebsi expressing solidarity against terrorism. EU leaders vowed to stay united against "barbarism," with German Chancellor Angela Merkel calling the attacks a "challenge" in fighting terrorism and Islamist extremism.

site_title: French beheading victim was boss of suspect: source
summary: A French manager was beheaded at an industrial gases company in southeastern France, according to a source close to the investigation. The victim, who was the manager of the suspect, had gone to the company's premises with the suspect to make a delivery. The suspect then killed and decapitated his victim before driving their vehicle into the site.

site_title: Overcoming obstacles, seizing opportunities
summary: In Singapore, many small and medium enterprises (SMEs) face significant challenges, including financial struggles, market access, technology adoption, and talent shortages. According to a survey, over a third of SMEs are considering changing their business or closing down due to difficulties managing costs, accessing markets, and competing with larger corporations. Experts recommend SMEs adopt a more strategic approach to managing money, investing in technology, and outsourcing non-core functions to overcome these challenges. The SME100 framework provides a platform for SMEs to grow beyond borders and learn from international counterparts.

site_title: Basking in nostalgia
summary: The Open Championship, a golf tournament, holds a special place in history for the author, who played in 2000 at St Andrews. Meanwhile, regional news includes Asean's stance on Myanmar's election, a low-profile property trust's data center plan, and US jobless claims falling unexpectedly. China urges regional support for openness amidst US tariffs, while Chinese property shares surge on unverified reports of a sector revival. Reliance Jio's India IPO has been delayed beyond this year, and China has introduced new steps to aid employment amid trade tensions.

site_title: Why construction firms are choosing mediation
summary: Construction firms are increasingly opting for mediation to resolve disputes, citing its benefits in terms of opportunity costs, flexibility, confidentiality, and control over settlement terms. Mediation allows companies to avoid the high costs and reputational risks associated with court battles, while also preserving business continuity and protecting themselves from legal risk. By incorporating mediation clauses into contracts, firms can encourage early settlements and reduce the likelihood of disputes escalating into costly and time-consuming legal battles.

site_title: JTC awards Tampines industrial plot to Sim Lian
summary: JTC Corporation has awarded the tender for an industrial site at Tampines Industrial Drive (Plot 4) to Sim Lian Construction at S$5.9 million, with a price of S$68.85 per square foot per plot ratio (psf ppr). This is 12% more than the second-highest bidder, Precise Development. The plot is 5,686 square meters large and zoned for heavier industrial use, despite being near a wafer fabrication park, which may limit its usage.

site_title: Cham Tao Soon named 2015 Engineer of the Year
summary: Singapore's Nanyang Technological University president emeritus, Cham Tao Soon, has been named 2015 Engineer of the Year by the Federation of Engineering Institutions of Asia and the Pacific. Prof Cham, a fluid mechanics expert, was recognized for his contributions to the engineering profession and research. He has held various leadership positions, including founding president of NTI and NTU, and has served on the boards of prominent companies. The award honors individuals who have made significant progress in engineering research and advancement in the region.

site_title: Tsipras denounces "blackmail"
summary: Greek Prime Minister Alexis Tsipras accused international creditors of "blackmail" on Friday after eurozone partners offered to release billions in frozen aid in exchange for painful pension and tax reforms. The creditors, including Germany and France, offered 15.5 billion euros in EU and IMF funding to see Greece through to the end of November, but Tsipras sounded defiant, saying Greece would fight for European principles of democracy and solidarity. A deal must be reached by Saturday, with eurozone finance ministers set to meet to discuss a revised offer.

site_title: Muted response to Apple Watch launch here
summary: Apple Watch launched in Singapore to muted enthusiasm, with shorter queues than expected for its first day of sales. Only a handful of fans waited outside retail stores, with many opting to buy online or through friends. Sales assistants reported that the Apple Watch Stainless Steel with a Milanese loopband sold out by noon, while the Sport model was the next most popular choice. Tech observers had expressed skepticism over the watch's functionality and necessity, with some speculating that people may be waiting for others to try it out first.

images.alt_text: ARE YOU GETTING ONE? Customers waiting in line to check out Apple Watches at Epicentre's outlet in ION Orchard mall on Friday, when the range of smartwatches officially went on sale in Singapore.

site_title: Malaysia's Panasonic shares soar on news of higher payout
summary: Malaysia's Panasonic shares rose 4.6% to RM23 following the announcement of a proposed final dividend of 35 sen and a special dividend of 92 sen per share, driven by a nearly quarter increase in net profit to RM100 million. Revenue rose 3.5% to RM931 million, mainly attributed to strong sales of ceiling fans and exports to Thailand, Vietnam, and the Philippines. The company plans to leverage operational efficiency and innovation to reduce production costs amid stiff competition from Korean and Chinese rivals.

site_title: Temasek unit accepts JCET's offer for STATS ChipPAC
summary: STATS ChipPAC's majority shareholder, Singapore Technologies Semiconductors Pte Ltd, has accepted a final cash offer from a consortium led by China's Jiangsu Changjiang Electronics Technology Co to buy out the company with the intention of taking it private. The company also announced the exit of two senior officials: CFO Dennis Chia and Senior Vice-President Janet Taylor. The deal is expected to result in STATS ChipPAC becoming a private company.

images.alt_text: Mindy Tan

site_title: Europe markets dip ahead of Greek weekend meeting
summary: European bonds and stocks fell as investors worried about the outcome of Greek negotiations with creditors over the weekend. If no deal is reached, Greece may default, impose capital controls, and potentially exit the eurozone. German Chancellor Angela Merkel urged the Greek government to compromise, while Greek Prime Minister Alexis Tsipras remained defiant. The ECB has countered a bank run with emergency lending, and creditors have offered a five-month extension of the bailout program if a deal is reached this weekend.

images.alt_text: DEBT TALKS: Mrs Merkel with Mr Tsipras (right) and French President Francois Hollande (left, with back to the camera) during a European leaders summit in Brussels on Friday.

site_title: Bubble in China? Not so clear cut: Citi
summary: China's stock markets retreated on Friday, prompting concerns about a potential bubble. However, Citi's Ken Peng suggests that investors are now reflecting accurate asset prices, rather than jumping on the bandwagon. Peng notes that significant policy changes have reduced skepticism about Chinese companies' health. The market's performance is now more nuanced, and it's not a clear-cut bubble situation. Peng's comments come as Singapore's NTT DC Reit's public offer was oversubscribed 9.8 times, and other markets reported mixed results.

site_title: IPO activity continues to surge in the Asia-Pac
summary: The Asia-Pacific region, particularly Greater China, saw a surge in initial public offering (IPO) activity in 2015, with 631 deals worldwide and 355 from the Asia-Pacific region. Total capital raised in the region was US$48.4 billion, a 66% jump from the first half of 2014. Singapore's Catalist and Greater China exchanges were among the most active, with Shenzhen and Shanghai exchanges ranking first and second in the world by number of deals. The surge in IPO activity is attributed to strong capital markets, favorable regulation, and increasing competitiveness.

images.alt_text: The Asia-Pacific region, and the Greater China area especially, continued to stand out in 2015 in initial public offering (IPO) activity and capital raised, despite the cooling down of global IPO activity during the first half of the year, according to EY.

site_title: Indonesia's power plans expected to boost coal market
summary: Indonesia plans to expand its power generation capacity by 46% in four years, with half of the new plants burning coal, potentially boosting coal prices by over 50%. This expansion, aimed at meeting the country's goal of 7% annual economic growth, may help break a four-year losing streak in the coal market. However, the project faces opposition from farmers and delays in land acquisitions, which could impact its success.

site_title: Half A Honda
summary: The Honda HR-V, a compact sport-utility vehicle, has become the best-selling car in the US after its launch in mid-April. Despite its stylish design and dynamic profile, it lacks the complete Honda formula. The vehicle is based on a stretched version of the Jazz platform and features camouflaged rear door handles. Its success can be attributed to low prices offered by grey importers and its attractive styling, which is similar to the Japanese domestic version, the Honda Vezel, available in Singapore since last year.

site_title: Honouring the cream of Singapore SMEs
summary: The SME100 Awards, now in its seventh year, recognizes the top 100 small and medium enterprises (SMEs) in Singapore, offering regional opportunities and recognition. Over 2,000 SMEs were monitored, and hundreds submitted entries. The awards use a rigorous 100% site audit process, with extensive site visits and phone interviews, to identify the crème de la crème of SMEs in Singapore. The winners are not just honored with a trophy but also gain access to regional opportunities and recognition, making the awards more meaningful during SG50.

site_title: Chinese stocks take another hard knock
summary: Chinese stocks plummeted 8.6% on Friday, falling within seven points of entering a bear market. The Shanghai Composite Index dropped to its lowest level since December 1996, with over 820 companies experiencing losses of more than 9.5%. European stocks also declined, and yields on Spanish and Italian bonds rose. Concerns about policy-makers withholding stimulus and tighter regulation of margin lending contributed to the decline, with German Chancellor Angela Merkel stating a weekend meeting of euro-area finance ministers will be decisive for Greece's debt repayment.

site_title: Eurozone stocks rise on optimism over Greek bailout
summary: Eurozone stocks rose on Friday due to optimism over Greece's potential bailout extension, with creditors offering an additional 12 billion euros to keep Greece from defaulting. The CAC 40 in Paris and Frankfurt's DAX 30 indices gained, while Athens' main index rose 2.03%. However, outside the eurozone, London's FTSE 100 index dropped 0.79% due to concerns over the ongoing Greek crisis. The extension is seen as a positive move, but a deal must be sealed by the weekend to avoid an IMF default.

site_title: Vietnam removes foreign ownership caps on most listed firms
summary: Vietnam has approved removing foreign ownership caps on most listed companies, lifting the 49% limit. The move, part of the country's economic reforms, aims to attract foreign investors and boost its private sector. The change will make Vietnam's market one of the region's most liberal, similar to Indonesia. The decision follows years of delay and frustration from foreign investors, with the ruling party's progressives pushing for a more open economic agenda. The new regulation will not apply to certain firms or sectors where the state retains controls.

site_title: One-year IP premium freeze on Medishield Life roll-out
summary: Integrated Shield Plan (IP) insurers in Singapore will freeze premiums for a year following the rollout of MediShield Life, a universal healthcare coverage program, at the end of 2015. The move aims to facilitate a smooth transition for policyholders. Claims for IPs have risen 12% annually for public hospital class A/B1 wards and 17% for private hospital IPs. The Life Insurance Association Singapore attributes the rise to larger medical bills, increased healthcare consumption, and newer, costlier procedures. Premiums for riders will also increase over time due to higher claims.

site_title: Britain to hold emergency meeting over French, Tunisian attacks
summary: Britain's emergency response committee will meet to discuss attacks in France and Tunisia, which have left at least 27 people dead. Prime Minister David Cameron expressed solidarity with France and offered condolences to Tunisia. He warned that the threat of radical attacks is a shared concern and must be combated with a "poisonous narrative" that turns young minds.

site_title: US consumer sentiment rises in June
summary: US consumer sentiment surged in June, reaching 96.1, its highest since January and surpassing economists' median forecast of 94.6. The increase is attributed to a stronger labor market and rising wages. This improvement in consumer sentiment may boost economic growth and spending.

site_title: Back to basics
summary: Australian celebrity chef Pete Evans adopted the paleo diet for his daughter's health after she was diagnosed with a tumor and found to be gluten and dairy intolerant. He eliminated grains, dairy, and processed foods, focusing on meat, vegetables, fruits, seafood, and spices. Evans emphasizes the importance of reading a well-researched book to understand the benefits of paleo and making informed choices for one's family's health. He shares simple meal ideas, such as chicken and vegetable soup, and offers tips like using broth as a nutrient-rich base for meals, and using alternative ingredients like coconut cream for desserts.

site_title: Greece's creditor propose to target shipping sector: documents
summary: Greece's creditors propose increasing the tonnage tax for the shipping sector and phasing out special tax allowances, according to documents. This move is aimed at generating more revenue for the country. The shipping sector, along with tourism, is a vital source of income for Greece. The proposals are part of the conditions set by Greece's lenders for the country to receive financial aid.

site_title: Striking gold by selling physical silver
summary: Gregor Gregersen, founder of Silver Bullion Pte Ltd, credits Lee Kuan Yew's book for inspiring him to start a business in Singapore's bullion market. Initially, he saw the demand for physical silver bullion during the 2008 financial crisis and created Silver Bullion to cater to this need. Since its inception in 2009, the company has sold about S$250 million of bullion and is recognized as the largest and most reliable supplier in South-east Asia. Silver Bullion's unique storage system and transparency have made it a pioneer in 24/7 online retailing of bullion in the region.

site_title: US: Wall St mixed at open ahead of Greece meeting
summary: US stocks opened mixed on Friday ahead of a Eurogroup meeting on Greece's bailout program. The Dow Jones rose 58.02 points, the S&P 500 gained 1.9 points, and the Nasdaq Composite dropped 4.17 points. The mixed performance was attributed to uncertainty surrounding the Greece meeting.

site_title: Germany's TUI offers to fly Tunisia tourists home
summary: Germany's tour operator TUI is offering to fly Tunisian tourists home after a deadly gun attack at a Tunisian beachside hotel. The attack killed at least 27 people, and TUI currently has 3,800 German tourists in the country. TUI will allow tourists to rebook or cancel free of charge until September 15. British travel operator Thomas Cook also offers free amendments to bookings for holidays departing up to July 24. The attack in Sousse follows a similar attack at Tunisia's Bardo museum in March.

site_title: Abbott to ink partnership deal with PM Lee here next week
summary: Australian Prime Minister Tony Abbott is set to sign a comprehensive strategic partnership (CSP) with Singapore next week, marking a significant expansion of bilateral relations between the two countries, which date back to 1965. Abbott's visit comes as a historic first since taking office in 2013. The partnership aims to strengthen economic ties, enhance security cooperation, and promote mutual understanding between the two nations. Details of the partnership deal are expected to be announced during Abbott's visit to Singapore.

images.alt_text: Australian Prime Minister Tony Abbott will arrive here on Sunday for his first official visit to Singapore since taking office in September 2013.
Lee U-Wen

site_title: Vietnam to end limits on foreign investment in many companies
summary: Vietnam will eliminate limits on foreign ownership in many listed companies, allowing overseas investors to increase holdings to 100% from 49%. The move aims to sustain the nation's equities rally and spur growth. The change applies to around 30 companies with 49% foreign ownership limits, and the cap on foreign investment in banks remains at 30%. The decision is expected to boost investor confidence and drive growth, following a 6.6% year-to-date gain in the benchmark VN Index.

site_title: British PM Cameron says needs promise of EU Treaty change
summary: British Prime Minister David Cameron stated that he will seek an agreement to change European Union treaties as part of Britain's renegotiation of its membership. This is a requirement for a British referendum, which is expected to take place in the future. Cameron acknowledged that treaty change is the difficult part, but emphasized that it must happen before the referendum. He previously suggested that treaty change could be completed by the end of 2017, but now says it will be more challenging to achieve.

images.alt_text: Prime Minister David Cameron said on Friday he would seek an agreement to change European Union treaties at some point in the future as part of his renegotiation of Britain's membership.

site_title: Watch out!
summary: Apple Watch has received a muted response, sparking concern over the product's viability in the market. Meanwhile, Singapore's Nanyang Technological University (SUTD) has launched an AI and Digital Innovation office to enhance design AI skills in students. Other tech-related news includes AI development, integrated enterprise solutions, and the establishment of AI-focused innovation hubs in Singapore, such as one by Amazon Web Services and mining giant BHP. Additionally, Lazada has invested US$100 million in its LazAffiliate Programme.

site_title: Airbnb closes in on US$1.5b fundraising: FT
summary: Airbnb is set to raise $1.5 billion in funding, valuing the company at $24 billion. The financing will be led by General Atlantic, Hillhouse Capital, and Tiger Global, with new investors Baillie Gifford and Wellington also participating. Current investors Fidelity and T Rowe Price are increasing their holdings. This deal marks a significant boost to Airbnb's valuation and position in the online home-rental marketplace.

images.alt_text: Online home-rental marketplace Airbnb Inc is closing on a US$1.5 billion fundraising that would boost the company's valuation to US$24 billion, the Financial Times reported.

site_title: Indonesia ban driving Malaysia bauxite exports
summary: Indonesia's ban on exporting bauxite, a key ore used in aluminum production, has led to a surge in exports from Malaysia, the Philippines, and Australia. At least five Indonesian mining companies have invested in Malaysia, with production more than quadrupling to 962,799 tonnes in 2014. Shipments from Malaysia to China have increased, benefiting these countries and challenging Indonesia's goal of boosting its metal-processing industry. Indonesia aims to produce 6 million to 8 million tonnes of alumina by 2021, but the ban has created a logistical advantage for Chinese buyers.

images.alt_text: GAINS FROM MINING: Bauxite production in Malaysia more than quadrupled to 962,799 tonnes in 2014 from 208,770 tonnes the year before. Malaysia has come from nowhere on the export-trade map to being a big exporter.

site_title: Tuck in all you want - for a hefty price
summary: The 2015 Dietary Guidelines Advisory Committee (DGAC) report concludes that there is no appreciable relationship between dietary cholesterol and serum cholesterol, allowing for the removal of the 300mg daily limit on cholesterol intake. A healthy diet characterized by increased consumption of vegetables, fruits, whole grains, and low-fat dairy can reduce the risk of heart attacks, strokes, and death by 20-50%. Diets such as the DASH and Mediterranean diets, as well as vegetarian diets, have been shown to have favorable effects on blood pressure, cholesterol, and cardiovascular disease outcomes, with a 9% decrease in overall death among vegetarians compared to non-vegetarians.

site_title: Manufacturing: Hopes for a better 2nd half
summary: Singapore's manufacturing sector contracted for the fourth straight month in May, with a 2.3% year-on-year decline. Economists attribute the slowdown to a lack of external demand, making a recovery in the second half of the year uncertain. Industrial output declined across all clusters, except for the chemicals sector.

site_title: Singapore Wrap Friday
summary: Singapore's manufacturing sector contracted for the fourth straight month in May with a 2.3% decline in industrial output. A consortium led by JCET announced its intention to acquire STATS ChipPAC. The Association of Banks in Singapore released guidelines for third-party service providers. Meanwhile, the Straits Times Index (STI) closed 0.9% lower, and Frasers Hospitality Trust raised S$123m through a private placement.

site_title: Bond funds worldwide post US$3.8b outflows in latest week: BofA
summary: Bond funds worldwide experienced their third consecutive week of outflows, totaling US$3.8 billion, according to Bank of America Merrill Lynch Global Research. Government bond funds, particularly those investing in US Treasuries, saw their ninth straight week of withdrawals. Meanwhile, stock funds attracted US$4.6 billion, with European stock funds experiencing their largest inflows in 11 weeks.

site_title: Hands on
summary: Young Urban Creatives, or Yuccies, are redefining work and making a living from obscure crafts, rejecting corporate jobs and "marketable" majors. They invest time and money in learning traditional trades, often through apprenticeships. Examples include Gwen Chan, who learned indigo dyeing in Japan, and Edwin Neo, who became a shoemaker after an apprenticeship in Hungary. Hughes Low, a former quantity surveyor, now crafts rare and exotic leather goods, while also mentoring apprentices. These individuals value hands-on work over digital pursuits, and their dedication to their crafts is paying off, with many building successful businesses and communities around their passions.

site_title: Latest earnings
summary: NTT DC Reit's Singapore public offer received 9.8 times oversubscription. Creative Technology warned of potential H2 revenue below target and operating loss similar to H1. London's Heathrow is considering higher fees for its £10 billion upgrade. Indonesia detained a Trafigura employee in a graft case. OCBC announced Tan Teck Long as its incoming CEO, replacing a DBS veteran. The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) and the People's Bank of China (PBOC) will deepen cooperation in green and transition finance. Singapore stocks rallied for a 5-day stretch ahead of GDP data release.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares end lower
summary: Malaysia's Kuala Lumpur Composite Index ended lower on Friday, closing at 1,710.47 after a 6.34-point decline. The index saw 1.35 billion lots traded, with 441 losers and 345 gainers.

site_title: French attack suspect had 'link' to Salafist movement
summary: A 35-year-old French man, Yacine Salhi, was arrested in connection with a gas factory attack that killed one person and injured two. Salhi had links to the Salafist movement and was investigated for radicalisation in 2006, but the probe was not renewed in 2008. He was known to have lived near Lyon, France's second-largest city. A local firefighter overpowered and neutralized Salhi after he was found at the scene, and police have taken several people into custody for questioning.

site_title: Don't settle for just any MBA . . .
summary:
Here's a 100-word summary of the article content:

When evaluating an MBA program, candidates must consider the shifting market dynamics and competition. A few programs will continue to offer massive value, but may not win the market contest due to increasing competition. Businesses and candidates should be aware of this before making a decision. The article highlights the importance of evaluating programs based on their unique strengths and value proposition, rather than relying on reputation or name recognition. By doing so, candidates can make informed decisions and set themselves up for success in the job market after graduation.

site_title: Air France denies reports of sweeping job cuts
summary: Air France has denied reports of 3,300 job cuts, including 3,000 ground crew departures and 300 pilots, as part of cost-cutting measures. The airline stated this in an email, contradicting a Le Monde report published earlier in the day. The report also mentioned the withdrawal of 20 planes from the fleet and additional route closures. Air France's denial comes as the airline faces ongoing financial challenges and competition in the European airline market.

images.alt_text: Air France on Friday denied a report that it was preparing to lay off 3,300 employees as part of continuing cost cutting at the French flag carrier.

site_title: MS Holdings' FY15 profit falls 36.5% to S$2 million on depreciation, IPO costs
summary: MS Holdings reported a 36.5% decline in FY15 net profit to S$2.04 million due to depreciation and listing-related expenses. Revenue rose 0.6% to S$17.09 million, while gross profit fell 8.1%. The company declared a final dividend of one Singapore cent per share. Despite a sharp increase in expenses, MS Holdings expressed cautious optimism about its prospects. Net profit per share was two Singapore cents.

site_title: Singapore shares close 0.9 per cent down on Friday
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) closed 0.9% lower on Friday, down 28.97 points to 3,320.9, amid Greece's failed negotiations to avoid a default next week. The STI was dragged down by banks and Singtel. Despite the decline, the index ended the week 0.6% higher than the previous Friday's close.

site_title: Hollande says attack in France was of "a terrorist nature"
summary: French President Francois Hollande confirmed an attack in southeast France was of "a terrorist nature" after a suspect was arrested and identified. A body with decapitated head and Arab writing was found at a US gas company, with two people injured and one fatality. A considerable police force was deployed to prevent further incidents, and industrial sites were protected.

site_title: HSBC ends sponsorship of key emerging market indexes
summary: HSBC is ending its 5-year sponsorship of the HSBC Markit Emerging Markets monthly purchasing managers' indexes (PMI), a key gauge of manufacturing activity in China and other developing countries. The decision comes as the bank carries out a cost-cutting overhaul and exits Brazil and Turkey. The sponsorship arrangement will be replaced soon, with Markit announcing new sponsors. The move may impact the reliability of the China PMI, which is closely watched for clues to the world's second-largest economy.

site_title: Eurozone lending picks up in May
summary: Eurozone lending to households and firms increased 0.5% in May, exceeding a 0.4% forecast, according to European Central Bank data. This growth bolsters the belief that the struggling eurozone economy is recovering. The M3 measure of money circulating in the eurozone grew at 5.0% in May, lower than the 5.3% growth rate in April. The improvement in lending suggests a slight recovery in the eurozone economy, despite sparse lending to companies.

site_title: Greece's creditors offer US$17.3b package to hasten deal
summary: Greece's creditors have offered a $17.3 billion package to hasten a deal, including a five-month extension of aid through November, in exchange for implementing economic measures. The proposal, which includes a €15.5 billion payout, comes as Greece's bailout expires on Tuesday and the country faces a potential payment deadline of $1.5 billion to the IMF. The deal's prospects remain uncertain, with creditors demanding harsh austerity measures and Greek Prime Minister Alexis Tsipras expressing frustration over the tough conditions.

site_title: Tsipras, Merkel, Hollande met in Brussels: source
summary: Greek Prime Minister Alexis Tsipras held a meeting with German Chancellor Angela Merkel and French President Francois Hollande in Brussels to discuss resolving tensions between Athens and its international creditors. The talks aimed to avoid a potentially disastrous Greek default and euro exit, but failed to reach a deal. Negotiators are racing against a June 30 payment deadline for a 1.5 billion euro IMF loan repayment, with creditors refusing to unlock 7.2 billion euros in bailout funds unless Greece accepts new reforms.

site_title: Greek deal 'must happen Saturday': Dijsselbloem
summary: Greek Prime Minister needs a bailout deal with EU-IMF creditors by Saturday to avoid missing a 1.5 billion euro IMF payment, which could trigger Greece's exit from the single currency and EU. Eurogroup head Jeroen Dijsselbloem urged a deal, stating that it must be clinched for parliamentary approval. Greece needs 7.2 billion euros in bailout funds to pay the IMF, but creditors are refusing until Athens agrees to new reforms. New Greek proposals aim to make 8 billion euros in savings through taxes and cuts, but creditors have counter-proposed further measures on pensions and defense spending.

site_title: Asia-Pacific crude-glut could worsen; Petronas sells Tapis
summary: The Asia-Pacific crude market is expected to worsen due to higher cargo inflows from the Atlantic basin. Malaysian state-owned Petronas sold a cargo of August-loading Tapis to a Philippine refiner, which will be processed domestically to avoid export duties. This move is seen as a response to the bearish outlook in the market. Traders are instead opting to ship crude to their own refining systems, adding to the glut. The situation is likely to continue, with no immediate signs of improvement.

site_title: Global insurance regulators pause on tougher capital requirement
summary: Global insurance regulators have postponed the implementation of tougher capital requirements for some of the largest companies by about a year, citing industry concerns and the need for more feedback. The Insurance Capital Standard (ICS) will now be released in 2017 and 2019, rather than 2016. The regulators are also working on Higher Loss Absorbency (HLA) standards, which require the largest insurers to hold additional capital to cover systemic risk. The ICS and HLA standards aim to prevent another financial crisis, which cost insurers and reinsurers $231 billion in 2008.

site_title: One decapitated in suspected terror attack on French factory
summary: A suspected Islamist attacker pinned a decapitated head covered with Arabic writing to the gates of a gas factory in eastern France, sparking a suspected terror attack. The attacker set off small explosive devices before being arrested. The motive and accomplices are unclear. France has been on high alert since the January Charlie Hebdo attacks, and the country has recently passed a new spying law.

images.alt_text: A suspected Islamist attacker pinned a decapitated head covered with Arabic writing to the gates of a gas factory in eastern France on Friday before being arrested, police said.

site_title: Explosion, decapitated body at French industrial site: media
summary: An explosion occurred at an industrial site in southeast France, resulting in one death and multiple injuries. A decapitated body was found at the scene, along with a flag bearing Islamist inscriptions. French Interior Minister Bernard Cazeneuve is heading to the site. The incident is being investigated as a potential act of terrorism, with no further details available.

images.alt_text: Unknown persons exploded gas containers at the premises of a company in southeast France on Friday, leaving one dead and several wounded, police sources said.

site_title: CapitaLand JV fulfils conditions to buy Danga Bay land parcels
summary: CapitaLand's joint venture, Hallmark Connection Sdn Bhd, has fulfilled conditions to acquire land parcels on A2 Island in Danga Bay, Iskandar Malaysia. The consortium, with CapitaLand owning 51%, will develop a premier waterfront residential community over 10-12 years. The project will be financed by equity, external financing, and property sales. The joint venture partners will contribute RM1.05 billion in equity, meeting the required conditions for the acquisition.

site_title: Apple Watch lands in competitive South Korea market
summary: Apple's smartwatch has landed in South Korea, where fans have formed long queues to buy the device despite concerns over its high price and local competition from brands like Samsung and LG. Analysts believe the watch will be a temporary hit among hardcore Apple fans, but its high-end products may not make a significant dent in the local market. The Apple Watch was released in six countries, including the US, China, and Japan, and has reportedly sold 2.8 million units through June.

images.alt_text: Apple's first smartwatch landed in South Korea, one of the world's most competitive markets on Friday, drawing a good response from fans, but analysts cast doubt on its long-term success there, citing a tough challenge from local brands.

site_title: Apple watch attracts few buyers in Swiss home of luxury watches
summary: Apple's smartwatch was launched in Switzerland, a hub for luxury watches, attracting a crowd of around 40 people, mostly young consumers, who lined up outside Apple's Zurich boutique. Many said they're ditching traditional watches for the Apple Watch due to its range of functions and design. The move may worsen the Swiss watch industry's difficulties, which are already struggling with a surge in the franc and a slump in demand from China. Swiss watchmakers, such as Swatch, are responding by introducing electronic devices to compete with the Apple Watch.

site_title: Singapore dollar lead Asian currencies drop amid Greek impasse
summary: Asian currencies dropped amid speculation of Greek default, with Singapore's dollar leading the decline, 0.4% lower in the Bloomberg-JPMorgan Asia Dollar Index. The euro-area finance ministers will meet on Saturday to discuss a potential bailout for Greece, which faces a debt repayment next week. Other affected currencies include South Korea's won, Taiwan's dollar, Malaysia's ringgit, and Thailand's baht, with the Malaysian ringgit down 2.7% this month due to credit rating concerns. The decline is attributed to risk aversion emanating from the Greek situation, with fears of capital outflows from Asia.

site_title: SIA Engineering renews SilkAir contract for S$197m
summary: SIA Engineering Co has renewed its contract with SilkAir for S$197 million, covering maintenance, repair, and overhaul services for A319 and A320 aircraft for five years with an option to extend. The agreement is not expected to impact SIA Engineering's financial performance in fiscal 2016.

site_title: StarHub names new chiefs for finance, marketing, strategic partnerships
summary: StarHub has appointed Dennis Chia, current CFO of STATS ChipPAC, as its new CFO, effective July 8. The telco also hired a new marketing chief and created a role for its outgoing marketing head as Chief Strategic Partnerships Officer (CSPO). These moves come as STATS ChipPAC is being acquired by a consortium and will announce a replacement for Chia after the takeover.

site_title: Greece offered five-month bailout extension: document
summary: Greece's EU-IMF creditors have offered a 5-month, 12-billion-euro extension of the country's current bailout program, set to end in November, in exchange for implementing reforms. This is the third bailout extension since December and would allow Athens to negotiate future financing from European partners.

site_title: One dead, several hurt in attack on French factory
summary: An attacker carrying an Islamist flag killed one person and injured several others at a gas factory in eastern France. The suspect, believed to be the attacker, was arrested. The attack occurred around 10:00 am local time and drew comparisons to the January attacks on Charlie Hebdo that killed 17 people. The incident is the latest in a series of terrorist attacks in France, which has seen a significant increase in extremist violence in recent years.

site_title: 'Malaysia is the winner': Indonesia miners go overseas after ban
summary: Malaysia is benefiting from Indonesia's ban on ore exports as mining companies from Indonesia invest in Malaysia's bauxite deposits to meet China's demand. At least five Indonesian miners have partnered with Malaysian companies to extract and ship ore to China, highlighting the challenge Indonesia faces in boosting its metal-processing industry. The ban has boosted prospects for rival suppliers, including Malaysia, the Philippines, and Australia, and may lead to more investments in Malaysian bauxite deposits.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks close 1.78% down
summary: Hong Kong stocks closed 1.78% lower on Friday, tracking a decline in mainland markets and Greece's debt reform talks. The Hang Seng Index fell 481.88 points to 26,663.87, with a turnover of HK$151.28 billion. The decline was attributed to concerns over Greece's debt reform and investor uncertainty.

site_title: Emirates A380 makes emergency landing in Colombo
summary: An Emirates A380 with 501 people on board made an emergency landing in Colombo, Sri Lanka, after pilots detected smoke in the cockpit. The plane landed safely 39 minutes after the distress call and all passengers and crew disembarked safely. The cause of the technical fault was not specified, and the aircraft was diverted to Colombo, which has not been upgraded to handle the A380. The airline transferred passengers to other flights and the incident was described as a "technical fault."

site_title: Greece determined to stay in eurozone, finance minister says
summary: Greece's Finance Minister Yanis Varoufakis stated that his country is determined to remain in the eurozone, despite creditor demands. He emphasized that Greece would not accept any unviable solution to its debt crisis. Varoufakis expressed frustration with the creditors, saying Greece has made all necessary accommodations, but the situation remains unresolved.

site_title: AirAsia India puts growth on hold while government dallies over reforms
summary: AirAsia India has halted its expansion plans after one year in business due to uncertainty over the government's decision on the 5/20 rule, which regulates overseas flights. The airline, which has a one per cent share of India's market, has been losing money due to high operating costs and frequent price wars. AirAsia India planned to lease 10 planes to fly to small Indian cities and overseas routes, but will wait for government clarity on the rule before proceeding. The airline's CEO said it will stick with domestic routes and invest in marketing instead.

site_title: China e-commerce firm JD.com to launch credit-scoring rival to Alibaba's
summary: China's No 2 e-commerce firm JD.com Inc is launching a credit-scoring system as a joint venture with US credit-scoring technology company ZestFinance, rivaling Alibaba's Sesame Credit. JD-ZestFinance Gaia will use machine learning to analyze JD.com's online shoppers' data and generate a credit risk score. The joint venture aims to create a reliable credit profiling system, which could be lucrative for both lending and selling profiles to third parties. JD.com will initially be the credit scorer's first customer, with plans to expand to various industries and lenders.

site_title: China says to curb risks, pace of setting up private banks
summary: China's banking regulator announced plans to encourage private banks, but will control risks and pace of establishment. Qualified investors will be treated equally, regardless of domestic or overseas status. Five private banks approved last year will launch operations, channeling loans to small businesses. The move aims to support struggling small businesses.

site_title: French consumer confidence steady in June at 4 1/2-year high: INSEE
summary: French consumer confidence remained steady in June at a 4 1/2-year high of 94, according to the INSEE statistics agency. This is the third consecutive month of stability, with households' outlook for their standard of living at its highest since October 2007. The number of households indicating it was a good time to make big purchases also increased, suggesting improved consumer spending.

site_title: China: Stocks fall more than 5%
summary: China's benchmark Shanghai Composite Index fell over 5% in afternoon trade on June 26, 2015, plummeting 252.57 points to 4,275.21. The Shenzhen Composite Index also declined 7.25% to 2,519.70. This marks a significant drop in the Chinese stock market, with the Shanghai Composite Index losing more than 5% in a single day. The decline is attributed to various factors, including economic concerns and market volatility.

site_title: STATS ChipPAC announces cessation of CFO as well as general counsel and company secretary
summary: STATS ChipPAC announced the cessation of its CFO, Dennis Chia Choon Hwee, and general counsel, Janet T Taylor, effective July 3 and June 30, respectively. Both are seeking new career opportunities. The company has found a permanent replacement for CFO and will announce the appointment when JCET-SC takes control. Elaine Sin Mei Lin will take over as company secretary and senior director of corporate legal, effective June 30.

images.alt_text: Mindy Tan

site_title: Indonesia regulator to issue rules to manage risk at financial conglomerates
summary: Indonesia's financial regulator plans to issue rules in September to manage risk at financial conglomerates, citing the growing size of these groups as a source of increased risk. The regulator oversees 50 financial conglomerates, including 35 banks. Details of the regulation were not immediately available.

site_title: Europe: Stocks decline as focus turns to weekend Greek meeting
summary: European stocks declined for a third day, falling 0.7% to 393.57, as euro-area leaders prepare for weekend talks on the Greek debt impasse. Finance ministers are set to reconvene on Saturday, with German Chancellor Merkel saying the talks will be decisive. Differences remain over pensions, sales-tax rates, debt relief, and corporate taxes, with French President Hollande expressing hope for a deal. The weekend gathering will determine the fate of Greece's debt crisis.

site_title: China: Stocks plummet as investors stampede out of the market
summary: China stocks plummeted 7.9% to 4,336.19, the worst loss in seven years, amid investor stampede out of the market. The Shanghai Composite Index fell 7.4% to 4,192.87 points, with nearly 2,000 companies slumping by 10% daily limit. Analysts attribute the downturn to shaky margin financing, monetary easing, and economic restructuring. Morgan Stanley predicts Shanghai's benchmark index to fall 2-30% over the next 12 months.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks close 0.31% lower
summary: Tokyo stocks fell 0.31% on June 26, 2015, amid concerns Greece's bailout reform talks ended in deadlock, raising fears of a potential default. The Nikkei 225 index closed at 20,706.15, and the Topix index was down 0.23%. The deadline for Greece to repay a debt loomed, adding to market uncertainty.

site_title: Update: China stocks fall more than 6%
summary: Chinese shares plummeted over 6% in afternoon trade on Friday, with the Shanghai Composite Index dropping 6.46% and the Shenzhen Composite Index falling 7.25%. Margin traders closed positions, citing concerns over market overvaluation. This comes after the benchmark index corrected sharply last week, dropping 13.32%. Outstanding margin debt in Shanghai dropped for a fourth straight day to 1.42 trillion yuan.

site_title: Quick Takes: Manufacturing recovery intact, but challenging outlook remains
summary: Singapore's industrial production fell 2.3% in May, marking a recovery from April's 9.1% decline, but still indicating contraction. This is the 6th consecutive month of decline. The output contracted in all clusters except chemicals.

site_title: Investors add most gold to funds in 5 months amid Greek impasse
summary: Investors added 6.9 metric tons of gold to physically-backed funds in the past week, the largest amount in nearly five months, amid uncertainty over Greece's debt repayment. This rebound comes as euro-area leaders convene in Brussels for talks, with German Chancellor Angela Merkel saying a weekend meeting of finance ministers will be decisive for Greece. Without a deal, ministers would need to map out ways to manage the potential consequences of a Greek default, which faces a debt repayment next week.

site_title: Eurozone loans to private sector growing again: ECB
summary: The European Central Bank (ECB) reported a 0.5% increase in loans to the private sector in the euro area, a sign that its monetary policy is working. This marks a reversal from long months of contraction, with private sector loans stagnating the previous month. The ECB's measures, including buying public sector bonds, are starting to boost economic activity. The eurozone money supply grew 5% in May, slower than April's 5.3%, but still a positive sign. The data suggests the ECB's efforts to stimulate credit and liquidity are having an impact.

site_title: Italy business and consumer confidence rise in June
summary: Italy's business and consumer confidence rose in June, beating expectations. The manufacturing confidence index increased to 103.9, while consumer confidence rose to 109.5, outperforming forecasts. The composite business morale index also rose to 104.3. This positive trend is a sign of Italy's nascent economic recovery, following a three-year recession. The country's GDP growth is expected to rise 0.7% over the year, according to Prime Minister Matteo Renzi's government.

site_title: Spain to hike economic growth forecast next week: Report
summary: Spain's government is expected to raise its economic growth forecast next week, following the country's strong first-half growth. The economy grew at 4% in the first half of 2015, surpassing the 2.9% expected for 2015 and 2016. The Bank of Spain has already raised its forecast to 3.1% for 2015 and 2.7% for 2016. The economic growth update is part of the 2016 budget preparations.

site_title: Singapore economy constrained by labour policies, strong currency: Citi strategist
summary: Singapore's economy is constrained by its labour policies and a strong currency, according to Citi strategist Ken Peng. This has led to declines in employment and industrial activity, with growth and profits squeezed in the past few years. Peng noted that the local labour market policies have had a significant impact, leading to levels of decline in employment and industrial activity last seen in 2009.

site_title: Australia: Shares fall on sell-off in banks, resources
summary: Australian shares fell 1.5% on Friday, extending losses for the second straight session, due to a sell-off in major banks and miners after Greece failed to clinch a deal with creditors. The S&P/ASX 200 index dropped 86.82 points to 5,545.9. Consumer staples sector rose, with Woolworths shares reaching a four-week high. The index is on track to end June in the red, marking its fifth consecutive monthly decline since March.

site_title: Japan's economy to grind to a halt in 2nd quarter: JPMorgan
summary: Japan's economy is expected to grind to a halt in the second quarter, according to JPMorgan Chase & Co. The economist Masamichi Adachi lowered the growth estimate to zero growth from a previous forecast of 1.5% annualized expansion. The slowdown is attributed to weaker-than-expected consumer spending and a decline in net trade. This marks a significant downward revision from the previous forecast, highlighting concerns about the country's economic stability.

site_title: Tesco sales down less than expected in first quarter
summary: Tesco, Britain's largest supermarket chain, reported a 1.3% decline in sales at British stores open for more than a year in its first quarter, beating analyst expectations. The decline is attributed to lower prices, improved product availability, and customer service, leading to increased sales volume. The result marks an improvement from the 1.7% fall in the previous quarter and suggests a tentative recovery in the key home market. CEO Dave Lewis attributed the improvement to better control and a more manageable turnaround plan.

site_title: ABS issues guidelines for third-party service providers for banks
summary: The Association of Banks in Singapore (ABS) has released guidelines for third-party service providers working with the banking industry, requiring financial institutions to rely on independent audit firms for assurance on provider controls. The guidelines, expected to be adopted within 12 months, aim to enhance the integrity and effectiveness of these controls. This move is part of ABS's efforts to strengthen the industry's risk management and compliance frameworks.

site_title: Singapore central bank seen keeping policy steady in October: Poll
summary: Singapore's central bank, the Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS), is expected to keep monetary policy steady in October, with core inflation expected to recover from five-year lows and edge higher later this year. Analysts believe the MAS will maintain its policy due to a tight labour market and wage cost pressures, with most economists predicting a 2-4% full-year economic growth forecast. Thirteen of 14 analysts polled by Reuters expect the MAS to leave its policy settings unchanged in October.

site_title: Australia Post slashes jobs as letter losses soar
summary: Australia Post is expected to axe 1,900 jobs due to a decline in letter volumes, resulting in forecast losses of almost A$500 million in its mail service business this financial year. The decline, which includes a 10% drop in ordinary mail volumes, is the largest-ever annual decline and would take overall losses to more than A$1.5 billion over the past five years. The company will introduce a voluntary redundancy program and retrain staff, with most job cuts expected in metropolitan areas. The decision comes as the postal service struggles with a dramatic shift in consumer behavior.

site_title: Singapore May factory output declines 2.3%, but still above forecast
summary: Singapore's manufacturing sector contracted for the fourth consecutive month in May, with industrial output falling 2.3% on a year-on-year basis. This follows April's 9.1% drop, and economists had expected a 2.6% decline. The chemicals cluster grew 1.3%, while other clusters contracted, with the transport engineering cluster performing the worst at 8.1% decline. After adjusting for seasonal factors, industrial production grew 2.4% month-over-month in May.

site_title: Japan, US can reach agreement for July pan-Pacific trade deal-Japan official
summary: Japan and the US are likely to resolve their remaining bilateral issues, allowing a 12-nation Trans-Pacific Partnership (TPP) deal to be struck in July. The deal, covering 40% of the world economy, is crucial for US President Barack Obama's strategic rebalance to Asia. Remaining issues include access to Japan's market for farm products and the US market for auto parts, but a senior Japanese official says these are not expected to be stumbling blocks. The US Senate has granted Obama "fast-track" power to negotiate trade deals, paving the way for a potential agreement.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks lose 0.48% at open
summary: Hong Kong stocks declined 0.48% at open on Friday, June 26, 2015, following debt reform talks between Greece and its creditors without a breakthrough. The Hang Seng Index fell 129.66 points to 27,016.09.

site_title: South Korea passes new law to curb Mers outbreak
summary: South Korea has passed a new law to curb the Mers outbreak, tightening quarantine restrictions and imposing jail sentences on those who defy anti-infection measures. The law allows for fines or prison sentences of up to two years for those who lie about their contact with the virus, and offenders who refuse to follow orders will also face penalties. The move aims to increase compliance among the public and healthcare workers, amid a crisis that has left 31 dead and 181 infected, with 81 recovered and 69 still being treated.

site_title: HSBC ends marketing tie-up with Markit to produce China purchasing managers index
summary: HSBC has ended its marketing tie-up with financial information firm Markit Ltd to produce the China Purchasing Managers Index (PMI). The tie-up, which was described as a success, will be replaced with HSBC developing other opportunities. The HSBC/Markit report, which often differed from official PMI data, focused on smaller and mid-sized companies. The decision comes after HSBC economist stopped providing comments to accompany the reports, sparking speculation about the end of the tie-up. Markit has not commented on the matter.

site_title: Vietnam's H1 2015 trade deficit seen at US$3.8b
summary: Vietnam's trade deficit for the first half of 2015 is estimated at US$3.8 billion, a reversal from a surplus of US$1.51 billion in the same period last year. Exports reached US$77.7 billion, while imports are forecast to reach US$81.5 billion, driven by a 15.2% increase in imports to US$171 billion. The government projects a trade deficit of US$6 billion in 2015, with exports expected to rise 10% to US$165 billion.

site_title: South Korea Mers outbreak claims two more deaths
summary: South Korea reported two more deaths from the Middle East Respiratory Syndrome (Mers) outbreak, bringing the total death toll to 31. A total of 181 people have been diagnosed with the virus since May 20, with 81 recovered and 69 still being treated. The latest fatalities were two women, aged 79 and 80, with existing health conditions. A doctor at Seoul's Samsung Medical Centre was also confirmed with the virus, adding to the hospital's suspension of services. The number of people in isolation has risen to 2,931.

images.alt_text: South Korea on Friday reported two more deaths from its outbreak of Middle East Respiratory Syndrome (Mers), and one new confirmed case.

site_title: China: Stocks tumble in early trade on policy concerns
summary: China's stocks plummeted 2.8% in early trade on Friday, following Thursday's losses, due to concerns over policy direction, increased IPOs, and a tighter cash supply. The CSI300 index fell to 4,573.87 points, while the Shanghai Composite Index dropped to 4,399.93 points. In Hong Kong, the Hang Seng index declined 0.5% to 27,016.09 points. The losses extended a period of market volatility, with traders seeking clarity on China's economic and policy trajectory.

site_title: Malaysia: Stocks open flat
summary: Malaysia's stock market opened flat on Thursday morning with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index remaining unchanged at 1,716.64 points. 27.9 million shares worth RM11.1 million were traded, with 102 gainers and 64 losers.

site_title: No increase in premiums for private insurance coverage portion of Integrated Shield Plans for 12 months
summary: Singapore's life insurers have committed to not increasing premiums for the private insurance coverage portion of Integrated Shield Plans for 12 months. This move aims to facilitate a smooth transition as the government prepares to provide healthcare coverage for life. The increase in MediShield Life coverage is expected to reduce claims payouts from the top-up portion of IPs, with estimates suggesting a 14 percentage point decrease for public hospital class A/B1 wards and a 6 percentage point decrease for private hospital wards. The decision reflects the industry's efforts to support policyholders during this transition period.

images.alt_text: Chairman Mr Bobby Chin (fourth from left) with members of the Medishield Life Review Committee, speaking during the press conference, held at the Suntec City Convention Centre on June 24, 2014.
Mindy Tan

site_title: In reversal, Taylor Swift to stream only on Apple
summary: Taylor Swift announced she will stream her album "1989" exclusively on Apple Music after the tech giant reversed course and increased payments to artists. Swift had initially threatened a boycott over compensation. The change comes after Apple stepped up payments following Swift's open protest. This marks a reversal of Swift's previous stance, with her previously opting to stream on other platforms.

site_title: Billions of China's lottery funds misused
summary: China's state lotteries generated nearly $3 billion in revenue between 2012 and 2014, but nearly a quarter of it, around $3.62 billion, was misused through embezzlement and corruption. The funds were used to purchase office buildings, buy vehicles, and finance overseas travel for officials. While some officials were "blamed" for the abuses, billions in assets were recovered. The misappropriation of lottery funds is a significant issue, as profits from the scheme are meant to fund social welfare projects. The Chinese government has launched a crackdown on corruption, but the extent of the punishment for those involved remains unclear.

site_title: Two rival self-driving cars have close call in California
summary: Two self-driving prototype cars, one operated by Google and the other by Delphi Automotive, had a close call in Palo Alto, California, on Tuesday. A Google self-driving Lexus cut off a Delphi self-driving Audi, forcing it to abort a lane change. No collision occurred. This incident is believed to be the first involving two vehicles specially equipped for automated driving. Both companies have previously reported minor collisions with human-piloted vehicles, with the self-driving cars not at fault in most cases.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open flat
summary: Tokyo stocks opened flat on Friday, slipping 0.06% due to risk aversion over deadlocked Greek bailout talks. The Nikkei 225 index fell to 20,758.43. The Dow Jones dropped 0.42% on Thursday due to Greek debt worries. The euro and dollar remained stable against other currencies.

site_title: Oil prices mixed with focus on Greece
summary: Oil prices were mixed in Asia, with US benchmark West Texas Intermediate falling 8 cents to $59.62 and Brent crude rising 20 cents to $63.40. The focus is on Greece's deadlocked debt talks, which are expected to come to a head over the weekend. Analysts weigh the potential negative impact on European energy demand. Meanwhile, a deal between Iran and Western powers to lift economic sanctions in exchange for nuclear program access may also affect oil prices, potentially leading to Iranian crude returning to the market and exacerbating oversupply.

images.alt_text: Oil prices were mixed in Asia on Friday as dealers eyed the deadlocked Greek debt talks expected to come to a head over the weekend, analysts said.

site_title: No deal for Greece, creditors; top-level talks resume on Saturday
summary: Greece failed to reach a deal with its international creditors on Thursday, prompting a last-ditch effort on Saturday to avoid default or mitigate euro zone financial market turmoil.
