Euro zone finance ministers ended their third meeting in a week without agreement, and German Chancellor Angela Merkel described the next meeting as "of decisive importance." Time is running out, with a default looming next week.

site_title: Frasers Hospitality Trust raises S$123m from placement of stapled securities
summary: Frasers Hospitality Trust (FHT) has raised S$123 million through a private placement of 150 million new stapled securities, priced at S$0.820 per unit. The trust plans to use the funds to part-finance the acquisition of Sofitel Sydney Wentworth. TCC Hospitality Limited subscribed for 59.34 million units, while the remaining 90.66 million units were two times subscribed. The trust's Reit manager said the placement was successful and the funds will be used to support the acquisition.

images.alt_text: Mindy Tan

site_title: Australia's Qantas says rethinking Jetstar Hong Kong after licence snub
summary: Qantas will reconsider Jetstar Hong Kong's operations after the Air Transport Licensing Authority in Hong Kong rejected the airline's application to start operations, citing a lack of compliance with laws requiring the principal place of business to be in the territory. Qantas had partnered with China Eastern Airlines and Shun Tak Holdings to launch a low-cost Asian airline. The airline's CEO, Alan Joyce, expressed disappointment, stating that Hong Kong appears to be "closed to fresh aviation investment" and that shutting the door to new competition can only serve vested interests.

site_title: Cameron pitches new EU deal at summit overshadowed by Greece
summary: British Prime Minister David Cameron announced a new EU deal at a Brussels summit, seeking to limit welfare benefits for migrants and secure opt-out clauses for Britain from euro rules. The move comes ahead of a 2017 referendum on Britain's EU membership, with Cameron facing opposition from Conservative Eurosceptics and EU leaders who want to keep Britain in the bloc. Cameron's proposals are seen as a gamble, with some EU leaders questioning the feasibility of treaty changes, and the UK's future in the EU uncertain.

images.alt_text: Prime Minister David Cameron told European Union leaders on Thursday he needed a new deal to keep Britain as a member, opening a struggle over the bloc's future at a summit preoccupied with keeping Greece from crashing out.

site_title: JCET announces 'firm intention' to make offer for STATS ChipPAC
summary: JCET, a consortium led by China's Jiangsu Changjiang Electronics Technology Co, has announced a firm intention to make an offer for STATS ChipPAC, a Singaporean mainboard-listed company. STATS ChipPAC plans to raise US$200 million through a non-renounceable rights issue of perpetual securities. The offer is part of JCET's plan to acquire STATS ChipPAC, although details of the deal have not been disclosed.

images.alt_text: Mindy Tan

site_title: A US$500 billion maybe: why big Iran moment may be years away
summary: Iran is seeking a nuclear accord with world powers to access billions of dollars in frozen assets, potentially worth $500 billion, to revive its economy. However, companies are hesitant to invest due to concerns about the risk of Iran violating the agreement, which would lead to sanctions being reimposed. Diplomats expect negotiations to extend beyond the June 30 deadline, but a final deal must be endorsed by the US Congress and the UN Security Council, with a 10-year suspension of sanctions and verification of Iran's compliance.

site_title: US spy chief says China 'leading suspect' in hack
summary: US intelligence chief James Clapper has identified China as the "leading suspect" in a massive data breach of Washington's government personnel files, affecting millions of employees and contractors. The breach, which may have compromised up to 14 million people, is believed to be part of an espionage effort. An investigation is ongoing, and the US administration has announced new security measures to boost online records.

site_title: Japan's consumer prices rise as Kuroda pumps record stimulus
summary: Japan's consumer prices unexpectedly rose 0.1% in May, exceeding economists' forecasts of no change. The central bank's unprecedented stimulus aims to generate inflation, which is forecast to slow this quarter due to a decline in oil prices. Only 2 economists predict the BOJ will reach its 2% target by September. The weak yen and higher ingredient costs are supporting inflationary pressures, but households may resist price increases due to stagnant wages. The BOJ will continue to monitor the situation, with some members maintaining expectations of eventual price increases.

site_title: JPMorgan sees US$500 billion of China debt in global hands by 2020
summary: JPMorgan estimates that China's debt could reach $500 billion in global hands by 2020, four-fold the current $118 billion, as China's markets open up to foreign investors. This could support President Xi Jinping's push for the yuan to be included in International Monetary Fund reserves and help clean up a regional debt mess. Overseas institutions have already seen a 84% increase in onshore bond holdings, and the central bank is expanding access to the interbank bond market, with 108 banks and 13 insurance companies now allowed to participate.

site_title: Looking good on paper
summary: STPI's annual summer show, "As We Never Imagined: 50 Years Of Art Making," features a curated selection of artworks from famous artists, including David Hockney, Roy Lichtenstein, and Helen Frankenthaler, created through decades of collaboration between STPI and its founder Kenneth Tyler. The exhibition showcases a range of mediums, including printmaking, sculpture, and installation. The show also highlights the work of notable Singapore artists, such as Chua Ek Kay and Suzann Victor, who have collaborated with international artists to create innovative and high-quality artworks. The exhibition runs until August 30 at STPI.

images.alt_text: Helmi Yusof

site_title: Greek pensions: at the heart of dispute with creditors
summary: Greece is racing to finalize a deal with its creditors to avoid default and potential eurozone exit. The country's generous state pension system is at the heart of the dispute, with creditors arguing it's unsustainable. Prime Minister Alexis Tsipras has proposed reforms to raise 2 billion euros, but creditors are demanding further cuts, including abolishing early retirement and increasing the retirement age to 67. The pension system, which provides an average of 713 euros per month, has decreased by 10-15% since 2010, with 50% of households relying on a retired family member's pension.

site_title: From menu of crises, Greece eats into Europe's agenda
summary: European Union leaders met in Brussels on Thursday, with Greece's looming bankruptcy forcing its way onto the agenda. The EU leaders demanded Prime Minister Alexis Tsipras to cut a cash-for-reform deal with their finance ministers, as Athens teeters on the brink of default. The summit's packed agenda also includes migrants, Russia, and Britain's threat to quit. Officials had to reshuffle the timetable due to Greece's crisis, with one leader joking it was no longer Britain for dinner but "Greece for dinner".

site_title: Euro steady as Greece debt talks stay deadlocked
summary: The euro remained steady against the dollar as Greece's emergency negotiations with creditors ended abruptly, pushing the crisis towards a critical weekend meeting to avoid a debt default. Greece needs creditors to unlock €7.2 billion in its bailout to pay an IMF debt payment on June 30. Talks are set to resume on Saturday, with markets lacking confidence in a deal to avert a default and possible eurozone exit. The European Central Bank's stimulus and the US Federal Reserve's potential interest rate hike also weighed on the euro's medium-term outlook.

images.alt_text: The euro was little changed against the dollar on Thursday as Greece once again failed to reach a deal with its creditors to avoid a debt default.

site_title: Transforming childhood memories to art
summary: Photographer Ernest Goh's first solo exhibition, "Breakfast at 8, Jungle at 9," at Objectifs Gallery features 3D installations incorporating flora and fauna, inspired by his childhood fascination with animals. The exhibition includes 2D photographic prints and interactive experiences, such as "The Gift Book" and "Time to Wrap Up," which showcase conceptual patterns using animals. Goh's work began in 2010, and he has since explored themes of nature and conservation in his art.

site_title: App helps farmers collect and retrieve data
summary: FarmLogs, an app developed by Jesse Vollmar, has revolutionized data management for farmers worldwide. Launched in 2011, the app allows farmers to record planting dates, watering schedules, and crop yield using mobile devices and share data via the web. The app also offers features such as remote soil health monitoring and real-time satellite image analysis to detect distressed areas. Currently, 70,000 US row-crop farms use the app, with plans to introduce paid subscriptions in 2016 for advanced features.

site_title: US: Stocks drop; hospitals surge on pro-Obamacare court ruling
summary: US stocks dropped 0.42% to 17,890.36, with the S&P 500 and Nasdaq falling 0.30% and 0.20% respectively, amid worries of a Greek default. However, health stocks surged after the Supreme Court upheld a key provision of President Obama's health care reform, benefiting hospital stocks like HCA Holdings (+8.8%) and Tenet Healthcare (+12.2%). Bond prices fell as the yield on the 10-year US Treasury rose to 2.40%.

site_title: Yuan trade volumes in London more than double in 2014
summary: London's renminbi trade volumes more than doubled in 2014, reaching US$61.5 billion, with spot trading volumes increasing by over three times to US$18.4 billion per day. This growth is part of London's efforts to attract Chinese banks and establish itself as a major centre for foreign exchange trading. The City of London Corporation attributes the growth to the increasing sophistication and depth of the market, with more active participants. London aims to bolster its position as a key player in the global foreign exchange market, with the launch of China's new international payments system expected to further boost the market.

images.alt_text: Chinese renminbi trade volumes in London more than doubled last year, according to figures from the City of London Corporation on Friday, in a further sign of deepening financial links between Britain and China.

site_title: Oil majors urged by UN to plan for phasing out fossil fuels
summary: The top European oil majors, including BP, Eni, Royal Dutch Shell, Statoil, Total, and BG Group, have been urged by the UN to plan for phasing out fossil fuel emissions by 2100. In a letter, UN climate diplomat Christiana Figueres called on the companies to work with governments on cleaner forms of energy and develop carbon capture and storage technology. This comes after the companies, which are meeting to discuss ways to better engage the climate debate, opened a schism with their US counterparts by calling for carbon pricing.

site_title: Petrobras urges US court to throw out investor suit
summary: Brazilian state-owned oil giant Petrobras asked a US court to dismiss a class-action lawsuit from investors who claim the company's massive corruption scandal devalued their investments. The lawsuit alleges Petrobras inflated its earnings, resulting in overpaid investments by individual investors and pension funds. Petrobras officials allegedly colluded with construction companies to overbill projects and bribe politicians, costing the company over $2 billion. The company claims the scandal was the result of "mismanagement" and "irregularities" by a handful of officials, not the company as a whole.

images.alt_text: Brazilian state-owned oil giant Petrobras asked a US court on Thursday to dismiss a class-action lawsuit from investors who claim its massive corruption scandal devalued their investments.

site_title: Sequoia leads charge in China buyouts
summary: Billionaire Neil Shen, co-founder of Sequoia Capital China, is leading a surge in buyouts of Chinese companies listed abroad, with at least five companies targeted this month. Sequoia is seeking higher multiples for its takeover bids, which have been 23% above companies' average 30-day trading price prior to announcements. The move is driven by China's surging stock market and Sequoia's desire to take companies public in the mainland, where they can command higher values.

site_title: Pacific trade talks enter 'fast and furious' phase
summary: Pacific Rim countries, including the US, Japan, and New Zealand, are racing to finalize the Trans-Pacific Partnership (TPP) trade pact by the end of July or early August. After US lawmakers granted President Barack Obama "fast-track" authority, negotiations are expected to be "fast and furious" in the next six weeks. Key issues still outstanding include monopoly periods for biologic drugs and phase-out periods for tariffs. Canada is holding out on opening its protected dairy market to more imports, and a ministerial meeting is planned for the near future to conclude the negotiations.

images.alt_text: Japanese Economy Minister Akira Amari said he hopes the Trans-Pacific Partnership (TPP) can be wrapped up by the end of July, and New Zealand Trade Minister Tim Groser said he sees a US summer break in August as a deadline.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: iX Biopharma's iFerret and Super BullsEye systems are being used at Tyndall Air Force Base in Florida, USA, following a contract announced in 2013. Frasers Hospitality Trust plans to raise up to $123 million by issuing new stapled securities to fund the acquisition of Sofitel Sydney Wentworth. Stamford Tyres reported an 83% fall in full-year net profit to $1.7 million due to pricing pressure and a property sale. Global Logistic Properties signed new lease agreements totaling 68,000 sqm in Brazil, while iX Biopharma lodged its preliminary offer document for a proposed listing on the Catalist.

site_title: Crown Estate achieves higher total returns
summary: The Crown Estate reported a record £11 billion in value, a 17% surge, and 20.8% total return over the past year. The company's assets, including West End properties and wind farms, outperformed the market. CEO Alison Nimmo stated that the business has nearly doubled its value over 10 years. This marks the highest total return since 2005.

site_title: Oil prices fall as Greece debt crisis talks drag on
summary: Oil prices fell on Thursday as traders awaited Greece's debt crisis talks, which have been prolonged, to avoid a debt default and eurozone exit. US benchmark West Texas Intermediate dropped 57 cents to $59.70 a barrel, while Brent North Sea crude fell 29 cents to $63.49 a barrel. The ongoing uncertainty weighed on oil prices, with investors keeping a close eye on the situation.

images.alt_text: Oil prices fell on Thursday as traders kept an eye on Greece's prolonged negotiations with creditors to avoid a debt default and possible exit from the eurozone.

site_title: GSK set to invest £38m more in Singapore facility
summary: GSK is investing £38m more in its Singapore antibiotic manufacturing plant, bringing the total investment to £98m. The additional investment will increase production by 50% and reduce the carbon footprint by up to 25% by using enzymatic technology instead of chemical processes. The project is part of GSK's 10-year manufacturing roadmap with the Economic Development Board (EDB) to improve pharmaceutical manufacturing efficiency in Singapore.

site_title: Shanghai Gold Exchange in talks with CME to list contracts
summary: The Shanghai Gold Exchange is in talks with the CME Group to list each other's gold contracts on their respective exchanges. The Shanghai exchange will list the CME's contracts first, with the CME's contracts to be available to Chinese members in a second phase. An agreement is expected to be signed in August, with trading potentially starting in the first quarter of 2026. This cooperation aims to expand China's presence in gold and currency markets worldwide, aligning with the country's efforts to increase its global influence in commodities and currency markets.

site_title: Banks readier than before for bad loans ahead: Credit Suisse
summary: Singapore banks are better prepared to handle an increase in bad loans due to tougher regulations and a shift towards less risky lending, according to a Credit Suisse report. The banks' mortgage books are expected to be more resilient, driven by the growth in the last five years. As interest rates pick up, Singapore banks are poised to handle an increase in bad loans more effectively than during the previous cycle. This is attributed to their growth being driven by less risky lending, and tougher regulations.

site_title: Singapore shares open 5.93 points lower on Friday
summary: Singapore shares dropped 5.93 points to 3,343.94 on Friday, amid deadlocked talks between Greece and its creditors. The Nikkei 225 index in Tokyo slipped 0.06% and the Dow Jones Industrial Average dropped 0.42% on Thursday. In Singapore, gainers outnumbered losers 81 to 64, with the Straits Times Index down for the day.

images.alt_text: Mindy Tan

site_title: EU ministers seek ambitious, binding deal at Paris climate talks: draft
summary: EU environment ministers are seeking a legally binding deal at the Paris climate talks, aiming for a 5-yearly review of progress. The draft statement emphasizes the need for predictability and durability in the agreement. EU ministers will finalize their joint position in Brussels on September 18, ahead of the UN climate talks in Paris in December. The deal must be "legally binding" to demonstrate the EU's commitment to curbing global warming.

site_title: Violent French taxi protests against Uber
summary: Protests against ride-hailing app Uber turned violent in France, with 3,000 taxi drivers blocking airports and damaging vehicles. Ten people were arrested, and seven police officers were injured. UberPOP, the French version of the service, has been illegal since January but continues to operate. Interior Minister Bernard Cazeneuve vowed to close down the service, but taxi drivers' unions remained defiant. The protests, sparked by Uber's unfair competition and lower prices, have left licensed cabbies concerned about their jobs and livelihoods.

site_title: US West Coast refiners snap up Russian crude to avoid seasonal shortage
summary: US West Coast refiners have purchased Russian ESPO crude to avoid a seasonal shortage of Alaskan supply, taking advantage of a narrow price gap between US and global prices. Up to four tankers are expected to carry nearly three million barrels of Russian crude to refineries in the US this month and next. This diversification effort comes as Asian markets battle oversupply and US companies are barred from drilling in Russia due to sanctions. The trend is seen as temporary, with refineries buying amid uncertainty over Alaska North Slope crude supply.

site_title: Consumer spending in US shows biggest gain in nearly six years
summary: US consumer spending increased 0.9% in May, the largest gain in nearly six years, driven by higher stock and home prices, rising employment, and lower petrol prices. Incomes rose 0.5% for the second month, and disposable income increased 0.2% after adjusting for inflation. This boost in spending may help accelerate consumer spending in the coming quarters, according to economists. The strong labour market and wage growth are expected to continue supporting consumer spending.

site_title: 50 notable Peranakans from Singapore's history
summary: The Peranakan Museum in Singapore has showcased 50 notable Peranakans from the country's history, highlighting their contributions to the community and the nation. The exhibition, "Great Peranakans: 50 Remarkable Lives," features more than 200 artefacts and highlights individuals from various fields, including politics, arts, and culture. The exhibition, which runs until April 2016, aims to educate visitors about the Peranakan community and its significance in Singapore's history.

site_title: Companies need to go the extra mile to rope in more women
summary: Singapore's corporate boardrooms are underrepresented by women, with only 9% holding board seats and 7% in leadership positions. This is lower than the global average of 12% for board seats and 4% for leadership positions. Unlike some Asian countries, Singapore does not have gender quotas, and having women appointed based on merit is considered more suitable. Companies are urged to go the extra mile to recruit more women to boards and top management positions, as it benefits their commercial interests and enhances diversity.

site_title: Sovereign reserve funds - the elephant in the room
summary: Sovereign reserve funds, managed by central banks and wealth funds, have become a significant investor group in global financial markets. With $12 trillion in assets, they rival institutional investors and have the potential to influence various markets. The growth of reserve accumulation has outpaced global trade growth, driven by the Asian crisis and the 2008 global financial crisis. However, the pace of reserve accumulation is slowing, and sovereign funds are diversifying into alternative assets, such as inflation-protected bonds and the Chinese renminbi, to improve investment performance.

site_title: US lawmakers give Obama's Pacific trade pact a boost
summary: US lawmakers approved legislation granting President Barack Obama the power to negotiate trade deals and send them on a fast track through Congress, advancing the Trans-Pacific Partnership (TPP) and a potential trade deal with the European Union. The 60-38 Senate vote comes after a six-week congressional battle, with some lawmakers backing down on opposition to fast-track authority. The TPP, a 12-nation agreement covering 40% of the world economy, aims to boost US exporters and global economic output. A deal could be wrapped up within weeks once lawmakers agree to fast-track.

site_title: Take stock of rising market volatility in asset management: StanChart
summary: Standard Chartered's Wealth Management Group has warned Singapore investors of rising market volatility and suggested a bullish strategy for the next 12-24 months, with a focus on equities, alternative asset management, and a positive outlook for the US dollar. The group recommends diversifying investments through exchange-traded funds, easily accessible equity management mutual funds, A-shares, and fixed income instruments, such as perpetual bonds and bonds with maturity around five years.

site_title: Putin calls Obama to discuss Ukraine, IS group: White House
summary: Russian President Vladimir Putin called US President Barack Obama on June 25, 2015, to discuss the Ukraine conflict, the Islamic State group's advances, and a deal on Iran's nuclear program. The US had announced plans to deploy heavy weapons in central and eastern Europe, following NATO's pledge to increase its military presence in the region. Putin reiterated Russia's commitment to the Minsk agreements, which have been unraveling, and discussed Syria and Iran's nuclear negotiations.

site_title: A celebration of restaurant food in S'pore
summary: Singapore Restaurant Month, organized by the Restaurant Association of Singapore, will feature 50 new dishes from 50 restaurant brands from July 1 to Aug 10. The event aims to celebrate Singapore's diverse dining scene and is the first-ever celebration of restaurant food in the country. The festival is part of SG50 celebrations, marking 50 years of Singapore's independence.

images.alt_text: Tay Suan Chiang

site_title: Alibaba affiliate launches Internet bank for SMEs
summary: MYbank, an internet bank launched by Alibaba's financial affiliate, has registered capital of 4 billion yuan and will offer loans of up to 5 million yuan to China's small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs). The bank aims to provide credit to SMEs that have struggled to obtain loans from major financial institutions.

site_title: Turning history into a dramatic thriller
summary: Singapore's tumultuous past, specifically the period of unrest known as Konfrontasi, is retold in the upcoming film "1965". The drama, directed by Randy Ang and produced by Daniel Yun, stars Qi Yuwu and Joanne Peh and explores the lives of ordinary people during this time, including those who would later become the Pioneer Generation. The film aims to humanize the period and highlights the fragility of racial harmony, rather than serving as propaganda. With a budget focused on realism, "1965" is set to be released on July 30.

images.alt_text: Dylan Tan

site_title: Standard Chartered Private Equity invests US$52m in Crystal Jade
summary: Standard Chartered Private Equity (SCPE) has invested US$52 million in Crystal Jade Group Holdings, a restaurant chain with over 100 outlets across Asia and beyond. The investment will fund the growth of Crystal Jade's existing network and global footprint. SCPE joins L Capital Asia, which acquired a majority stake in Crystal Jade last year, with a focus on expansion into new markets and eventual public listing. The partnership aims to further exploit Crystal Jade's tremendous growth opportunity.

site_title: Religare Capital Markets appoints head of Asean trading
summary: Religare Capital Markets has appointed Stephen Conway as its head of Asean trading, marking the second senior hire this month. Conway brings over 25 years of experience in trading Asian markets, previously working at RHB Securities, MF Global, and Credit Suisse. The appointment is part of Religare's efforts to expand its presence in the region, following recent hires and announcements of strategic partnerships in the Philippines, Thailand, Indonesia, Malaysia, Japan, Taiwan, and China.

site_title: Malaysian billionare gives Rome opera one million euros
summary: Malaysian billionaire Tan Sri Francis Yeoh has donated 1 million euros (S$1.5 million) to Rome's struggling Teatro dell'Opera di Roma. The gift aims to help the institution "distinguish itself on an international level" as a premier artistic center. A long-time admirer of Italian opera singers, Yeoh has previously financed classical music concerts globally. The donation comes after a series of strikes at the Roman theatre, highlighting the struggle of the arts sector in Italy amid funding cuts.

images.alt_text: A long-time admirer of Italy's prized opera singers Pavarotti and Andrea Bocelli, Mr Yeoh has financed numerous classical music concerts at home and abroad.

site_title: Counting the cost of hacking
summary: Australian communications firm Codan suffered significant losses after hackers stole its metal detector designs, leading to a collapse in sales and prices. The company was forced to slash prices to compete with counterfeiters, resulting in a net profit drop of $35.8 million. Experts say hackers steal $160 billion worth of intellectual property annually, and many companies are too focused on reverse engineering capabilities to address cybersecurity. The Australian government's inaction in addressing Codan's issue highlights the challenges of protecting commercial assets from cyber threats.

site_title: Australia passes RET, unblocks A$14b in projects
summary: Australia has passed a renewable energy target (RET) legislation, ending months of policy uncertainty and allowing wind and solar developers to invest in over A$14 billion worth of projects. The new target sets a goal for 33,000 GWh of renewable energy by 2020, with Acciona SA and SunEdison Inc planning to develop large-scale projects in the country. The legislation is expected to boost investment in the renewable energy sector, providing opportunities for companies like Acciona and SunEdison to discuss projects with banks and retailers.

site_title: Apple signs thousands of indie labels in royalty deal
summary: Apple has signed thousands of independent record labels for its streaming service, Apple Music, after changing its policy on royalties following public criticism from Taylor Swift. The deal ensures that royalties will be paid even during the service's three-month trial period. The Beggars Group and Merlin, which represent small and indie labels, reached the licensing agreement with Apple, contradicting the company's initial proposal that did not pay royalties during the trial period.

site_title: Chocolate that doesn't melt in your hands when it gets hot
summary: Researchers at Barry Callebaut AG have developed chocolate that can remain solid at temperatures as high as 38 degrees Celsius, making it suitable for hot climates. The company aims to start selling this heat-resistant chocolate within the next few years, with competitors like Nestle and Hershey also working on similar projects. The demand for heat-resistant chocolate is expected to grow significantly in Asia-Pacific, Latin America, and the Middle East and Africa, driven by the region's warm climates and large populations.

site_title: Average indicative dividend yield of 7.1% for business trusts
summary: The average indicative dividend yield of Singapore-listed business trusts stands at 7.1%, according to a June 25 market update by the Singapore Exchange. This represents an increase from the previous month's 6.9%. The top-performing trusts in the year so far include First Ship Lease Trust, Keppel Infrastructure Trust, and Ascendas India Trust, with average total dividend-boosted returns of 18.5%. The business trusts have seen average price gains of 5.1% and a total average return of 9.2%, driven by stronger demand for tankers and other assets.

site_title: Greek ministers unyielding as creditors make cash-for-reform proposal
summary: Greek ministers remain unyielding to creditors' cash-for-reform proposal, which would increase tax and social contributions to address Greece's budget hole. The proposal was rejected by Greek officials, who claim it would not raise enough revenue. The deadline for a deal is Sunday, with a default on an IMF repayment looming, potentially triggering a bank run and capital controls. The European Commission, ECB, and IMF gave Greece an ultimatum to offer a credible reform plan by Thursday, but Greece's leftist Prime Minister Alexis Tsipras refused to compromise on key reforms.

site_title: Citic to invest 700b yuan in China's 'One Belt, One Road'
summary: Citic Ltd, a Chinese state-owned conglomerate, plans to invest over 700 billion yuan in China's "One Belt, One Road" initiative, involving about 300 projects from Singapore to Turkmenistan. The investments will support infrastructure development, energy, agriculture, and culture projects across central, west, and south Asia. Citic's banking, securities, trust, and construction divisions will jointly participate in the initiative, with Citic Bank Corp providing financing for up to 200 projects and establishing a "One Belt, One Road" fund to finance Chinese companies expanding overseas.

site_title: Equity issuing activity and proceeds on SGX take hit in H1 (Amended)
summary: Equity fundraising on the Singapore Exchange (SGX) fell 40% year-on-year in the second quarter of 2015, with proceeds from stock sales totaling US$826.2 million. This marks a 54% decline from the first half of 2014. The real estate sector dominated equity fundraising activity, generating US$618.8 million in proceeds, while energy and power issuers accounted for 32.6%. The number of IPOs decreased, with only three listings during the period, raising US$28.4 million.

site_title: Singapore banks must move faster on digital technology
summary: Singapore banks are urged to accelerate their adoption of digital technology to stay competitive. Despite high internet penetration and mobile phone usage, some banks are slow to adopt digital trends, losing customers to non-banking players. Digital banking enables banks to reach tech-savvy customers online, reducing acquisition costs and redefining the role of physical branches. Experts warn that banks must shop where customers are online and not the other way around to remain relevant, or risk losing out completely.

site_title: Choa Chu Kang Waterworks now partly solar-powered
summary: Singapore's National water agency PUB has installed a 1 Megawatt peak solar photovoltaic system at its Choa Chu Kang Waterworks, covering nearly 70% of the plant's surface area. The system generates about 7% of the plant's average daily needs, producing 1.1 Gigawatt hours of clean energy per year. The project uses solar leasing, where the contractor bears the upfront costs of $2.3 million, and PUB pays only for the electricity consumed. The PPA will last for 20 years, with plans to deploy similar systems at other plants by 2020, aiming to reduce imported energy use by half in the next decade.

site_title: The future of intelligent automation: making businesses more agile
summary: A blended model of automation involving robots, analytics, and humans is emerging as the optimal approach for businesses, providing optimal outcomes. According to a Cognizant study, this combination extends human productivity and problem-solving capabilities, improving business results. Automation complements human work, enabling people to focus on complex tasks while robots handle repetitive and rote processes. Organizations that master smart robots and data analytics are expected to outpace rivals, driving sustainable future growth through efficiency improvements and innovation.

images.alt_text: It must be remembered that the real prize of process automation is in the explosion of rich process-level data. Analytics can help make meaning of this data and extract insights from it, which in turn can help organisations improve performance and innovate for the needs of tomorrow.

site_title: General Motors developing wireless download of new features
summary: General Motors is developing a wireless download technology for new features, dubbed "Global B", which will move computer power to the cloud and enable future cars to receive upgrades wirelessly. The company's global product development chief, Mark Reuss, announced the move, citing Tesla's successful implementation of similar technology. GM plans to deploy the new electrical and data systems soon, with the potential to increase profit margins for its vehicles. The company is also working on a low-cost vehicle for emerging markets, including India, where it faces competition from low-cost vehicles from the Renault-Nissan Alliance.

site_title: More than just performing live
summary: The T'ang Quartet, Singapore's first professional string quartet, is doing more than just performing live music. They dedicate a significant amount of time to outreach work in schools, presenting music in unique and engaging ways. The quartet has been involved in various outreach programs for about 15 years, including a recent music video shoot at Sanitorium Lake and a performance at a Woodend Winter Festival in Australia. Their dedication to bringing music to the people and connecting with them is evident in their work, which aims to educate and inspire young children about music.

site_title: Asia leads world in value of building spats
summary: Asia leads the world in construction disputes, averaging a value of US$86 million, according to Arcadis's fifth annual study. The region's average dispute value in 2014 increased by 104% from the previous year, and is nearly three times that of North America. Failure to properly administer contracts is the top reason for disputes. Asia's construction disputes are driven by large, complex projects with private financing, and the rise of joint venture agreements, which can lead to internal conflict and inflexibility in negotiations.

site_title: China's Wanda Group to buy more sports firms
summary: China's Wanda Group will acquire at least three more sports companies this year, according to Chairman Wang Jianlin. This move aims to increase the company's influence in the global sports business. Wanda has already acquired a 20% stake in Atletico Madrid and a 45 million euro share, as well as a 1.05 billion euro deal for Swiss sports marketing group Infront. The acquisitions are part of Wanda's plans to become the world number one in the sports industry, ahead of the 2022 Winter Olympics and potential 2026 football World Cup hosting bid.

site_title: East European ports hit by 2014 drop in visitors and spending
summary: East European ports experienced a 7% decline in visitor numbers and spending in 2014, the first drop in a decade, due to Americans cancelling trips to the Baltic and Mediterranean over geopolitical concerns. This decrease follows a 9% growth in the previous year. The decline was attributed to a decrease in cruise ship visits, with European ports of call seeing a 7% drop in visitor numbers.

site_title: SIA Cargo clinches award for Best Air Cargo Carrier in Asia
summary: SIA Cargo has been awarded "Best Air Cargo Carrier - Asia" by readers of Asia Cargo News in the 2015 AFLAS Awards. The airline's president, Chin Yau Seng, expressed gratitude to loyal customers and pledged to continue delivering excellent service. The award was received by Patrick Kwang, regional vice-president (North Asia), at the awards ceremony held in Hong Kong. This recognition is a testament to SIA Cargo's commitment to providing high-quality air cargo services in the Asian region.

site_title: Bordeaux wine fair fights off newcomers
summary: The Vinexpo 2015 trade fair in Bordeaux, France, drew over 48,000 attendees from 120 nationalities, featuring 2,300 wineries and wine companies. Despite its long history and reputation, the fair faces competition from other trade fairs and globalisation, which has created new centers of power in the wine industry. Producers and importers attended to reach new markets, while consumers may not see the significance of the fair. The event's emphasis on luxury and high-end wines may be part of its problem, as it struggles to adapt to a more populist and affordable wine market.

site_title: China's economy may soon have reliable data on jobs
summary: China's National Bureau of Statistics plans to launch a new, survey-based unemployment rate starting in July, aiming to provide a more accurate and reliable data on the country's largest labor market. The new rate will be based on a nationwide survey of 120,000 households, excluding migrant workers, and will be published monthly. The move is part of Premier Li Keqiang's efforts to improve employment data, which currently relies on quarterly registered urban jobless rates. The new rate is expected to provide a more accurate indicator of short-term economic fluctuations and inform macro policy decisions.

site_title: As economy loses lustre, Japanese swap gems for yen
summary: Japan's economy, struggling with aging population and stagnation, is seeing a shift in luxury goods market. Exports of used diamonds are up 77% this year, with Japan unloading unwanted jewels for cash and shipping them to China and India. This trend dovetails with Prime Minister Shinzo Abe's plan to encourage more shopping and less saving. The market for second-hand goods has expanded 10% annually since 2009, reaching 1.5 trillion yen, as people opt for simpler lives by selling luxury items.

site_title: Huge Chinese demand for Aussie homes swamps crackdown against illegal buyers
summary: Chinese demand for Australian homes is outpacing efforts to curb illegal buyers, with the government struggling to address concerns of unaffordable housing. Since announcing a crackdown in February, only one foreigner has been forced to sell. Chinese buyers already account for almost a quarter of new homes in Sydney, with their outlay expected to double to A$60 billion by 2020. The government plans to increase fines and jail time for violators, but a national register of foreign buyers remains incomplete, hindering policy evaluations.

site_title: China moves closer to 'riskiest' step with removal of loans cap
summary: China has removed a 75% cap on loans relative to deposits, a two-decade-old rule, in a move to usher in market-based economics. The change, expected to boost credit growth, may be constrained by limited demand for funds in a faltering economy. The central bank plans to monitor the loan-to-deposit ratio, and a cap on deposit rates is likely to be scrapped this year, potentially leading to excessive competition and instability in the financial system.

images.alt_text: The People's Bank of China has indicated that a cap on deposit rates is likely to be scrapped in the second half of the year.

site_title: Europe's bankers fear Brexit more than Grexit
summary: European bankers are more concerned about the possibility of Britain leaving the European Union (Brexit) than Greece exiting the euro zone (Grexit), according to a financial industry conference. The UK's inclusion in the EU is crucial to the bloc's long-term future, with bankers warning of a year of uncertainty if Britain were to leave. Meanwhile, last-ditch talks in Brussels aim to keep Greece solvent and avoid a potential exit from the euro zone, with creditors holding out for billions of euros in bailout funds.

images.alt_text: Mr Cameron has promised to renegotiate Britain's relationship with the EU

site_title: Swiss franc falls on SNB warning shot; euro stays flat
summary: The Swiss franc fell to a 10-day low against the euro after the head of the Swiss National Bank warned that the currency was "considerably over-valued" and would continue to intervene in currency markets. The euro remained flat against the dollar. Analysts expect a weaker euro if a Greek deal is reached, driven by ultra-loose monetary policy in the eurozone and US interest rates moving higher.

site_title: Google expands its reach with 14th data centre
summary: Google has opened its 14th data centre in Alabama, repurposing a former coal-fired power plant. The facility, Google's seventh in the US, is expected to bring in alternative power from the Tennessee Valley Authority (TVA). The company claims to be reducing its energy usage per search, citing a 3.5 times increase in computing power from the same amount of energy over the past three years. This move aligns with Google's efforts to promote renewable power, with the company now using 1.5% of US wind power capacity.

site_title: Singtel performance shares: what's the moratorium?
summary: Singtel's chairman, Simon Israel, addressed concerns about the company's CEO pay structure. He mentioned a long-term incentive scheme in the form of performance shares, which appear to be awarded once a year. However, Israel did not provide details on how long these performance shares need to be held before they can be sold in the open market. This lack of transparency has raised questions about the moratorium on selling these shares.

site_title: S Korea announces US$14b package to boost growth
summary: South Korea announced a US$14 billion stimulus package to boost its economy, which is being weighed down by the deadly Mers outbreak, which has killed 29 people and infected 151. The package aims to contain the effects of the outbreak, prop up growth, support exports, and create jobs. The finance ministry slashed its growth forecast for this year to 3.1 per cent, citing risks from the global economic recovery, a weak yen, and euro, as well as rising household debt. The government will issue bonds to fund the extra budget and encourage corporate restructuring.

site_title: Cheap, China-made drug gains following in Florida
summary: Cheap, China-made synthetic drug "flakka" or Alpha-PVP has killed dozens in Florida, particularly in Broward County. Manufactured in China, it's sold online for $1,500 per kilogram, making it accessible to vulnerable populations. The drug, which can cause heart trouble, aggression, and psychosis, has been linked to 34 deaths since its appearance in September. Authorities attribute its widespread availability to its integration into existing distribution lines for other similar drugs. The low price and ease of online purchase have made it a lucrative business, with Chinese companies openly advertising and mailing the substance to customers.

site_title: Directors' gift to nation and charities
summary: Seven prominent Singaporean directors, including Boo Junfeng and Eric Khoo, have collaborated on a film project called "7 Letters" with all proceeds going to charity. The film, comprising seven segments, will premiere at the Capitol Theatre in July and will have three matinee screenings sponsored by corporations for senior citizens and underprivileged students. The directors, who worked on the project during their free time, aim to raise funds for several charities, including the Alzheimer's Disease Association and the Movement for the Intellectually Disabled of Singapore.

images.alt_text: Dylan Tan

site_title: The new economic indicator: beer sales
summary: Beer sales are emerging as a new economic indicator, particularly in developing Asian nations. Despite economic slowdowns, beer consumption is surging in countries like China, Brazil, and Myanmar, driven by rising incomes and younger populations. Chinese brands now dominate the global beer market, with Snow and Tsingtao among the top 10. However, rising taxes, restrictions, and economic challenges may impact beer sales in countries like Indonesia and Malaysia, with the World Bank forecasting slower growth for these nations this year.

site_title: 6 Singapore firms make it to Forbes Asia's 'Best Under a Billion' list
summary: Six Singapore firms have made it to Forbes Asia's "Best Under a Billion" list, recognizing 200 public companies with annual revenue of up to US$1 billion for consistent growth. The six Singapore companies include NTT DC Reit, Creative Technology, and others, exceeding the three companies listed in 2014.

images.alt_text: Mindy Tan

site_title: CRYPTIC CROSSWORD
summary: A cryptic crossword puzzle was published on June 25, 2015, featuring Across clues such as "Awakening of love in Laura's unexpected" and "Tommy's upset about parking warning sign".

site_title: North Korea's 'landmark' airport terminal to open on July 1
summary: North Korea's new airport terminal, built at the leader Kim Jong-un's whim, is set to open on July 1, according to state media. The Terminal 2 at Pyongyang International Airport was partly demolished and rebuilt during a recent tour led by Kim Jong-un, his wife Ri Sol-ju, and sister Kim Yo-jong. The grand opening is seen as a showcase of the country's development, despite reports of significant costs and potential delays.

site_title: Citigroup ascends league table as M&A drives fees in Middle East
summary: Citigroup has taken the top spot in Middle East investment banking fees, more than quadrupling its income to $27.5 million in the first five months of 2015. The surge in mergers and acquisitions, driven by regional sovereign wealth funds, has helped the US bank surpass competitors such as Qatar National Bank and Abu Dhabi Islamic Bank. M&A fees in the region rose 13% to $317 million, the highest since 2013, with Citigroup earning $22 million from deals. The bank expects "a lot more" M&A activity this year.

site_title: City buzz
summary: The Singapore International Festival of Arts pre-festival OPEN is showing for three nights only, featuring "The Imagination of the Future" and "Another Country". "The Imagination of the Future" is a what-if scenario imagining a Chilean president resisting the 1973 coup, while "Another Country" dramatizes writings by Singapore and Malaysian authors. Meanwhile, new pizzerias Baker & Cook and Spizza Mercato have opened, offering unique pizza experiences. The Her World Golf Challenge 2015 returns with a Mad Hatter theme, and online wine specialty store wanderwine offers sommelier-curated wines with tasting notes and food-pairing recommendations.

site_title: 2 sitcoms set to tickle viewers
summary: Two new HBO sitcoms, Ballers and The Brink, are set to premiere, featuring former WWE wrestler Dwayne "The Rock" Johnson in Ballers and Oscar winner Tim Robbins and Jack Black in The Brink. The Brink shows more promise in its pilot episode, offering a bit more accessibility and potential. Both comedies are expected to bring a cinematic feel to television, with Ballers starring Johnson and The Brink boasting a strong cast. The Brink has more potential and is considered a promising addition to HBO's lineup.

images.alt_text: Dylan Tan

site_title: Soft market, global leadership changes at Colliers see more talents leave for rivals
summary: Colliers International has experienced a series of departures from its retail team, with four members joining JLL's retail agency team, following a spate of resignations from industrial-services and office-services teams. The departures are attributed to a soft market and instability stemming from leadership changes at the global level. Colliers' managing director, Dennis Yeo, and Gary Nonis, who is moving to JLL, deny it's a case of poaching, citing the weak market and competition for expertise.

site_title: Wilmar books shipment for its record sugar deal
summary: Wilmar International Ltd has booked shipments for almost all 1.9 million tonnes of sugar it purchased for $550 million, marking the biggest ever exchange deal. The company expects to call on sellers to load remaining tonnage this week, potentially restoring calm to the sugar market. Prices remain near six-and-a-half-year lows due to a fifth straight surplus year. The bookings may alleviate concerns of cancellation and stashed sugar, but traders remain wary of weak demand and low prices.

site_title: US on track to grow 2.1% in second quarter: Atlanta Fed
summary: The US economy is expected to expand 2.1% in the second quarter, according to the Atlanta Federal Reserve's GDPNow forecast model. This is a slight increase from the prior estimate of 2.0% and is driven by stronger consumer spending and income in May. The forecast for real consumption in the second quarter has been revised to 3.0% from 2.9%.

site_title: Scope may exist to review oversight roles of Singapore exchanges: MAS
summary: MAS and Singapore Exchange (SGX) are reviewing oversight roles to reduce overlaps between the two entities amid increasing industry competition. MAS managing director Ong Chong Tee said the regulator is open to improving arrangements to help remisiers adapt to all-day trading and gathering feedback from stakeholders. The MAS and SGX will hold dialogue sessions to improve the country's capital markets, addressing issues such as quality listings, minimum trading prices, and customer suitability assessment.

site_title: Europe: Stocks finish mixed
summary: Europe's main markets finished mixed on Thursday, with London's FTSE 100 index falling 0.54% and the eurozone's CAC 40 slipping 0.07%. In contrast, Frankfurt's DAX 30 edged up 0.02%. The mixed performance was attributed to gains in mining and healthcare shares, while US-EU trade talks took center stage.

site_title: Why small booms cause big busts
summary: A relatively small boom in the housing market from 2002 to 2006 led to a massive economic crisis, with the US economy being 6% smaller than expected, resulting in $1.8 trillion in lost production annually. A study by Òscar Jordà, Moritz Schularick, and Alan M Taylor found that large credit booms exacerbate the damage caused by asset bubble collapses. This is in line with John Maynard Keynes' views, who believed that the problem lies in clogged credit channels, not just high investment levels. Keynes proposed a fix, but current policy options are limited due to fiscal austerity and inflation targets.

site_title: Bank of China in US$3.55b multi-currency landmark deal
summary: Bank of China has issued a US$3.55 billion multi-currency bond, dubbed the "Silk Road" bond, in honor of China's "One Belt, One Road" initiative. The bond includes a S$500 million tranche, the largest-ever SGD senior unsecured bond issued by a commercial bank in Singapore. The deal attracted over US$13 billion in orders and was oversubscribed 5.6 times for the 10-year US dollar bonds. The Bank of China Singapore branch listed both bonds on the Singapore Exchange to commemorate Singapore's 50 years of independence.

site_title: Whole Foods accused of overcharging in NY stores
summary: Whole Foods Market in New York has been accused by the city's Department of Consumer Affairs of overstating the weight of prepackaged products sold in its stores. Tests of 80 products found all were labelled with erroneous weights, resulting in customers being overcharged an average of $2.50 for a vegetable platter and $4.13 for chicken tenders. Whole Foods plans to fight the fines, claiming they are "excessive." The company has previously paid an $800,000 fine in California for similar allegations.

site_title: Oil prices slip as Greece and Iran rattle market
summary: Oil prices fell on Thursday as concerns over Greek debt negotiations and potential sanctions easing on Iran overshadowed strong US demand figures. Brent crude oil traded within a narrow range, influenced by a weak physical crude market in the Atlantic Basin and reports of healthier demand for gasoline and diesel in the US and Europe. The risk of a downside for oil prices remains, with Greece's debt talks and Iran's nuclear negotiations potentially affecting European oil demand and supply.

site_title: STI lethargy mirrors Greece deadlock
summary: The Singapore stock market mirrored the eurozone's Greece deadlock, with the Straits Times Index (STI) slipping 1.46 points to 3,349.87. Despite regional indices suffering losses of up to 3.5%, the STI remained relatively stable, with turnover at 1.26 billion shares worth S$940 million. The local market's inactivity reflects the eurozone's apparent impasse over Greece's bailout proposal, with a June 30 deadline for debt repayment looming.

site_title: Achieving a robust and vibrant securities market
summary: The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) and Singapore Exchange (SGX) have introduced new measures to strengthen the securities market, aiming to achieve a robust and vibrant market where companies can raise capital efficiently, investors can pursue their objectives, and intermediaries can serve their customers' needs effectively. The measures include improving the quality of listings, enhancing investor protection, and strengthening enforcement. The MAS also plans to adapt to a changing landscape, with technology providing real-time access to local and international markets, and brokerages firms and remisiers needing to upgrade their services.

images.alt_text: SGX has introduced several measures to improve the quality of listings, including raising the entry bar for companies seeking to list on the mainboard.

site_title: EU lifts safety ban on all Philippine airlines
summary: The European Union (EU) has removed all Philippine airlines from its safety blacklist, lifting a ban on flying into European airspace. The decision comes after a positive review of the airlines by a five-man EU safety assessment team following inspections in April. The seven remaining Philippine carriers, including budget airlines, can now operate in European airspace, potentially boosting tourism and flights to Europe. Flag carrier Philippine Airlines and Cebu Pacific have already been cleared to fly to European destinations, with PAL planning to add more.

site_title: EU capital markets plan must protect investors better: UK watchdog
summary: The European Union's Capital Markets Union (CMU) plan needs more work to protect investors and achieve its economic goals, according to the UK's Financial Conduct Authority. The plan aims to develop Europe's capital markets, which are less developed than in the US, but critics say it may take years and could be hindered by barriers to non-EU countries. Experts warn that the plan could be used to unpick new regulation and that victory must not be declared too soon, with some arguing that it needs to focus on increasing long-term savings.

site_title: Lives of devadasi women interpreted through choreography
summary: French play "The Maids" inspires Indian dancers Navtej Johar and Lokesh Bharadwaj to create "Frenemies," a dance piece commenting on socio-religious issues in India, particularly the lives of devadasi women. Devadasi women, from the "untouchable" class, dedicate their lives to temple worship, often in exchange for wealth and power. The new work, blending dance, yoga, and theatre, explores power and subjugation, wealth and poverty, and how devadasi women navigate their complex relationships with patrons and the elite classes.

images.alt_text: Johar (left) and Bhardwaj reinterpret Jean Genet's classic play The Maids as a contemporary Indian dance in Frenemies, showing next week at the OPEN festival.
Helmi Yusof

site_title: Sugar exports from India seen doubling
summary: India is expected to double its sugar exports to 2 million tonnes in the 12 months starting October 1, driven by a record crop and a surplus that will force producers to ship as much as possible. The glut threatens to extend a 35% slump in New York futures, and the government has approved interest-free loans and subsidies to help mills clear debt and export excess sugar. Prices have fallen to a seven-year low due to weak demand and mounting stockpiles, leaving the industry with no alternative but to incur losses.

site_title: Dubai ready for drop in home prices
summary: Dubai's real estate market is expected to experience a 10-20% drop in home prices this year due to oversupply, lower oil prices, and weaker currencies. Analysts attribute this to the emirate's recent history of rapid price growth, which was fueled by speculation and lax lending regulations. However, developers and lenders are better prepared this time, with reduced reliance on speculation and increased dependence on rental income. The government has implemented measures to curb price increases, and the rental market remains stable, with demand expected to remain strong.

site_title: Ensemble cast breathes new life into old movies
summary: A trio of upcoming Singaporean films, Our Sister Mambo, 1965, and 7 Letters, will pay tribute to the country and its people through unique storytelling. Our Sister Mambo, a family comedy, features a star-studded cast, including Moses Lim, Audrey Luo, and Michelle Chong, and is set to celebrate Cathay's 80th anniversary. The films mark Cathay's first production in 16 years and aim to honor the studio's legacy, with director Michael Chiang drawing inspiration from classic Cathay movies.

site_title: Citigroup combines retail banking and mortgage operations
summary: Citigroup has combined its retail banking and mortgage operations under Jonathan Larsen, who will oversee both divisions. Larsen also holds the position of head of consumer banking for Asia. Fabio Fontainha, the head of consumer banking in Brazil, will assume additional responsibility for consumer banking in Latin America. This reorganization aims to streamline operations and enhance efficiency.

site_title: US: Wall St opens higher as data suggests recovery
summary: US stocks opened higher on Thursday as data on rising consumer spending and a tightening labor market suggested a recovery in the economy. The Dow Jones industrial average rose 0.39%, the S&P 500 gained 0.3%, and the Nasdaq Composite added 0.37%. These gains follow previous record-breaking performances, with the S&P 500 and Nasdaq reaching fresh records despite ongoing trade tensions.

site_title: Boeing to further slow 747 production in 2016
summary: Boeing plans to slow 747 production by 23% to one 747 per month starting in March, citing sluggish demand for the iconic plane. The move follows a 13% reduction in its long-range forecast for large wide-body aircraft and only 32 orders on its books for the 747. Despite recent commitments from airlines, Boeing expects "overcapacity of freighters in the market" to prompt the production slowdown. The decision aims to keep the production line running amid reduced demand for the 747, which costs around $370 million at list price.

site_title: AirAsia CEO casts other work aside amid accounting worries
summary: AirAsia CEO Tony Fernandes has committed to spending more time on repairing the airline's financial damage amid a report questioning the company's accounts, causing its share price to drop 24% since June 10. Fernandes and his long-term business partner Kamarudin Meranun will take a more hands-on approach to addressing the issues, according to analysts. The airline's worst-performing year to date, AirAsia faces increased competition and a crash of an Airbus jet that killed 162 people in December. Despite concerns, analysts believe Fernandes is the best person to turn the airline around, citing its strong route network and brand recognition.

site_title: US services sector growth slows in June: Markit
summary: US services sector growth slowed for a third consecutive month in June, according to a report by Markit, with the Purchasing Managers Index falling to 54.8 from 56.2 in May. New business and hiring rates also eased, with new business at service companies at 55 and the composite PMI at 54.6. This marks the smallest rise in service sector activity since January and the slowest growth in factory output in over a year and a half.

site_title: ABS to start charging for Sibor and SOR data from Oct 1
summary: Singapore's ABS Benchmarks Administration Co (ABS Co) will start charging for Sibor and SOR data from October 1, with monthly fees ranging from US$1,500 to US$5,000. Subscribers will be charged a monthly usage fee, while those receiving real-time data will have to pay end-user fees of US$5. The exemptions include Sibor panel banks and third-party redistributors. The move aims to strengthen the robustness, transparency, and efficiency of the benchmark contribution process in Singapore.

site_title: Different generations, same people
summary: The article discusses the experiences of Baby Boomers, born after World War II, and how they have lived through three generations. They were characterized by limited technology and international exposure, but have tried to catch up. Generation X, born in the 60s and 70s, experienced emerging global communications and business, but were mostly left to their own devices. This generation is now in leadership positions, with accumulated wealth putting a strain on family units. The article contrasts the views of these generations, with Baby Boomers respecting their parents and Generation X being more insular.

site_title: IMF says 'on same page' with Europeans on Greece
summary: The International Monetary Fund (IMF) is "on the same page" with European creditors on Greece's negotiations, with discussions on debt sustainability and financing to wait until key reforms are implemented. IMF spokesman Gerry Rice emphasized the need for a balanced approach, requiring Greece to agree and implement reforms in exchange for financing and debt sustainability. The IMF had previously insisted on debt relief, but now appears closer to the euro zone's position, which does not discuss debt restructuring until after Greece completes its bailout program.

site_title: UK retail sales growth eases in June from five-month peak: CBI
summary: UK retail sales growth slowed to a 29-point balance in June, down from a five-month high of 51 in May, driven mainly by a decline in the grocery sector. Despite the slowdown, retailers remain optimistic for the summer season. The CBI survey also reported a decrease in expected sales for the next month, although a three-month moving average showed a new high.

site_title: Malaysia says no electricity tariff hike for second half of 2015
summary: Malaysia's Ministry of Energy, Green Technology and Water announced that it will not raise electricity tariffs for the rest of 2015. This decision comes after the last tariff hike in January 2014, when oil prices were at US$110 a barrel. The government cited efforts to boost its fiscal position by cutting subsidies. The decision was made despite a recent increase in oil prices to US$63.59 a barrel.

site_title: ECB holds emergency funding for Greek banks steady: source
summary: The European Central Bank (ECB) has maintained the emergency funding limit for Greek banks at around 89 billion euros, marking the second consecutive day of unchanged decision. This decision was made by the ECB's Governing Council via a telephone conference.

site_title: Stamford Tyres' FY15 net profit drops 83% to S$1.7m on price pressures, one-offs
summary: Stamford Tyres' FY15 net profit plummeted 83% to S$1.7m due to pricing pressure and one-offs, despite a 0.7% revenue increase to S$292.5m. The company cut its dividend to 1c per share from 1.5c and expects a challenging operating environment due to an uncertain global economic outlook. Gross profit slipped 2.6% to S$64.5m.

site_title: Eurogroup talks end with no deal, likely to meet again Saturday
summary: Eurozone finance ministers' talks on a Greek debt deal ended without an agreement, with leaders likely to meet again on Saturday. The talks, which included Greek Prime Minister Alexis Tsipras and EU-IMF officials, failed to reach a breakthrough, producing two rival texts. Eurogroup head Alexander Stubb said the institutions would continue work, but no deal was reached. The impasse comes ahead of a summit of all 28 EU leaders, with Tsipras expressing confidence in reaching a compromise.

site_title: US consumer spending posts largest gain in nearly six years
summary: US consumer spending increased 0.9% in May, the largest gain in nearly six years, driven by strong demand for automobiles and other big-ticket items. This upward revision from April's 0.1% increase suggests households are spending down savings from lower gasoline prices. The solid economic reports cap a month of positive economic indicators, indicating economic growth momentum in the second quarter.

site_title: US jobless claims rise; four-week average falls
summary: US jobless claims rose 3,000 to 271,000 for the week ended June 20, the Labor Department reported. This marked the 16th consecutive week of claims below 300,000, indicating a tightening labor market. The four-week average of claims fell, suggesting labor market conditions are improving.

site_title: Frasers Hospitality Trust to raise up to S$123m by selling 150m new stapled securities
summary: Frasers Hospitality Trust plans to raise up to S$123 million by issuing 150 million new stapled securities at 81-82 Singapore cents apiece to fund its acquisition of Sofitel Sydney Wentworth. The offering represents 12.5% of existing issued units. Existing security holders will receive an advanced distribution of 2.1 Singapore cents per security before the new securities are issued. TCC Hospitality will take a proportionate stake in the new securities to maintain its interest in the Trust. The manager will declare the distribution to existing holders from April 1 to July 5, 2015.

site_title: Opec petroleum exports fall below US$1t in 2014 on oil slump
summary: Opec's petroleum exports fell below $1 trillion in 2014, the first time since 2010, due to the oil price slump. The value of exports dropped to $964.6 billion from $1.10 trillion in 2013, according to Opec's Annual Statistical Bulletin. This decline illustrates the impact of the oil price drop on the producer group. The data includes crude oil, refined fuel, and light oil condensate.

site_title: Noble's share buyback spree continues
summary: NOBLE Group, a commodities trader, announced its seventh share buyback this month, totaling S$93.5 million for 134.2 million shares, averaging S$0.70 apiece. The company's stock recovered 2.8% on the announcement, bringing its total repurchase this month to S$93.5 million. Noble's shares have been under pressure since February due to concerns over accounting practices and a weak commodities outlook. Analysts, including OCBC Investment Research, see the recent buybacks as providing support for the stock, but maintain a "somewhat muted" outlook for the medium term.

images.alt_text: Noble Group on Thursday announced its seventh share buyback the day before, bringing its total repurchase this month to S$93.5 million for some 134.2 million shares, averaging close to S$0.70 apiece.

site_title: Top consumer brands pledge to halve food waste by 2025
summary: The world's top consumer brands, including Unilever and Nestle, have pledged to halve food waste by 2025, aiming to prevent government regulation and address environmental, economic, and social costs. The pledge follows similar initiatives by governments and companies globally, with the European Commission proposing a 30% reduction by 2025. Food waste is estimated to be worth US$750 billion, equivalent to 3.3 billion tonnes of greenhouse gases released into the atmosphere annually.

site_title: Pimco says Greece accord near, debt restructuring should follow
summary: Pimco expects Greece to resolve its financial aid standoff with creditors, but investors may need to take losses on their debt holdings. A possible agreement could involve stretching debt maturity to 60 years, and would be followed by a discount on Greek securities. Prime Minister Alexis Tsipras is meeting with creditors in Brussels, with a June 30 deadline looming. Pimco's "baseline scenario" suggests a last-minute agreement, but geopolitical risks, including the conflict in Ukraine and Islamic State militants, could destabilize the eurozone.

site_title: Wilmar calls up boats for almost all record ICE sugar delivery
summary: Wilmar International Ltd has booked spots on vessels for almost all 1.9 million tonnes of sugar it bought in a record $550 million exchange deal. The company expects to call on sellers to load the remaining 100,000 tonnes this week. This move comes as traders worry about weak demand and low prices, but Wilmar remains committed to its sugar delivery.

site_title: ECB's Smets says QE is showing positive results
summary: The European Central Bank's (ECB) quantitative easing (QE) programme is showing positive results, according to ECB governing council member Jan Smets. Launched in March, the programme aims to inject 1 trillion euros into the eurozone economy, creating macroeconomic stability and addressing imbalances. Without the programme, the eurozone risked further deflation, but with it, the risk is reduced. Smets warned that low interest rates can lead to excessive risk-taking, but emphasized the programme's effectiveness in supporting financial stability.

images.alt_text: The European Central Bank's bond buying programme is working and has had positive effects on the economy, ECB governing council member Jan Smets said on Thursday.

site_title: AIIB agreement to be signed next week
summary: Representatives of 57 prospective founding countries of the Asian Infrastructure Investment Bank (AIIB) will meet in Beijing next week to sign an agreement of the bank. The AIIB aims to finance infrastructure construction in the continent, with authorized capital of $100 billion and initial subscribed capital expected to be around $50 billion. The signing is seen as a significant step towards the bank's establishment, which will provide financing for infrastructure projects in the region.

site_title: Many big companies live in fear for their future in digital age
summary: Big companies are concerned about their future in the digital age as small start-ups with innovative business models and new technologies threaten to disrupt established industries. A survey of 941 business leaders found that four out of 10 top-ranked companies worldwide may not survive the next five years. Industries such as hospitality, media, retail, and financial services are most at risk, while sectors like pharmaceuticals and utilities are less likely to be disrupted. Digital threats come from companies like Tesla, Uber, and Airbnb, and are driving mergers, corporate venture funding, and changes in business models.

site_title: Thailand says it will invest US$71m in economic zones this year
summary: Thailand plans to invest US$71 million in six special economic zones this year, aiming to boost cross-border trade. The zones, located in six provinces, will receive funding for 35 projects. The government has announced special tax exemptions for investors in the zones. This move is part of the government's efforts to strengthen trade and economic growth, following weak trade performance.

site_title: Hong Kong authority rejects application by low cost carrier Jetstar
summary: Hong Kong's Air Transport Licensing Authority rejected Jetstar Hong Kong Airways Ltd's application to operate scheduled air services, citing the carrier's principal place of business not being in Hong Kong. The decision was made after considering objections from existing airlines and a public inquiry. Jetstar, backed by Qantas, China Eastern, and Shun Tak Holdings, had applied for a licence two years prior. The authority found that Jetstar did not meet the basic law requirement, leading to the application's refusal.

site_title: ECB limits funding lifeline for Athens amid Bundesbank protest: sources
summary: The European Central Bank limited emergency funding for Greece's banks for the second day, amid protests from the Bundesbank's President Jens Weidmann, who expressed concerns about providing continued support. Weidmann warned against using emergency credit to prop up Greece's banks, which have seen their reserves dwindle. This move increases pressure on the Greek government to agree on a cash-for-reforms deal with creditors to avoid a default. The decision raises concerns about the stability of Greece's banking sector, which is now reliant on the Emergency Liquidity Assistance (ELA) funding.

site_title: Singapore Wrap Thursday
summary: Six Singapore companies have made it to Forbes Asia's "Best Under a Billion" list, three more than in 2014. Meanwhile, a US$3.55 billion multi-currency deal was announced by Bank of China, with a S$500 million tranche. Other notable news includes Vietnam's surprise reaction to US tariffs, China's slowing GDP growth, and the UK economy's contraction for the second consecutive month.

site_title: Oil steadies as stronger demand balances glut
summary: Crude oil prices steadied above $60 a barrel as strong demand for oil products balanced a global glut. US gasoline demand reached its highest seasonal level since 1991, while US crude stocks declined for the eighth straight week. Analysts expect further economic growth in the US, which would boost demand for oil. UBS raised its 2015 Brent crude price forecast to $61.50 per barrel and 2016 forecasts to $70 per barrel. The market remains cautious amid weak physical crude markets and reports of unsold oil cargoes.

site_title: Greece, creditors say still no deal ahead of eurozone meeting
summary: Greece and its EU-IMF creditors are set to submit rival proposals to end a five-month debt row ahead of a eurozone finance ministers' meeting. Despite a meeting between Greek Prime Minister Alexis Tsipras and creditor officials, no deal was reached, leaving ministers to consider the proposals. The proposals are seen as a basis for discussion, but a senior eurozone official stated there is no answer yet, leaving Greece at risk of default and potential exit from the eurozone. The IMF payment deadline looms on June 30, with Greece needing to unlock the remaining €7.2 billion of its bailout.

site_title: Hong Kong regulator opposes proposal to allow dual-class shares
summary: Hong Kong's Securities and Futures Commission opposes a plan by Hong Kong Exchanges & Clearing Ltd to allow dual-class shares. The regulator stated that there is no assurance a company would treat its shareholders fairly. The proposal, which sparked opposition from major investors, including Blackrock and Li Ka-shing, is effectively killed. The decision is a result of regulators rejecting the governance structure of Alibaba last year, prompting the Chinese e-commerce company to turn to the US for an IPO.

site_title: China reveals misuse of US$2.7b in lottery funds
summary: China's National Audit Office has uncovered widespread misappropriation of $2.7 billion in lottery funds, with 16.9 billion yuan misused for office buildings, hotels, and embezzlement. The irregularities account for a quarter of total lottery funds received in the 2012-2014 investigation, spanning 18 provinces. The lottery market has boomed in China, with 17 provinces flouting laws by selling lottery tickets online without approval, and 32 shops using 3.1 billion yuan to construct office buildings. The misappropriation comes as President Xi Jinping's government wages a fight against corruption.

site_title: Nomura CEO's compensation tops 300 million yen for first time
summary: Nomura Holdings Inc. CEO Koji Nagai's compensation exceeded 300 million yen for the first time, reaching 328 million yen, a 10% increase from the previous year. This is the first time a Nomura executive's compensation has surpassed 300 million yen since the company started disclosing the information in 2010. The surge in profit is attributed to a stock-market rally, which has boosted asset-management fees and brokerage commissions. Nagai's total pay includes a base salary of 102 million yen, stock options, cash bonuses, and deferred bonuses.

site_title: Europe's bankers fear Brexit more than Grexit
summary: European bankers prioritize the potential UK exit from the EU (Brexit) over Greece's possible departure from the euro zone (Grexit). Britain's inclusion in the EU is crucial for the bloc's long-term future, with bankers citing the UK's significant economic importance. Despite ongoing bailout talks for Greece, bankers believe the UK's exit would have a greater impact on the European economy. British Prime Minister David Cameron has promised to renegotiate the UK's relationship with the EU, with a vote on its future by the end of 2017.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks end down 0.95%
summary: Hong Kong stocks ended 0.95% lower, following global market losses, amid Greece's debt reform talks collapse, sparking fears of default and eurozone exit. The Hang Seng Index fell 259.22 points to 27,145.75 on HK$118.54 billion turnover.

site_title: Vietnam approves controversial US$16b mega airport
summary: Vietnam's National Assembly approved a US$16 billion mega airport project near Ho Chi Minh City, with 86% of lawmakers in favor. The Long Thanh airport aims to serve 100 million passengers and 5 million tonnes of cargo annually by 2050, easing congestion in the business hub. The 40km-long airport will be built around 25 miles from the city, positioning Vietnam to become one of the world's busiest aviation hubs.

site_title: Business trusts' average dividend yield rises to 7.1%
summary: Business trusts on the Singapore Exchange have seen an average dividend yield rise to 7.1%, up from 6.9% in May. The 10 listed trusts have a combined market capitalization of S$14.3 billion and average price-earnings ratio of 12.7, with price gains of 5.1% and dividend-boosted returns of 9.2% this year. The best performers include First Ship Lease Trust, Keppel Infrastructure Trust, and Ascendas India Trust, with one-year average dividend-adjusted returns of 18.5%.

site_title: China lending tweak shifts emphasis to quality from quantity
