summary: China has proposed scrapping the 75% limit on banks' lending at 75% of deposits, aiming to boost investment and economic growth. The move is expected to benefit smaller banks and private businesses, potentially encouraging them to support innovation and new start-ups. The reform is part of a broader effort to rebalance funding costs and reduce short-term speculation, following previous easing moves that failed to spur investment. The change is still pending approval, but is seen as a step towards a market-based financial system and improved monetary policy transmission.

site_title: SNB's Jordan says base case is that Greece remains in euro
summary: Switzerland's central bank chairman Thomas Jordan stated that the base case is Greece remaining in the eurozone despite the country's debt crisis. Jordan also expressed hope for a US interest rate hike as soon as possible and plans to maintain negative interest rates and intervene in currency markets to keep the Swiss franc from appreciating. The SNB's negative interest rate policy will be adjusted based on the international situation. Jordan's comments come as the global economy faces various challenges, including the US, China, and the UK's economic slowdown.

site_title: China's US$46b Aussie home blitz swamps crackdown
summary: China's surge in demand for Australian homes is overwhelming the government's efforts to curb illegal purchases, with Chinese buyers accounting for almost a quarter of new homes in Sydney. Despite a crackdown, only one foreigner has been forced to sell, and a national register of buyers' citizenship remains incomplete. The government plans to increase fines and jail time for violators, but experts warn that the market may be nearing a bubble due to high prices and slowing growth.

images.alt_text: Surging Chinese demand for Australian homes is dwarfing efforts to root out illegal buyers as the government struggles to avert a backlash against unaffordable housing.

site_title: Hong Kong regulator slams exchange's proposal to change listing rules
summary: Hong Kong's Securities and Futures Commission (SFC) has unanimously rejected a proposal by Hong Kong Exchanges and Clearing Ltd (HKEx) to change the city's listing rules, which gave equal voting rights to shareholders. The rule change led to the loss of the $25 billion Alibaba Group IPO last year. The SFC stated its opposition to the proposal, citing concerns about its potential impact on the market.

site_title: Asia FX pessimism eases on slow US rate hike view
summary: Asia FX sentiment improved in the last two weeks due to a slower-than-expected US interest rate hike view and hopes for a Greek debt deal. Long positions in the Chinese yuan, Indian rupee, and Singapore dollar rose, while short positions in the Malaysian ringgit, South Korean won, and Indonesian rupiah declined. Despite this, most regional currencies remained in bearish territory due to solid US economic data and expectations of future rate hikes.

site_title: Philippine central bank cuts 2015, 2016 inflation estimates
summary: The Philippine central bank has revised its inflation estimates for 2015 and 2016, cutting projections to 2.1% and 2.5% respectively, citing slower economic growth and steady food supply. The benchmark interest rate remains steady at 4.0% for the sixth consecutive meeting.

site_title: S&P says discontinues rating of China developer Kaisa
summary: Standard & Poor's (S&P) has discontinued its ratings for China developer Kaisa Group Holdings Ltd. due to insufficient and timely information on the company's credit quality. Kaisa is unlikely to restore normal operations in the near term, with ongoing debt restructuring negotiations and frozen projects. The company missed interest payments on senior notes in March 2015, leading to a downgrade of its ratings. S&P's decision reflects concerns about Kaisa's ability to regain customer and business partner confidence after default.

site_title: Cameron steps up EU renegotiation as UK business asks to stay
summary: British Prime Minister David Cameron will step up EU renegotiation efforts, meeting with EU leaders to outline his proposals on Thursday. Business leaders, including Richard Branson and Martin Sorrell, have urged Cameron to remain in the EU, citing it as "overwhelmingly in Britain's interest." Cameron aims to protect British sovereignty, reduce regulation, and ensure fair treatment for non-eurozone countries while preserving the single market. He plans to call a referendum on EU membership by the end of 2017, seeking to convince voters of real change.

site_title: China to merge 3 cargo airlines to create Asia leader: Xinhua
summary: China plans to merge its three largest cargo airlines, Air China's freight arm, China Cargo Airlines, and China Southern Airlines Cargo, to create the Asia's largest air cargo operator. The merger is currently being actively pushed by the Civil Aviation Administration of China, with the goal of building a single entity. The combined airline will surpass existing cargo carriers in the region, solidifying China's position as a major player in the air cargo market.

site_title: Singapore shares close flat on Thursday
summary: Singapore shares ended unchanged on Thursday, mirroring an impasse in the eurozone over Greece's bailout. The Straits Times Index dropped 1.46 points to 3,349.87, but was supported by local banks. The index had previously surged 0.4% on Wednesday, driven by investors' optimism despite tariff uncertainty and split Fed views.

site_title: Toyota, Nissan to recall more than 3m more cars over airbag
summary: Toyota and Nissan are recalling over 3 million cars globally due to airbag concerns linked to explosions that have caused eight deaths worldwide. Toyota will recall 2.86 million vehicles, while Nissan will recall 198,000 units. The defect is thought to be linked to a chemical propellant that can cause airbags to deploy explosively. The recalls are part of a global crisis sparked by airbags made by Japanese parts maker Takata, which has recalled over 30 million vehicles worldwide.

site_title: South Korea hospitals to monitor emergency room visitors in battle on Mers
summary: South Korea has ordered hospitals to track all emergency ward visitors amid the Mers outbreak, after difficulties in tracing exposed individuals led to a large number of cases. The country has reported 29 deaths and 77 ongoing cases, with most fatalities among elderly patients or those with pre-existing illnesses. To address the issue, hospitals must now record all patients, family members, ambulance workers, and visitors, in an effort to prevent further spread of the disease.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares end lower
summary: Malaysia's Kuala Lumpur Composite Index fell 14.87 points to 1,716.81, closing lower. Trading volume reached 1.65 billion lots, valued at RM2.08 billion. The decline was largely attributed to the market's reaction to global economic developments, including the ongoing US-EU trade talks and rising tariff uncertainty.

site_title: Gold ticks up from 2-week low as market eyes Greece
summary: Gold prices rose 0.2% to $1,176.80 an ounce, rebounding from a two-week low, amid uncertainty over Greece's debt negotiations. Investors await news on talks with international lenders to avert a default. A stronger dollar and expectations of a US interest rate increase also weigh on gold prices. The US Federal Reserve's potential rate hike is seen as a major factor, as higher rates lift the opportunity cost of holding non-yielding bullion.

site_title: Alibaba affiliate launches Internet bank for SMEs, "little guys"
summary: Alibaba's financial affiliate, MYbank, launched an internet bank for small- and medium-sized Chinese enterprises, offering loans of up to 5 million yuan. MYbank has 4 billion yuan of registered capital and aims to provide affordable loans to "little guys." The bank is 30% owned by Ant Financial Services Group and will only accept deposits when facial recognition technology is approved, allowing customers to remotely open bank accounts. MYbank's goal is to serve small businesses, not the wealthy, and provide banking services to those who struggle to obtain credit from major financial institutions.

site_title: Europe: Shares fall further on Greek worries, H&M down
summary: European shares fell for a second straight session due to concerns over a Greek debt default, with the pan-European FTSEurofirst 300 index down 0.5% at 1,569.82 points. Euro zone finance ministers accused Greece of refusing to compromise, despite a deadline next week that could put it on a path out of the euro zone. H&M fell 2.2% after reporting a fiscal second-quarter profit in line with expectations, but with increased purchasing costs due to a stronger dollar.

site_title: Bank of China in US$3.55 billion multi-currency landmark deal, includes S$500 million tranche
summary: Bank of China has priced a record-breaking US$3.55 billion multi-currency bond deal, featuring four currencies and issued from four branches worldwide. The "Silk Road" bond, honoring China's One Belt, One Road initiative, attracted a total order book size of over US$13 billion. This includes a S$500 million Singapore dollar tranche, the largest senior bond issue by a commercial bank in the Singapore dollar market. Joint global co-ordinators, lead managers, and book runners included BOC, Barclays, Citi, DBS Bank, and HSBC.

site_title: Taiwan central bank keeps interest rate unchanged as expected
summary: Taiwan's Central Bank maintained its interest rate at 1.875% in its quarterly policy meeting, as expected by all 14 economists polled. The decision comes amid a patchy global recovery and slipping external demand for Taiwan's tech goods. The bank has deemed its monetary policy accommodative, but economists believe it can do little to address the trade-reliant economy's slowing growth. The rate has remained unchanged since July 2011.

site_title: Britain to privatise its 'green' bank
summary: Britain plans to privatise its 'green' investment bank, the Green Investment Bank (GIB), to access larger pools of capital and invest in environmentally-friendly infrastructure. The move aims to reduce the country's national debt. Since its establishment in 2012, GIB has committed £2.0 billion, financing 50 projects, including waste management technologies and offshore wind power. The funds raised from selling shares will be used to pay down the national debt and deliver lasting economic security for working people. The privatization is expected to enable the bank to act more freely and invest in a broader range of green sectors.

site_title: China: Stocks tumble on afternoon wave of selling
summary: China stocks plummeted 3.6% and 3.5% in the CSI300 and Shanghai Composite Index, respectively, on Thursday. Investors reduced risk exposure after morning gains, citing fragile market conditions following last week's 13% drop. A campaign of "deleveraging" continues, with outstanding margin loans shrinking for the first time in two weeks. HSBC predicted near-term consolidation as the leverage-driven rally cools, and cautious investors ignored the central bank's market-friendly move to ease short-term liquidity.

site_title: JBIC's Watanabe sees yen at current levels, Kuroda's weak yen view not strange
summary: Former Japanese currency diplomat Hiroshi Watanabe believes the yen is likely to remain around current levels until year-end, despite potential US interest rate hikes. Watanabe disagrees with Bank of Japan Governor Haruhiko Kuroda's view that the yen will not weaken further, calling his comment "misleading" as it referred to a real effective exchange rate rather than nominal yen levels. The yen is currently trading at around 123.5 to the dollar.

site_title: SIA Cargo wins 'Best Air Cargo Carrier - Asia' award
summary: SIA Cargo won the "Best Air Cargo Carrier - Asia" award at the 2015 Asian Freight, Logistics and Supply Chain Awards, as voted by Asia Cargo News readers. The award was received by Chin Yau Seng, president of SIA Cargo, who thanked customers for their support and pledged to continue delivering excellent service. The ceremony took place at the Sky 100, International Commerce Centre in Hong Kong on June 25, 2015.

images.alt_text: Nisha Ramchandani

site_title: China's ICBC says keen on joining London gold price benchmark
summary: ICBC expresses interest in joining London gold price benchmark. Zhou Ming, general manager of the bank's precious metals department, stated that ICBC is "very keen" on participating in the benchmarking process. This comes after the London Bullion Market Association announced that the Bank of China would become the first Chinese bank to participate in the electronic platform.

site_title: Standard Chartered Private Equity invests US$52m in Crystal Jade
summary: Standard Chartered Private Equity (SCPE) has invested US$52 million in Crystal Jade Group Holdings, a portfolio company of L Capital Asia. The investment will fund the growth of Crystal Jade's Asian outlets and international expansion. SCPE's managing partner Ravi Thakran and global co-head of private equity Nainesh Jaisingh welcomed the investment, citing Crystal Jade's strong Asian brand and potential for growth across Standard Chartered's footprint. The deal strengthens resources for Crystal Jade's growth and expansion.

images.alt_text: Mindy Tan

site_title: French cabbies angry at Uber block Paris airports, highway
summary: French taxi drivers blocked Paris airports and a major highway in protest of competition from ride-hailing service Uber, citing job losses and safety concerns. The strike, which involved thousands of cabs, aimed to block space and pressure the government to regulate Uber drivers. The taxi lobby has been fierce in its opposition to Uber, with some drivers resorting to violent tactics to deter competitors. The dispute highlights tensions between traditional taxi services and ride-hailing apps in the European market.

images.alt_text: French cab drivers angry at competition from taxi app Uber on Thursday blocked access to Paris airports and on a busy highway around the capital as they protested losing customers to the popular service.

site_title: Asia: Markets retreat as Greece talks stumble
summary: Asian markets declined on Thursday due to concerns over Greece's debt reform talks, which stalled after Athens' leader accused creditors of rejecting his proposals. The deadlock may lead to Greece defaulting and possibly exiting the eurozone. Tokyo, Hong Kong, Shanghai, Sydney, and Seoul all fell, with Tokyo easing 0.10%, Hong Kong losing 0.28%, and Sydney dropping 0.30%. The Dow and S&P 500 also retreated, while the euro held steady.

site_title: Sugar exports from India seen doubling as bumper crop looms
summary: India's sugar exports are expected to double to 2 million metric tons in the next 12 months, driven by a bumper crop, which would extend the country's surplus for a sixth year. Production is forecast to reach 27.25 million tons, with a stockpile of 10 million tons adding to the surplus. The glut threatens to further lower global prices, with domestic prices already at a seven-year low. The government has pledged a subsidy and interest-free loans to help mills clear debts owed to farmers.

site_title: Standard Life shuts Singapore insurance business
summary: Standard Life is closing its Singapore insurance business, generating a non-operating loss of around £45 million, to focus on its Chinese and Indian joint ventures and asset management business. The Edinburgh-based firm remains committed to its Asian operations, with an increasing focus on building relationships with Chinese and Indian partners and expanding its asset management presence.

site_title: Seoul: Shares steady ahead of EU summit on Greece; won edges down
summary: South Korean shares closed flat ahead of an EU summit on Greece, despite a government announcement to inject extra fiscal stimulus to counter the economic impact of Middle East Respiratory Syndrome (MERS). The won edged down 0.1% to 1,110.0 to the dollar, marking its third straight decline. The Korea Composite Stock Price Index (KOSPI) ended at 2,085.06 points, flat from the previous close.

site_title: Accreditation status of five training providers cancelled
summary: The Ministry of Manpower (MOM) has cancelled the Accredited Training Provider status of five training providers, Work Safe Academy Pte Ltd, Propel Consultants Pte Ltd, Regent Global Consultants Pte Ltd, Bright Training Centre Pte Ltd, and Ark HSE Management Solutions Pte Ltd, for training and assessment malpractices. Investigations found that the providers failed to conduct courses according to stipulated durations, ensure trainees' language proficiency, and uphold examination procedures. This marks the fifth time since 2010 that MOM has cancelled the accreditation status of training providers for similar violations.

images.alt_text: Mindy Tan

site_title: LTA, SMRT detail service improvement measures for LRT system, stations
summary: The Land Transport Authority (LTA) and SMRT are implementing measures to improve the Bukit Panjang LRT system. The measures include addressing system faults caused by lost train signals and traction power, in collaboration with Bombardier Transport. The LTA and SMRT are working together to enhance the system's robustness.

images.alt_text: The Land Transport Authority (LTA) and SMRT will be implementing enhancements to increase the reliability of the Bukit Panjang LRT.
Mindy Tan

site_title: El Nino threatens Modi inflation goal as monsoon rain curbed
summary: India's Prime Minister Narendra Modi faces a threat to his inflation goal as a strengthening El Nino is expected to curb the monsoon rain, which is crucial for farming and food production. The Indian Institute of Tropical Meteorology predicts a "large-scale reduction" in rainfall during the first half of July, which could boost food prices and hinder efforts to lower interest rates. This could have an adverse impact on the economy, particularly on agriculture, which accounts for 15% of India's GDP.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks close down 0.46%
summary: Tokyo stocks closed down 0.46% on Thursday, easing from 18-year highs due to concerns over Greece's stalled debt reform talks. The Nikkei 225 index dropped 96.63 points to 20,771.40, while the Topix index fell 0.53% to 1,670.91.

site_title: McDonald's says looking to sell Taiwan stores to a franchise operator
summary: McDonald's plans to sell its 413 Taiwan-based stores to a franchise operator, as part of a turnaround plan to bounce back from a food safety scare in China. The move follows a statement by new CEO Steve Easterbrook in May that the company would sell restaurants to franchisees. This decision aims to increase efficiency and adapt to changing market conditions.

site_title: US regulator freezes Chinese executive's assets over "suspicious" Qihoo trades
summary: The US Securities and Exchange Commission (SEC) has frozen the assets of Chinese online gaming CEO Luo Haijian, alleging he made over $1 million in suspicious trades ahead of a $10 billion buyout offer for US-listed Qihoo 360 Technology Co Ltd. The SEC claims Luo had material, non-public information about the deal and traded options while in possession of this information. Luo's assets have been frozen, and he is facing a final judgment ordering him to disgorge his gains with interest and penalties.

images.alt_text: The US securities regulator has obtained a court order to freeze the assets of a Chinese online gaming CEO over what it described as "suspicious" trading activity ahead of a US$10 billion deal by US-listed Qihoo 360 Technology Co Ltd.

site_title: Shell executives visit Tehran for projects if sanctions end
summary: Royal Dutch Shell Plc executives visited Tehran to discuss partnerships and outstanding debt, marking a significant step towards the company's potential return to Iran. The meeting with Iranian officials covered debt owed US$2.16 billion and potential business cooperation. This visit comes as talks on a nuclear deal are scheduled to conclude at the end of the month, with Iran seeking billions of dollars to revitalize its ailing oil industry. The move suggests a deepening engagement by Shell and other major Western oil companies.

site_title: Religare Capital Markets appoints Stephen Conway head of Asean trading
summary: Religare Capital Markets has appointed Stephen Conway head of Asean trading, based in Singapore. Conway has over 25 years of experience in trading Asian markets, previously working at RHB Securities, MF Global, BTIG, and Credit Suisse. This appointment follows the recent hiring of Matthew Lutter as managing director and head of Asean equities, marking Religare's second senior hire this month.

images.alt_text: Mindy Tan

site_title: Asia sees conclusion of Trans-Pacific Trade Pact after US vote
summary: The US Senate passed legislation granting President Barack Obama fast-track trade-negotiating authority, paving the way for the completion of the 12-nation Trans-Pacific Partnership. The vote allows ministers to meet in the near future to reach an agreement on the pact, which covers about 40% of global commerce. This development bolsters efforts by Japan and the US to accelerate talks on the pact and is seen as a positive step for US business and engagement in the region.

site_title: Thai finance minister says difficult to cut rates, drought a threat
summary: Thailand's finance minister, Sommai Phasee, stated that cutting interest rates further would be difficult due to already low rates of 1.50%. A severe drought threatens the economy, potentially cutting growth by 0.5 percentage points this year. The government is taking measures to cushion the impact on the farming sector.

site_title: German consumers gloomier going into July: GfK
summary: German consumers became more cautious in July, with the GfK consumer sentiment indicator dropping to 10.1 from 10.2 in June, due to concerns over Greece's potential exit from the euro zone. This is the first time since October that consumers' confidence has decreased. Despite high employment and wage hikes, uncertainty and the prospect of a Greek default have led to shoppers feeling less willing to make purchases. Private consumption remains a major economic driver, but its growth may slow due to the decrease in consumer confidence.

site_title: GSK to invest another £38m in Singapore facility
summary: GlaxoSmithKline (GSK) will invest £38m (S$80.1m) in its Singapore antibiotic manufacturing plant, increasing production by 50% and helping meet growing demand in emerging markets. The investment is on top of a previous £38m (S$60m) commitment in 2012. The new facility will support the company's research and development of cutting-edge pharmaceutical manufacturing technologies, aligning with Singapore's vision of becoming a key site for such activities.

site_title: Australia: Shares turn lower as Greek worries sting
summary: Australian shares fell 1.0% to 5,632.7, as investors turned cautious amid Greek default worries. The S&P/ASX 200 index hit a three-week high the previous day. Without a deal by Saturday, Greece may default on its IMF repayment, potentially exiting the eurozone. New Zealand's NZX 50 index also fell 0.7%. The decline follows a week of gains, with investors concerned about the impact of a Greek default on the global economy.

site_title: Sibor and SOR data to be subject to fees from Oct 1, 2015
summary: Singapore's Sibor and SOR data will be subject to a monthly fee of US$1,500 starting Oct 1, 2015. Subscribers who receive real-time data will pay an end-user fee of US$5 per month, while delayed data will be available for free. ABS Benchmarks Administration Co, the administrator of the benchmarks, aims to strengthen the benchmark contribution process with increased work, oversight, and investment. The fee structure is intended to ensure the governance processes of the benchmarks remain robust and acceptable to market participants.

site_title: India, China pledge nearly US$1.5 billion in Nepal quake aid
summary: India and China pledged nearly US$1.5 billion in aid for Nepal's earthquake reconstruction efforts. The aid, offered on June 25, 2015, includes US$1 billion from India and is part of a larger US$2 billion assistance package over the next five years. The quakes on April 25 and May 12 killed 8,832 people and injured over 22,000, with the estimated recovery cost at over US$6.6 billion. China also offered significant aid, although the exact amount was not specified.

site_title: Singapore shares open 5.72 points lower on Thursday
summary: Singapore shares dropped 5.72 points to 3,345.61 on Thursday, following news that Greece and its creditors broke off talks without a deal. This move aligned with lower global equities, with a total of 49.8 million shares changing hands. Losers outnumbered gainers 90 to 27, with the Straits Times Index down 5.72 points.

images.alt_text: Mindy Tan

site_title: Oil prices mixed in Asian trade
summary: Oil prices in Asia were mixed on Thursday, influenced by a bearish US energy report and ongoing talks over Iran's nuclear program. US benchmark West Texas Intermediate fell 3 cents to $60.24, while Brent gained 14 cents to $63.63. Analysts attribute the price fluctuations to the report's data, which showed a record 9.6 million barrels of domestic crude output and near-record stockpiles. The Iran nuclear talks are also expected to extend, potentially impacting oil prices.

site_title: Hot stock: Noble Group gains 2% in wake of more share buyback news
summary: Noble Group shares rose 2% after the company announced another share buyback, buying 14.45 million shares at S$0.7178 apiece for S$10.40 million. This brings the company's total shares to 134.16 million, equivalent to 1.99% of equity. Analysts at OCBC Investment Research maintained a "hold" rating, citing a supported share price, but bumped up their fair value to S$0.69. The company's share buybacks are seen as a positive sign for the stock.

site_title: South Korea reports two more Mers deaths
summary: South Korea reported two more deaths from the Mers outbreak, bringing the total fatalities to 29. The two new cases were a 65-year-old man diagnosed on June 6 and a 70-year-old woman diagnosed on June 22, who was a relative of another infected patient. The Mers outbreak, caused by Middle East Respiratory Syndrome, is a deadly virus that has been spreading in the country.

site_title: Singapore's proposed bail-in regime is credit positive for senior bank creditors: Moody's
summary: Singapore's proposed bail-in regime, targeting subordinated creditors, is credit positive for senior bank creditors, according to Moody's. The regime excludes senior unsecured creditors, legacy debt, and deposits, making it investor-friendly for non-subordinated debtholders. If implemented, it will be credit positive for senior unsecured bondholders, as they won't be subject to bail-in outside of bank liquidation. The regime aims to strengthen the Monetary Authority of Singapore's powers to resolve failed banks while maintaining critical bank functions.

site_title: North Korea's 'landmark' airport terminal to open on July 1
summary: North Korea's new airport terminal, dubbed a "landmark of the Songun era", is set to open on July 1. The terminal, built at leader Kim Jong Un's whim, was partly demolished and rebuilt after failing to meet his "Juche" philosophy standards. Kim oversaw its construction, deploying 200,000 soldiers, and will host a grand opening ceremony. The facility, designed for international civilian flights, is expected to be nearly empty due to limited foreign flights, further highlighting the isolated nation's low travel demand.

images.alt_text: North Korea's showcase new airport terminal, which had to be partly demolished and rebuilt at leader Kim Jong Un's whim, is to open on July 1, state media said Thursday.

site_title: Taiwan: Stocks up; tech, Hon Hai family companies rise
summary: Taiwan's stocks rose 0.9% to 9,481.73, driven by a strong tech sector and companies linked to Hon Hai Precision Industry Co Ltd. The financials subindex gained 0.4% and the electronics subindex rose 1.1%. This follows a similar trend in other regional and global bourses. The rally is seen as a positive response to the market despite uncertainty over US trade policies.

site_title: US, China bridge some economic differences in Washington talks
summary: US and Chinese negotiators made progress in annual bilateral talks, bridging some differences over economic policy. The US agreed to support China's inclusion of the yuan in the International Monetary Fund's SDR currency basket and China agreed to hold off on yuan value interventions except in disorderly market conditions. The two sides also committed to improving a bilateral investment treaty and publishing economic data to meet IMF standards. However, the US remained opposed to China's Asian Infrastructure Investment Bank, which it claims undermines social and environmental standards.

site_title: South Korea unveils US$14b stimulus package to spur growth
summary: South Korea unveiled a $14 billion stimulus package to boost its economy, which has been affected by the deadly MERS outbreak. The package includes infrastructure projects, job creation, and support for low-income earners to offset the impact of the virus, drought, and economic slowdown. The finance ministry slashed its growth forecast to 3.1% and lowered its inflation outlook to 0.7%. The move comes after the central bank cut interest rates to a record low 1.5% in an effort to stimulate growth and contain the economic fallout of the MERS outbreak.

site_title: Six Singapore companies make it to Forbes Asia's 'Best Under a Billion' list
summary: Six Singapore companies, including Cordlife Group, Hock Lian Seng, and Q&M Dental Group, made it to Forbes Asia's 'Best Under a Billion' list, up three from 2014. The list recognizes 200 top Asian public companies with annual revenue between $5 million and $1 billion. China and Hong Kong led the list with 84 companies, followed by Taiwan with 36. The list saw 123 new additions, with India and Malaysia also represented.

images.alt_text: Mindy Tan

site_title: Texchem's delisting deadline extended
summary: Texchem-PACK Holdings' application to extend its delisting deadline for major shareholder Texchem Resources Bhd has been conditionally approved. The new deadline is Aug 7, 2015, allowing the company's major shareholder to make a reasonable exit offer to shareholders. This extension follows a previous extension, and the company will now have additional time to negotiate a buyout.

images.alt_text: Mindy Tan

site_title: China securities regulator approves new batch of 28 IPOs
summary: China's securities regulator has approved 28 initial public offerings, including 10 on the Shanghai Stock Exchange, 10 on Shenzhen's SME board, and 8 on ChiNext. This is part of the regulator's increased efforts to greenlight IPOs, with two batches of listings approved each month. The move aims to increase share supplies in China's red-hot stock market.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open 0.43% lower
summary: Tokyo stocks opened 0.43% lower on June 25, 2015, amid concerns over Greek debt talks. The Nikkei 225 index fell 90.34 points to 20,777.69, following US and European markets' decline. US stocks dropped 0.98% and European markets fell 0.62%. Greek Prime Minister Alexis Tsipras held a late-night meeting with creditors, but talks failed to produce a breakthrough, with Tsipras set to continue marathon negotiations in Brussels.

site_title: Aging Japanese swap old diamonds for yen from eager China buyers
summary: Japan is experiencing a surge in the market for second-hand diamonds, with exports of used diamonds increasing by 77% this year, according to Ministry of Finance data. The trend is driven by an aging population and shrinking economy, with many individuals selling unwanted luxury items, including diamond jewelry, to fund travel or simpler lifestyles. The market has expanded about 10% annually since 2009, reaching 1.5 trillion yen, and is attracting buyers from China and India, who are drawn by the value of diamonds in the weakened Japanese yen.

images.alt_text: Diamonds aren't necessarily forever. At least not in Japan, where jewellery owners are unloading unwanted jewels for cash at a record pace and shipping them off to buyers in China and India.

site_title: Mers prompts fiscal stimulus in South Korea as confidence falls
summary: South Korea plans a fiscal stimulus package of over $13.5 billion to cushion the economic impact of a deadly respiratory disease and drought. The 15 trillion won package includes a supplementary budget and aims to boost spending and keep it expansionary. The move comes as consumer confidence fell to the lowest level since 2012 and tourist cancellations rose. The country's growth forecast was cut to 3.1% and inflation to 0.7%, and borrowing costs were reduced to a record low of 1.5%.

images.alt_text: South Korea plans a stimulus package of more than 15 trillion won (US$13.5 billion) to cushion the economic impact of a deadly respiratory disease and a drought.

site_title: El Nino may cut Australian wheat crop to lowest in eight years
summary: Australia's wheat crop may be cut to its lowest in eight years due to the developing El Nino event, according to National Australia Bank Ltd. The crop is expected to be reduced to 20 million metric tons or lower, according to agribusiness economist Phin Ziebell. This would be the lowest since the 2007-2008 season. The El Nino is strengthening and poses a risk for the global economy by hurting crops and boosting inflation.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks down 0.28% at open
summary: Hong Kong shares declined 0.28% at the opening on June 25, 2015, amid fears of a Greek default due to stalled bailout talks. The Hang Seng Index dropped 75.80 points to 27,329.17. This move was triggered by the impending repayment deadline, which could lead to a default if talks fail.

site_title: AirAsia CEO Fernandes casts other work aside amid accounting worries
summary: AirAsia CEO Tony Fernandes has pledged to dedicate more time to the budget airline amid concerns over its accounting practices and declining share price. Fernandes, who also owns a hotel chain, insurance business, and English football club, will focus on repairing the financial damage done to AirAsia, with analysts saying he and his partner Kamarudin Meranun will take a more hands-on approach. The airline's share price has fallen 40% this year, with concerns over related-party transactions and reliance on associates. Fernandes has refuted a report questioning AirAsia's accounts, but analysts say he is the best person to turn the airline around.

images.alt_text: AirAsia Bhd boss Tony Fernandes has told staff and analysts he will spend more time working on the budget airline and put his other business and sporting interests to one side, after a report questioning the company's accounts sent its share price tumbling.

site_title: Australia: Shares retreat as Greek worries flare up, NZ also sag
summary: Australian shares fell 0.6% on Thursday, tracking global declines amid Greek debt default concerns. The S&P/ASX 200 index retreated to 5,651.6, its lowest level in three weeks. The big four banks and major miners, including Rio Tinto, suffered losses. The decline follows a three-week peak reached earlier in the week, as investors reacted to the ongoing Greek debt crisis and US-EU trade talks.

site_title: Noble continues share buyback
summary: NOBLE Group has conducted its second consecutive share buyback, purchasing 14.45 million shares at S$0.7178 apiece for a total of S$10.40 million. The company now holds 134.16 million shares, equivalent to 1.99% of its equity. This follows a similar buyback of 14 million shares at S$0.69445 apiece for S$9.75 million on Wednesday.

images.alt_text: Mindy Tan

site_title: China to launch yuan-denominated gold fix this year
summary: China's Shanghai Gold Exchange plans to launch a yuan-denominated gold fix by the end of the year, aiming to give China more influence over the pricing of gold. The fix will complement the global London gold fix and provide a more diversified benchmark. This move is part of China's efforts to increase its influence in the global gold market. The launch of the yuan fix is seen as a strategic move by China to promote its currency and increase its economic influence.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares fall on Thursday opening
summary: Malaysia's stock market fell on Thursday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index down 2.05 points to 1,729.63 points. The decline was driven by a loss of 98 gainers to 82 winners, with 38.63 million shares worth RM15.9 million traded.

site_title: US SEC and JPMorgan in talks to settle probe regarding product steering
summary: JPMorgan Chase & Co is in talks with the US Securities and Exchange Commission to settle a probe into whether the bank inappropriately advised its private-banking clients towards its own investment products. A potential settlement may occur this summer, which could include a fine. The probe was sparked by the bank's disclosure of receiving subpoenas from the SEC regarding its mutual fund sales. Other government authorities have also sought information about JPMorgan's use of proprietary products in its wealth-management business.

site_title: End of clean energy paralysis in Australia unblocks A$14 billion in projects
summary: Australia's new renewable energy target has ended months of policy uncertainty, paving the way for A$14 billion in wind and solar projects. The legislation allows developers to start work on projects, with Acciona SA and SunEdison Inc committing to A$750 million and exploring large-scale projects, respectively. Despite a scaled-back target, industry experts expect significant investment in big solar plants, with solar forecast to account for almost half of new large-scale capacity by 2021. The resolution aims to spur investment in renewable energy and address financing challenges.

site_title: Alibaba goes Hollywood with 'Mission: Impossible' stake
summary: Alibaba, China's largest online retailer, made its first foray into Hollywood by investing in the next "Mission: Impossible" film. The deal, announced on June 24, 2015, marked Alibaba's entry into the film industry and made it the official promoter of the film in China. The agreement is seen as a step towards Alibaba's internationalization, with plans to establish a world-class entertainment platform. Alibaba Pictures CEO Zhang Qiang stated that the partnership will consolidate resources, technologies, and talents to enhance the film industry.

site_title: US not spying on France's Hollande or French officials: Kerry
summary: US Secretary of State John Kerry stated that the US is not spying on French President Francois Hollande or any French government officials. Kerry emphasized that foreign intelligence surveillance activities only occur for specific and validated national security purposes. There was no direct confrontation or finger-pointing at China regarding cyber-theft during high-level discussions in Washington.

site_title: Share valuations of world's top medical glove makers surge - but not on Mers
summary: Share valuations of top Malaysian medical glove makers Top Glove, Supermax, Kossan Rubber Industries, and Hartalega have surged to historic highs, with a median forward 12-month price-to-earnings ratio of 18. The companies' combined revenue is expected to grow 20% in 2015, driven by the ringgit's slump to nine-year lows against the dollar and low raw material prices. Analysts advocate selective stock-picking, with Top Glove seen as the top pick, and attribute recent interest to the Mers outbreak in South Korea, but expect no material impact on earnings.

site_title: GM to test Cisco technology for sharing road safety spectrum
summary: General Motors plans to test Cisco's technology that allows vehicles to share radio communication bands with roadside Wi-Fi devices, potentially improving road safety. The technology, set to be deployed in 2017 Cadillac CTS sedans, enables "talking" cars to share the same radio band as vehicle-to-vehicle safety systems without causing interference. This could help avoid collisions and provide warnings in 80% of car accidents involving multiple vehicles. The move comes as US regulators consider requiring V2V technology in vehicles by the end of the year.

site_title: China's US$10 trillion economy may soon have reliable jobs data
summary: China is set to introduce a more accurate and reliable employment statistics system, starting in July, with 15,000 surveyors collecting data from 120,000 households. The new system aims to provide a broader and more accurate survey-based unemployment rate, which will be a key indicator for China's macro policy decisions. The existing quarterly registered urban jobless rate is criticized for excluding over 200 million migrant workers, and the new system is expected to better reflect China's labor market, potentially improving economic decision-making.

site_title: Offshore tax zones cost developing countries US$100b a year: UN
summary: Developing countries are losing around US$100 billion annually in revenues due to foreign investors channelling profits through offshore tax zones to avoid tax, according to a UN study. The study, published in the World Investment Report, found that this "tax avoidance practice" leads to a significant leakage of development finance and resources. The UN recommends removing aggressive tax planning opportunities and promoting investment through anti-avoidance measures to help developing countries build up their tax collecting capabilities.

site_title: China moves closer to 'riskiest' step with removal of loans cap
summary: China has removed a 75% cap on loans relative to deposits, a two-decade-old rule, in a major banking reform step. Premier Li Keqiang aims to usher in market-based economics, potentially boosting credit growth, but limited demand for funds in a faltering economy poses a bigger constraint. The central bank plans to monitor the loan-to-deposit ratio and may scrap a cap on deposit rates this year, which could lead to higher borrowing costs for companies. This move is part of China's financial deregulation efforts, marking a significant step towards a market-based banking industry.

images.alt_text: China took one of its biggest steps in banking reform, moving to end a two-decade-old rule that has capped lending relative to deposits as Premier Li Keqiang seeks to usher in market-based economics.

site_title: Ascott Reit to acquire seven assets in Australia and Japan for S$298.3m
summary: Ascott Residence Trust (Ascott Reit) plans to acquire seven assets in Australia and Japan for S$298.3 million, increasing distribution income by S$3.9 million and distribution per unit by 2.9%. The acquisitions include three serviced residences and four rental housing properties, with the three serviced residences to be managed by Ascott. Unitholders are set to vote on the transactions at an extraordinary general meeting on July 24, 2015.

images.alt_text: Mindy Tan

site_title: UK car production up in May as domestic demand surges
summary: British car production rose 2.3% to 119,338 cars in May, driven by a 13.3% increase in domestic demand. Exports, accounting for around 85% of production, decreased 0.2% to 94,546 cars due to cooling demand in China and Russia. Industry body SMMT credits improved EU market performance for lifting export production levels. Despite recent challenges, UK car manufacturing has seen a steady performance this year, bolstered by a strong home market.

site_title: US to continue pressing China on currency policy: Lew
summary: US Treasury Secretary Jack Lew stated that the US will continue to press China to adopt a market-determined exchange rate. China's commitment to intervene in currency markets only when disorderly conditions arise will be tested when its currency faces pressure to appreciate. Lew emphasized that the US will monitor China's currency policy closely, aiming to prevent manipulation and maintain a stable exchange rate.

site_title: Greece's Tsipras resumes crunch debt talks with creditors
summary: Greek Prime Minister Alexis Tsipras resumed emergency talks with creditors in Brussels on Thursday to discuss a debt deal, amid a looming June 30 deadline for a huge IMF payment. The talks aim to finalize a bailout deal, with creditors demanding spending cuts and pension reforms. Tsipras has resisted these demands, seeking to end five years of austerity imposed under two bailouts worth 240 billion euros. A breakthrough is hoped for, with the European Commission, IMF, and ECB monitoring the talks, and a potential agreement could unlock the last 7.2 billion euros of Greece's bailout.

site_title: StanChart CEO Winters to shift power to regional hubs such as Singapore
summary: Standard Chartered Plc CEO Bill Winters plans to shift capital to regional hubs, including Singapore, to revitalize the bank and meet new regulatory demands. Winters aims to reverse two years of declining earnings and is expected to give more power to subsidiaries in markets such as Hong Kong, India, and Africa. Analysts predict a capital raising of 5-10 billion pounds (US$7.8-15.6 billion) to strengthen the bank's business and capital. The move is part of Winters' efforts to restore the bank's performance after two years of declining earnings.

images.alt_text: Standard Chartered Plc Chief Executive Officer Bill Winters is planning to shift capital to regional hubs in an overhaul aimed at reviving the bank and meeting new regulatory demands, the Financial Times reported.

site_title: Microsoft makes Word available on Android phones
summary: Microsoft has made its popular Word, Excel, and PowerPoint programs available on Android phones through the Google Play Store. The apps, which were previously only available on tablets and iPhones, allow users to access cloud-based Office 365 services such as OneDrive and Google Drive. The move is part of Microsoft's strategy to make its applications accessible across multiple devices. The apps were released after a preview period, which included feedback from users, and are aimed at inspiring more people to subscribe to Microsoft's Office 365 service.

site_title: UN wants Internet chiefs to crack down on 'digital terror'
summary: The UN has recommended that internet and social media chiefs report to the UN on combating groups like Islamic State, which use "digital terror" to spread propaganda. A report released Wednesday stated that the scale of digital activity linked to ISIL and Al-Qaeda affiliates is of deep concern. Experts suggested that internet companies be invited to brief the Security Council on their efforts to respond to exploitation by these groups, citing the growth of high-definition digital terror and the widespread use of social media platforms like Facebook, Twitter, and YouTube.

site_title: UN forecasts rebound in global investment flows this year
summary: The UN Conference on Trade and Development (UNCTAD) forecasts a rebound in global foreign direct investment (FDI) in 2015, reversing a 16% decline in 2014 due to a fragile economy and conflicts. FDI flows dropped to $1.23 trillion in 2014, largely attributed to shaky investor confidence. The report notes an unprecedented rise in conflicts, including the Ukraine conflict, which contributed to the decline. The rebound in FDI is expected to be driven by a recovering global economy and increased investor confidence.

site_title: Saudi carrier takes 50 Airbus planes in Islamic leasing deal
summary: Saudi Arabian Airlines agreed to a 50-aircraft deal with Airbus, valued at around $8.2 billion, in an Islamic leasing deal. The deal includes 30 A320neo and 20 A330-300 Regional aircraft, with Dubai-based International Airfinance Corporation (IAFC) financing the purchase. This is the largest Islamic financing aviation deal and marks Airbus' efforts to gain an edge over Boeing in the Gulf market. The A330-300 Regional is tailored for domestic and short regional flights, and the deal will join Saudi Arabian Airlines' existing Airbus fleet.

images.alt_text: Saudi Arabian Airlines will take delivery of 50 aircraft from Airbus in the largest aviation deal to be secured via Islamic financing, as the European planemaker tries to gain an edge over rival Boeing in the key Gulf aviation market.

site_title: Dollar slips as Greek talks fray
summary: The US dollar edged lower versus the euro on Wednesday as Greek talks with creditors raised market risk. Greek Prime Minister Alexis Tsipras met with EU President Jean-Claude Juncker in Brussels to discuss a deal on 7.2 billion euros, but no agreement was reached. The dollar, which had surged 1.5% on the euro Tuesday, lost 0.3% to US$1.1208 per euro as caution filled the markets. A final deal is unlikely to boost the euro, with markets focusing on potential further liquidity expansion by the ECB.

site_title: Singapore clinches 'Best Seaport - Asia' award for 27th time
summary: Singapore has won the 'Best Seaport - Asia' award for the 27th consecutive time at the 2015 Asia Freight, Logistics and Supply Chain Awards. The award recognizes the Port of Singapore's strong performance in 2014, with annual vessel arrival tonnage reaching 2.37 billion GT and container throughput hitting 33.9 million TEUs. The port's total cargo tonnage handled reached 580.8 million tonnes, and it remains the world's largest bunker sales hub. The award comes as the port prepares to expand its capacity to 50 million TEUs by 2017.

images.alt_text: The Port of Singapore has been named the best seaport in Asia for the - for the 27th time - beating fierce rivals Hong Kong and Shanghai.
Mindy Tan

site_title: South Korea finance minister sees local economy lagging prior forecast
summary: South Korea's finance minister, Choi Kyung Hwan, stated that the local economy is expected to lag its forecasted growth path due to the ongoing Middle East Respiratory Syndrome (Mers) outbreak. The minister noted that Mers has affected the economy more rapidly than the 2014 ferry disaster, which killed over 300 people and dented consumer sentiment. The virus's impact on the economy is expected to last for a considerable time after the outbreak subsides.

site_title: IT failure may have triggered Polish airline meltdown
summary: A computer systems meltdown at Polish airline LOT may have been triggered by human error, not a cyber attack as initially reported. The incident grounded over 1,400 passengers at Warsaw's Frederic Chopin Airport on Sunday. According to unofficial sources, a report by Poland's Internal Security Agency (ABW) revealed the failure was caused by human error, not a cyber attack. The airline's initial description of the incident as a "first attack of its kind" has been disputed.

site_title: 2015 may be a pivotal year for Asean
summary: The Association of Southeast Asian Nations (Asean) is poised for a pivotal year in 2015 as the Asean Economic Community (AEC) comes to fruition, strengthening regional cooperation and partnership among its 10 member countries. The AEC aims to create a single market, promote equitable economic development, and integrate the region into the global economy. With 80% of businesses viewing the AEC as an opportunity for growth, the region is expected to see increased cross-border trade, investment, and economic growth, driven by a growing population, increasing per capita incomes, and favorable demographics.

site_title: US: Stocks retreat as Greece talks stall
summary: US stocks retreated on Wednesday, dropping 0.98% to 17,966.07, as Greece's talks with international creditors stalled. The Dow Jones Industrial Average fell 178.00 points, with DuPont and Boeing experiencing significant losses. Bond prices rose, with the yield on the 10-year US Treasury falling to 2.38%. The S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite Indexes also declined, with Monsanto and Netflix experiencing losses.

site_title: Supermarket operators Ahold and Delhaize agree to merge
summary: Dutch supermarket operator Ahold has agreed to merge with Belgian peer Delhaize, creating the sixth-largest food retailer in the US and the largest in Europe's Benelux region. The merged entity will have 54.1 billion euros in sales, over 6,500 stores worldwide, and a 61% stake held by Ahold.

site_title: Indonesia risks own goal as rupiah-only rule lifts company costs
summary: Indonesia's central bank, Bank Indonesia, will prohibit the use of foreign currencies for local transactions starting July 1, affecting an estimated $12 billion daily transactions. This move will increase costs for companies like PT Kalbe Farma, which relies on dollar-denominated raw materials and loans, with potential price hikes and higher costs for working capital. The rule aims to curb the rupiah's 29% drop in the last three years, but its timing is seen as challenging, particularly with the US expected to hike interest rates and Indonesia's economy slowing down.

images.alt_text: For Indonesian drug maker PT Kalbe Farma, a ban on using currencies other than the rupiah for local transactions is coming at the worst possible time.

site_title: Obama urges China to 'cool' cyber, maritime tensions
summary: US President Barack Obama urged China to take "concrete steps" to ease tensions over cyber intrusions and maritime claims during three days of talks. The talks, which included Vice Premier Liu Yandong and Vice Premier Wang Yang, aimed to improve relations and cooperation on issues such as nuclear non-proliferation and ocean conservation. Obama expressed concerns about cyber hacking and its impact on American businesses, while China agreed to step up efforts to combat illegal wildlife trafficking and protect the oceans. The two countries also launched a joint initiative to protect the oceans and vowed to work together on creating a marine protected area in Antarctica.

site_title: Korea govt fund rejects SK move in warning to chaebol
summary: South Korea's National Pension Service rejected a proposed merger within the SK Group, citing concerns it wasn't in the best interest of all shareholders. The move, which opposes about 9% of proposals from Korean companies last year, is a blow to the ruling Chey family's efforts to solidify its holdings. The pension fund will make a similar decision in July regarding Samsung Group's proposed deal, which is also expected to pass despite opposition. The move is seen as a step towards prioritizing shareholder value over family control in the country's dominant conglomerates.

site_title: US, eyeing Russia, urges NATO allies to harden cyber defenses
summary: US Defense Secretary Ash Carter urged NATO allies to strengthen cyber defenses amid concerns about Russia's advanced threat. Following Russia's annexation of Crimea, cyber vulnerabilities within NATO have come into focus. Carter emphasized the importance of cyber defense, stating it's more crucial than developing offensive capabilities. The US has disclosed a cyber intrusion by Russian hackers and plans to bolster NATO members' defenses through a new initiative, coordinated through an Estonia-based cyber center. The goal is to deter Russia and bolster the resilience of NATO partner nations.

images.alt_text: (Front Left-right) NATO Secretary General Jens Stoltenberg, U.S. Secretary of Defense Ashton Carter and Britain's Defence Secretary Michael Fallon pose with other defense ministers for a family photo, following a meeting of North Atlantic Council (NAC) in Defense Ministers session at the NATO headquarters in Brussels, Belgium on June 24, 2015.

site_title: Greek debt talks halted as Tsipras blasts creditors
summary: Greek Prime Minister Alexis Tsipras' talks with Eurozone finance ministers have been halted until the next day due to a lack of agreement on a bailout deal. Tsipras had rejected fresh demands from creditors, calling it a "face-saving game." The talks broke up after a seven-hour meeting, with Athens needing an accord to unlock vital bailout funds and avoid defaulting on a huge IMF payment on June 30, putting its place in the eurozone at risk. The deadlock raises concerns about Greece's future in the single currency and the European Union.

images.alt_text: Eurozone finance ministers on Wednesday halted crunch talks on a desperately needed Greece bailout deal until the next day, as Greek Prime Minister Alexis Tsipras lashed out at his country's creditors.

site_title: Big economic discovery! Booms may really be the cause of busts
summary: A new economic theory suggests that booms may actually cause busts, contradicting the long-held assumption that excessive optimism and easy credit lead to unsustainable borrowing and eventual crashes. For the past half-century, macroeconomists have believed that economic growth is driven by steady technological improvements and interrupted by unpredictable "shocks." However, this theory is being challenged, with some arguing that booms and busts are random and alternate in a cyclical pattern, rather than being directly linked.

site_title: US Congress passes key trade bill in victory for Obama
summary: The US Congress passed a key trade bill, allowing President Barack Obama to negotiate a Pacific trade accord, known as the Trans-Pacific Partnership, without lawmakers' ability to scrutinize the deal. The bill passed the Senate 60-38 and the House previously, with 15 pro-trade Democrats joining all but five Republicans in supporting it. Senate Majority Leader Mitch McConnell hailed the vote as a "win" for the American middle class, citing the expansion of Obama's trade negotiation powers. The bill now needs passage by the House, where its fate is uncertain.

images.alt_text: Senate Majority Leader Mitch McConnell (R-KY) (C) talks to reporters with Sen. John Barrasso (R-WY) (L) and Senate Majority Whip John Cornyn (R-TX) after the weekly Republican Senate policy luncheon at the U.S. Capitol on June 23, 2015 in Washington, DC.

site_title: US lawmakers studying patent box tax approach
summary: US lawmakers are exploring a patent box tax break, which would lower tax rates on income from patents and intellectual property. The idea aims to benefit technology and pharmaceutical companies, but critics argue it would deprive the government of revenue and favor companies that can easily move income abroad. The proposal has garnered support from some lawmakers, but its details are still being settled, and its implementation is uncertain due to election politics and differing opinions among key players.

site_title: GDP shrinks less than estimated, thanks to consumer spending
summary: The US economy shrank in the first quarter by 0.2% annualized rate, less than the initially reported 0.7% drop, thanks to a stronger-than-expected increase in consumer spending. This reduction in growth was attributed to temporary factors such as harsh winter weather and port delays, but underlying household spending fundamentals appear favorable. Despite a softer start, economists expect the economy to rebound in the second quarter, with growth projected to average 3% in the second half of the year.

site_title: 'Eight is enough' actor Dick Van Patten dies at 86
summary: Actor Dick Van Patten, best known for his role as Tom Bradford in the TV series 'Eight is Enough,' died on June 24, 2015, at 86 due to complications from diabetes. The show, which aired from 1977 to 1981, was a family drama that tackled larger issues, following the lives of a family of eight children. Van Patten also appeared in comedies by Mel Brooks, including 'High Anxiety' and 'Robin Hood: Men in Tights.' A veteran actor, Van Patten began his career at age seven and continued to act on stage and screen until his death.

site_title: Snapchat joins Daily Mail and WPP in marketing venture
summary: Snapchat has formed a marketing venture, Truffle Pig, with WPP and Daily Mail to create social content for brands, capitalizing on the desire for campaigns targeting young consumers. Truffle Pig combines WPP's advertising expertise, Snapchat's social reach, and Daily Mail's news coverage to offer a unique approach to branding. The partnership will introduce branded content on DailyMail.com, Elite Daily, and Snapchat, with plans to expand to other digital properties based on client strategy. This move aims to address marketers' concerns about using Snapchat effectively, with the goal of reaching young, engaged consumers.

site_title: Vietnam embarks on record deal spree on looming foreign threat
summary: Vietnam is on a record-breaking dealmaking spree, with acquisitions reaching up to $4.5 billion this year, surpassing 2012's $4.2 billion. The country is preparing for increased foreign competition as it opens up its economy. Companies are seeking to bulk up through mergers and acquisitions, with Vietnamese companies targeting low-capitalized entities to improve competitiveness. The VN Index has gained 8.1% this year, and the government is pushing deals to boost competitiveness and corporate governance.

images.alt_text: A worker checks for mistakes on beer along production line of a factory of Saigon Beer Corporation (Sabeco) in Hanoi, Vietnam May 26, 2015.

site_title: Brazil graft probe may ensnare electric utility
summary: Brazil's largest corruption investigation may expand to Eletrobras, the country's largest electric utility, and over a dozen foreign companies. Prosecutor Carlos Fernando dos Santos Lima stated that a similar scheme to Petrobras may have occurred at Eletrobras on major projects like the Angra 3 nuclear reactor and the Belo Monte hydroelectric dam. The investigation is expected to continue for at least two years, targeting foreign companies and potentially leading to charges. This development could further destabilize Brazil's business and political landscape.

site_title: US airs concerns over cyber security in dialogue with China
summary: The US and China held annual talks, known as the Strategic and Economic Dialogue, to maintain working relations despite rising tensions. US Treasury Secretary Jacob Lew expressed concerns over Chinese government-sponsored cyber-enabled theft, while US Vice-President Joe Biden emphasized the importance of the relationship. China's Vice-Premier Liu Yandong said differences could be managed with an "overall perspective" and respect for each other's core interests. No significant practical progress was expected, with China viewing the talks as preparation for President Xi Jinping's visit to Washington in September.

site_title: US$ takes a breather as focus shifts to rate hike
summary: The US dollar index eased 0.3% to 95.155, after hitting its highest level in over a week, as investors shifted focus from Greece to US interest rate hikes. US 10-year Treasury yields dipped, and comments from Federal Reserve governor Jerome Powell suggested potential rate hikes this year. The euro remained strong at $1.1200, despite Greece's struggles, as investors focused on underlying factors such as divergent monetary policies.

site_title: Blackrock to list Spanish rent-controlled housing unit
summary: BlackRock's real estate investment trust, Fidere Patrimonio, will list its shares on Spain's alternative stock market MAB next week. The trust owns 2,688 rent-controlled housing units in Madrid and Barcelona, valued at 212 million euros, which were sold to private investors during Spain's economic crisis. The listing aims to provide liquidity and transparency, but raises concerns about the treatment of tenants, who will be required to show they are solvent and not on a creditor blacklist. This move comes amid efforts by Madrid's new leftist mayor to reverse housing evictions and review the sale of properties.

site_title: Prospect of new economic 'miracle' gives Tokyo stocks a boost
summary: Tokyo stock prices hit an 18-year high after Japanese Prime Minister Shinzo Abe announced a government-led drive to boost domestic investment and raise productivity, aiming for a 3% annual GDP growth rate. The "Abenomics 2.0" strategy prioritizes economic growth over fiscal retrenchment, mirroring the Bank of Japan's monetary policy. Analysts predict a "new Japanese miracle" with a high chance of success, citing a potential tax multiplier effect and increased capital investment in areas like AI and robotics.

site_title: Facebook allows users to sign up for Messenger without account
summary: Facebook has enabled users without an account to sign up for its Messenger app with a phone number, expanding the app's reach and making it a standalone platform. Users will be prompted to sign up with their name, phone number, and photo when opening the app. This move aims to connect users directly with businesses, as stated by CEO Mark Zuckerberg earlier this year. The update follows Facebook's previous move to open up Messenger to developers.

site_title: Lumiere Capital sees value opportunities in HK
summary: Lumiere Capital, a local boutique house, sees value opportunities in Hong Kong stocks due to China's equity run. Co-founder Wong Yu Liang believes Hong Kong stocks are not expensive from an absolute valuation basis, especially if China is fundamentally changing for the better. Lumiere has invested in copper wire maker Jiangnan Group and financial card maker Goldpac Group, citing their strong relationships and potential for industry consolidation and urbanization. The investments aim to capitalize on China's equity run and provide a two-bagger return.

site_title: Tianjin's Manhattan project may be getting second wind
summary: Tianjin, China's Manhattan project, a massive urban development, may be experiencing a resurgence after some developers abandoned their plans. The city aims to expand its floor space to about 10 times that of London's Canary Wharf. Despite initial setbacks, new projects are moving forward, indicating a potential revival of the ambitious project.

site_title: More reasons for Richard Elman to quit as Noble exec chairman
summary: Richard Elman's tenure as Noble Group's executive chairman is under scrutiny due to concerns over corporate governance. Following a lax regulatory environment in Singapore, Noble chose to list in the country, raising questions about investor protection. The recent appointment of Yu Xubo, president of Cofco, as a Noble non-executive director is seen as an attempt to avoid shareholder scrutiny. Elman's influence as founder and executive chairman has led to calls for him to step down, citing the need for reforms to protect minority shareholders and the company's reputation.

site_title: Cofco president joins Noble board; group unveils further buyback
summary: Noble Group has appointed Patrick Yu, president of China's state-owned food-processing company Cofco Corporation, as a non-executive director, replacing retired Li Rongrong. The commodities group also announced a further market buyback of 14 million shares for S$9.75 million, bringing the total market acquisitions to 119.7 million shares this month. The move aims to boost investor confidence, following a 40% drop in the share price due to criticisms of Noble's accounting practices. The appointment and buyback are seen as a bid to enhance shareholder value, with China's sovereign wealth fund China Investment Corp (CIC) supporting the move.

site_title: Port expansion critical - for both maritime sector and Singapore
summary: Singapore's Pasir Panjang container terminal expansion project, worth $3.5 billion, marks a significant milestone. The 15 new berths will increase capacity to 15 million containers per year by 2017. Meanwhile, a mega port in Tuas, set to open by 2027, will further boost capacity to 65 million containers, utilizing advanced technology and green technology to enhance competitiveness. Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong emphasized the port's importance to Singapore's economy, warning that global warming and sea-level rise could erode the country's relevance as a global seaport.

site_title: SATS unit clinches 30b yen catering contract from Delta
summary: SATS' Japan-based catering company TFK Corporation has secured a multi-year contract with Delta Air Lines worth approximately 30 billion yen (S$325.2 million). The contract, set to begin in October, will see TFK supply catering services to Delta at Tokyo's Narita and Haneda International airports. SATS holds a near 60% stake in TFK, which serves over 40 airlines. The agreement re-establishes SATS' long-standing relationship with Delta, which had ended in 2009 following a merger.

images.alt_text: Nisha Ramchandani

site_title: China's green objectives for UN climate talks to cost US$6.6t
summary: China's lead negotiator for UN climate talks, Xie Zhenhua, stated that meeting the country's greenhouse gas reduction goals will cost over $6.6 trillion, requiring a reconfiguration of its coal-dependent energy mix and development of new energy sources. China aims to cap its emissions by 2030 and fill 20% of its energy needs from zero-carbon sources. The US and China plan to partner on two carbon capture projects to commercialize the technology, with the US climate envoy expressing hopes for a strong, updated set of targets in the final Paris agreement.

site_title: Qingjian launches services and info mobile app
summary: Qingjian Realty (South Pacific) Group has launched a free mobile app, HiLife, allowing existing and new customers to access a range of curated home and lifestyle services, including yoga classes, facility bookings, and interior design. The app aims to support homeowners beyond sales transactions and is available on Google Play and the App Store. Initially rolled out to homeowners at Riversound Residence, HiLife will be progressively introduced to all Qingjian customers, with no impact on unit prices. The app features 19 partners and will continue to be developed with more vendors and services added over time.

images.alt_text: Fiona Lam

site_title: Chile sea bass increasingly scarce as nation's fish stocks become depleted
summary: Chile's fish stocks are depleting due to overfishing, with catches of sea bass slumping from 12,000 tonnes in 2000 to 2,000 tonnes in 2014. The government's failure to impose stricter quotas and let the fishing industry self-regulate led to the crisis. Small fishermen blame the large industrial fleets for the decline, while environmental groups argue the government's inaction is the primary cause. The country's fishing industry, worth $6.2 billion, is now classified as over-exploited or exhausted for most species.

site_title: China seizes 3b yuan of decades-old smuggled meat
summary: China has seized approximately 100,000 tonnes of frozen meat worth around $650 million, including some rotting and 40-year-old meat, in a nationwide crackdown on smuggling. The operation targeted two gangs in the central province, and officials found meat from Vietnam, which was shipped to Hong Kong and then to the mainland. The seized meat was bought abroad, smuggled, and sold on the black market, with some products being over four decades old, dating back to the rule of Mao Zedong.

site_title: Paris kicks off bid to host 2024 Summer Olympics games
summary: Paris officially kicked off its bid to host the 2024 Summer Olympics, marking a second attempt after previous losses to Beijing in 2008 and London in 2012. The city is emphasizing its readiness to accommodate athletes and is seeking support from French athletes, who spoke emotionally about their desire to see Paris win the bid. Other cities, including Rome, Budapest, Boston, and Hamburg, are also considering bids. All bids are due in September, with Paris citing its modern Olympic mettle and the centennial of its last Olympics appearance in 1924 as key arguments.

images.alt_text: Paris kicked off its bid to host the 2024 Summer Olympics on Tuesday in the presence of French politicians and athletes, and appeared to be hoping that this time would be a charm.

site_title: Ikea to raise US minimum hourly wage to retain workforce
summary: IKEA Group, the world's largest furniture retailer, will raise the US hourly minimum wage for 32% of its US hourly retail staff and some distribution workers by 10% to $11.87, effective January 1, 2026, in an effort to retain employees. This increase follows a 17% boost to $10.76 an hour in 2015. The move aims to keep workers from moving to other merchants that have increased pay recently.

site_title: Instagram aims to beat Twitter with its updated live photo feed
summary: Instagram has launched an updated live photo feed, allowing users to experience live events more effectively, a move that aims to beat Twitter's text-based updates. The new feature, which began rolling out on Tuesday, uses a stream of photos and videos to bring users closer to current events. Instagram CEO Kevin Systrom believes this approach will provide a more immersive experience, especially for events like Taylor Swift's concerts and the Emanuel AME Church shooting memorials. The update also improves search functionality and features hand-selected collections to help users discover interesting content.

site_title: Is anyone home?
summary: Singapore's private residential property market shows a majority of condo developments remain dark at night, despite a "decent level of leasing activity." Half of the 10 projects sampled had been fully sold, but units in most developments remain unlit, indicating owners may be using them as holiday homes. Leasing activity is driven by expats and foreign buyers, particularly in upscale projects like Marina Bay Suites and The Vermont on Cairnhill. However, some suburban projects, such as NV Residences and Canberra Residences, show more local factors at play, with buyers often holding onto their HDB flats due to soft market conditions.

images.alt_text: Kalpana Rashiwala

site_title: Things are looking up for Canada oil firms
summary: Canada's oil firms are gaining traction as oil prices stabilize, signaling potential takeover targets. Companies like Teine Energy Ltd and Canbriam Energy Inc are experiencing significant gains in their bond market, with Teine returning 30% and Canbriam earning 13%. This resurgence is attributed to stable oil prices, which have risen 23% since March. Investors are taking notice, with bonds of private-equity backed firms becoming more attractive, according to Geof Marshall of CI Investments.

site_title: Asia-Euro Holidays saga: A cautionary tale for SMEs
summary: Asia-Euro Holidays, a family-run travel agent, abruptly closed in May, leaving 500 customers stranded. The company's downfall was attributed to S$2 million losses on property dealings, resulting from diversifying beyond its core business. This case serves as a cautionary tale for SMEs, highlighting the importance of treading carefully when venturing beyond their competencies. The incident underscores the risks of overextending and the need for companies to prioritize their core strengths.

site_title: Heinz sells US$10b of bonds for Kraft merger
summary: Heinz sells US$10 billion of bonds to finance its pending US$46 billion merger with Kraft, raising US$9 billion in dollars and up to US$11 billion across currencies. The bonds were priced at a 15-25 basis point discount from initial thoughts, with investors piling into the offering. The merger, backed by Warren Buffett's Berkshire Hathaway and 3G Capital, was announced in March and is seen as a convincing deal despite the strong demand.

site_title: Women in boardrooms: Singapore typical of South-east Asia peers
summary: Singapore has a low proportion of women in boardrooms, with just 9% of board seats held by women, lagging behind European economies like Norway, which has 37% women on boards. The energy and resources industry has the highest proportion of women, followed by financial services and technology. Deloitte attributes the gap to insufficient family support and traditional barriers. Local initiatives, such as BoardAgender, aim to raise awareness and promote gender diversity, but Singapore does not have gender quotas.

site_title: Amazon.com rumbles with Brazil, Peru on rights to Internet name
summary: Amazon.com has faced opposition from Brazil and Peru in its bid to secure a .amazon Internet domain. The company had applied for the domain in 2012, but was rejected due to concerns that it would detract from the Amazon biome. Two lawmakers have now intervened, arguing that Brazil and Peru do not have rights to the term "Amazon". Amazon has attempted to work with the governments on a compromise, but was rejected. The company may continue to pursue the domain, with Amazon vice-president Paul Misener stating that the company had tried to find a solution.

site_title: Qualcomm to make microchips with China firm
summary: China's largest microchip maker, SMIC, has partnered with Qualcomm and a Belgian microelectronics research centre to develop and produce advanced semiconductors for electronics products like smartphones and servers. The new company aims to help SMIC close the gap with rivals. This collaboration will focus on developing new generations of semiconductors, marking a significant move for SMIC to enhance its capabilities and compete globally.

site_title: Tsipras struggles to bridge gaps with Greece's creditors as markets turn nervous
summary: Greek Prime Minister Alexis Tsipras struggled to reach a deal with international creditors, presenting counter-proposals just hours before eurozone finance ministers were set to convene. The creditors demanded sweeping changes to tax and reform plans, while Tsipras sought to maintain his existing proposals. A deal is crucial to unlock aid and avoid a debt default next week. The negotiations were tense, with the creditors' proposals covering sensitive issues, leaving the outcome uncertain.

images.alt_text: The more concessions Mr Tsipras makes, the more resistance he will face in parliament within his leftist Syriza party and on the streets.

site_title: MAS raps SGX for market outage lapses
summary: The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) has reprimanded the Singapore Exchange (SGX) for its failure to meet service recovery standards during a three-hour market meltdown in November. The MAS has slapped a fee freeze on the exchange and ordered it to spend S$20 million on improving its tech infrastructure. The SGX has pledged to fully comply with MAS's directives, aiming to enhance its services and prevent future outages.

site_title: France tells US to stop spying on allied governments
summary: The US must respect its commitment not to spy on allied governments, President Francois Hollande's office stated after an emergency meeting. A WikiLeaks report revealed the US had spied on French leaders, including Hollande, Sarkozy, and Chirac, from 2006 to 2012. The French government considers the spying "unacceptable" and has summoned US Ambassador Jane Hartley. Despite the incident, French government spokesman Stephane Le Foll urged allies to show responsibility and not let the crisis escalate. No state secrets appear to have been breached, and the US National Security Council denied targeting French communications.

site_title: San Francisco has greatest risk for car thefts in US
summary: San Francisco has the highest rate of car thefts in the US, surpassing previous years, according to a report by the National Insurance Crime Bureau (NICB). California led the nation in stolen cars per person, with the Bakersfield and Stockton-Lodi areas ranking second and third.
