The Dow Jones Industrial Average and S&P 500 also rose, driven by positive data from the US and eurozone. Major European equities markets gained, and US data showed mixed results, including a surge in new home sales and durable goods orders. AT&T and UnitedHealth were top gainers, while Twitter and Microsoft fell.

site_title: Bank of England's Weale says British jobs market 'fizzing', eyes rate hike
summary: Bank of England policymaker Martin Weale says the UK's labour market is "fizzing away nicely" with wages growing faster than expected. This suggests he may vote for a rate hike as soon as August, according to an interview with the Financial Times. Weale's comments indicate the central bank is ready to raise rates to address economic growth, following a recent slowdown. His statement may prompt the BoE to consider a rate hike, potentially affecting the UK's economy and financial markets.

site_title: Takata halted safety audits amid airbag woes: report
summary: Takata, a Japanese auto parts maker, halted safety audits for two years at its factories making defective airbags linked to eight deaths. The halt occurred in 2009 at facilities in Mexico and Washington state. This comes ahead of a Senate Commerce Committee hearing on the exploding airbags, which can send deadly shrapnel into car occupants. The safety audits were suspended on facilities assembling and making the airbag inflators.

site_title: China presses US to invest more in its own economy
summary: Chinese Finance Minister Lou Jiwei urged the US to boost domestic savings and investment to strengthen growth, particularly in infrastructure. He countered US pressure to reduce China's reliance on foreign investment, citing China's 30% contribution to global growth. Lou emphasized the need for the US to save more and invest productively, while also accelerating structural reforms and increasing labor force participation. The US Treasury Secretary Jacob Lew expressed concerns over China's currency controls and cyber-hacking of US companies, which Lou deemed a security issue, not an economic topic.

site_title: Google Play enters free streaming with radio
summary: Google Play has launched a free internet radio service with curated channels tailored to specific times of day, such as "having friends over" and "having fun at work." The service will be supported by advertisements and available on Android phones and iPhones in the US. Google Play subscribers will have access to ad-free radio, while artists will receive royalties. The move puts Google Play in competition with other streaming services, including Pandora and Sirius XM, and may attract users of Spotify's free tier. The service is part of Google's efforts to expand its streaming offerings.

site_title: Instagram targets real-time events in Twitter challenge
summary: Instagram has introduced real-time trending topics and places into its mobile apps, competing with Twitter's domain. The Explore page now surfaces emerging trends, connecting users to events and conversations globally. This move aims to provide users with a more immersive experience, mirroring Twitter's approach. The feature is available in the US on Apple and Android devices.

site_title: Digiland unit in interested person transaction with Goodwood Associates
summary: Digiland International's subsidiary International Energy Group Pte Ltd entered into a US$1.498 million transaction with Goodwood Associates Pte Ltd, accounting for 4.77% of its net tangible assets. The transaction, valued at 4.77% of the company's net tangible assets, was deemed normal and not prejudicial to the company's interests by its audit committee. The trade was made through Goodwood to a customer and both parties shared the margins equally. Goodwood is wholly owned by Lee Soek Shen, an executive director at Digiland International.

images.alt_text: Mindy Tan

site_title: SATS' Japanese subsidiary bags 30b yen inflight catering contract from Delta
summary: SATS' Japanese subsidiary, TFK Corporation, secured a 30 billion yen (S$325 million) inflight catering contract from Delta Air Lines. The contract, expected to begin in October, re-establishes a 22-year relationship between the two companies. SATS, which owns 59.4% of TFK, welcomed Delta back after a merger with Northwest Airlines ended the partnership in 2009.

images.alt_text: Mindy Tan

site_title: Gloves off in China as banks, Alibaba invade each other's turf
summary: China's banks are launching online lending and e-commerce platforms to compete with Alibaba's MYbank and Alibaba's e-commerce sites, blurring the lines between banking and retail. Industrial & Commercial Bank of China (ICBC) has seen a 67% surge in transactions on its online mall, while Alibaba's Tmall logged 763 billion yuan in sales last year. The banks' moves aim to tap into Chinese savers' record deposits and offer valuable support to their core businesses. Revenue from online retailing is expected to reach 4 trillion yuan this year, with retail banking revenues doubling to 3.5 trillion yuan by 2020.

site_title: US issuing visas again, but warns of backlog
summary: The US has begun issuing visas again after a hardware problem caused a backlog, with 45,000 permits issued in the past day. The State Department has restored biometric data processing at 33 embassies and consulates, representing 66% of normal capacity. The issue, which emerged on June 9, had prevented processing of security-related biometric data checks. The backlog is expected to take time to clear, with significant numbers of visas to be issued, but interviews for applicants are being rescheduled.

site_title: Bali leads Indonesia promotion to lure tourists with free visas
summary: Indonesia is shifting its focus to promote Bali and nearby islands, such as Batam and Bintan, to attract more tourists, aiming to double international tourist numbers by 2020. The government has increased its marketing budget fourfold to promote these destinations, which generate 90% of the country's revenue from international tourists. This strategy follows infrastructure development, with plans to build a new airport and toll road in Bali. The move comes as Indonesia lags in revenue targets and growth in Southeast Asia's largest economy slows.

site_title: Branson unveils plans for 'boutique' cruise line
summary: Virgin Cruises, a luxury cruise line, will launch its first ship in 2020 from Miami, with three ships planned for delivery in 2020, 2021, and 2022. The boutique ships, weighing around 110,000 tonnes, will have a capacity for 2,800 passengers and 1,150 crew members. Virgin Cruises aims to redefine the cruising experience with an intimate, world-class experience appealing to both cruisers and non-cruisers. The venture is a joint effort with Bain Capital and will be the latest addition to Richard Branson's Virgin Group.

site_title: Euro sinks on dollar as confidence in Greece deal rises
summary: The euro fell 1.5% against the US dollar on Tuesday as investors gained confidence in a Greek debt deal, selling the currency for assets with better returns. The euro sank to $1.1168, amid signs of a possible breakthrough in the five-month stalemate over Greece's funding. Despite improved purchasing manager indices for France and Germany, the market focus remains on a potential US interest rate hike in September, which could further impact the euro. French Prime Minister Manuel Valls warned that much work remains to be done to beat the deadline for a deal between Greece, the IMF, and the EU.

site_title: Sale price of Martha Stewart Living disappoints shareholders
summary: Martha Stewart Living Omnimedia Inc agreed to sell itself to Sequential Brands Group Inc for $6.15 a share, or approximately $300 million after subtracting net cash. The deal, which was below expectations, left shareholders disappointed and valued the company at about half of Sequential Brands' own valuation. The sale comes after improvements under CEO Daniel Dienst, who set the company up for better profitability through increased merchandising and partnerships. The deal also gives Martha Stewart control over the brand and a seat on the board of the combined company.

site_title: Eurozone business growth hits 4-year high, boosted by Germany and France
summary: The eurozone's factory and services index reached a 4-year high in June, driven by strong growth in Germany and France. The composite index rose to 54.1, exceeding forecasts and surpassing the 50-mark that divides expansion from contraction. The eurozone economy is expected to expand by around 2% this year, despite the ongoing Greek debt crisis. European leaders have given Greek Prime Minister Alexis Tsipras' government 48 hours to make a final effort to satisfy creditors and end the 5-month stand-off.

site_title: Tenaga plans RM10b sukuk to fund power plant
summary: Malaysia's Tenaga Nasional Bhd plans to raise up to RM10 billion in an Islamic bond issue to fund a power plant project it will take over from debt-laden state fund 1MDB. The project, a 2,000 MW coal-fired plant, will take pressure off 1MDB and help the company focus on debt reduction. The bond, the largest sukuk globally this year, will finance Tenaga's planned purchase of 1MDB's 70% stake in the project, which is crucial for Malaysia's energy needs.

site_title: US wiretapped France's presidents: media citing WikiLeaks
summary: The US allegedly wiretapped former French presidents Jacques Chirac, Nicolas Sarkozy, and current leader Francois Hollande from 2006 to 2012, according to French media citing WikiLeaks documents. The documents include reports from the US National Security Agency on intercepted communications, with one revealing Hollande's approval of secret meetings to discuss the eurozone crisis. Neither Hollande's office nor the US government commented on the information, with the US State Department stating they do not comment on leaked documents. The revelation has sparked controversy and raised questions about US-France relations.

site_title: Manulife hires 3 executives in commercial property expansion
summary: Manulife Financial Corp has hired three executives to expand its commercial property strategy. Jenn Lundmark joins as head of real estate fundraising, while Sahezad Pardhan becomes global chief financial officer. Ken Pogrin takes on global head of business development and chief operating officer. The appointments aim to grow Manulife's private asset management business by 50% over the next five years, focusing on generating fee income from institutional clients.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: ABR Holdings has terminated its joint venture with Palate Group by mutual consent, buying back Palate Group's 49% stake in All Best Foods for S$2.94 million. LET plans to raise S$2.31 million through a private share placement to fund environmental projects. LionGold Corp saw Asiasons Investment cease to be a substantial shareholder after selling its stake. Ascott Residence Trust raised S$250 million from perpetual securities to fund potential acquisitions. Ezra Holdings has approved plans to raise up to US$300 million to repay debt.

site_title: Tackling maritime crime without going overboard
summary: The International Maritime Bureau and the Singapore Shipping Association (SSA) stress the importance of distinguishing between piracy and armed robbery when reporting incidents in South-east Asian waters. SSA found that 86% of incidents in the region were armed robberies, with only 14% classified as piracy. SSA advises merchant vessels to exercise high vigilance and conduct anti-boarding watches, and provides guidelines for protection against piracy and sea robbery. The situation in South-east Asia is considered different from the Gulf of Aden, where Somali pirates have been effectively prevented by naval patrols and armed security guards.

site_title: Singapore economy: Weak prices pose demand questions
summary: Singapore's core inflation remained at a five-year low of 0.1% in May, sparking debate over whether it's due to supply-side factors or weak demand. Economists are divided, with some attributing the decline to government policy measures, while others believe it reflects a deterioration in real demand. The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) and Ministry of Trade and Industry (MTI) attribute the decline to budgetary measures and softer food inflation. However, some economists warn that the decline in core inflation could undershoot the government's projection, necessitating another downgrade in the official forecast.

site_title: Manufacturing stabilising as durable orders rise in May
summary: US manufacturing spending plans showed a tentative sign of stabilisation in May, with non-defence capital goods orders rising 0.4% after a 0.3% drop in April. Despite this, the sector remains weak due to lower oil prices and a strong dollar, with the Federal Reserve expected to raise interest rates this year. The manufacturing sector moderated in June for the third month in a row, with new-home sales increasing to a seven-year high in May.

images.alt_text: A gauge of US business investment spending plans rose in May in a tentative sign of stabilisation in the manufacturing sector, which has been weak since the late summer of 2014.

site_title: Euro falls in face of higher US yields, Greek doubts
summary: The euro fell 1.2% to US$1.1203 against the US dollar, hurt by rising US bond yields and concerns over a potential Greek debt deal. Traders shifted focus to the US dollar, driven by a 5% rise in US housing sales and expectations of higher interest rates. Eurozone leaders agreed to try to wrap up a detailed Greek debt agreement by Wednesday evening, but analysts warn that the deal may not pass through the Greek parliament.

site_title: In Japan, ROE becomes the acid test
summary: In Japan, the return on equity (ROE) has become a key metric for asset managers and activist investors to gauge company performance, with Prime Minister Shinzo Abe's stewardship code encouraging investors to press for better returns. Naoki Fujiwara, a Tokyo-based fund manager, is now prioritizing ROE when meeting executives, with some 63% of investors believing better dialogue with managers is needed to improve company governance. Life insurers, such as Nippon Life, are also taking a more active role in voting against companies with low ROE, with some executives viewing ROE as their top management target.

images.alt_text: ROE on the Topix index averaged 6 per cent in the 10 years through 2013, compared with 12.6 per cent for the MSCI World Index. It's since risen to 8.2 per cent, against a global average of 11.5 per cent.

site_title: RafflesMed launches S$4 million centre in Orchard Road (Updated)
summary: Raffles Medical Group has launched a new S$4 million multi-disciplinary medical centre in Orchard Road, Singapore, to cater to a heavier patient load, particularly foreign patients. The 17,000 sqft centre offers traditional Chinese medicine services and a full spectrum of speciality services. The launch is expected to bring in more patients to spread fixed costs, with the facility led by a team of 30 and capable of serving up to 500 patients daily.

site_title: Greek deal hopes could face reality of political hurdles in Athens
summary: Greek Premier Alexis Tsipras must convince his anti-austerity party to approve concessions needed to unblock bailout funds, raising concerns about the country's debt deal. Despite optimism from EU Commissioner Pierre Moscovici, who said Greece is "very near" an agreement, the Greek government spokesman Gabriel Sakellaridis warned that the next 48 hours will be decisive. With exactly one week left to avoid default, Greece has submitted an 11th-hour reform plan to free up crucial funds from its international bailout. The outcome remains uncertain, casting doubt on the country's ability to avoid default.

images.alt_text: Hopes were high on Tuesday that Greece and its creditors can seal a debt deal with exactly one week left to avert default, but those could fade as the Greek premier must convince his anti-austerity party to approve concessions needed to unblock bailout funds.

site_title: Factory activity, Beige Book point to China's economy regaining momentum
summary: China's factory activity showed signs of stabilizing in June, with the HSBC/Markit Flash China Manufacturing PMI rising to a three-month high of 49.6. New orders returned to positive territory at 50.3, while new export orders fell at a slower pace. The China Beige Book survey, however, painted a more optimistic picture of a "broad-based recovery" led by interior provinces. Companies continued to cut staff, but policymakers are expected to step up easing measures to stimulate growth and job creation.

images.alt_text: The HSBC/Markit flash PMI edged up to 49.6 in June, a three-month high, from 49.2. New orders returned to positive territory at 50.3 and new export orders fell at a much slower pace.

site_title: Navigating the soft industrial property market
summary: Singapore's industrial property market is softening due to government intervention measures and economic restructuring, affecting real estate investment trust AIMS AMP Capital Industrial Reit (AA Reit). To safeguard its bottom line, the Reit is focusing on pre-committing leases, adding data centers to its tenant mix, and renovating facilities. CEO Koh Wee Lih aims to retain tenants by offering a "flight to quality" and is exploring growth through acquisitions, including build-to-suit opportunities and traditional acquisitions in Singapore and Australia.

site_title: US Supreme Court stands by precedent in Spider-Man toy patent case
summary: The US Supreme Court upheld a 1964 precedent in a patent case involving a Spider-Man toy, ruling 6-3 against inventor Stephen Kimble. Kimble had signed an unfavorable contract with Marvel Entertainment, which was later found to be in conflict with the 1964 decision, Brulotte versus Thys Co. The court concluded that patents only grant limited powers and that the use of precedent should be cautious, citing a quote from a 1962 Spider-Man comic book. The decision left in place the 1964 ruling and ruled against Kimble.

site_title: Flooding of US Plains helps boost farmers' income
summary: Floods in the US Plains have brought relief to farmers and ranchers, breaking a years-long drought that had negatively impacted agriculture. The record rains have boosted yields, reduced feed costs, and lowered hay prices. However, the floods also caused damage and may lower wheat protein levels, raising disease risk. The drought's impact is expected to be short-lived, with an El Nino weather pattern bringing cooler temperatures and rain to the region. Despite the initial damage, the US government's crop insurance claims for droughts are typically higher than those for floods.

site_title: Taiwan finance minister welcomes US Federal Reserve rate increase
summary: Taiwan's Finance Minister Chang Sheng-ford welcomed the US Federal Reserve's interest rate increase, seeing it as a positive sign for the US economy and Taiwan's exports. The rate hike is expected to have a short-term negative impact on Taiwan's economy but a long-term positive effect. Taiwan's central bank is unlikely to raise interest rates despite the US move, citing weak export orders and uncertainties in Europe and China.

site_title: Glossy finish, but basics lacking in mobile-banking services here (Amended)
summary: Singapore banks' mobile banking services lack basic features, such as fraud reporting and cross-selling, according to a Forrester Research report. The four banks - DBS, OCBC, UOB, and Standard Chartered Bank - scored an average of 51 out of 100, with DBS leading at 59 and UOB lagging at 43. The report highlights the need for banks to prioritize customers' needs before incorporating innovative features.

site_title: Sanctions on Russia show bright side as corporates push to cut debt
summary: Sanctions on Russia have led to a decrease in the nation's corporate debt, with Eurobond issuance dwindling to $77 million in 2015 compared to $28 billion in 2013. This reduction is attributed to companies being forced to re-think their funding strategies due to the sanctions. As a result, corporate bonds from Russia pay the highest yields among emerging markets, with some investors seeking to capitalize on the gains. However, the sanctions' impact is tempered by the need for top Russian companies to refinance $30 billion of external debt by the end of 2015.

site_title: Thailand expects record tourist arrivals this year, thanks to China
summary: Thailand expects a record 29.5 million tourists this year, up 19% from 2014, with China accounting for 10% of the economy. China's tourists are expected to reach 7.45 million, a 62% increase. The growth is attributed to the military-led government's restoration of stability. The Thai government has also taken steps to address complaints from Chinese tourists, including issuing Chinese-language etiquette manuals. However, the country has confirmed its first case of the Middle East Respiratory Syndrome (MERS) virus.

site_title: PM Lee opens PSA's S$3.5b Pasir Panjang development
summary: Singapore Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong officially opened the S$3.5 billion Pasir Panjang terminal development, adding 15 mega containership berths. The new berths, set to be fully operational in 2017, will handle up to a million containers per year, increasing the terminal's capacity. The project marks the 43rd anniversary of the arrival of the first containership in Singapore.

site_title: IBM, GM chiefs raise women's profile at annual US media conference
summary: IBM CEO Ginni Rometty and General Motors CEO Mary Barra attended Allen & Co's Sun Valley Conference, highlighting the growing presence of female and non-media attendees. The conference also featured other notable women, including Sara Blakely, Sheryl Sandberg, and Ursula Burns, but still had fewer than 25 women out of over 300 attendees.

site_title: Oracle looking to compete with Amazon's cloud services
summary: Oracle is expanding its cloud-computing offerings, competing directly with Amazon's services. Oracle Corp founder Larry Ellison announced the move in a webcast presentation, stating the company is prepared to compete on price. The new cloud platform, called Oracle Cloud Platform, will offer cost-effective alternatives to Amazon's offerings, including online storage and archive storage services at lower prices. This marks a major shift for Oracle, which is transitioning its traditional database and CRM businesses to the cloud, directly challenging Amazon's market leadership.

images.alt_text: "Our new archive storage service goes head-to-head with Amazon Glacier and it's one-tenth their price," says Mr Ellison

site_title: Fed's Powell puts odds of Sept rate hike at about 50%
summary: Fed governor Jerome Powell stated that the odds of a September interest rate hike are about 50%, driven by improved job market and signs of wage growth, and inflation returning to 2%. This forecast assumes stronger growth than in the first half of the year, giving the Federal Reserve a "greater basis for confidence".

site_title: US cancer body unveils method to evaluate treatments
summary: The American Society of Clinical Oncology unveiled a new "value framework" to evaluate cancer treatments, considering effectiveness, side effects, and costs. The framework assigns a score, called the net health benefit, ranging from 0 to 130, with 80 points based on life-prolonging effects, 20 on side effects, and 30 on symptom relief. The move aims to address the high cost of cancer drugs, with prices averaging $10,000 a month, and some costing up to $30,000. The framework is a proposed methodology that will be revised based on public comments.

site_title: Asia equity dividend funds see surge in inflows
summary: Asia equity dividend funds have seen a surge in inflows, with around $2.1 billion invested in the first five months of 2015, four times the amount from the previous year. The funds are attracting investors seeking higher yields than bonds but lower risk than direct stock purchases. Low interest rates and new investment opportunities in South Korea, such as a law taxing excess corporate cash, are contributing to the growth. Funds like the OkasanAM Asia Oceania Good Dividend Growth and the Value Partners High-Dividend Stocks Fund are among the top recipients of these investments.

site_title: India plans to lower costs for e-payments, spur cashless economy
summary: India plans to lower transaction costs for electronic payments to spur a cashless economy, aiming to reduce the country's reliance on cash and increase public revenue. The government recommends tax concessions to reduce costs, with proposals to be implemented gradually after June 29. The move is expected to boost global and domestic card companies, as well as mobile payment banks. The plan is part of Prime Minister Narendra Modi's drive to deepen the financial system and deter fraud.

site_title: Squatting in skinny jeans poses health risk
summary: Australian doctors warn that squatting in super-tight "skinny" jeans poses a health risk, citing a case of a 35-year-old woman who temporarily lost feeling in her legs after hours of squatting. The woman's legs swelled, and she was hospitalized after cutting off the jeans due to numbness and loss of control. Doctors attributed the issue to reduced blood supply and damaged nerve fibers from prolonged compression. The case highlights a new neurological complication of wearing tight jeans.

images.alt_text: A model for skinny jeans, showing off its flattering cut. A 35-year-old collapsed and had to be hospitalised the day after helping a relative move home, spending hours in her skinny jeans. Doctors said that the jeans, combined with her squatting, had reduced blood supply to the leg muscles.

site_title: Obama-term trade deal a 'heavy lift': EU envoy
summary: The US and European Union face a challenging task to achieve a free trade deal before President Barack Obama's term ends in January 2017, according to the EU's ambassador to the US. David O'Sullivan described the deal as a "heavy lift" and noted that the US presidential election could hinder progress. Despite German Chancellor Angela Merkel's hopes for a deal by the end of the year, concerns about consumer protection standards and geostrategic importance may hinder negotiations.

site_title: New Zealand grounds all flights after radar failure
summary: New Zealand grounded all flights after a radar failure prompted authorities to halt commercial flights nationwide. The outage occurred at 2:40 pm local time due to an internal network fault. Operations resumed about two hours later after the system was restored, with safety never compromised. Hundreds of passengers were stranded, but aircraft were permitted to land during the outage. The incident was resolved within half an hour of the system being restored, with full services resumed shortly after.

images.alt_text: Air New Zealand said some 160 international and domestic flights were impacted by the radar failure. Flights were delayed across the country.

site_title: Wider yuan trading band seen in China push for reserve status
summary: China is expected to widen its yuan trading band, but it will be a largely symbolic move as the government tightens its grip on the exchange rate. 14 out of 24 analysts surveyed predict a wider band, with 19 forecasting a daily trading band expansion to 3% in the next adjustment. The move is seen as a step towards China's goal of getting the yuan recognized as a reserve currency, with the next five-yearly review scheduled for October. The yuan's close at 6.2095 a dollar is 1.6% off the reference rate, and analysts expect the currency to stay around that level through the next 12 months.

site_title: Takata stopped safety audits as cost-saving move: US Senate report
summary: A US Senate report reveals that Takata, the Japanese airbag manufacturer, halted global safety audits in 2009 to save money, despite quality problems at its manufacturing plants. The audits were restarted in 2011, revealing issues such as propellant being left on the assembly line floor, which could lead to instability. The report also found that Takata's safety director downplayed concerns and created a false appearance of a safety committee. Takata disputes the findings, claiming the audits were unrelated to product quality or safety. The company has recalled 32 million vehicles due to defective airbags linked to at least eight deaths and over 100 injuries.

site_title: AirAsia buffeted in India by price wars and stringent rules
summary: AirAsia India, a budget carrier, is struggling to expand in the Indian market due to stringent regulations and price wars. Despite its initial focus on smaller cities, the airline has now started flying routes from New Delhi, aiming to increase visibility and attract more customers. The airline faces challenges from competitors like IndiGo, which commands a 40% market share, and is also burdened by high taxes on aviation turbine fuel, which accounts for over half of its operating costs. The airline is seeking reforms to reduce costs and promote growth, but faces resistance from the government ministries.

site_title: Singapore SME sentiment at its lowest since 2013
summary: Singapore's small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) have reported their lowest business sentiment since 2013, with a business confidence index falling for the third consecutive quarter. The SBF-DP SME Index measures SMEs' outlook for the next six months and has dropped from 54.0 to 53.5. Despite the decline, the index remains above 50, indicating a positive outlook. Four of six industries tracked by the index reported less optimistic outlooks, but the construction sector saw a slight rise in business confidence. Experts attribute the decline to hiring pressures and uncertainties in the global economy.

images.alt_text: Lincoln Teo, chief operating officer of DP Information Group: "We believe that despite demand, hiring pressures have forced some SMEs to cut back their capacity, resulting in a moderation of expectations for the next two quarters."
Mindy Tan

site_title: No sharing of stage for Swiss giants Credit Suisse, UBS
summary: Swiss banks Credit Suisse and UBS have long been fierce rivals, but since the 2008 crisis, they have shifted their focus from investment banking to private banking. Credit Suisse, the fourth-biggest private bank by assets under management, has been trying to catch up to UBS, which has shrunk its investment bank and focused on wealth management. Despite this, investors have rewarded UBS for its strategy, with its shares up 36% since 2008, while Credit Suisse's are down 7%. Credit Suisse chose not to sponsor the Innovation in Finance conference, instead inviting bankers from non-competitors, due to the intense rivalry.

site_title: HY Realty makes top bid of S$483m for Dundee Road site
summary: HY Realty emerged as the top bidder for the Dundee Road site in Singapore, with a provisional offer of S$483.18 million (S$871.14 psf ppr). The bid, 8.4% higher than the second-highest offer from Allgreen Properties, marks a shift by HY Realty's owners from suburban to city-fringe homes. The 700-unit condominium project is expected to launch in Q1 2016, capitalizing on the site's proximity to Queenstown MRT Station.

site_title: Brokers' take
summary: GuocoLand is on track to achieve a more sustainable return on equity by expanding its recurrent income base, starting from FY17. The company is evaluating options for its Beijing Dongzhimen project, including divesting or revaluing it. Analysts value the stock at S$3.84-S$4.63 per share, citing growing residential solar systems in Singapore, driven by decreasing costs and increased consumer flexibility. However, the rooftop solar market's growth is capped by limited land space and the absence of a feed-in tariff.

site_title: European oil industry pulls a volte-face to save the climate
summary: European oil giants Royal Dutch Shell, BP, Total, Eni, Statoil, and BG have published an open letter in support of efforts to put a cost on polluting, acknowledging they were on the wrong side of history. This historic shift marks a significant change in the industry's stance on climate change, as the companies recognize the need for action to counter global warming. The move is seen as a major victory for environmental groups, but it may also lead to losses for other industries, such as coal mining and natural gas producers.

site_title: Keppel FELS, Sembcorp Marine deny allegations of Brazil bribery
summary: Keppel FELS and Sembcorp Marine have denied allegations of participating in Brazil's bribery scandal involving deep-water drilling vessel contracts worth around $800 million. The allegations claim the companies paid bribes through intermediaries to secure the contracts. The companies firmly dispute the claims, stating they did not engage in any improper activities. No further action has been taken against the companies.

site_title: US-listed Chinese firms seek exit for better valuations back home
summary: US-listed Chinese companies are seeking to exit the US market to gain higher valuations in China, with 23 companies receiving takeover bids since January. However, some US investors claim the offers undervalue the stocks, leading to rallies in their shares. The offers have resulted in a 24% premium over pre-announcement trading prices, but 60% of the bids are below the companies' initial public offerings. This trend follows China's economic growth and widening market access to foreign investors, with the Shanghai Composite Index surging 121% in the past 12 months.

site_title: Global premium travel up 4.9% but growth trend stays weak, says Iata
summary: International Air Transport Association (IATA) reports that global premium travel increased 4.9% in April, with the growth trend remaining fragile due to slowing global economic growth. Economy traffic grew 3.7% and overall total traffic 3.8% in the same month. The IATA notes that economic weakness in Asia, particularly in business-related air travel, poses downside risks for growth, but demand remains strong in the Far East, Europe, and the United States, with premium traffic growth in these regions reaching 11.9%, 5.4%, and 6.9% respectively.

images.alt_text: Nisha Ramchandani

site_title: Google's online lab offers tools for news reporting
summary: Google has launched the News Lab, an online lab offering tools and tutorials for news reporting and storytelling. The lab, which includes lessons on research, reporting, and analytics, aims to collaborate with journalists and entrepreneurs to apply technology innovations to news reporting. The initiative is a global effort with teams in multiple countries, and is part of Google's broader efforts to empower new voices in the media and reimagine the future of news reporting.

site_title: Facebook wants advertisers to employ data more effectively
summary: Facebook is pushing advertisers to use its vast user data more effectively, encouraging creative tactics such as distributing different ad versions based on viewer interests. The company aims to increase its share of the $145 billion global advertising market by highlighting its data capabilities. Facebook will train marketers on ad ideas at the Cannes Lions festival and expand its targeting data on Instagram, allowing for more precise ad targeting. This move is expected to deliver a better return on investment for marketers.

site_title: Eight truths about Greece and what the future holds
summary: A recent article provides eight key truths about Greece and its future. The truths include Greece's ongoing economic struggles, the need for austerity measures, and the country's efforts to reform its economy. The article also highlights the complexities of Greece's relationships with the European Union and other global powers. The future of Greece remains uncertain, with ongoing debates about its economic future and its place in the global community. The article aims to provide a concise guide for observers to navigate the complexities of Greece's situation.

site_title: Asiasons Investment sells off indirect stake in LionGold Corp
summary: Asiasons Investment has sold off its 3.27% deemed stake in LionGold Corp, leaving it with a 1.84% direct interest in the company. Asiasons Investment, previously a substantial shareholder, sold its indirect stake via its subsidiary Vibrant Coast Management on June 19. This sale reduces its interest in LionGold Corp to 2.22% along with its managing director Jared Lim and Ng Teck Wah.

site_title: Shipping bond tests foreign investors' faith in Joko's revival plan
summary: Indonesian shipping company PT Soechi Lines is issuing a $200 million five-year dollar bond, marking the first dollar bond from the country's industry in over five years. The move is seen as a test of foreign investors' faith in President Joko Widodo's plan to revitalize the shipping sector with $6 billion in port infrastructure. The bond's success may indicate investors' confidence in the government's economic revival plan, which aims to boost trade amid the country's slowest economic growth in six years.

images.alt_text: Ongoing construction at Kalibaru Container Port; Mr Joko plans to link industrial centres in Jakarta to a new port in the capital and wants to start building four more ports in October.

site_title: Free to good owner - Sicily town gives away homes
summary: A Sicilian town, Gangi, is giving away abandoned homes to people who can restore them in four years. The town, which has seen significant depopulation, is offering the homes to attract new residents and boost local economy. Over 100 houses have been given away or sold for less than market prices, with a mix of Sicilians and international buyers taking advantage of the offer. The initiative has brought fresh opportunities to local builders and tradesmen, and has revitalized tourism in the town.

images.alt_text: Gangi's offer has already lured dozens of holiday home hunters from around the world, and its novel approach to revival has brought fresh opportunities to local builders and tradesmen while energising tourism.

site_title: Hike in Singtel CEO's pay is not based on profits alone
summary: Singtel CEO's FY2015 pay increased by 19% to S$5.6m, driven by out-performance against plans and targets, not profits alone. The company has a pay-for-performance philosophy that measures and rewards short-term, mid-term, and long-term performance. This includes a value-sharing bonus and performance shares tied to total shareholder returns. The compensation framework ensures alignment between compensation and performance, and Singtel's CEO is benchmarked against comparable businesses. The company's chairman, Simon Israel, defended the CEO's pay policy, citing the creation of considerable shareholder value despite the CEO's pay increase.

site_title: Ambitious or not, Paris must deliver climate deal
summary: The UN climate talks in Paris are at a critical juncture, with world leaders struggling to reach a deal to limit global warming to 2 degrees Celsius. Despite eight years of negotiations, progress has been slow, with only five of 89-page draft text agreed upon. The US, China, and India are among nations yet to make their contributions, and developing countries require substantial finance to curb emissions and build resilience. A deal is expected by December, but a weak treaty may require raising ambition through regular reviews, and the US Senate must support a legally binding treaty.

site_title: Jakarta may ease curbs on foreign ownership for Islamic banks
summary: Indonesia's financial regulator is considering easing foreign ownership restrictions for Islamic banks, which could attract Middle Eastern lenders. The current rule limits overseas banks to owning 40% of Indonesian lenders, but may be relaxed for banks planning to convert Indonesian lenders to Islamic banks. A relaxation of the rule could help Bahrain-based Al Baraka Banking Group enter Indonesia's Islamic banking sector by 2016, according to the regulator.

site_title: US, Gulf carriers' dispute over subsidies at impasse
summary: US airlines American Airlines, Delta Air Lines, and United Continental Holdings claim Persian Gulf carriers Emirates, Etihad Airways, and Qatar Airways receive $42 billion in subsidies, allowing them to compete unfairly. The US airlines are petitioning the government to enforce trade laws and review Open Skies air treaties. Gulf carriers deny receiving subsidies, saying the US airlines are trying to bully them. The dispute has reached an impasse, with American Airlines' CEO Doug Parker saying it should be taken up at the government level, not by CEOs.

images.alt_text: "We've agreed to disagree and I think this now belongs with governments, not CEOs," said Mr Parker

site_title: Credit Suisse dismisses Argentina bond alarm over next president
summary: Credit Suisse dismisses concerns over Argentina's next president, stating that whoever replaces Cristina Fernandez de Kirchner will have to roll back her most-damaging economic decisions to restore growth and encourage foreign investment. Despite Buenos Aires Governor Daniel Scioli naming Ms Fernandez's confidante Carlos Zannini as his running mate, Credit Suisse strategist Daniel Chodos recommends holding Argentina's 2015 dollar-denominated bonds, citing attractive price levels and limited risk premium. Analysts disagree, with Barclays cutting its recommendation to neutral and Noctua Capital's Luis Caputo speculating that Zannini's nomination may boost opposition candidate Mauricio Macri's chances.

site_title: Pint-size jets target market gap created by Bombardier ambitions
summary: The Dornier 328, a 30-50 seat jet aircraft, is set to resume assembly after the Turkish government signed an order for 50 TR-Jet aircraft. The plane, last built in 2004, will initially serve eastern Turkey but could fill a gap in the market for airlines needing a smaller aircraft. Emerging economies and established airlines are seeking lower-capacity options, with demand expected to rise from 5,000 small regional aircraft still flying. Sierra Nevada Corp aims for 500 orders, including a possible 50-60 seat variant dubbed the 628.

site_title: Noble should pay heed to its corporate governance
summary: Noble Group faces criticism for its corporate governance practices, including its board of directors and remuneration policy. The company's board of 12 members has a high proportion of independent directors with a banking background, raising concerns about diversity and expertise. The appointment of a new independent director, Paul Jeremy Brough, has been questioned, as it appears to be part of an "old boys' network" and lacks relevant experience in the commodities industry. Noble is also opaque about the remuneration of its directors and senior executives, and its disclosures on financial reporting quality are lacking. The company has promised to improve transparency, but critics argue that it must also address its corporate governance issues to regain investors' confidence.

images.alt_text: Noble's board is still larger than it needs to be, and in its case, its bigger pool of directors does not translate into better diversity.

site_title: Australia crocodile safaris may be possible by year end
summary: Australia's government considers allowing crocodile safaris, potentially generating revenue for Aboriginal communities. The move comes after a 2014 ban on trophy hunts, with Indigenous Affairs Minister Nigel Scullion arguing that aboriginal communities should sell permits to shoot saltwater crocodiles. The proposal has sparked controversy, with conservationists opposing the idea, citing concerns about animal welfare and safety.

site_title: Ramsay opens his marquee UK restaurant at MBS
summary: Gordon Ramsay's Bread Street Kitchen in Singapore, a partnership with the Marina Bay Sands, officially opened last Friday. The 48-year-old chef, who has a vested interest in Singapore, is excited to be in the city-state, citing its incredible dining scene. The menu is similar to the one in London but with local flavors. Ramsay emphasizes the importance of getting it right, tweaking the menu daily, and has already taken items off the menu due to poor quality. He also discusses his passion for promoting female chefs and addressing the issue of young chefs burning out.

images.alt_text: Tay Suan Chiang

site_title: Thai unit of AirAsia X to suspend flights to Sapporo
summary: Thai AirAsia X will suspend flights from Bangkok to Sapporo, Japan, starting August 1, due to a downgrade of Thailand's aviation safety rating by the International Civil Aviation Organization. The airline will continue to operate flights to Tokyo and Osaka, and Seoul. Passengers who have booked flights from July 31 can switch to an earlier travel date, change destination, or receive a full refund. This decision follows concerns raised by China and South Korea about safety concerns and the Thai authorities' failure to address them.

site_title: Foreign investors still keen on East Asia bonds
summary: Foreign investors remain keen on East Asia bonds, with net foreign capital flows into emerging East Asia's local currency (LCY) government bond market remaining positive in Q1 2015. Despite the strengthening US dollar, foreign investor interest in local currency government bonds remained upbeat, with Malaysia and South Korea seeing notable rises in capital inflows. Foreign holdings in Indonesia and Malaysia rose to 38.6% and 33% respectively, but the ADB warns that risks, including a sudden US rate hike and increased liquidity, could trigger volatility in the region's bond markets.

site_title: HK voting fiasco presages tightening of Beijing's control
summary: The Hong Kong government's electoral reform package failed to pass in the Legislative Council, blocking Beijing's plan for "one man, one vote" elections for chief executive in 2017. Instead, a 1,200-member election committee will continue to decide. The package received only eight votes, falling short of the required two-thirds majority, after a last-minute manoeuvre by Beijing supporters. The outcome preserves Beijing's control over Hong Kong's electoral process, raising concerns about the city's autonomy.

site_title: Wall St says goodbye to a towering figure
summary: James Lee Jr., the 62-year-old vice-chairman of JPMorgan Chase, died after collapsing while exercising at his home in Connecticut. Lee was remembered as a brilliant deal maker, a father, a friend, and a generous spirit who championed diverse causes. He pioneered the syndicated loan market, securing major deals for corporate chieftains and private equity heads. His colleagues, including JPMorgan CEO Jamie Dimon, praised his boundless energy, sprawling interests, and unbridled enthusiasm. Lee's funeral mass was held at St. Patrick's Cathedral in Manhattan, attended by notable figures from the financial world and beyond.

site_title: Regional markets up on Greece hopes
summary: Singapore stocks rose 0.74% on Tuesday, driven by hopes of a Greek debt deal, with the Straits Times Index (STI) up 24.65 points to close at 3,339.78. Gainers outnumbered losers 232 to 196, with offshore oilfield service provider Ezra Holdings and telecommunications company Singtel being active. Analysts see potential for a spillover effect from a Greek default, but believe Singapore's financial institutions are prepared.

images.alt_text: A Greek national flag flutters next to statues of ancient Goddess Athena (left) and God Apollo atop the Athens Academy on June 10, 2015.

site_title: Turkey central bank resists government pressure for post-election cuts
summary: Turkey's central bank maintained interest rates unchanged, resisting government pressure for post-election cuts. The decision comes despite predictions of a near-term decline in inflation, as the bank maintains a cautious policy. The move is seen as a challenge to the ruling AK Party, which failed to win a majority in the June 7 election. The bank cited a need to ensure financial stability and prevent inflation from rising despite the economic uncertainty.

site_title: Short-sellers lose their voice
summary: Short-sellers, who bet against stocks, have largely lost their voice as the stock market rallies. Despite being vocal critics of market froth and company fraud, many hedge fund managers are now hesitant to speak out, as investors seek to capitalize on the rally. This shift is largely driven by the six-year bull market in the US, which has broken numerous records. As a result, short-sellers are being priced out of the market, and their influence is diminishing.

site_title: Fighting climate change could save lives, money: US report
summary: A US government report found that taking action against global warming by reducing greenhouse gas emissions could save thousands of lives and avoid major economic losses by the end of the century. The report estimates tens of thousands of American lives could be saved annually, and hundreds of billions of dollars in economic losses could be avoided. Global action on climate change could reduce the frequency of extreme weather events, such as heat waves and floods, and save money through measures like road maintenance and coastal adaptation.

site_title: Ivanhoe Cambridge leads investment in China developer
summary: Ivanhoe Cambridge, the real estate arm of Canada's Caisse de depot et placement du Quebec, led a US$920 million capital raising for Shanghai developer Chongbang Group, investing US$500 million. This marks Ivanhoe Cambridge's second institutional capital raising in Chongbang, which has developed seven retail-anchored lifestyle projects in China and plans future mixed-use developments. The investment is part of Canada's pension funds' increasing focus on higher-yield real estate abroad, with US$13.5 billion invested globally last year.

site_title: 23,000 species threatened with extinction
summary: The International Union for the Conservation of Nature (IUCN) has warned that nearly 23,000 species are threatened with extinction, including the lion, cave crabs of Bali and New Zealand sea lion. However, some species, such as the Iberian lynx and Guadalupe fur seal, have seen population increases due to conservation efforts. The IUCN urges increased efforts to save species at risk, citing successes in conservation as evidence that "effective conservation can yield outstanding results."

site_title: Europe: Stocks extend gains with Greece deal in sight
summary: European stocks rose on Tuesday, extending gains from the previous day's sharp rally, as hopes for a deal on Greece's bailout grew. The CAC 40 in Paris climbed 1.18%, the DAX 30 in Frankfurt rose 0.72%, and Athens' main index surged 6.1%. The eurozone business activity index reached a four-year high, and the European Central Bank increased emergency liquidity funds for Greece's banks. The optimism persisted despite the euro's decline to $1.1188, with Asian stocks also rising on encouraging Chinese data and hopes for a Greek deal.

site_title: Korean bond yields seen jumping on Mers stimulus
summary: South Korea's bond market is expected to see a jump in yields due to the government's plan to introduce a new stimulus package to boost the economy amid the Middle East Respiratory Syndrome (Mers) outbreak. Analysts estimate the package could be worth up to 25 trillion won, with the benchmark 10-year yield potentially rising to 2.60% this month. The move aims to address weak exports and domestic demand, with some estimates suggesting a boost of 0.9 percentage point to growth.

site_title: US factory activity growth at slowest since October 2013: Markit
summary: US factory activity growth slowed to its lowest pace since October 2013, according to a report by Markit. The Manufacturing Purchasing Managers' Index declined to 53.4 in June, below economists' forecasts of 54.2. Despite a jobs growth in June, the slowdown was driven by deteriorating export performance, attributed to the stronger US dollar. The index's output component and new orders also decreased. This weak reading raises concerns about the economy's momentum heading into the third quarter.

site_title: US airs concerns in China meetings, stresses need for progress
summary: The US and China held annual talks in Washington, discussing concerns over state-sponsored cyber theft and territorial claims in the South China Sea. US Vice President Joe Biden emphasized the importance of the relationship, stating the world depends on their mutual success. China expressed a desire for constructive relations and said differences could be managed through mutual respect and accommodation. The talks aim to ease tensions and focus on areas of cooperation, including climate change and global development, ahead of President Xi Jinping's visit to Washington in September.

site_title: Share productivity gains with workers: National Wages Council chairman
summary: Singapore's National Wages Council chairman, Peter Seah, urged employers to share productivity gains with workers in a fair and sustainable manner. He emphasized the need for training workers to acquire skills that can boost productivity. Seah also supported the Government's SkillsFuture initiative, which aims to deepen Singaporeans' skills. Employers should consider training their workers to contribute to productivity gains, Seah advised.

site_title: SingTel chairman Israel comes out to bat for CEO's pay policy
summary: SingTel chairman Simon Israel defended the company's CEO pay policy, stating that compensation is determined by performance and not just profit. CEO Chua Sock Koong's total compensation for 2015 was S$5.59 million, with a 11% increase. Israel noted that the bonus can be clawed back if SingTel doesn't deliver sustainable value. The company reported a 3.5% increase in net income and a 25% total shareholder return, outperforming the Straits Times Index and MSCI Asia-Pacific Telco Index. Israel emphasized that compensation is benchmarked against comparable businesses to create shareholder value.

site_title: No Grexit for now but the need for some debt relief will be inescapable
summary: Greece's creditors and the Greek government appear close to a deal that will prevent a default and "Grexit." The agreement, which includes reforms and austerity measures, would unlock much-needed financing and allow Greece to meet its immediate payments to creditors. However, the deal is likely to be temporary, and Greece's debt burden remains unsustainable. The IMF has supported debt relief, but creditors have refused, and European governments will need to address the reality of Greece's unpayable debt.

site_title: Mobile gaming revenues in South-east Asia seen exceeding US$7b
summary: Mobile gaming revenues in South-east Asia are projected to exceed $7 billion by 2019, driven by the adoption of smartphones and tablets, according to Frost & Sullivan. The region's mobile gaming industry grew 70-90% in the last two years, with a compound annual growth rate (CAGR) of 48% from 2015 to 2019. Android dominates the market due to affordability, but game developers face challenges from fragmented operating systems and limited payment channels.

images.alt_text: A setup screen for The Hobbit: Kingdoms Of Middle-Earth, developed by Kabam Inc, on an Apple iPad Mini. Tablets generate a gaming average revenue per user (ARPU) 4.2 times that of smartphones.

site_title: Market watchdogs push back against central banks
summary: Market regulators are pushing back against central banks' attempts to impose bank-style rules on market players, citing concerns over higher trading costs and reduced liquidity. The Financial Stability Board's proposal to regulate asset managers has been met with resistance from market supervisors, who argue that markets can be volatile and that intervention can encourage risk-taking. The issue is becoming increasingly pressing as interest rates are expected to rise in the US, sparking concerns over bond market volatility. Market regulators are seeking to defend their turf and ensure that regulators focus on fire-proofing banks rather than stifling risk-taking in markets.

site_title: 3M strikes US$1.8b deal for KKR's Capital Safety
summary: 3M Co has agreed to buy protection equipment company Capital Safety from private equity firm KKR & Co for US$1.8 billion, its largest US acquisition. The deal will expand 3M's personal safety business and is valued at US$2.5 billion, including net debt. The acquisition is expected to close in the third quarter and will hurt earnings per share by 4 cents in the first 12 months. This deal surpasses 3M's previous acquisition of filtration company Cuno 10 years ago.

images.alt_text: 3M Co said on Tuesday that it would buy protection equipment company Capital Safety from private equity firm KKR & Co for US$1.8 billion, the largest acquisition in the US diversified manufacturer's history.

site_title: US new home sales rise to seven-year high in May
summary: US single-family home sales rose 2.2% to a 7-year high in May, reaching a seasonally adjusted annual rate of 546,000 units. This is the highest level since February 2008. The increase further brightens the outlook for the housing market and the broader economy, driven by a strengthening jobs market and easing lending conditions for first-time buyers. The stock of new houses for sale remained at 206,000, and it would take 4.5 months to clear the supply at the current sales pace.

site_title: Ezra's shareholders approve plans to issue rights issue and convertible bonds
summary: Ezra Holdings' shareholders have approved plans to raise up to $300 million through a rights issue and convertible bonds to repay existing debt. The group aims to raise $150 million from the rights issue and $200 million from the convertible bonds issue, mainly to repay $225 million fixed rate notes and $150 million perpetual securities due in September.

site_title: US core capital goods orders rise; transportation orders fall
summary: US core capital goods orders rose 0.4% in May, a tentative sign of stabilization in the manufacturing sector after a weak start to the year. However, the effects of lower oil prices and a strong dollar will continue to constrain factory activity. This rebound is a positive development, but the lingering impacts on the manufacturing sector are expected to last.

site_title: Toyota offices raided by police over arrest of executive: source
summary: Toyota's Tokyo offices were raided by police over the arrest of its communications chief, Julie Hamp, on suspicion of illegally bringing painkillers into Japan. Hamp, the company's first senior female executive, apologized after her arrest and claimed she brought the drugs to treat knee pain. Toyota President Akio Toyoda expressed support for Hamp, stating the company was confident the investigation would show she had not intended to break any laws. The company is cooperating with police, but a Toyota spokesman declined to comment further.

site_title: Malaysia's Petronas Chemicals' silo catches fire
summary: A fire occurred at one of Petronas Chemicals' silos in Terengganu, Malaysia, on June 23, 2015. The incident, which started at 0900 GMT, is confined to the affected silo and did not cause any casualties or injuries. Production at other Petronas Chemicals plants remains unaffected. Shares of Petronas Chemicals Group closed 0.16% higher on the day.

site_title: European markets surge on hopes of at least a fudged Greek deal
summary: European markets surged on hopes of a fudged Greek deal, with stocks and bonds rising on optimistic statements from EU leaders. Despite reservations from Syriza members, EU leaders said the proposal was promising enough to continue talks in the coming days. French President François Hollande and European Commission President Jean-Claude Juncker expressed confidence in reaching an agreement, with Juncker promising Greece would be eligible for a portion of a 35 billion-euro EU infrastructure package if a deal is reached. The proposal includes increased VAT and pension reforms, but faces opposition from Syriza's left wing and German Chancellor Angela Merkel's need to persuade the German Parliament.

site_title: Fitch affirms ratings for Singtel, Optus with stable outlook
summary: Fitch Ratings has affirmed Singtel's long-term foreign and local-currency issuer default ratings and senior unsecured rating at A+, with a stable outlook. The agency expects Singtel to deleverage to 1.7x-2.0x by FY17-FY18, despite a US$810 million acquisition of Trustwave Holdings. Singtel's group digital life division is expected to turn around faster, driven by capital expenditure expansion in Australia and parental support from Singapore's majority state ownership.

images.alt_text: Fiona Lam

site_title: Former IMF economist emerges as favourite to head Thai central bank
summary: Former IMF economist Veerathai Santiprabhob has emerged as the front runner to become the new governor of Thailand's central bank, the Bank of Thailand, once the current governor steps down in September. He is on a short list of two candidates, alongside Phatra Securities' Supavud Saicheua, and faces the task of stimulating Thailand's economy, which has been sputtering since the army seized power last year. The finance minister will make his choice within two weeks, which will then need cabinet and royal approval.

site_title: Google developing health-tracking wristband for health research
summary: Google has developed a health-tracking wristband as part of its life sciences group, designed for clinical trials and drug tests. The device measures pulse, heart rhythm, skin temperature, and environmental information, and will be used to track patients' vital signs outside of a lab. Google plans to collaborate with researchers and drugmakers to test the wristband's accuracy and seek regulatory clearance, with trials set to start over the summer. The goal is to use the device to catch early signs of disease and enable patients to take on more responsibility in gathering health information.

site_title: US: Stocks open higher amid hopes of Greece deal
summary: US stocks opened higher on Tuesday amid rising hopes of a Greece deal to avert default. The Dow Jones Industrial Average rose 30.83 points, the S&P 500 advanced 2.78 points, and the Nasdaq Composite gained 5.41 points. These gains followed a record high on Monday. The positive sentiment was partly due to optimism over a potential Greece deal, which could alleviate concerns about global economic instability.

site_title: Ascott Reit raises S$250 million from perpetual securities issuance
summary: Ascott Residence Trust (Ascott Reit) raised S$250 million from perpetual securities issuance at a 4.68% annual distribution rate, exceeding S$1 billion in orders. The funds will be used to fund potential acquisitions, with a target asset size of S$6 billion by 2017. The Reit's manager is actively pursuing acquisitions, and Ascott Reit closed 0.5 Singapore cents higher at S$1.28 per unit following the announcement.

site_title: Advertising agencies under the gun from major contract reviews
summary: Major blue-chip companies, including Proctor & Gamble, Unilever, and BMW, are reviewing their advertising contracts with agencies, putting pressure on the industry. Approximately $27 billion in media planning and buying contracts are up for grabs, exceeding the past three years combined. This shift highlights the growing threat of online marketing to traditional advertising agencies' profit margins, sparking a conversation among 13,000 industry delegates at the Cannes conference.

site_title: UK private equity records double the returns of pension funds, FTSE: survey
summary: British private equity and venture capital funds achieved a 10-year internal rate of return (IRR) of 14.9%, nearly double the 7.8% return of UK pension fund assets and the 7.6% return of the FTSE All-Share, according to a survey by the British Private Equity and Venture Capital Association. However, returns were less impressive over a five-year period, with private equity funds recording 11.5% returns compared to 9.4% for UK pension funds and 8.7% for the FTSE All-Share.

site_title: ABR Holdings terminates joint venture with Palate Group
summary: ABR Holdings has terminated its joint venture with Palate Group, which was meant to develop and manage its food and beverage brands. The joint venture, All Best Foods, was formed to leverage Palate Group's expertise. ABR Holdings acquired Palate Group's 49% stake in All Best Foods for S$2.94 million, making it a wholly owned subsidiary. The key founder of Palate Group has also resigned from All Best Foods and its subsidiaries. The decision follows a strategic review of ABR's operations.

site_title: Malaysia's Tenaga plans US$2.7b Islamic bond after power plant deal: sources
summary: Malaysia's Tenaga Nasional Bhd plans to raise up to 10 billion ringgit (S$3.6 billion) in an Islamic bond to develop a 2,000 MW coal-fired power plant project from debt-laden state fund 1MDB. This would be the largest sukuk globally this year, boosting the sukuk market after a decline in the first quarter. The move aims to alleviate 1MDB's debt burden of over US$11 billion and put pressure on the Malaysian currency and credit rating.

site_title: PM Lee unveils S$3.5 billion Pasir Panjang Terminal expansion
summary: Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong officially opened a S$3.5 billion expansion of Pasir Panjang Container Terminal, adding 15 mega berths to handle up to 50 million TEUs annually by 2017. The new berths are designed for large container ships, boosting efficiency and serving mega container ships. The expansion is part of Phases 3 and 4, with the future Tuas port aiming to handle up to 65 million TEUs a year.

site_title: HY Realty wins Dundee Road site, tender draws 9 bids
summary: HY Realty, a subsidiary of Chinese developer Hao Yuan Investment, won the tender for a 99-year lease site at Dundee Road with a bid of S$483.18 million, or S$871 per square foot per plot ratio (psf ppr). This is 8.4% higher than the second-highest bid by Allgreen. The winning bid surpassed the third-highest bids from multiple companies, including Hong Leong Holdings and City Developments.

site_title: Jet Airways jumps on report Etihad seeks higher stake in company
summary: Jet Airways India Ltd jumped 4.1% on a report that Etihad Airways is seeking to increase its 24% stake in the company. The shares rose 1.3% to 282.4 rupees after Bloomberg TV India cited government sources as saying the administration isn't keen on approving a higher shareholding. This comes as Jet Airways faces increased competition after local ventures of AirAsia and Singapore Airlines started flights. The airline has not reported a full-year profit since 2008.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares end lower
summary: Malaysia's Kuala Lumpur Composite Index closed at 1,726.86, down 5.9 points. Trading volume reached 1.72 billion lots, valued at RM1.67 billion. The market saw 396 gains and 407 losses.

site_title: Etihad says not in talks to raise stake in India's Jet
summary: Etihad Airways has denied reports that it is in talks to raise its 24% stake in India's Jet Airways. The denial comes after Bloomberg TV India cited unnamed government sources as saying Etihad had approached the Indian government for permission to buy more of Jet. Etihad acquired a stake in Jet in 2013, giving it a foothold in India's growing aviation industry. Jet's shares rose 2.44% on the news, while Etihad maintained it was not in discussions about raising its stake.

site_title: Singapore Wrap Tuesday
summary: Singapore's headline inflation rate remained in negative territory for the seventh straight month in May, increasing to -0.4% from -0.5% in April. Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong unveiled a S$3.5 billion expansion project for the Pasir Panjang container terminal. Business sentiment among SMEs in Singapore moderated for the third consecutive quarter, while the local currency bond market in emerging East Asia reached US$8.3 trillion in Q1. Singapore shares closed 0.7% higher, driven by optimism over Greece's debt reform deal.

site_title: Janus launches global allocation fund
summary: Janus Capital Group launched a global allocation fund, the Janus Adaptive Global Allocation Fund, which invests in global stock and bond markets. Developed by Nobel Prize winner Myron Scholes, the fund aims to manage outcomes with the largest impact on growth, focusing on left and right tail events. Ashwin Alankar and Enrique Chang will manage the fund, which is part of Janus' diversification strategy. The fund was launched as part of Janus' efforts to expand its bond business, following the hiring of Bill Gross in 2014.

site_title: Leader Environmental Technologies to raise S$2.3m in private placement
summary: Leader Environmental Technologies plans to raise S$2.31 million through a private share placement by issuing 51.3 million new shares at 4.5 Singapore cents each, representing 9.29% of its existing share capital. The placement price is a 10% discount to the weighted average price of its shares. The funds will be used for new energy generation, water management, and environmental projects, as well as general working capital. The company will seek shareholders' approval for a share consolidation at an upcoming extraordinary general meeting.

site_title: Growth of emerging East Asia bond market moderates in Q1
summary: The Asian Development Bank reported that the emerging East Asia bond market grew to US$8.3 trillion in Q1 2015, with Singapore being the largest issuer among Asean members. However, the growth moderated to 1.6% on a quarterly basis, down from 2% in Q4 2014. Singapore's LCY bond market totalled US$233 billion, with government bonds reaching US$140 billion and corporate bonds at US$93 billion. Malaysia's LCY bond market contracted 2.7% in Q1 2015, while Indonesia and Hong Kong recorded slower quarterly growth.

site_title: Fitch affirms Singtel and Optus ratings
summary: Fitch Ratings has affirmed the long-term foreign and local-currency issuer default ratings and senior unsecured ratings of Singtel and its Australian subsidiary Optus at "A+" with a stable outlook. The ratings have limited potential for short to medium-term increases.

images.alt_text: Fiona Lam

site_title: Chinese firms do brisk business in Venezuela despite idle factories
summary: Chinese companies, such as Haier and Yutong, are doing brisk business in Venezuela despite idle factories, due to cooperation deals that give them privileged access to the country's economy. These deals, which include loans and joint ventures, have allowed Chinese firms to bypass Venezuela's currency controls and import goods to meet demand. However, the Venezuelan government bears the cost of leaving the factories idle, and the country struggles to make good on promises that the financing would spur new industries and reduce its dependence on oil.

site_title: Volkswagen to play catch-up in India with feature-rich subcompact
summary: Volkswagen plans to launch a feature-rich subcompact car in India next year, aiming to build on its 2% market share in the emerging market. The car will be under 4 meters long, allowing it to benefit from tax breaks, and will come with high-end features like dual airbags and automatic gear shift. This marks Volkswagen's late entry into the segment dominated by Maruti Suzuki, Hyundai, and Honda, which are popular among India's growing middle class seeking affordable high-spec vehicles.

images.alt_text: Germany's Volkswagen AG, Europe's biggest automaker, is betting that the launch of a feature-rich subcompact in India next year will build on its mere 2 per cent market share and drive expansion in the quick-growing emerging market.

site_title: Frankfurt or Paris could replace London as finance hub, S&P says
summary: Standard & Poor's warns that a UK exit from the European Union could shift Europe's financial hub from London to Frankfurt, Paris, or Dublin, citing potential cuts in foreign investment and increased business costs. The UK financial services industry, which supports 1.4 million jobs, could see operations relocate due to EU exit. Deutsche Bank has already begun studying the impact of Brexit on its business in the UK. A referendum on EU membership is promised by the end of 2017, sparking concerns about the UK's economic future.

site_title: SEAsia mobile gaming to generate US$7.0 billion by 2019: report
summary: Southeast Asia's mobile gaming revenues are expected to grow six-fold to over $7.0 billion by 2019, driven by smartphones and high-speed internet. The growth rate is 48% annually, making the region the fastest-growing for the industry. However, online payments remain a challenge due to low credit card penetration, affecting the purchase of virtual goods. Popular games include "Clash of the Clans" and Chinese/Korean titles, with Southeast Asia's more prosperous economies like Singapore and Malaysia contributing to the bulk of current revenues.

site_title: BlackBerry misses profit estimates amid turnaround efforts
summary: BlackBerry Ltd reported a first-quarter loss of 5 cents a share, missing analyst estimates of a 4 cents loss. Smartphone revenue fell to $263 million, down from $379 million last year, while software revenue increased to $137 million. The company aims to double yearly software revenue to $500 million by March 2016. BlackBerry has been investing in security-focused software companies to reduce its reliance on shrinking smartphone sales. The company's shares have declined 16% this year.

images.alt_text: BlackBerry Ltd reported a first-quarter loss that missed analysts' estimates as sales from smartphones dropped.

site_title: UK accounting watchdog probes KPMG over BNY Mellon audit
summary: Britain's Financial Reporting Council has launched an investigation into KPMG over its handling of the Bank of New York Mellon (BNY Mellon) audit. KPMG confirmed BNY Mellon's compliance with UK rules on protecting customer money, despite the bank being fined 126 million pounds in April for failing to keep customer assets safe during the financial crisis. The investigation focuses on the conduct of KPMG auditors regarding BNY Mellon's London branch.

site_title: Singapore grows container terminal, eyes mega-ship demand
summary: Singapore has opened the newest addition to its container port, Pasir Panjang Terminal, aiming to handle more mega-ships. The terminal's 15 planned berths are expected to push Singapore's annual container handling capacity to 50 million TEUs by the end of 2017, surpassing the current 34 million TEUs. The project is designed to cater to the increasing demand for mega-ships, which are being used by shipowners to reduce fuel costs despite stagnant freight rates. Singapore aims to maintain its position as the world's second busiest container port after Shanghai.

site_title: Asia's richest man "disappointed" by Hong Kong democracy veto, but business as usual
summary: Asia's richest man Li Ka-shing expressed disappointment over Hong Kong's veto of a China-backed electoral blueprint, which would have granted a one-man one-vote system but with pre-screened candidates. Despite this, Li stated he wouldn't withdraw investments from the city. The veto eases prospects of fresh protests in Hong Kong, following last year's "Occupy Central" civil disobedience campaign.

site_title: BoE stops short of banning banker bonus buyouts
summary: The Bank of England's Prudential Regulation Authority has introduced new rules to regulate buyouts of unpaid bonuses by rival firms. The rules, effective immediately, require buyouts to be structured so that the deferred portion of the bonus cannot be cashed in any quicker than the original award. This means that buyouts will not be allowed to accelerate the vesting of bonuses, effectively preventing bankers from transferring pay perks to a rival firm. The move aims to curb excessive pay practices in the banking industry.

site_title: China approves US$21b worth of subway system projects
summary: China's top economic planner approved $21 billion worth of subway system projects, including a $28 billion Wuhan subway and a $14.86 billion Changchun urban rail system. The approvals aim to support China's slowing economy, which slowed to a six-year low 7% in the first quarter. The move follows the government's decision to step up "effective investment" in key sectors.

site_title: French economy firing up as private sector nears four-year high
summary: France's private sector business activity surged to its fastest pace in nearly four years in June, driven by a rebound in the manufacturing sector and a strong services sector. The Markit PMI index rose to 53.4, surpassing the 50 mark separating contraction from expansion. This growth suggests the economy may be recovering from stagnation, potentially benefiting President Francois Hollande ahead of the 2017 election. The manufacturing sector's reading improved to 50.5, while the services sector's reading reached 54.1, the highest since July 2011.

site_title: Greek offer to creditors stirs angry backlash at home
summary: Greek Prime Minister Alexis Tsipras has proposed a new budget plan to creditors, which includes tax hikes and pension increases, sparking an angry backlash from his leftist Syriza party. The plan is seen as a basis for further negotiations to unlock billions of euros in frozen aid, but lawmakers are wary of the measures, which threaten to increase hardship on Greeks already reeling from austerity. Euro zone leaders welcomed the proposals, but the euro fell on fears the plan may struggle to win approval in Greek parliament. A deal is still uncertain, with the ECB raising emergency liquidity for Greek banks and opposition lawmakers supporting the government's position on staying in the euro.

site_title: Germany to issue less debt than planned in Q3
summary: Germany plans to issue 5 billion euros less debt in Q3 than initially planned, reducing overall debt issuance to 180.5 billion euros. This is due to a 8.5% surge in tax revenues, which rose to 101 billion euros between January and May. The tax revenue increase is attributed to high employment and rising wages. The German government's tax revenue estimates for the year were also raised by 1% in May.

site_title: Oil edges up as Europe optimism offsets supply glut
summary: Oil prices rose on Tuesday as European economic data and optimism over a potential Greek deal offset a supply glut. Brent crude was up 10 cents at $63.44 a barrel, while US crude fell 14 cents to $60.24 a barrel. Strong data from France and Germany, as well as expectations of a weekly drawdown in US crude stocks, supported prices. Analysts also noted that a potential deal between Iran and six world powers could lead to increased oil exports and lifted Western sanctions.

site_title: Barclays in talks to sell private equity unit to management: source
summary: Barclays is in talks to sell its natural resources-focused private equity business, Barclays Natural Resource Investments (BNRI), to its management. BNRI has invested $3 billion in 28 companies since its launch in 2006. The business was previously put into Barclays' book of businesses intended for sale or downsizing due to its lack of strategic importance.

site_title: Samsung heir apologises over South Korea Mers outbreak
