summary: Samsung heir Jay Lee publicly apologized for the Mers outbreak at the company's flagship hospital in Seoul, where 175 confirmed cases have been reported, with 27 deaths and 54 recoveries. Lee vowed to overhaul the medical center, take full responsibility, and support the development of a vaccine against the Mers virus. The hospital, which has accounted for half of all Mers cases in South Korea, has admitted to shortcomings in initial responses to the disease.

site_title: Singapore tops KPMG's Change Readiness Index
summary: Singapore has emerged as the most change-ready country for the second consecutive year, according to KPMG's Change Readiness Index. The country's economic openness, strategic planning, and human capital are key drivers of its change-readiness. European countries such as Switzerland, Norway, and Sweden also ranked highly, with Asian economies like Hong Kong and Japan also making the top 15. The CRI measures countries' capacities along three dimensions, including enterprise capability, government capability, and people and civil society capability, and highlights the importance of change-readiness in the face of accelerating global changes.

site_title: World Bank pledges up to US$500m for quake-hit Nepal
summary: The World Bank has pledged up to $500 million to help Nepal rebuild after two devastating earthquakes that killed nearly 9,000 people and left hundreds of thousands in poverty. The bank will contribute $200 million to rural home reconstruction and $100 million directly to the Nepalese government. The funds can also be redirected from existing projects to focus on reconstruction. The total reconstruction cost is estimated at $6.6 billion over five years, with aid from international donors already supporting two-thirds of Nepal's economic development.

site_title: Eurozone business growth accelerates in June to 4-year high: PMI
summary: The Eurozone experienced its fastest business growth in four years in June, with a Composite Flash Purchasing Managers' Index (PMI) rising to 54.1, surpassing forecasts. The data indicates a solid recovery in the region, with both Germany and France showing strong growth. The European Central Bank's efforts to boost growth and inflation appear to be paying off, with a predicted 0.4% economic growth in the second quarter. However, demand from abroad remains weak due to a global economic slowdown and concerns over a Greek debt default.

site_title: Tour de France winner Riis knew his team was doping, probe finds
summary: Former Tour de France winner Bjarne Riis knew about doping in his team but failed to act, a Danish report found. The report, based on 50 interviews, revealed Riis' team, Team Saxo, had knowledge of doping but didn't intervene. Riis was sacked in March after a dispute with owner Oleg Tinkov, who criticized Riis for failing to stop doping. The report recommends increased testing, delayed test results, and licensing for team managers. However, the statue of limitations for doping cases applies, and no disciplinary charges can be brought against Riis.

site_title: EU's Oettinger sees roaming charges ending in 2017: newspaper
summary: EU Commissioner Guenther Oettinger expects roaming charges for mobile phone calls and data in Europe to be abolished in 2017, according to a German newspaper. The European Commission had previously set a 2015 deadline but EU member states have since pushed it back to December 2018, with lawmakers seeking a 2016 deadline. Oettinger believes a compromise will be reached, leading to the end of roaming charges by the end of 2017.

site_title: Australia: Shares hit 3-week high on hopes for Greek resolution
summary: Australian shares reached a 3-week high on June 23, 2015, as investors bet on a Greek resolution, driving the S&P/ASX 200 index up 1.3% to 5684.3. This was the benchmark's highest level since June 2 and its largest one-day gain since June 11. The positive sentiment was shared across Asia, with New Zealand's benchmark closing flat. The rally came despite Greece's latest budget proposals and ongoing debt concerns.

site_title: Strong franc lures EU workers to Switzerland
summary: The strong Swiss franc has lured EU workers to Switzerland, with a rise in foreign commuters, particularly from Italy and Spain, amid a government cap on franc strength against the euro being scrapped. Foreigners make up over a quarter of the workforce in some regions, and nearly a fifth in border cities. Despite overall EU immigration falling, Switzerland's economy has performed relatively well, with nearly 2 million foreigners living in the country, accounting for 24.3% of the population.

site_title: Greek optimism curbs demand for gold as equities rise
summary: Greek optimism boosts equities, curbs gold demand. Spot gold remained steady at $1,185.50 an ounce after Greece presented new budget proposals, which euro zone leaders welcomed as a basis for a possible agreement. The removal of the "Greek irritant" as a bullish issue may lead to further selling pressure on gold. Sluggish physical demand and outflows from gold-backed ETFs are also weighing on the metal. Strong economic data in the US may prompt the Federal Reserve to raise interest rates, hurting demand for gold.

site_title: Taiwan May export order slump deepens gloom for tech demand
summary: Taiwan's export orders in May fell 5.9% annually, the largest drop in over two years, darkening the outlook for global technology demand. The decline was worse than expected and follows a 4% slide in April. Economists expect the central bank to keep interest rates unchanged, citing uncertainties in Europe and China's slowdown. Orders from Asia's leading indicators, such as China and Japan, also contracted. The weak data may lead to an annual decline in Taiwan's export orders for the full year, affecting the island's technology exports.

site_title: End oil export ban, or face competition from Iran: US senator
summary: A US Senate report warns that if the US doesn't lift its 40-year ban on crude oil exports, Iran could soon compete in global markets, potentially driving down global crude prices. The report, prepared for the Senate energy committee, states that if a nuclear deal with Iran is reached, the country could produce significantly more oil by the end of 2016, outcompeting US oil companies. Senator Lisa Murkowski has introduced a bill to overturn the ban, but its passage is uncertain.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks close 0.93% up, Shanghai bounces
summary: Hong Kong shares rose 0.93% on Tuesday, driven by hopes of a Greece debt reform deal and improving Chinese manufacturing activity. The Hang Seng Index gained 252.61 points to 27,333.46, while the Shanghai Composite Index surged 2.19% to 4,576.49. Mainland China's Shenzhen Composite Index also rose 1.18% to 2,774.64. The gains came after a 13% drop in the Shanghai Composite Index the previous week.

site_title: UK factory orders index lowest since mid-2013, hurt by weak exports: CBI
summary: The UK factory orders index reached its lowest level since mid-2013, with a total order book balance of -7, down from -5 in May. Weak export demand, a strengthening pound, and ongoing Greek uncertainty are cited as factors. Despite this, manufacturers became slightly more optimistic about output volumes in the coming three months. The CBI's director of economics noted that export demand is yet to drive forward, but overall economic growth is expected to bounce back in the April-June period.

site_title: Japan PM Abe met with rare heckling at Battle of Okinawa ceremony
summary: Japanese Prime Minister Shinzo Abe was heckled and met with cries of "Go home!" during a ceremony marking the 70th anniversary of the Battle of Okinawa. The outburst occurred in conservative Japan, where residents have long resented hosting US troops and facilities on the southern island. Okinawa Governor Takeshi Onaga rejected a proposal to move a US Marines base, calling for it to be moved off the island. Abe acknowledged the burden of hosting US bases, vowing to "lighten your burden."

site_title: Quick takes: Fall in Singapore consumer prices unlikely to prompt monetary policy change: economists
summary: Singapore's headline inflation rate for May came in at -0.4%, matching market expectations, and core inflation eased to 0.1% due to lower services and food inflation. Economists predict no change in monetary policy stance by October, citing a growing risk of core inflation undershooting forecasts and a steady GDP growth profile. Experts note that supply-side factors, such as government budget measures and lower global commodity prices, are driving the declines, making it difficult for the Monetary Authority of Singapore to change policy.

site_title: Britain cuts Lloyds Banking Group stake to below 17%
summary: Britain has reduced its stake in Lloyds Banking Group to below 17% as part of efforts to return the bank to full private ownership. The government has recovered 11.5 billion pounds from the taxpayer's initial 20.5 billion pound bailout during the 2007-9 financial crisis. UK Financial Investments has extended a trading plan allowing Morgan Stanley to sell Lloyds shares beyond June 30, potentially leading to a full exit in the next year.

site_title: Thai hotelier Erawan says sees no Mers impact on 2015 growth
summary: Thai hotelier Erawan Group maintains its annual 35% revenue growth target despite concerns over Middle East Respiratory Syndrome (Mers). The company's shares fell to six-month lows earlier but rebounded 0.47% on Tuesday. Erawan expects an increase in foreign tourists to boost occupancy rates to 77% this year, with no cancellations for room bookings so far. Analysts have warned of potential impact from Mers, but Erawan's CEO remains confident in achieving targets.

site_title: German private sector grows, points to 0.3% growth in Q2: PMI
summary: Germany's private sector grew at a faster rate in June, with a 54.0 PMI reading, indicating a 0.3% expansion in Q2. This marks 26 consecutive months of expansion. Despite a slightly lower average Q2 PMI, the economy is expected to grow by 0.3% for the quarter, comparable to its performance in 2015. Uncertainty about Russia and the Greek debt crisis, as well as increased competition from Spain and Ireland, are affecting the business environment.

site_title: SilkAir flight from Singapore makes emergency landing in Haikou due to typhoon
summary: A SilkAir flight MI8334 from Singapore to Sanya Phoenix International Airport made an emergency landing in Haikou on June 23, 2015, due to a typhoon that made landfall on Hainan Island. The plane was forced to divert to Haikou to refuel after attempting an aborted landing at the airport. The flight was delayed for an hour before the decision was made to make the emergency landing. No injuries or fatalities were reported.

site_title: Update: Singapore yards alleged to be part of Brazil bribe scandal
summary: Singaporean shipbuilders Keppel Fels Ltd and Jurong Shipyard Pte are implicated in a bribery scandal related to deep-water drilling vessel contracts for Petrobras. The companies allegedly paid bribes through intermediaries to secure the contracts worth US$800 million each. A former Petrobras and Sete director, Pedro Barusco, has agreed to return US$97 million, and Marcelo Odebrecht, CEO of Odebrecht SA, has been detained despite denying wrongdoing. The scandal threatens Brazil's domestic oil industry development plans and may impact established offshore vessel suppliers in China, South Korea, and Norway.

site_title: Australia set to strip citizenship for terror links
summary: Australia is set to introduce new laws stripping dual nationals linked to terrorism of their citizenship. The legislation will expand the Citizenship Act to include those who fight against Australia in a terrorist group, currently 20 of which are on Canberra's list. The power to strip citizenship will not be granted to a single minister, but rather to the Attorney-General. This move aims to prevent individuals with ties to terrorism from holding Australian citizenship. The new laws are expected to be introduced this week.

site_title: Oil prices fall on oversupply concerns, weak economic data
summary: Oil prices fell on Tuesday due to concerns over a global glut and weak economic data, particularly in China and Japan. Despite a projected drawdown in US crude stocks, Brent crude was down 5 cents at $63.29 a barrel. The drop was attributed to bearish market sentiment, partly due to US President Trump's tariffs on Canada and other countries.

site_title: China: Stocks reverse earlier losses to end sharply higher
summary: China's stocks reversed earlier losses to close sharply higher on Tuesday, ending a volatile session. The CSI300 index rose 3.2% to 4,786.09, while the Shanghai Composite Index gained 2.2% to 4,576.49 points. Investors cut losses after the market resumed trading following a public holiday, with both local and foreign investors buying in, believing the bull market is not yet over.

site_title: Seoul: Shares post largest gain in 2 months; won falls
summary: South Korean shares posted their largest gain in two months, closing up 1.3% at 2,081.20 points, driven by hopes that Greece's new budget proposals will avert a debt default. The won fell 0.5% to 1,104.6 to the dollar. LG Display Co Ltd lost 4.7% due to declining display panel prices, its lowest closing level since March 2014. The gains come as investors remain optimistic despite ongoing global economic uncertainty.

site_title: China says up to United States to resume cyber security talks
summary: China's foreign ministry stated that the US must create conditions to resume regular cyber security talks, amid tensions over suspected Chinese hacking. The two countries began high-level meetings in Washington. The US has been investigating a data breach at the Office of Personnel Management, which compromised 4 million federal employees' data, fueling US suspicions of Chinese involvement. China has denied any involvement in the breach.

site_title: Sharp shareholders re-elect CEO, approve bailout to secure survival
summary: Sharp Corp's shareholders re-elected CEO Kozo Takahashi and approved a bailout plan to secure survival amid a deep downturn in its display business. The company had previously cut 5,000 jobs and sold its headquarters. Support for the CEO fell to 97% from 100% last year due to disappointment over losses and a massive bailout cut to capital. The plan aims to help the company survive fierce competition.

site_title: Tokyo: Benchmark index climbs to new 15-year high
summary: Tokyo's benchmark Nikkei index reached a new 15-year high, closing at 20,809.42, with a 1.87% gain. The rally followed hopes for a Greek bailout deal, which drove European and US markets up. The Topix index also rose 1.69%. Eurozone leaders aim to seal a deal this week to save Greece from default, while the dollar rose to 123.67 yen. Toshiba rose despite a report on improper accounting, while Sharp fell after explaining revival plans.

site_title: Europe: Shares hit three-week high on Greek optimism
summary: European shares reached a three-week high on Tuesday, driven by optimism over Greece's potential deal with international creditors. Greece presented new budget proposals, which were welcomed by euro zone leaders, and European Council President Donald Tusk called them a "positive step forward." The FTSEurofirst 300 index rose 0.9% to a high of 1,580.14 points, while the Euro STOXX 50 index climbed 0.8% to a three-week high. The deal, if finalized, could unlock frozen aid and avert a looming default, boosting market sentiment.

site_title: French manufacturing shakes off recession as business pick-up strengthens: PMI
summary: France's manufacturing sector expanded for the first time since April 2014, driven by a pick-up in private sector business activity, according to a survey. The Markit PMI reading rose to 53.4, surpassing the 50 mark separating contraction and expansion. Manufacturing PMI reached 50.5, its highest since April 2014, while services PMI rose to 54.1, the best since July 2011. This marks the fifth consecutive month of growth in private sector business activity.

site_title: Australia: Shares hit highest in 3 weeks on Greek deal hopes
summary: Australian shares rose 1.3% to their highest level in three weeks, driven by hopes that Greece's latest budget proposals will stave off a debt default and lead to a deal with lenders. Banks surged, with the top lender Commonwealth Bank up 1.9%, while telecommunications heavyweight Telstra Corp rose 1.3%. The S&P/ASX 200 index reached 5680.1, its highest intraday level since June 2.

site_title: Singapore yards alleged to be part of Brazil bribe scandal
summary: Singaporean shipbuilders Keppel Fels Ltd and Jurong Shipyard Pte have been implicated in a bribery scandal in Brazil, where they allegedly paid bribes to win contracts for building deep-water drilling vessels. The scandal, which involves Petrobras and other companies, threatens to derail Brazil's plans to develop a domestic oil industry. A former Petrobras and Sete director has agreed to pay $97 million in bribes, including payments to shipyards, and several executives have been detained and questioned. The companies involved have denied wrongdoing, but the scandal raises concerns about corruption in the oil industry.

images.alt_text: Singaporean shipbuilders Keppel Fels Ltd and Jurong Shipyard Pte are sinking deeper into a graft scandal that has transfixed Brazil and buffeted local oil industry suppliers.

site_title: China says hopes Greece gets out of debt crisis soon
summary: China hopes Greece resolves its debt crisis soon to enable stable EU integration, Foreign Ministry spokesman Lu Kang said. Greece presented new budget proposals on Monday, which euro zone leaders welcomed, potentially unlocking frozen aid and averting a default. Chinese Premier Li Keqiang will discuss the issue during his upcoming Europe trip, but did not confirm whether China would offer emergency loans or buy assets in the event of a default. China previously signalled support for Greece by agreeing to buy bonds when it issues debt again.

site_title: Glitch temporarily grounds all aircraft in New Zealand
summary: A radar problem at Airways New Zealand's air traffic control system temporarily grounded all commercial and civilian aircraft in New Zealand on June 23, 2015. The issue occurred at 2:40pm and affected all flights, including international and domestic services. Flights were cleared to land and the problem was resolved within 90 minutes, with Airways NZ blaming an internal network failure. Transport Minister Simon Bridges assured the safety of passengers, and airlines advised passengers to expect delays at Auckland airport.

images.alt_text: All commercial and civilian aircraft in New Zealand were temporarily grounded on Tuesday when a fault crippled the nation's air traffic control system, an official said.

site_title: Solar Impulse set to take off early Wednesday
summary: A solar-powered plane, Solar Impulse 2, is set to take off early Wednesday from Japan to Hawaii, marking the eighth and most challenging leg of its round-the-world attempt. The plane, which was diverted to Japan three weeks ago due to weather conditions, has been cleared to fly after a favorable forecast. The mission, led by Andre Borschberg, aims to fly continuously for five days and five nights, taking advantage of calm winds and turbulence in the early morning hours. The plane has 17,000 solar cells and on-board rechargeable batteries, covering a top speed of 140 km/h.

site_title: Amtek responds to Bloomberg report on 'plans to double sales'
summary: Amtek Engineering clarified its plans to double sales to US$2 billion in five to seven years through acquisitions, stating it was in relation to an earlier Bloomberg article from 2014 and not a new projection. The company advised shareholders to exercise caution when dealing in shares, as the statement was not material new information. Amtek's acquisition of US precision-tool maker Interplex Industries last year is seen as the basis for the plan.

site_title: Singapore inflation edges up to -0.4% in May
summary: Singapore's headline inflation rate edged up to -0.4% in May, staying in negative territory for the seventh consecutive month. Core inflation eased to 0.1% due to lower services and food costs. The moderation was attributed to budgetary measures and softer food inflation. The Monetary Authority of Singapore and Ministry of Trade and Industry reiterated official forecasts for 2015, projecting headline inflation at -0.5 to 0.5% and core inflation at 0.5 to 1.5%.

site_title: Brazil's Petrobras hits snag in ethanol unit sale: sources
summary: Brazil's state-run oil company Petrobras is struggling to sell its 42.9% stake in ethanol producer Guarani SA, with the company seeking $200 million but valuing it at $407 million. The sale has hit a snag due to the low price of sugar, which is trading at its lowest levels in six years, and Petrobras' need to raise $3 billion in assets this year and $13.7 billion by the end of 2016.

site_title: ECB raises emerging funding for Greek banks after eurozone summit: source
summary: The European Central Bank (ECB) has raised emergency funding for Greek banks for a second time, increasing the ceiling to about 86 billion euros. The move comes after eurozone leaders held an emergency meeting in Brussels, aiming to clinch a cash-for-reforms deal with Greece. The ECB had previously approved 2 billion euros of Emergency Liquidity Assistance (ELA) on Monday, and now meets almost daily as bank withdrawals continue and negotiations reach a climax.

site_title: Hopes for Greek debt deal with one week to go
summary: Greece and its creditors are working to seal a bailout deal with just one week left before Athens is due to repay the IMF around 1.5 billion euros. A breakthrough in talks is seen as possible, with European leaders expressing optimism after Greece submitted a reform plan. However, sticking points remain, including Greece's proposals for VAT measures, and the IMF has warned that time is running out. If a deal is not reached, Greece risks defaulting on its IMF payment and possibly exiting the eurozone and EU.

site_title: Singapore: STI opens 9.88 points higher on Tuesday
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) opened 9.88 points higher on Tuesday, reaching 3,325.01, following a global rally fueled by optimism over a potential Greek default deal. Gainers outnumbered losers 94 to 45, with 47.7 million shares worth S$91.8 million changing hands.

site_title: Itochu exits US shale selling biggest energy purchase for US$1
summary: Itochu Corp sold its 25% stake in Samson Resources Corp back to Samson for $1, reversing its $1 billion investment in 2011. The decision was made due to the poor state of Samson's operations and low gas prices in North America. Itochu, Japan's third-largest trading house, expects to post a record annual profit this fiscal year and will be cautious with future US shale investments. This sale follows rival Japanese trading company Sumitomo Corp's first net loss in 16 years due to US shale investments.

site_title: Ascott markets Sing dollar subordinated perpetual bonds
summary: Ascott Residence Trust is offering Singapore dollar non-call five perpetual bonds at a price guidance for a yield in the 5 per cent area, its second perpetual bond offering. The bonds are unrated and will reset every five years based on the prevailing Singapore dollar five-year SOR plus a fixed spread. The issuance is led by OCBC, with pricing expected today.

site_title: Radar fault grounds all aircraft in New Zealand: official
summary: A radar fault in New Zealand's air traffic control system grounded all commercial and civilian aircraft in the country on June 23, 2015. Airways New Zealand reported the issue occurred at 2:48 pm local time and technicians were working to find the cause. All flights, including international and domestic services, were affected, with aircraft held on the ground and those in the air cleared to land. Auckland airport warned of expected delays, and the impact was felt across the country, with no aircraft taking off. A fix was not expected until later.

site_title: Stalled Indonesia-Australia trade talks may restart after spats
summary: Australia is seeking to restart stalled trade talks with Indonesia after diplomatic spats left the negotiations in limbo. Trade Minister Andrew Robb plans to revive talks by the end of the year, despite ongoing issues such as the death penalty for drug crimes and tension over asylum seekers. Robb aims to expand trade from $11.8 billion to a more comprehensive agreement, with Indonesia being Australia's 11th-largest trading partner.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks up 0.20% at open
summary: Hong Kong shares rose 0.20% at open, following a rally on Wall Street and Europe. Greece is moving towards a debt reform deal, potentially averting a default and eurozone exit. The Hang Seng Index added 53.51 points to 27,134.36.

site_title: New medical centre in town to cater to growth plans: Raffles Medical Group
summary: Raffles Medical Group has launched a new multi-disciplinary medical centre at Shaw Centre in Singapore, aiming to cater to growing patient demand. The 17,000 sq ft centre offers Traditional Chinese Medicine services, alongside specialty services like cardiology and obstetrics. With over a third of flagship hospital patients being foreigners, the new centre is expected to treat a higher foreign patient load, with a focus on patients from Vietnam and Russia. This marks the first time Raffles Medical Group has incorporated Traditional Chinese Medicine outside its main clinic.

site_title: Asia dividend-paying equity funds take top spot
summary: Asia dividend-paying equity funds have drawn billions of dollars in investments, surpassing other equity funds in the region. Inflows jumped four-fold to around $2.1 billion for the OkasanAM Asia Oceania Good Dividend Growth fund in January to May. Low interest rates and new investment opportunities in South Korea, such as a law taxing excess corporate cash, are driving the trend. This shift is expected to continue for at least two to three years, according to Chuck Ng, CEO of Value Partners Asset Management Singapore.

site_title: Oil prices down in Asia
summary: Oil prices fell in Asia, with the possible return of Iranian crude to the global market exacerbating concerns over a supply glut. Iranian crude could enter the market if a deal between Iran and major western powers is reached by June 30, potentially increasing the current oversupply and driving prices lower. This could further impact the already bearish oil market, which has seen prices decline from over US$100 a barrel in June last year.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares rise on Tuesday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rose 1.37 points to 1,734.13 points on Tuesday, driven by a gainers-to-losers ratio of 162 to 71. Volume reached 66.4 million lots worth RM24.9 million.

site_title: Japan announces dates for G7 summit in 2016
summary: Japan announced the dates for the 2016 G7 summit, which will be held in central Mie prefecture on May 26-27. The summit is expected to discuss the crisis in Ukraine and Japan's concerns over Asian security issues. Russian President Vladimir Putin's invitation remains undecided, following his exclusion from the 2014 G7 summit due to his "aggression in Ukraine." The 2015 G7 summit in Germany issued a joint communique warning Russia of stepped-up sanctions.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks rise as optimism grows for deal on Greece debt
summary: Japanese stocks rose 0.6% to 1,658.67, driven by optimism over a potential deal between Greece and its creditors. European leaders gave Greece's Prime Minister Alexis Tsipras 48 hours to reach a final agreement, amid a five-month standoff over aid. The European Commission President Jean-Claude Juncker expressed confidence in a breakthrough, while German Chancellor Angela Merkel noted that hours of intense deliberations lie ahead. The positive news also boosted US stocks, with the S&P 500 gaining 0.6% in New York.

site_title: Nissan says paid CEO Ghosn S$11.22m last year
summary: Nissan Motor Co. paid CEO Carlos Ghosn $11.22 million in compensation last year, a 4% increase from the previous year. Ghosn, also CEO of Renault and AvtoVAZ, received the high pay despite being dwarfed by Softbank Corp's Nikesh Arora's record-breaking compensation. The Japanese automaker reported an 18% jump in operating profit and forecast a 15% rise for this year, with Ghosn being the top individual shareholder in Nissan, holding 3.122 million shares worth about $30 million.

site_title: South Korea reports three new Mers cases, bringing total to 175
summary: South Korea reported three new cases of Middle East Respiratory Syndrome (MERS), bringing the total to 175. This outbreak, while still the largest outside Saudi Arabia, appears to have leveled off. 54 people who tested positive for the virus have recovered and been discharged, with 27 deaths, mostly among elderly or ill patients.

site_title: Taiwan: Stocks rise following Asian peers on Greece optimism, Nasdaq record
summary: Taiwan's stocks rose 1% to 9,431.16 points on Tuesday, following Asian markets higher on Greece optimism. The Nasdaq's record close boosted local technology shares, particularly chipmakers UMC and ASE. The Taiwan dollar strengthened to T$0.183 to T$30.787 per US dollar. Export orders data for May, expected to fall but show some improvement, will be released after the market closes.

site_title: Toyota finds airbags in demand on world's deadliest roads
summary: Toyota Motor Corp has found that customers are willing to pay more for airbags on the world's deadliest roads. After installing airbags in all models sold locally in India, sales rose 19% in the period, outperforming the industry's 5% growth. This is a departure from carmakers' previous reluctance to make airbags standard due to concerns over increased costs. The company's sales director, N Raja, notes that even in smaller cities, people are realizing the need for safety features, indicating a shift in consumer behavior towards prioritizing safety.

site_title: Singapore eDevelopment asked by Coface to pay guaranteed sum of S$3.4m
summary: Singapore eDevelopment has been asked by insurance company Coface to pay a guaranteed sum of S$3.4 million, following the failure of a subsidiary to pay a similar amount. The company is in negotiations to settle the debt in stages, with no expected impact on its financial results for the current year. The demand was made by the Housing & Development Board (HDB), the project owner, after Coface claimed S$2.8 million under the Jurong West Performance Bond.

site_title: Hot stocks: Petrobras scandal resurfaces to haunt Keppel Corp, SembMarine
summary: Keppel Corp and SembMarine, Singapore shipbuilders, saw their shares decline on Tuesday amid the resurfacing of the Petrobras scandal. The Brazilian court released testimony alleging that Keppel Fels and Jurong Shipyard paid bribes to win contracts for deep-water drilling vessels. The companies have denied the allegations, but the news may impact their stock prices, with Keppel's shares trading at S$8.38 and SembMarine's at S$2.87. Market analyst Nicholas Teo warned that Keppel's stock may break below S$8.40, potentially leading to a further decline.

site_title: KrisEnergy gets SGX approval in-principle for listing and quotation of S$169.5m rights shares
summary: KrisEnergy, a mainboard-listed oil and gas company, received approval in-principle from the Singapore Exchange (SGX) for the listing and quotation of its S$169.5 million rights shares. The rights issue aims to support capital expenditure for growing oil and gas production. Keppel Corporation and First Reserve have subscribed for 137.9 million and 87.3 million rights shares, respectively. The remaining rights shares have been underwritten by Merrill Lynch. The listing is subject to certain conditions and will generate net proceeds of about S$165.6 million.

images.alt_text: Keppel Corporation has subscribed for its full entitlement, which amounts to 137.9 million rights shares, or about 31.3 per cent of the rights issue.

site_title: East Asia bond markets growth moderates in Q1, Singapore is largest Asean bond issuer in that quarter
summary: The Asian Development Bank reported that East Asia's local currency (LCY) bond market grew to US$8.3 trillion in Q1 2015, moderating quarter-over-quarter growth to 1.6%. Singapore was the largest Asean issuer in Q1 2015, with US$233 billion in LCY bond market, driven by government and corporate bond issuance. Total LCY bond issuance in the region was US$924 billion, down from US$1,032 billion in Q4 2014.

site_title: China June factory activity still weak but some signs of stabilising
summary: China's factory activity showed signs of stabilizing in June, with the HSBC/Markit Flash China Manufacturing Purchasing Managers' Index (PMI) edging up to 49.6, a three-month high. However, the index remained below the 50 mark, indicating contraction. New orders and exports showed some improvement, but companies increased layoffs at the fastest pace in over six years, raising concerns for policymakers. This suggests the need for further stimulus measures to support China's economy.

site_title: Greece given 48 hours to reach deal as EU leaders weigh debt
summary: European leaders have given Greek Prime Minister Alexis Tsipras 48 hours to finalize a deal with creditors to avoid a split from the eurozone. After Greece submitted reform measures, leaders agreed to step up negotiations, with a meeting of euro-area finance ministers set for Wednesday. The deal aims to address debt concerns, with the European Commission and IMF to examine the proposals in detail. However, disagreements remain, particularly over sales-tax rates, and a parliamentary vote is required for the deal to be finalized, with Germany insisting on economic policy changes before agreeing to a revised aid deal.

site_title: Business sentiment among SMEs dips for third consecutive quarter
summary: Business sentiment among Singapore's small and medium enterprises (SMEs) has dipped for a third consecutive quarter, according to the SBF-DP SME Index. The overall index score fell from 54.0 to 53.5, its lowest level since 2013. Four industries showed less optimism, while the construction sector saw a slight increase due to infrastructure spending and skill-raising efforts. The decline in sentiment reflects global economic uncertainty and a tough local business environment, according to the Singapore Business Federation (SBF).

images.alt_text: Singapore Business Federation (SBF) chief executive Ho Meng Kit speaking to Singapore media where he is attending the APEC Business Advisory Council (ABAC) at the Ayana Resort and Spa in Jimbaran, Bali.

site_title: Asia: Markets follow US, Europe higher on Greece hopes
summary: Asian markets rose on Tuesday, following the US and Europe, on hopes that Greece and its creditors will reach a debt reform deal. The euro stood firm, and Athens surged 9.0%. Shanghai edged up 0.38% and Tokyo jumped 1.43%. The gains were also boosted by preliminary figures showing a contraction in Chinese manufacturing activity may be easing. Eurozone leaders expressed confidence in reaching a deal ahead of an EU summit on Thursday, with European Commission chief Jean-Claude Juncker saying he was "convinced" a deal would be done.

site_title: Softbank, Bharti, Foxconn to invest US$20b in India solar projects
summary: SoftBank, Bharti, and Foxconn are investing US$20 billion in India's solar projects, the largest such investment in the country's renewable energy sector. The companies aim to generate 20 gigawatts of energy, with SoftBank holding majority control in the newly formed SBG Cleantech. The investment follows India's Prime Minister Narendra Modi's goal to make the country a leading renewable energy market, aiming for 100,000MW of output by 2022. The move is seen as a boost to Modi's efforts to encourage investment in renewable energy and reduce the country's reliance on coal.

site_title: China aims to challenge US air dominance: Pentagon
summary: China is rapidly closing the technological gap with the US, developing radar-evading aircraft, advanced reconnaissance planes, sophisticated missiles, and electronic warfare equipment. The Pentagon acknowledges the competitive aspect of the US-China relationship, particularly in military capabilities, and is seeking new technologies and systems to stay ahead. Deputy Defence Secretary Robert Work said the US must "hedge against this international competition turning more heated" and develop new technologies to maintain its edge, citing the erosion of its technological superiority over the past 25 years.

site_title: Design maven Martha Stewart sells namesake company for US$353m
summary: Martha Stewart Living Omnimedia has sold its namesake company for $353 million to Sequential Brands Group. The deal, valued at $6.15 per share, is half-cash and half-stocks. Martha Stewart, 73, will remain as chief creative officer. The sale marks the end of her 18-year tenure as CEO.

site_title: Stocks to watch: Singapore eDevelopment, KrisEnergy, China Environmental Resources
summary: Singapore eDevelopment faces a S$3.4 million payment obligation after being called upon by insurance company Coface, in accordance with a performance bond agreement. KrisEnergy receives in-principle approval from the Singapore Exchange for its S$169.5 million rights issue. China Environmental Resources Group plans to raise HK$116.3 million through a placement of new shares, representing 20% of its issued share capital.

site_title: Foreign investors remain buyers of East Asia bonds
summary: Foreign investors continue to buy East Asian bonds, despite the strengthening US dollar, with net foreign capital flows remaining positive in Q1 2015. Malaysia and South Korea saw notable rises in capital inflows, while Indonesia's foreign capital flows turned negative in March before recovering. Foreign investors hold over 30% of government bonds in Indonesia and Malaysia, with the rupiah and ringgit being the worst-performing Asian currencies against the US dollar. Foreign funds are chasing yields in the Indonesian LCY government bond market, which offers the highest yields in the region.

site_title: US, China hold 'frank' talks on hacking, maritime row
summary: US and Chinese diplomats held "candid" talks on maritime disputes, cyber hacking, and military relations, with the two-day Strategic and Economic Dialogue kicking off on Tuesday. The talks aim to resolve simmering issues between the two world powers, including China's claims to the South China Sea and US accusations of cyber espionage. The discussions also touched on human rights, nuclear cooperation, and space relations. The talks follow a series of high-profile incidents, including the devastating breach of US government computer networks and China's projection of military power beyond its borders.

site_title: Manulife hires Jenn Lundmark for real estate at US$77 billion unit
summary: Manulife Financial Corp has appointed Jenn Lundmark as head of real estate fundraising for its private markets unit. Lundmark, previously at American Realty Advisors and Goldman Sachs, will focus on raising equity capital for real estate investments. The move is part of Manulife's strategy to grow its private asset management business, with Lundmark joining a team that also includes Sahezad Pardhan, global chief financial officer, and Ken Pogrin, global head of business development and chief operating officer.

site_title: Indonesia seeks to mend fences with wary investors in resources
summary: Indonesia seeks to mend relations with investors in its resources sector, which was hit by nationalistic policies last year, including a ban on unprocessed mineral exports. The previous administration's policies cost the sector about $6 billion in lost revenue. However, under President Joko Widodo, there are signs of a shift towards encouraging investment and trade. The resources sector contributed around 12% of Indonesia's GDP last year, generating about $101 billion. The government is working to attract more investment and revenue back into the sector.

site_title: Euro stable versus dollar as Greek debt deal shows life
summary: The euro held steady against the dollar on Monday as Greece made progress with creditors over its bailout, sparking cautious optimism among traders. Eurogroup head Jeroen Dijsselbloem said Athens's new proposals were a "welcome step" towards a deal. The euro traded at $1.1340, little changed from its Friday level. A potential deal could prevent a Greek default and chaotic exit from the eurozone, boosting European equity markets and sending Wall Street stocks to a new record close. A final decision on Greece is expected by the end of the week.

site_title: How the European oil industry decided to save the climate
summary: Top European oil companies, including Royal Dutch Shell, BP, Total, Eni, Statoil, and BG, published an open letter in June 2015, announcing their support for efforts to put a cost on polluting and acknowledge their role in global warming. The move marks a significant shift, as the companies, who had previously opposed such measures, now recognize the need to address climate change. The decision is seen as a major victory for environmental groups, who have been pressing for action from the industry.

images.alt_text: The chiefs of some of Europe's biggest energy companies decided to pull an historic about-face. It was time to heed the protesters marching in the snow outside their industry conference demanding action to counter global warming.

site_title: China: Stocks open mixed after sharp correction last week
summary: China's stock market opened mixed on Tuesday after a 13% correction last week, with the CSI300 index rising 0.2% to 4,644.19 points and the Shanghai Composite Index losing 0.2% to 4,467.50 points. Liquidity concerns, triggered by margin financing tightening and tight money conditions, were cited as the main cause of the correction. China's stock market is expected to face more volatility ahead, with futures markets showing a 1.1% decline in July. The correction is the worst since the 2008 global financial crisis.

site_title: Amazon to pay self-published authors based on pages read
summary: Amazon is set to pay self-published authors based on the number of pages read in their Kindle ebooks, rather than borrowing frequency, starting next month. This change aims to incentivize authors to write longer books. The shift is part of Amazon's Kindle Direct Publishing platform, which allows authors to set list prices, decide rights, and edit their books at any time. The new payment system is expected to reward authors for producing more content, potentially leading to an increase in book length and quality.

site_title: Greek capital controls discussed, Belgian finance minister says
summary: Greek euro-area finance chiefs discussed introducing capital controls, but the discussion was inconclusive, with some in favor and others opposed. The Greek government has rejected capital controls despite running out of cash and facing bank deposit outflows. Euro-area heads of government will meet in Brussels to discuss Greece, and EU leaders will gather on June 25-26 for a regular summit. A deal between Greece and its creditors is uncertain, with more work needed to specify and quantify terms.

site_title: China margin trades buckle as selloff puts US$364 billion at risk
summary: China's stock market is experiencing a significant selloff, with the benchmark index declining at its fastest pace globally. Margin traders, who have taken on large amounts of debt to buy stocks, are facing forced liquidations as their shares plummet. At least $364 billion is at risk, with the 30 most heavily leveraged stocks in Shanghai having dropped an average of 17% since the market peaked. The China Securities Regulatory Commission is planning to curb margin trading and short selling, which could exacerbate the market decline and lead to a correction.

site_title: Greek government says budget proposals 'exceed' creditor demands
summary: Greek Prime Minister Alexis Tsipras stated that Greece's budget proposals for 2015 and 2016 exceeded creditor demands, aiming for a 1.51% and 2.87% fiscal surplus of GDP, respectively. This surpasses the creditors' one percent and two percent targets. Tsipras' letter to European Commission chief Jean-Claude Juncker indicates Greece's commitment to balancing its budget, meeting the desired primary surplus targets.

site_title: HSBC Singapore joins Nets payments network
summary: HSBC Singapore has joined the Nets payment network, allowing its debit cardholders to make payments at 87,000 acceptance points island-wide. This move follows Standard Chartered Bank and Maybank, and makes HSBC the latest foreign bank to offer this payment capability. The partnership enables drivers and commuters to top up their cash cards and MRT cards easily, and levels the playing field for HSBC with domestic banks in Singapore.

site_title: Oil prices rise with focus on Greece, Iran
summary: Oil prices rose on Monday due to hopes for a Greek bailout deal and potential return of Iranian supplies to the global market. US benchmark West Texas Intermediate edged up seven cents to $59.68 a barrel, while Brent North Sea crude closed at $63.34 a barrel. Eurozone leaders expressed optimism about Greece's reform proposals, but warned of a potential default and exit from the eurozone if talks fail. Conversely, a possible agreement between Iran and world powers on its nuclear program could lead to increased oil supplies and lower prices.

site_title: Chinese firms see broad-based recovery in Q2: survey
summary: China's economy experienced a broad-based recovery in Q2, according to a private survey of over 2,000 firms. Retail and property sectors drove the rebound, with rising revenue growth and profits. Manufacturing, services, and agriculture also saw gains, while shipping and travel decelerated. The labor market improved with stable wages, and home prices rose for the first time in 13 months. However, capital expenditures remained weak, and the recovery is not yet widespread, with firms in coastal regions showing no improvement. China's economy is slowly turning around, but not out of the woods yet.

site_title: Russia orders cuts in 2018 World Cup spending
summary: Russia orders 30 billion roubles (S$742.1 million) in cuts to 2018 World Cup spending due to economic crisis, following a global price of oil collapse and Western sanctions. Total spending now set at 631.5 billion roubles, with cuts mainly affecting hotels and non-essential expenses. Sports Minister Vitaly Mutko says stadium construction and renovation will proceed as planned. Despite investigations into corruption, President Vladimir Putin remains confident Russia will host the finals, citing it as a chance to showcase Russia as a modern state ahead of a presidential election in 2018.

site_title: US Port Authority makes overtures to aircraft-noise activists
summary: The Port Authority of New York and New Jersey has taken steps to address complaints about noise pollution from aircraft using the region's two airports, La Guardia and Kennedy. After years of lobbying by activists, officials have expanded the region's noise monitoring system, adding about a dozen new machines, and formed community round tables to discuss noise and other aviation-related issues. While progress has been made, there is uncertainty about whether these efforts will lead to significant solutions, and the complexity of the region's airspace makes changes in flight schedules and patterns challenging.

site_title: Google opens News Lab to sharpen journalism skills
summary: Google has launched the News Lab, an online lab where journalists can learn and sharpen Internet Age reporting skills. The lab aims to collaborate with journalists and entrepreneurs to apply technology innovations to reporting news. Google offers various tools, including Maps, YouTube, and Fusion Tables, to help newsrooms with reporting and storytelling. The News Lab mission is to enhance journalism skills and improve the way news is reported.

site_title: US: Nasdaq closes at new record high
summary: The Nasdaq Composite Index reached a fresh record high on Monday, closing at 5,153.97, driven by optimism over a potential Greek deal that could avert a default. The Dow Jones Industrial Average and S&P 500 also rose, with the Nasdaq outperforming its predecessors. Key stocks such as Cigna, Williams, and Under Armour benefited from the positive sentiment, while Martha Stewart Living Omnimedia fell 12.3% after being acquired by Sequential Brands Group. Bond prices fell, with the 10-year Treasury yield rising to 2.38%.

site_title: Climate change may destroy health gains: panel
summary: Climate change may erase global health gains made over the past 50 years due to increased heatwaves, floods, droughts, hunger, and diseases. An expert panel, led by University College London professor Hugh Montgomery, warns that tackling carbon emissions would yield significant health benefits. The panel considers climate change a medical emergency, highlighting the urgent need to address the issue to prevent a loss of health progress.

site_title: Japan, S Korea leaders mark 50 years of diplomatic ties with call for 'future-oriented relationship'
summary: Japanese Prime Minister Shinzo Abe and South Korean President Park Geun Hye marked the 50th anniversary of diplomatic ties between their countries with calls for a "future-oriented relationship." The leaders expressed a desire to improve relations, despite past issues such as the comfort women issue, and agreed to work towards a trilateral summit with Chinese leaders later this year. The developments come as tensions between Japan and South Korea have eased, with a thaw in relations appearing to have begun.

site_title: US energy firm rejects pipeline tycoon's US$48b takeover offer
summary: US energy firm Williams Cos has rejected a US$48 billion takeover offer from billionaire Kelcy Warren, worth US$53.1 billion including debt. The offer, a 32% premium to Williams' last close, was for shares in a new unit. Williams stated the bid undervalued the group, prompting the company to explore alternative options. The bid was made by Energy Transfer Equity LP, a pipeline magnate. Williams has hired banks to explore alternatives to the offer.

site_title: AirAsia audit committee clarifies non-consolidation of associates
summary: AirAsia's audit committee clarified that the airline did not consolidate its associate joint-venture companies due to aviation regulations in countries where they operate, preventing the airline from having legal control. The committee acknowledged that consolidation would better reflect the airline's actual financial position, but stated that this was not feasible. Despite concerns over accounting practices, AirAsia's senior management assured investors that the airline's business fundamentals remain intact, and shares have rebounded from a five-year low.

site_title: Abe signals shift in emphasis of Abenomics
summary: Prime Minister Shinzo Abe announced a shift in Japan's "Abenomics" strategy, focusing on persuading businesses to increase capital investment to boost growth. The move aims to offset the impact of an aging society and labor shortage. The strategy includes raising investment in areas such as robotics and artificial intelligence. This shift emphasizes going beyond monetary stimulus and encouraging businesses to invest in productivity-boosting initiatives.

site_title: Tricks to prolong the family trade's success
summary: A survey by EY and Kennesaw State University found that 76% of the world's largest family-owned businesses (25 in 21 global markets) identify themselves as family businesses in their promotional materials. This branding strategy sets them apart from competitors, improves customer trust, and is seen as a key factor in their success. According to Joe Astrachan, professor of management and entrepreneurship, family engagement in messaging and image delivery is crucial for business success and family health. This approach allows families to connect with stakeholders and shape the company's message.

images.alt_text: Mindy Tan

site_title: Uncertainties crimp fundraising in H1 but rebound seen in next half
summary: Singapore's corporate fundraising has been sluggish in the first half of 2015 due to macroeconomic uncertainty, with only three initial public offerings (IPOs) raising a total of S$46 million. The slowdown extends to bonds and syndicated loans, with issuers raising less than last year. However, market professionals expect the pipeline to open up again in the next six months, driven by factors such as China's 'One Belt, One Road' initiative and companies seeking to shore up their balance sheets. Investors are optimistic about the second half, with potential issuers and companies looking to diversify their funding sources.

site_title: Li & Fung said to form JV with 2 China retailers
summary: Li & Fung Ltd plans to form a joint venture with Shanghai Bailian Group Co and Beijing Wangfujing Department Store Group Co to develop their own clothing and home product brands. Li & Fung will license and manage the brands, aiming to help the Hong Kong-based company offset losses from Walmart business. The deal may also help Li & Fung adapt to intensifying US retail competition, where retailers are increasing discounts to attract customers. A signing ceremony is scheduled for Tuesday in Shanghai.

site_title: New Eurogroup meeting on Greece Wednesday: EU's Tusk
summary: Eurozone finance ministers will meet on Wednesday to reach a final bailout deal for Greece ahead of an EU leaders' summit. EU President Donald Tusk and European Commission chief Jean-Claude Juncker expressed confidence in a deal being reached this week, despite a five-month standoff. Greece's left-wing government has balked at further austerity measures, risking a default and possible eurozone exit if a deal isn't reached by June 30. The Eurogroup aims to finalize a reform plan by Wednesday evening to be presented to EU leaders the following day.

site_title: Ferrero offers £112m for British chocolate maker Thorntons
summary: Ferrero, the maker of Nutella, has offered to buy British chocolate company Thorntons Plc for £112 million. The deal, backed by Thorntons' board, brings together two of Europe's best-known chocolate makers. Shares in Thorntons rose 42.9% after the announcement, and the company's directors said the offer is "fair and reasonable." Ferrero, which already owns 29.9% of Thorntons, plans to conduct a strategic review of the business to identify synergies.

site_title: Talk of Malaysia in 1997/98 style meltdown unduly alarmist
summary: Malaysia's Prime Minister Najib Razak has warned of headwinds for the economy, sparking market concerns of a repeat of the 1997/98 financial crisis. However, experts argue that the country's high household debt is growing at a slower pace and its foreign currency assets stand at around US$100 billion. The current account has been in surplus for every quarter since 2005. Najib's troubles are centered on the 1MDB scandal, with the parliamentary Public Accounts Committee investigating the firm's accounts and demanding an audit. The opposition alliance has also fragmented, contributing to investor anxiety, but economists believe the country can respond effectively to any economic challenges.

site_title: Universal Medical seeks US$546m in HK IPO
summary: Universal Medical Financial & Technical Advisory Services Co, a Chinese medical equipment lessor, is seeking up to US$546 million in a Hong Kong initial public offering (IPO). The Beijing-based company is offering 423.2 million shares at HK$7.68 to HK$10 apiece. Cornerstone investors have agreed to buy US$200 million of stock in the offering. The IPO is expected to price on June 30 and trade on July 8, with Goldman Sachs and Nomura Holdings serving as joint sponsors.

site_title: Widodo port revival tested as Indonesia shipper ends bond hiatus
summary: Indonesia's shipping sector is seeking a revival with the issuance of a $200 million five-year dollar bond by PT Soechi Lines, the country's largest private tanker operator. The move is seen as a test of President Joko Widodo's plan to invest $6 billion in ports to boost trade, which has been hindered by a shortage of ports and economic growth. Moody's and Fitch Ratings have downgraded Soechi's debt to junk-rated, citing high leverage and a high barrier of entry in the market, but analysts expect the bond to be successful due to Soechi's strong relationship with state-owned oil company PT Pertamina.

images.alt_text: An Indonesian shipper is offering the first dollar bond from the country's industry in more than five years. President Joko Widodo must be hoping it succeeds.

site_title: Maersk seen favouring acquisitions over better rating
summary: Maersk, the Danish shipping giant, plans to use its strong credit rating to reward shareholders and make acquisitions, rather than seeking a higher rating. With a BBB+ rating at S&P and a Baa1 grade at Moody's, the company will prioritize cash returns and acquisitions over a higher credit grade. Maersk is seeking to expand its oil unit and invest in new container vessels and terminals. The company's head of group finance stated that financial policy remains unchanged, and analysts predict that Maersk will guard against a change in its credit rating.

site_title: Athens' reform proposal lifts Asian bourses
summary: Athens' reform proposal to stave off Greece's default and potential Grexit lifted markets across the region, with the Straits Times Index rising 0.4% and Hong Kong climbing 1.2%. The proposal still needs to be negotiated at an emergency European summit in Brussels. Singapore's Singtel led the local index's rally, driven by a joint venture with Indonesian telco Telkom, while three local banks gained ground as interest rates are expected to rise.

site_title: Silicon Valley firm gets help to carry on after CEO's sudden death
summary: SurveyMonkey's CEO Dave Goldberg, 47, died suddenly while on vacation in Mexico, prompting an emotional companywide meeting. The company, on the cusp of significant growth, navigates his death by replacing him, managing employee emotions, and dealing with recruitment calls from other tech companies. Temporary executive chairman Zander Lurie and mentorship programs have been implemented to keep employees focused, with regular staff surveys to monitor their well-being. The company plans a week of volunteering and a final celebration of Goldberg's legacy.

site_title: Medical tourism expertise helps Thailand cope with Mers
summary: Thailand's medical tourism industry may be helping contain the spread of Middle East Respiratory Syndrome (Mers), with the country reporting no new cases after a 75-year-old man from Oman was diagnosed with the virus. Authorities have heightened screening at Suvarnabhumi Airport and quarantined staff at the high-end Bumrungrad Hospital where the patient was treated. The World Health Organisation commended Thailand's response, and medical tourism experts believe the country's experience handling foreign visitors and high-risk regions will aid in containing the outbreak.

site_title: Global stocks surge on hope of Greece deal this week
summary: Global stocks surged on Monday, with European markets experiencing the largest gains, as a potential breakthrough in Greek debt talks sparked relief and hope. The CAC 40 in Paris jumped 3.81% and Frankfurt's DAX 30 rose 3.81%, while the US Nasdaq Composite reached a fresh record. Asian markets also rose, with Tokyo, Seoul, and Sydney gaining, as traders anticipated a Greek debt deal. The euro remained stable, and US bond yields surged, reversing last week's fall.

site_title: Amtek seeks new markets to expand; majority owners mull divestment
summary: Amtek Engineering Ltd, a Singapore-based component maker for Tesla Motors, is seeking new markets outside Asia as its majority shareholders consider a possible divestment. The company plans to focus on Latin America and boost research and development services. With over half of its revenue coming from Asia, CEO Daniel Yeong is looking abroad due to slowing growth in China. Private equity firms CVC Capital and Standard Chartered Private Equity are exploring a sale of their 58% stake, which could attract buyers due to the company's growth prospects.

site_title: Global body slams banks over Fifa transactions
summary: The Financial Action Task Force (FATF) criticized banks for lax oversight of suspicious Fifa transactions, warning that many corruption-related transfers may have gone undetected. The warning came after the US indictment of nine Fifa officials and five business executives on corruption charges. The FATF urged banks to step up scrutiny, following the indictment, which highlighted the need for improved anti-money laundering measures.

site_title: Goldman Sachs bullish on Australian banks, adds to holdings
summary: Goldman Sachs Asset Management has increased its holdings in Australian banks, betting on productivity improvements to bolster earnings despite concerns over capital levels and a weak economy. The move comes as bank valuations are near their cheapest since 2012 relative to global peers. Head of Australian equities Dion Hershan expects credit growth to continue and funding costs to decrease, citing improvements in banks' productivity and cost-to-income ratios. The investment adds to the firm's A$6.5 billion in Australian equities.

site_title: Vietnam bets on easing of business regulation to boost investments
summary: Vietnam aims to boost investments by easing business regulations, reducing the number of prohibited areas from 51 to six, and accelerating the sale of state-owned firms' shares. The government hopes to trigger an "investment wave" and increase foreign direct investment (FDI) to US$23 billion this year. The revised laws will also simplify permits and licenses, and the government predicts economic growth will reach 6.1% in the first six months of 2015. The move is seen as a major milestone to encourage both domestic and foreign investors, with the benchmark VN Index gaining one percent.

site_title: 'Extremely difficult' for government to support housing prices: BNP
summary: BNP Paribas predicts Singapore's private property prices could fall 10% over the next two years, citing supply overhang, tighter immigration policies, and slower regional growth. The bank believes the government's controls, including the total debt servicing ratio framework, will limit the ability to reverse the decline. This could have a negative wealth effect and constrain private consumption growth. The bank expects a "relatively orderly unwind" of the property market, with prices falling to 8.5 times income ratio, but warns of a prolonged downturn.

site_title: US health insurance sector catches merger mania
summary: The US health insurance sector is experiencing a surge in merger activity, driven by the Affordable Care Act's expansion of Medicaid and state marketplaces. Anthem Inc. has made a $47 billion takeover bid for Cigna, while UnitedHealth Group is reportedly in talks with Aetna. Other companies, including Cigna, are also exploring deals for Humana. Analysts say the mergers will help insurers reduce costs and increase negotiating power with healthcare providers, but regulators may scrutinize the deals to prevent market consolidation.

images.alt_text: Cigna has rejected Anthem's US$47 billion bid as "inadequate and not in the best interest of Cigna's shareholders".

site_title: Singtel CEO's FY2015 pay up 19% at S$5.6m
summary: Singtel CEO Chua Sock Koong received a 19% pay rise to S$5.6 million for FY2015, surpassing her peers at StarHub and M1. The bulk of the increase came from a variable bonus of S$3.83 million, up 28.6% from FY2014. The company's net profit grew 3.5% and operating revenue increased 2.2% in FY2015. The pay increase comes after Singtel rebranded in January and faced a social media controversy in March.

site_title: US mutual funds losing their shine
summary: US mutual funds, particularly hedge fund-like mutual funds, are experiencing a decline in investor interest, with flows slowing to the weakest pace since 2008. The category, which includes non-traditional bond funds and alternative stock funds, attracted $1.2 billion in the first five months of 2015, down from $39 billion last year. This drop is attributed to the strong performance of stocks and bonds last year, leading investors to question the need for alternative strategies. However, some funds, such as the US$30.7 billion BlackRock Strategic Income Opportunities Portfolio, are bucking the trend and attracting deposits.

site_title: Today's renters could turn buyers in 2016
summary: Nomura predicts that Singapore renters may switch to buying in 2016 due to the raising of the CPF salary ceiling from S$5,000 to S$6,000, which will increase monthly CPF contributions and potentially lower monthly mortgage payments. With current rental prices and higher mortgage rates, buying becomes a more affordable option, especially for those with mortgages of 20 years or less. Additionally, property owners may be willing to sell at a discount due to the weak leasing environment, further encouraging renters to buy.

site_title: UK bankers prone to be unethical, says report
summary: A survey by PricewaterhouseCoopers and the London Business School found that UK bankers are more likely to behave unethically when under pressure to meet performance targets. The study, involving 2,431 managers, revealed that anxiety and a desire for financial rewards led to unethical choices. The findings come as the financial industry faces stricter regulation, including the senior managers' regime, which increases non-executive directors' responsibilities and introduces potential jail sentences for bankers who take risks leading to firm failure. The report highlights the need for a culture shift in the industry.

site_title: Asian IT professionals have big role in region's transformation
summary: Asian IT professionals are playing a crucial role in the region's transformation towards a service-based economy. The Asian Development Bank predicts Asia's urban population will nearly double by 2050, driving growth in the service sector. This shift will require IT professionals to acquire new skillsets, with business skills such as communication and service management becoming more important than technical skills. The region's emerging tech workforce and booming e-commerce industry will also contribute to the growth of services, making Asia well-placed to thrive in the global service economy.

site_title: How companies change bad practices
summary: Major US clothing companies responding to Bangladesh factory collapse, increasing safety checks and forming consortia to coordinate checks. This follows the Bangladesh authorities filing murder charges against those involved in the 2013 Rana Plaza factory collapse. Companies face publicity problems and social movement threats if they don't act quickly, driving reforms. However, less than one-third of Bangladesh's clothing factories are being checked, leaving many unsafe ones.

site_title: Octogenarian aims for world record for simultaneous chess
summary: An 87-year-old Hungarian woman, Brigitta Sinka, aims to set a world record by beating 1920s Cuban chess grandmaster Jose Raul Capablanca in simultaneous play. Sinka, a former top amateur player, has played over 13,000 documented games of simultaneous chess, surpassing Capablanca's total of 13,545. Despite three heart operations, Sinka remains determined to achieve her goal, which she hopes will be recognized by Guinness Records.

site_title: Falling back on family ties when firms go bust
summary: Family-owned companies are often better equipped to handle bankruptcy proceedings due to a combination of financial and non-financial motivations. Research found that family firms emerged from bankruptcy faster and had higher recovery rates for debt, with a 32% faster exit and a 12% higher recovery rate. This is likely due to the emotional ties and reputation of the family, as well as their desire to retain control of the company. As a result, minority shareholders and lenders are willing to lend at lower interest rates, recognizing the effectiveness of family blockholders in managing bankruptcy.

site_title: How to attain 4% growth and lose weight without dieting
summary: Jeb Bush's presidential campaign promises to double the US economy's growth rate to 4% and enable Americans to lose weight without dieting, but experts argue that these goals are unrealistic. The US has struggled to achieve consistent economic growth, with only three presidents (Clinton, Reagan, and Bush Sr.) achieving an average growth rate of 3.4% or higher since 1990. Bush's record as governor of Florida, which experienced a housing bubble and subsequent slump, is also questionable. Critics argue that his party's boasting about rapid economic growth is self-serving and based on "voodoo economics," a term coined by George HW Bush to describe trickle-down tax policies.

site_title: AIIB remains an unknown quantity
summary: The Asian Infrastructure Investment Bank (AIIB), led by China, is preparing to sign its Articles of Agreement, but its true intentions and scope remain unclear. Established to provide massive infrastructure investment, the AIIB shares similarities with the Silk Road Fund, a Chinese organization aiming to bind the Eurasian continent into a single entity. This may launch China as a global economic and political power, while potentially marginalizing the US. European nations, including Britain, have joined the AIIB, possibly driven by the prospect of financing infrastructure across the Eurasian continent.

site_title: Norway fund to open Tokyo office
summary: Norway's Government Pension Fund Global, worth $890 billion, plans to open an office in Tokyo as part of its expansion into Asia's real estate market. The fund, which has already invested in prime locations such as Times Square and Champs Elysees, aims to focus on 10-15 cities globally, with Tokyo and Singapore being top targets. The office opening is expected to happen this year, with a team being built to manage investments in the region. The fund sees Tokyo as a major market for real estate, with no official spending target announced.

site_title: Market for Islamic aircraft-loans doubles
summary: The market for Islamic aircraft loans has doubled in size with Saudi Arabia's state-owned carrier placing orders for 50 planes from Airbus Group, valued at $7.7 billion. This deal, facilitated by the Aircraft Leasing Islamic Fund, marks the largest sukuk on record for aviation financing. The growing importance of Islamic financing in the airline industry is expected to nearly double global Syariah-compliant financial assets by 2018, according to Ernst & Young. This trend is seen as a smart way to finance aviation, offering a new world of investors, particularly in Saudi and Kuwait.

site_title: Singapore M&A deals fall sharply in Q2
summary: M&A deal volumes in Singapore dropped 37% in Q2 to US$9.8 billion, with a 53% decline compared to the first quarter. Domestic deals, where both parties were based in Singapore, dried up to a trickle. Cross-border and outbound transactions took a hit, with a 68% decline in announced deal volumes year-on-year. The energy and power sector was the most active, but experts expect cross-border transactions to remain key drivers of M&A activity in Singapore.

site_title: Eurozone welcomes new Greek debt plans
summary: Eurozone finance ministers welcomed Greece's new debt plans, calling them "comprehensive" and a "basis to really restart the talks". However, they require detailed study and may not lead to an agreement to avert a default. Greece must make a 1.6 billion euro repayment to the IMF by June 30, and officials will reconvene later this week to discuss the proposal. The proposal includes tax increases, pension reform, and a value-added-tax system reform. While some leaders, like Chancellor Angela Merkel, expressed optimism, others, like German Finance Minister Wolfgang Schaeuble, were pessimistic, citing a lack of substance in the proposal.

images.alt_text: Mr Tsipras (far left) is welcomed by European Commission president Jean-Claude Juncker for a meeting ahead of the eurozone emergency summit in Brussels on Monday. Officials made clear that they would only agree on a political timetable for a deal.

site_title: Japan should start negotiations for an FTA with the EU
summary: Japan should initiate negotiations for a free trade agreement (FTA) with the European Union (EU), given its significant stake in the IMF and the EU's financial struggles. The EU has been courting Japan to join their consultations, following the exposure of the IMF loan as a default risk. This move aims to emphasize Tokyo's role as a senior partner in international finance and commerce, potentially benefiting Japan's export-enhancing yen devaluation and completing Prime Minister Shinzo Abe's Abenomics reform.

site_title: Microsoft executive reaches new heights
summary: Microsoft executive Terry Myerson is set to expand his role as the company's most powerful product leader after a series of senior executives departed following the consolidation of engineering efforts. Myerson, 42, will oversee Microsoft's growing family of devices, including Windows, Xbox, and Lumia smartphones, and will lead over 10,000 employees. His appointment is seen as a significant move to address Microsoft's struggling smartphone division, with his success on Windows Phone and Windows 10 expected to be closely watched.

site_title: Euro is poor guide to fate of single-currency project
summary: The euro is trading near its three-month high despite concerns over Greece's potential default or exit from the eurozone. Currency traders are citing underlying pessimism, but exchange rates also reflect the Federal Reserve's actions and investors' concerns about the monetary union. However, bond yields and stock prices may be a better indicator of investors' views, as they show a more accurate reflection of the single currency's prospects. The euro's resilience is expected to be tested if Greece's situation worsens, but the bond and stock markets may provide a more accurate guide to its future.

images.alt_text: The Greek crisis is compromising currency traders' reputation for being the first and fastest to react to big economic or political news.

site_title: No flood of orders for US food yet from Cuba
summary: US food exports to Cuba have dropped by half since President Barack Obama's announcement of a new opening to the island, from $160 million in 2014 to $83 million this year. Despite the potential for a $2 billion annual market, Congress must lift the embargo to allow for trade relations. Cuban rice is now mostly sourced from Vietnam, and frozen chicken has lost favor in Havana. US producers are urging Congress to overturn restrictions, citing a missed opportunity for revenue and quality competition.

site_title: UK banks find regulator's data request too onerous
summary: The UK Financial Conduct Authority (FCA) has sent a sweeping draft request to banks for data on thousands of bond and equity deals over the past five years, including investor order sizes and final allocations. The request is part of a probe into competition in the investment banking industry, which has sparked concerns about the potential scale of the demands. Banks have expressed concerns about the feasibility of providing such extensive data, citing the need to protect client confidentiality and the potential for substantial resources to be required.

site_title: Asia exporters struggle to overhaul economic model
summary: Asian exporters struggle to adapt to a changing global economy, with export-led growth no longer serving the region well. Despite a slight increase in exports to the US, economists warn that world trade recovery is capped due to frugal American consumers and stagnant global trade talks. Asian countries, including Indonesia, Malaysia, and South Korea, are considering new economic models, targeting Chinese consumers rather than factories, as exports have fallen an average of 5% this year. Economists fear a structural slowdown, rather than a cyclical slowdown, and a return to strong growth is unlikely.

site_title: Surbana Jurong buys two companies and is scouring for more
summary: Surbana Jurong, a Singapore-based urbanisation and infrastructure consultancy, has acquired two companies, KTP Consultants and Sinosun Architects & Engineering Co Ltd, to expand its presence in China and increase its technical capabilities. The acquisition doubles the group's reach in China to 16 cities, boosts its staff strength by a quarter to 4,000, and deepens its capabilities. This move aims to position Surbana Jurong as an Asian powerhouse in the industry.

images.alt_text: Surbana Jurong group chief executive Wong Heang Fine and chairman Liew Mun Leong (standing, second and third from left respectively) at the signing ceremony with (seated, from left) KTP Consultants director Allan Teo and managing director Yeo Choon Chong, Surbana International Consultants chief executive Pang Yee Ean, and Sino-Sun Architects & Engineers general manager Xu Jianwei and deputy general manager Deng Xiaoai.

site_title: Malaysia steps up screening for Mers at entry points
summary: Malaysia has stepped up health screenings at all entry points, including airports, to monitor for Middle East Respiratory Syndrome (Mers) after the first reported case in neighboring Thailand. The country is also briefing visitors on precautions to avoid infection. Meanwhile, South Korea reported two more Mers deaths, bringing the total to 27, and confirmed three more cases, taking the outbreak total to 172. There have been no reported cases in Malaysia. The virus is believed to be linked to camels, with isolated cases previously reported in Asia.

site_title: Weaker shareholder rights may prove ominous for Hong Kong
summary: Hong Kong's stock exchange is considering a change to its voting system, allowing only a select few companies with billions of US dollars in value to give some investors extra votes. This move is seen as a compromise to attract fast-growing companies, but is met with skepticism from large fund managers like BlackRock and Fidelity. The change could weaken shareholder rights, jeopardizing Hong Kong's reputation for transparency and predictability, which is increasingly valuable as China's capital markets open up.

site_title: Christie's clobbers Sotheby's with a gavel
summary: Christie's surpassed Sotheby's in a recent auction, achieving a total of $1.7 billion in sales over four days in New York. The auction house sold $706 million worth of 20th-century art in under two hours, including a record-breaking $179.4 million for Pablo Picasso's "Les Femmes d'Alger". This marks Christie's biggest week ever and solidifies its position as a leading player in the contemporary art market.
