EPIC BATTLE: Napoleon, emperor of France, was outmanoeuvred by the Duke of Wellington (above) commanding the British, Dutch, Belgian and German allied army.

site_title: Bond funds worldwide post biggest outflows in two years: BofA
summary: Investors worldwide withdrew $10.3 billion from bond funds in the week ended June 17, marking the largest outflows in two years, according to a Bank of America Merrill Lynch report. Investment-grade bond funds saw $2.1 billion in outflows, while high-yield bond funds faced their biggest withdrawals since December, totaling $4 billion. In contrast, stock funds attracted $10.8 billion, with all new cash flowing into exchange-traded funds, marking their largest inflows in three months.

site_title: Europe: Stocks advance amid optimism Greek resolution is close
summary: European stocks rose 0.4% on Friday, driven by optimism over a potential resolution to Greece's debt talks. The Stoxx Europe 600 Index reached its highest level since February, with benchmark indexes in Ireland and Italy also advancing. Greek stocks rose 0.6% after the European Central Bank increased emergency funding for Greek lenders. Fears of contagion easing led to a reversal of losses, with European equities reversing their lowest level since February.

site_title: Daimler sells Mercedes dealerships in east Germany to China's Lei Shing Hong
summary: Daimler is selling around a quarter of its 160 Mercedes-Benz dealerships in eastern Germany to China's Lei Shing Hong Group. This move is part of Daimler's plan to overhaul its dealership operations. The sales outlets will be located in eastern Germany, where Mercedes accounts for about half of the brand's car sales. Lei Shing Hong is expanding in Germany to gain experience in a mature market. The deal is the latest step in Daimler's efforts to streamline its dealership operations.

site_title: Switzerland may tighten anti-money laundering rules
summary: Switzerland may tighten its anti-money laundering laws following a report by a government-appointed group that found the country is still vulnerable to financial crime. The report, released amid a corruption scandal surrounding FIFA, recommends eight measures to improve the existing anti-money laundering infrastructure, including dialogue between the public and private sectors and developing statistics. The Swiss government will make its recommendations to parliament, amid concerns that Switzerland's trading hub for crude oil and iron ore makes it an attractive location for money laundering.

site_title: US: Stocks little changed as resolution nears on Greece crisis
summary: US stocks remained little changed on Friday as investors anticipate a resolution to the Greek debt crisis, despite a record high reached by the Nasdaq Composite Index on Thursday. The S&P 500 slipped 0.1% to 2,119.87, while the Nasdaq rose to a record high. Investors are focusing on the Federal Reserve's reassurance that any rate hike will be gradual, citing past rate mistakes as a major concern. The Greek standoff has been a non-event for US equity investors, with the S&P 500 up 1.3% through Thursday.

site_title: EU finance chiefs agree on draft law tackling big banks
summary: EU finance ministers have reached a deal on a law to tackle too-big-to-fail banks, with France securing a last-minute change to exempt UK lenders. The compromise, reached after weeks of negotiations, will assess banks to determine if they should split off trading activities from consumer services. The deal, circulated by Latvia, aims to strengthen EU banking regulations and ensure the stability of the financial system. The agreement marks a significant step forward in EU efforts to regulate large banks and prevent future financial crises.

site_title: CapitaLand's CMA Japan Trust acquires Japanese mall for 3.05b yen
summary: CapitaLand's CMA Japan Trust acquired Vivit Minami Funabashi, a shopping mall in Greater Tokyo, Japan, for 3.05 billion yen (S$33.1 million). The mall is part of CapitaMalls Japan Fund Pte Ltd's portfolio, in which CapitaLand has a 26.3% stake. This acquisition is part of CMA Japan Trust's efforts to expand its portfolio and increase its presence in the Japanese real estate market.

site_title: China to allow full foreign ownership of some e-commerce businesses
summary: China has announced that it will allow full foreign ownership of some e-commerce businesses to boost foreign investment and industry competitiveness. The move, effective immediately, applies to "online data handling and trade handling services." However, the specific businesses affected were not specified. This change is aimed at encouraging foreign investment in the e-commerce sector, which is a key area for China's economic development.

site_title: Bank of England's McCafferty sees chance of 2015 rate rise, hinges on data
summary: Bank of England policymaker Ian McCafferty suggests the possibility of raising interest rates as early as the end of 2015, depending on wage and economic growth data. This contradicts current market expectations, which point to a rate hike in May or June 2016. McCafferty's stance is data-dependent, and he previously supported a rate rise late last year until inflation fell below the 2% target. His comments indicate a potential shift in the Bank of England's monetary policy.

images.alt_text: The Bank of England could raise interest rates as early as the end of this year, or six months later, depending on growth in wages and the economy as a whole, BoE policymaker Ian McCafferty was reported as saying on Friday.

site_title: IHC to acquire related firm Healthway
summary: International Healthway Corporation (IHC) will acquire Healthway Medical Corporation through a scheme of arrangement, purchasing shares at S$0.10 apiece and issuing new IHC shares at S$0.45 apiece. The deal will make Healthway a wholly owned subsidiary of IHC, with Healthway shareholders becoming IHC shareholders. The scheme is expected to provide diversification opportunities and access to a broader healthcare business, including facilities-based assets across Asia. If approved, Healthway will be delisted from Catalist.

site_title: Brazil targets 2 Petrobras contractors in corruption probe
summary: Brazilian police have targeted two major Petrobras contractors, Odebrecht and Andrade Gutierrez, in a corruption investigation. Federal police conducted raids in four Brazilian states, seizing documents and making arrests. The "Lava Jato" probe has led to the indictment of numerous executives and politicians, including those from President Dilma Rousseff's government. This development has shaken Rousseff's government and weighed on Brazil's economy, already in recession. The investigation is ongoing, with no further details on the targeted contractors available.

site_title: Norway proposes to place main interbank rate under FSA oversight
summary: Norway proposes to place its main interbank rate under the oversight of the Financial Supervisory Authority (FSA) to prevent mispricing of financial instruments and maintain confidence among market participants. The decision comes after a 2013 investigation found that the rate was being manipulated. Finance Norway agreed to transfer the rate to the Oslo stock exchange in 2013. The proposal aims to increase transparency and regulate the benchmark rate, which has significant economic implications.

site_title: Singapore monitoring Mers situation in Thailand but no airport screening yet: Gan Kim Yong
summary: Singapore is monitoring the Middle East Respiratory Syndrome (Mers) situation in Thailand, but currently does not screen travellers at the airport due to a single case and contained situation. Health Minister Gan Kim Yong stated that Singapore will continue to closely monitor developments and consider introducing additional measures if necessary.

site_title: Latest earnings
summary:

NTT DC Reit's Singapore public offer was oversubscribed 9.8 times. Creative Technology warned of potential revenue shortfall and operating loss similar to the first half of the year. London's Heathrow is considering higher fees for a £10 billion upgrade. Indonesia detained a Trafigura employee in a 285 trillion rupiah graft case. OCBC announced Tan Teck Long as its incoming CEO. The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) and the People's Bank of China (PBOC) plan to deepen cooperation in green and transition finance. Singapore stocks continued their 5-day rally ahead of GDP data.

site_title: Credit Suisse seen US$14 billion short of capital: Barclays
summary: Credit Suisse Group AG is seen US$14.1 billion short of capital, according to Barclays analysts, citing a leverage ratio that ranks the bank second-lowest among 11 banks analyzed. The Swiss National Bank has urged the bank to boost its leverage ratio, and speculation of a capital increase has grown following the upcoming leadership change. The bank trades at a higher discount to its sum of parts valuation, raising concerns over its capital adequacy.

site_title: Greek central bank chief says banking system stable
summary: Greek central bank governor Yannis Stournaras confirmed the stability of the banking system, citing joint actions with the European Central Bank. Despite a surge in bank deposit outflows of 3 billion euros this week, Stournaras sought to calm concerns, emphasizing the system's full security. The comments come as Greece faces a potential default at the end of the month without a deal with creditors.

site_title: EU reaches deal on bank bill as France wins late concessions
summary: European Union finance ministers reached a deal on a law to tackle too-big-to-fail banks, with France securing concessions on exemptions for UK lenders. The draft law would strengthen financial stability by protecting the deposit-taking business of complex EU banks from risky trading activities. Under the proposed rules, banks with annual trading activities over $113 billion would face added scrutiny, and exemptions would apply for banks with few retail deposits. The deal paves the way for compromise talks with the European Parliament on the final version of the law, which could be finalized by the end of this year.

site_title: After doubts, economists find China kills US factory jobs
summary: A generation of economists has revised their views on the decline of US factory jobs, concluding that China's trade policies are a significant factor. This shift in opinion may impact the opposition to President Barack Obama's Trans-Pacific Partnership. The findings contradict the long-held assumption that automation was the primary cause of the decline in manufacturing employment. The trend of declining manufacturing employment is not unique to the US, with other developed nations like Japan also experiencing similar declines. This new perspective may influence US trade policies and the Democratic Party's stance on international commerce agreements.

site_title: Scoot flight to Singapore grounded overnight in Hong Kong
summary: A Scoot flight from Hong Kong to Singapore was grounded overnight due to a technical fault. The budget carrier stated that a maintenance service provider in Hong Kong was unable to obtain a replacement part from Singapore, leading to the aircraft being grounded. The flight was scheduled to depart at 7:10am on Friday.

images.alt_text: Scoot flight TZ 221, which was scheduled to depart Hong Kong for Singapore at 7.10am on Friday, was grounded "due to a technical fault".

site_title: Britain to simplify visa process for Chinese visitors to Europe
summary: Britain is simplifying its visa process for Chinese visitors to Europe, allowing them to apply for UK and European visas in a single process. The scheme starts on July 1, creating a one-stop shop for Chinese visitors to the UK and Europe, whether for business or leisure. This change aims to remove a barrier discouraging tourists from visiting Britain while touring Europe.

site_title: Malaysia central bank seeks to cool political noise on ringgit
summary: Malaysia's central bank, Bank Negara Malaysia, has urged the country to resolve domestic issues affecting the weakening ringgit, rather than politicizing the debate. The statement comes after Deputy Finance Minister Ahmad Maslan linked former leader Mahathir Mohamad's criticism of Prime Minister Najib Razak to the ringgit's weakness. The bank stated that fundamentals remain sound and markets should look beyond political noise, with the ringgit declining over 6% this year.

site_title: Singapore Wrap Friday
summary: Singapore's Ministry of Transport expressed surprise over Malaysia's plan to terminate the high-speed rail project at Johor Bahru instead of Jurong East. The government may review property cooling measures at year-end, according to a UOB research note. Minister Lim Hng Kiang announced continued investment in public electronics R&D. Fitch Ratings assigned a 'AAA(EXP)' rating to DBS Bank's mortgage covered bonds. The Ministry of National Development plans to study help for resale flat buyers. Singapore shares stayed flat, with caution over Greece and China weighing on the market.

site_title: Germany raises 5 billion euros in auction of mobile phone frequencies
summary: Germany successfully auctioned off 5.1 billion euros in mobile phone frequencies, with Vodafone, Deutsche Telekom, and Telefonica purchasing frequencies for 2.1 billion, 1.8 billion, and 1.2 billion euros respectively. The auction aimed to provide faster internet connections in rural areas via smartphones and tablets. The proceeds will be invested in digital infrastructure, a significant increase from the 50.8 billion euros raised in the 2000 auction for new 3G network licenses.

site_title: Singapore: STI stays flat as Greece, China dampen market
summary: Singapore shares stayed flat on Friday, with the Straits Times Index closing at 3,300.96, as caution over Greece and China weighed on the market. Modest gains from Singapore Telecommunications and banks supported the index, despite a 1.2% drop from Jardine Cycle and Carriage. The market saw 1.37 billion shares traded, with gains outnumbering losses 242 to 179.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares end higher
summary: Malaysia's Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rose 3.65 points to close at 1,721.77 on Friday, driven by gains in 489 stocks while 299 lost value. Total trades valued RM2.42 billion.

site_title: CVC, Standard Chartered said to weigh Amtek Engineering sale
summary: CVC Capital Partners and Standard Chartered Private Equity are exploring a sale of their majority stake in Amtek Engineering Ltd, a Singapore-based parts manufacturer, with the help of Rippledot Capital Advisers. The buyout firms own a 58% stake valued at S$212 million, and may wait until Interplex Industries, a US precision-tool maker acquired by Amtek, is fully integrated before actively seeking buyers. Amtek aims to double sales to $2 billion in five to seven years through acquisitions, and its CEO believes the company is "very attractive" to potential buyers.

site_title: UK said to pick Goldman to replace JPMorgan for RBS sale
summary: The UK government has hired Goldman Sachs to replace JPMorgan Chase as its adviser for selling shares in Royal Bank of Scotland Group Plc and Lloyds Banking Group Plc. Goldman Sachs will act as privatisation-strategy advisor to UK Financial Investments Ltd, which manages taxpayer stakes in bailed-out lenders. Chancellor George Osborne plans to return RBS to private ownership in the coming months, despite a potential loss for UK taxpayers. Taxpayers own 79% of RBS and 18% of Lloyds, with a trading plan to sell Lloyds shares by the end of December.

site_title: China business confidence falls in Q2 vs Q1: Central bank survey
summary: China's business confidence fell in the second quarter of 2015 compared to the first quarter, according to a survey by the People's Bank of China. Fewer households deemed housing prices "unacceptably high" in Q2, while more bankers believed the economy had cooled. This decrease in business confidence may raise pressure on policymakers as China's GDP growth is expected to slow.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks end up 0.25%
summary: Hong Kong stocks ended the day 0.25% higher, mirroring a broader Asian advance and following a record finish on Wall Street. The Hang Seng Index rose 65.87 points to 26,760.53 on HK$140.61 billion in turnover. The gains came despite ongoing US-China trade tensions and uncertainty.

site_title: Trading house Gunvor to sell bulk of terminals in Russia: Interfax
summary: Gunvor, a trading house, plans to sell the majority of its Russian terminals, including the Ust-Luga and Novorossiisk terminals. CEO Torbjorn Tornqvist stated the company's intention to invest in Russia in the future. This move comes after Gunvor expanded into new markets, including base metals trading, and reduced its exposure to Russia following sanctions imposed on its co-founder and Russian businessman Gennady Timchenko in 2014.

site_title: Singapore May consumer prices seen falling for 7th straight month
summary: Singapore's consumer price index is expected to fall 0.5% from a year earlier in May, marking the seventh straight month of decline, according to a Reuters poll. The drop is attributed to lower housing costs. In contrast, the Monetary Authority of Singapore's core inflation measure is forecast to rise 0.5% from a year earlier. This suggests that the central bank is closely monitoring inflation, but overall prices are still expected to remain under control.

site_title: Tokyo: Shares end up 0.92%
summary: Tokyo stocks rose 0.92% on Friday, with the Nikkei 225 index closing at 20,174.24, following Japan's central bank's unchanged record stimulus plan. The Topix index also increased 0.89%. This move came despite global economic uncertainty, with the US and EU trade talks in focus.

site_title: China's US$100 billion E Fund plans offices in New York, London
summary: E Fund Management Co, a Guangzhou-based fund-management company overseeing $100 billion, plans to open offices in New York and London to promote its brand and products overseas. The company aims to capitalize on growing interest in yuan assets and China's increasing global financial presence. With offices in Asia, the US, and Europe, E Fund aims to expand its reach and offer its core fixed-income and equity products to foreign investors. The move is seen as a vital stepping stone for the company's growth in the global market.

site_title: Juncker says 'I don't understand Tsipras': report
summary: European Commission chief Jean-Claude Juncker expressed frustration with Greek Prime Minister Alexis Tsipras, stating "I don't understand Tsipras" and that the trust Juncker placed in him was not reciprocated. This comes amid the deepening debt crisis in Greece, with Juncker and Tsipras reportedly falling out several times.

site_title: Tsipras says deal can be done as Greek banks lead stocks higher
summary: Greek Prime Minister Alexis Tsipras expressed confidence that a deal on his country's finances can be reached at an emergency summit of European leaders on Monday. This optimism led to a rise in the Athens Stock Exchange index, with banks contributing to the growth. Tsipras stated that those relying on crisis scenarios will be proven wrong, indicating a positive development in the path toward a deal.

site_title: Grexit 'beginning of the end of the eurozone': Greek PM
summary: Greek Prime Minister Alexis Tsipras stated that a Greek exit from the eurozone would mark the beginning of the end of the single currency. He warned that such a move would be "irreversible" and "very negative" for the European Union. Talks between Greece and EU finance ministers broke down, with a summit set for Monday in Brussels to discuss a reform deal. Greece must agree to austerity terms by the end of June to avoid defaulting on an IMF debt payment and potential eurozone exit. The EU sees an agreement as still possible, but the outcome is uncertain.

site_title: Hong Kong bourse to launch formal consultation on weighted voting rights
summary: Hong Kong's stock exchange, HKEx, plans to launch a formal consultation on weighted voting rights, a move that could allow companies with different share classes to list on the market. The proposal aims to loosen strict listing rules, but HKEx has cautioned that weighted voting rights should not be available in all circumstances. The consultation is expected to be finalized in the third or fourth quarter of this year.

site_title: South Korea says Mers outbreak shows signs of subsiding
summary: South Korea reported one new Mers case, the lowest rate of new infections in two weeks, bringing the total confirmed cases to 166. The number of people in quarantine has fallen 12% to 5,930. A rural village was reopened after a two-week quarantine, and the government expressed optimism that the outbreak is subsiding. However, the WHO chief Margaret Chan noted that the outbreak may take a little longer to bring under control, and scientists detected no genetic change in the virus.

site_title: Europe: Stocks mixed at open
summary: Europe's main stock markets opened mixed on Friday, with London's FTSE 100 down 0.18% to 6,695.95 points, while Frankfurt's DAX 30 rose 0.19% to 11,121.30 points. Paris' CAC 40 gained 0.09%. The markets await a key meeting on Greece's bailout, with investors also monitoring US-EU trade talks.

site_title: RWE promotes cooperation with Abu Dhabi, cuts further costs
summary: RWE AG, Germany's largest power producer, is promoting cooperation with Abu Dhabi on renewable energy technology as the emirate pursues climate targets. CEO Peter Terium said the company is in talks with Abu Dhabi investors about taking a minority stake in RWE's projects, including solar and wind farms, grids, and energy efficiency. RWE aims to cut further costs amid sliding wholesale power prices and debts of 27.7 billion euros. The company plans to make further cost cuts and simplify its legal structure in Germany, but is less likely to consider a split-up of the company.

site_title: Chinese stock markets have worst week since global financial crisis
summary: Chinese stock markets have recorded their worst week since the 2008 global financial crisis, with the Shanghai index ending the week down 13.3%. Analysts had warned of market volatility and excessive valuations, with some companies trading at 200-300 times earnings. The doubling of primary indexes since late last year has made Chinese markets the world's best performing major market, with a net market capitalization of 66.2 trillion yuan, exceeding the country's GDP.

site_title: Noble closes disposal of Mongolian coal subsidiary
summary: Noble Group, Asia's largest commodities trader, has closed the disposal of its Mongolian coal subsidiary Enkhtunkh Orchlon LLC for up to US$65 million. The consideration was agreed on a willing-buyer, willing-seller basis, taking into account the development prospects of the 50,022-hectare tenement in Mongolia's South Gobi basin. Noble had previously conducted exploration activities, including drilling 200 holes, which confirmed coking and thermal coal. The disposal follows Noble's latest financial statements, which valued the shares at US$57.8 million and US$57.5 million.

images.alt_text: Asia's largest commodities trader, Noble Group, has closed the disposal of its equity interest in its wholly-owned Mongolian coal subsidiary Enkhtunkh Orchlon LLC for an aggregate consideration of up to US$65 million, following the exercise of an option on Dec 24 last year.

site_title: Uber braces for face-off in France over its labour practices
summary: Uber is bracing for a strike in France over its labor practices, with taxi unions calling for a nationwide, unlimited strike starting June 25. The French government has already taken steps to crack down on Uber's use of unlicensed chauffeurs, and companies like UberPop are opposed by the government. Uber faces similar challenges in other European countries, including Portugal, Belgium, and Germany. The company's business model, which classifies drivers as independent contractors, is being challenged in California, where the labor commissioner has ruled that they must be considered employees.

site_title: Saudi Arabia pumps oil flat out in Citi, Goldman's new oil order
summary: Saudi Arabia plans to pump oil at maximum levels, potentially exceeding 11 million barrels per day, in an effort to maintain its market share and pressure US and other oil producers. This move, supported by Goldman Sachs and Citigroup, comes as the global glut continues to rise, with oil prices rebounding 40% since January. Saudi Arabia has already increased production to a 30-year high of 10.3 million barrels per day, and its decision is seen as a shift away from cutting supplies to shore up prices.

site_title: Metro eyes online, international expansion
summary: Metro AG, Germany's fourth-largest retailer, plans to expand its online and international operations after selling its Kaufhof department store chain for 2.8 billion euros. CEO Olaf Koch aims to open more Media Markt and Saturn stores abroad, and invest in digital businesses and online delivery services. This move follows Hudson's Bay Co's acquisition of Kaufhof, which plans to aggressively expand e-commerce. Metro will focus on developing its cash-and-carry and consumer-electronics businesses, and reduce debt through recent sales.

site_title: Shenzhen-HK stock connect preparation going smoothly: regulator
summary: China's Shenzhen-HK stock connect scheme preparation is progressing smoothly, according to the China Securities Regulatory Commission (CSRC). The CSRC has consistently supported the scheme, which aims to boost investment in China's markets. The regulator also announced that institutions other than brokerages can act as market makers in the country's main over-the-counter exchange, further facilitating the scheme. The move is expected to enhance market efficiency and increase access to China's markets.

site_title: Singapore expresses "surprise" at statement of high-speed rail terminating at JB (Amended)
summary: Singapore's Ministry of Transport expressed "surprise" over Malaysia's statement that the high-speed rail (HSR) link between Kuala Lumpur and Singapore will terminate at Johor Bahru instead of Jurong East. Both countries had agreed to build the HSR in 2013, and studies have been conducted. Singapore believes terminating the HSR in Johor Bahru will not achieve the direct connection between city centers, contrary to Malaysia's claims. The crossing of the Johor Bahru-Singapore RTS Link will be determined after both terminus locations are confirmed, with Singapore's terminus already confirmed at Woodlands North station.

site_title: Kuroda says yen's slump isn't crimping BOJ's policy flexibility
summary: Bank of Japan Governor Haruhiko Kuroda stated that the yen's slump isn't hindering the central bank's policy flexibility, despite the currency's recent decline. The BOJ maintained its record monetary stimulus, aiming for 2% inflation by mid-next fiscal year. Analysts note emerging risks to economic recovery, including sluggish export growth and warehouse stockpiles. The central bank will continue to expand the monetary base at an annual pace of 80 trillion yen.

site_title: China Aircraft CEO resigns during vacation, can't be contacted
summary: China Aircraft Leasing Group Holdings Ltd CEO Poon Ho Man resigned during his annual leave, citing "personal reasons." The company received his resignation letter on June 17, but the board has been unable to contact him since. Chairman Chen Shuang took over as CEO, and CFO Yu Tai also resigned. The company's shares plummeted 22% in Hong Kong trading, the largest intraday drop since listing in 2014. The sudden departure has raised concerns about the company's stability and future prospects.

site_title: Biggest wealth fund ready to battle 'flash boys' in Asia
summary: Norway's $890 billion wealth fund is taking steps to avoid high-frequency trading in Asia, where the practice is gaining momentum. The fund, which owns 1.3% of the world's equities, has cut back on algorithmic trading to dodge "flash boys" who might pre-empt its moves. The fund's head of asset strategies, Oeyvind Schanke, is working to reduce transaction costs and retain profits by trading in large blocks, rather than relying on fast-paced transactions. This move aims to counter the impact of high-frequency traders who harm other investors by sniffing out their strategies.

site_title: Britain, Belgium to start new visa scheme for Chinese
summary: Britain and Belgium have launched a new visa scheme for Chinese nationals, allowing them to apply for visas for both the UK and the wider Schengen area through a single visit to application centres in Beijing, Guangzhou, and Shanghai. The pilot scheme, set to begin on July 1, aims to create a one-stop shop for Chinese visitors to the UK and Europe, with the UK opting out of the Schengen Agreement. The new scheme is part of efforts to boost tourism and business between the two countries.

site_title: Indonesian central bank sees Q2 GDP growth below 5%
summary: Indonesia's central bank governor predicted the country's Q2 GDP growth will be below 5% due to limited budget disbursement and depressed corporate performance. The annual growth rate in January-March was 4.7%, the slowest in six years. The central bank also expects an annual inflation rate of 7.40% in June, 0.66% higher than May. This comes after the US announced tariffs on Asian garments, which may impact the country's economy.

images.alt_text: Indonesia's central bank governor said on Friday annual growth in Southeast Asia's largest economy would likely remain below 5 per cent in the second quarter.

site_title: Greece stumbling toward euro exit as meeting ends in rancour
summary: Greece edged closer to exiting the euro after a meeting of finance officials ended in rancour, with thousands of Greeks protesting outside parliament in Athens. The European Central Bank prepared for an emergency session as key players expressed frustration with Greek negotiators, with International Monetary Fund Managing Director Christine Lagarde stating that a dialogue with "adults in the room" is needed. A deadlock has left Greece's fate uncertain, with the spectre of capital controls looming and the possibility of a Greek default having limited market impact.

site_title: German public mood darkens on Greece
summary: Germany's public mood darkens on Greece as a majority now believes Athens should leave the eurozone, with 51% of respondents in a recent poll supporting a "Grexit". The mood reflects growing exasperation with the Greek government's hardball negotiating tactics and its refusal to implement austerity measures. German Chancellor Angela Merkel's attempts to keep Greece in the eurozone have failed to sway public opinion, with many Germans feeling that the country is "gambling away its future". The sentiment is also fueled by perceptions of Greek "blackmail" and the perception that Greece is not playing by the same rules as other EU countries.

site_title: Gold firm near US$1,200 on dovish Fed, set for 2nd weekly jump
summary: Gold prices rose to nearly US$1,200 an ounce, set for a second weekly jump, due to the Federal Reserve's cautious stance on US interest rate hikes and a softer dollar. The Fed's projections showed slightly lower rates by the end of 2016 and 2017, comforting investors and boosting bullion demand. However, investor positioning remains bearish, with assets of gold-backed exchange traded funds at their lowest since 2008, and speculators increasing short positions.

site_title: Singapore property cooling measures could be reviewed at year-end: UOB
summary: Singapore's government may review property cooling measures at the end of the year, according to a UOB research note. The bank expects a 5-10% correction in housing prices this year, driven by market speculation and the TDSR framework. UOB suggests relaxing seller's stamp duty and ABSD rates for Singaporeans, but notes that a 10% price drop is required for a loosening of cooling conditions, similar to the government's reaction to major external shocks like the Asian Crisis.

site_title: Australia creates jobs at US speed, still not enough
summary: Australia is creating jobs at a similar pace to the US, with 238,000 jobs created in the year to May, a 2.1% growth rate. However, the unemployment rate has edged up to 6.0% due to a larger workforce and relatively rapid population growth of 1.5%, more than twice the US rate. Despite a strong services sector, economists say the jobs market needs to grow faster to trend consistently lower.

site_title: Germany will negotiate with Athens "until last minute"
summary: Germany will negotiate with Greece "until the last minute" to reach a solution to the debt crisis, according to Peter Altmaier, Merkel's chief of staff. All EU member states, including Germany, the European Commission, and the International Monetary Fund, agree that Greece must present sensible reforms. Altmaier expressed hope that Athens and its international lenders could reach a solution, but emphasized the need for Greece to be prepared to carry out reforms.

images.alt_text: Germany will negotiate with Athens "until the last minute", a senior ally of German Chancellor Angela Merkel told Germany's Inforadio on Friday, but stressed that Greece must be prepared to carry out reforms.

site_title: Hijacked tanker Orkim Harmony released, pirates flee: Malaysia officials
summary: The hijacked oil tanker Orkim Harmony was released by pirates on June 19, with 22 crew members freed after being held for nearly a week. The pirates, armed with pistols and machetes, fled in the ship's rescue boat. The incident is the second tanker seizure in Southeast Asia this month, raising concerns over piracy in the region. One crew member was slightly injured during the ordeal.

site_title: Malaysia's Tenaga says 1MDB power project stake buy is "not a bailout"
summary: Malaysia's national utility firm Tenaga Nasional Bhd (TNB) has defended its decision to buy 1MDB's entire stake in a 2,000 MW coal-fired power project, saying it's not a bailout. The project's tariff rate is estimated at 26.67 sen (S$0.10) per kilowatt-hour, and TNB will not pay a premium. The deal will bring positive value to TNB in the long-run, according to TNB CEO Azman Mohd. 1MDB's ability to build the project is uncertain due to its liquidity problems, and Japan's Mitsui & Co will retain its 30% stake.

site_title: Pertamina to take over Indonesia's biggest gas block from Total
summary: Indonesia's state energy company PT Pertamina will take over majority ownership of the country's largest gas block, Mahakam, from Total SA and Inpex Corp. The contract will expire in 2017, and Pertamina will gain a 70% stake, with the current operators retaining 30%. The move aims to boost domestic gas production and follows President Joko Widodo's pledge to renegotiate contracts with foreign companies to prioritize domestic use. The new production sharing contract is expected to be signed by the end of the year, with Pertamina focusing on lifting production and cutting overseas spending.

images.alt_text: Indonesia's state energy company PT Pertamina will take over majority ownership and become the operator of Mahakam, the country's biggest gas-producing block, from current stakeholders Total SA and Inpex Corp.

site_title: Australia: Shares rise on Wall Street rally, bargain hunting
summary: Australian shares rose 1.2% on Friday, tracking a Wall Street rally, as investors hunted bargain-priced stocks after a heavy sell-off the previous day. The S&P/ASX 200 index rose 67.30 points to 5592.200, driven by gains in financials and mining sectors. The Fed's decision to keep interest rates on hold until the end of the year also contributed to the market's stability.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks up 0.58% at open
summary: Hong Kong shares opened 0.58% higher on June 19, 2015, following a record close on Wall Street. The Hang Seng Index rose 155.71 points to 26,58850.37, despite Greek debt talks ending without a deal, which sparked fears of an exit from the eurozone.

site_title: ECB to hold emergency meeting on Greek bank funding: sources
summary: The European Central Bank (ECB) will hold an emergency meeting on Friday to discuss a request from the Bank of Greece for increased liquidity to Greek banks, amid accelerated deposit withdrawals. The request comes as Greece faces a June 30 deadline to agree on a reform deal to secure its remaining international bailout. The ECB's decision-making council will consider a possible increase in the Emergency Liquidity Assistance facility, following a recent 1.1-billion-euro increase in the ELA ceiling. The EU has called an emergency summit next week to address the ongoing Greek debt talks.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open flat on Friday
summary: Malaysia's shares opened flat on Friday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rising 0.59 points to 1718.71. Volume was 13.68 million lots worth RM7.04 million. Gainers outnumbered losers 74 to 37.

site_title: Taiwan: Markets closed on Friday
summary: Taiwan's financial markets were closed on Friday for a public holiday. Meanwhile, Singapore's stocks rallied for a fifth consecutive day ahead of GDP data, while US markets edged towards fresh records despite ongoing trade uncertainty. In Asia, mining and healthcare stocks saw gains, and US-EU trade talks were in focus. The STI index rose 0.4% on Thursday, driven by investor positivity despite tariff uncertainty and split Federal Reserve views.

site_title: Yoga can spur 10% growth and bolster nation, India guru says
summary: India's famous guru, Baba Ramdev, says yoga can spur 10% growth and boost national pride, with the country earning 20 billion rupees annually from traditional products. On Sunday, Ramdev will help Prime Minister Narendra Modi set a world record for the most people doing yoga in one place, marking the first United Nations-backed International Day of Yoga. The event is expected to increase India's esteem, garnering support from 177 countries, including 47 Muslim nations.

site_title: Oil little changed, held down by demand outlook, shale output forecast
summary: Oil prices remained steady on Friday, with US July crude at $60.40 a barrel and Brent crude at $64.27 a barrel. Higher US shale oil output and potential increased imports to the US are expected to put downward pressure on oil prices. Despite Saudi Arabia's optimistic outlook, oil prices are unlikely to move far from their current levels. Global demand is expected to improve, with Russia and Saudi Arabia planning to discuss cooperation at an economic forum.

site_title: Thai aviation shares, hoteliers fall after first Mers virus case confirmed
summary: Thai shares plummeted on Friday after the country's first confirmed case of Middle East Respiratory Syndrome (Mers). Airports of Thailand, Thai Airways International, Nok Airlines, Central Plaza Hotel, and Minor International all dropped over 3-6.6% as investors reacted to the public health threat. The Mers outbreak has raised concerns about the impact on tourism and the economy.

site_title: Thailand took four days to confirm first Mers case, 59 being monitored
summary: Thai authorities confirmed the country's first case of Middle East Respiratory Syndrome (Mers) on Thursday, a 75-year-old businessman from Oman who arrived in Bangkok for medical treatment. The diagnosis took nearly four days, raising concerns of further spread in Asia. 59 people who had come into contact with the infected man are being monitored, with three hospitalized and the rest advised to stay at home for 14 days. This case compounds fears of a repeat of the 2002-2003 Sars outbreak in Asia.

site_title: China: Stocks head for worst week since 2008 amid margin concern
summary: China's stocks plummeted, heading for their worst week since 2008, amid concerns over margin trading and excessive valuations. The Shanghai Composite Index fell 1.5% to 4,712.15, extending its weekly loss to 8.7%. The China Securities Regulatory Commission is working on margin-trading risk management rules for securities firms. The decline follows a world-beating rally over the past year, with investors bracing for potential government intervention to curb market excesses.

site_title: HKEx CEO says closing auction to curb abuse, help index trackers
summary: Hong Kong Exchanges & Clearing (HKEx) CEO Charles Li announced plans to reintroduce daily closing auctions for equities to curb market manipulation and improve trading for institutions. The system, set to launch next year, will apply to heavily-traded stocks, impose an order entry band of 5% during auctions, and publish results. The move aims to bring HKEx in line with developed markets and make it more difficult for traders to manipulate prices. The bourse will also introduce volatility controls to prevent extreme price movements.

images.alt_text: Hong Kong Exchanges & Clearing Ltd Chief Executive Officer Charles Li said the proposed reintroduction of daily closing auctions for equities will mitigate market manipulation and make trading smoother for institutions.

site_title: Asia's hedge funds assets surge to record on China stock rally
summary: Asia's hedge funds have reached a record $177 billion in assets under management in May, driven by strong returns from China stock trades. China's market capitalization has more than doubled to $9.6 trillion this year, contributing to the surge. The Eurekahedge Asian Hedge Fund Index has gained 11% in the first five months of the year, outperforming North America and Europe. The China rally is expected to continue, with some funds returning up to 67% this year. The industry's maturity and growth are expected to continue, with a shift towards more complex strategies.

site_title: Singapore to keep investing in public R&D in electronics: Lim Hng Kiang
summary: Singapore will continue to invest in public research and development (R&D) in electronics, aiming to develop critical capabilities that will position the country to seize opportunities from new technologies. Minister for Trade and Industry Lim Hng Kiang announced this commitment during the opening of Seagate Technology's S$100 million design centre. The government will work with key partners like Seagate to support the design and manufacture of critical components and drives for the digital world.

site_title: Asia: Markets mostly higher after Wall St record
summary: Asian markets rose Friday, following a record US stock performance, with Tokyo (0.81%), Hong Kong (0.72%), and Sydney (1.29%) advancing. However, Shanghai fell 1.99% due to liquidity woes. The euro remained stable despite concerns over Greece's debt reform. Investors await the Bank of Japan's policy meeting for guidance on the country's economy and stimulus plans.

site_title: Noble Group sues ex-China customer to block bid to wind up unit
summary: Noble Group, Asia's largest commodity trader, sued a former Chinese customer, Rizhao Zhongrui Native Produce Co., to block a bid to wind up its Singapore unit over an alleged debt of US$102,718. The Singapore High Court granted an interim injunction, and a hearing is scheduled for June 25. Noble Resources International Pte claims the Chinese firm is trying to harass and exert undue commercial pressure, while Zhongrui alleges poor quality iron ore and reputational damage. This case comes as Noble faces criticism over its accounting practices and a separate lawsuit against a former employee accused of spreading false information.

site_title: BOJ maintains record stimulus as inflation challenges Kuroda
summary: The Bank of Japan maintained its record monetary stimulus, expanding the monetary base at an annual pace of 80 trillion yen (S$867 billion) to spur inflation. Governor Haruhiko Kuroda aims to reach the central bank's 2% inflation target by September 2016, citing rising wages and a tight labor market. Despite sluggish export growth and slowing economic growth forecast to 1.4% this quarter, the BOJ will continue its stimulus to ensure inflation remains on track.

images.alt_text: The Bank of Japan maintained its record monetary stimulus as Governor Haruhiko Kuroda seeks to spur inflation that vanished last month.

site_title: Still an underdog, but China govt deals help Alibaba's cloud ambitions
summary: Alibaba's cloud unit Aliyun has secured a deal with China's northeastern port city of Dalian to build a cloud computing center and provide online government services. The pact is part of a growing portfolio of similar deals between Alibaba and government bodies in China, aiming to build scale and expertise before a potential global campaign. Despite being an underdog in the global cloud computing industry, Aliyun has a significant market share in China and is working to expand its presence both domestically and internationally, with partnerships with foreign firms such as Intel and Equinix.

site_title: Europe's banks head to Asia amid US$1 trillion capital shortfall
summary: European banks are shifting capital to Asia due to new rules requiring them to sell over $1 trillion in equity and subordinated debt to increase loss buffers. French and German lenders have sold $1.8 billion in notes, while Dutch and Italian banks have stepped up activity since 2012. The move to Asia is driven by attractive pricing and ample cash to buy securities, with banks still needing to issue four times the required amount. This shift is part of a broader effort to address the $266 billion of subordinated debt accumulated in Europe since 2008.

site_title: India proposes gold-linked bonds to lower bullion imports
summary: India plans to issue gold-linked bonds to divert 300 tonnes of annual gold demand and curb imports, reducing the trade deficit. The bonds will have a minimum interest rate of 2% and aim to reduce physical gold demand. The country consumes nearly 1,000 tonnes of gold annually, mostly imported. This move is part of efforts to manage the gold import bill, which is the second-largest expense on the import bill after oil.

images.alt_text: India is planning to issue sovereign bonds linked to the bullion price in an effort to divert some of the estimated 300 tonnes of annual demand for gold bars and coins and curb bullion imports, which can push up the trade deficit.

site_title: MND to look into more help for resale flat buyers wishing to live near parents: Khaw
summary: The Ministry of National Development (MND) plans to study providing more assistance for resale flat buyers who want to live near their parents. Minister Khaw Boon Wan noted that more Singaporeans prefer to buy flats in mature estates to be close to extended families. Since 2011, MND has introduced priority schemes and flat types to support extended family living, resulting in higher success rates. The government will consider increasing help for first-timer families to buy resale flats in mature estates, citing limited land availability.

images.alt_text: The Ministry of National Development (MND) will study whether it can provide more help for those who wish to buy a resale flat to live near their parents, said Minister for National Development Khaw Boon Wan on Friday.

site_title: Quick takes: Economists weigh in on emergency EU summit on Greece
summary: EU leaders will hold an emergency summit in Brussels on June 22 to discuss Greece's bailout, following failed talks between eurozone finance ministers. Economists express skepticism, with Rabobank stating that a deal is unlikely and OCBC's treasury research team noting a lack of mutual respect and trust. Mizuho's Vishnu Varathan suggests that Greek Prime Minister Alexis Tsipras may concede ground, but warns that the real concern is the liquidity crisis and the ECB's appetite for extending ELA. Global markets appear relatively nonchalant, with US equities rising despite the ongoing impasse.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open up 0.81%
summary: Tokyo stocks opened 0.81% higher on Friday, driven by gains on Wall Street and a breather in the yen's rise against the dollar. The Nikkei 225 index rose 161.59 points to 20,152.41, following four days of losses. The Nasdaq surged 1.34% to a fresh record, while the euro held up after rising amid uncertainty over Greece's debt crisis. Investors awaited the outcome of a Bank of Japan policy meeting, with governor Haruhiko Kuroda set to speak later in the day.

site_title: Rate of Mers infections in South Korea slows with one new case
summary: South Korea reported one new case of Mers, bringing the total to 166 since May. The daily infection rate has slowed, with the lowest rate since June 3. A patient has become the 24th person to die in the outbreak.

site_title: Stocks to watch: SIA, Ley Choon, KrisEnergy, Noble
summary: Singapore Airlines is in talks to develop a non-stop US flight, while Ley Choon Group secured a S$24.8 million contract to resurface Changi Airport's taxiways. KrisEnergy began oil production from the Nong Yao field in the Gulf of Thailand. Noble Group intensified its share buyback, purchasing 39.74 million shares.

site_title: McDonald's says number of US restaurants will shrink this year
summary: McDonald's plans to shrink its US restaurant count in 2015, with the impact being minimal compared to its 14,000 US restaurants. The company has already announced 350 US restaurant closings and plans to open 300 new restaurants globally. CEO Steve Easterbrook aims to reorganize business units, sell restaurants to franchisees, and cut costs to turn the business around.

site_title: Short-sellers descend on Singapore stock market
summary: Singapore's stock market has seen a surge in short-selling activity, with nearly 1.2% of companies' free float on loan, exceeding the 0.9% level on December 31. The increase is attributed to China's slowing economy and low energy prices, as well as attacks on commodity trader Noble Group Ltd by short-sellers. Energy and manufacturers of capital goods are the most popular targets, with Noble Group's shares falling 40% since allegations of asset value inflation were made. The surge in short-selling has raised concerns about market volatility in the region.

site_title: Pop-up fun at stores
summary: Two lifestyle stores, Crate and Barrel and APS Lifestyle Gallery, will host pop-up markets over the weekend. Crate and Barrel's "The WeddingParty Event" will feature 17 partners offering exclusive promotions, while APS Lifestyle Gallery's "9MCM" will celebrate Singapore's Jubilee with 50 iconic food and retail creations. The 9MCM will also feature unique vendors, 50% of the sale proceeds will be donated to a home for the aged. The events are free to attend, with RSVPs required for Crate and Barrel's event.

images.alt_text: Tay Suan Chiang

site_title: LSE studying stock-connect scheme with Shanghai: state media
summary: The London Stock Exchange (LSE) is researching a stock trading link with the Shanghai Stock Exchange, similar to the Hong Kong-Shanghai link, to liberalize China's capital markets. The LSE is discussing regulatory requirements with regulators, clients, and asset firms. The potential link would allow mainland-listed Chinese shares to trade on the LSE via yuan-denominated global depositary receipts (GDRs). The move aims to add complexity to the LSE's operations, but the LSE is working to understand what is involved.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: Changjiang Fertilizer Holdings Limited's executive chairman CAI Jian Hua will resume his duties as chairman following his leave of absence. The Competition Commission of Singapore (CCS) has closed its investigation into Cordlife Group's exclusive agreements with baby fair organisers and hospitals after the company made voluntary commitments to address concerns. Meanwhile, NTT DC Reit's Singapore public offer was 9.8 times oversubscribed.

site_title: Durian tastes even sweeter as ringgit drops on oil slump
summary: Malaysia's ringgit has dropped, making durian cheaper for Singaporeans, who are buying the fruit in large quantities due to the weaker currency. Sales at Uncle Lim's durian farm have doubled, with buyers able to purchase two top-grade durians for the price of one in Singapore. The fruit, banned from Singapore's subways and hotels, can now retail for over S$40 apiece, a significant drop from its Singapore price. The weaker ringgit is driving the surge in demand for the Southeast Asian native fruit.

site_title: One-third of Japan firms' profit targets at risk at current yen rate: Reuters poll
summary: A Reuters poll of 480 Japanese firms found that one-third of companies believe their profit targets are at risk due to the current yen rate of 120-125 to the dollar. This risk increases to a majority of firms if the currency weakens further to 130 yen. Despite concerns about a weaker yen, the survey also showed positive signs of resilience in the service sector, with exporters benefiting from a weak yen and service-sector firms passing on higher import costs to customers.

images.alt_text: Disappointing growth figures released in Japan on Tuesday rekindled speculation that the central bank might have to unleash yet more stimulus to prop up a faltering recovery that is refusing to take root.

site_title: Most Japan firms reluctant to unwind cross-shareholdings: Reuters poll
summary: Nearly 80% of Japanese firms with cross-shareholdings have no plans to sell them this year, citing them as essential for business ties and long-term stability. The government's efforts to improve corporate governance by encouraging sales have been met with resistance, with 79% of firms saying they will not sell. The reluctance to part with stable shareholders is attributed to rising concerns about activist investors, and reducing cross-shareholdings could also improve asset efficiency and boost return on equity.

site_title: Oil prices ease on US dollar, higher shale output forecast
summary: Oil prices eased on Friday as the US dollar strengthened, with US crude futures falling 7 cents to $60.38 a barrel and Brent crude falling 14 cents to $64.12 a barrel. Higher shale oil production forecasts this year contributed to lingering demand concerns. The decline followed a previous day's gains, which were attributed to bearish Trump tariff outlook.

images.alt_text: Oil prices dipped slightly on Friday as the US dollar edged up from its overnight lows, while forecast higher production by US shale oil producers this year added to lingering worries over demand.

site_title: South Korea's May producer prices fall at slowest pace in 5 months
summary: South Korea's producer prices fell 3.5% in May, marking a 10th consecutive month of decline, but at their slowest pace in five months. The Bank of Korea forecasts inflation will rise in the second half of the year. Industrial product prices, which have the heaviest weighting, fell 5.8% from a year ago due to lower coal and oil prices. The decline in producer prices is a positive sign for the country's economy.

site_title: Obama's Pacific trade pact revived in US House, heads to Senate
summary: The US House of Representatives approved "fast-track" legislation for President Barack Obama's trade deal with Pacific Rim nations, sending it back to the Senate. The vote, 218-208, gives Obama the authority to speed trade deals, including the Trans-Pacific Partnership (TPP), to conclusion with reduced interference from Congress. The TPP aims to bolster US ties with Asia and counter China's influence, encompassing 40% of the global economy. However, the Senate's outlook for fast-track remains uncertain, with Democrats tied to the fate of the Export-Import Bank.

site_title: IMF praises eurozone policy but warns on future
summary: The International Monetary Fund (IMF) praised the eurozone's recovery, citing a weaker currency, low oil prices, and monetary policy, but warned that risks from Greece and potential future economic shocks could threaten growth. The IMF said the eurozone's economies would expand by 1.5% this year and 1.6% in 2016, but urged Europeans to implement reforms and strengthen the eurozone's fiscal backstop to avoid low growth and vulnerability to shocks. The IMF also noted that many growth factors could evaporate in the future, requiring deeper reforms and integration to support growth.

images.alt_text: Pedestrians walk past the International Monetary Fund (IMF) building in Washington, D.C., U.S., on Wednesday, April 2, 2008.

site_title: Fitch rates Singapore's first mortgage covered bond from DBS Bank
summary: Fitch Ratings has assigned a 'AAA(EXP)' rating with a Stable Outlook to DBS Bank's inaugural series of mortgage covered bonds, the first covered bond programme in Singapore. The rating reflects DBS's Long-Term Issuer Default Rating of 'AA-' and a dynamic pool of Singapore residential mortgage loans, with a breakeven asset percentage of 85.5% and a cover pool credit loss of 4.2% in a 'AAA' scenario. The rating also considers the moderate high discontinuity risk assessment related to liquidity gap and systemic risk.

site_title: In-flight entertainment of future will include iris-tracking
summary: Thales has unveiled a prototype for the next generation of business class seats featuring iris-tracking technology, which can pause films when a passenger falls asleep and restart automatically when they wake up. The technology is expected to be installed in business class cabins within 5-10 years. Meanwhile, Panasonic is introducing a software that allows passengers to sync their personal devices with the onboard system, enabling browsing and shopping during flights. The in-flight entertainment sector is growing at 10% per year, driven by innovations and the increasing trend of "bring your own" entertainment.

site_title: Singapore: STI opens 0.44% higher on Friday
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) rose 0.44% to 3,314.83 on Friday, following gains on Wall Street. Top gainers included Jardine Strategic Holdings, DBS, and UOB. Trading volume reached 49.8 million shares worth S$67.4 million. This marks the fifth consecutive day of rally ahead of upcoming GDP data.

site_title: Suspect caught in US black church 'hate crime' rampage
summary: A 21-year-old white suspect, Dylann Roof, was arrested in connection with the mass killing of nine people at the Emanuel African Methodist Episcopal Church in Charleston, South Carolina. The shooting, which occurred during a Bible study meeting, was described as a hate crime and the worst at an American place of worship in decades. President Barack Obama condemned the attack, calling it a "senseless murder" that highlights the need for the US to address its gun culture. The victims included the church's pastor, a Democratic state senator, and several community leaders.

images.alt_text: Police detained 21-year-old Dylann Roof, shown wearing the flags of defunct white supremacist regimes in pictures taken from social media, after nine churchgoers were shot dead.

site_title: Shanghai Composite now a must-watch indicator
summary: The Shanghai Composite Index has become a key indicator for global bond and currency markets, according to Bank of America's David Woo. China's rally has grown significantly, and when it eventually collapses, it could weigh on the global economy, particularly on US Treasuries and the dollar. Woo predicts a 30% drop in Chinese shares, which could have a "knock-on effect" on the world economy, with a bullish impact on the dollar and US Treasuries. The rally has been fueled by monetary stimulus and record inflows from amateur investors, with shares trading at an average 264 times reported earnings.

site_title: Cars banned from much of New York's Central Park
summary: Cars will be banned from most of New York's Central Park by June 29, reducing traffic and making the area safer and quieter. The ban applies to park drives north of 72nd Street, while four roads will remain open to traffic. Mayor Bill de Blasio says the move will create "safe zones for kids to play" and allow visitors to enjoy the park in peace. The measure follows similar initiatives in Prospect Park in Brooklyn, where one main thoroughfare will be closed starting July 6.

site_title: Oil up 3rd day on dollar slump, US crude draw data
summary: Oil prices rose for a third consecutive day, boosted by a weakening US dollar and reports of a draw in crude inventories at Cushing, Oklahoma. The dollar hit a one-month low, and the euro gained momentum due to hopes of a positive Greek fiscal crisis resolution. Oil prices closed up 53 cents at $60.45 a barrel, with Brent crude settling at $64.26 a barrel. Despite the gains, some analysts express doubts about the sustainability of the rally, citing lingering concerns about demand and the impact of gasoline demand on the market.

site_title: Hong Kong veterans pep up Wonder Mama
summary: Hong Kong film director Clifton Ko made a comeback with the comedy-drama "Wonder Mama," starring Petrina Fung Bo Bo as a 50-year-old librarian and single mother whose life is turned upside down by her parents' divorce and a live-in maid's pregnancy. Fung brings comic energy and dramatic weight to the film, while veteran actor Kenneth Tsang steals the show with a quietly moving performance. Despite some absurd moments, the film balances humor and heartbreak, based on true events and exploring the complexities of family matters. Ko's comeback film received a B- rating.

images.alt_text: Dylan Tan

site_title: Revolt against super rich may be inevitable
summary: Christine Lagarde, IMF managing director, warns of a potential "revolution" against the super-rich and high finance, citing rising global inequality and the need for more equitable wealth distribution. She notes that economic growth has failed to lift the poor and middle class, and that excessive inequality is a problem for economic growth and development. The IMF predicts a lower growth potential for advanced and emerging economies due to changing demographics and lower productivity. Lagarde emphasizes that lifting the incomes of the poor and middle class is not only morally and politically correct but also good economics, as it will generate higher, more inclusive, and more sustainable growth.

site_title: Lessor sees pick-up in demand for A380 in next 2 years
summary: MARC Lapidus, a financier, believes demand for the Airbus A380 will increase in the next two years as airlines start to see the benefits of the jumbo jet. Lapidus, who owns leasing company Amedeo, has held discussions with airlines to optimize the aircraft, which he claims was not ideally configured when it first entered service in 2007. He expects 15 new buyers to emerge in the next two years, with Turkish Airlines expressing no interest in the plane. Lapidus remains optimistic and expects to present a customer for the A380 this year.

site_title: Denmark's government ousted as anti-immigration party surges
summary: Denmark's government was ousted after a general election, with the anti-immigration Danish People's Party emerging as the largest force. The party won nearly one-fifth of the votes, almost doubling its support since 2011, and promised tougher immigration and asylum laws. The group is skeptical of the EU and border controls. Prime Minister Helle Thorning-Schmidt's government lost its majority, marking a significant shift in Danish politics.

site_title: Waves of migration a call for global action
summary: Global migration is escalating, with an estimated 5% of European populations born outside their country. The pressure is mounting, with over 3.5 million people leaving Africa, 618,000 from Bangladesh to India, and 489,000 from Indonesia to Malaysia. The root causes of migration, including persecution and poverty, require coordinated global action. Governments must cooperate to address the root causes, build better living standards in home countries, and provide financial assistance to developing nations. An open-door policy is unsustainable, and a cultural shift is already occurring in Europe, with increased nationalism and xenophobia.

site_title: Eurozone sets emergency summit on Greece as money flees
summary: Eurozone leaders will hold an emergency summit on Monday to address Greece's debt crisis after bank withdrawals accelerated and government revenue slumped. Greece must repay a 1.6 billion euro loan to the IMF by the end of June, and the ECB warned that Greek banks may not be open on Monday. Finance ministers failed to make a breakthrough on a cash-for-reforms agreement, with the IMF declaring Greece in default if it misses the payment. Greek Prime Minister Alexis Tsipras is demanding debt relief in exchange for concessions, while European leaders are pushing for a deal.

site_title: Asean set to become Asia's next Pearl River Delta
summary: ASEAN is poised to become Asia's next low-cost manufacturing powerhouse as China's wage competitiveness wanes. With rising household affluence and high GDP growth, companies relocating from China's Pearl River Delta can tap into a large and growing consumer market. Despite labour shortages and rising wages, many manufacturers are investing in automation and streamlining processes. Vietnam and Cambodia are expected to be among the biggest beneficiaries, with potential cost savings of 19% and 20% respectively. ASEAN's diverse manufacturing capabilities and need for better integration make it an attractive alternative to China.

site_title: Allergan bets on rising popularity of botox for men
summary: Allergan is investing in the growing market of male cosmetic treatments, acquiring Kythera Biopharmaceuticals for $2.1 billion. The deal includes an experimental drug for male-pattern baldness and a non-surgical treatment for double chins, targeting a previously underserved market. This move is part of Allergan's strategy to expand into smaller markets in the traditional pharmaceutical industry.

site_title: Business case for Kra canal unclear: OECD official
summary: A senior OECD official stated that the Kra canal project in Thailand could pose a threat to Singapore's port if viable, but its viability is uncertain. The official downplayed concerns, saying it's not clear if there's a business case for the project. Instead, Singapore's port faces challenges from mega ships, environmental sustainability, and managing quality of life issues. The official noted that even if the Northern Sea Route becomes a viable commercial service, it won't happen soon. Singapore's port will need to stay efficient and adopt new technology to handle large vessels.

site_title: Krone selloff embraced by Norges Bank governor promising more
summary: Norway's central bank, Norges Bank, cut its main rate to an historic low of 1% to avoid a recession in western Europe, sparking a 1.8% drop in the Norwegian krone against the euro. Governor Oeystein Olsen signaled another potential cut as soon as September, citing the economy's strong performance. The bank also revised its economic forecast, predicting a decline in mainland growth and petroleum investments. Olsen emphasized the central bank's patience in responding to currency market fluctuations, stating that the reactions in the market "make sense" based on their judgments.

site_title: M1 independent director Barlow dies
summary: M1 Ltd announced the June 14 death of its longest-serving independent non-executive board director, Roger John Barlow, 65, who served on the board since 2002. Barlow chaired the remuneration and nominating committees and maintained high standards of professionalism and governance. The company expressed gratitude for his invaluable contributions. Barlow was a director of RJB Consultants and formerly worked at PCCW Limited. The board and management extended condolences to his family.

site_title: First Sponsor Group acquires two hotels in Amsterdam
summary: First Sponsor Group has completed its 54.6 million euro (S$82.9 million) acquisition of two hotels in Amsterdam, including a Holiday Inn and a Holiday Inn Express, with 509 carpark lots. The acquisition is the company's first in the Dutch market. First Sponsor Group, a Singapore-based investment holding company, reported a net profit of S$10.73 million in the first quarter of 2015, driven by growth in its property financing business.

site_title: California rules Uber drivers are employees
summary: California's labor commissioner has ruled that Uber drivers are employees, requiring the company to guarantee a minimum wage, mileage compensation, and social security payments. This decision could have significant implications for the "sharing economy" and define the future of internet-enabled companies. Uber has 22,000 drivers in San Francisco, 26,000 in New York, and 15,000 in London, and has faced federal lawsuits questioning whether its workers have employee protections. The ruling applies to a single driver, contradicting previous rulings, and Uber plans to appeal the decision.

site_title: 6 banks in US slapped with more mortgage restrictions
summary: Six major US banks, including JPMorgan Chase and Wells Fargo, have been slapped with additional mortgage restrictions and fines for failing to improve their mortgage operations as agreed in 2011. The Office of the Comptroller of the Currency (OCC) found that the banks had not made the necessary changes to address issues such as wrongful foreclosures, deficient paperwork, and excessive fees. Wells Fargo and HSBC will face the most severe penalties, with Wells Fargo barred from acquiring new mortgage servicing rights and HSBC facing additional fines and restrictions.

images.alt_text: Because of the extent of their problems, HSBC and Wells Fargo will be barred from acquiring any new mortgage servicing rights from other banks.

site_title: US$ under pressure as Yellen signals slow hike
summary: The US dollar weakened to 123.14 yen after Federal Reserve chief Janet Yellen signaled a slow hike in interest rates due to the US economy's weakness. The euro ticked up to $1.1362, despite concerns over a Greek debt default. Yellen's comments followed a similar stance by the European Central Bank, which has also been cautious on interest rate hikes. The dollar's decline was attributed to a lack of clear guidance on future rate hikes, causing investors to reassess their expectations.

site_title: Fed up?
summary: The Federal Reserve is prioritizing economic data over IMF and World Bank advice, potentially delaying interest rate hikes into 2016. Despite the IMF and World Bank urging caution due to a fragile global economy, Fed Chair Janet Yellen plans to start raising interest rates this year. The reasons cited for avoiding rate hikes include low inflation and stagnant wage growth.

site_title: US agencies face uphill battle for Silicon Valley talent
summary: US government agencies face a challenging task in attracting Silicon Valley's top tech talent, with many viewing them as untrustworthy due to past surveillance controversies, such as the 2013 Edward Snowden leak. Despite efforts to mend fences, including the opening of Silicon Valley offices and recruitment programs, the tech community remains skeptical. Federal agencies are struggling to compete with private companies like Facebook and Google, which offer more generous salaries and lifestyles, and reforms such as increased transparency and oversight may be necessary to improve their image.

site_title: Industrial past haunts former Beijing showcase
summary: A former steel plant in Beijing, China, once a showcase for Communist leader Mao Zedong's modernization efforts, now lies abandoned and decaying. The facility, which operated from 1919 to 2011, was closed to reduce air pollution ahead of the 2008 Olympics. Local officials plan to turn the site into an arts, tourism, and finance hub, despite concerns over soil pollution from the plant's industrial past. The site's closure highlights the challenges facing northern China's iron and steel industry, which suffers from excess capacity and contributes to smog.

site_title: Japan pushes LNG for transport to boost energy security
summary: Japan plans to increase the use of liquefied natural gas (LNG) in trucks and ships to boost energy security and reduce carbon emissions. The government aims for 10% of long-distance trucks to run on LNG by 2025 and plans to build more natural gas stations. LNG trucks emit 20% less carbon dioxide than diesel trucks and can carry twice as much fuel as compressed natural gas trucks. The move is part of Japan's efforts to diversify its energy sources and improve its ability to respond to energy crises, following the 2011 Fukushima disaster.

site_title: No grace period for Greece's 1.5b euro payment: IMF
summary: IMF Chief Christine Lagarde stated that Greece will immediately be considered in default if it fails to make a 1.5 billion euro payment by June 30. Despite German Chancellor Angela Merkel's optimism that a deal can be reached, Greece's bid to obtain aid is going down to the wire with its euro-area bailout agreement expiring in less than two weeks. The European Central Bank is reviewing emergency funding for the Greek banking system, and Greece is refusing to accept IMF demands to reform its pension system and accept debt relief.

site_title: Nothing wrong in wanting new SGX CEO to fix things
summary: A letter to the editor expresses dissatisfaction with the current SGX CEO and calls for a new CEO to address various issues, including the "gap risk" between lunch breaks and the Minimum Trading Price initiative. The writer believes that the new CEO should have face-to-face meetings with the stockbroking community to address concerns and implement changes. The writer also questions the current CEO's performance, citing their high salary and the lack of response to previous concerns. The writer advocates for a committee of inquiry to investigate and address issues.

site_title: Bankers serving SMEs to go back to school
summary: United Overseas Bank (UOB) has launched the UOB-SMU Banker's Executive Certificate programme to equip bankers serving small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) with the skills and knowledge needed to meet the expansion demands of businesses. The programme combines classroom-based study with practical skills-training, focusing on credit and risk management, trade financing, and regional regulatory frameworks. The bank aims to train 120 of its small-business bankers by the end of this year, responding to the growing need for specialist skills in managing foreign-exchange risk and navigating regulatory landscapes for SMEs expanding overseas.

site_title: Noble intensifies share buyback, pumping in another S$28.43m
summary: Noble Group intensified its share buyback program, purchasing 39.74 million shares at an average of 71.38 cents apiece for S$28.43 million. This is the fourth buyback since April 17, and the total value of shares bought this month is around S$71.23 million. The company's CEO, Yusuf Alireza, also issued an open letter to a critic, Michael Dee, in an effort to address investor concerns, which Noble has been battling for five months amid a 41% decline in its shares since mid-February.

site_title: Novartis sees profit margin hike as it revamps drug portfolio
summary: Novartis expects to increase its profit margin this year as it restructures its drug portfolio and cuts costs. The company is generating cash for a higher dividend and smaller, strategic acquisitions. Recent advances with new drugs, such as LCZ696 and Cosentyx, are expected to buffer it from cheaper competition. Novartis is also expanding its work in cancer treatments and cell-based immunotherapy, a leading approach in the field. The company maintains a diversified approach to healthcare and is a dominant player in eyecare and off-patent generic medicines.

site_title: Microsoft revamps management team to focus on 3 areas
summary: Microsoft's CEO Satya Nadella overhauled the company's management team, focusing on cloud computing, personal computing, and productivity. Senior executives Kirill Tatarinov and Eric Rudder left, while Terry Myerson took over the Windows and Devices Group and Scott Guthrie led the Cloud and Enterprise group. The changes reflect a strategy shift towards cloud and mobile software, aiming to deliver better products and services to customers. The move comes after Microsoft's profit exceeded analysts' estimates last quarter, driven by boosted cloud software sales.

site_title: Japan faces a 16-tonne plutonium question
summary: Japan is facing a nuclear conundrum with 16 tonnes of plutonium stored in France after being reprocessed. With its reactor fleet shut down following the Fukushima crisis, Japan needs to find alternative countries to use the fuel or pay others to do so. The issue has taken on urgency as the French nuclear company Areva faces significant losses. Meeting nuclear proliferation specialists and government officials in Tokyo, Japan may need to consider paying other countries to use the plutonium, potentially at a high cost.

site_title: Thailand confirms its first Mers case
summary: Thailand has confirmed its first Middle East Respiratory Syndrome (Mers) case, a 75-year-old man from Oman who arrived in Bangkok three days ago. The patient was treated for a heart problem before testing positive for Mers. Authorities are investigating those who came into contact with the man and have moved him to a specialized hospital. The World Health Organization (WHO) expressed guarded optimism over South Korea's ability to contain the Mers outbreak, which has killed 23 people.

site_title: Unwavering creditors of Greece must see they are playing with fire
summary: Greece is hurtling towards another deadline to repay massive debts, potentially leading to a Greek exit from the euro and the European Union. While some market players view the situation as manageable, experts warn that unwavering creditors are playing with fire, risking an extended recession for Greece and fault lines in the euro bloc. A Greek exit could cast uncertainty over the future of the euro, making peripheral economies less willing to accept austerity demands. The US Federal Reserve chairwoman Janet Yellen also expressed concerns about potential disruptions to global financial markets.

site_title: China home prices up in May for first time in 13 months
summary: China's new home prices rose 0.2% in May, the first increase in 13 months, as the central bank cut interest rates and eased mortgage restrictions. However, economists warn that massive inventories of unsold homes could continue to drag on the economy well into next year, potentially hindering a full recovery in the property sector. Despite signs of stabilization, a full-blown recovery is unlikely this year, with economists predicting a more muted recovery than past recoveries.

site_title: Edge of reason
summary: Greek banks are struggling to manage a massive exodus of deposits as Athens continues to reject a bailout deal with European negotiators. To address the issue, euro zone finance ministers are considering imposing capital controls, which could restrict Greeks' access to their money. This move could have an immediate impact, but its effectiveness is uncertain. On June 15, Greek banks were only able to cover 400 million euros in withdrawals by tapping into their own central bank's emergency funds. The move is seen as a last resort to stabilize the Greek financial system.

site_title: Google's Nest Labs unveils camera, smoke alarm for the smart home
