summary: Google's Nest Labs has unveiled new smart home products, including a $199 Nest Camera and a slimmed-down Protect smoke alarm. The Nest Camera features better night vision and higher resolution, while the smoke alarm automatically ensures it's working without false alarms. The updates are part of Nest's efforts to push the company deeper into smart home technologies, competing with rivals like Samsung and Apple. The new products are designed to work together seamlessly, using secure and safe communication.

site_title: Airbus pips Boeing at Paris Air Show with US$13.7b last-minute order
summary: Airbus secured a significant deal at the Paris Air Show, netting a US$13.7 billion order for 110 A321neo aircraft from Hungary's Wizz Air. The deal, announced just before the show closed, gave Airbus a narrow lead over Boeing, which had US$50.2 billion in deals for 331 planes. Despite the large orders, the final tally is likely to fall short of last year's Farnborough Air Show record due to less-aggressive buying by airlines. Airbus won US$57 billion in deals for 421 aircraft, while Boeing secured US$50.2 billion for 331 planes.

images.alt_text: Nisha Ramchandani

The world's two biggest planemakers Airbus and Boeing went head-to-head in the battle for plane orders this week at the 51st Paris Air Show, with Airbus narrowly pulling ahead with a huge, 11th-hour deal that gave it the edge over its US rival.

site_title: G-7 target on fossil fuels raises many questions
summary: The Group of Seven (G-7) has agreed to limit global temperatures to 2 degrees Celsius above pre-industrial levels by 2050 and phase out fossil fuels by 2100. The US and China have also committed to reducing emissions by 2025. However, environmentalists question whether this plan is sufficient, as the use of fossil fuels remains widespread, particularly for transportation. The International Energy Agency estimates that half of global oil demand is for petrol for cars, and a quarter for truck diesel. Experts warn that a global agreement to stop fossil fuel use by 2100 may not be achievable without significant changes in global transportation flows and infrastructure.

site_title: IMF's Vinals says central banks may have to be "market makers"
summary: IMF Director Jose Vinals warns that central banks may need to become "market makers of last resort" to address shrinking market liquidity during volatile sell-offs. This measure is proposed as a potential solution to ensure liquidity, but it may take time for the global regulatory community to find a solution.

site_title: Shadow of Greece looms large over STI
summary: Singapore shares slipped 0.8% to 3,300.42 on Thursday, marking the third negative session this week, as concerns over Greece's debt crisis overshadowed the US Federal Reserve's dovish policy statement. The Straits Times Index fell despite a more accommodative Fed, with market observers citing Greece's hardening stance with creditors as a major concern. Small caps, including Magnus Energy Group, which jumped 71.4%, drew trading queries, but analysts attributed the move to short covering.

site_title: Wall St needs help to remain centre for jobs, innovation
summary: Wall Street is facing a job and innovation crisis as major banks and financial institutions, such as JPMorgan Chase and HSBC, have reduced their workforce. Over the last five years, New York City has seen a net loss of 25,000 financial-services jobs, with banks and insurance companies shedding the most positions. Critics argue that the sector's size and high salaries are unsustainable, and that the decline of jobs is detrimental to the city.

site_title: Singapore office market less attractive now: fund manager
summary: Singapore's office market is less attractive due to a space glut and slowing rental growth, according to Union Investment. Office rents in the central business district (CBD) are expected to slide 14% to S$9.12 per square foot over the next two years. Fund manager Eric Cheah attributes this to the city-state's economic growth slowing and the government's control of land supply. As a result, Union Investment is increasing bets on central district offices in Australia and Japan, while some landlords consider selling properties, with BlackRock expressing interest in Asia Square Tower 1 for over S$4 billion.

site_title: SIA in talks to develop new plane that can fly non-stop to US
summary: Singapore Airlines (SIA) is in talks with Airbus and Boeing to develop a new plane that can fly non-stop from Singapore to the US, aiming to restore the 19-hour trip to the US profitably. The airline stopped the service in 2013 due to lack of commercially viable aircraft. Using a twin-engine plane is more economical for long-range flights, and SIA is exploring partnerships with other airlines to offer more destinations. The airline plans to develop hubs outside Singapore to expand its network connectivity.

site_title: City buzz
summary: CharaExpo 2015, a Japanese-themed comic and anime convention, will take place in Singapore from June 20-21 at the Singapore Expo Hall 7. The event will feature top anime, manga, and gaming talents, as well as a wrestling exhibition match and J-pop performances. The organizer, Bushiroad Inc, aims to support the local anime community and provide opportunities for budding artists and developers to meet with Japanese companies and creatives. Tickets are available for S$6 (advance) and S$8 (door).

site_title: SunMoon taking 51% stake in China fruit-selling venture
summary: SunMoon Food Company has agreed to acquire a 51% stake in Harvest Season Singapore for S$3.1m, paid through the issuance of 60 million new shares at 5.18 cents each. This deal will constitute approximately 18.82% of SunMoon's current issued share capital. The acquisition is part of SunMoon's expansion into the Chinese fruit-selling market.

images.alt_text: Sunmoon Food Company wants a bite of the fruit-selling business in China. It has proposed to acquire a 51 per cent stake in Harvest Season Singapore, having entered into a conditional sale and purchase agreement to acquire 510,000 ordinary shares in the latter.

site_title: Indonesia's central bank holds interest rate as rupiah weakens
summary: Indonesia's central bank, Bank Indonesia, held its main interest rate at 7.5% for a fourth consecutive month, as a weakening rupiah limits policy easing to boost growth. The decision reflects the bank's dilemma in stimulating an economy growing at its slowest pace since 2009, constrained by inflation above 7% and a currency-weakening current-account deficit. The rupiah has lost about 7% against the US dollar this year, making it the worst-performing major Asian currency.

site_title: The lifeblood of Art Basel
summary: Art Basel, the world's largest art fair, continues to attract 92,000 global visitors with its diverse range of artworks, performances, and exhibitions. The fair features 284 international galleries showcasing works worth US$3 billion, with top artists selling pieces for millions of dollars. Despite the high prices, Art Basel's director Marc Spiegler emphasizes the fair's commitment to providing a platform for artists, not just for wealthy collectors. The fair's programming includes bold and thought-provoking installations, and Singapore gallery STPI returns for its third year, highlighting the growing presence of Asian galleries in the global art market.

images.alt_text: Helmi Yusof

site_title: Brokers' take
summary: Ezion Holdings, a Singapore-based operator of marine vessels, has withdrawn its lawsuit against Atlantic Marine Services (AMS) following a change in management. AMS has released Ezion from all claims alleged, and the operator will continue to engage with AMS to meet Maersk Oil's operating requirements. This outcome is seen as beneficial for Ezion, potentially allowing it to retain its charter agreements.

site_title: Japan business mood signals pick-up in private consumption
summary: Japan's business mood has improved for the second consecutive month, with manufacturers' confidence rising and retailers being the most optimistic in over a year, according to a Reuters poll. The Reuters Tankan survey suggests the economic recovery will strengthen over the next year, but analysts doubt the Bank of Japan's 2% inflation target for 2016. Private consumption, accounting for 60% of the economy, appears to be picking up, with retailers' mood at a record high. However, some analysts predict further monetary expansion in October due to still-low inflation and persistent economic slack.

site_title: Cesar holds court with kooky canines
summary: Celebrity dog behavior expert Cesar Millan brought his TV show to life on stage at The Max Pavilion, performing in front of 3,000 canine lovers. Despite a slow start, the 100-minute show improved after intermission, with Millan successfully rehabilitating problem dogs on stage. The event featured a range of breeds, including a Maltese and a Husky, showcasing Millan's "pack leadership" skills. The show was attended by former remisier king Peter Lim and his family, with many praising Cesar's ability to "save" the dogs.

images.alt_text: Dylan Tan

site_title: Close fight emerges for Toa Payoh condo site
summary: A consortium led by Evia Real Estate won a 99-year private condo site in Toa Payoh with a top bid of S$725 to S$755 per square foot per plot ratio (psf ppr). The winning bid was just 1.1% higher than Sing Holdings' bid. Evia plans to build a 590-unit project, with half the units priced below S$1 million, aiming to make them affordable. The project will be developed on a site in Toa Payoh, with the remaining units expected to be sold at higher prices.

images.alt_text: Kalpana Rashiwala

site_title: Now serving: Italian coffee by Caffe Cagliari
summary: OWL International, a Singapore-based 3-in-1 coffee brand, has appointed Super Group Ltd as the sole Asia distributor for Italian coffee brand Caffe Cagliari. Caffe Cagliari, present in 45 countries, will be made available in Singapore through OWL International. This partnership aims to bring a taste of Italy to Singaporean consumers, expanding Caffe Cagliari's presence in the region.

site_title: Rate hike likely to come 'later this year': Fed chief
summary: The Federal Reserve left its benchmark interest rate unchanged at near zero, with Chair Janet Yellen stating a likely rate hike "later this year" due to the economy's moderate growth and improving labor market. The Fed trimmed its 2015 GDP growth forecast to 1.8-2.0% and expects inflation to rise, warranting initial monetary policy tightening. Yellen noted weak points in the labor market and cyclical weakness, particularly in wage growth and labor force participation.

site_title: Where the muse leads
summary: Filipino artist Jayson Cortez staged his international solo exhibition, "Portal," in Singapore, showcasing his hyper-realistic paintings with a touch of surrealism. Cortez, 28, draws inspiration from his younger sister and childhood memories, using oils on canvas to convey nostalgia. He has gained recognition for his work, including winning the 2014 Jurors' Choice award and exhibiting in Makati City and Mandaluyong City. Cortez's solo exhibition at One East Asia runs until June 23.

site_title: US investors in forex suit 'hopeful' of settlement
summary: US investors in the forex market are hopeful of reaching a settlement with HSBC, Barclays, Goldman Sachs, and BNP Paribas within 30 days, according to their lawyer. The investors claim the banks manipulated foreign exchange rates, violating US antitrust law, and have been scrutinized by authorities worldwide. The banks have introduced measures to clean up the market, but the investors claim bank employees used online chat rooms to rig the market, resulting in billions of dollars in fines and some criminal convictions. Serious discussions have taken place between the banks and investors.

site_title: Poltergeist - sans the screen screams
summary: The article discusses the disappointing remake of the 1982 horror film Poltergeist. Director Gil Kenan and producer Sam Raimi attempt to revive the classic, but the final product is too faithful to the original, failing to bring anything new to the table. The remake's reliance on outdated elements and lack of creativity makes it feel like a rehashing of previous supernatural films. The only redeeming qualities are the likable cast, particularly Sam Rockwell and Rosemarie DeWitt, and the better-than-average 3D visuals. Overall, the remake is a missed opportunity, and fans of the original may want to wait for it to air on TV instead.

images.alt_text: Dylan Tan

site_title: China's ODI hits 278.4b yuan, closes FDI gap
summary: China's outbound direct investment (ODI) reached 278.4 billion yuan in the first five months of 2015, a 47.4% jump, closing the gap with foreign direct investment (FDI) inflows. Local firms are seeking growth opportunities abroad due to a cooling economy, prompting the government to encourage investments. Analysts expect ODI to surpass FDI this year, driven by the "One Belt, One Road" initiative and a slowdown in the domestic economy.

site_title: Singapore Compact re-elects president for second term
summary: The Singapore Compact for Corporate Social Responsibility (CSR) has re-elected Kwek Leng Joo as president for a second term. The organization, now renamed Global Compact Network Singapore, aims to strengthen ties with the United Nations Global Compact and promote CSR among businesses in Singapore. The rebranding reflects the organization's commitment to the UNGC's 10 principles, which include human rights, labour rights, and environmental responsibility. The move is expected to enhance the Compact's role in promoting CSR and best practices among Singaporean businesses.

site_title: May CPI sees biggest gain in over 2 years
summary: US consumer prices rose 0.4% in May, the largest increase in over two years, driven by a surge in petrol prices. This marks the end of an energy-driven disinflationary trend, but underlying inflation pressures remain low due to a strong dollar. The core CPI, which excludes food and energy costs, rose 0.1% and remains unchanged from a year ago. Despite this, economists expect the Federal Reserve to raise interest rates later this year due to a tightening labor market and expected wage growth.

images.alt_text: US consumer prices in May recorded their largest increase in more than two years as petrol prices surged, suggesting an energy-driven disinflationary trend had probably run its course.

site_title: China developers offer gifts with flat sales
summary: China's debt-ridden developers are offering luxury gifts and discounts to lure buyers and shed unsold homes, with sales jumping 32% in May. To reduce debt, developers are focusing on clearing inventories, with only two major developers generating positive cash flow in 2014. The government's easing of property curbs has sparked a recovery, but developers are cautious, buying less land and holding off price hikes. Generous incentives aim to avoid alienating previous buyers and increase liquidity, with some developers offering discounts of up to 11% or cancelling purchases.

site_title: Tri5 Ventures unveils S$5m fund for Singapore ICT startups
summary: Tri5 Ventures, a Singapore-based venture capital firm, has launched an S$5 million fund to invest in seed-stage ICT startups in Singapore. The fund, which has already invested in three startups, will provide between S$100,000 and S$400,000 in each startup. Tri5 Ventures focuses on companies that can demonstrate how they will benefit Singapore and its people, and operates a "rolling programme" to help startups grow profitably. The firm's goal is to build a pay-it-forward ecosystem in Singapore, where previous entrepreneurs can mentor and invest in new generations of startups.

site_title: Europe: Stocks little changed amid Fed optimism, Greek Debt Talks
summary: European stocks remained largely unchanged, rising 0.1% to 384.22, amid optimism about a gradual Federal Reserve rate hike. The news followed better-than-expected US jobless claims and economic indicators, as well as slower-than-expected consumer price inflation. Economists cited a reduced need for the Fed to act quickly, with one saying a "relatively modest inflation number suggests that the imperative for the Fed to act isn't that strong."

site_title: Oil-sand megaproject era in Canada seems to be over
summary: Canada's oil-sands megaproject era appears to be fading due to factors such as the crude price slump, pressure to transition to cleaner energy, and tax increases. Companies like Suncor Energy and Imperial Oil are shifting towards smaller, cheaper projects with quicker returns, reducing cost overruns and increasing competitiveness with US shale producers. As a result, Canadian oil production is expected to drop 17% by 2030, and spending is poised to decline 30% to C$23 billion this year.

images.alt_text: Suncor Energy's oil-sands mine near Fort McMurray, Alberta, Canada. Firms are deferring new mines in favour of cheaper, bite-sized drilling programmes that deliver quicker returns and require less labour.

site_title: MFS favours US large-cap tech, consumer, bank stocks
summary: US stocks, particularly large-cap tech, consumer, and bank stocks, are favored by James Swanson, chief investment strategist at MFS Investment Management, due to the country's strong economy and low interest rates. He expects the business cycle to continue for a few more years and notes that US companies enjoy advantages such as cheap labor and low energy costs. Swanson predicts accelerated world growth by the end of the year, with Asia benefiting from lower input costs, and technology stocks seeing fast growth in cash flows and earnings.

site_title: Residential site at West Coast up for sale
summary: The Urban Redevelopment Authority (URA) has put a 18,909 sq m residential site at West Coast Vale up for sale, potentially yielding 595 units. Bids are expected to exceed S$600 per square foot per plot ratio (psf ppr), with 10-14 bids anticipated. Consultants are divided on the site's appeal, with some expecting healthy interest and others citing weak buyer sentiments and competing alternatives in the area.

site_title: Local indie acts to share famed English stage
summary: Local indie acts Charlie Lim, Pleasantry, and Gentle Bones will perform at Rough Trade's East London outlet as part of The Music Society Singapore's Live Showcase initiative. The trio, representing Singapore, will share the stage with other artists alongside established British acts. This event marks a significant milestone in promoting Singaporean music globally, further solidifying Rough Trade's reputation as a platform for discovering emerging talent. The showcase aims to bring together diverse musical styles and genres, fostering a unique and exciting experience for music lovers.

images.alt_text: Dylan Tan
Dream-pop quintet Pleasantry will perform at Rough Trade in London next week

site_title: Myanmar steps up forex sales to boost struggling kyat
summary: Myanmar's central bank has started unrestricted sales of foreign currency at its own specified rate to boost the struggling kyat, which has weakened by 26% since 2012. The move aims to address the disparity between official and unofficial exchange rates caused by a shortage of dollars in imports. The decision is the first significant economic reform by the semi-civilian government, which took office a year earlier. The move is part of efforts to address the economic challenges faced by the country.

site_title: Ley Choon wins S$24.8m deal from Changi Airport Group
summary: Ley Choon Group Holdings has secured a S$24.8 million contract from Changi Airport Group to resurface taxiways and install new LED airfield lighting at Changi Airport. The contract, valued at S$24.8 million, is part of a larger deal to improve airport infrastructure. Works began on June 15 and are expected to complete by February 14, 2017. The company's CEO, Toh Choo Huat, attributed the win to the group's expertise in asphalt construction and its new premix manufacturing capability.

site_title: Healthcare sector must align with SkillsFuture movement, say industry players
summary: Singapore's healthcare sector must align with the SkillsFuture movement to provide training and development programs that cater to workers' varying educational qualifications and work experience. Industry players emphasize the need for integrated training in areas such as health workforce development, healthcare technology, and elderly care. By 2020, the demand for intermediate and long-term care will increase, prompting a shift in emphasis from acute to chronic care. The sector must also adapt to emerging technologies and patient-centric care, with a focus on practical training, mentorship, and accountability.

site_title: Consumer comfort in US climbs after falling record nine weeks
summary: US consumer confidence rose to 40.9 in June after a record nine-week decline, stabilizing at a four-week average. The Bloomberg Consumer Comfort Index increased to 47.5 from 44 in May, with a 33% of households saying the economy is getting worse falling to 33%. A rise in jobs and housing market reports also boosted confidence, but gasoline prices could hinder further gains.

site_title: US leading economic indicator points to firming growth
summary: US economic activity is showing signs of firming growth, according to a leading economic indicator that increased 0.7% in May, surpassing forecasted gains. This follows a similar increase in April, suggesting the economy is regaining momentum after a slow start in the first quarter. The Conference Board's Leading Economic Index is seen as a gauge of future economic activity, and its rise indicates a potential rebound in growth.

site_title: M'sian navy is in contact with pirates aboard hijacked tanker
summary: A Malaysian naval vessel has located the hijacked tanker Orkim Harmony in Vietnamese waters, where it is in contact with the pirates aboard, promising them they will be unharmed. The crew and cargo are safe, and negotiations are underway. Eight pirates, armed with pistols and machetes, are on board. This is the second hijacking in the same area in two weeks, raising concerns over piracy in South-east Asia. The hijacking occurred on June 11, carrying 50,000 barrels of RON95 petrol.

site_title: US current account widens on weak exports, overseas profits
summary: The US current account deficit widened to its highest level since 2012, reaching $113.3 billion in the first quarter, a 9.9% increase. This was largely due to a strong dollar negatively impacting overseas profits and exports. Exports of goods fell 6.5% to $382.7 billion, while direct investment income receipts from abroad fell $9.1 billion. The deficit remains below a record high of 6.3% in 2005, but economists warn of potential impact on multinational corporations' sales and profits.

site_title: KrisEnergy begins oil production in Nong Yao, Thailand
summary: KrisEnergy Ltd has begun oil production from the Nong Yao field in the Gulf of Thailand, with three initial wells producing oil this week. The Nong Yao development will feature up to 23 wells and has a production capacity of up to 15,000 barrels of oil per day. KrisEnergy holds a 22.5% interest in the G11/48 licence, covering 3,374 sq km in water depths of up to 75 meters.

site_title: Champagne for dinner, anyone?
summary: A dinner hosted by Nicola Lee, commandeur of the Singapore branch of Les Orde des Coteaux de Champagne, showcased Perrier-Jouett champagnes, including Grand Brut NV, Blanson Rose, and Belle Epoque Edition Premiere 2007. The event featured winemaker M Herve Deschamps, who presented the wines. The champagnes were found to be perfect for fine dining, with Perrier-Jouett's style characterized by finesse, subtlety, and gentleness. The Belle Epoque 1996 was particularly impressive, with great strengths that may require maturity to display its full potential.

site_title: Tenaga to take over 1MDB's stake in power plant
summary: Malaysia's national utility Tenaga is acquiring 1MDB's 70% stake in a 2,000 MW coal-fired power project for an undisclosed sum, sparking a slump in Tenaga's shares. The deal marks 1MDB's first sale of a power asset, as the state fund faces debt of nearly RM42 billion. Tenaga's shares fell 4.3% after the announcement, while 1MDB's liquidity problems have put its ability to build the project in question. The deal comes at a time when 1MDB plans to pare down its debt and pare down its debt.

site_title: US jobless claims fall more than expected
summary: US jobless claims fell 12,000 to 267,000 in the week ended June 13, exceeding expectations. This marks the 15th consecutive week claims have been below 300,000, indicating a tightening labor market. The Federal Reserve's recent assessment of the labor market also suggested a decrease in labor market slack. Economists had forecast claims to fall to 275,000, and the four-week moving average of claims decreased to 276,750.

site_title: Fed may hike just once in 2015 as Yellen strikes less certain tone
summary: The Federal Reserve may hike interest rates just once in 2015, according to a growing number of policymakers, including Fed Chair Janet Yellen, who has struck a less certain tone on rate hikes. This shift in the committee's centre of gravity suggests the Fed may wait until late in the year to raise rates, contrary to previous expectations of two hikes this year. The decision will depend on data in coming months, particularly on job creation and inflation, which may influence the Fed's stance on monetary policy.

site_title: Asia-Pacific pips North America in high net worth individuals
summary: The Asia-Pacific region surpassed North America to become the region with the most high net worth individuals, according to the World Wealth Report 2015, with 4.69 million HNWIs. The Asia-Pacific region experienced the fastest growth in HNWIs in 2014, growing at 9%. This trend is expected to continue, with the region projected to be the world's number one in terms of wealth by the end of the year.

site_title: Airline industry confident of global emissions deal next year: IATA
summary: Airlines are optimistic about reaching a global emissions deal by 2016, according to IATA. The aviation industry believes a simple offset mechanism will be the most effective scheme. IATA's director general, Tony Tyler, stated that a successful Paris agreement in November could boost momentum for the International Civil Aviation Organization (ICAO) talks, which aim to establish a global market-based system to regulate aviation emissions. The talks follow the European Union's Emissions Trading System, which covers emissions from European flights.

site_title: Mercedes's US$230,000 Maybach defies China's cooling luxury market
summary: Mercedes-Benz is selling nearly 500 Maybach cars per month in China, surpassing its global sales of Maybach cars in a year. The ultra-luxury variant of the Mercedes S-Class, priced at around $230,000, is attracting wealthy buyers in the country. This marks a significant turnaround for the brand, which sold only 200-300 cars per year between 2002 and 2011. Mercedes is optimistic about sustaining sales momentum, driven by strong growth in China, which is crucial for the company's goal of overtaking BMW and Audi in global sales by the end of the decade.

site_title: First Mers case confirmed in Thailand: Public health minister
summary: Thai health officials confirmed the country's first Mers case, a 75-year-old man from the Middle East, who had traveled to Thailand with his family. The patient is receiving treatment and is in stable condition. This marks the first Mers case in Thailand, following a deadly outbreak in South Korea.

site_title: Pimco CEO says investors had enough time to prepare for Greece
summary: Pimco CEO Douglas Hodge says investors have had three years to prepare for a possible Greek default, stating that the market "is fairly sanguine" about Greece exiting the eurozone. European stocks declined as finance chiefs gathered to discuss a potential 7.2 billion euro bailout for Greece. Despite hopes for a deal, Chancellor Angela Merkel says a solution is possible if the Greek government follows through on economic-reform pledges. Hodge expresses confidence in Europe's financial stability, citing strong economies and a functioning financial system.

site_title: Oil prices higher after data, Fed
summary: Oil prices rose on Thursday following a mixed US energy report and the US Federal Reserve's decision to keep near-zero interest rates unchanged. US benchmark West Texas Intermediate increased 67 cents to $60.59 a barrel, while Brent North Sea crude rose 87 cents to $64.74 a barrel. Analysts attribute the price rise to falling US inventories and rig counts, which could help reduce global supply glut. The Fed's decision also helped ease concerns about interest rate adjustments, which can impact oil demand.

site_title: UK plans to end onshore wind subsidy programme a year early
summary: The UK plans to end its onshore wind subsidy programme a year early, with the Renewables Obligation programme closing to new projects in April. The decision, made by Energy Secretary Amber Rudd, aims to cut subsidies and give local communities more control over wind farm development. However, the move is criticized by the renewable-energy industry, which argues it will halt funding to the cheapest form of large-scale renewable power. The government maintains its commitment to decarbonizing power production, but the decision sends a "chilling signal" to investors.

site_title: US: Stocks up but Oracle slumps on weak earnings
summary: US stocks rose on Thursday, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average up 113.61 points (0.63%) to 18,049.35, and the S&P 500 gaining 9.75 (0.46%) to 2,110.19. Oracle shares plummeted 7.2% after reporting disappointing earnings, citing a strong dollar. The gains followed a dovish Federal Reserve policy announcement and news conference. Meanwhile, inflation rose 0.4% in May due to higher gasoline prices, and US jobless claims dropped 12,000 to 267,000.

site_title: US consumer prices post largest gain in more than two years
summary: US consumer prices rose 0.4% in May, the largest gain in over two years, driven by a surge in gasoline prices. The Labor Department reported the increase, which left the 12-month CPI unchanged at 0.2%. Economists had forecast a 0.5% rise. Despite energy price stabilization, a strong dollar curbs underlying inflation. The Federal Reserve expressed confidence that inflation will move towards its 2% target, with interest rate hikes likely later this year.

images.alt_text: US consumer prices in May recorded their largest increase in more than two years as gasoline prices surged, suggesting an energy-driven disinflationary trend had probably run its course.

site_title: Art Apart Fair focus: Philippines
summary: A southern Philippines-based gallery, Qube, is hosting an Art Apart Fair to showcase the art of seven Cebu-based artists, defying the conventional notion that Manila is the only art market for southern artists. The fair, themed "Overlap: Diversity in art and artistry," aims to present Cebu's unique art scene to the Asian region. The selected artists were chosen for their varied qualities and reflection of the current art market trend in Cebu. The fair will provide an opportunity for these artists to gain exposure to a broader audience.

site_title: Super Group unit gets Asia distributorship of Italian coffee brand
summary: Super Group Ltd's subsidiary OWL International was appointed the sole distributor for Italian coffee brand Caffe Cagliari in Asia. OWL will manage and distribute Caffe Cagliari's products, including whole beans, coffee grounds, and machines. Caffe Cagliari, with 100 years of history, also plans to use Singapore as its regional distribution hub.

site_title: Philly Fed factory activity expands at fast pace in June
summary: US factory activity in the mid-Atlantic region expanded in June at a faster pace than expected, with the Philadelphia Federal Reserve Bank's business activity index rising to 15.2, nearly double analyst expectations. This is the highest level since December 2014 and indicates expansion in the region's manufacturing. The index rose across nearly every component, with new orders and prices paid surging, but employment fell. The expansion is seen as a positive sign for US manufacturing and may influence the national report by the Institute for Supply Management.

site_title: Green love-in at Paris Air Show but weaker sales
summary: The Paris Air Show focused on environmental issues, with industry leaders and government ministers sharing a love for reducing emissions. Airbus and Boeing showcased planes promising significant fuel savings, but sales were weaker than expected, with Boeing securing 145 orders worth $18.6 billion and Airbus 124 orders worth $16.3 billion. Despite a slowdown in sales, the industry remains optimistic, with order books full for the next decade and a predicted demand for over 30,000 planes in the next 20 years.

site_title: China rates China Development Bank bonds as risk-free indefinitely
summary: China's bank regulator has indefinitely rated China Development Bank Corp bonds as risk-free, cementing the bank's role as the country's biggest policy bank. The decision applies to bonds denominated in yuan and foreign currencies, and marks the bank's return to its traditional role. With over 10.3 trillion yuan in assets, CDB funds China's urbanization drive, such as infrastructure development, and finances overseas expansion of Chinese firms like Huawei. The move is seen as a significant shift, following a review every few years to assess the bank's commercial viability.

site_title: Noble Group to supply Egypt with LNG cargo
summary: Noble Group has secured a contract to supply a single liquefied natural gas (LNG) cargo to Egypt in late June, following a closed tender launched two weeks ago. The tender, which was only open to Vitol, Trafigura, and Noble Group, aims to procure an additional LNG cargo this month.

site_title: IMF Lagarde affirms Greece's June 30 deadline to make IMF payments
summary: IMF Managing Director Christine Lagarde set a hard deadline for Greece to make a 1.5 billion euro payment to the International Monetary Fund on June 30, with no grace period. Euro-area finance ministers are at a stalemate over releasing 7.2 billion euros of aid in Greece's 240 billion-euro bailout, which expires on the same day. The IMF payment is part of a larger bailout deal, and Greece must reach an agreement with creditors by the deadline to avoid default.

site_title: Malaysia's central bank says global, domestic factors drive ringgit's volatility
summary: Malaysia's central bank attributes the recent volatility in the ringgit currency to both global and domestic factors. The currency slid to nine-year lows in June due to weak commodity prices and concerns over government-linked entities, including 1MDB, which has faced allegations of financial mismanagement. The central bank launched an inquiry into 1MDB and emphasized its commitment to delivering its mandates without being drawn into politics. The ringgit recovered slightly, closing at 3.71 against the dollar.

site_title: SNB says no immediate need to influence monetary landscape
summary: The Swiss National Bank (SNB) believes its current monetary policies are sufficient for the current economic landscape, despite the strong Swiss franc. Board member Fritz Zurbruegg stated that economic growth and inflation forecasts remain unchanged, with no immediate need to influence conditions. However, the SNB may reconsider its stance if Greece's talks with creditors fail, potentially leading to future interventions. The SNB's decision aims to maintain stability in the monetary landscape.

site_title: Singapore Wrap Thursday
summary: Singapore's office market is expensive due to a space glut and slowing rental growth, according to Union Investment. Singapore Airlines plans to develop a new plane with new technology to restore nonstop flights to the US. A 99-year condo site in Toa Payoh fetched 14 bids, while First Sponsor completed its acquisition of two Amsterdam Holiday Inn hotels. Noble Group executed its fourth share buyback this month, and Singapore shares slipped 0.8% due to concerns over Greece overshadowing dovish Fed comments.

site_title: Poland seeks to balance Pope's climate call with energy security
summary: Poland plans to reconcile its use of coal for energy security with Pope Francis's warning on fossil fuel pollution. The country aims to lower pollution from coal using new technologies, despite its reliance on coal deposits to counter energy dependence on Russia. Poland's Treasury Minister, Andrzej Czerwinski, announced the plan, which aligns with the Papal encyclical's call for reducing fossil fuel emissions to combat global warming.

site_title: WHO chief voices optimism over South Korea Mers outbreak
summary: WHO chief Margaret Chan expressed optimism over South Korea's ability to contain the Mers outbreak, stating the country is "on a very good footing" despite initial slow response. The outbreak has killed 23 people, infecting 165, with 35% of cases involving family and friends of infected patients. The WHO acknowledged a lack of awareness among health workers and the public contributed to the rapid spread. Despite a recent decline in new cases, experts criticize the government for inadequate quarantine measures, and the situation remains a public health concern.

site_title: KrisEnergy begins oil production from Nong Yao field in Thailand
summary: KrisEnergy Ltd has begun oil production from the Nong Yao field in Thailand. The Nong Yao development, which includes up to 23 wells and facilities for crude export, has a production capacity of up to 15,000 barrels of oil per day and a processing capacity of 30,000 barrels of fluids per day. This marks a significant milestone for KrisEnergy, further solidifying its presence in the Thai oil and gas market.

site_title: Ringgit rallies as Fed rate signal eases pressure from lower oil
summary: Malaysia's ringgit rose 1.3% to a two-week high of 3.7090 per dollar after the Federal Reserve signaled it will raise interest rates gradually this year, easing pressure on the currency due to falling oil prices. The move alleviated concerns about the impact of lower oil prices on the nation's oil exports. The ringgit's gain is seen as technical adjustments, while a report forecast an acceleration in May's inflation rate. Ten-year government bonds rose, with the yield falling to 4.04%.

site_title: HSBC, Citigroup top earners as Mideast investment bank fees gain
summary: Investment-banking fees in the Middle East rose 13% in the first five months of 2015, with HSBC and Citigroup leading the rankings. Total fees reached $317 million, the highest since 2013, driven by M&A transactions. The value of deals in the region increased 25% to $28 billion, with equity capital market deals rising 67% and bond sales falling 25%. The surge is attributed to increased market volatility and demand for liquidity among clients.

site_title: M1's longest serving independent director dies at 65
summary: M1 Ltd announced the death of its longest-serving independent board director, Roger John Barlow, 65, who passed away on June 14. Barlow, a former chairman of the remuneration committee and nominating committee, served on the board since 2002. The company expressed gratitude for his invaluable contributions and extended condolences to his family.

site_title: Chinese tyre makers set for higher costs under new rubber standard
summary: Chinese tyre makers face increased costs next month as Beijing adopts a new standard for compound rubber, capping natural rubber at 88%. The change, aimed at boosting domestic rubber producers' prices, is expected to curb the use of the compound and add to companies' problems due to US anti-dumping duties. Analysts doubt a delay or scrapping of the standard, and some firms may be forced to import natural rubber, raising concerns about a drop in rubber demand from the world's biggest consumer.

site_title: Singapore: STI eases 0.8% as Greece casts shadow over dovish Fed
summary: Singapore shares slipped 0.8% on Thursday, with the Straits Times Index down 25.49 points to 3,300.42, due to concerns about Greece overshadowing dovish comments from the US Federal Reserve. The most actively traded stock, Magnus Energy, rose 71%, while losers outnumbered gainers 241 to 180. This follows a 5-day rally ahead of GDP data and despite US stocks reaching fresh records despite tariff uncertainty.

site_title: Papal move boosts hopes for climate deal: activists
summary: Pope Francis's encyclical, "Laudato Si", has boosted hopes for a UN climate deal by framing the issue as a pressing moral concern, rather than a remote environmental problem. The 184-page document is seen as a milestone by green campaigners, potentially transforming the climate issue for many Catholics. The UN accord on curbing greenhouse-gases, due in less than six months, could see a significant impact from the Pope's document, as it mobilizes action on climate change.

images.alt_text: Pope Francis's encyclical on the environment provides a massive mobilising boost for efforts to reach a UN deal on climate change this year, green campaigners said Thursday.

site_title: 99-year condo site in Toa Payoh draws 14 bids
summary: A 99-year leasehold private condo site in Lorong 6/Lorong 4 Toa Payoh attracted 14 bids, with the top offer from a consortium at S$345.86 million (S$755.30 per square foot per plot ratio). Other notable bidders included Sing Holdings and UOL Venture Investments, with bids of S$747.09 and S$740.32 per square foot, respectively. The 1.2-hectare site can generate an estimated 535 homes, and the tender was conducted by the Housing & Development Board.

images.alt_text: Kalpana Rashiwala

site_title: Malaysia: Shares end lower
summary: Malaysia's Kuala Lumpur Composite Index closed 8.74 points lower at 1,718.12, with 1.45 billion lots valued at RM1.97 billion traded. The market saw 380 gainers and 369 losers.

site_title: Malaysia says committed to MH370 hunt despite ship pull-out
summary: Malaysia reaffirms its commitment to finding the missing MH370 flight, despite not renewing its contract with the search vessel GO Phoenix due to winter conditions. The country has invested over $46 million in the search and recovery efforts, and plans to continue scouring an additional 60,000 square kilometers. Malaysia's Transport Minister, Liow Tiong Lai, stated that the country remains committed to finishing the search, despite speculation that its involvement was flagging. The search for MH370, which vanished in March 2014, has yet to yield any wreckage or confirmation of the plane's fate.

images.alt_text: Malaysia on Thursday insisted it was committed to completing the hunt for missing flight MH370 despite not renewing its contract with one of three search vessels scanning the Indian Ocean seabed.

site_title: Norway central bank cuts key rate to record low 1.0%
summary: Norway's central bank cut its key interest rate to a record low 1.0% to counteract the impact of lower oil prices on the economy. The decision was made due to a slightly weaker-than-expected economy and a deteriorating economic outlook. The bank warned of a possible further cut, citing a 40% drop in oil prices and a rise in unemployment to 4.1%. The move aims to stimulate the economy and combat the effects of lower oil prices, which have impacted the country's gross domestic product.

site_title: UN aviation agency downgrades safety ratings of Thai body
summary: Thailand's civil aviation body has been downgraded by the International Civil Aviation Authority (ICAO) to Category 2 due to failing to properly oversee airlines under its jurisdiction. The downgrade comes after a January audit found issues with certification for the transportation of hazardous goods and a shortage of technical officers. The move may prompt global aviation agencies to reevaluate the safety of Thai aviation facilities, potentially impacting airlines such as NokScoot and Thai AirAsia X.

site_title: Pope urges drastic fossil-fuel emission cut to protect climate
summary: Pope Francis urges a drastic cut in fossil-fuel emissions to protect the climate, calling it a "spiral of self-destruction" caused by rich nations and the global economy. In his 181-page encyclical "Laudato si'", he appeals to people of good will to take action, weaving together science, theology, and morality. The document, published in eight languages, stands as a key legacy of Francis's papacy, emphasizing the need for urgent and drastic action to protect the planet and the world's poorest people.

site_title: UBS gave out 'instruction manual on fixing Libor,' Hayes said
summary: UBS distributed an "instruction manual on fixing Libor" to suit their trading positions, according to former trader Thomas Hayes, who testified in 2013. The guide, titled "Guide to Publishing Libor Rates," instructed traders to adjust their submissions based on their "delta/fixing position." This allegedly allowed UBS to influence benchmark interest rates for its own benefit, with the manual specifying increases or decreases in Libor rates depending on the trader's exposure. The revelation was made in a 2013 trial, where Hayes was charged with manipulating benchmark rates.

site_title: Heads to roll in Indonesian government after poor performance: official
summary: Indonesia's President Joko Widodo plans to fire several top government officials due to poor performance, according to Cabinet Secretary Andi Widjajanto. This move comes amid frustration over the country's flagging economy and policymaking issues. The president has set priorities that need to be implemented seriously, and those failing to meet targets may face dismissal. This is the first cabinet reshuffle since Widodo took office in October, with officials in ministries and state-owned enterprises potentially at risk.

site_title: Indonesia central bank holds benchmark rate at 7.50%
summary: Indonesia's central bank maintained its benchmark reference rate at 7.50% during its Thursday meeting, as expected. This decision aims to control inflation and reduce the current account deficit. The overnight deposit and lending facility rates remained unchanged at 5.50% and 8.00%, respectively. The move follows a Reuters poll predicting the bank would hold the key rate steady.

site_title: Thailand's investment in renewables seen at least S$4b in 2015
summary: Thailand aims to invest at least S$4 billion in renewable energy in 2015, driven by a surge in solar farm and rooftop projects. The country seeks to reduce its dependence on natural gas to 40% by 2036, focusing on clean coal and renewable power. Solar energy is expected to make up 31% of the country's renewable capacity by 2036, with a total capacity of 19,635 MW. The government aims to invest 4.8 trillion baht in new power plants and transmission lines to meet a doubling of generating capacity to 70,000 MW by 2036.

site_title: Mega ship trend close to reaching optimal size limits: OECD official
summary: The global shipping industry is approaching the optimal size limit for mega vessels, according to Olaf Merk, a senior official from the International Transport Forum. Currently, ships with a capacity of 19,000 twenty-foot equivalent units (TEU) are becoming increasingly unprofitable, with a capacity oversupply of about 20-30%. Increasing ship size further would only result in a 5% cost savings, making it financially unviable to build even larger vessels. This trend suggests that the industry is nearing its peak in terms of ship size.

site_title: Indonesia's Lion Air likely to delay planned IPO from Q1 2016: Group CEO
summary: Indonesian carrier Lion Air is likely to delay its planned initial public offering (IPO) from Q1 2016 due to weak market conditions. The airline hopes to raise around 10 trillion rupiah (S$1 billion) from the IPO, initially intended for airport expansion. Lion Group's CEO, Rusdi Kirana, did not disclose a new timeline for the IPO.

site_title: Indonesia's president signs decree to cap staple food prices: spokesman
summary: Indonesia's President Joko Widodo has signed a decree allowing the government to cap prices of staple foods, cement, and other basic goods during peak demand periods, particularly during religious holidays or price volatility. This move aims to stimulate the flagging economy, which is at its weakest since 2009. The decree is part of President Widodo's efforts to control inflation and support the economy, following his decision to limit the rise in domestic petrol prices. The government's price control measures are expected to take effect during the upcoming Ramadan fasting month.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks end 0.22% lower, Shanghai slumps
summary: Hong Kong shares declined 0.22% on Thursday, following losses across the region, as Shanghai tumbled 3.67% on liquidity concerns. The US Federal Reserve stated that any rate rises would be gradual. The Hang Seng Index fell 59.13 points to 26,694.66, while the Shanghai Composite Index dropped 182.54 points to 4,785.36.

site_title: Rio Tinto sees weaker iron ore demand as China's economy shifts
summary: Rio Tinto expects weaker iron ore demand due to China's economic shift, with reduced consumption of new steel in the housing sector. China's imports fell in May, and prices touched a decade low in April. Despite this, Rio Tinto remains committed to increasing output to 350 million metric tons by 2017. Other major iron ore suppliers, BHP Billiton and Vale, have also considered trimming or slowing expansions due to weakening demand.

site_title: Crew of missing MT Orkim Harmony tanker safe: navy chief
summary: The crew of the missing MT Orkim Harmony tanker has been safely detected in Cambodian waters, with Navy chief Admiral Tan Sri Abdul Aziz Jaafar stating that hijackers on board are being persuaded to surrender. The suspects have been promised not to be harmed by authorities. The KD Terengganu is shadowing the vessel and is in communication with the captain.

site_title: Malaysia's Tenaga Nasional to take over 1MDB's stake in Project 3B
summary: Malaysia's state fund 1MDB is selling its 70% stake in the US$3.6 billion Project 3B coal-fired plant to national utility Tenaga Nasional Bhd, citing debt reduction efforts. The deal aims to pare down 42 billion ringgit (US$11.31 billion) in debt. The sale is part of 1MDB's efforts to stabilize its finances and alleviate pressure on the Malaysian credit rating.

site_title: UK retail sales slow in May as shoppers buy fewer clothes
summary: UK retail sales growth slowed to 0.2% in May, matching economists' expectations, with clothing sales down 1.6% and food stores up 0.6%. Despite this, sales are still 4.6% higher than last year, and when adjusted for lower prices, consumer spending could be on track for its strongest year in a decade. The slowdown in sales growth is attributed to cooler weather, but some economists believe that low inflation and rising wages are boosting household disposable income.

site_title: Cisco to invest US$10 billion in China
summary: Cisco plans to invest over $10 billion in China over several years to promote innovation, globalisation, and job creation. The investments will focus on areas such as research and development, equity investment, and talent development. Cisco has signed memoranda of understanding with the National Development and Reform Commission and an association of universities to expand its presence in China. The initiatives aim to help China "innovate and globalise" and contribute to the country's GDP growth. This move comes as China's economy expanded 7.0% in the first quarter, the weakest result in six years.

site_title: AirAsia shares battle back after critical report
summary: AirAsia shares rebounded 8.5% on Thursday after a critical report by research house GMT Research questioned the airline's accounting practices and profit outlook. Despite concerns over weak cash flow, analysts say the business model remains intact and a buying opportunity has emerged. CEO Aireen Omar's recent share purchase has helped alleviate bearish sentiment. AirAsia faces challenges in the regional low-cost sector, but analysts express confidence in its ability to recover from the Indonesia AirAsia crash and intensifying industry competition.

site_title: Oil prices dip on US gasoline build, but supported by weak dollar
summary: US oil prices dropped 42 cents to $59.50 a barrel as gasoline stocks rose more than expected, contrary to analyst predictions. The decline was partially offset by Middle East tensions and a weaker US dollar. Brent crude fell 30 cents to $63.57 a barrel. The US Federal Reserve's interest rate decision also contributed to the decline, with the US dollar sliding and Wall Street stocks rising.

site_title: China lets local regulators approve asset-backed securities: sources
summary: China has given local regulators the power to approve asset-backed securities, a move aimed at quickening the development of the country's securitisation market. Provincial branches of the China Banking Regulatory Commission can now sign off on new ABS issuance, while big commercial banks must still seek approval from the central bank. This simplification is part of broader efforts to deepen China's financial market, which could lower financing costs for companies and increase investment avenues for savers. The move is the latest step in China's bid to encourage securitisation.

site_title: Swiss central bank keeps target rate and sight deposit charge unchanged
summary: The Swiss National Bank (SNB) maintained its target rate and sight deposit charge at 0.75% and -1.25% to -0.25% for the three-month Libor, respectively. The central bank stated that it considers the exchange rate's impact on inflation and economic developments when making monetary policy decisions. The decision was seen as a move to keep the franc stable in currency markets, with the SNB remaining active in the foreign exchange market.

site_title: Merkel says deal with Greece still possible if Athens musters will
summary: German Chancellor Angela Merkel stated that Greece can still reach an agreement with its international creditors if the country decisively implements reforms. Merkel emphasized the importance of Greece remaining in the eurozone, saying "If those in charge in Greece can muster the will, an agreement with the three institutions is still possible."

images.alt_text: German Chancellor Angela Merkel said on Thursday that it is still possible for Greece to reach an agreement with its international creditors - the European Union, International Monetary Fund and European Central Bank.

site_title: Merkel wants to seal framework for US/EU trade deal by year end
summary: German Chancellor Angela Merkel stated that Berlin aims to reach a trade framework with the US by the end of this year. She believes Germany will gain significant economic benefits from the Transatlantic Trade and Investment Partnership (TTIP). Merkel will not discuss Britain's EU reform at an upcoming EU summit, but will ask European Council President Donald Tusk to examine the issue.

site_title: Future in-flight entertainment will know when you're asleep
summary: Thales has unveiled a prototype for the next generation of business class seats, featuring iris-tracking technology that can detect when passengers are asleep. The screen can pause and restart automatically, providing a more personalized in-flight entertainment experience. The technology is set to be integrated with personal devices via new apps, allowing passengers to sync their content with the onboard system. This innovation aims to improve passenger comfort and convenience during flights.

site_title: Societe Generale signals exit from Amundi with IPO plan
summary: Societe Generale is planning to sell its 20% stake in asset manager Amundi through an initial public offering (IPO) this year. The move aims to bolster capital for the French bank, which faces declining activity and rising losses in Russia. Amundi, overseeing $1.1 trillion in assets, may be valued at $8 billion. The IPO will provide liquidity to Societe Generale, and Amundi will remain a key partner for the bank's retail and insurance networks for at least five years.

site_title: Japan pushes LNG for transport to help climate, energy security
summary: Japan plans to promote the use of liquefied natural gas (LNG) in trucks and ships for long-distance transport, aiming to reduce carbon emissions and diversify energy sources. The country's trade ministry is drafting a report to encourage 10% of its 300,000 trucks to use LNG by soon, with a goal of using gas for a "substantial" part of the fleet. This move is also driven by energy security concerns, as Japan is the world's biggest importer of LNG. The plan is part of Japan's efforts to reduce its reliance on fossil fuels and mitigate climate change.

site_title: Seoul: Won posts biggest daily gain in 3 months; shares up
summary: The South Korean won posted its largest daily gain in three months, rising 1% to 1,107.1 to the dollar, driven by the US Federal Reserve's signal to raise rates at a slower pace than expected. The won's gains tracked the Japanese yen's rise, and the Korea Composite Stock Price Index (KOSPI) closed up 0.3% at 2,041.88 points.

site_title: Allianz to raise clean-energy spending, may buy US wind farms
summary: Allianz SE is increasing its clean-energy investments by 75% to 350 million euros, bringing total investments to 500 million euros in 2015. The insurer is also exploring opportunities to invest in US wind farms, including offshore wind farms via a joint venture. This move is part of Allianz's expansion into the US market and diversification of its clean-energy investments. The company, one of the largest institutional investors in clean energy, aims to capitalize on growing demand for renewable energy.

site_title: China's outbound investment jumps, catching up with FDI
summary: China's outbound direct investment surged 47.4% to 278.4 billion yuan (S$59.63 billion) in the first five months of 2015, closing the gap with foreign direct investment inflows. This growth is driven by non-financial firms seeking growth opportunities abroad to boost competitiveness. Outbound investment is expected to surpass foreign direct investment this year, as the government encourages firms to invest abroad to slow down foreign exchange reserve build-up. Analysts attribute the jump to a cooling economy prompting businesses to seek growth elsewhere.

site_title: Japan faces dilemma over plutonium stored in France
summary: Japan faces a dilemma over 16 tonnes of plutonium stored in France, a legacy of its reprocessing facility at La Hague. With its reactor fleet shut down after the Fukushima crisis, Japan is unable to take the fuel and must find alternative countries to use it, or pay other nations to do so. The situation has taken on urgency as Areva faces billions of dollars in losses, and experts warn that the world's growing plutonium inventory poses a "clear and present danger" of proliferation.

site_title: Europe: Stocks slip at open
summary: Europe's stock markets fell at the start of trade on Thursday, with London's FTSE 100 down 0.17% to 6,669.25 points, and Frankfurt's DAX 30 down 0.37% to 10,937.67 points. The decline follows concerns over Greece's bailout repayments, which have led to fading hopes of a deal with creditors.

site_title: Chinese buy foreign cars no matter what more than 60% of time
summary: Chinese consumers prefer foreign-branded autos over local makes, favoring quality and brand reputation over cost. SAIC Motor Corp, China's largest carmaker, reported declining sales due to low demand for Buicks and Chevrolets. The company's joint ventures with General Motors and Volkswagen have been successful, but SAIC's own brands, MG and Roewe, have seen a 34% decline. Despite this, SAIC's shares have risen 9.8% this year, outperforming the Shanghai Composite Index. SAIC's chairman, Chen Hong, attributes the preference for foreign brands to "hard to change consumer perception."

site_title: SNB urges progress from UBS, Credit Suisse on leverage ratios
summary: The Swiss National Bank (SNB) urged UBS and Credit Suisse to improve their leverage ratios to better withstand a potential crisis, although the country is expected to hold off on tougher capital requirements until new international standards are outlined later this year. The SNB's annual financial stability report noted that Switzerland's biggest banks are not currently ahead of rivals in terms of leverage ratios, and that regulators should prepare for increased capital requirements. The central bank emphasized the need for big banks to improve their resilience, citing the "too big to fail" problem as a priority for regulators.

site_title: Thai junta's legislature considering changes to interim charter
summary: Thailand's National Legislative Assembly is considering amendments to the junta-drafted interim constitution, which would allow for a national vote on the next charter and permit previously banned politicians to take formal roles in the junta government. The proposed changes also stipulate that officials can pledge allegiance to the king through a representative instead of the ailing monarch. Critics have called for the process to be delayed, while supporters have suggested a referendum could be held as early as January 2016. The outcome of the vote could determine the timeline for elections and the drafting of a permanent constitution.

site_title: Seoul: Shares set to post biggest daily gain in 4 weeks; won up
summary: South Korean shares are poised for their largest daily gain in four weeks, with the Korea Composite Stock Price Index (KOSPI) up 0.7% at 2,049.14 points. The US Federal Reserve signaled a more dovish tone, lowering its expectations for 2015 economic growth and reducing its growth and federal funds rate forecast. The won also rose, touching a week high against the dollar, amid concerns about the Greek issue and the ongoing US-EU trade talks.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks close down 1.13% on stronger yen
summary: Tokyo stocks declined 1.13% on Thursday, falling below the 20,000 mark for the first time in a month, due to a stronger yen and investor anticipation of the Bank of Japan's policy meeting. The Nikkei 225 index dropped 228.45 points to 19,990.82, while the Topix index fell 1.04% to 1,616.66. Investors also await the outcome of the US Federal Reserve's policy meeting, where caution on interest rate hikes is expected.

site_title: SunMoon to acquire 51% stake in Harvest Season SG
summary: SunMoon Food Company plans to acquire a 51% stake in Harvest Season Singapore through a conditional sale and purchase agreement. The acquisition price is approximately S$3.11 million, paid through an allotment of 60 million new SunMoon shares. The deal is part of SunMoon's expansion into the fruit-selling business in China.

site_title: Swiss franc inches up after SNB keeps rates unchanged, tweaks forecasts
summary: The Swiss National Bank (SNB) kept interest rates unchanged at -0.75% and revised its economic forecasts, citing a -1% inflation rate for this year. The Swiss franc strengthened against the euro and dollar, rising 0.2% against the euro and 0.3% against the dollar. The 10-year government bond yield increased to 0.146% from 0.131%. The SNB's rate decision and revised forecasts had little impact on the markets, with the euro and dollar trading flat.

site_title: Tsipras says 'blind insistence' on pension cuts would worsen crisis
summary: Greek Prime Minister Alexis Tsipras has warned that "blind insistence" on cutting pensions will worsen Greece's financial crisis. In a German newspaper commentary, Tsipras rejected pension cuts, citing a 25% unemployment rate and high youth unemployment, and stated that Greeks work longer than Germans. He also denied that German taxpayers are paying Greek pensions, challenging perceptions among Germans that they are. Tsipras's government faces dire warnings of being forced out of the euro zone if it fails to strike a deal with creditors by the end of June.

images.alt_text: The "blind insistence" on cutting Greek pensions will only worsen the country's already dire financial crisis, Greek Prime Minister Alexis Tsipras wrote in a German newspaper commentary on Thursday.

site_title: Malaysia's hijacked oil tanker detected in Cambodian waters
summary: A Malaysian oil tanker hijacked last week has been detected in Cambodian waters, according to local reports. The vessel, MT Orkim Harmony, has been repainted and renamed, and Malaysian authorities are tracking it from the air. The ship's lead is believed to have followed a sighting by an Australian aircraft. Malaysian Chief of Navy Admiral Abdul Aziz Jaafar confirmed the vessel's location and said efforts to recover it are ongoing.

images.alt_text: The small oil tanker that was hijacked off the southeast coast of Malaysia last week has been detected in Cambodian waters, according to local media reports on Thursday.

site_title: Hong Kong vetoes China-backed electoral proposal
summary: Hong Kong's legislature vetoed a China-backed electoral reform package, rejecting the blueprint that aimed to define the city's democratic future. The proposal was criticized by opposition lawmakers and activists as flawed and undemocratic. With 37 legislators present, 28 voted against the package and 8 in favor, while one abstained. The veto marks a significant setback for China's efforts to exert control over Hong Kong's electoral system.

site_title: Shanghai studies Singapore-style limit on license plate validity
summary: Shanghai is studying a Singapore-style limit on license plate validity, a measure that would restrict the number of vehicles on the road and curb demand. The city aims to balance this with the stability of car prices, which have surged to 90,000 yuan in past years. If implemented, this move could be followed by other Chinese cities, but it may not solve the problem of restricting vehicle population. Experts warn that consumers may find ways to circumvent the measure by registering vehicles in other cities with fewer restrictions.

site_title: Gold extends gains on dovish Fed, softer dollar
summary: Gold prices rose 0.2% to $1,187.06 an ounce after the Federal Reserve hinted it may hike US interest rates later than expected and cut economic growth forecasts. The Fed maintained near-zero interest rates and indicated a potential hike only after improving labor market conditions and inflation. A softer dollar also boosted gold prices. Analysts expect further gains in gold, citing rising speculative short positions and a dovish tone from the Fed statement.

site_title: Greek banks face capital hole even if bailout agreement reached
summary: Greek banks face a potential capital hole even if a bailout agreement is reached, as a recession drives up losses from bad loans. The four largest banks, accounting for 91% of Greek banking assets, may need an additional 16 billion euros in provisions to cover losses from overdue and restructured loans. Even with a bailout, the banks' capital is still thinly capitalized, with more than half made up of deferred tax assets that have limited value. A potential agreement with creditors may alleviate liquidity concerns, but solvency remains a concern, with shares of the four banks having lost about half their value in recent months.

site_title: SoftBank launches robot venture with Alibaba, Foxconn
summary: SoftBank launched a joint venture with Alibaba and Foxconn to sell its human-like robot Pepper to consumers worldwide. The robots, initially used in stores, will now be available to the general public. SoftBank will hold a 60% stake in the venture, with Alibaba and Foxconn holding 20% each. Pepper robots will be used in various roles, including baby-sitting, medical work, and party companions.

images.alt_text: Japan's SoftBank Corp said on Thursday that it was setting up a joint venture with Alibaba and Foxconn Technology to sell its human-like robot Pepper to consumers around the world.

site_title: Changjiang Fertilizer's chairman resumes duties
summary: Changjiang Fertilizer Holdings Limited's chairman, Cai Jian Hua, has resumed his duties as chairman with immediate effect after a six-month leave of absence. The company had announced his leave on February 28 to "sort out personal matters," stating there would be no negative impact on performance. The acting chairman, Zhu Xue Cheng, will step down, and the company expresses gratitude for his temporary role.

site_title: Samsung to roll out updates to fix security risk on SwiftKey app
summary: Samsung will release an update to its Knox security software to address a vulnerability in the SwiftKey app, which affects over 600 million Samsung devices. The update will eliminate the risk of hackers accessing the devices, even if the app isn't being used as the default keyboard. The update will be available for download to all Galaxy models since the S4, but Samsung did not comment on plans for older models. The vulnerability was discovered by consultant NowSecure, which warned that devices could be spied on due to flaws in SwiftKey's update process.

site_title: Philippines budget swings to a surplus in April
summary: The Philippine government recorded a budget surplus of 52.6 billion pesos in April, largely due to annual tax payments. This is the first time the government posted a monthly budget surplus this year. The four-month total surplus is 19.1 billion pesos, compared to a 3.3 billion pesos shortfall in the same period last year. However, Manila faces pressure to accelerate expenditures due to slowed quarter-on-quarter growth.

site_title: Philippines allows foreign lenders to own local trust corporations
summary: The Bangko Sentral ng Pilipinas (BSP) has allowed foreign lenders to fully own local trust corporations, a move aimed at reducing risks and enabling better monitoring of trust entities. This change was made to separate bank and trust functions, and to enhance prudential standards and governance. The move is part of efforts to encourage banks to spin off their departments and allow market players to provide trust services. The decision was made by BSP Deputy Governor Nestor Espenilla, who stated that this would allow for better capital allocation and governance standards for the trust business.

site_title: Asia-Pacific's HNWI population overtook North America's in 2014
summary: The Asia-Pacific region surpassed North America as the largest number of high net worth individuals (HNWIs) in 2014, according to the World Wealth Report 2015. The region's HNWI population grew 8.5% to 4.69 million, while their wealth rose 11.4% to $15.82 trillion. This shift is driven by growth in China and India, with Singapore's HNWI ranks expanding 2.2% to 107,000. The report predicts Asia-Pacific will surpass North America on wealth terms by 2015.

site_title: Japan business mood signals pick-up in private consumption: poll
summary: Japan's business confidence has risen for the second consecutive month, with manufacturers and retailers showing optimism, according to a Reuters poll. This signals a potential pick-up in private consumption, which could support the country's economic recovery. The Reuters Tankan survey also suggests that the Bank of Japan's inflation target may be achievable, although analysts doubt it. The positive mood follows stronger-than-expected economic growth in the first quarter, driven by increased capital investment.

site_title: Airbnb said in talks to raise funds at US$24 billion valuation
summary: Airbnb is in talks to raise funds at a US$24 billion valuation, more than double its previous estimate of US$10 billion in 2014. The seven-year-old company projects 2015 revenue of US$900 million, up from US$250 million in 2013, and is raising US$1 billion in new capital. With a service available in 190 countries, Airbnb is expanding internationally and becoming one of the most valuable private companies in the world, behind Xiaomi Corp and Uber Technologies Inc.

images.alt_text: Home-sharing startup Airbnb Inc is in talks to raise financing at a valuation of US$24 billion, according to a person familiar with the matter.

site_title: Macroeconomist Lawrence Christiano named MAS Term Professor at NUS
summary: Macroeconomist Lawrence Christiano has been appointed as the MAS Term Professor in Economics and Finance at the National University of Singapore (NUS) and the Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS). Christiano, a renowned researcher in macroeconomic theory and policy, will engage senior policymakers and conduct research seminars at NUS. He will also advise PhD students on their research. The appointment aims to strengthen Singapore's financial and economic research infrastructure and contribute to a vibrant research community. Christiano is the 11th distinguished scholar to hold the MAS Term Professorship.

site_title: US foreclosure activity up in May as bank repossessions rise
summary: US foreclosure activity reached a 19-month high in May, with 126,868 homes in the foreclosure process, up 16% from the same time last year. Bank repossessions rose 1% from April, totaling 44,892 homes. Foreclosure starts were down 1% but rose 4% from last year. Florida led states with the highest foreclosure rates, followed by New Jersey, Maryland, Nevada, and Ohio. Despite stabilizing foreclosure starts, the number of homeowners losing their homes to foreclosure remains above pre-crisis levels and is on the rise.

site_title: South Korea parliament approves Park's pick for PM after scandal
summary: South Korea's parliament approved President Park Geun-hye's nominee for prime minister, Justice Minister Hwang Kyo-ahn, after the incumbent stepped down due to allegations of accepting illegal campaign funds. Hwang, a career prosecutor, aims to clean up corruption and promote reform. The move comes as Park's public support has dipped below 35% due to criticism over the government's response to a Middle East Respiratory Syndrome outbreak. Hwang is the third prime minister to serve under Park, who began a five-year term in 2013.

site_title: HSBC, Goldman, Barclays, BNP in talks to resolve forex suit
summary: HSBC, Goldman Sachs, Barclays, and BNP Paribas are in talks to settle a lawsuit alleging they manipulated foreign exchange rates. Investors claim the banks conspired to rig currency benchmarks, and their lawyer says serious discussions have taken place, with a possible settlement within 30 days. The case, filed in 2013, involves US antitrust law and involves a dozen banks, with billions of dollars in fines and criminal convictions already obtained. The banks have declined to comment on the talks, but a report suggests they may agree to settle the case.

site_title: China says to step up investment to support economy
summary: China's cabinet announced plans to increase investment in key sectors, including shantytown renovation, rural power infrastructure, and modern logistics, to support economic growth. The government aims to renovate 18 million urban and 10.6 million rural houses over three years and boost investment in infrastructure projects. This move comes as China's economic growth slowed to a six-year low in the first quarter, and the government seeks to step up policy stimulus to address downward pressure on the economy.

site_title: UOB partners SMU to offer programme for small business bankers
summary: United Overseas Bank (UOB) has partnered with the Singapore Management University (SMU) to launch the UOB-SMU Banker's Executive Certificate programme, designed for small business bankers. The two-year programme combines classroom-based study and practical skills training in areas such as credit and risk management, trade financing, and regional regulatory frameworks. The programme aims to equip bankers with specialist skills to manage foreign exchange risk and navigate regulatory landscapes in different markets. UOB expects to train 120 small business bankers by the end of the year, targeting companies with annual turnovers of S$20 million and below.

site_title: China May FDI rises 7.8% y-o-y
summary: China's foreign direct investment (FDI) rose 7.8% year-over-year to 57.4 billion yuan in May, exceeding the 10.5% growth seen in the first five months of the year. Non-financial outbound FDI increased 47.4% to 278.4 billion yuan during the same period. This growth suggests China's economy is continuing to attract foreign investment, despite concerns about slowing GDP growth.

site_title: Australia: Shares fall on Greece worries, fiscal-year book closing
summary: Australian shares fell 1.2% on Thursday, with the S&P/ASX 200 index dropping 70.43 points to 5,525, amid concerns over Greece and the Federal Reserve's lack of clarity on interest rate hikes. Analysts attributed the sell-off to investors closing their financial year books and re-evaluating market optimism. Key sector losers included financials, consumer staples, and major miners, with QBE, Westpac, and Woolworths leading the declines.

site_title: Singapore Air (SIA) plans to reclaim world's longest flight
summary: Singapore Airlines plans to develop a new plane with Airbus and Boeing to enable nonstop flights to the US, a goal to revive its discontinued 19-hour Singapore to New York route. The airline is exploring twin-engine options, such as the Airbus A350 and Boeing 777X, to increase efficiency and profitability. Reviving nonstop flights will help the carrier compete with Asia-Pacific rivals Cathay Pacific and Qantas, and fill a gap in its network.

images.alt_text: The airline is in talks with Airbus Group SE and Boeing Co on developing a plane with new technology that would allow it to fly nonstop to the US profitably, Singapore Air Chief Executive Officer Goh Choon Phong said.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open lower on Thursday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index fell 3.27 points to 1725.28 on Tuesday, with 32.4 million lots traded worth RM14 million. Gainers outnumbered losers 107 to 53.

site_title: Biggest Chinese SUV maker seen triggering wave of price cuts
summary: Chinese automaker Great Wall Motor Co has triggered a wave of price cuts on SUVs, with its H2 and H6 models now priced 5,000 and 6,000 yuan lower, respectively. This move has led to a 5-month low in Great Wall's Hong Kong stock. Analysts predict more local OEMs will follow, resulting in widespread price declines.

site_title: US to put woman on new US$10 bill
summary: The US Treasury announced plans to feature a woman on the US$10 bill, replacing Alexander Hamilton, starting from 2020. This marks the first time a woman will be on US paper currency in over a century. The Treasury will choose the woman through public suggestions, with the goal of honoring a champion for inclusive democracy. The change is expected to coincide with the 100th anniversary of women's suffrage.

site_title: URA releases residential site at West Coast Vale for sale
summary: The Urban Redevelopment Authority (URA) released a 18,908.7 sq m residential site at West Coast Vale for sale. The site, located along the waterfront of Sungei Pandan, can potentially yield about 595 residential units.
