The tender for the land parcel will close on Aug 4, 2015, with a maximum gross floor area of 52,945 sq m and a 99-year lease period.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks up 0.12% at open
summary: Hong Kong stocks rose 0.12% in early trading on June 18, 2015, after the Federal Reserve head suggested US interest rates would rise by year-end at a slow pace. The Hang Seng Index increased 32.74 points to 26,786.53.

site_title: Ringgit rallies as Fed rate signal eases pressure from lower oil
summary: Malaysia's ringgit rose by 0.7% to 3.7318 a dollar, its largest gain in six weeks, after the Federal Reserve signaled a gradual interest rate hike this year. The move alleviated pressure on the currency, which had declined amid falling oil prices. The ringgit's rise was attributed to technical adjustments, rather than the Fed's comments, according to a foreign-exchange strategist. The currency's gain trimmed the past month's loss to 4.4%.

site_title: Standard Chartered client chief said to exit as Winters starts
summary: Standard Chartered's global head of client coverage, Sean Wallace, is leaving the bank at the end of June, one of the first senior executives to depart since Bill Winters became CEO. This departure adds to the bank's senior management turnover since Peter Sands' announcement in February. Winters aims to reverse declining profits and rebuild investor confidence, while Wallace's exit is seen as part of a broader effort to rebuild the bank.

site_title: Brazil's Petrobras mulls sale of ethanol plants: sources
summary: Brazil's state-run oil company Petrobras is considering selling up to $13.7 billion of assets, including its ethanol plants, to raise cash for new investments and debt. The company aims to sell up to 9 ethanol plants and 5 biodiesel plants by the end of 2016. This move comes as Petrobras seeks to cut losses and increase profitability, with the company's debt reaching $125 billion. The sale of assets is part of Petrobras' efforts to diversify and adapt to changing market conditions.

images.alt_text: Brazilian state-run oil company Petrobras is looking to sell some of its biofuel assets as it tries to raise cash to cover investment for new offshore oilfields and service its debt, two sources told Reuters on Wednesday.

site_title: Competition Commission of Singapore halts Cordlife probe
summary: The Competition Commission of Singapore (CCS) has halted its investigation into Cordlife Group's exclusive agreements with baby fair organisers and hospitals, citing the company's voluntary commitments to not rely on these arrangements. Cordlife stated that the commitments will have no material impact on its finances and operations. The investigation was launched due to concerns over the potential limitation of competition.

site_title: AirAsia shares up nearly 6% after defending accounting practices
summary: AirAsia shares rose nearly 6% after the airline defended its accounting practices following a research firm's concerns. The stock had fallen 30% since June 10, but rebounded as the airline assured investors its practices were solid. The stock was trading at 1.6 ringgit, 4.6% higher than the previous day's close, against the 0.18% drop in the index.

site_title: Taiwan: Stocks up with overseas markets, smaller tech stocks seeing gains
summary: Taiwan's main TAIEX index rose 0.1% to 9,197.76 points, driven by investors seeking bargains in small-cap stocks amid upbeat overseas sentiment. The move follows a 0.3% decline on Wednesday. Markets in Taiwan will be closed on Friday for the Dragonboat Festival public holiday and will reopen on Monday.

site_title: Airline group backs off plan for smaller carry-ons
summary: The International Air Transport Association (IATA) has paused its plan to introduce a standard size carry-on bag, citing concerns from US lawmakers and airlines. The proposed size, 55cm tall, 35cm wide, and 20cm deep, was intended to end last-minute gate disputes over bag size. Airlines, including Delta, expressed concerns about the proposal without input from the industry. IATA will reassess the plan, which was meant to be a guideline, not an industry standard. The decision comes after intense interest from airlines and travelers.

site_title: Hong Kong democrats stick to their guns as reform vote looms
summary: Hundreds of Beijing supporters gathered outside Hong Kong government buildings as legislators resumed debate on a Beijing-backed electoral package, which would allow a direct vote but only pre-screened, pro-Beijing candidates. Pro-democracy legislators vowed to veto the package, calling it a "fake" democratic model, amidst weeks of protests that posed a challenge to China's ruling Communist Party. The US expressed support for universal suffrage, and authorities aim to avoid a repeat of last year's protests that brought the city to a standstill.

images.alt_text: Hundreds of Beijing supporters converged outside government buildings in Hong Kong on Thursday as city legislators prepared to resume debate on a Beijing-backed electoral package that will define the Chinese-controlled city's democratic future.

site_title: El Nino seen by Mistry boosting palm oil as users seek supplies
summary: El Nino is expected to boost palm oil prices due to dry weather and producers holding back sales, with futures in Kuala Lumpur rising 9% since May. Consumers in India and China are seeking supplies, with exports to these countries increasing. Malaysian exports to India almost quadrupled in May, while shipments to China climbed 37%. The Indian monsoon and El Nino's impact on crops and food inflation are concerns, but supply shows no signs of falling, and prices are likely to rise further if the weather problems develop.

site_title: China's 2 trillion yuan public projects lure skyscraper builder
summary: China's largest developer, Greenland Holding Group Co, is investing in public projects to help fund nearly $430 billion of infrastructure projects. The company has set up a 100 billion yuan subway fund and plans to create water treatment funds, with the goal of raising cash from individual investors. This move comes as the government seeks to replace public borrowings with private obligations to defend a 7% economic growth target. Other developers are considering building public-private partnerships (PPPs) funds, with property development along subway lines seen as a way to boost profitability.

site_title: US hedge fund steps up campaign against US$8b Samsung asset shake-up
summary: US hedge fund Elliott is intensifying its campaign against a proposed $8 billion Samsung merger, seeking corporate governance improvements rather than an unfair deal. Elliott has launched a website to detail its case and filed two injunction requests to block the merger. The fund, the third-largest shareholder in Samsung C&T Corp, wants the conglomerate to "properly recognise" the value of the company. Samsung C&T plans to proceed with the merger, saying it aims to maximize shareholder value.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open 0.13% lower following Fed decision
summary: Tokyo stocks opened 0.13% lower on Thursday ahead of the Bank of Japan's policy meeting, following the US Federal Reserve's decision to keep its interest rate unchanged. The benchmark Nikkei 225 index fell 25.68 points to 20,193.59. Chair Janet Yellen pledged a cautious approach, stating the Fed would likely raise interest rates "later this year" if economic growth sustains. The Bank of Japan's meeting on Friday is expected to determine its stimulus programme expansion.

site_title: Moody's says Mers outbreak credit negative for South Korea
summary: Moody's has downgraded South Korea's credit rating due to the impact of the Middle East Respiratory Syndrome (Mers) outbreak on consumer sentiment. The virus has weakened domestic demand and threatened economic growth, which could be undermined by policy stimulus measures. This decision is a credit negative for the sovereign, indicating that the economic effects of the outbreak could have long-term consequences. Moody's expressed concerns over the potential for dampened consumer confidence and weakened economic growth.

site_title: Oculus out to let people touch virtual worlds
summary: Oculus, a Facebook-owned company, has developed a prototype for virtual reality (VR) controllers called Oculus Touch, allowing users to interact with virtual objects in fantasy realms. The controllers, which can be gripped like pistols, were tested with the Oculus Rift VR headset, enabling users to play games such as ping pong and detonate fireworks. The goal is to create an immersive experience where users can interact with virtual objects naturally, even when physically apart. Oculus plans to release a market-ready version of the Rift headset early next year, with pricing and details to be disclosed later.

site_title: China home prices fall 5.7% year on year in May
summary: China's average new home prices fell 5.7% year on year in May, marking the ninth consecutive month of decline. This compares to a 6.1% drop in April. Shenzhen saw a rebound, with prices rising 7.5% from the previous month. Beijing and Shanghai also experienced declines, with prices falling 2.3% and 2.2% respectively. China's real estate investment growth slowed to the lowest since May 2009, with inventory levels remaining high in lower-tier cities, posing a risk to the economy's expected 25-year low growth.

site_title: Yellen says tentative signs of wage growth 'not yet definitive'
summary: Federal Reserve Chair Janet Yellen expressed cautious optimism about wage growth, citing a 2.8% rise in private-sector wages and a decline in unemployment to 5.5% in May. While these signs are "tentative," they suggest companies may be increasing pay to attract workers. Yellen emphasized the need for "additional strength" in the labor market to boost inflation confidence, but acknowledged progress has been made. The Fed aims to raise interest rates when labor market improvement and inflation expectations are solidified.

site_title: Singapore office property costly as new towers vie for tenants
summary: Singapore's office market is considered expensive due to a space glut and slowing rental growth, according to Union Investment. The fund manager, which has one office asset in Singapore, is increasing bets on central district offices in Australia and Japan. Union Investment's Asia-Pacific head of investment management, Eric Cheah, stated that while Singapore's assets are of high quality, their economic returns are less attractive at this point in time. This shift in focus highlights the challenges facing Singapore's office market.

site_title: Oil prices dip on US gasoline stock build
summary: Oil prices dropped on Thursday after US gasoline stocks and distillate inventories rose, contradicting analysts' expectations. US crude edged down 16 cents to $59.76 a barrel, while Brent crude fell 8 cents to $63.79 a barrel. The US Federal Reserve's potential delay in raising interest rates also contributed to the decline. Geopolitical tensions in the Middle East and economic data from China and Greece also influenced the market.

images.alt_text: Oil prices slipped on Thursday after US government data showed that gasoline stocks and distillate inventories rose last week, although falls were checked by continuing Middle East geopolitical tensions.

site_title: Logistics Holdings secures S$13.8m contract from JTC
summary: Logistics Holdings secured a S$13.8 million contract from JTC Corporation for addition and alteration works at Seletar Aerospace Park. The project involves six conserved buildings and infrastructure upgrades at Park Lane, The Oval, and Hyde Park Gate. This contract was secured by Logistics Construction, the wholly-owned subsidiary of Logistics Holdings.

images.alt_text: Mindy Tan

site_title: Hackers attack Canada government websites
summary: Hackers from the collective Anonymous disrupted Canadian government websites, including those for social services and Parliament, in protest of a controversial anti-terror law. The attack, which lasted several hours, did not compromise personal data. The law, Bill C-51, has been widely criticized for its potential to infringe on civil rights. In response to the attack, the government is increasing its cybersecurity resources and policies to address future threats.

site_title: Singapore: STI opens 0.18% lower on Thursday
summary: The Straits Times Index (STI) in Singapore opened 0.18% lower on Thursday, closing at 3,320.04, following the US Federal Reserve's decision to keep interest rates near zero. Despite this, the STI had a 5-day rally ahead of GDP data. Top gainers included Jardine Matheson Holdings, UOB, and ARA Asset Management. The total number of shares traded was 74.9 million worth S$63 million, with 73 gainers outnumbering 63 losers.

site_title: First Sponsor completes acquisition of 2 Amsterdam Holiday Inn hotels
summary: First Sponsor Group completed its acquisition of two Amsterdam Holiday Inn hotels, including a Holiday Inn and Holiday Inn Express, for 54.6 million euros (S$82.9 million). The acquisition was announced in April after the company posted a net profit of S$10.73 million in the first quarter of 2015, driven by growth in its property financing business.

site_title: Noble buys back 40m shares in fourth such move this month
summary: Noble Group, a commodities firm, executed its fourth share buyback this month, purchasing 39.74 million shares for S$28.43 million. The move aims to boost investor confidence, following a 41% decline in its shares since mid-February due to criticisms of its accounting practices.

images.alt_text: Commodities firm Noble Group has executed its fourth share buyback in a month, continuing its efforts to shore up confidence among investors.

site_title: South Korea reports 3 more deaths in Mers outbreak, 3 new cases
summary: South Korea's health ministry reported three more deaths in the country's Mers outbreak, bringing the total fatalities to 23. The total number of cases rose to 165, with three new cases confirmed.

site_title: Buy a flat, get a free Porsche as China developers rush to sell
summary: China's debt-ridden developers are offering luxury cars and discounts to lure buyers and clear unsold homes. The incentives come as the country's property market experiences a rebound in sales and prices. Despite the efforts, inventory remains high, and developers are prioritizing destocking. Generous incentives are being used to avoid outright discounts that could alienate previous buyers. The government's easing of property curbs has sparked a recovery, but sales gains are uncertain, and cash flows at developers are expected to improve slightly this year.

site_title: Stocks to watch: Noble, Frasers Centrepoint, SingPost, Logistics, First Sponsor, Cordlife, telcos
summary: Noble Group's CEO and former Temasek executive sparred over claims, with no resolution in sight. Frasers Centrepoint acquired Malmaison Hotel du Vin for £363.4 million. SingPost invested in Australian e-commerce firm Hubbed Holdings for A$4.3 million. Logistics Holdings secured a S$13.8 million contract. First Sponsor Group completed its hotel acquisition in Amsterdam for 54.6 million euros. Cordlife's exclusive agreements with baby fair organisers and hospitals were cleared by the Competition Commission of Singapore. Singapore's telcos will see service monetisation opportunities from the closure of 2G networks.

site_title: Fifa's Blatter hires US lawyer for corruption probe
summary: Fifa President Sepp Blatter has hired US lawyer Richard Cullen to represent him amid a corruption probe. Blatter, 79, announced his resignation four days after re-election on June 2, citing loss of mandate from the soccer world. The move comes as a corruption investigation rocks the global governing body. Cullen, chairman of law firm McGuireWoods and a former US federal prosecutor, will likely play a key role in defending Blatter against the allegations.

site_title: Wearable fitness tracker Fitbit IPO priced at US$20 per share
summary: Fitbit Inc, a wearable fitness tracker manufacturer, priced its initial public offering (IPO) at US$20 per share, valuing the company at US$4.1 billion. The offering raised US$731.5 million, exceeding its expected price range of US$17-19 per share. Fitbit's shares are expected to start trading on the New York Stock Exchange under the symbol "FIT".

site_title: UK pension pots should be app-friendly, real-time: survey
summary: A survey by Saxo Bank found that over two-thirds of affluent UK consumers want to manage their pension investments on their smartphones, with 50% seeking more transparency and 70% wanting real-time performance updates. Nearly 20% of respondents were unaware of their pension investments. The survey suggests a "digital wealth management revolution" is underway, with retail trading platforms set to play a significant role, potentially disrupting traditional banking services.

site_title: California ruling against Uber hits at business model
summary: A California state panel has ruled that an Uber driver is an employee, requiring the company to reimburse the driver for expenses. The ruling could have significant implications for Uber's business model, which relies on independent contractors. If the ruling applies globally, it could lead to hefty payments for social security and workers' compensation. Uber has appealed the decision and claims it only affects one driver, but the outcome could impact its operations worldwide.

site_title: New Zealand growth slows in March quarter
summary: New Zealand's economic growth slowed to a two-year low in the January-March quarter, with a 0.2% increase in gross domestic product (GDP). Annual growth was 3.2%, but the quarterly figure was the lowest since 2013 due to a 2.9% fall in primary industries. Lower oil and gas production, as well as dairy prices, contributed to the slowdown. The Reserve Bank of New Zealand may cut interest rates further due to the weaker-than-expected GDP data, which could strengthen the case for more rate cuts.

site_title: Uber says open to being regulated in massive Mexico City market
summary: Uber is open to regulation in Mexico City, a move aimed at addressing protests from taxi cab organizations over the company's presence. Uber entered Mexico City in 2013 and has grown to around 300,000 users. The city's government is holding round-tables to discuss regulating apps like Uber and Cabify, which claim to be private car services rather than taxis. This development comes as the ride-hailing service seeks to expand in one of the largest cities in the Americas.

site_title: Amazon sees line-of-sight hurdle to US drone parcel delivery
summary: Amazon is delaying its 30-minute Prime Air parcel delivery by drone in the US due to concerns over the Federal Aviation Administration's proposed regulations. The FAA's proposed rules require drones to fly only in full view of their operators on the ground, but Amazon disagrees, stating that flying beyond line of sight is not a major safety concern. Amazon plans to continue testing its technology in other countries, including Canada, until the US regulations are clarified. The FAA is expected to miss its September deadline for finalizing drone rules.

site_title: Surging home prices unlikely to fall on loan curbs: NAB
summary: National Australia Bank predicts that surging home prices in cities like Sydney won't be affected by loan curbs on investors. The lender attributes the market's struggle with undersupply and significant foreign demand for the surge. APRA's measures to reinforce sound lending standards, including higher mortgage risk weights and Basel IV rules, are unlikely to impact house prices. Experts consider the market a "bubble," but an unlikely surge in unemployment or interest rates are the main risks to the housing market.

site_title: Japan business mood signals pick-up in private consumption: Reuters Tankan
summary: Japan's business confidence rose for the second consecutive month in June, according to a Reuters poll, indicating a potential pick-up in private consumption. Retailers were at their most optimistic in over a year, following a stronger-than-expected economic growth in the first quarter. The Bank of Japan's view that the economic recovery will strengthen over the next year is supported by the positive business mood, although analysts doubt the central bank's 2% inflation target for fiscal 2016.

site_title: Russia's Sechin says US, not Opec, rules oil markets
summary: Russian energy minister Igor Sechin stated that the US, not OPEC, controls global oil markets, citing the US shale boom as a key factor. The US now accounts for 10% of global crude production, up from 6% in 2008. Sechin believes OPEC's influence has declined due to lower oil prices, which have halved since 2014. He forecasts volatility in the market but predicts a long-term rising trend in oil prices as companies' costs increase.

site_title: Global aid hits record in 2014 aided by Gulf states but fails to meet needs: data
summary: Global humanitarian aid reached a record $24.5 billion in 2014, with Gulf states contributing $1.6 billion, more than doubling their previous contributions. Despite the increase, aid fell short of needs in conflict zones, with only $4.8 billion of $18.8 billion needed received. The shortfall highlights the need for sustainable solutions to address underlying causes of crises, according to experts. Only a quarter of required funds had been received, leaving a $14 billion gap.

site_title: Citibank Malaysia chief executive sanguine about macrolandscape challenges
summary: Citibank Malaysia's CEO, Lee Lung Nien, is eight months into his post, and his future is uncertain. He has expressed loyalty to the bank, where he has worked since 1990, but hasn't ruled out a return to Singapore if another opportunity arises. Despite challenges in Malaysia's macro landscape, including a weakened ringgit and high household debt, Lee is confident in Citibank's ability to navigate the market, focusing on its mass affluent and top-tier corporate clients. The bank is hiring to expand its operations in Malaysia, which delivers retail and corporate banking services.

images.alt_text: Anita Gabriel

site_title: US: Stocks rise as Fed keeps rate unchanged
summary: US stocks rose on Wednesday as the Federal Reserve kept its benchmark interest rate unchanged, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average gaining 31.26 points (0.17%) and the S&P 500 advancing 4.15 (0.20%). Chair Janet Yellen pledged a methodical approach to raising rates, citing weak points in the economy and jobs market. The move was seen as "pretty dovish" by market strategist Brent Schutte, who noted that Yellen emphasized a slow and gradual pace of rate hikes.

site_title: Four banks pay US$1b to settle forex rigging suit: sources
summary: Four major banks, Goldman Sachs, BNP Paribas, Barclays, and HSBC, have agreed to settle a US civil lawsuit over alleged foreign-exchange rigging for nearly $1 billion. The settlements, totaling $990 million, come after Barclays will pay $375 million, HSBC $285 million, BNP Paribas nearly $100 million, and Goldman Sachs about $130 million. The banks have not admitted to the alleged rigging of the $5.3 trillion currency market, and the deal is subject to US authority approval.

site_title: Small and big car COE premiums fall
summary: COE premiums for small and big cars in Singapore have dropped significantly, with Category A premiums falling by S$5,000 to S$61,000 and Cat B premiums dropping by S$3,491 to S$71,509. Dealers were expecting a smaller drop, with some surprised by the magnitude of the decrease. The sales manager of a mid-sized Japanese dealership attributed the drop to mostly replacement buyers who are budget-conscious and will not overpay for their new cars. The COE supply is expected to increase by at least 10-20% in August.

images.alt_text: Premiums for small and big car certificates of entitlement (COEs) slumped the most in Wednesday's bidding exercise, amid falls across all five categories.

site_title: New US limits on six banks over mortgage problems
summary: US banking regulators imposed new limits on six banks, including JPMorgan Chase, Wells Fargo, and HSBC, for failing to fully implement a 2011 settlement on home foreclosure abuses. The Office of the Comptroller of the Currency (OCC) restricted their ability to buy mortgage servicing rights and appoint senior officials. The banks face additional enforcement actions, including possible fines, and have been mandated to upgrade their mortgage servicing operations since 2011. Over 3.2 million borrowers have received more than $2.7 billion in relief under the settlements.

images.alt_text: The group, which includes JPMorgan Chase, Wells Fargo, HSBC and Santander, faces new barriers in buying mortgage servicing rights from other companies and appointing senior mortgage service officials, among other restrictions, said the Office of the Comptroller of the Currency (OCC).

site_title: US oil prices dip on mixed inventory report
summary: US oil prices declined on Wednesday following a mixed US petroleum supply report. West Texas Intermediate fell 5 cents to $59.92 a barrel, while Brent oil rose 17 cents to $63.87 a barrel. US commercial oil stocks dropped 2.7 million barrels for the seventh straight decline, but crude supplies in Cushing, Oklahoma, increased by 100,000 barrels. Gasoline stocks rose by 500,000 barrels, surprising experts and leading to profit-taking. The report undermines the recent rally, particularly in the gasoline market, according to John Kilduff, a hedge fund partner.

site_title: DBS to test demand in Singapore's first covered bond programme
summary: DBS will launch its US$10 billion covered bond programme, the first of its kind in Singapore, starting June 22. The bonds will be sold to investors in Asia, Europe, and the US, with expected triple-A ratings. The programme is backed by mortgage loans in a unique and closely regulated property market. The global roadshow aims to test demand for high-grade debt from Singapore, marking a significant milestone for the country's financial sector.

site_title: Fed keeps rate unchanged; calls US growth 'moderate'
summary: The Federal Reserve maintained its benchmark interest rate at near zero, describing US economic growth as "moderate" despite a winter slowdown. The Fed trimmed its 2015 growth forecast to 1.8-2.0% and expects the economy to strengthen slowly, with a 2.4-2.7% pace next year. The unemployment rate is expected to drop to 5.2% by year-end and 4.9% in 2016. The Fed also noted that inflation remains low, largely due to transitory effects, and will continue to monitor inflation developments closely.

images.alt_text: The Federal Reserve left its benchmark interest rate unchanged at near zero on Wednesday, while describing US economic growth as "moderate" after the winter slowdown.

site_title: India exporters hoping for Yellen's guidance
summary: India's overseas sales are declining, with a 20% drop in May, the longest monthly losing streak since 2009. The decline is attributed to falling oil prices and weak demand in developed economies. Indian exporters are closely watching Federal Reserve Chair Janet Yellen's guidance, hoping for insight on how to navigate the challenging global market.

site_title: Arts district catches on in slow-paced US city
summary: The Starland District in Savannah, Georgia, a slow-paced US city, is finally gaining momentum after nearly two decades. Originally envisioned in 1998 by two local art graduates, the district features art studios, small offices, galleries, cafes, and retail shops around Bull Street. After years of development, the area is starting to attract attention and investment, potentially transforming the city's arts scene.

site_title: Twitter buys artificial intelligence group Whetlab
summary: Twitter acquired artificial intelligence startup Whetlab, bolstering its analytics capacity. The deal was announced without disclosing terms. Whetlab's technology can help Twitter determine relevant tweets and advertising messages for users, or filter out spam. The acquisition comes as Twitter searches for a new CEO after Dick Costolo's departure. With 300 million active users, Twitter aims to improve its internal machine learning efforts with Whetlab's technology, which was developed to make machine learning better and faster for companies.

site_title: Noble CEO issues open letter to refute claims
summary: Noble Group CEO Yusuf Alireza has issued an open letter to refute claims made by former Temasek Holdings executive Michael Dee, criticizing Noble's valuation of Yancoal Australia and inventory repurchase agreements. Alireza argues that Noble must rely on a cash-flow model, citing the company's low liquidity and market pressure on coal prices. Critics, however, remain skeptical, pointing to a significant disparity between Yancoal's market value and Noble's carrying value, and calling for more transparency on Noble's accounting practices. Despite Noble's aggressive share buybacks, the company's shares continue to plummet, with Goldman Sachs downgrading Noble from a "buy" to a "neutral" and slashing its target price.

site_title: Uber, rivals offer China commuters free rides in fight for market share
summary: Uber and its Chinese rival Didi Kuaidi are offering free rides to commuters in Beijing to gain market share. The move comes as cheaper and cleaner chauffeured cars have become increasingly popular, with 41-year-old user Jessica Yang switching from taxis to ride-hailing services. The competition between Uber and Didi Kuaidi is intensifying as the two companies try to win over customers in the Chinese market.

site_title: Boeing's US$15b haul widens its lead over Airbus
summary: Boeing secured a $15 billion deal at the Paris Air Show, widening its lead over Airbus. The US company received 100-jet orders for its 737 Max, including a 40-plane agreement with Korean Air Lines and SMBC Aviation Capital. This surpassed Airbus's single-aisle sales, with Boeing's list value at $33.5 billion and Airbus's at $16.4 billion. Boeing's commercial aircraft unit head Ray Conner described the day as a "big highlight" of the show, while analyst Cai von Rumohr praised Boeing's announcements, citing commercial demand and sales of the C-17 military transport.

site_title: Thailand expects dual-track railway to be ready by 2020
summary: Thailand expects a dual-track railway project to be completed by 2020, boosting economic growth. The project aims to strengthen infrastructure and ease logistics costs, which are crucial for the country's trade-dependent economy. Deputy Prime Minister Pridiyathorn Devakula forecasts an annual growth rate of 5-6 percent once the project is completed, despite the current economic growth forecast of 3-4 percent for this year. The 2,470 km railway project will help reduce the country's reliance on road transport, accounting for 75 percent of logistics.

site_title: Crisis deepens as Greek central bank warns of euro exit
summary: Greece's central bank has warned that the country could suffer a "painful" exit from the eurozone and EU if it fails to reach a bailout deal with international creditors. A deadlock remains over the release of $10.9 billion in rescue funds, with a meeting of eurozone finance ministers set to take place on Thursday. US Federal Reserve Chair Janet Yellen has warned of significant global economic turmoil if Greece and its creditors fail to reach an agreement, while Greek Prime Minister Alexis Tsipras has accused EU leaders of trying to "humiliate" his country with demands for pension cuts.

site_title: Europe car sales rise at slowest pace in 6 months
summary: European car sales rose 1.4% to 1.15 million vehicles in May, the slowest pace in six months, due to concerns over unemployment and the Greek sovereign debt crisis. This pared the gain in the first five months of the year to 6.7%. Despite this, some markets, such as Spain and Italy, saw increases in registrations. Renault was the only major manufacturer to post group sales growth, with a 5.4% gain, while Daimler AG and BMW AG also reported increases.

site_title: EU to extend sanctions on Russia by six months
summary: The European Union has agreed to extend economic sanctions on Russia by six months until January 31, 2026, maintaining unity in the West's stance towards Moscow. The decision, made by EU ambassadors in Brussels, comes amid renewed fighting in eastern Ukraine and amid recriminations between Russia and the West. The sanctions, originally imposed in 2014, target Russia's energy, defense, and financial sectors. The extension maintains Western unity despite reservations from some EU members, with US officials urging EU leaders to maintain sanctions.

site_title: Water plants aim to be self-sufficient in energy
summary: Singapore's water-reclamation plants aim to become self-sufficient in energy by utilizing food waste and used-water sludge to generate biogas, reducing reliance on external energy sources. A new demonstration plant, set to be completed by September, will test the efficiency of this process, which could increase energy production by up to 70% and reduce the carbon footprint of the plants. The technology, developed by Anaergia, will be scaled up in future plants, including the Tuas Water Reclamation Plant and the National Environment Agency's Integrated Waste Management Facility, set to open in 2024.

site_title: Outlook still tepid for Singapore growth
summary: Singapore's economy is expected to grow at a conservative 2-2.9% this year, with uncertainty over the US and China's growth and global monetary policy moves. The country's manufacturing sector is forecast to shrink 0.3% in Q2, with weak trade conditions and a slowdown in China's economy. Despite this, the construction sector is expected to grow 3.3% and the finance and insurance sector 7% this year. Inflation is expected to remain at 0% for 2015, with core inflation at 1%.

images.alt_text: The Singapore economy may have performed better than expected in Q1, but a rocky start to the second quarter and uncertainty over the US and China's growth and global central banks' moves have kept expectations for full-year growth conservative.

site_title: Cameron suffers 1st party rebellion since re-election
summary: British Prime Minister David Cameron suffered his first parliamentary rebellion since re-election as he attempted to unite his party on Europe by making concessions on the timing and rules of a planned EU membership referendum. Cameron promised not to hold the vote on May 5, a date opposed by Eurosceptic lawmakers, and partially agreed to their demands to limit government influence during the final four weeks of the campaign. The move shows the challenge Cameron faces in keeping his party united on the issue that helped topple his predecessors.

site_title: US refiners profit as petrol sales surprise even analysts
summary: US refiners are experiencing record profits as petrol sales exceed expectations, despite abundant oil supplies. The Energy Information Administration forecasted 8.71 million barrels of petrol per day, but Americans used 100,000 more than that in the first quarter. Petrol prices have risen 17% to $2.804 a gallon, and refineries are running at nearly 95% capacity. The shale drilling boom has made refining cheaper, and refiners are delaying shutdowns and repairs until next year to maximize profits, with refining margins averaging $15.53 per barrel.

site_title: Bird flu sends US egg prices up, but weak demand prevents shortage
summary: US egg prices rose significantly due to the avian flu outbreak, which affected 47 million chickens and turkeys, but are now reversing due to buyer resistance and limited demand. Wholesale egg prices peaked at $2.49 a dozen in May but declined 13.25% to $2.16 by June 16. The USDA predicts a 4% decline in egg production this year, with prices potentially reaching record highs. Restaurants and food companies, which rely on eggs for various products, drove up prices initially, but now face challenges in maintaining higher prices due to intense competition.

images.alt_text: The USDA predicts that egg production this year will be down by roughly 341 million dozen, or about 4 per cent from last year.

site_title: Singapore consumers more satisfied with retail, infocomm sectors
summary: Singapore consumers reported higher satisfaction in the retail and infocomm sectors in the first quarter of 2015, with retail scores increasing by 0.5% and infocomm by 0.9%. The motor vehicles subsector and petrol service stations subsector saw the largest improvements, rising by 3.1% and 2.1% respectively. These increases brought retail scores to 70 points and infocomm scores to 67.4 points.

images.alt_text: Customer satisfaction for the retail and infocomm sectors in Singapore edged up in the first quarter of 2015, results from the Customer Satisfaction Index of Singapore (CSISG) unveiled on Wednesday showed.

site_title: US per capita income will be double China's even in 2061: study
summary: A study by the Federal Reserve Bank of Minneapolis predicts that by 2061, US per capita income will be double China's, despite China's income growth rate expected to be two to three times faster. China's per capita GDP is projected to reach $15,400, while the US will have a per capita GDP of around $31,200. The study aims to assess potential economic ramifications for the US in the event of an economic shock in China, as the nation undergoes a transformation to a more consumer-driven economy.

site_title: Properties in London, Paris, Tokyo a draw for Taiwan life insurers: CBRE
summary: Taiwanese life insurers are seeking higher returns by investing in international properties, particularly in London, Paris, and Tokyo. Commercial properties in these cities yield 4-5% annually, compared to 2.5% in Taipei. The island's insurance companies aim to increase their real estate assets by $9 billion in four years, driven by low interest rates and excess savings. The central bank may not raise interest rates until mid-2016, supporting the growth of global property demand.

site_title: Candidate Hillary's volte-face on TPP
summary: Hillary Clinton has shifted her stance on the Trans-Pacific Partnership (TPP) free trade agreement, embracing a "fair trade" approach after initially supporting it as Secretary of State. This move comes as the Democratic Party has moved towards a left-wing and populist direction, with Clinton's husband's centrist policies seen as too close to Wall Street. Clinton now opposes granting trade promotion authority and suggests that the TPP should be renegotiated to address concerns about its impact on American workers. This shift in her position is seen as a response to the growing influence of progressive Democrats and left-wing activists in the party.

site_title: Pinched pensions limit chances of demand-led recovery in Japan
summary: Japan's pensioners are limiting the chances of a demand-led recovery due to their reluctance to spend their cash. Household spending by pensioners, who make up 38% of all households, fell 1.5% last fiscal year, keeping overall household spending flat. Rising retirees and stagnant pensions, which have fallen for six years, are restricting private consumption growth. Economists predict that income gains among working generations will offset the negative impact, but policymakers must find ways to boost incomes for the elderly beyond pensions.

site_title: India's Maggi noodles saga raises awareness about fast food hygiene
summary: A government lab in Uttar Pradesh, India, found Maggi noodles had high levels of lead and flavoring agent mono sodium glutamate, sparking a national controversy. The Food Safety and Standards Authority of India deemed the product unsafe, citing risks of brain damage, paralysis, and other health issues. The incident has raised awareness about fast food hygiene and highlighted the need for stricter regulation. The government must balance the concerns of street food vendors, who provide affordable and nutritious food, with the need to ensure food safety.

site_title: NorthStar acquiring Frankfurt skyscraper from US owners
summary: NorthStar Realty Finance Corp acquired the Trianon office tower in Frankfurt for 540 million euros from Madison International Realty LLC and a Morgan Stanley fund. The 2007 purchase price was 620 million euros, with Madison buying a 57% stake in 2012. The building has tenants including Deka Gruppe, Linklaters LLP, and the Bundesbank. NorthStar expects an 8% initial current yield, increasing its European property portfolio value to approximately $2.6 billion.

site_title: Alstria Reit takes over German rival
summary: Alstria Office Reit, a German real estate investment trust, has acquired Deutsche Office in a deal valued at approximately 800 million euros (S$1.2 billion). Majority shareholder Oaktree Capital Group accepted the bid, which offered 0.381 of a new bearer share for each Deutsche Office share, representing a 12% premium over the company's closing share price. The acquisition aims to strengthen Alstria's market position in the German office sector.

site_title: Australia, China sign landmark trade agreement
summary: Australia and China signed a landmark trade deal on June 17, 2015, abolishing tariffs in various sectors and providing a boon for growth and jobs. The deal includes penalties on goods, lifting duties on agricultural exports and removing existing tariffs on Chinese electronics. China won concessions on foreign investment, while Australia will remove tariffs on Chinese goods. The agreement aims to underpin Australia's prosperity for years to come, with estimated billions of dollars in economic benefits and thousands of jobs created.

site_title: Dairy prices hit six-year low on slump in demand
summary: Dairy prices have hit a six-year low due to a slump in demand from major importers like China, causing the GlobalDairyTrade (GDT) price index to fall 1.3% and reach its weakest since 2009. The benchmark price is now at US$2,409 per tonne, down from its peak in 2014. Total volumes sold have continued to fall, with economists predicting prices may recover later in the year as Chinese processors return to the market, but analysts warn that the volume of milk powder on offer will increase, limiting further price recovery.

site_title: Dates are a unifying staple during Ramadan
summary: During Ramadan, Muslims worldwide unite through the common food of dates, an ancient and culturally significant symbol of hospitality and rest in the Middle East. Traditionally, women cook and stockpile dates for the iftar meal after sunset, while children do not fast. Dates are a staple due to their high nutritional value, providing a quick energy boost. With thousands of variations available, dates are often mentioned in the Quran and other ancient texts. As Ramadan begins on June 17, many Muslims seek out dates from their ancestors' home countries, highlighting the cultural significance of this food during the holy month.

site_title: US Fed interest rate hikes may flummox newbies and old hands alike
summary: The US Federal Reserve is set to raise interest rates, which may disrupt financial markets. Years of low interest rates have distorted asset prices, making them less responsive to monetary tightening. Investors in bonds and equities may be less affected than in the past, as they have sought higher returns in riskier assets. Higher volatility and reduced investor confidence could lead to market lurches, making it challenging for experienced traders and banks to navigate. The Fed's rate hike may also impact credit markets and default rates, potentially leading to a higher risk premium for benchmark bonds.

site_title: China mixes up crowdfunding and groupthink
summary: China has incorporated crowdfunding into its financial system, blending it with groupthink. The country's Web users can invest in startups, with equity investment being the most popular form. Despite regulation, including a minimum income requirement and restrictions on guaranteed returns, the market has grown rapidly. However, concerns arise from the lack of accountability when companies fail, and the blurring of lines between legitimate crowdfunding and mass-market wealth management products. The World Bank predicts China could account for half of the developing world's crowdfunding by 2015, estimated at US$50 billion.

site_title: Longest glut in 30 years looms as Opec keeps pumping
summary: The world is on the brink of its longest-lasting oil glut in at least three decades, with oil supply exceeding demand for the past five quarters. Opec's continued pumping at current rates would result in the longest surplus since at least 1985 by the third quarter. This glut is attributed to Opec's quest for market share, and experts warn that it could become a persistent issue if left unchecked.

site_title: Blackstone hires CIO for its property-debt unit
summary: Blackstone, the largest real estate private equity firm, has hired Jonathan Pollack as chief investment officer of its property-debt unit, overseeing nearly $10 billion in investor capital. Pollack, who previously led Deutsche Bank's commercial real estate group, will report to Michael Nash. The move expands Blackstone's real estate executive ranks as the company grows its property business. Pollack's expertise will help Blackstone navigate the global debt market, which is expected to continue growing as banks cut back on real estate investments.

site_title: Bank of China joins London's gold price setting system
summary: Bank of China has joined London's gold price setting system, increasing the link between China and global markets. The move, facilitated by the London Bullion Market Association, will see Bank of China participate in the twice-daily auction system for pricing gold, alongside lenders such as Goldman Sachs and Barclays. This marks the first time a Chinese bank has participated in the system, further solidifying China's growing influence in the global financial system and the $20 billion gold market.

site_title: STI breaks slide ahead of Fed report
summary: Singapore stocks ended a two-day slide with a slight gain ahead of the US Federal Reserve's overnight policy statement, with the Straits Times Index adding 0.8% to close at 3,325.91. Analysts attribute the market's optimism to a "dovish slant" from Janet Yellen, anticipating a potentially market-friendly tone from the Fed. Banks rose, with DBS, OCBC, and UOB gaining between 0.8% and 1.4%, while Noble Group slipped due to a downgrade from Goldman Sachs.

site_title: US$ up on prospect of September rate rise
summary: The US dollar rose against the yen and Antipodean currencies as investors awaited a Federal Reserve statement potentially signaling a September interest rate hike for the first time in nearly a decade. The Swiss franc also rallied, driven by concerns over Greece's debt crisis. Investors expect the Fed to hint at rate increases later this year, citing a surge in US housing permits. The Kiwi and Australian dollars fell, while the Swiss franc reached a two-week high against the euro.

site_title: China net capital inflows hit US$20b in first 5 months
summary: China saw net foreign capital inflows of US$20 billion in the first five months of 2015, suggesting stabilization in a leakage of funds that had been a concern for the central bank. This reverses eight months of net sales and follows the central bank's efforts to boost liquidity. The inflows are seen as a positive sign for the Chinese economy, but may be short-lived due to a slowing economy and investors' concerns about the nation's corruption crackdown.

site_title: Russian firms switching to local software
summary: Russian companies are increasingly buying local software to avoid international sanctions, posing a challenge to major US firms like Microsoft and Oracle in Russia's $3 billion local market. OAO Sberbank and OAO Gazprom have started using local software, with the government aiming to cut foreign program reliance to less than 50% by 2025. This trend may boost local developers, including Kaspersky Lab and 1C Co, but foreign suppliers may still find ways to comply with new rules, such as SAP's exploration of local partnerships.

site_title: Tackling the new threat of hackers and cyber-terrorists
summary: Hackers and cyber-terrorists pose an evolving threat to airlines, with experts warning of vulnerabilities in airline computer systems, including the potential for drones to be used to disrupt flights. While hacking a plane is considered nearly impossible, companies like Airbus and Boeing take the risks seriously. New threats include drones sending confusing signals to aircraft and employees uploading malware to systems. A joint cybersecurity organization is proposed to address the issue, which affects not only airlines but also the entire aeronautic industry.

site_title: EU unveils rules to make firms pay their fair share of taxes
summary: The European Commission has unveiled a new tax action plan to make companies pay their "fair share" of taxes by aligning tax rules and increasing disclosure requirements across the 28-nation EU. The plan includes proposals for an EU-wide common corporate tax base, country-by-country tax reporting, and limits on preferential tax regimes. The EU has also released a list of 30 non-cooperative jurisdictions, including Hong Kong, Monaco, and the Bahamas, and is seeking unanimous approval from all 28 nations for the proposals to take effect.

site_title: Google's new secret weapon in cloud technology
summary: Google is unveiling its cloud computing capabilities, competing with Amazon and Microsoft, by revealing more information about its users and computing resources. The company's ultrafast fibre network, big data resources, and custom-built computers and software enable lightning-fast data processing. Google has partnered with HTC to build a new computing architecture for smartphone apps, and a senior executive will discuss the overall network design, including key tools for large-scale management. This move aims to position Google as a capable and cutting-edge cloud provider, capable of handling big data and complex tasks.

site_title: In return to Twitter, Dorsey aims to follow path of Jobs
summary: Twitter's interim CEO Jack Dorsey is being reappointed, following the precedent set by Steve Jobs, who was also brought back to Apple after being ousted by his board. Dorsey was previously Twitter's CEO from 2006 to 2008 and returned in 2015 after the company's board sought to replace him. The move aims to stabilize the company following recent layoffs and service issues.

images.alt_text: Mr Dorsey sits on the board of the Walt Disney Co and has helped lead the success of Square, estimated to be worth billions.

site_title: China broker to raise US$4.8b in the country's biggest IPO since 2010
summary: China's largest brokerage, Guotai Junan Securities Co, is raising $4.8 billion in the nation's biggest domestic IPO since 2010. The brokerage will sell shares at 19.71 yuan each, giving it a market capitalization of $32.6 billion. The IPO, which will finance margin trading, brings Chinese securities firms' total fundraising to a record $12.4 billion this year, with analysts warning the market may be nearing a peak due to the rapid expansion of brokerages.

site_title: Americans starting to worry about climate change . . . again
summary: Americans are increasingly worried about climate change, with 69% of adults now considering it a "very serious" or "somewhat serious" problem, up from 63% in 2010. This concern has not returned to its peak in 2006, when 79% of adults considered global warming serious. The increase in concern may be linked to the financial crisis and the Democrats' climate legislation attempts in 2009 and 2010, which may have reduced anxiety levels at the time.

site_title: China New Town and partners setting up 10 billion yuan fund
summary: China New Town Development Company, along with partners Bank of Communications Schroder Fund Management and China Development Bank Capital Corp, is setting up a 10 billion yuan (S$2.2 billion) fund to invest in quality urbanisation projects in China, focusing on old town reformation, shanty town reformation, and municipal facilities. The partnership aims to leverage China's national policy on urbanisation as an engine of economic growth, with a focus on fixed-income investments and a 8-year investment period.

images.alt_text: Nisha Ramchandani

site_title: Swiss prosecutors looking into 53 'suspicious' Fifa cases
summary: Swiss prosecutors are investigating 53 "suspicious" FIFA cases related to the 2018 and 2022 World Cup bids, including money laundering. The probe, led by Attorney General Michael Lauber, involves individuals and companies, with nine terrabytes of data seized. FIFA officials, including President Joseph Blatter and General Secretary Jerome Valcke, may be questioned. The investigation, one of two major fraud inquiries, comes as the US has charged 14 people in a separate bribery investigation, affecting the 2018 World Cup in Russia and the 2022 World Cup in Qatar.

site_title: FDA gives food sector 3 years to ditch trans fats
summary: The FDA has given the food industry three years to eliminate artery-clogging trans fats from the food supply, a move expected to save thousands of lives annually. The agency has ruled that partially hydrogenated oils, the source of trans fats, are no longer considered safe for consumption. Trans fats have already been substantially reduced in foods, but still remain in many popular products. The FDA estimates that banning trans fats could prevent 20,000 heart attacks and 7,000 deaths each year.

site_title: Value chain move-up spells trouble for world's factory
summary: China's low-end manufacturing sector, which accounts for 40% of the country's manufacturing GDP, is facing significant challenges due to government policies aimed at promoting high-tech industries. Factory owners, such as Wu Zongjun, are struggling with high labor costs, interest rates, and shrinking profit margins, leading to job losses and economic instability. The government's "Made in China 2025" program, which aims to upgrade the country's manufacturing capabilities, has instead accelerated the decline of low-end manufacturers, posing a major conundrum for China's economic recovery.

site_title: AirAsia shares slide on investor concerns
summary: AirAsia shares slid 13% on June 17, 2015, amid investor concerns over the airline's accounting practices. CEO Tony Fernandes downplayed the need for recapitalization, citing cash-raising opportunities from fleet and investments. Despite this, shares have dropped nearly 30% to five-year lows since a report questioned the airline's accounting methods. Fernandes had previously announced plans to raise US$300 million from associates in Indonesia and the Philippines.

site_title: Beijing allows broader ownership at Bank of Communications
summary: China's Cabinet has approved Bank of Communications' plan to introduce more private shareholding as part of Beijing's financial reforms to revitalise state-owned banks. The move aims to drive growth by bringing on board commercially adept strategic investors and incentivising employees through stock ownership plans. The reform won't weaken central government control, and shares in the bank trade publicly, with state-owned institutions remaining the largest shareholders. This follows a two-year overhaul of state-owned enterprises and comes amid China's top banks facing a cooling economy and rising bad loans.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: Geo Energy Resources' subsidiary PT Sungai Danau Jaya signed a memorandum of understanding with PT Bukit Makmur Mandiri Utama (Buma) for coal-mining services. Buma will provide services such as overburden removal and coal hauling for SDJ's 235.5-hectare mining area in South Kalimantan. This agreement aims to improve SDJ's mining operations. Separately, Ezion Holdings announced that a lawsuit filed by Atlantic Marine Services BV against it has been withdrawn, and the two companies will cooperate on a common client in the North Sea.

site_title: Emerging market investors favour Asian bonds
summary: Emerging market investors favor Asian bonds due to their higher quality and attractive yields, which remain stable despite global market volatility. Asian countries such as China, Japan, and India are pursuing reforms, providing long-term growth potential. Asian bonds have been the most resilient within emerging markets, with yields rising 46 basis points since January. Investors see Asian bonds as an attractive option for buying during major corrections, citing macroeconomic stability and room for monetary easing.

site_title: Frasers Hospitality in £363m hotel acquisition
summary: Frasers Hospitality, the hospitality arm of Frasers Centrepoint Limited, has acquired Malmaison Hotel du Vin (MHDV) for £363.4 million from an affiliate of KSL Capital Partners LLC. This acquisition doubles Frasers Hospitality's hotel offerings in Europe to over 4,000 keys in 34 cities, and marks a significant expansion of its portfolio to 129 properties with over 21,100 keys globally. The acquisition is expected to enhance Frasers Hospitality's platform and management expertise in Europe, and is part of its strategy to achieve 30,000 keys globally by 2019.

site_title: Heterogeneity stands in the way of eurozone consensus
summary: The eurozone faces challenges due to heterogeneity among its member countries, hindering consensus on key issues like Greece's debt relief. The European Central Bank's (ECB) bond purchase program aims to restore 2% inflation, but interest rate spreads persist between government bonds. Different countries experience economic effects at varying speeds, and the ECB's quantitative easing (QE) may not achieve its goal uniformly across the euro area. Heterogeneity is a persistent issue, making it difficult for the eurozone to achieve a unified economic recovery.

site_title: Murdoch passes the baton to sons at Fox group
summary: Rupert Murdoch is passing the leadership of 21st Century Fox to his sons, James Murdoch, 42, and Lachlan Murdoch, 43, who will become CEO and executive co-chairman, respectively. The transition is part of a long-planned succession plan, with James Murdoch succeeding his father as CEO and Lachlan taking on co-leadership. Rupert Murdoch, 84, will remain executive co-chairman, with Chase Carey stepping down as COO and Roger Ailes reporting to the new leadership. The Murdochs retain control through a dual-class stock structure, with the family trust owning about 40% of the voting shares.

site_title: UOB sets up new renminbi solutions unit
summary: UOB establishes a new renminbi solutions unit to assist companies in managing their yuan cross-border business, amid the currency's internationalisation. The unit, led by senior executives, will provide advice on policy and regulatory changes and financial solutions in areas such as cash management, foreign exchange, and hedging. The move comes as the yuan becomes increasingly used in global trade, with Singapore emerging as a key offshore yuan trading hub. The unit's launch reflects the growing importance of renminbi financial solutions as China's economic influence expands.

site_title: Slowdown in China, US weighs on Japan exports
summary: Japan's export growth slowed for a second month in May, with exports growing 2.4% year-on-year, less than expected. Weak external demand, particularly from China, threatens to erode economic growth in the current quarter. The Bank of Japan is expected to keep its monetary stimulus programme unchanged, citing a slowdown in China and stalling momentum. Shipments to Asia rose 3.3% and to the US grew 7.4%, but imports fell 8.7%, leading to a trade deficit. This slowdown in exports is a concern for Japan's economy, which relies heavily on export growth.

site_title: McDonald's advertises US$2.50 summer deals to revive sales
summary: McDonald's is offering a double cheeseburger and fries for US$2.50 through the summer, aiming to revive sales in a competitive fast-food market. This promotion is one of the first nationally advertised specials since Steve Easterbrook became CEO in March. Some locations are also offering a "Summer Break Menu" with similar deals.

site_title: UK watchdog defends hefty fines on banks that break rules
summary: The UK's Financial Conduct Authority (FCA) has defended hefty fines on banks that break rules, stating that record penalties have not undermined financial stability or lender solvency. Acting director of enforcement Georgina Philippou said fines are related to profits from misconduct and are a long way from damaging the industry. Philippou emphasized the need for international cooperation in levying fines to avoid weakening the banking system. The FCA is exploring changes to its handling of misconduct cases and is pushing for strong punishments and information-sharing among regulators.

site_title: Pay growth revives hopes that UK is casting off crisis hangover
summary: The UK's pay growth accelerated in the three months to April, with wages rising at their fastest rate in nearly four years. This has revived hopes that the Bank of England will finally raise interest rates, putting investor attention back on the prospect. The recovery in living standards seems to be gaining momentum, suggesting a potential end to the UK's crisis hangover.

site_title: Iata clarifies carry-on guide following objections
summary: The International Air Transport Association (Iata) clarified its carry-on luggage guideline, stating it's not a maximum size but an "optimum" 21.5x13.5x7.5 inches. Airlines can set their own higher limits, and approved bags with a "Cabin OK" logo will get priority on full flights. The proposal aims to address the issue of scarce overhead bin space and frequent gate-checking. Airlines have expressed reluctance to adopt the new size, with US carriers showing no plans to change their limits.

site_title: Keeping Mers at bay - and the outbreak in perspective
summary: South Korea has reported 162 Mers cases and 20 deaths, with over 6,500 people in quarantine, following the first confirmed case in the country in May. The outbreak's rapid expansion is attributed to initial mismanagement, including a lack of knowledge about the virus and inadequate quarantine measures. The World Health Organization has described the outbreak as "large and complex." With tourist arrivals falling 25% and estimated losses of $900 million in tourism revenue, South Korea is working to reassure visitors and contain the disease.

site_title: Transformation is the key, says Nintendo
summary: Nintendo emphasizes transformation as key to its longevity, according to Nintendo of America president Reggie Fils-Aime. This was stated during a presentation at the Electronic Entertainment Expo (E3) in Los Angeles. Fils-Aime believes transformation is the secret to maintaining successful Nintendo franchises.

site_title: Sellers of homes renege on transactions, banking on further hikes in prices
summary: In China's Shenzhen, home sellers are renegeing on sales contracts, anticipating further price surges. The city's property market is expected to post a second consecutive annual rise in May, driven by scarce land supply, favorable policies, and a stock market rally. Prices are up 40% from the first batch launched last year, with a forecast of 2.89% increase in May. The market's rapid growth has raised concerns of overheating, with a wealth effect from the stock market boom contributing to the surge.

images.alt_text: Shenzhen was the first China city to see a rebound in housing prices in April, reversing a six-month slide.

site_title: Statoil, Newfoundland near deal on offshore drilling
summary: Statoil is close to a deal with Newfoundland and Labrador to develop the 600 million-barrel Bay du Nord oil discovery off Canada's Atlantic coast. Premier Paul Davis said the province is optimistic about reaching terms, with production expected to begin in the next decade. If approved, it could be Canada's fifth offshore oil project and reverse years of production declines. The deal comes after Statoil postponed development of its Corner oil sands project in Alberta due to rising costs and limited pipeline space.

site_title: New misadventures in independence
summary: Singaporean corporate governance is still plagued by issues of director independence, with long-serving directors often being redesignated as independent despite serving non-independent roles for years. The 2012 Code of Corporate Governance introduced stricter guidelines, but its implementation has been lacking, with many companies failing to conduct rigorous reviews of director independence. The lack of clear guidance on what constitutes a "particularly rigorous review" and the absence of a clear definition of "material services" have contributed to the problem. Furthermore, the current system allows non-controlling shareholders to have limited say in the nomination and election of directors, hindering efforts to achieve true independence.

site_title: Starwood to list timeshare unit on NYSE
summary: Starwood Hotels & Resorts Worldwide Inc plans to list its timeshare unit, Vistana Signature Experiences Inc, on the New York Stock Exchange by the end of 2015 under the ticker VSE. The new company includes 19 vacation ownership resorts and three other properties, with Starwood adding more hotel inventory as part of the transaction. This move is part of the company's asset-light strategy, aiming to focus on property management and franchising.

site_title: Top banker Nazir Razak denies plans to set up political party
summary: Malaysia's top banker, Nazir Razak, has denied plans to set up a new non-partisan political party, despite reports suggesting he was secretly meeting with business leaders to form the party. Razak stated that he was only in talks to establish a non-governmental organization (NGO) and not a political party. His remarks, deemed candid, sparked excitement among reform-hungry Malaysians who are weary of the country's divisive racial politics. Razak's brother, Malaysian Prime Minister Najib Razak, has also been embroiled in controversy over the 1MDB scandal, which has fueled speculation about a potential power shift in the country.

images.alt_text: Mr Nazir, brother of Malaysian prime minister Najib Razak, has made unusually candid remarks on his growing concern about the socio-political environment and its impact on the economy.
Anita Gabriel

site_title: EU reaches deal to shine light on 'shadow banking'
summary: The European Union reached a deal to increase transparency and mitigate risks in the "shadow banking" sector, a system of financial transactions using assets as guarantees for credit. The sector, valued at $75 trillion, has grown by $5 trillion since 2013, but lacks transparency, making it difficult to identify owners and assess risks. The new law requires stricter reporting requirements, including registration of securities financing transactions, and disclosure of how assets are being used. The deal aims to improve oversight and assess the risks involved in the sector.

site_title: Pimco calls for more Aussie property curbs
summary: Pimco is calling for tougher measures to curb Australia's booming property market, citing "irrational exuberance" among households. The investment firm believes stricter home lending curbs are needed to address financial stability risks and give the Reserve Bank of Australia maximum flexibility in setting interest rates. This comes as the central bank has already slashed rates to a record-low 2% to stimulate the economy. Pimco's call follows warnings from the Secretary to the Treasury and the Reserve Bank Governor that Sydney's property market is in a "bubble."

site_title: Water infrastructure reveals 2 sides of Myanmar's economic boom
summary: Myanmar's economic boom is creating a lucrative bottled water market, with international companies like Nestle and local brands like Alpine producing millions of bottles. However, the majority of the population relies on unsafe water supplies, with 8 in 10 people forced to drink from wells, springs, and streams. The high price of bottled water, at around 36 Singapore cents per liter, makes it unaffordable for most. The country's poor infrastructure and lack of investment under junta rule have contributed to the issue, with only 31% of city dwellers consuming purified water.

site_title: US rival acquires software startup JustCommodity
summary: Singapore-based commodity management software startup JustCommodity has been acquired by Texas-based Allegro Development Corporation for over US$20 million. The acquisition brings together complementary solutions in agriculture and energy commodities, with JustCommodity's platform CxC being used by over 30 clients in Asia. JustCommodity co-founder Joel Lou will become managing director for Asia-Pacific at Allegro, while Allegro CEO Frank Brienzi sees the acquisition as part of his company's growth strategy in Asia and vision to expand into adjacent markets.

images.alt_text: Joel Lou, chief executive officer (CEO) of JustCommodity Software Solutions.

site_title: UE uncovers irregular transactions relating to subsidiaries
summary: United Engineers (UE) discovered irregular transactions involving its subsidiaries, totaling approximately S$11 million, between 2010 and 2015. The irregularities, including forged quotations, were uncovered during an internal audit and resulted in the suspension of several employees. The company has reported the matter to authorities and is consulting with lawyers. The transactions do not appear to have a material effect on UE's consolidated financial statements between FY10 and FY14, but the company will make further announcements as developments occur.

site_title: IVF doctors aghast at 65-year-old mum of quadruplets
summary: A 65-year-old German woman, Annegret Raunigk, gave birth to quadruplets via in-vitro fertilization (IVF) in May, setting a record for the oldest woman to have IVF quadruplets. Experts at the European Society of Human Reproduction and Embryology conference expressed concern over the mother's age and the risks for the babies, citing the dangers of multiple pregnancies and the need for single embryo transfers. The clinic's decision to implant multiple embryos is seen as "extremely questionable" by the German Society for Reproductive Medicine, raising questions about IVF ethics and regulation.

site_title: More developers allowed to issue bonds
summary: China is allowing more property developers to issue bonds on the interbank market, with state-owned companies rated "AA" and higher eligible to sell medium-term notes. Priority will be given to 16 central government-owned groups and their units, as well as developers owned by provinces and cities. This move is part of efforts to ease financing restrictions and boost economic growth, which has been hindered by a sluggish property market. The National Association of Financial Market Institutional Investors (NAFMII) will continue to support local government financing vehicles to sell bonds for projects in innovative industries.

site_title: SingPost acquires 30% stake in e-commerce firm Hubbed
summary: SingPost has acquired a 30% stake in Australian e-commerce firm Hubbed Holdings for about S$4.45 million. Hubbed, with a network of 680 newsagents, provides parcel delivery services across Australia. The partnership aims to provide seamless e-commerce access to customers, complementing SingPost's existing CouriersPlease service. If performance benchmarks are met, Quantium Solutions will pay an additional A$1 million. This investment is part of SingPost's strategy to develop an e-commerce ecosystem and strengthen its presence in the Asia Pacific region.

site_title: US oil stocks fall as gasoline inventories rise unexpectedly: EIA
summary: US crude oil stocks fell by 2.7 million barrels last week, surpassing analysts' expectations of a 1.7 million barrel decrease. Gasoline stocks and distillate inventories rose unexpectedly, with crude stocks at the Cushing, Oklahoma delivery hub increasing by 112,000 barrels for the first time since mid-April. The data from the Energy Information Administration contradicts the bearish outlook on the oil market due to President Trump's tariff policies.

site_title: Greece may exit eurozone, and even EU, without bailout deal, warns central bank
summary: Greece's central bank warns that the country may exit the eurozone and EU if it fails to reach a bailout deal with international creditors. The Bank of Greece stated that failure to agree would lead to a Greek default and ultimately Greece's exit from the euro area and EU. Negotiations over the release of €7.2 billion in rescue funds are deadlocked, with payment deadlines looming. The Bank of Greece believes that only "little ground" remains between Greece and creditors before a deal can be struck, but the situation remains tense, with a meeting of eurozone finance ministers on Thursday.

site_title: 2G network closure offers opportunities for S'pore telcos: BMI
summary: Singapore's telcos, Singtel, M1, and StarHub, will see opportunities to monetize their services as the country's 2G networks are set to be closed. The spectrum will be refarmed for 3G/4G mobile broadband, allowing for the development of comprehensive OTT service platforms. However, the introduction of new low-priced operators, MyRepublic and OMGTel, may disrupt the market, forcing existing players to resort to complex bundling strategies and potentially diluting ARPU. Mobile ARPUs are expected to decline from S$48.70 to S$45.40 over the 2015-2019 forecast period.

site_title: OECD warns of finance downside on growth
summary: The Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development (OECD) has released a report warning that over-expansion in credit can make economies more crisis-prone, particularly in advanced economies. The report notes that an over-rapid growth in credit, especially household debt, can lead to income inequalities and reduce long-term growth. The OECD suggests that a more balanced financing system, with a better composition of finance, is essential for healthy economic growth, and recommends reforms to achieve this, including breaking up too-big-to-fail banks and tax reforms.

site_title: Global watchdog says to study bond market liquidity
summary: Global regulators, including the International Organization of Securities Commissions (IOSCO), are reviewing the bond market's structure to assess its liquidity, amid concerns of "taper tantrums" as interest rates rise. The review aims to understand the market's resilience and potential risks. IOSCO Chairman Greg Medcraft notes that the bond market's recent volatility is partly due to higher capital charges, which have led to market makers withdrawing from the market. Regulators warn that steps to avert volatility could create unintended problems elsewhere in markets, where investors have always taken risks.

site_title: Aussie IPO revival fizzles as buyers baulk over stock slump
summary: Australia's initial public offerings (IPOs) have seen a decline in 2015, with first-time share sales raising A$2.9 billion, down from A$5.2 billion in the first six months of 2014. Investors are hesitant to buy new shares due to the nation's worst-performing market, with the benchmark index on track for a 5% slide this quarter. Foreign money managers are also deterred by the weakening Australian dollar, which has fallen 17% in the past 12 months. Several IPOs have been cancelled, including Greenstone Ltd and IVE Group, as investors wait for more attractive business models.

site_title: Europe: Stocks decline as investors watch Greek crisis, Fed
summary: European stocks declined 0.5% to 383.74, amid Greece's ongoing crisis and speculation about the Federal Reserve's monetary policy. The Stoxx Europe 600 Index fell 0.8% earlier after German Finance Minister Wolfgang Schaeuble mentioned contingency plans for Greece's failure to reach an aid deal by June 30. The US Federal Reserve concludes its policy meeting, with traders putting the odds of a September interest rate hike at 47%. Greek Prime Minister Alexis Tsipras intensified his criticism of creditors, while German Chancellor Angela Merkel vowed to keep Greece in the euro.

site_title: US regulator limits mortgage servicing activities at 6 banks
summary: US bank regulator, the Office of the Comptroller of the Currency, has imposed restrictions on mortgage servicing activities at six banks, including HSBC and Wells Fargo, for failing to meet settlement requirements following the 2007-2009 financial crisis. The restrictions include limiting acquisitions of residential mortgage servicing rights and outsourcing servicing to others. Wells Fargo and HSBC face the toughest restrictions, while JPMorgan Chase, EverBank, Santander, and US Bank will have certain activities limited. The settlement has resulted in over $2.7 billion in payments to borrowers, with $280 million expected to remain unclaimed by the end of 2015.

site_title: Google releases tool to track ad effectiveness across devices
summary: Google has released a tool to track ad effectiveness across devices, including smartphones, tablets, and desktop computers. The tool measures customer responses from the initial ad click to the final purchase, regardless of device used. This allows advertisers to understand how ads perform across different devices and platforms, helping them optimize their campaigns. According to Neal Mohan, vice president for video and display advertising, 90% of consumers switch devices throughout the day, making it essential to track ad effectiveness across multiple devices.

site_title: Fed expected to signal rate hike later this year
summary: The Federal Reserve is expected to keep interest rates on hold, but analysts predict a rate hike in September as the economy continues to grow. Fed Chair Janet Yellen has expressed increasing confidence in future growth, signaling the end of crisis-era ultra-low interest rates. The federal funds rate has been at zero since 2008, and a September hike would mark the first rate increase in nine years.

site_title: Jakarta to end power subsidy in budget reform
summary: Indonesian President Joko Widodo is proposing to end electricity subsidies for middle-class households, shifting the funds to poor households, in an effort to revive waning domestic demand. The plan, part of his economic reform efforts, aims to free up billions in the budget but may face backlash from emerging middle-class voters. Experts warn that the move could lead to increased prices for households, particularly those who rely heavily on electricity. The proposal is part of a series of micro-measures aimed at improving the economy, but investors are seeking bolder structural reforms.

site_title: Atlantic Marine Services withdraws suit against Ezion Holdings
summary: Atlantic Marine Services BV (AMS) has withdrawn its lawsuit against Singapore-based offshore service provider Ezion Holdings, releasing and discharging Ezion from all claims. AMS had accused Ezion of a conspiracy to breach charter agreements, but Ezion maintained that AMS was in financial trouble and had failed to meet its obligations. The company will cooperate with Ezion to support a common client's operational requirements in the North Sea.
