The contracts include a rigid pipelay contract for the Aviat field development in the UK North Sea under a frame agreement with Apache. This marks a significant win for the company.

images.alt_text: Mindy Tan

site_title: Elements that make a top business leader
summary: Achal Agarwal, president of Kimberly-Clark Asia, emphasizes that leadership is about execution, creating a winning feeling, and being repetitive. He lists eight key elements of a successful business leader, including execution, building a loyal team, creating a winning feeling, and being repetitive. Agarwal's experience managing large organizations in Asia informs his perspective on leadership, which he shared in a recent presentation at NUS Business School. His definition of success focuses on building a loyal team and creating a positive work environment.

site_title: Outlook murky for Obama's trade pact in Congress, Clinton weighs in
summary: US President Barack Obama's Pacific trade pact, the Trans-Pacific Partnership (TPP), faces uncertainty in Congress, with no clear path forward despite hopes to revive the deal by the end of summer. Former Secretary of State Hillary Clinton weighed in, saying Obama should use lawmakers' concerns to win changes to the pact. The White House is working to address Democrats' concerns, but time is running out to secure fast-track authority and pass the deal before 2016 presidential elections.

images.alt_text: President Barack Obama speaks to Nike Employees and other Oregonians at Nike Headquarters on May 8, 2015, in Beaverton, Oregon. Obama spoke about the Trans-Pacific Partnership trade pacts which include the U.S. in a trade agreement with 11 other nations.

site_title: Swiss economy faces its first recession in six years
summary: The Swiss economy is facing its first recession in six years, with the Swiss National Bank (SNB) struggling to stabilize the economy due to a slump in consumer prices and a shrinking economy. The SNB's deposit rate is already at a record low of minus 0.75%, and a further cut is unlikely without risking a run on cash. The SNB's new forecasts predict a 0.2% contraction in the first quarter, with the economy expected to shrink further this quarter, putting it in its first recession since 2009.

site_title: Greece, creditors locked in stalemate over loan deal
summary: Greece and its creditors remain locked in a stalemate over a loan deal, with Athens just two weeks away from a catastrophic default on its debt. Despite EU-IMF creditors making "major concessions," Greece's radical left government continues to reject austerity demands. The talks, which have dragged on for five months, are set to resume "at any time," but a deal must be reached by a meeting of eurozone finance ministers on June 30 to meet Greece's bailout deadline. The deadlock has led to a sharp decline in the Athens Stock Exchange, with bank stocks particularly hard hit.

site_title: Chemicals giant Teijin to close Jurong Island plant, sell the site
summary: Teijin, a Tokyo-listed chemical and pharmaceutical company, plans to close its polycarbonate resin plant in Singapore by year's end. The decision is part of the company's restructuring efforts to address high energy costs and low-cost Chinese rivals. The Jurong Island plant will be put up for sale through an expression of interest. The move is aimed at reducing losses from the company's loss-making businesses.

site_title: Desperate for growth, Indonesia unveils raft of micro-measures
summary: Indonesia's President Joko Widodo has introduced a series of micro-measures to boost the economy, including tax and regulation tweaks, as growth remains stagnant. The measures include removing luxury taxes and cutting tariffs for Eid al-Fitr. However, economists warn that these steps may not have a significant impact without larger changes, such as kick-starting infrastructure projects and cleaning up the bureaucracy. The central bank is also under pressure to cut interest rates, but its options are limited due to high inflation and volatile capital flows.

site_title: ICBC Singapore launches USD/SGD dual currency card
summary: ICBC Singapore has launched a USD/SGD dual currency credit card with zero administrative fees for US dollar transactions, aiming to expand its retail banking presence in Singapore. This is the first dual currency card to combine both USD and SGD customer accounts in one credit card. The launch follows other banks' efforts to grow their card spending, with OCBC and ANZ also introducing new credit cards this year.

site_title: Japan raises view on capex after surprise upward GDP revision
summary: Japan's government raised its capital expenditure assessment for the first time in six months after business investment showed an unexpectedly strong pick-up in the first quarter. The Cabinet Office upgraded its forecast, citing robust plans from companies to increase investment. The government maintains its assessment that the economy is in a gradual recovery phase, with consumer spending and exports stabilizing. Prime Minister Shinzo Abe's government is counting on business investment to boost economic growth and create jobs.

site_title: SC Capital staying clear of Singapore home market until prices drop 30%
summary: SC Capital Partners' founder Suchad Chiaranussatti says the Singapore residential market needs a 30% price drop before he considers re-entering the market. The fund booked a loss from the sale of apartments to Blackstone Group LP in January, citing the intensity and severity of government cooling measures as a surprise. Home prices have fallen for a sixth consecutive quarter, with luxury properties declining 20% since 2013. Chiaranussatti expects investment opportunities to arise in the next two years as prices decline further, but predicts the government will not remove property curbs for at least two years.

site_title: From tree to greens, a US Open unlike any before
summary: The 2015 US Open at Chambers Bay Golf Course in Washington state is set to be unlike any previous tournament due to its unique landscape, which features a single surviving tree that endured a vandal attack, a freight train that thunders past several holes 60 times a day, and fine fescue grass that is rarely used at North American golf courses. The course's innovative design and weather conditions near Puget Sound have made it an ideal location for this first Pacific Northwest US Open. The tournament will take place on the grass, which is a biological experiment, and will be marked by the sounds of the train and the view of the tree.

site_title: Londoners pay record rents as landlords capitalise on shortfall
summary: Londoners are paying record rents, with the average rent for a new lease in Greater London reaching £1,506 (S$3,146) a month in May. This is more than double the average for the rest of the UK. A shortage of 10,000 homes annually is boosting rents, with 32,000 new homes expected to be completed in the next five years. Tenants are choosing to stay in the city, with 80% of brokers saying there are more tenants than properties available, according to a HomeLet survey.

site_title: Water supply: Look beyond technology and innovation
summary: A global summit on water management in Singapore is underway, focusing on the need for long-term, consistent political commitments to address water problems. Despite technological advancements, significant improvements in the next decade are unlikely to come from technological innovations or new engineering solutions. Instead, they will come from better understanding of human interactions with water and their interrelationships through efficient economic instruments and social policies. Consumers worldwide are losing trust and confidence in water utilities, with households increasingly spending more on bottled water and point-of-use treatment systems than on water rates.

site_title: Fired miner's 50% pay cut just start of Australian wage pain
summary: Australian workers are facing stagnant wages, with the country experiencing its first recorded decline in wages in the first quarter of 2015. The decline is attributed to the collapse of the nation's commodities market, which has led to a sharp depreciation of the currency and reduced demand for goods and services. This has significant implications for the economy, including limiting household spending, impeding government efforts to repair the budget, and forcing the central bank to maintain low interest rates or cut them further.

site_title: Etihad Airways seen eyeing US$1b through debut bond issue
summary: Etihad Airways is in talks to raise around $1 billion through a debut bond issue, with Goldman Sachs and National Bank of Abu Dhabi expected to be lead arrangers. The airline plans to use the funds to lend to its global partners, fund expansion plans, and cover general expenses. Etihad owns stakes in several airlines, including Alitalia and Jet Airways, and is seeking to transform its frequent-flyer program into a wider lifestyle program. The airline has secured a "A" rating from rating agency Fitch and is looking to issue junk-rated bonds.

site_title: Alibaba set to offer video streaming service
summary: Alibaba plans to launch Tmall Box Office, a video streaming service aiming to serve 600 million families in China, rivaling Netflix and HBO. The service will be available on set-top boxes and smart TVs through Alibaba's operating system. The company aims to create a new family entertainment experience and explore e-commerce businesses based on film stars' brands. Alibaba's online video market value is expected to triple to 90 billion yuan by 2018, with the company raising 530 million yuan through its crowdfunding platform Yu Le Bao.

site_title: Developers' sales slump amid lack of new major launches
summary: Singapore's developers saw a significant drop in sales in May, with 638 private residential units sold, 45% fewer than the previous month. The sales slump is expected to continue in June due to the school holidays, with no major project launches taking place. However, new projects will be rolled out in July, including two EC projects and a massive 1,390-unit High Park Residences. Despite the cooling measures, steady underlying buying demand supports the residential primary market, with projected sales ranging between 6,500 and 9,000 private housing units for the year.

site_title: Fight for the jobs of tomorrow: NTUC chief
summary: NTUC secretary-general Chan Chun Sing emphasizes the need for workers to adapt to the changing job market, where traditional jobs are being replaced by robots and automation. He advocates for workers to upskill and reskill to secure higher-value-added jobs in precision engineering and robotics. The goal is to ensure workers can keep pace with new demands and not fight for jobs of yesterday, but rather be ready for jobs of tomorrow, enabling them to earn a better quality of life.

images.alt_text: Mr Chan (centre) visiting Yamazaki Mazak on Monday. He says corporations such as Mazak require highly qualified skilled machinists and people with many years of experience, examples of the jobs of tomorrow.

site_title: Fossil fuel subsidies stymie pollution curbs: IEA report
summary: The International Energy Agency (IEA) reports that fossil fuel subsidies hinder efforts to curb pollution, with a US$115 per tonne of carbon dioxide incentive. This is more than 15 times the cost of buying emission permits in carbon markets. Despite some countries cutting subsidies, the world's estimated remaining budget for curbing emissions will be consumed by 2040, with the path to a 2°C temperature increase likely to continue after 2030. The IEA urges stronger action to meet climate goals.

site_title: Singapore's quarterly total employment falls for the first time in 5 years
summary: Singapore's total employment fell for the first time in 5 years in the first quarter of 2015, with 6,100 jobs lost, according to the Ministry of Manpower. The overall unemployment rate remained low at 1.8% and declined for residents, while the number of redundancies decreased slightly. The contraction was attributed to "seasonal declines and sharper moderation" in sectors with less favourable business conditions. Despite this, the employment numbers are still 2.7% higher than a year ago.

images.alt_text: Lee U-Wen

site_title: Online discounts soar as S Koreans avoid public places
summary: South Korean shoppers are avoiding public places due to the spread of Middle East respiratory syndrome, resulting in a decline of in-store sales at large department stores. To combat this, retailers such as Shinsegae Co and Lotte Shopping Co are offering online discounts of up to 80% and 70% respectively, with cinema visits also down 52% this month. This trend is expected to continue throughout June, with online shopping becoming the preferred choice for consumers.

images.alt_text: Department store sales fell 17 per cent in the first week of June from a year earlier, the Ministry of Strategy and Finance said on Monday. Sales at large retail stores fell 3.4 per cent.

site_title: TPA snafu a blow not just to Obama but also American national interests
summary: US President Barack Obama's trade agenda was dealt a blow when Democrats in the House of Representatives blocked a move to grant him trade promotion authority (TPA) for the Trans-Pacific Partnership (TPP) trade agreement. The bill was approved in the House but stalled in the Senate after Democrats forced a vote on a related Trade Adjustment Assistance (TAA) bill, which was defeated. The vote has raised doubts about the TPA's passage and may harm US national interests, as the TPP deal is central to Obama's global agenda and could define his legacy as president.

site_title: Yuan near 5-week low; US$ will be focus of the week
summary: China's yuan traded near a five-week low, falling to 6.2098 a dollar, amid speculation of a potential monetary policy cut. The People's Bank of China is expected to cut reserve-requirement ratios as early as June 13-14, following a slowdown in economic growth and easing inflation. The yuan's decline may be influenced by the International Monetary Fund's consideration of including the yuan in its Special Drawing Rights basket later this year, which could boost global demand for the currency.

site_title: Greek shares, bonds slump on default concerns
summary: Greek shares and bonds plummeted due to concerns over a potential debt default, with a 12% decline in the two-day trading period. The Greek stock market fell by 7% on Monday, and shares of Piraeus Bank, Eurobank Ergasius, and National Bank of Greece dropped by 18.5%, 13.8%, and 13.4% respectively. The fear is that German Chancellor Angela Merkel is losing patience with debt negotiations, which have so far failed, and a default is imminent.

images.alt_text: Mr Tsipras' left-wing government is refusing to accept new spending cuts and tax rises.

site_title: Boeing sees huge potential for a niche mid-market jet
summary: Boeing is exploring a potential market for a niche mid-market jet, approximately 20% larger than its 757 and capable of flying further. The company has received interest from airlines for a plane that would put it beyond the reach of Airbus's A321LR single-aisle offering. Boeing's sales chief has not ruled out investing in a new jetliner, but has not made a decision yet.

site_title: Mapletree Greater China buys plaza in Shanghai
summary: Mapletree Greater China Commercial Trust (MGCCT) has acquired Sandhill Plaza in Shanghai for about S$402 million. The 83,801.5 sq m property has a 50-year leasehold and a 96.2% occupancy rate. The acquisition is MGCCT's first since listing and is in line with its strategy to invest in best-in-class real estate assets in the Greater China region. Moody's expects the acquisition to reduce its reliance on Festival Walk in Hong Kong and maintain a stable rating outlook.

images.alt_text: Mindy Tan

site_title: Former PetroChina vice-chairman to be prosecuted for graft
summary: Former PetroChina vice-chairman Liao Yongyuan has been expelled from the Communist Party and will be prosecuted for bribery, embezzlement, and adultery. He was accused of abusing his position to help with job promotions and taking "enormous" bribes. Liao, a 30-year veteran at CNPC, stepped down in March after the party's graft watchdog began an investigation. The case is part of President Xi Jinping's anti-corruption campaign, which has led to the downfall of several senior officials. Liao and evidence of his crimes will be handed over to legal authorities for prosecution.

site_title: Big Oil to attend Russia's top investment forum
summary: Big Oil executives, including BP, Royal Dutch Shell, and Total, are attending Russia's top investment forum, defying Western sanctions and tensions. The event comes as Russia's oil and gas reserves have jumped above 100 billion barrels, making it economically vital for major energy firms to maintain ties with Moscow. Despite a shaky ceasefire in Ukraine, Western energy bosses are attending the forum, seeking to boost investments and deals, and cooperating with the Kremlin to convey a message of business as usual.

site_title: Felda Global shares sold down on proposed Rajawali deal
summary: Malaysia's state-owned Felda Global Ventures Bhd (FGV) is facing criticism for its proposed acquisition of Indonesia's Rajawali Capital International, with investors selling down its shares by 11% due to concerns over the deal's price. The acquisition, valued at US$680 million, works out to a 72% premium over the target's Friday closing price. FGV's cash reserves are depleting, and its financial leverage is rising, raising concerns about the company's long-term viability.

site_title: AVJennings to develop land parcel in NSW
summary: AVJennings, a Singaporean developer, has acquired the right to develop a land parcel at Warnervale in NSW, Australia, expected to produce around 540 lots. This follows recent land acquisitions in Victoria and Victoria. The development aims to secure a strong pipeline of projects, delivering quality residential communities to customers. AVJ's counter ended trading 0.5 Singapore cents higher after the announcement.

site_title: More offshore & marine firms may seek equity lifeline soon
summary: Singapore's offshore and marine (O&M) firms with high debt levels may seek equity lifelines amid a crude oil slump and oversupply of OSVs. Companies such as Otto Marine, Swiber, and Marco Polo Marine are likely to make cash calls, with the bond route deemed prohibitive. This comes as funds dry up for these firms, which face increased pressure due to the downturn in the industry.

site_title: Greece, EU urged to show flexibility and adopt tough choices to resolve crisis
summary: Greece's debt crisis deepens, with key figures Charles Dallara and Olivier Blanchard urging flexibility and tough choices to prevent a damaging Greek exit from the euro area. Dallara calls for reduced interest rates and concessions from Greece, while Blanchard suggests tougher commitments from both sides to avoid a default. The euro skidded on Monday after talks in Athens collapsed, and Asian shares fell as markets digested the implications. A Greek exit is becoming a real possibility, with Germany reportedly preparing for such an event, and the IMF chief economist warning that "tough choices" must be made to avoid a crisis.

site_title: AirAsia units plan US$300m bond issues
summary: AirAsia, Asia's largest budget airline, plans to raise up to $300 million by issuing bonds and selling up to 20 planes to cut debt. CEO Tony Fernandes said the moves aim to improve the airline's financial situation, which has been affected by competition and a recent crash that killed 162 people. The airline reported a net loss for 2014 and is taking on fewer new aircraft to manage capacity. Fernandes expressed optimism about 2015, citing a better operating environment and rational market, but analysts have questioned the move, citing the airline's lack of earnings.

site_title: Food firms seek chemical-coating alternatives
summary: Food firms are shifting away from bisphenol A (BPA), a chemical used in canned goods coatings, but transparency about safer alternatives is lacking. Despite FDA's position that BPA is safe at current levels, health advocates and scientists raise concerns about newer options, citing conflicting evidence and potential health risks. Companies such as General Mills and Target continue to use BPA-free coatings, but fail to disclose which chemicals are being used. The Environmental Working Group and other organizations criticize the lack of information and the potential for alternative chemicals to be just as hazardous as BPA.

site_title: CBRE poaches 5 industrial brokers from Colliers
summary: CBRE has poached five industrial brokers from Colliers International, including Brenda Ong, who will lead the new team at CBRE's industrial and logistics services. The move aims to solidify CBRE's market leadership in the industrial arena, which is seen as a lucrative sector with opportunities for revenue growth. The appointments come as Singapore's economy undergoes structural change, with manufacturing companies looking to optimize their industrial premises.

images.alt_text: Kalpana Rashiwala

Set to solidify CBRE Singapore's market leadership in the industrial arena: Seated (from left) Bernard Goh, Moray Armstrong, Brenda Ong and Rimon Ambarchi. Standing (from left) Jonathan Tan, Loh Lee Fen, Elsie Foo, Maverick Li and Raphael Lee

site_title: Singtel donates S$20m to National Gallery Singapore
summary: Singtel donates S$20 million to the National Gallery Singapore, one of the largest corporate endowments the museum has received. In return, the gallery dedicates three spaces from its old City Hall building as the Singtel Special Exhibition Gallery, featuring twice-yearly shows showcasing art from museums worldwide and local artists. The gallery aims to create a dialogue between art from Singapore and South-east Asia with global art, generating new knowledge of art and art history.

site_title: Volatile bond markets prompt asset managers to revise their risk models
summary: Volatile bond markets have led to a $640 billion loss in sovereign debt worldwide since April, prompting asset managers to revise their risk models. Yield fluctuations have surged, with 10-year German bunds rising to 1% and 30-day volatility reaching 300%. To assess risk, firms like BlackRock and JPMorgan are testing new worst-case scenarios and calculating "liquidity premiums" for top-rated bonds. Experts warn that instability may seep into other assets, putting pressure on companies and governments with rising borrowing costs.

images.alt_text: With US$4.8 trillion in assets - or about the size of Japan's economy - no one manages more money than BlackRock Inc. So, it's worth paying attention when the firm says it's time to cast aside its trusted models for assessing risk in bonds.

site_title: Ringgit nearing crisis peg as Zeti's optimism not shared by everyone
summary: Malaysia's ringgit is nearing a crisis peg, with the currency sinking to within 0.7% of the 3.80 peg imposed in 1998. Macquarie Bank is reviewing its year-end forecast of 3.75 US dollars per ringgit due to the currency's weakness. Despite central bank assurances, the decline is not convincing everyone, raising concerns about the country's economic stability.

images.alt_text: The ringgit is down 5.3 per cent at 3.7635 per US dollar in the past month, Asia's worst performance, and analysts are once again lowering end-2015 projections.

site_title: End game approaches as US warns of accidental Grexit
summary: The International Monetary Fund (IMF) has pulled out of talks with Greece, citing the government's failure to compromise on key areas such as labor market and pension reforms. Standard & Poor's has downgraded Greece's credit rating to "CCC", further increasing tensions. Greek Prime Minister Alexis Tsipras has requested a nine-month extension of the current bailout package until March 2016, but this may only defer a potential crisis for a few months. The IMF warns of an "accidental" Greek exit from the eurozone, with potential economic fallout for Europe, and US Treasury Secretary Jack Lew has expressed concerns about the risks of Grexit.

site_title: JM Ice keeps things cool with bots and tech
summary: JM Ice, a Singapore-based ice manufacturer, has successfully implemented robotic arms to automate its ice-stacking process, increasing productivity by over 20%. The company, which serves over 5,000 clients, has seen a significant reduction in labor costs and improved efficiency. The robotic arms, funded by Spring Singapore's Capability Development Grant, have enabled the company to shed its reliance on nine workers and redeploy them to other roles. With the increased output, JM Ice aims to improve its bottom line and maintain its market share in the ice manufacturing and distribution industry.

images.alt_text: Prisca Ang

site_title: Earnings leaks to local press not unfair, says outgoing head of JPX
summary: Japan's outgoing head of the stock exchange, Atsushi Saito, says publishing companies' financial results in local press before official announcement isn't unfair, as long as media outlets aren't trading on the information. He believes it's a free competitive market and can't criticize journalists' competition. This practice, which has occurred for years, has raised concerns that it creates an uneven playing field for individual investors, with some calling for a more robust attitude toward disclosure from the bourse.

site_title: China margin finance boom fuels record brokerage bond sales
summary: China's margin finance boom has fueled record offshore bond sales by Hong Kong brokerages, with overseas bond issuance from non-bank financial institutions jumping four times to $11.5 billion this year. The surge is driven by Chinese investors seeking to amplify equity profits with borrowed funds, with margin debt reaching $358 billion. Brokerages are growing their Hong Kong business, especially margin financing, to take advantage of lower costs. Chinese regulators have announced plans to limit brokerage lending for stock trading amid rising concerns about risks.

site_title: A-shares in MSCI index: potential US$40b long-term fund inflow
summary: MSCI's delayed inclusion of China's A-shares in its Emerging Market index is expected to draw in nearly US$40 billion in long-term passive fund inflows. Initially, the inclusion will be limited, but its impact will be significant. The index provider had delayed the inclusion, citing concerns over market liberalization, including quotas on foreign investors and restrictions on capital repatriation. MSCI plans to include China A-shares at a 5% weighting, increasing to 21% by May 2017, when the index reflects the A-shares market on a free-float adjusted basis.

site_title: Greece's threat of suicide may be futile
summary: Greece's Prime Minister Alexis Tsipras's rejection of a bailout offer has increased the likelihood of a Greek default, but the European Central Bank's bond-buying program aims to mitigate the consequences. The ECB's program is designed to protect the euro from a Greek exit or default. Tsipras's refusal to accept the offer may lead to catastrophe for his country, humiliation for his party, or both. The ECB's program may be futile if Tsipras continues to believe Greece needs Europe as much as Europe needs Greece.

images.alt_text: The ECB's newfound ability to print money, essentially without limit, to support both banks and governments has reduced Greek contagion to insignificance.

site_title: Banks among biggest drags as STI slips
summary: The Straits Times Index fell 0.9% on Monday, closing at 3,323.13, due to failed Greece talks, a selloff in China, and anticipation of a US Federal Reserve meeting. Singapore banks, including DBS, OCBC, and UOB, were among the biggest drags, with declines of 1.1-1.4%. Commodity trader Noble Group and Mercurius Capital Investment were exceptions, gaining 5.1% and 14.3%, respectively. The market sentiment was dampened by the failed Greece talks and tightening margin financing rules in China.

site_title: Lippo Malls Indonesia trust raises S$75m through bonds
summary: Lippo Malls Indonesia Retail Trust (LMIRT) raised S$75 million through a five-year bond issuance with a 4.1% coupon, exceeding S$100 million in orders. The bond, not rated, is for refinancing and potential acquisitions. This marks LMIRT's first bond issuance since it received an investment-grade rating, allowing it to set a new pricing benchmark. The trust has a Moody's rating of Baa3 with a stable outlook. The funds will be used for debt refinancing and potential acquisitions.

site_title: FDA to work with online patient forum to mine drug safety data
summary: The US Food and Drug Administration (FDA) is collaborating with PatientsLikeMe, a patient-networking website, to mine drug safety data. The online forum, with 350,000 members, reports adverse events, symptoms, and hospitalizations, providing valuable insights into medication side effects. The FDA hopes to learn more about the impact of adverse events on patients' daily lives and potentially influence changes in drug labeling or reaction times to safety issues. This collaboration aims to improve the agency's understanding of medication side effects and explore the use of social media and online forums for reporting adverse events.

site_title: Looking for the ideal way to divide team tasks
summary: A recent study found that self-managed teams tend to divide tasks into objects rather than activities, even when it's not the most effective approach. In experiments, groups performed better when dividing tasks by activity, while individuals were more likely to default to object-based divisions. This tendency can lead to projects going astray. Managers can mitigate this by actively encouraging teams to consider multiple possibilities and reminding them to focus on performance over social dynamics. A balanced approach, combining object-based and activity-based divisions, may be the most effective way to divide tasks.

site_title: Billionaires flock to the 'gilded age' of art at Basel fair
summary: Billionaires and art collectors are flocking to Basel, Switzerland, for the 46th edition of the world's largest modern and contemporary art fair. The fair features 284 galleries from 33 countries showcasing works by 4,000 artists, with an estimated €3 billion (S$4.5 billion) of art on view. Billionaire hedge fund manager Dan Loeb and Lightyear Capital chairman Don Marron are among the collectors attending the event, which opens to invited guests on Wednesday. The fair's massive scale and high-end art offerings have earned it the nickname "the gilded age" of art.

site_title: China investors lose US$1.2b in alleged Swiss scam
summary: Chinese investors lost approximately $1.2 billion in an alleged Swiss scam, with returns promised of up to 10% a month from currency trading by API Premiere Swiss Trust AG and associated companies. The investors, who number around 29,000, were lured by the promise of secure investments and were directed to deposit money in Hong Kong or China. The Swiss Financial Market Supervisory Authority (Finma) is investigating API and an associated company, and the Chinese government is urging the Swiss government to cooperate in the investigation.

site_title: Jurassic World sets global box office opening weekend record
summary: Jurassic World has set a global box office opening weekend record, raking in $511 million worldwide, including $100 million from China. The film surpassed Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows: Part 2's record, topping the box office in 66 countries. Its success can be attributed to a combination of nostalgia, legacy, and pedigree, as well as smart marketing. The film's unprecedented haul boosted its performance in North America, where it made $204.6 million, just short of Marvel's The Avengers record.

site_title: South Korea president warns of 'excessive' public alarm over Mers
summary: South Korea reported its 16th death from Middle East Respiratory Syndrome (Mers) on June 15, as the country's Mers outbreak continued to spread, with 150 cases and 17 patients in unstable condition. President Park Geun-Hye warned of "excessive" public alarm and called for efforts to minimize economic damage, which has seen consumer spending and foreign tourist numbers plummet. Over 100,000 foreigners have cancelled trips to South Korea, and the tourism industry faces a dire situation.

site_title: Small investors side with US fund in Samsung C&T deal
summary: Hundreds of small investors in Samsung C&T Corp are opposing a proposed $8 billion merger with Cheil Industries Inc, citing a low-ball takeover offer. The investors, known as "ants" in local trading circles, are backing US hedge fund Elliott Associates LP, which has filed court injunctions to block the deal. The move is unusual in South Korea, where family-controlled conglomerates typically get their way, and may set a precedent for more careful consideration of deals involving powerful families.

site_title: Shell moves Gulf of Mexico staff ahead of storm
summary: Shell Oil Co removed non-essential workers from offshore platforms in the Gulf of Mexico as a precautionary measure ahead of a low-pressure storm system with an 80% chance of becoming a tropical cyclone in 48 hours. The US National Hurricane Center warned of potential tropical storm conditions along Texas and Louisiana coasts by Tuesday. Shell stated that offshore production would not be impacted by the removal of workers.

site_title: India seeks to use its oil thirst to drive bargains
summary: India is leveraging its position as the world's fourth-largest oil consumer to strike better deals with oil exporting nations. The oil ministry is moving beyond seeking additional barrels for import and is in talks with exporters. India aims to use its oil demand as a bargaining chip to strengthen its economy and create jobs. The country's growing economy, with a 7.5% growth rate in the last quarter, is also driving its oil consumption, with fuel demand rising rapidly.

site_title: Retail sales up 5% in April, buoyed by motor vehicles
summary: Retail sales in Singapore expanded 5% year-over-year in April, driven by a 56.4% increase in motor vehicle sales. Excluding vehicles, sales were down 0.7% year-over-year. Other categories, such as telecommunications and department stores, saw higher sales growth. However, petrol service stations and food & beverages saw lower sales. Economist Benjamin Shatil noted that despite stable wage growth and negative inflation, private consumption has not seen a convincing pickup.

images.alt_text: Nisha Ramchandani

site_title: Bank of England's Forbes sees little contagion risk from Greece
summary: Bank of England policymaker Kristin Forbes expressed minimal contagion risk from Greece's debt crisis, citing manageable bank exposure and a better prepared financial system than the 1997 Asian crisis. Forbes also viewed interest rate normalization as an opportunity for savers, despite acknowledging the ongoing impact of the financial crisis on productivity growth.

site_title: Europe: Greek stocks lead Europe markets lower as debt talks break down
summary: Greek debt talks broke down, causing European stocks to drop to their lowest level in almost four months. The Stoxx Europe 600 Index fell 1.6% and Greece's ASE Index dropped 4.7% as creditors and the Greek government failed to reach a compromise on a bailout deal. The European Central Bank warned of the risk of Greece's exit from the euro, and volatility in European markets increased.

site_title: Honda picks easy-going insider to repair reputation
summary: Honda has appointed Takahiro Hachigo, a 56-year-old insider, as its new president to repair its reputation amid a global auto safety crisis following seven deaths in its cars. Hachigo, who has spent his entire career at Honda, will take over from Takanobu Ito, whose tenure was plagued by recalls and rupturing air bags. The company's decision to pick an insider from within is part of its 41-year tradition, but critics say it won't bring radical change and may perpetuate the insularity that has characterized Japan Inc.

site_title: Huawei says to invest US$450m in Germany: Handelsblatt
summary: Huawei plans to invest $449.88 million in research and development in Germany by 2018, according to the company's rotating chief executive Ken Hu. This investment is expected to bring the total number of Huawei workers in Europe to 5,000. Huawei has also been expanding its patent portfolio, filing 400 million euros in patents in Europe in 2014, up from 13th place the previous year.

site_title: China's next bear market seen in US$358b of margin loans
summary: China's record US$358 billion margin debt is seen as a potential early warning sign for a bear market. Regulators may struggle to limit a sell-off if investor concerns over margin-trading restrictions escalate. The securities regulator recently announced plans to limit brokerages' lending for stock trading, which may have sparked the recent decline in the Shanghai Composite Index. Experts predict that when the margin debt unwinds, the sell-off will be severe, putting pressure on policymakers to address the issue.

site_title: London leads house prices to record in post-election surge
summary: London's house prices reached a record high, with asking prices increasing 5.7% to over £600,000 (S$1.25 million) in June, driven by gains in Kensington and Chelsea. Nationally, prices rose 3% to £294,351, also a record. The surge is attributed to the Conservative Party's election victory, which boosted investor confidence.

images.alt_text: Home prices in the most expensive London districts rose 5.7 per cent to more than £600,000, with Kensington (above) and Chelsea up 25 per cent, property website operator Rightmove says.

site_title: Asia's wealthy see bargains in Europe property
summary: Wealthy investors from Asia are betting the euro's 12-month decline is over, leading to real-estate bargains in Europe. A Singapore-based hedge fund has bought over 1,200 apartments in Germany, with plans to buy more. The euro's slide against Asian currencies has made European properties attractive to investors from China to Malaysia. The fund's success is a result of Stephen Diggle's conviction that the euro's decline is nearing its end, with potential implications for global markets and real estate investments.

site_title: Lesson from Invesco's Noble strategy
summary: Invesco bought 1.18 million shares of Noble Group on June 2, making it a substantial shareholder, but sold over 10 times the amount the next day, reducing its stake to 4.8%. This strategy resulted in losses for Invesco, raising questions about the effectiveness of "buy high, sell low" investment strategies. The article advises retail investors to take long-term positions with diversified portfolios, citing the significant losses incurred by Noble Group over the past five years, and to be cautious of major investors' changing views.

site_title: KrisEnergy to raise S$169.5m from 42-for-100 rights issue
summary: KrisEnergy is raising S$169.5m through a S$440.1m rights issue, offering 42-for-100 rights shares at 38.5 cents each, a 13.5% discount. Singapore conglomerate Keppel and private equity specialist First Reserve are subscribing for 31.3% and 19.8% respectively. The issue will support the company's strategy of growing oil and gas production and near-term development projects. The rights issue is expected to be completed by mid-August, subject to regulatory approvals.

site_title: Asia self-storage sector set to grow: CBRE
summary: Singapore is expected to experience significant growth in the self-storage sector, with a shortage of 2.4-5.5 million sq ft, according to a CBRE study. This is comparable to the US state of New York, which has a higher market saturation level. The study attributes the growth to low market saturation, office and e-commerce expansion, and demographic factors such as aging populations and rising divorce rates in Hong Kong and Singapore. However, investors face challenges due to limited awareness, scarce properties, and short lease terms in Asia.

site_title: SMEs won bulk of public tenders in H1 2014
summary: In the first half of 2014, 79% of public tenders in Singapore were awarded to small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs), surpassing multinational corporations (MNCs). A study by VSC found a high correlation between a company's financial strength and success in winning public tenders, suggesting that SMEs must be more proactive in managing their balance sheets to compete.

images.alt_text: Fiona Lam

site_title: Drought may hit rural Indian economy, aggravating poverty
summary: India's farm economy is expected to contract this fiscal year due to drought, threatening Prime Minister Narendra Modi's poverty-lifting drive. This year's rainfall is forecast to be only 88% of the long-term average, with roughly half of India's farmland lacking irrigation. The drought could aggravate poverty in rural areas, which is a key concern for Modi's party.

site_title: Virtual reality headsets raise some real concerns about people's behaviour
summary: Virtual reality headsets are raising concerns about people's behavior, particularly in social settings. Thousands of developers and early adopters are testing the technology, navigating real-life surroundings while wearing headsets, and learning etiquette around virtual reality interactions. The potential for harassment and abuse in virtual reality games is a concern, with developers exploring solutions such as "bounding boxes" or force fields to protect players' personal space. As virtual reality technology advances, its impact on people's behavior and social interactions is being closely monitored, with some experts predicting that it could amplify both the positives and negatives of human nature.

site_title: The retreat of 'peak oil'
summary: The Organization of the Petroleum Exporting Countries (Opec) meeting has resulted in no production cut, potentially leading to lower oil prices. Oil analyst Larry Goldstein believes prices will drop due to a surplus of oil supply exceeding demand. Crude prices have fluctuated between $50 and $60 per barrel, while US petrol prices have decreased from $3.50 to $2.50 per gallon. Despite a recovering world economy, prices have collapsed, likely due to technological advances and increased global supplies.

site_title: Time for Asia to let go of current account surpluses: DBS economist
summary: Asia needs to stop running current account surpluses to boost investment, according to DBS economist David Carbon. The region's 18-year trend of running surpluses, averaging 6% of GDP, has led to declining investment growth. Carbon suggests countries like Singapore, which has averaged a surplus of 20% of GDP, should instead run deficits to invest domestically, potentially raising productivity and incomes. This would also counter falling inflation and growth, as seen in Singapore's core inflation hitting a five-year low in April.

site_title: Confusing disclosures about substantial shareholder by China New Town
summary: China New Town Development disclosed that its substantial shareholder, Shi Jian, has been required by the PRC Changzhou Procuratorate to remain under "custody in designated residence". The company assured shareholders that the measures would not have a material adverse impact on its financial and operations. However, the company's announcement appears confusing, with Shi Jian holding an executive director role despite not being involved in daily operations, and being paid executive director remuneration. This raises concerns about potential conflicts of interest and the company's remuneration practices.

site_title: MOH bans new forms of tobacco products from Dec 15, 2015
summary: Singapore's Ministry of Health has banned new forms of tobacco products, including smokeless cigarettes and dissolvable tobacco or nicotine, effective December 15, 2015. This move aims to reduce tobacco consumption and promote public health.

site_title: 2G mobile services to cease from April 2017
summary: Singapore's 2G mobile services will cease on April 1, 2017, as the Infocomm Development Authority (IDA) approves a request by three mobile network operators (MNOs) to close their 2G networks. Approximately 250,000 users, mostly foreigners, will need to upgrade to 3G or 4G connections. The MNOs will offer 3G and 4G handsets at various price points to facilitate migration, while the Consumer Association of Singapore will raise awareness through advertisements and outreach programs.

site_title: Greece agrees to EU, IMF budget targets: EU spokeswoman
summary: Greece has agreed to EU and IMF budget targets for 2015, following crunch talks with creditors. EU spokeswoman Annika Breidthardt stated that the Greek authorities agreed to the targets, but questioned their credibility. The agreement aims to unlock crucial bailout cash before the end of the month.

site_title: Singapore eDevelopment acquires BMICP
summary: Singapore eDevelopment acquired BMI Capital Partners International (BMICP) for HK$1 (17 Singapore cents) from Chan Heng Fai. BMICP, an investment holding company, has a wholly-owned software technology subsidiary SeD Capital Shanghai with a registered share capital of 30 million yuan. The acquisition is funded by internal resources and is not expected to impact the company's financials for the current year. BMICP and SeD have a consolidated net equity deficiency of HK$60,721, which will be repaid after the acquisition.

site_title: Greek banks see deposit outflow of 400 mln euros on Monday: bankers
summary: Greek banks experienced a deposit outflow of approximately 400 million euros on Monday, following a breakdown in talks with creditors over an aid-for-reforms deal. This marks a significant increase from daily withdrawals of 200-250 million euros in recent weeks. The uncertainty and fears of capital controls have unnerved savers, contributing to the outflow.

site_title: First BoE rate hike to 0.75% still expected in Q1 2016: Reuters poll
summary: The Bank of England is expected to raise interest rates in the first quarter of 2016, with a 25 basis point hike still predicted, according to a Reuters poll of 40 economists. The median forecast now suggests a hike before April, down from 60% in May, but a 70% chance of a hike by the end of June. The decision comes as inflation creeps back towards the Bank of England's target and the economy continues to grow.

site_title: IMF study finds reducing income inequality gives boost to growth
summary: The International Monetary Fund (IMF) has released a study finding that reducing income inequality by increasing the poor's share of wages boosts economic growth. The study suggests that for every 1 percentage point increase in the income share of the richest 20%, output growth is 0.08 percentage points lower in the following five years. Conversely, income growth in the bottom fifth boosts expansion by 0.38 percentage points. The IMF concludes that reducing inequality is crucial for economic growth and macroeconomic stability, and that a more equitable distribution of income is necessary for sustained growth.

site_title: Paris's 'dangerous' rent cap seen deterring home investors
summary: France's rent cap in Paris, limiting new leases to 20% above and 30% below a neighborhood's average, may deter investors while benefiting the wealthiest tenants. The proposal, set to be introduced August 1, could lead to a third of capped leases dropping by less than 50 euros per month, with the rest increasing by more than 100 euros. Experts warn that the cap will slow renovation works and increase litigation, potentially harming landlords and deterring buy-to-let investors. The policy aims to address rising rents, which have climbed 42% in the past decade.

site_title: CVS to buy Target's pharmacy, clinic businesses for US$1.9 billion
summary: CVS Health Corp to acquire Target's pharmacy and clinic businesses for US$1.9 billion. The deal will include over 1,660 Target pharmacies across 47 US states, operated through a store-within-a-store format. CVS will acquire the pharmacy and clinic businesses, which include retail clinics and pharmacy services. The acquisition is expected to expand CVS' presence in the US market.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares end lower
summary: Malaysia's Kuala Lumpur Composite Index ended lower on Monday, closing at 1,722.16 after a 12.21-point decline. The index saw 1.55 billion lots traded, with 150 gains and 777 losses.

site_title: Airbus, Boeing announce US$20b in orders as Paris Air Show takes off
summary: Airbus and Boeing kicked off the Paris Air Show with nearly $20 billion in orders, with Airbus securing deals for 50 planes from Saudi Arabian Airlines and 60 A320neos from GE Capital Aviation. Boeing followed with a $4.8 billion order for 14 777s from Qatar Airways. The sales war highlights the booming civilian aircraft market, with Airbus predicting 32,600 planes worth $4.9 trillion to be sold over the next 20 years. The industry aims to maintain production lines through 2020, requiring around 300-400 sales.

site_title: Apple to pay 70% of music subscription revenue to labels, publishers
summary: Apple will pay music owners 71.5% of revenue from its US$9.99 monthly music streaming service in the US, and an average of 73% overseas. The payments, slightly higher than industry standard, will be made to owners of sound recordings and publishing rights. Apple Music, launched last week, will not pay music owners for its three-month free trial period. The company's payouts aim to support music owners and publishers, leveraging its deep music roots and global brand.

site_title: Manufacturing, mining drag US industrial production
summary: US industrial production unexpectedly fell 0.2% in May, reversing April's 0.5% drop, due to a strong dollar and energy spending cuts. Manufacturing output also declined 0.2%, hampered by a strong dollar, while mining production fell 0.3% due to a 7.9% drop in oil and gas well drilling. The decline in industrial production signals lingering economic challenges, with capacity use falling to 78.1% and officials citing room for growth before inflation becomes a concern.

site_title: Saudi Arabia targets 2017 MSCI emerging markets inclusion
summary: Saudi Arabia aims to join MSCI's emerging markets index in 2017, following the introduction of new rules allowing foreigners to directly access its equities. The kingdom's stock market is opening up as the nation diversifies its economy away from oil. The new rules restrict direct trading to institutional investors with $5 billion in assets and cap foreign holdings at 10% of the market. The country expects a budget deficit this year and plans to issue a development bond to fund it, according to CEO Adel Al-Ghamdi.

site_title: China's Hanergy loses US$585 million intra-group order signed in May
summary: Hanergy Thin Film Power Group, a Chinese solar energy firm, has lost a US$585 million intra-group order signed in May, which accounts for nearly half of its annual sales. The order was cancelled by its biggest client, Fujian Apollo, without giving a reason. This setback comes after Hanergy's shares plunged 47% in May, wiping US$18 billion off its market value, amid a Hong Kong probe for alleged market manipulation. The cancellation highlights Hanergy's vulnerability due to its dependence on a limited client base.

site_title: Alwaleed says Twitter interim CEO Dorsey brings continuity, would back him as CEO
summary: Prince Alwaleed bin Talal, a Saudi Arabian investor in Twitter, expressed support for Jack Dorsey as interim CEO, stating he would back him if he wished to become CEO permanently. Dorsey, a co-founder of Twitter, was named interim head after Dick Costolo's sudden departure. Prince Alwaleed praised Dorsey's knowledge of the company and his ability to bring continuity during the transition.

site_title: 195 erroneous May 2015 CDP printed statements were mailed out, says SGX
summary: The Singapore Exchange (SGX) has mailed out 195 erroneous Central Depository (CDP) statements in May 2015 due to human error in the printing process. The exchange initially stated that less than one percent of statements were affected, but later confirmed the issue. Corrected statements have been mailed out, and customer service officers will contact affected account holders to address any questions or concerns.

site_title: US home builder sentiment rises in June: NAHB
summary: US homebuilder sentiment rose to its highest level since September, reaching 59 in the NAHB/Wells Fargo Housing Market index in June, surpassing economists' expectations of a 56 reading. This marks the first time the index has been above 50 since June 2014, indicating more builders view market conditions as favorable than poor.

site_title: China may be Indonesia's top investor if Widodo can smooth the way
summary: China is poised to become Indonesia's top foreign investor, with plans to invest over $83 billion, surpassing Singapore and Japan. President Joko Widodo's efforts to simplify business conduct may facilitate this influx of capital. China has expressed interest in investing in smelters, cement, and power plants. However, previous investments have largely failed to materialize. If successful, this investment could significantly boost Indonesia's economy and cement China's position as a major player in Southeast Asia.

site_title: New York state manufacturing activity worsens in June: NY Fed
summary: New York state manufacturing activity declined in June, reaching its weakest level in over two years, according to the New York Federal Reserve survey. The Empire State general business conditions index fell to -1.98, down from 3.09 in May, while new orders dropped to -2.12. Prices paid improved slightly, and employment gauges showed a rise in employees and workweek. The future business conditions index also fell to 25.84, the weakest since February, exceeding economists' expectations of a rise to 6.0.

site_title: Russian central bank cuts key rate by 1 percentage point
summary: Russia's central bank cut its main interest rate by 1 percentage point to 11.5% as inflation eases and the economy worsens. The move was in line with economists' predictions. The decision aims to stimulate economic growth amid a downturn.

site_title: ECB will keep funding lifeline for Greece open if banks solvent
summary: European Central Bank President Mario Draghi announced that the ECB will continue funding Greece's banks if they are solvent, with a total of 118 billion euros already provided. Draghi called for a "quantum leap" in the eurozone's organization and signaled limits to such assistance, including a prohibition on direct funding of governments by central banks. Talks between Greece and its eurozone backers collapsed, and Draghi urged the Greek government to demonstrate a credible perspective for a successful conclusion to the current review and implementation of the bailout program.

site_title: Europe raises heat on Greece to make further concessions
summary: European policymakers are pressuring Greece to make further concessions to unlock aid, following failed weekend talks. The European Central Bank's Mario Draghi stated that the Greek government must meet the demands of the negotiating parties. The policy divide remains unresolved, causing a decline in stocks and the euro. A "strong and comprehensive agreement" is needed, with the ball lying in the Greek government's court, according to Draghi.

site_title: Facebook plans new data centre in growing Irish cloud hub
summary: Facebook plans to build a new data centre in Ireland, its second in Europe, as part of the country's growing cloud hub. The centre, which will be energy-efficient, is the latest move by a technology giant to set up shop in Ireland, following Apple and Google. The country's low corporate tax rate and temperate climate have attracted major tech companies, with Microsoft also having a presence in Ireland. This investment is part of a larger trend of tech giants expanding their operations in Ireland.

site_title: Suzuki signs agreement with Malaysia's Proton to rebadge compact
summary: Suzuki Motor Corp has signed an agreement with Proton Holdings Bhd to assemble compact passenger cars using Suzuki's parts and sell them under the Proton brand in Malaysia. The first model will be built at the Proton plant in Tanjung Malim starting from August 2016. Suzuki's expertise in manufacturing compact cars will benefit Proton, with the collaboration aiming to leverage Suzuki's technology. A definitive agreement is expected to be signed by next year, with Suzuki and Proton also exploring additional models.

site_title: Greece contagion sweeps euro zone bond markets, hits shares
summary: Global financial markets experienced significant contagion from the Greek crisis on June 15, 2015, after 11th-hour talks between Greece and its creditors collapsed. The euro zone's bond markets signaled alarm, with the premium for holding Spanish and Italian government bonds over low-risk German Bunds reaching 2015 highs. European and Asian stocks fell, led by banks, and the euro weakened against the dollar. The US stock index futures also declined, and the prospect of a Greek default weighed heavily on sentiment.

images.alt_text: Global financial markets suffered their first bout of significant contagion from the Greek crisis this year on Monday after 11th-hour talks between the near bankrupt country and its creditors collapsed.

site_title: Asia's rich seek euros for bargains in apartments, luxe hotels
summary: Wealthy investors from Asia, including Singapore, China, and Malaysia, are seeking bargains in European real estate and hotels due to speculation that the euro is bottoming out. The euro's decline against Asian currencies has uncovered affordable properties, with over $8.6 billion in cross-border property investment by Asians in the first quarter. Investors are betting on the euro's potential recovery, with some predicting a strengthening of the currency against Asian peers in the next year.

site_title: Japan Q1 output gap narrows to -1.6%: Cabinet Office
summary: Japan's output gap narrowed to -1.6% in the first quarter, according to the Cabinet Office. This improvement suggests deflationary pressure is receding and is encouraging for the Bank of Japan's inflation target. Japan's GDP growth was revised up to a 3.9% annualized rate, and core consumer prices rose 0.3% on year in April. The narrowing output gap is important for the Bank of Japan, which aims to meet its 2% inflation target around the first half of 2016.

site_title: Singapore: STI slips 0.9% as failed Greece talks hit banks
summary: Singapore shares closed 0.9% lower on Monday as the Straits Times Index fell 30.72 points to 3,323.13, following Europe's failure to reach a deal on Greece. Banks, including DBS Group Holdings and United Overseas Bank, declined 1.1% and 1.4%, respectively. The market saw a net loss of 305 to 127 gainers, with Noble Group being the most actively traded stock.

site_title: Trade bodies urge regulators to sort out derivatives reporting
summary: Market participants, including banks and hedge funds, are urging regulators to resolve confusion over derivatives trades reporting, which was introduced to prevent another financial crisis. A letter to regulators calls for five action points to clarify the reporting requirements. The move comes as the industry seeks to ensure transparency and spot potential destabilizing risks early. The proposal aims to bring unity across the financial sector and address the confusion that has arisen since the reporting requirements began in 2014.

site_title: Hong Kong lawmakers say China-backed election plan will fail
summary: Hong Kong lawmakers are expected to reject a China-backed plan for the city's first direct election for chief executive, amid growing public opposition to the bill. Pro-democracy protesters, who have been marching and demonstrating against the plan, reported a lower turnout than predicted, reflecting a change in strategy. The plan, which would mandate the selection of candidates by a committee of elites, faces opposition from at least four pro-democracy legislators, making passage unlikely.

site_title: Saudi Arabian Airlines orders 50 Airbus worth US$8b
summary: Saudi Arabian Airlines ordered 50 Airbus planes worth US$8 billion, consisting of 20 A330-300 Regionals and 30 A320ceos. The medium-haul planes can carry 400 passengers and have a range of 5,000km, allowing the airline to increase capacity on popular regional routes. The A330-300 Regionals will be the first to be flown by the Saudi airline. The order is seen as a solution for markets with large populations and fast-growing air traffic flows.

site_title: Greek PM must consider election, referendum if talks fail: deputy speaker
summary: Greek Prime Minister Alexis Tsipras must consider calling a snap election or referendum if talks with creditors fail, a deputy speaker said. Talks collapsed over demands for less harsh terms, bringing Greece closer to a default that could exit the eurozone. The deputy speaker urged Tsipras to reconsider the national negotiating plan, giving the prime minister the authority to decide on a referendum or elections.

site_title: Majority of Singapore public tenders won by SMEs: study
summary: A study by VSC and NUS Business School found that 79% of public contracts in Singapore were won by small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs), surpassing multinational corporations (MNCs). The study also identified a strong correlation between a company's financial strength and success in winning public tenders.

images.alt_text: Fiona Lam

site_title: Oil declines a third day as US, Opec output prolongs surplus
summary: Oil prices declined for a third consecutive day, falling 1.2% in New York, amid concerns over the US and Opec's production levels. Despite a 27-week decline in US drill rigs, the nation's production reached a three-decade high of 9.61 million barrels a day. Opec's decision to maintain its output quota, led by Saudi Arabia, Iraq, and the UAE, is expected to keep global markets oversupplied. The decline in oil prices brings the three-day loss to 3.6%.

site_title: Air-traffic control spinoff from FAA sought by key US lawmaker
summary: US lawmakers propose spinning off the government-run air-traffic control system into a nonprofit corporation, seeking to insulate the Federal Aviation Administration from political interference and budget uncertainty. The move, backed by House Transportation and Infrastructure Committee Chairman Bill Shuster, would create a federally chartered, independent corporation governed by users of the aviation system, including airlines and unions. Funding would come from user fees, and the FAA would continue to set standards and oversee safety. The plan has been met with opposition from some powerful aviation interests and would require approval in a bill to renew the FAA's authorization.

site_title: Singapore Wrap Monday
summary: Singapore's total employment contracted by 6,100 in the first quarter, marking the first decline in five years. The drop is attributed to a decrease in the number of people employed. In other news, Vietnam expressed surprise over the US' announcement of tariffs on its garment industry, while Malaysia's agency plans to seize assets worth RM3 billion from Daim Zainuddin. China's GDP growth is expected to slow, putting pressure on policymakers. The US stock market is being targeted for higher tariffs, with Citigroup predicting a target of 1,150 for the MSCI global equity index by mid-2026.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks slip as Greek debt talks collapse
summary: Tokyo stocks fell 0.09% on Monday as Greece's debt reform talks collapsed, sparking fears of a default and eurozone exit. The Nikkei 225 index dropped 19.29 points to close at 20,387.79. The broader Topix index edged up 0.03% to 1,651.92. The collapse of Greece's talks added to market uncertainty, particularly amid US-China trade tensions and a split Federal Reserve.

site_title: Singapore retail sales up 5% in April
summary: Singapore's retail sales expanded 5% in April, driven by double-digit sales growth in motor vehicles. The total retail sales value reached S$3.3 billion, up from S$3.1 billion a year ago. Excluding vehicle sales, retail sales decreased 0.7% year on year.

images.alt_text: Nisha Ramchandani

site_title: Midas associate NPRT secures 2.1b yuan worth of metro, tram contracts in China
summary: Midas Holdings' joint venture NPRT secured 2.1 billion yuan worth of metro and tram contracts in China, including a 971 million yuan contract for Hefei Urban Rail Transit and an 808 million yuan contract for Shanghai Rail Transit Line 8 Phase 3. Additional contracts worth 326 million yuan were awarded for Suzhou New District Tramway. Delivery is scheduled between 2016 and 2017, expected to contribute positively to Midas' financial performance for FY2016 and FY2017.

site_title: Germany says 'the ball is in Greece's court' in debt talks
summary: Germany's finance ministry says it's up to Greece to make proposals to reach a deal with creditors, stating "the ball is in Greece's court" in debt talks. Greece faces an end-of-month deadline to repay 1.6 billion euros and is seeking reforms in return for the last 7.2 billion euros of its 240-billion-euro bailout. Germany's chancellor Angela Merkel's basic position remains unchanged, with Berlin seeking Greece to remain in the eurozone and agree on a reform package that leads to necessary fiscal and structural results.

images.alt_text: Germany's finance ministry said Monday it is now up to Greece to make proposals to reach a deal with its creditors that will save it from default in down-to-the-wire talks.

site_title: Oil prices down in Asian trade
summary: Oil prices fell in Asia on Monday as dealers worried about Greece's debt crisis and a possible return of Iranian supplies. US benchmark West Texas Intermediate dropped seven cents to $59.89 and Brent crude eased seven cents to $63.80. Analysts cited the euro's decline and investors' focus on Iran's nuclear deal deadline as factors. A potential agreement would ease sanctions on Iran's petroleum industry, but for now, oil prices remain volatile due to global economic uncertainty.

site_title: Athens: Stocks plunge more than 6% after talks collapse
summary: The Athens stock market plummeted over 6% on Monday after debt talks between Greece and its creditors collapsed, raising fears of a Greek default and exit from the euro. Greek Prime Minister Alexis Tsipras stated that Athens would "wait patiently" for a more realistic offer. The collapse follows a failed weekend of talks in Brussels.

site_title: Saudi stock market opens to foreigners
summary: Saudi Arabia's stock market opened to foreign investors, allowing qualified foreign investors to trade shares in the Arab world's largest exchange. The Tadawul All-Shares Index began trading under new rules on Monday, marking a significant opening up of the conservative Islamic kingdom to the global economy. Foreign banks and investors are now allowed to invest directly, provided they meet the requirements. Analysts do not expect a sudden rush of funds, and the move is seen as a step towards further integration with the global economy.

site_title: Indonesia delays start date for palm export levy to July 1: minister
summary: Indonesia has delayed the implementation date of its planned levy on crude palm oil exports to July 1 from June 15 due to administrative issues. The export levy, part of new biodiesel regulations, requires exporters to pay a levy of US$50 per tonne of crude palm oil and US$30 for processed palm oil products. The regulations aim to stabilize the global palm oil market and generate revenue for the government. The delay is expected to have minimal impact on the market, which had already been anticipating the levy.

site_title: China's central bank appoints new policy advisers
summary: China's central bank has appointed three new economic professors - Fan Gang, Huang Yiping, and Bai Chong-en - as advisers to its monetary policy committee, replacing Qian Yingyi, Chen Yulu, and Song Guoqing. The new advisers come from China's elite universities, Peking University and Tsinghua University. The appointments are part of scheduled changes to the advisory committee, which meets quarterly to discuss the economy and recommend policy changes. However, the central bank's influence is limited by the need for senior Chinese leaders' approval for interest rate decisions.

site_title: SNP threatens fresh referendum unless Scotland gets more powers: FT
summary: The Scottish National Party (SNP) has threatened to call for another referendum to break up the UK unless the British government agrees to devolve more powers to Scotland. The party's Treasury spokesman, Stewart Hosie, stated that if London fails to go further than the proposed devolution measures, another ballot could be triggered within a few years. This comes after Scotland rejected independence in a referendum last year, and the SNP is pushing for amendments to allow the Scottish parliament to claim new powers.

site_title: Tsipras hardens Greek stance after collapse of bailout talks
summary: Greece and its creditors exchanged recriminations after a last-ditch attempt to bridge differences in bailout talks collapsed. Prime Minister Alexis Tsipras portrayed Greece as a democracy facing unrealistic demands, while Chancellor Angela Merkel's caucus leader said Greeks must reconcile with reality. The collapse of talks has raised concerns over Greece's ability to avoid default and its continued euro membership. A June 18 meeting of euro-area finance ministers may decide Greece's fate, with markets already plummeting in response to the breakdown.

images.alt_text: Greece and its creditors swapped recriminations over who was to blame for the breakdown of bailout talks, as each side hardened its position after a last- gasp attempt to bridge differences collapsed in acrimony.

site_title: Hong Kong: Shares close down on China slump, political concerns
summary: Hong Kong stocks dropped 1.5% on Monday, following weak China markets and ahead of a potentially volatile vote that could spark mass protests. The Hang Seng index fell to 26,861.81, while the China Enterprises Index declined 2.6% to 13,622.76 points. China's markets fell 2% due to IPO and margin tightening worries. The decline in Hong Kong stocks reflects the region's sensitivity to China's economic concerns and potential political instability.

site_title: KrisEnergy launches S$169.5m rights issue to support growth in oil and gas production
summary: KrisEnergy, an upstream oil and gas company, has launched a S$169.5 million rights issue to support its capital expenditure in growing oil and gas production. The rights issue will generate approximately S$165.6 million, with 440 million new shares issued at S$0.385 each, representing a 13.5% discount to the closing price. The proceeds will be used to fund existing fields and near-term development projects, aiming to increase oil and gas production.

site_title: Shrinking western banks prompt Dubai's DIFC to shift sights east
summary: Dubai's Dubai International Financial Centre (DIFC) is shifting its focus from Western banks to Asian and African institutions, aiming to triple its financial firms to 1,000 by 2024. This pivot comes as Western banks grapple with rising capital requirements, regulatory scrutiny, and slower growth following the global financial crisis. DIFC Governor Essa Kazim stated that the center will rely mainly on Asian and African institutions using Dubai as a hub to expand, driven by the need for growth and diversification in the face of Western banking challenges.

site_title: Europe: Stocks slide at open as Greek talks collapse
summary: Europe's main stock markets began trading on Monday with a decline, as fears of a Greek euro exit intensified after talks with creditors collapsed. London's FTSE 100 slid 0.52%, Frankfurt's DAX 30 lost 1.28%, and Paris's CAC 40 fell 1.15%. The collapse of negotiations raises concerns of a Greek default, which could lead to the country exiting the eurozone and repaying billions of euros in loans by the end of the month. Analysts doubt a solution can be reached, citing Greece's refusal to make concessions on pension issues.

site_title: MGCCT's Sandhill Plaza acquisition will enhance portfolio diversification: Moody's
summary: Mapletree Greater China Commercial Trust (MGCCT) has acquired Sandhill Plaza in Shanghai for 1,888.1 million yuan (S$412.2 million), enhancing portfolio diversification and reducing reliance on its Hong Kong asset. The acquisition adds a third income-generating asset, with greater geographical diversification within China. Moody's Investors Service maintains the trust's Baa1 issuer rating with a stable outlook, citing the Shanghai asset's addition as a positive factor. The trust's existing portfolio includes a shopping mall in Hong Kong and an office building in Beijing.

site_title: Hong Kong police seize explosives ahead of political reform vote
summary: Hong Kong police seized explosives, including triacetone triperoxide (TATP), and arrested 9 radical group members ahead of a crucial vote on political reform. The arrests were made without confirming a direct link to the vote. The explosives and chemical substances were found in suspects' homes. The vote on Hong Kong's chief executive selection in 2017 has sparked widespread protests, with pro-democracy lawmakers vowing to veto Beijing's proposed direct vote for pre-screened candidates.

site_title: Second small oil tanker goes missing in Malaysia this month
summary: A small oil tanker, the MT Orkim Harmony, carrying 7.5 million litres of petrol, has gone missing off the coast of southern Malaysia near Singapore. The 7,300 DWT vessel, operated by Orkim Ship Management, lost contact on June 12. This is the second reported hijacking of a vessel by the company since June 4, when the 7,100 DWT oil tanker Orkim Victory was hijacked in the same area. An official briefing by the Malaysian Maritime Enforcement Agency (MMEA) is scheduled for 0700 GMT.

site_title: Singapore mobile operators to cease 2G services from April 2017
summary: Singapore's three major mobile operators, M1, Singtel, and StarHub, will cease 2G services by April 1, 2017. The majority of mobile customers have already migrated to 3G and 4G networks, leaving only a small percentage using 2G-only devices. The spectrum used for 2G will be repurposed for faster 3G and 4G services. This move aims to upgrade the mobile network infrastructure and provide better services to customers.

images.alt_text: Mindy Tan

site_title: Oil prices down in Asian trade
summary: Oil prices fell in Asian trade on June 15, 2015, as dealers worried about Greece's debt crisis and potential Iranian supply disruptions. US benchmark West Texas Intermediate fell 20 cents to $59.76, while Brent crude eased 37 cents to $63.50. Analysts closely tracked the Greek debt crisis and Iran negotiations, citing concerns over the global market.

site_title: Euro drops after Greek debt talks collapse
summary: The euro dropped to US$1.1220 and 138.50 yen after Greek debt talks collapsed, bringing the threat of a Greek exit from the eurozone closer. Negotiations broke down on Sunday with both sides blaming the other's refusal to back down on certain issues. Investors are now waiting for a Thursday meeting of the eurozone's 19 finance ministers, who control the bailout purse strings, and fear that a deal may not be reached in time. The eurozone's financial crisis is intensifying, with Greece's cash-starved government facing a huge IMF debt payment at the end of the month.

site_title: With CEO shakeup, Twitter under pressure to please advertisers
summary: Twitter faces pressure to appease advertisers following CEO Dick Costolo's sudden resignation amid concerns over increasing the user base and improving direct response advertising, the most lucrative type on the microblogging site. Interim CEO Jack Dorsey is not seen as a long-term solution, with many advertisers backing Adam Bain, the company's president and head of revenue, as the best candidate to address advertisers' demands. Bain's experience in monetizing advertising platforms and understanding the media business make him a key figure in helping Twitter meet advertisers' demands and increase revenue.

site_title: Industrial site on Jurong Island up for sale by expression of interest
summary: TEIJIN Polycarbonate Singapore has listed its 1.5 million sq ft industrial facility on Jurong Island for sale by expression of interest. The site has a 12-year remaining tenure with an option to renew for another 30 years, and is zoned for "Business 2" use. This is considered a rare opportunity for private sale, with long-term industrial land leases becoming increasingly rare.

images.alt_text: Mindy Tan

site_title: Indonesia posts US$950m trade surplus in May
summary: Indonesia posted a trade surplus of US$950 million for May, its sixth straight surplus, driven by weak imports and declining exports. Imports dropped 21.40% to US$11.61 billion, while exports fell 15.24% to US$12.56 billion. This marks the eighth straight month of declining imports and exports. The surplus surpasses analysts' expectations of a US$410 million surplus.

site_title: ICBC Singapore launches US$-S$ dual currency credit card
summary: ICBC Singapore has launched a dual currency credit card that combines US dollar and Singapore dollar accounts, allowing customers to make payments in either currency with zero administrative fees. This move aims to ease costs associated with cross-border transactions. The bank is also offering incentives for new applications, including cashback rewards. This is the bank's second dual currency credit card, following the launch in 2011.

images.alt_text: Industrial and Commercial Bank of China (ICBC) Singapore has launched a dual currency credit card that combines US dollar and Singapore dollar customer accounts, it said in a press release on Monday.

site_title: Developers sold 638 Singapore private condo units in May
summary: Developers in Singapore sold 638 private condo units in May, down from 1,167 units in April. The top-selling project was Westwood Residences, which sold 118 units at a median price of S$803 per square foot. Other notable sales included UOL's Botanique at Bartley (94 units) and Frasers Centrepoint's North Park Residences (59 units). Total residential units sold by developers reached 845 units, with the total cumulative sales for these projects exceeding 1,000 units.

site_title: Schools reopen as South Korea seeks normality in Mers outbreak
summary: South Korea reopened thousands of schools nearly four weeks into an Mers outbreak, with five new cases reported, bringing the total to 150. The Health Ministry also confirmed the 16th fatality. Four hospitals have been shut down, and over 10,000 people are in quarantine. Schools were allowed to reopen after the World Health Organization recommended it, citing no link between schools and Mers transmission. The reopening comes as South Korea seeks normalcy, with President Park Geun-hye urging businesses to continue as usual and reassuring consumers.
