site_title: Tech costs beat regulation, cyber attacks as worries for financial services execs
summary: Financial services executives worldwide cite rising IT costs as their top concern, surpassing regulation and cyber attacks. The survey by global risk adviser Willis found IT costs to be the second-highest worry, followed by macroeconomic concerns such as quantitative easing. Regulation and cyber crime were the third and fourth-highest concerns, respectively. The survey suggests that financial institutions are struggling to keep pace with new technology, potentially allowing newcomers to gain market share.

site_title: Gold treads water as strong dollar offsets haven bids from Greek crisis
summary: Gold prices remained flat on Monday as a stronger US dollar offset safe-haven bids following the failure of Greece and its creditors to reach a deal on a debt default. The metal traded in a narrow range ahead of the Federal Reserve's policy meeting later this week, which may provide clues on US interest rates. A rate hike could boost the dollar and diminish demand for non-interest-paying gold. Holdings in the world's largest gold-backed ETF are at their lowest since 2008, with hedge funds and money managers slashing their net long stance in gold.

site_title: Honda reports another death in exploding airbag crisis
summary: Honda has reported a new death linked to an exploding airbag crisis, bringing the global total to seven fatalities and scores of injuries. A woman in Louisiana died in April after the faulty inflator in her 2005 Honda Civic's airbag ruptured, firing metal shrapnel. The defect, linked to a chemical propellant, can cause airbags to deploy with explosive force. Honda is the most heavily affected by the recall, which has also affected Toyota, Ford, General Motors, Nissan, and BMW, with nearly 34 million vehicles recalled worldwide.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks down 0.68% at open
summary: Hong Kong stocks fell 0.68% in opening trade on June 15, 2015, following losses on Wall Street and concerns over Greece's debt talks. The Hang Seng Index eased to 27,095.18. Investors were spooked by the collapse in Greece's debt talks, increasing the likelihood of a default and exit from the eurozone.

site_title: Australia tells Indonesia to fix its borders
summary: Australia's Foreign Minister Julie Bishop told Indonesia to improve border security after Jakarta demanded answers to allegations that Australia paid to turn back asylum-seekers. The claims, made to Indonesian police, involved a boat captain and crew being paid US$5,000 each to return to Indonesia. Indonesia called the allegations a "new low" for Australia's handling of the issue, prompting Bishop to rebuke the country to "fix its borders." The dispute highlights the complexities of asylum seeker policies in the region.

site_title: Varoufakis rules out 'Grexit', deal possible if Merkel takes part
summary: Greece's Finance Minister Yanis Varoufakis ruled out a 'Grexit' as a sensible solution to the Greek debt crisis, stating a debt restructuring is the only way forward. He said a deal could be possible if Chancellor Angela Merkel takes part, and Greece would forego further aid in exchange for a debt haircut. Varoufakis stated the austerity program has failed and that a clean sweep is needed. Talks with creditors broke up in failure, with EU officials blaming Athens for not offering new concessions to secure funding.

images.alt_text: Greece Finance Minister Yanis Varoufakis said he could rule out a 'Grexit' because it would not be a sensible solution to the Greek debt crisis and in a German newspaper interview on Monday also said a debt restructuring was the only way forward.

site_title: AVJennings acquires right to develop land in New South Wales
summary: AVJennings has acquired the right to develop a land parcel at Warnervale in New South Wales, expected to produce around 540 lots. This follows recent land acquisitions in Victoria, including 2,000 lots and 850 apartments. Managing director Peter Summers stated the deal is part of AVJ's strategy to build a land bank in key markets, securing a pipeline of projects to deliver quality residential communities.

images.alt_text: Mindy Tan

site_title: Taiwan: Stocks down, HTC up on technical rebound
summary: Taiwan's main TAIEX index fell 0.1% to 9,293.16 on Monday, following Asian markets. The financials index gained 0.4% while the electronics index declined 0.1%. HTC Corp shares rose 9.3% after rebounding from a sharp decline last week, while China Development Financial gained 0.8%. The Taiwan dollar strengthened to T$30.983 to the US dollar, amid a lack of domestic cues and concerns about Greece.

site_title: AirAsia eyes up to US$300m bond issuance, jet sales to raise funds
summary: AirAsia plans to issue up to $300 million in bonds and sell up to 20 aircraft to raise funds. The move comes after a report questioned the airline's accounting practices, leading to a 2.2% drop in shares. CEO Tony Fernandes revealed the plans in a letter to investors, stating some details are still work-in-progress. The airline aims to diversify its funding sources and strengthen its financial position.

site_title: Asia: Stocks, euro down as Greek talks fall apart
summary: Asian stocks and the euro fell on Monday due to concerns Greece could default on its debts, following failed debt reform talks with its creditors. The euro sank to US$1.1220, while the eurozone's stock markets fell 0.14-0.70% in Tokyo, Hong Kong, and Sydney. The collapse of talks raises the spectre of Greece crashing out of the eurozone, which could lead to a default and economic instability.

site_title: Mers cases in South Korea rise to 150 with 5 more, 1 death
summary: South Korea's Mers cases rose to 150, with 5 new cases and 1 death, the 16th fatality. The outbreak, the largest outside Saudi Arabia, began in May.

site_title: Former PetroChina vice chairman to be prosecuted for graft
summary: Former PetroChina Vice Chairman Liao Yongyuan has been expelled from the Communist Party and will be prosecuted for bribery, corruption, and other crimes. He was accused of abusing his position, taking enormous bribes, and being an adulterer. Liao, a 30-year veteran at PetroChina, was the company's second-highest ranking official. The Communist Party's graft watchdog had previously investigated him for "serious disciplinary violations" stemming from his role at PetroChina's parent company, China National Petroleum Corporation. This latest move is part of President Xi Jinping's ongoing corruption crackdown.

images.alt_text: A garbage collector stands in front of a PetroChina company logo at its gas station in Shanghai. Former PetroChina Vice Chairman Liao Yongyuan has been expelled from the Communist Party and will be prosecuted for crimes including bribery, the party said on Monday, the latest official caught up in a sweeping corruption crackdown.

site_title: Singapore's total employment dips for first time in 5 years: MOM
summary: Singapore's total employment contracted by 6,100 in the first quarter of 2015, marking the first time in five years. The country's total employment stood at 3,617,800 in March, a 2.7% increase from the previous year. The unemployment rate declined to 1.8% in March, with fewer redundancies. Despite this, the labor market remained tight, with job openings outnumbering job seekers.

images.alt_text: Lee U-Wen

site_title: Japan PM Abe's support lowest since 2012 amid doubts about security bills
summary: Japanese Prime Minister Shinzo Abe's cabinet support has fallen to 41.1% amid opposition to his security bills, which would allow Japan to exercise collective self-defence and aid a friendly country under attack. The bills face criticism that they violate the pacifist constitution and have sparked widespread protests, with 62.5% of voters opposing the exercise of collective self-defence and 63.7% opposing the legislation's enactment. Abe's support has dropped to its lowest level since taking office in 2012, raising concerns about the passage of the bills in parliament.

site_title: Malaysia: Share opens flat on Monday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index opened flat on Monday at 1733.28, with 62 gains outweighing 61 losses. The country's shares saw little movement amidst global market trends.

site_title: Shares of Malaysia's AirAsia fall 1.7%
summary: Shares of Malaysia's AirAsia fell 1.7% on Monday, declining as much as 1.7% amid concerns over accounting practices. The airline's long-haul arm AirAsia X was flat. The decline was underperformed by the benchmark stock index, which fell 0.06%.

site_title: Alibaba group plans to create China version of Netflix, HBO
summary: Alibaba Group plans to launch a Chinese version of Netflix and HBO, called Tmall Box Office, in about two months. The service will be offered through Alibaba's set-top boxes and smart TVs, featuring both in-house and overseas content. The move aims to capture China's growing online video market, valued at an estimated 90 billion yuan by 2018. Alibaba's goal is to become a major player in the market, similar to US-based Netflix and HBO.

site_title: Australia: Shares fall as Greece weighs
summary: Australian shares fell 0.5% on Monday, marking a second consecutive session of decline, amid uncertainty over Greece's euro membership and the US Federal Reserve's policy statement. The S&P/ASX 200 index dropped 27 points to 5,517.7. Financials, led by Westpac's 1% decline, were a major drag, while energy stocks fell nearly 2% due to oil price concerns. The benchmark index is on track for its fourth straight month of losses in June, down 4.6% so far this month.

site_title: Foxtel to take 15% stake in Ten network in A$154 million raising
summary: Foxtel will acquire a 15% stake in Ten Network Holdings Ltd. as part of a $154 million capital raising. Foxtel will pay 15 Australian cents per share for the $77 million stake, representing a 43% discount from Ten's closing price. The deal aims to reduce Ten's debt and improve its ratings and revenue performance. Ten will also gain a 25% stake in Multi Channel Network and a two-year option to join Presto's board, with Foxtel's representative to join Ten's board.

site_title: Oil prices fall on oversupply, but US crude supported by Gulf of Mexico storm
summary: Oil prices declined on Monday due to oversupply, but US crude prices were supported by a potential storm in the Gulf of Mexico that could disrupt operations. Saudi Arabia hinted at increasing production above record levels, leading to lower prices. US crude fell 26 cents to $59.70 a barrel, while Brent futures dropped 44 cents to $63.43 a barrel. The US National Hurricane Center predicted a 70% chance of a tropical cyclone developing in the region, potentially impacting oil production.

site_title: Singapore fund that sold homes to Blackstone says market costly
summary: A Singapore fund, SC Capital Partners, has expressed concerns over the country's housing market, stating that prices need to drop another 30% to make investments attractive again. The fund, which booked a loss from the sale of apartments to Blackstone Group LP, believes that prices will not decline until the government removes curbs on the market. Despite this, some investors, including Blackstone CEO Steven Schwarzman, expect the restrictions to be lifted over time.

site_title: Japan Inc faces stormy AGMs in governance shake-up
summary: Japan's corporate governance is set to undergo a significant shake-up as companies face increased pressure from investors at upcoming annual general meetings (AGMs). The new corporate governance code and stewardship code require companies to appoint multiple outside directors, engage with shareholders, and consider the views of those who oppose management-backed proposals. This may lead to strong dissent at companies like Sharp Corp, Toshiba Corp, and Sony Corp, which are already facing challenges. Despite the increased scrutiny, investors in Japan are enjoying record returns, and companies are responding by implementing measures to boost shareholder returns.

site_title: China, US armies agree to framework for dialogue
summary: The US and Chinese armies agreed on a framework for dialogue, aiming to reduce the risk of miscalculation or accidents during air-to-air encounters. The pact, signed in Washington, will be augmented with guidelines to be implemented next year, potentially leading to joint land exercises. The agreement comes ahead of Chinese President Xi Jinping's planned visit to the US and amid rising tensions in the South China Sea. The dialogue framework is expected to open a new channel for leaders to discuss issues like humanitarian assistance and disaster response practices.

images.alt_text: The US and Chinese armies have agreed on a framework for dialogue, and will soon augment a shared code of conduct with guidelines to avert errors or mishaps when their aircraft operate near each other, the China Daily newspaper reported.

site_title: Malaysian- flagged tanker missing in South China Sea: piracy watchdog
summary: A Malaysian-flags tanker, MT Orkim Harmony, carrying petrol, has gone missing in the South China Sea. The International Maritime Bureau reported that the last contact with the ship was late on Thursday. The vessel is feared hijacked, prompting concerns about piracy in the region. Authorities are investigating the incident, but no further information is available at this time.

site_title: Lippo Malls markets Singapore dollar bond at low 4% area
summary: Lippo Malls Indonesia Retail Trust launched a Singapore dollar bond offering at a price guidance of low 4% yield. The $750 million, five-year bonds will be issued through OCBC and Standard Chartered, with HSBC serving as trustee and guarantor. The proceeds will likely be used for merger-and-acquisition purposes and refinancing debt, following the trust's recent $260 million term loan from BNP Paribas and StanChart. Moody's recently assigned a Baa3 rating to the trust, citing its $1.8 billion net lettable area and expected currency hedging.

site_title: Mapletree Greater China trust buys Sandhill Plaza in Shanghai for S$402m
summary: MAPLETREE Greater China Commercial Trust (MGCCT) has acquired Sandhill Plaza in Shanghai for approximately S$402 million. The acquisition, valued at 1,888.1 million renminbi, includes the property and working capital adjustments. MGCCT's CEO, Cindy Chow, stated that the acquisition aligns with the trust's strategy to invest in premium real estate assets in the Greater China region, marking the start of growing MGCCT through accretive acquisitions.

images.alt_text: Mindy Tan

site_title: China: Stocks fall in Hong Kong as stimulus bets don't pan out
summary: China's stocks in Hong Kong fell for the first time in three days, as stimulus bets didn't materialize, leading to declines in financial and industrial companies. The Hang Seng China Enterprises Index dropped 1.3% to 13,804.51, while the Hang Seng Index retreated 0.9%. Analysts attributed the drop to concerns over controlling risks and fragile sentiment, following data showing slumping exports and producer prices. Margin debt on the Shanghai Stock Exchange reached a record 1.45 trillion yuan, prompting brokerages to limit margin trading and short selling.

site_title: In US$8b Samsung bid, some Koreans break ranks to side with foreign activists
summary: Hundreds of Samsung C&T Corp small investors in South Korea are protesting a proposed $8 billion merger with Cheil Industries Inc, citing a low-ball offer that undervalues the conglomerate. The investors, known as "ants," are siding with US hedge fund Elliott Associates LP, which opposes the deal. The unusual move challenges the traditional dominance of the Lee family's conglomerate and could lead to a reevaluation of the powerful families' influence in the country's economy.

site_title: LSE gets Hong Kong regulatory nod to HK firms to become LSE members
summary: The London Stock Exchange (LSE) has received approval from the Hong Kong Securities and Futures Commission to allow Hong Kong trading firms to become LSE members. This move enables direct access to Europe's most liquid markets, further strengthening the financial ties between the UK and Greater China. Hong Kong trading firms will gain access to the LSE's derivatives market, enhancing their global trading capabilities.

images.alt_text: London Stock Exchange said on Monday it has received approval from Securities and Futures Commission to allow Hong Kong trading firms to become members of the LSE.

site_title: Clinton urges Obama to work with Pelosi on trade deal
summary: Hillary Clinton urged President Barack Obama to work with congressional Democrats, including Nancy Pelosi, on a proposed Pacific trade deal, pushing for tougher labor protections. Clinton said Obama should try to get rid of objectionable parts and drive a harder bargain, warning that "there should be no deal" if the terms are not favorable. Her comments came after a trade package was rejected last week, and critics on both left and right have criticized her for not taking a stand on the Trans-Pacific Partnership.

images.alt_text: Democratic presidential front-runner Hillary Clinton (pictured) on Sunday urged President Barack Obama to work with congressional Democrats who rejected his trade agenda last week, and to seek tougher labour protections in a proposed Pacific trade deal.

site_title: Singapore: STI opens 0.43% down on Monday
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) opened 0.43% down on Monday, with 61.1 million shares changing hands. The decline comes after a failed attempt to reach a euro-area bailout agreement in Brussels. The STI fell 14.28 points to 3,339.57, with losers outnumbering gainers 92 to 57. The index had rallied 0.4% on Thursday despite US tariff uncertainty and split Fed views.

images.alt_text: Mindy Tan

site_title: Hot stock: Noble continues share buyback
summary: NOBLE Group has purchased an additional 25 million shares at S$0.6728 each, totaling S$16.86 million. This brings the total number of shares bought to 50 million, equivalent to 0.74% of outstanding shares. The company has now spent a total of S$33.63 million on share buybacks since the program began.

images.alt_text: Noble Group has bought a further 25 million shares at S$0.6728 each, said the group on Monday. The total consideration for the shares, which were purchased on Friday, is S$16.86 million.
Mindy Tan

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open 0.99% lower
summary: Tokyo stocks opened 0.99% lower on Monday, June 15, 2015, due to concerns over Greece's possible default and exit from the euro. Last-ditch talks between Athens and its EU-IMF creditors collapsed, increasing the threat of default. The Nikkei 225 index fell 201.98 points to 20,205.10, following a 0.78% decline in the Dow Jones Industrial Average on Wall Street. The euro also fell, buying US$1.1222 against US$1.1260.

site_title: Ezra wins subsea contracts worth over US$115m
summary: Ezra Holdings' subsea services division secured contracts valued over US$115 million, including a rigid pipe lay contract for the Aviat field development in the UK North Sea. The company will also undertake engineering and offshore support work in West Africa with a subsidiary and deploy the Lewek Centurion for subsea pipeline and well operations in Asia. CEO Lionel Lee stated the contracts demonstrate Ezra's position in the North Sea and opportunities from a framework agreement with Apache.

images.alt_text: Mindy Tan

site_title: Euro drops after Greek debt talks collapse
summary: The euro dropped to US$1.1222 and 138.50 yen after Greek debt talks with creditors collapsed, increasing fears of a Greek exit from the common currency. The euro had already fallen in anticipation of the crisis, with Greek stocks and bonds also declining. Investors are now waiting for a meeting of eurozone finance ministers on Thursday, which could trigger sharp falls in the euro if negative news emerges. Despite two rescue programs worth 240 billion euros, Greece's economy remains shattered.

site_title: UK asking prices for homes hit new high after election
summary: The average asking price for homes in England and Wales reached a new record high of £294,351 (S$614,426) after the UK national election, according to Rightmove. This represents a 3% monthly increase from May 10 to June 6. London prices surged by nearly 6% following a previous 2.3% drop due to concerns over the Labour Party's proposed "Mansion Tax".

images.alt_text: The average asking price for homes in England and Wales hit a new record high as buyers returned to the market after last month's national election, property website Rightmove said on Monday.

site_title: Hospital at centre of South Korea's Mers suspends services as death toll reaches 15
summary: South Korea's Samsung Medical Center has suspended most services due to the spread of Middle East Respiratory Syndrome (Mers), a deadly respiratory disease that has killed 15 people since its diagnosis in the country nearly four weeks ago. The World Health Organization (WHO) has called an emergency meeting to discuss the outbreak, which has surpassed 145 cases and is believed to be linked to hospitals. The hospital's failure to properly manage emergency room staff is being blamed for the spread of the disease, with nearly 200 people coming into contact with an infected orderly.

site_title: Swiss face recession threat with rate firepower seen near empty
summary: The Swiss National Bank is facing a recession threat with its interest-rate firepower nearly depleted, according to President Thomas Jordan. The SNB's deposit rate is at a record low of minus 0.75% and is unlikely to cut rates further without risking a cash run. Economists predict a 0.2% contraction in GDP this quarter, marking the first recession since 2009. The SNB will announce its interest-rate decision on Thursday, with no policy change forecast but warnings of readiness to act if the outlook worsens due to the Greek debt crisis and euro area instability.

site_title: China to extend economic diplomacy to EU infrastructure fund
summary: China is set to pledge a multi-billion dollar investment in Europe's new infrastructure fund, expected to come with a request for return investment in its "One Belt, One Road" plan. The pledge, made at a Brussels summit on June 29, is part of China's efforts to shape global economic governance and follows major EU governments' decision to join the Chinese-led Asian Infrastructure Investment Bank. In return, China wants European companies and governments to take a greater interest in its initiative, which aims to create a modern Silk Road Economic Belt across Central, West, and South Asia.

site_title: Goldman dives back into high-speed stock trading
summary: Goldman Sachs is reviving its high-speed stock trading unit, hiring executives and investing in software and infrastructure, amid pressure from competitors. The bank, which had previously called for reforms in the practice, now seeks to execute faster and catch up with rivals. Goldman Sachs plans to pitch its improved systems to customers, highlighting fill rates and aiming to win business from quantitative hedge funds. The move is expected to boost revenue growth, with the bank potentially achieving a double-digit growth rate in revenue from these clients.

site_title: Italy threatens to 'hurt' Europe if not given help with migrants
summary: Italy's Prime Minister Matteo Renzi threatened to implement "Plan B" to deal with migrants if Europe doesn't provide greater help, stating it would "hurt Europe." Over 57,000 migrants have been rescued and brought to Italy this year, with Rome seeking other countries to shoulder part of the burden. Italy wants the EU to share the cost of repatriating economic migrants and to change the Dublin Convention, which leaves Italy to deal with asylum seekers.

site_title: Stay disciplined and diversified: retirement planner
summary: A retirement planner advises investors to maintain a disciplined and diversified portfolio to ride out market crashes, rather than chasing short-term performance. This is due to the risk of increasing exposure to underperforming investments. By diversifying, investors can reduce risk and achieve long-term financial goals.

site_title: Fifa official urges Blatter not to go back on quit promise
summary: Fifa's head of audit and compliance, Domenico Scala, urged Sepp Blatter not to go back on his resignation promise, calling reforms "indispensable." Blatter, who announced his resignation on June 2, has been under pressure following corruption allegations and a call from the European Parliament for him to step down. Scala's statement came after reports suggested Blatter might reconsider his decision, citing messages of support from Asian and African federations. A date for Blatter's successor will be determined by the end of the year, with an extraordinary meeting set for July 20.

site_title: Japan targets 20m tourist arrivals by 2020
summary: Japan aims to attract 20 million tourists by 2020, boosting its economy by nearly one percentage point in five years, with a projected contribution of 4 trillion yen to GDP. The government plans to increase the number of inbound tourists, targeting visitors from outside Asia, and encourage longer stays by promoting luxury experiences. To achieve this, the government will establish 20,000 tax-free shops and invest in eco-tourism and industrial tours, which are expected to create a virtuous cycle between tourism and exports.

site_title: Default dangerously closer after Greece debt talks collapse
summary: Greece's debt talks with EU-IMF creditors collapsed, bringing the threat of a Greek exit from the euro closer than ever. The negotiations failed due to the International Monetary Fund's intransigent demands, including further pension cuts and a rise in value-added tax. Greece's economy is heavily burdened with debt, equivalent to 180% of GDP, and the country faces significant IMF payments due by the end of the month. The European Commission and IMF have expressed a willingness to discuss a reform deal, but the outcome remains uncertain, with the Greek government refusing to implement tough reforms.

site_title: Geneva whodunit has Chinese alleging US$1.2 billion currency scam
summary: A Chinese investment scam allegedly targeted 29,000 investors, robbing them of US$1.2 billion. API Premiere Swiss Trust AG and associated companies promised returns of up to 10% a month, but the money disappeared from accounts in January. Protests have taken place in Beijing and Hong Kong, with Chinese investors demanding answers. The Swiss public prosecutor is investigating API and an associated company, and a Hong Kong court has filed a lawsuit against API Premiere Ltd. The scam has raised concerns about cross-border crime and the vulnerability of Chinese investors to international scams.

site_title: Share sale proceeds double in China, HK as firms ride stock market dragon
summary: Chinese companies have almost doubled their proceeds from share issues in initial public offerings and secondary markets, reaching US$63 billion so far this year, due to government policies and bullish stock market reports. The mainland market has risen 150% in the past year, with investors taking on greater risk as valuations outstrip fundamentals. New share issues by Chinese companies in China and Hong Kong are expected to continue, driven by financial firms, media and entertainment companies, and healthcare firms, as Beijing pushes to nurture China's soft power.

site_title: Ringgit sinks toward Asia-crisis peg as Zeti optimism not shared
summary: Malaysia's ringgit is sliding toward its 1998 peg of 3.80 per dollar, despite central bank assurances that the weakness will be temporary. The currency has fallen to within 0.7% of the peg, prompting concerns about the nation's economic fundamentals and the ability of Bank Negara to defend the currency. A weaker currency may help revive exports, but it also threatens inflationary pressure. Analysts predict the ringgit will breach the peg soon, with some estimating it will end the year at 3.95, and Fitch Ratings warns of a 50% chance of downgrading Malaysia's credit rating.

images.alt_text: Malaysia's ringgit is sliding toward its fixed exchange rate of a decade ago and central bank assurances the weakness will prove temporary aren't convincing everyone.

site_title: Total shuts down La Mede refinery over strike
summary: French oil major Total shut down its La Mede refinery in south-east France after a union launched a strike against plans to stop crude processing. The refinery, which processes 153,000 barrels of crude oil per day, will be halted by the end of 2016 due to declining demand for petroleum products in Europe. The move is part of Total's efforts to adapt to changing market conditions.

site_title: RadioShack files bankruptcy plan after stores' sale
summary: RadioShack Corp has filed a bankruptcy liquidation plan to distribute the remaining assets of its stores, following the sale of 1,700 locations and the rights to its name to Standard General LP. The hedge fund plans to run the locations under a co-branding arrangement with Sprint Corp. This move comes after the retailer struggled to stay afloat in the face of increased competition and declining sales. The distribution plan outlines how the remaining assets will be divided among creditors, with the goal of maximizing returns for stakeholders.

site_title: China to end entry permit requirement for Taiwanese
summary: China will lift an entry permit requirement for Taiwanese traveling to the mainland as part of efforts to reduce barriers between the two communities. Chairman of the Chinese People's Political Consultative Conference, Yu Zhengsheng, made the announcement in Xiamen, China. This move is seen as a step towards easing tensions and promoting exchanges between the two sides. China still views Taiwan as part of its territory awaiting reunification.

site_title: US data better, but Fed likely to hold off on rate rise
summary: The US economy appears to be rebounding, with consumers spending more, job creation rebounding, and wages rising. However, the Federal Reserve is likely to hold off on raising interest rates, as it wants to see more evidence of a firm tightening in the jobs market. Despite a strong May job creation report and rising wages, consumer spending remains cautious, and inflation remains below the Fed's target of 2%. The Fed is expected to wait a couple of months to move, with a potential September rate hike more likely.

site_title: Imperva CEO aims to wrest back security deals from IBM
summary: Imperva CEO Anthony Bettencourt is seeking to regain security deals from IBM, with whom the company lost 203 contracts from 2010 to 2015. Since Bettencourt's leadership, Imperva has more than doubled in stock value and won 39 deals against IBM in the last 18 months. Bettencourt aims to steal IBM's Guardium unit business, targeting contracts worth up to $200 million. Imperva's growth is driven by high-profile data breaches and its expanded product range, which analyst Andrew Nowinski says will help it win larger deals.

site_title: Australia's prolonged growth hinders deficit action
summary: Australia's prolonged economic growth has made households less concerned about budget deficits and debt, complicating efforts to adjust policy. Head of the government's financial system inquiry, David Murray, says the public is not well connected to the risks of debt and deficits, making it hard to make a case for policy adjustments. The government, aiming to shore up voter support, has stepped back from budget repair despite slowing growth and plunging commodity prices pushing Australia's finances further into the red. Murray urges a timely response to his review of the financial system to avoid market uncertainty.

site_title: Bumpy ride as India's taxi-app firms face safety concern, protesting cabbies
summary: India's ultra-competitive app-based taxi-hailing market is facing controversy over safety concerns and protesting cabbies. Ola Cabs and Uber, the dominant players, are booming despite the issues. The industry's rapid growth is threatened as cabbies reject licenses and demand better working conditions. The safety concerns and protests have sparked a debate about the industry's sustainability, potentially slowing its spectacular rise.

site_title: Doubts over EU's proposals for saving US trade deal
summary: The European Union's proposed Transatlantic Trade and Investment Partnership (TTIP) faces opposition due to concerns over investor rights, which could prevent governments from banning unsafe products or taxing businesses. The EU has made concessions, such as limiting the circumstances under which a claim can be made, but experts say the changes are not sufficient to address concerns. The treaty could add billions of euros to both the EU and US economies, but critics warn it may deter governments from introducing regulations that benefit citizens.

site_title: Proxy access: when shareholders nominate directors
summary: Proxy access, allowing shareholders to nominate directors, is gaining momentum globally, particularly in the US. Companies like Bank of America, General Electric, and Hewlett-Packard have adopted the "three and three" approach, allowing up to 20% of directors to be nominated by shareholders who own over 3% of the company's stock for at least three years. This reform aims to increase shareholder accountability and transparency, but opponents worry about activist investors and the potential cost of proxy access. Singapore's Companies Act already allows shareholders to nominate directors, but its use is limited by high ownership thresholds.

images.alt_text: In March, Bank of America changed its bylaws to let a group of up to 20 shareholders nominate up to 20% of its directors if they have owned over 3% of the company's stock for at least three years.

site_title: Tapas-sake bar menu with a lot of bite
summary: Boruto, a new sake and tapas bar in Singapore, offers a unique dining experience with dishes that blend Japanese flavors with Asian touches. The menu, designed by chef Max See, features dishes such as Saga beef tataki and Zuwai Gani sausage, which pair well with the bar's extensive selection of sakes. The restaurant's focus on balance and flavor, rather than traditional Japanese cuisine, sets it apart from other Japanese restaurants in Singapore. With a welcoming vibe and affordable prices, Boruto is a great option for those looking for a non-traditional Japanese dining experience.

site_title: Japan takes to the streets against Abe's security bills
summary: Thousands of Japanese protesters gathered outside the parliament building on Sunday to oppose Prime Minister Shinzo Abe's plans to bolster the nation's military. The protest came as Abe attempts to force through parliament a set of controversial bills that would expand the military's role and scope. The move has sparked widespread concern among the public, who fear it could undermine Japan's pacifist constitution. The protest is part of a growing backlash against Abe's nationalist policies, which have been met with significant opposition from both the public and lawmakers.

site_title: Record plane order books turn focus to jetmakers' production
summary: The Paris Airshow, set to take place from June 15-21, is expected to focus on production processes and supply chain viability rather than large plane orders, as the industry faces a daunting task of producing $1.8 trillion worth of jets sold. Analysts predict fewer multi-billion-dollar deals and more emphasis on execution and ramping up production output. Key players, including Boeing and Airbus, are under pressure to meet their commitments and balance market share with production demands, with some suppliers worried about investing in production lines that may not yield returns.

site_title: Fund managers' opaque practices give retirees the short end
summary: Retired US firefighters, police officers, teachers, and other employees who have pensions invested in private equity funds may be paying more for services due to opaque practices. A recent SEC investigation found 41 private equity firms, overseeing $600 billion in client assets, had actual or potential conflicts of interest, including discounts from lawyers and auditors not shared with investors. These discounts can result in higher fees for investors, while the firms reduce their own costs. Regulators have identified certain fees as problematic, and some pension funds, like CalPERS, are re-examining their private equity managers to reduce costs.

site_title: Unclear timing of rate hike causing Reit jitters
summary: Singapore Reit shares are experiencing volatility due to the unclear timing of the interest rate hike. Analysts expect a 25 basis point increase in interest rates in September, but some Reits may not have priced in the rate hike yet. Despite 80% of Reit borrowings being hedged, fears of a selldown still persist. The office and industrial property sectors are expected to face challenges, while retail is on a structural downtrend. Analysts recommend selective stock picking and a cautious approach, with some predicting a relief rally rather than a significant selloff.

site_title: Virtual reality gets real at US video game expo
summary: Virtual reality technology is expected to take center stage at the Electronic Entertainment Expo (E3) in Los Angeles, with major companies like Oculus and Sony showcasing their latest VR headsets and games. Oculus will demonstrate its Rift headsets, which will be sold early next year, while Sony will unveil its Project Morpheus virtual reality headgear. YouTube and Twitch will also compete for gamers, with YouTube launching its YouTube Gaming platform and Twitch streaming press conferences and demos. The event is seen as a coming-of-age for virtual reality, with analysts predicting a fiercely competitive market.

site_title: Harder for older US workers to pay off mortgage
summary: Older US workers are facing challenges in paying off their mortgages, with a sharp decline in home prices and high consumer debt contributing to their financial woes. In 2011, 6.1 million homeowners aged 65 and older were paying monthly mortgages, a significant increase from 3.8 million a decade earlier. Many retirees are opting to keep their low-interest mortgages, using the funds to invest elsewhere or fund renovations, rather than paying them off. This trend is expected to continue, with mortgage debt for this age group tripling between 1992 and 2010.

site_title: Gold bulls lose key ally as diehard coin buyers disappear in US
summary: US gold coin demand is expected to slump to its lowest level since 2008, with global demand predicted to fall 12% to 220 tonnes this year. The decline is attributed to a lack of confidence among diehard coin buyers, who are hesitant to invest in gold after a bear market over the past two years. Retail investors are shifting to other assets, and the Federal Reserve's potential interest rate hikes further erode the appeal of gold as a haven.

site_title: Azerbaijan hosting European Games has its pros and cons
summary: The European Games, held in Baku, Azerbaijan, have both positive and negative aspects. The event has a large budget of $1.11 billion and features 6,000 athletes from 50 nations competing in 20 sports. However, Azerbaijan's human rights record and potential propaganda purposes have raised concerns. The event has been criticized by Human Rights Watch, and some European heads of state, including Germany's Chancellor Angela Merkel, declined to attend the opening ceremony. Despite the controversy, the games aim to promote sports and European unity, but their significance in the sports calendar is limited, with many European stars not participating.

site_title: 'Connected' bikini sends out sunscreen alert
summary: A French designer has created a smart bikini with a UV sensor that sends sunscreen alerts to a smartphone or tablet, warning users when they need more protection. The two-piece swimsuit, priced at 149 euros, is calibrated to the wearer's skin type and tan preference. While a dermatologist praised the idea, a journalist noted that the device may not be revolutionary, and the high price may be out of reach for the market. The bikini is available for purchase on the designer's website.

site_title: Organic farmers object to Whole Foods new ratings system
summary: Organic farmers are criticizing Whole Foods' new "Responsibly Grown" ratings system, which they claim unfairly compares conventional produce to organic produce. The system awards ratings of "good", "better", or "best" to farms based on factors such as waste management, energy use, and pesticide use, potentially giving conventional farmers an advantage. Farmers argue that the system devalues the organic certification process and undermines Whole Foods' efforts to promote organic produce. The move is seen as a response to increasing competition from mainstream grocery chains and other organic outlets.

site_title: Jump in Swedish house prices 'worrying': minister
summary: Swedish house prices have surged, prompting Finance Minister Magdalena Andersson to describe the development as "worrying." The government plans a "powerful package" to address supply constraints in the autumn budget. This move aims to cool the housing market, which has seen significant price increases. Andersson's comments indicate that policymakers are taking action to mitigate the impact of the rapid price growth.

site_title: California cuts farmers' share of water as state faces prolonged drought
summary: California is imposing sharp cutbacks on farmers' water rights, dating back to 1903, due to the state's prolonged drought. The restrictions, announced on June 13, 2015, will limit farmers' use of surface water and are expected to grow as the summer months progress. The cuts apply to over 100 water rights holders in the San Joaquin and Sacramento watersheds and delta, affecting farmers, small city and municipal agencies, and state agencies. The drought, with snowpack at a historic low, has prompted officials to take drastic measures, with further cuts possible by the end of the year.

site_title: FOMC main focus of another difficult week
summary: The Federal Open Market Committee (FOMC) meeting on Tuesday and Wednesday will likely be a major market focus, with Fed Chair Janet Yellen's comments potentially influencing interest rates. The meeting follows a presentation on the US economy and a press conference. Markets have been cautious, with the Dow Jones falling below 18,000 and a survey showing only 27% of small investors are bullish. The economic recovery's sustainability remains uncertain, with no clear consensus on the impact of the Fed's extraordinary monetary actions since the 2008 sub-prime crisis.

site_title: Reit consolidation not likely: analysts
summary: Singapore's Reit sector is unlikely to experience consolidation due to a lack of necessary factors, including valuation disparity and market disruption. Analysts cite the sector's strong financial health and saturated market, particularly in the industrial space, as reasons against consolidation. The Reit market is expected to see new listings from offshore, cross-border firms, which will add diversity and boost investor options, rather than cannibalizing interest in existing Reits.

images.alt_text: The erratic outlook for the Reit sector has rekindled market talk of possible consolidation - be it smaller players grouping together, or larger players taking smaller ones out - should market conditions worsen.

site_title: Vedanta offers US$2.3b for Cairn India minorities
summary: Vedanta Ltd offered a US$2.3 billion deal to buy out minority shareholders in Cairn India, repaying debts. Shareholders will receive one share in Vedanta Ltd for every share held. The deal is expected to close in Q1 2016 and is at a 7.3% premium to Cairn India's Friday closing price.

site_title: China's stock market value tops US$10t for first time
summary: China's stock market value has surpassed $10 trillion for the first time, with companies listed in China experiencing a $6.7 trillion increase in 12 months, according to Bloomberg data. This marks a significant milestone in the nation's world-leading stock market rally. The US stock market is the largest globally, valued at almost $25 trillion.

site_title: ECG to have more overseas offices, franchisees
summary: ECG Property Services, a Singapore-listed company, is expanding its overseas presence with the backing of its parent company, Teho International. ECG aims to open two more overseas offices and establish at least six franchisees in the next 18 months. The company is targeting higher profit margins, particularly in overseas markets where agents take a lower commission cut, and expects to achieve a net margin of 18% by the third quarter of 2017. This follows a net profit margin of 10-12% for its agency business this year, compared to 4-5% in Singapore.

site_title: Twitter co-founder returns as chief, to shrugs and quips
summary: Twitter co-founder Jack Dorsey returned as the company's chief executive, after a two-year absence. He made his return with a distinctive beard, which even his mother joked about on Twitter. The decision to return is seen as a surprise, given his relatively low public presence during his time away. Dorsey's return is expected to be a significant development for the company, which is one of the world's largest social networks.

site_title: Hands up for Citi record
summary: A record-breaking event took place in Singapore where 1,143 people painted a Singapore map, raising S$10,000 for a savings program. The funds, combined with a Citi Foundation grant, will support the program, which helps low-income students save from a young age. The event was part of the Citi-South East CDC MoneyWise Matched Savings Programme 2016.

site_title: US home mortgages still a concern after property bust
summary: US homeowners still struggle with mortgages, with 15.4% owing more on their loans than their properties' worth in the first quarter, according to Zillow. This rate has slowed but remains above the 1-2% threshold for a healthy market. Experts warn that underwater mortgages will continue to impact the economy, restrain housing recovery, and exacerbate wealth inequality. Home prices have risen 4.14% nationally, but the pace of improvement is decelerating, and the prospect of lingering underwater mortgages for 5-6 years is a concern.

site_title: More merger options for both T-Mobile and Dish
summary: T-Mobile US Inc, the fourth-largest US wireless carrier, is considered a prime target for potential mergers. The company has seen significant growth, with shares more than doubling since 2013. Dish Network Corp, a major satellite-TV provider, has expressed interest in acquiring T-Mobile, but its CEO, Charlie Ergen, has stated that Deutsche Telekom AG, T-Mobile's German parent, may not be willing to sell. Analysts estimate T-Mobile could command a 25% premium for a takeover, potentially worth $62 billion. Other potential buyers, including Comcast Corp, Altice SA, and foreign carriers, are also being considered.

site_title: Malaysian-flagged tanker missing: piracy watchdog
summary: A Malaysian-flagged tanker carrying petrol, MT Orkim Harmony, has gone missing off the south coast in the South China Sea, with the International Maritime Bureau suspecting it has been hijacked. The ship was last in contact with its owners late Thursday, and an alert was sent to all ships in the area to guard against attacks. The vessel was carrying a cargo that is typically hijacked, and 22 crew members, including 16 Malaysians, are feared to be in danger. This incident is part of the ongoing piracy concerns in Southeast Asia.

site_title: World's biggest wine fair eyes African tipplers
summary: The world's biggest wine fair, Vinexpo, opened in Bordeaux, France, with 45,000 buyers from 120 nations attending. The event aims to tap into Africa's growing wine market, particularly Nigeria, where champagne consumption is rising. Africa is expected to experience 3.5% growth in the wine industry over the next three years. France, the world's leading wine producer, is seeking to diversify its export markets, with the US and China being the current top wine-lovers.

site_title: Ghost villages mar Slovakia's economic success
summary: Slovakia's economic success is marred by ghost villages as people leave rural areas in search of jobs, driven by EU membership and free movement. Once thriving villages like Harakovce and Havranec now have fewer than 10 residents, with many residents working abroad. Despite a 3.2% economic growth forecast, joblessness remains high, especially in rural areas, at 11.6% nationwide and 17% in rural areas. Efforts to invest in the countryside and provide EU regional development funds have failed to address the issue, leaving a deep impression on rural communities.

site_title: Awakening the sleeping tiger
summary: India has the potential to reach a per capita income similar to China's today by the mid-2020s, but urgent reforms are needed to avoid the "middle-income trap." The country's economic growth has been disappointing compared to China and other Asian peers, but it has shown signs of improvement in recent years. The new government has taken steps to reverse previous policy mistakes and implement structural reforms, including restarting the investment engine, reviving domestic savings, and strengthening education. If successful, India's growth path is expected to be around 7% per capita GDP growth by the end of this decade, with a doubling of income in every 10 years.

images.alt_text: The government has pledged to better promote the manufacturing sector by initiating the "Make in India" campaign and improving the country's ranking in the World Bank's Ease of Doing Business survey. These efforts could help to attract foreign direct investment and lift India's manufacturing competitiveness.

site_title: Mixed reaction in Asia over US trade deal setback
summary: The US House of Representatives voted down a package of trade-related bills, dealing a setback to President Barack Obama's free-trade initiative and Japan's Prime Minister Shinzo Abe's efforts to revive his country's anaemic economy through the Trans-Pacific Partnership (TPP). The failure is seen as a victory for China, which has been wary of the pact, and may also benefit South Korea, which has been seeking to join the talks. The delay could lead to a more uncertain outcome for the TPP, with some experts predicting it may not be finalized this year.

images.alt_text: The vote against Mr Obama's trade-related bills is a blow to Mr Abe, who wanted to forge a wide-ranging trade pact with the US.

site_title: Oil prices rally; metals mixed
summary: Oil prices surged last week, driven by a 6.8 million barrel drop in US crude inventories and Opec's forecast of increased demand. Brent crude rose to $64.35 a barrel and WTI to $59.99 a barrel. The International Energy Agency predicted a slowdown in world oil demand growth, while Opec maintained its prediction of total oil demand in 2015. Gold prices rose amid market tensions over Greece, while silver and platinum prices were mixed.

site_title: Buying remains high, selling rebounds
summary:
Here is a 100-word or less summary of the article content:

Director transactions in Singapore companies showed a rebound in selling activity, with 61 purchases worth S$5.53 million and six disposals worth S$1.38 million recorded in the second week of June. Significant transactions included GP Batteries International, Hyflux Limited, and Keppel Corporation buying back shares, while M1 Limited and Xyec Holdings saw rare insider buys. Conversely, QAF Limited and Nobel Design Holdings reported insider sales. These transactions reflect the complex dynamics of corporate shareholder sentiment, with some companies experiencing price gains following buyback activity, while others saw share prices decline after sales.

site_title: While the sun shines
summary: Singapore is poised to expand its use of solar energy due to decreasing costs and increasing eco-social awareness. Business leaders attribute the growth of solar energy to its cost-effectiveness, environmental benefits, and potential for grid integration. The government can encourage adoption through grants, tax incentives, and subsidies. Experts agree that a pro-solar culture is necessary, with a dedicated centre to educate the public on solar energy benefits. The industry expects a significant increase in solar energy usage, with some predicting it will become the cheapest source of electricity within the next 10 years.

site_title: Blatter may seek to stay on as Fifa boss: source
summary: Sepp Blatter, FIFA president, may reconsider stepping down amid support from African and Asian football associations, citing an anonymous source close to him. However, FIFA's audit and compliance committee head Domenico Scala insists that Blatter's departure is necessary for reforms, contradicting Blatter's statement that he will continue to drive reforms until a successor is elected. A decision on Blatter's future is expected after an extraordinary congress in Zurich between December and February.

site_title: A two-horse race for the top position
summary: Thailand leads the SEA Games with 87 gold medals, narrowly ahead of Singapore's 82. Despite trailing in medals, Singapore has a higher overall medal count of 252. The battle for top sporting nation status is intense, with both countries vying for the top spot. Thailand's football team, the War Elephants, is favored to win the gold medal, having defeated Myanmar in the semi-finals, and aims to beat them for their 15th title.

images.alt_text: Lee U-Wen

site_title: US airlines struggle for investors' trust amid seat-glut concern
summary: US airlines are facing investor concerns over seat capacity, which may lead to decreased ticket prices. Despite profitable operations and low fuel costs, stocks are under pressure due to a decline in revenue gauge and memories of past fare wars. Analysts warn that jockeying for market share could harm the industry's growth, with some carriers adding seating capacity faster than US GDP growth. Airlines must prove themselves after a decade of losses to regain investor trust.

images.alt_text: Mr Parker is among those who vow that the industry has changed for good and won't return to the days when airlines added seats to fend off a competitor

site_title: Flight club
summary: Airbus secured a record-breaking $13.7 billion last-minute order at the Paris Air Show, surpassing Boeing. This deal marks a significant win for the European aircraft manufacturer. Meanwhile, London's Heathrow is considering increasing fees for its $10 billion upgrade, and Tesla is expanding its robotaxi service to California and Arizona. FedEx partnered with a Singapore startup to deploy robots for commercial deliveries, and Delta Air Lines offered a positive outlook on travel demand, boosting its shares.

site_title: US faces US$300 bn in illicit funds in anti-laundering fight
summary: The US faces approximately $300 billion in illicit funds each year, with the majority coming from fraud and the drug trade. Despite efforts to crack down on money laundering, terror groups have been forced to use cash smuggling due to crackdowns on banks and charities. However, this method makes them more vulnerable. The US financial system still has vulnerabilities, including increased charity collections by unregistered individuals and online networks for money transfers, which may be vulnerable to abuse by terrorist financiers.

images.alt_text: The US has largely blocked terror groups from moving money through banks, but tens of billions of dollars in illicit funds still transit the financial system each year, the Treasury said Friday.

site_title: Safety, security surveillance a key aviation trend: Stratech founder
summary: Stratech's founder, David Chew, believes safety and security surveillance will be a key aviation trend in 2015, driven by recent incidents and the pursuit of Smart Cities and Smart Airports. Stratech's flagship product, iFerret, a patented airfield and runway surveillance system, is gaining recognition and has secured major contracts at Hong Kong International Airport and Dubai International Airport. iFerret can detect and track foreign objects and debris in real-time, providing superior image quality even at night and in extreme weather conditions. Stratech aims to turn its ailing company around by securing fresh contracts and building up project pipelines.

site_title: Greece and its creditors engage in last-ditch talks
summary: Greece and its creditors are engaged in last-ditch talks, with European Commission President Jean-Claude Juncker attempting to broker a deal before markets open on Monday. Greece's Prime Minister Alexis Tsipras has sent a delegation to Brussels with new proposals on pensions, taxes, and a primary surplus target. However, positions remain hard, and the talks are the last attempt to reach a compromise, with the IMF, ECB, and European Stability Mechanism waiting to join negotiations if progress is made. The talks come as European leaders express growing frustration with Greece's brinkmanship and warn of a potential Greek euro exit if no deal is reached.

site_title: Blatter may seek to stay as Fifa boss, source tells Swiss paper
summary: Sepp Blatter, FIFA president, may attempt to stay in office despite resigning over a corruption scandal. A Swiss newspaper reported that Blatter received messages of support from African and Asian football associations, prompting him to reconsider his decision. US and Swiss authorities are continuing their investigations, and EU lawmakers are calling for his immediate departure.

site_title: China reaffirms 2030 climate commitments: state council
summary: China's Premier Li Keqiang reaffirmed the country's commitment to achieving peak carbon emissions by around 2030, according to a statement from the State Council. This commitment was made without new pledges ahead of the Paris climate talks. China's coal consumption decreased for the first time in years in 2014, and the country's energy consumption and carbon dioxide emissions per unit of GDP dropped by 29.9% and 33.8% respectively over 2005. China aims to increase non-fossil fuel energy sources in its energy supply mix, but the statement did not include explicit plans to cap coal consumption.

site_title: Inflation fears recede in Malaysia, positive for ringgit
summary: Malaysia's inflation has receded to 1.8%, below expectations, due to low oil prices. The country's recent GST policy appears to be a timely event, and deflation resulting from falling oil prices is expected to remain under control, even if oil prices rebound. This suggests that inflation will average 3-4% for the year. As a result, interest rates are likely to remain unchanged, and the ringgit may strengthen. However, the currency has been under pressure due to optimistic bets on the US economy, but this is expected to reverse, allowing the ringgit to recover.

site_title: China to remove visa requirements for Taiwanese
summary: China announced plans to remove visa requirements for Taiwanese traveling to the mainland, part of a broader effort to reduce barriers between the two communities. The move, made by Chairman Yu Zhengsheng, aims to support exchanges between compatriots and oppose separatist forces. The policy change will replace an entry permit requirement with a card allowing automatic entry. This follows a trend of increased tourism between the two sides, with over 5 million Taiwanese visits to the mainland in 2014, up from 1 million in 2008. The change is seen as a step towards improved relations.

site_title: Comet probe Philae wakes up
summary: European space probe Philae, which has been in hibernation for nearly seven months, has woken up and is ready to resume science work. The tiny robot successfully communicated with its ground team for 85 seconds, and its temperature and energy levels are sufficient for ongoing communication. The lander's systems are functioning well, and it is expected to be ready for operations within a week. This marks a fresh chapter in Philae's extraordinary voyage, which aims to unlock the secrets of comets and reveal how the Solar System was formed.

images.alt_text: This file picture released by the European Space Agency on December 20, 2013 of an artist's impression of Rosetta's lander Philae (back view) on the surface of comet 67P/Churyumov-Gerasimenko. Europe's comet lander Philae has woken up overnight after a months-long sleep, hurtling towards the Sun in deep space.

site_title: Eurosceptics complicate Cameron's referendum strategy
summary: British Prime Minister David Cameron is facing challenges from eurosceptics as the country's relationship with the European Union is up for review. Around 50 Conservative lawmakers are likely to want to leave the EU, and a newly-formed group called Conservatives for Britain is pushing for a "fundamental renegotiation" of relations. Cameron's majority in the House of Commons is slim, making it difficult to pass legislation if eurosceptics block it. The outcome of the renegotiation and potential referendum on EU membership are uncertain, with some fearing the government can sway the result with pro-EU sweeteners.

images.alt_text: Mr Cameron, who wants to stay in the EU subject to reforms, is not the first Conservative prime minister to face trouble from eurosceptics.

site_title: Japan desires quick passage of US trade adjustment bill
summary: Japan's top government spokesman, Yoshihide Suga, expressed desire for swift passage of a US trade adjustment bill, crucial to President Barack Obama's push for a Pacific Rim trade pact. The bill was narrowly approved by the US House of Representatives, giving Obama "fast-track" authority to negotiate the Trans-Pacific Partnership (TPP) trade deal. A successful TPP agreement is key to reviving Japan's economic fortunes, with the Japanese government seeking its swift passage.

site_title: 400 million still lack access to key health care services:World Bank
summary: 400 million people worldwide lack access to essential health services, according to a report by the World Bank and World Health Organization. Despite 80% of people having access to key health services, many are forced into poverty due to healthcare costs. The report defines universal health care as services such as family planning, vaccinations, and HIV treatment, but highlights that many people lack access to these services. The World Bank calls for governments and communities to expand access to health services and protect the poorest from financial hardship.

site_title: South Korea reports seven new MERS cases
summary: South Korea reported seven new MERS cases, bringing the total infections to 145, and no new fatalities. The new cases were identified in Samsung Medical Centre, Daejeon, and Hwaseong. A paramedic involved in transporting a MERS patient also tested positive. A South Korean man suspected of having the virus was hospitalized in Slovakia. The World Health Organization warned of a "large and complex" outbreak, but found no evidence of community transmission. Ten patients have recovered so far.

site_title: Mers: WHO says South Korean outbreak large and complex
summary: A World Health Organization (WHO) team has deemed South Korea's Mers outbreak as "large and complex," anticipating more cases. The outbreak, which began on May 20, has infected 138 people and killed 14. The WHO conducted a joint review with South Korean officials and experts, highlighting the need for continued vigilance.

site_title: US data breach is intelligence coup for China
summary: A massive US data breach, targeting millions of government employees, is believed to be an intelligence coup for China. The breach, which compromised personal data of current and former employees, is thought to be part of a long-term effort by Chinese intelligence to collect and compile data for future use. Experts say the breach is a "Holy Grail" for intelligence agencies, providing valuable information for espionage and recruitment. Similar software signatures have been found in other recent breaches, suggesting a potential overlap in the effort to compile intelligence data.

site_title: McDonald's names chief field officer to help with franchisees
summary: McDonald's Corp has appointed Karen King as its new chief field officer to oversee 14,000 US restaurants and strengthen ties with franchisees. The move is part of CEO Steve Easterbrook's efforts to revamp the company and simplify operations. King, who currently serves as chief people officer, will focus on franchise relations and operations in four US zones. The changes come as franchisees have expressed concerns about their ties to corporate bosses, with a recent survey rating them as the worst in at least a decade.

site_title: US data better, but Fed likely to hold off on rate rise
summary: The US economy is showing signs of recovery, with consumers spending more, job creation rebounding, and wages rising. However, the Federal Reserve is unlikely to raise interest rates in June, citing mixed data, including weaker-than-expected consumer spending and lower inflation. Analysts expect a rate hike in September, but it will depend on steady improvement in key economic indicators. The Fed is cautious due to persistent underemployment, weak wage growth, and concerns about the economy's vulnerability to tighter monetary conditions.

site_title: Tsipras sends new plans to Brussels as EU warns Greece on brink
summary: Greece's Prime Minister Alexis Tsipras is sending a new proposal to Brussels as the European Union warns Greece is on the brink of insolvency. EU leaders, including German Chancellor Angela Merkel and European Union President Donald Tusk, have expressed growing frustration with Greece's stance, with Merkel urging Tsipras to accept a framework for financial aid. The deadline for a deal looms, with Greece's bailout extension set to expire June 30, and a meeting of finance ministers in Luxembourg on Thursday. Tsipras' government has rejected previous proposals and is aiming to reach an agreement in the next few days.

site_title: S$202 million in Medisave top-ups for Pioneer Generation this year
summary: The Singapore government will disburse S$202 million in Medisave top-ups to around 440,000 Pioneer Generation members this year. The top-up amount ranges from S$200 to S$800 per year. In addition to the Medisave top-up, Pioneers will also receive letters informing them of other benefits, including special subsidies at Community Health Assist Scheme clinics and MediShield Life premiums. The letters will be sent out this week.

images.alt_text: Nisha Ramchandani

site_title: Mers: South Korea reports 1 more death, total now 13; and 12 more cases
summary: South Korea's health ministry reported 12 new cases of Middle East Respiratory Syndrome (Mers), bringing the total to 138, and a 14th death, for a total of 13. The 12 new cases include an ambulance driver who transported a previous patient.

site_title: US agency confirms seventh death tied to Takata air bags
summary: A woman's death in a car crash in Louisiana is likely the seventh US fatality linked to Takata Corp's defective air-bag inflators, according to the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration. The agency has confirmed a ruptured Takata air-bag inflator was involved in the crash, which occurred just days after a lawsuit was filed claiming the air bag deployed with too much force and caused the death. The defect affects about 34 million air-bag inflators, and Honda has been trying to speed repairs, but many owners remain unaware due to the defect's age and frequent changes in ownership.

site_title: Jet engine maker CFM vows to meet output goals
summary: CFM International, a joint venture between Safran and General Electric, has pledged to meet production goals for its LEAP engine, which powers the Boeing 737 MAX and Airbus A320neo. The company aims to increase production from 1,560 engines in 2014 to 1,670 this year, with a gradual transition to LEAP production expected by 2020. CFM has sold 314 CFM56 engines and "about 500" LEAP engines so far this year, and is expecting a fall in orders this year after a record 2014.

site_title: Twitter's CEO-exit rally fizzles as Dorsey seen more of same
summary: Twitter's CEO Jack Dorsey, who returned as interim CEO, stated that he will not implement significant changes to the company's strategy or direction. Despite initial optimism, Twitter shares are now paring gains after Dorsey's comments. Analysts express skepticism, citing stagnant user growth and revenue forecasts, which could continue to weigh on the stock. The company's search for a permanent CEO is ongoing, but no timetable has been set.

images.alt_text: When Twitter Inc announced a change in leadership, the stock gained on optimism that co-founder and interim Chief Executive Officer Jack Dorsey would bring the vision and product expertise to improve the service.

site_title: US airlines seen favouring small fare increases over big boosts
summary: US airlines are shifting to smaller, targeted fare increases as broad-based hikes have become less effective. According to FareCompare, airlines have reached maximum levels they can charge and now focus on specific customers to extract higher prices. This approach is evident in recent fare hikes by JetBlue, Southwest, and other carriers. Industry analysts see this as a positive trend, as it suggests airlines are adapting to changing market conditions and increasing competition. The Bloomberg US Airlines Index rose 1.5% following the news, indicating investor confidence in the airlines' pricing strategies.

site_title: YouTube getting into game of streaming play
summary: YouTube is launching YouTube Gaming, an online arena for video game streaming, to compete with Amazon-owned Twitch. The platform will feature over 25,000 games, live streams, and channels dedicated to game publishers and personalities. YouTube Gaming will debut in Britain and the US in the coming months, with a preview showcased at the Electronic Entertainment Expo. The move follows Amazon's $970 million acquisition of Twitch last year, which had been a target for Google before anti-trust concerns were raised.

site_title: Computer in Merkel's office hit by cyber attack
summary: A cyberattack targeted the German parliament's lower house, the Bundestag, in May, affecting Chancellor Angela Merkel's office. The attack, described as a Trojan Horse-style malware, infected one of the computers in Merkel's office. The Bundestag struggled to control the attack, which was initially thought to be limited but later found to be broader. The incident highlights the vulnerability of government systems to cyber threats.

site_title: Gold embracing dollar once more as haven demand fails to emerge
summary: Gold prices fell 0.1% to $1,179.20 an ounce as the dollar dominated the market, driven by relative calm in global markets and a lack of demand for safe-haven assets. The Bloomberg Dollar Spot Index rose 0.6% as the US economic report and Fed speech were parsed for clues on interest rate hikes. Fed officials are unlikely to raise rates before September, according to a Bloomberg survey of economists. Gold prices have been stuck in a trading range since April, with the 30-day correlation with the dollar index at its lowest since December.

site_title: IMF board postpones decision on reform for three months
summary: The International Monetary Fund's board has postponed its decision on reforming emerging countries' voting rights by three months to the end of September. The reforms aim to give more voting power to countries like China and India, but the US has been unable to pass necessary funding changes due to Congressional opposition. The IMF will implement any changes by mid-December.

images.alt_text: The International Monetary Fund's board on Friday decided to postpone by three months its decision on how to raise emerging countries' voting rights at the institution, as it seeks to get past US foot-dragging on reforms.

site_title: Japan's Dream Incubator to launch US$100m fund in S'pore, region
summary: Tokyo-listed venture firm Dream Incubator (DI) will launch a $100 million fund in Singapore and the region, targeting emerging companies across South-east Asia and India. The fund, DI Asian Industrial Fund II, is the second to be jointly operated by DI and Japanese financial services group Orix. The fund will focus on growth-stage companies in consumer industries, with investments ranging from $10 million to $20 million for a 20-30% equity stake. DI has had its eyes on the Singapore startup scene since venture capital investments exceeded that of Japan and Hong Kong, and considers Singapore as one of the most attractive talent pools in Asia.

site_title: Total ordered halting of France's La Mede refinery due to strike
summary: France's Total ordered the halt of its La Mede refinery in southeast France due to a strike by the CGT union. The refinery, which processes 153,000 barrels of crude oil per day, will be shut down by the end of 2016 as demand for petroleum products declines in Europe. The strike, which started on Thursday, affects around 18 of the plant's 430 employees. Total plans to cut 180 jobs and invest €200 million to create France's first biorefinery, despite ongoing talks with other unions.

site_title: Europe: Stocks drop on Greek default fears
summary: Europe's main stock markets plummeted on Friday amid concerns of a Greek default, with London's FTSE 100 index down 0.90% and eurozone markets losing 1.41% to 1.20%. Eurozone officials discussed a "worst-case" scenario of Greece defaulting on its bills, while the IMF withdrew from talks, citing a far-off agreement. The Greek government announced it would make counter-proposals to unlock bailout funds by Saturday. Failure to reach a compromise will lead to default and possible eurozone exit.

site_title: Prudential unit invests US$300m annually in Asia
summary: M&G Real Estate, a property investment unit of Prudential plc, plans to invest US$300 million annually in Asian property over the next three to five years. The UK-based manager expects strong demand from institutional investors, citing attractive risk-adjusted returns in Asian markets. Its existing portfolio includes offices and logistics facilities in Sydney, Melbourne, Tokyo, Osaka, and Fukuoka. The company may boost investments in Japan's residential market and South Korea's logistics and retail sectors.

site_title: US: Stocks end week on a down note
summary: US stocks closed the week on a down note, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average falling 138.33 points (0.77%) to 17,901.04. The S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite Index also declined, with losses of 14.73 (0.70%) and 31.41 (0.62%), respectively. The decline was attributed to European markets tumbling due to fears of a Greek debt default, as well as concerns over the Federal Reserve's interest rate hike plans.

site_title: Airbus sees US as biggest A400M customer
summary: Airbus CEO Tom Enders believes the US will be the largest customer for the A400M military transport plane by the next decade, despite current technical issues. Airbus has no rival product, and the A400M is more fuel-efficient and versatile. The US military has grounded its A400M planes after a fatal crash during a test flight in May, killing four people. Airbus is sticking to its sales and earnings targets for 2015 and is considering upgrading its A380 superjumbo by the end of the year.

site_title: Time for football SEA change after Games
summary: Team Singapore's football team failed to make it to the SEA Games semi-finals, despite being the host nation, after losing to Indonesia in the final match. Coach Aide Iskandar resigned following the loss, citing disappointment with the team's results. The Young Lions had shown promise in the group stage but struggled under pressure, losing to Myanmar and then Cambodia. Thailand is now favored to defend their championship, while the other semi-final match between Vietnam and Myanmar is expected to be a close contest.

images.alt_text: Lee U-Wen

site_title: MAS makes emergency landing safely in Melbourne
summary: A Malaysia Airlines Airbus 330 made an emergency landing in Melbourne after an engine fire alert was triggered during take-off. The plane, carrying 300 passengers, dumped fuel and landed safely at an aviation rescue site. However, no evidence of fire was found externally, and further assessments are underway. The incident has raised concerns about the airline's reliability, which has been marred by previous incidents such as MH370's disappearance and MH17's downing. All passengers were disembarked safely.

site_title: PBOC seen cutting reserve requirement
summary: China's central bank, the People's Bank of China (PBOC), is expected to cut its reserve requirement ratio as early as this weekend to boost economic growth and counter a surge in municipal bond sales. A 100-basis-point cut to 17.5% is predicted, with the goal of lowering borrowing costs and guiding longer rates downward. This move comes as China's economy grew the least in six years last quarter, and municipal bond sales have surged, locking up an estimated 6.7 trillion yuan of funds.

site_title: Temasek to buy Intel Cap's stake in Policybazaar: report
summary: Temasek, a Singapore investment company, is acquiring Intel Capital's nearly 8% stake in insurance web aggregator Policybazaar for around $23.1 million. The deal values Policybazaar at over $15 billion. Intel Capital, which initially invested in 2011, will exit the company following the sale. This marks the second major investment in Policybazaar in recent months, following a $300 million investment from Founders United Trust.

images.alt_text: Angela Tan

site_title: Petronas to move ahead with Canada LNG project
summary: Petronas, a Malaysian state energy firm, will proceed with its Pacific NorthWest LNG project in British Columbia, Canada, on the condition that it receives approval from the country's environmental regulator. The US$11 billion liquefied natural gas (LNG) export terminal will be Canada's first LNG facility if constructed. The project's development has been paused multiple times due to environmental concerns, but Petronas has made changes to its design to mitigate impact on a sensitive salmon habitat. A final investment decision was made after satisfying technical and commercial components.

site_title: Facebook presents virtual reality goggles for gaming and more
summary: Facebook has unveiled its first commercial version of virtual reality goggles, Oculus Rift, designed for gaming and other applications. The device, initially tethered to high-end gaming computers, will eventually feature microphones for communication, voice recognition software, and laser-based wireless data transfers. Oculus Rift is expected to be available in the first quarter of 2016, with no pricing announced. The device will work with the Xbox One gaming controller and Oculus Touch, a new controller that allows users to interact with virtual objects. Facebook is investing significant resources into making Oculus Rift a success.

site_title: What if Mers strikes? Analysts give their take on defensive plays
