site_title: Pricy beef bowls help to beat Japan's 'deflationary mindset'
summary: Japanese restaurants and food producers are shifting from discount-driven strategies to raising prices, driven by the yen's decline and higher costs of imported ingredients. Companies like Matsuya Foods and Seven & I Holdings Co. are introducing premium products and increasing prices to maintain revenue growth. This move is seen as a step towards the virtuous cycle of higher prices, increased spending, and wage rises, aiming to combat Japan's deflationary mindset and meet Prime Minister Shinzo Abe's inflation target of 2%.

site_title: Noble down 5.7% after year's first buyback; stock second most active
summary: NOBLE Group's shares dropped 5.7% after executing its first share buyback in a year, making it the second-most actively traded stock on the Singapore market. The company bought 25 million shares at an average price of 66.92 cents, totaling S$16.8 million. This move follows questions about its accounting practices and weak commodity outlook, prompting a downgrade by OCBC and Standard and Poor's, which cut its outlook to "negative". Noble chairman Richard Elman urged shareholders for "confidence and patience" as the company works to recover share value.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open higher on Friday morning
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rose 5.93 points to 1,740.69 points on Friday morning, driven by gains. The index saw 112 gainers and 61 losers, with a trading volume of 34 million lots worth RM18.9 million.

site_title: Investors grow risk-averse, picky on Indonesian property stocks
summary: Indonesian property stocks have seen a decline in October due to weak consumer spending and high interest rates, with investors becoming more risk-averse. Shares of diversified real estate developers like PT Summarecon Agung Tbk and PT Lippo Karawaci Tbk have outperformed the market, gaining 10.5% and 12.7% respectively. In contrast, shares of property developers exposed to high-end residential projects, such as PT Ciputra Property Tbk, have taken a beating, sliding 31% this year. The government's revision of luxury sales tax policy has also raised concerns.

site_title: China: Stocks head for second week of gains on monetary bets
summary: China's stocks rose for the second week in a row, with the Shanghai Composite Index up 0.6% to 5,150.68, driven by bets on monetary stimulus. Real estate shares jumped 3.2% and consumer-staples producers rose 2.5% after data showed parts of the economy stabilizing. The People's Bank of China may cut banks' reserve-requirement ratios as early as this weekend, according to analysts. Despite a flood of new share sales, investors remain optimistic about more monetary easing, with one analyst stating "more loosening is coming."

site_title: Temasek to buy Intel Cap's stake in Policybazaar: report
summary: Temasek, a Singaporean sovereign fund, is acquiring a nearly 8% stake in Intel Capital's investment in Policybazaar.com for around Rs 110 crore. The deal values Policybazaar at over Rs 1,500 crore. Intel Capital, which initially invested Rs 30 crore in 2011, will exit the company following the sale. The transaction is expected to be completed within two to three weeks.

site_title: Stocks to watch: Albedo, Jason, Lippo Malls, Raffles Education
summary: Albedo agreed to acquire a majority stake in a Taiwanese aesthetic medicine group for S$18.9 million. Jason Holdings chairman Jason Sim reached a deal with a creditor to avoid a loan default, while Lippo Malls Indonesia Retail Trust received commitments for a S$260 million loan. Raffles Education Corp's subsidiary invested A$5.2 million in Australian real estate developer Axiom Properties. These announcements may affect trading activity on Friday.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open 0.24% higher
summary: Tokyo stocks rose 0.24% on Friday, driven by a lower yen and higher US shares following a solid retail sales report. The Nikkei 225 index gained 48.81 points to 20,431.78. The US retail sales report suggested American consumers are gaining confidence, boosting the Dow Jones Industrial Average 0.22%.

site_title: Noble Group purchases 0.37% of shares in buyback
summary: Singapore-listed Noble Group Ltd purchased 25 million of its own shares, accounting for 0.37% of its issued shares, for S$16.8 million. The move followed a 9% rebound in its share price after it hit a six-year low of S$0.63. Credit rating agency Standard & Poor's cut its outlook on Noble to 'negative' from 'stable', citing expected earnings volatility.

site_title: Japan delays nuclear fuel removal schedule for Fukushima plant
summary: Japan has delayed the removal of spent uranium fuel rods from the Fukushima Daiichi nuclear power station, the world's worst nuclear disaster since Chernobyl. The revised "roadmap" for decommissioning the station now delays the start of fuel removal by up to three years, pushing it to 2017 or later. This is the second revision of the roadmap, following a 2013 revision. The delay is due to Tepco's struggles to reduce high radiation levels, with the overall goal to complete decommissioning work in 30-40 years remaining unchanged.

site_title: Petronas gives conditional approval to Canadian LNG project
summary: Petronas, Malaysia's state energy firm, has given conditional approval to the Pacific NorthWest LNG project in British Columbia, Canada, pending approval from the Canadian Environmental Assessment Agency. The $11 billion liquefied natural gas export terminal will be Canada's first LNG facility, with a broader $36 billion investment by Petronas and its partners. The project's environmental review has been paused for a third time, with the CEAA requesting additional information on its impact on a salmon habitat and traditional aboriginal fisheries.

site_title: South Korea reports 4 new cases of Mers, total 126
summary: South Korea reported 4 new cases of Mers, bringing the total to 126, with 10 deaths attributed to the virus. The cases are outside of Saudi Arabia, which has the largest Mers outbreak. All 10 deaths were from individuals with serious pre-existing health conditions.

site_title: South Korea May import prices fall for 33rd mth, pace of decline slows
summary: South Korea's import prices declined for the 33rd straight month in May, but at their slowest pace in five months, according to the Bank of Korea. Prices fell 14.6% in May from a year earlier, with intermediate materials prices dropping 7.6% and coal/oil prices falling 31.7%. Export prices also declined 3.5% in May. This marks the slowest annual pace of falls since December last year.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks up 0.65% at open
summary: Hong Kong stocks opened 0.65% higher on Friday, following a positive lead from Wall Street. The Hang Seng Index rose 174.75 points to 27,082.60. This marks the latest in a series of gains, as investors continue to brush off new threats from US President Trump. Despite tariff uncertainty, the market remains optimistic, with the S&P 500 and Nasdaq also reaching fresh records earlier in the week.

site_title: Australian, Japanese govt bonds fall on signs of economic pickup
summary: Australian and Japanese government bonds fell due to signs of economic improvement, with benchmark yields reaching their highest this year. The decline followed a global fixed-income slump, triggered by record-low yields in Asia and Europe. The stronger-than-expected Australian labour force data and US job growth beating expectations further contributed to the sell-off, with investors expecting a potential interest rate hike in the US. This led to a decrease in government securities, affecting both countries.

site_title: 'Selfie Pilot' suspended by Japan Airlines for safety violation
summary: A Japan Airlines pilot, 47, was suspended for violating flight regulations after taking a selfie with a stewardess in the cockpit while his partner was on a bathroom break. The incident occurred on June 7 on a flight from northern Japan to Osaka, where the pilot seated the 28-year-old attendant in the co-pilot's chair and snapped a photo after the plane reached 10,000 feet. This incident comes after the Germanwings cockpit incident in March, where a co-pilot locked the captain out of the cockpit, leading to the death of all 150 people on board.

site_title: Ringgit gains as Zeti says losses not reflective of fundamentals
summary: Malaysia's ringgit strengthened 0.2% to 3.7370 against the US dollar, rebounding from its lowest level since 2006, after central bank Governor Zeti Akhtar Aziz said the currency's weakness doesn't reflect economic fundamentals. The ringgit has fallen 44% from its 2014 peak due to the drop in Brent crude prices, but Zeti expects a temporary rebound. Analysts say the currency has been heavily punished relative to its Asian peers, and a technical overshoot is possible but the fundamental picture is less dire.

images.alt_text: Malaysia's ringgit strengthened as some investors judged excessive the slide that's made it Asia's biggest loser over the past month and after central bank Governor Zeti Akhtar Aziz said the weakness doesn't reflect economic fundamentals.

site_title: Update: Noble Group still 58% away from analyst stock price targets
summary: Noble Group's stock price is significantly underperforming analyst expectations, with a 58% price increase needed to meet average strategist forecasts. The commodity trader has declined for six straight months, and its valuation is near its lowest since 2008. Despite efforts to improve transparency, Noble's accounting and business model are under scrutiny, with some analysts questioning its cash flow and management. The company's shares have advanced 9.3% on elevated volume, but many analysts remain cautious, citing the lack of transparency in major contracts and the risk of further losses in the commodity market.

site_title: Oil prices drop as IEA sees demand growth cooling
summary: Oil prices dropped on Thursday after the International Energy Agency (IEA) predicted that a recent surge in world crude demand would end. US West Texas Intermediate oil fell 66 cents to $60.77 a barrel, while European Brent oil dropped 59 cents to $65.11 a barrel. The IEA's bearish outlook is attributed to a decline in global demand growth. The price drop is also influenced by President Trump's tariff moves, which have created a bearish market outlook.

site_title: BOJ's Harada says no need to ease if trend inflation improving: Sankei
summary: Bank of Japan board member Yutaka Harada stated that if inflation approaches the 2% target by the first half of fiscal 2016, there is no need to ease stimulus further. Harada expects inflation to accelerate from autumn this year due to economic improvements, and cutting interest rates could stimulate the economy by encouraging banks to invest and lend more. The BOJ can hold off on expanding stimulus, even if inflation doesn't meet the 2% target, as long as the broad price trend continues to improve.

site_title: Raffles Education unit investing A$5.2m in Aussie developer
summary: Raffles Education Corp's subsidiary Oriental University City Holdings is investing A$5.2 million in Australian real estate developer Axiom Properties, acquiring a 19.9% stake. Oriental University has already bought a 14.9% stake for A$3.678 million, and will subscribe for A$1.54 million of new shares. The investment aims to expand Oriental University's student housing business into Australia.

site_title: Singapore: STI up 0.1% in early trading; Albedo most active
summary: Singapore shares rose 0.1% in early trading, with the Straits Times Index increasing 4.86 points to 3,352.53, driven by overnight gains in the US markets. Albedo was the most active stock, rising 0.004 to 0.017 after announcing a S$18.9 million deal to buy a majority stake in a Taiwanese aesthetic medicine group. The rally marks the 5th consecutive day of gains ahead of GDP data release.

site_title: Lippo Malls secures S$260m loan to refinance bonds due July
summary: Lippo Malls Indonesia Retail Trust (LMIRT) secured a S$260 million, 54-month term loan from BNP Paribas and Standard Chartered to refinance S$200 million of bonds due in July and for working capital. The loan is a vote of confidence in the trust's prudent management and stable operational performance. Proceeds from the loan will be used to refinance bonds, work capital, and cover general corporate expenses.

site_title: Germanwings pilot saw 7 doctors in month before crash: prosecutor
summary: Prosecutor Brice Robin announced an expanded probe into the Germanwings crash, which killed 150 people, to determine if anyone could be held liable for manslaughter. Pilot Andreas Lubitz, who intentionally crashed the plane, saw 41 doctors in five years, including seven in the month before the crash. The investigation will focus on whether airline companies adequately monitored Lubitz's mental health. The remains of 44 Germans have been returned home for burial, with the rest to be repatriated by the end of June. An expanded probe aims to identify potential faults or negligence by Lufthansa in detecting Lubitz's health.

site_title: Christopher Lee, evil count of cinema, dies at age 93
summary: British actor Christopher Lee, known for his iconic roles in horror classics and later in films like "Star Wars" and "The Lord of the Rings," has died at age 93. Lee, who portrayed Dracula, Frankenstein's monster, and the Mummy, died on Sunday in a London hospital due to respiratory problems. A master of the macabre, Lee's deep voice and imposing frame made him a standout in the horror genre, and he continued to work in film until his death, appearing in movies like "Hugo" and "Dark Shadows."

site_title: Fifa: Blatter resists quit calls, top ally resigns
summary: FIFA President Sepp Blatter has resisted calls to immediately step down, despite a European Parliament resolution demanding his resignation. Blatter intends to continue in office until a successor is designated, likely by the end of the year. Meanwhile, FIFA Director of Communications and Public Affairs Walter De Gregorio has resigned, citing his decision to continue serving on a consultancy basis until the end of the year. The FIFA Congress, scheduled for July 20, will focus on passing reforms and electing a new president.

site_title: US House takes key steps toward 'fast-track' vote Friday
summary: The US House of Representatives approved a measure authorizing funds to help workers who lose their jobs due to trade deals, without cutting Medicare health benefits. The vote, 397-32, passed ahead of a final vote on Friday. The move comes as President Barack Obama seeks "fast-track" negotiating authority on a Pacific Rim trade deal. Unions are urging Democrats to vote down a program that would kill the trade drive, citing concerns about aid for workers. The Senate had proposed cutting Medicare benefits to fund the program.

site_title: Spanish king strips graft-accused sister of duchess title
summary: Spanish King Felipe VI has issued a decree stripping his sister Princess Cristina of her title as Duchess of Palma due to tax evasion charges. Princess Cristina, 49, is accused of taking part in tax evasion by her husband, former Olympic handball player Inaki Urdangarin. The royal sibling faces trial on two counts of accessory to tax fraud, marking the first time a member of the Spanish royal family has been sent to court. The decision comes amid a corruption controversy that has embarrassed the monarchy.

site_title: Twitter CEO Costolo out as growth pressure mounts
summary: Twitter CEO Dick Costolo is stepping down on July 1, handing the reins back to co-founder Jack Dorsey. Dorsey will take an interim role, and a search committee will find a permanent replacement. The move comes amid pressure from investors to boost user growth and revenues. Twitter's shares jumped 4% after the announcement, and Dorsey expressed faith in Costolo's strategy, but acknowledged the need for changes to attract users and advertisers.

site_title: India's push to offer banking for all stumbles on empty accounts
summary: India's "banking for all" initiative, launched by Prime Minister Narendra Modi last August, has seen 53% of 160 million accounts opened remain empty as of June 3, despite millions signing up for free insurance and overdraft facilities. The government aims to curb cash use, limit corruption, and rein in the informal economy, but experts say payment mechanisms need improvement and direct subsidies could encourage account use. The annual cost of empty accounts is estimated at 21 billion rupees, while subsidies could potentially improve account usage and yield returns for banks.

site_title: Europe: Gains on shares fizzle out as caution returns over Greece
summary: Europe's stock market rally stalled on Thursday as concerns over Greece's debt problems led to a late pullback. Despite the Greek stock market's 8.2% gain, the pan-European FTSEurofirst 300 index closed up 0.6% at 1,557.95 points. Investors remain cautious, with some expecting a resolution to Greece's debt crisis, while others see signs of progress. European markets, including Germany's DAX and France's CAC, also rose, with automotive stocks leading the gains.

site_title: New birth for social democracy
summary: A new compact is needed to empower citizens in the face of today's tech transformation, which is driving workers worldwide under significant pressure. The changing nature of work, driven by services and technology, is displacing many types of workers and creating new business models. To address this, centre-left parties must develop strong social policies, including lifelong individual budgets of support and security, compatible with new technologies. This approach would require the public sector to take primary responsibility for financing social protection and frame cooperation among government, employers, and recipients to eliminate duplication and bolster effectiveness and fairness.

site_title: US: Wall St climbs after retail sales data; healthcare up
summary: US stocks rose on Thursday, driven by retail sales data and gains in healthcare shares. The S&P 500 climbed 0.17% to 2,108.86, while the Dow Jones industrial average rose 0.22%. Healthcare stocks, including Eli Lilly and Gilead, were among the day's best performers, with Eli Lilly hitting a 14-year high. Retail sales increased 1.2% in May, beating expectations, and solid job growth and stabilizing manufacturing activity suggest the economy is gaining momentum.

site_title: Boeing trials Honeywell precision landing tech
summary: Boeing and Honeywell Aerospace have successfully tested precision landing technology, known as Honeywell's SmartPath Ground-Based Augmentation System (GBAS), on a Boeing 787 flight test plane. The technology enables safe runway approaches and landings in adverse weather conditions, improving air traffic operations. The test included 12 CAT III approaches and landings, allowing pilots to land in low-visibility weather conditions, reducing crowded approaches and improving on-time arrivals and take-offs. This technology aims to enhance operational efficiency, save fuel, and reduce carbon dioxide emissions.

site_title: Government trims private housing land supply as expected
summary: The Singapore government has trimmed the private residential land supply in the second half of the year, with 7,825 units introduced across 17 confirmed and reserve list sites, a 11% decrease from the first half. This move indicates confidence in the demand-side cooling measures, which have dampened the market, and a shift from price growth control to maintaining sufficient supply to meet long-term housing demand. The government aims to balance supply and demand dynamics, ensuring a "respectable pipeline" for developers.

site_title: Modi's solar embrace in India is leaving wind power in the shade
summary: India is set to surpass wind power for the first time as it adds more solar capacity, with 2,500 MW of solar installations planned by March 2016, exceeding the 2,400 MW target for wind. Prime Minister Narendra Modi aims to scale up clean energy fivefold by 2022, driven by the nation's abundant sunlight and reliance on coal-fired power. The government estimates a $200 billion investment is needed to achieve this goal, with several companies pledging to support the clean-energy transformation.

site_title: Company board should lead the assurance process
summary: Company board members should lead the assurance process, defining corporate objectives and setting expectations for risk management. This includes fostering a corporate culture aligned with the business strategy and ensuring long-term growth. Over three-quarters of participants in a corporate governance seminar agreed that an effective board prioritizes strategies and sustainable business models. The board is also responsible for overseeing risk assurance and ensuring that objectives are achieved. This emphasizes the importance of a strong corporate governance structure in driving business success.

site_title: China's loan-hungry developers move from shadows to cloud
summary: China's real estate developers are increasingly turning to internet financing, such as peer-to-peer lending and crowdfunding, as traditional loan sources become scarce. This shift is driven by the need to secure funds for billion-dollar projects, with some developers raising billions of yuan online. However, regulators have expressed concerns about the maturity of the online market, citing information asymmetry and inadequate risk management. Despite these risks, internet financing is expected to triple this year, with the China Real Estate Crowdfunding Alliance forming to standardize the industry.

site_title: Lone Star to buy up to 500m euros of land in Spain to build homes
summary: Lone Star Funds, a private-equity firm, plans to invest up to 500 million euros in Spain to develop housing projects, targeting areas with low home stock and solvent demand. The company, led by Neinor Homes, aims to build homes for middle-class buyers aged 40-50 in Madrid, Barcelona, and coastal regions. This investment signals a rebound in Spain's residential property market, which has been recovering after a six-year slump. Demand for homes in these areas is expected to rise, with transactions increasing by 9.4% in the first quarter.

site_title: New CFO at Maybank Kim Eng Singapore
summary: Maybank Kim Eng Singapore has promoted Chuah Lai Hock to chief financial officer (CFO) effective July 1, replacing Ronnie Fernandiz. Fernandiz, who previously held the role from 2013 to 2015, will become finance head for group global banking in Malaysia. This change comes as the Singapore equities market remains quiet. The move also marks a return for Fernandiz to the Maybank Kim Eng fold.

site_title: China posts slowest property investment growth in six years
summary: China's real estate investment growth slowed to 5.1% in the first five months of 2015, its lowest rate in six years, but floor area sold declined only 0.2%. Home sales measured by floor area rose 16.4% in May, the first increase since November 2013. Analysts attribute the uptrend to government stimulus policies, which are expected to support the market in the short term. Moody's changed its outlook to stable from negative, forecasting 0-5% growth in China property sales over the next 12 months.

site_title: World Bank sees tough times for emerging markets
summary: The World Bank predicts emerging markets will face "tough challenges" in 2015 due to rising global interest rates, currency swings, and reduced capital flows. Asia-Pacific's growth is expected to ease to 6.7% in 2015, while Russia and Brazil will bear the brunt of the slowdown. Developing countries are projected to grow 4.4% this year, with a possible rise to 5.2% in 2016 and 5.4% in 2017. High-income countries, including the US, euro area, and Japan, are expected to grow 2.8% this year.

site_title: Global inter-connectivity means Mers will come to Singapore in time: PM Lee
summary: Singapore Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong stated that the country will eventually face a Middle East Respiratory Syndrome (Mers) case due to its high inter-connectivity. He made this point during a visit to Tan Tock Seng Hospital, saying that Singapore "must assume" Mers can and will enter the country. Lee emphasized that with proper systems in place, there is no need to panic, and Singapore will be prepared to cope with the virus.

site_title: China's industrial output up 61.%, retail growth rebounds
summary: China's industrial output surged 6.1% in May, a three-month high, while retail sales rebounded 10.1% from a nine-year low, offering cautiously positive signs for the world's second-largest economy. These growth indicators suggest China's economy may be stabilizing, contrary to previous concerns about slowing GDP growth.

site_title: Moody's keeps Ba3 rating on Yanlord Land with stable outlook
summary: Moody's has maintained Yanlord Land Group's Ba3 rating with a stable outlook, citing the developer's strong brand, high-quality properties, and access to debt and capital markets. Despite weak 2014 credit metrics due to high debt leverage and low interest coverage, Moody's expects Yanlord's credit metrics to remain weak in the next 12-18 months. The rating agency also notes that Yanlord's focus on developing high-end properties in prime areas supports premium branding and pricing, mitigating margin pressures.

site_title: Sars scars fuel fear in HK as Mers virus plan starts
summary: Hong Kong is taking proactive measures against the Mers virus, with a 23-page preparedness plan in place. The city has no confirmed cases, but a suspected case led to a social media frenzy and stock market drop. The response is part of Hong Kong's extensive infectious disease response program, shaped by its experience with Sars in 2003. Immediate testing, fever screening, and quarantine camps are being implemented, giving the city an edge in protecting itself against another epidemic. Stocks rebounded after the government confirmed no Mers cases.

site_title: Innovations needed for electric vehicle sector to move ahead
summary: Singapore's electric vehicle (EV) test-bed is set to expand with Phase 2, deploying 1,000 EVs for car-sharing purposes between 2016 and 2026. Despite initial higher purchase prices, EVs are cheaper to recharge, but the high cost of building charging infrastructure offsets this advantage. The government's contracted fee for unlimited charging in Phase 1 was S$180, comparable to the cost of petrol. The test-bed aims to assess the feasibility of EVs in Singapore's transportation sector.

site_title: Calling time out on my Apple Watch
summary: A writer reflects on their decision to break up with their Apple Watch, citing that its constant attention and attempts to be a fashion accessory made it difficult to enjoy. The watch's functionality was often overshadowed by its marketing and the assumptions it drew from its design, leading the writer to feel self-conscious and uncomfortable. The decision was made after realizing the watch was not transforming their life as they had hoped, and instead, they have learned valuable truths about themselves, such as not wanting to be defined by a product.

site_title: GoGoVan raises Series B+ funds, plans expansion
summary: GoGoVan, an on-demand delivery van startup, has secured an "eight-figure" Series B+ round of funding co-led by existing shareholder Renren and new investor Zemin Hu. The funding will enable the company to rapidly expand its platform offerings and global presence. GoGoVan has already expanded beyond Hong Kong to Singapore, South Korea, China, and Taiwan, with over 80,000 drivers and $100 million in transaction value. The company plans to develop technology for more customer segments and increase driver quality in Singapore, and is exploring more delivery service options.

site_title: South Korea cuts rates as Mers clouds outlook
summary: South Korea's central bank cut interest rates by 25 basis points to a record-low 1.5% as the country struggles with a deadly outbreak of Middle East respiratory syndrome (Mers), with 14 new cases and 10 fatalities reported. The move aims to soften the economic blow from the outbreak, which has forced the cancellation of thousands of trips and closures of schools and businesses. The outbreak, the largest outside Saudi Arabia, has raised concerns about the disease's spread, but experts say China is capable of containing any outbreak.

site_title: Sad vibrations from biopic of a tortured musical genius
summary: "Love & Mercy," a biopic about Brian Wilson of The Beach Boys, tells the story of a musical genius struggling with his talent and personal demons. The film, directed by Bill Pohlad, follows Wilson's life in two parallel narratives: his creative peak in the 1960s and his descent into instability in the 1980s. Played by Paul Dano and John Cusack, Wilson's complex and troubled personality is portrayed in a searing and intense portrayal, exploring the intersection of music, mental health, and the pressures of fame.

site_title: Expectations of incoming SGX CEO should be toned down
summary: The article advises that expectations for the new CEO of Singapore Exchange (SGX) should be toned down due to the long wish-list from stakeholders. It's unlikely that the new CEO can reverse existing policies, and those who want to bring back the lunch break or uncollaterised trading are being unrealistic. The Society of Remisiers (Singapore) has changed its stance, supporting a 5% collaterised trading environment, which may indicate a shift towards treating SGX as a more regulated market, rather than a casino.

site_title: US should ditch 'outdated' oil export ban: Harvard paper
summary: The US should lift its 40-year-old ban on oil exports to capitalize on its hydraulic fracturing boom, according to a Harvard Business School and Boston Consulting Group study. Lifting the ban is expected to add $23 billion to the economy by 2030, create tens of thousands of jobs, and provide the US with more diplomatic clout overseas. The ban has reduced market opportunities for producers and reduced US growth, with no clear offsetting benefits. The study calls for steps to fully benefit from the fracking boom, addressing concerns about air and water pollution.

site_title: Some furniture, personal items of Lee Kuan Yew donated to NHB
summary: Lee Kuan Yew's furniture and personal items, including a desk he worked on for years, have been donated to the National Heritage Board (NHB) for a major public exhibition at the SG50 Tribute Gallery in August or September. The items were given "for the people of Singapore" by his executors and trustees, following his death in March 2015. The donation is in line with his last Will and Testament, which stated that his house at 38 Oxley Road should be demolished after his death.

site_title: Dinosaurs rule in old-fashioned action adventure
summary: Jurassic World, a summer blockbuster film, brings back dinosaurs as the stars of the show, updating the 1993 original Jurassic Park with modern-day thrills and chills. The film, directed by Colin Trevorrow, features a genetically modified hybrid, Indominus Rex, that goes rogue and wreaks havoc on the island. A team of characters, including a former Navy man-turned-dinosaur trainer, must work together to stop the chaos and save the day. The film's action-packed adventure and nostalgic value are expected to propel it to the top of the box-office food chain.

site_title: Worst shortage in 4 decades drives up UK house prices
summary: The UK house price growth accelerated for a fourth month in May, driven by the worst shortage of properties for sale in nearly four decades. The Royal Institution of Chartered Surveyors (RICS) reported a 34-point price gauge, up from 32 in April, with London seeing its highest measure in almost a year. Home sales were down 14% from a year earlier, and the average house price in England and Wales reached a new high of £277,178. Experts warn that prices will continue to rise unless housing supply increases.

site_title: Power companies are a favourite target of computer hackers
summary: Hackers have targeted the energy industry, with 47% of energy organisations reporting attacks in a survey by Trend Micro. The sector is vulnerable due to its increasing reliance on technology and interconnected systems. Cybercrimes cost energy companies an average of $13.2 million annually, and spending on cybersecurity for oil and gas infrastructure is expected to reach $1.9 billion by 2018. The industry faces threats from hackers, including state-sponsored attackers, and companies are struggling to protect themselves from cyberattacks.

site_title: Nestle challenges Maggi ban in Mumbai court
summary: Nestle is challenging a ban on its popular Maggi instant noodles brand in India after tests showed excessive lead levels. The company is seeking judicial review of a June 5 order from the government's food safety regulator. Despite pulling the product from sale, Nestle will continue to keep it off store shelves. The ban has led to a loss of market share for Nestle, with rivals ITC and Bambino filling the gaps. If the product remains off shelves for July, Nestle could lose nearly three billion rupees in sales.

site_title: Local band dominates charts and hearts
summary: The Sam Willows, a local band, is set for its biggest year with a new single already chart-topping. The quartet, comprising siblings Benjamin and Narelle Kheng, along with friends Sandra Riley Tang and Jon Chua, has become one of the most successful bands in the local music scene. They recently toured the US and played to a record-breaking 50,000 people at the SEA Games opening ceremony. Their major label contract with Sony Music Entertainment and wholesome image have contributed to their success.

images.alt_text: Dylan Tan

site_title: Noble is a far better company today
summary: Noble Group's Chairman, Richard Elman, wrote a letter to subscribers expressing confidence in the company's future despite past challenges. He stated that Noble has not changed and is working behind the scenes to protect its interests. Elman attributed the company's current strength to its ability to adapt to market changes and emphasized that Noble is a "far better company today" than it was a year ago. He urged subscribers to have confidence and patience, assuring them that Noble will "right the damage" and recover share value.

site_title: India carmakers pray for good monsoon to drive demand
summary: Indian carmakers are concerned about the impending drought due to the El Nino weather phenomenon, which may lead to the driest two-year spell in nearly three decades. A poor monsoon could negatively impact farmers, potentially delaying the purchase of new cars, including electric vehicles like Tesla. The drought could also affect the automotive industry, with potential implications for car manufacturers and the overall economy.

site_title: Deutsche may lose Asia forex lead on Jain's exit
summary: Deutsche Bank may lose its lead in Asia's foreign exchange and fixed income markets following the exit of co-CEO Anshu Jain. Jain's departure could lead to a scaling back of capital-intensive businesses, creating opportunities for other banks like JPMorgan, Citigroup, and HSBC to grow in the region. Despite Jain's commitment to defending Deutsche's market position, the bank's Asia-Pacific revenue has been growing at a slower rate than other regions. Other banks are expected to gain market share, potentially ending Deutsche's dominance in the Asian FX and fixed income space.

site_title: SC Capital aims to raise US$400m for property fund
summary: SC Capital Partners, a Singapore-based real estate money manager, aims to raise US$400 million for an Asia-focused property fund. The fund, which will be marketed to global institutional investors starting next week, seeks to provide long-term appreciation in the Asia-Pacific region. The company, founded in 2004, is looking to capitalize on the region's growth as the main economic driver in the world.

site_title: EMA launches framework to meet Singapore power sector's manpower needs
summary: The Energy Market Authority (EMA) of Singapore has launched the National Energy Competency Framework (NECF), a new framework to guide the power sector's manpower needs. Developed in collaboration with the industry and training providers, NECF provides career progression pathways and competencies for 26 electricity and gas job families. The framework aims to attract and retain talent, and enhance staff development in the power sector. Institutions can use NECF to align their curriculum and training programs, and the EMA has established a "Powering Lives" portal to provide information on career and scholarship opportunities.

site_title: Rivals MAS and AirAsia Group undergo reboots to survive
summary: Malaysia Airlines (MAS) and AirAsia Group are undergoing reboots to survive in a highly competitive market. MAS aims to become profitable in three to four years after cutting 6,000 jobs and axing four unprofitable routes. AirAsia Group, despite posting a loss of RM429 million in the October-to-December quarter, has completed a rights issue to raise funds and returned to profitability in the first quarter. Analysts predict mixed outcomes, with some expecting AirAsia to return to profitability in FY17 and MAS to achieve profitability in three to four years.

site_title: London to start selling down its 80% stake in RBS: Osborne
summary: The British government, led by Chancellor George Osborne, plans to sell down its 80% stake in Royal Bank of Scotland (RBS) in an effort to exit the banking business. The government may record a loss on some of its holdings, but ultimately aims to recoup its investment plus £14.5 billion from bailouts. The sale of RBS shares is expected to improve the marketability of remaining holdings, benefiting taxpayers.

site_title: Microsoft's huge touch screens - Made in America
summary: Microsoft is set to start selling the Surface Hub, a 84-inch touch-screen computer, to companies as a high-tech replacement for conference room whiteboards. The device, priced at $20,000, is made in the US, specifically in Wilsonville, Oregon, where it was previously manufactured by a startup acquired by Microsoft. This move is seen as a rare example of high-tech manufacturing jobs returning to the US, but experts note that such instances are still outliers in the industry.

site_title: Singapore-Thailand economic ties to be strengthened
summary: Singapore and Thailand aim to deepen their economic ties, with Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong calling for greater business-to-business cooperation. Bilateral trade has grown to S$30 billion, with the two nations seeking to promote mutual benefits. The strengthened ties follow a retreat between Lee and Thai Prime Minister Prayut Chan-o-cha.

images.alt_text: Lee U-Wen

site_title: The Dog Whisperer sends a clear message
summary: Dog trainer Cesar Millan emphasizes that showering dogs with excessive affection can lead to behavioral issues. He recommends a balanced approach of exercise, discipline, and affection in that order. Millan's "live" engagement in Singapore aims to promote responsible dog ownership. He believes that dogs need structure and boundaries to thrive, rather than constant displays of affection. By prioritizing exercise, discipline, and affection, dog owners can create a harmonious relationship with their pets.

images.alt_text: Dylan Tan

site_title: Noble shares rebound on Elman's pledge to 'right the damage'
summary: Noble Group shares have rebounded after chairman Richard Elman pledged to "right the damage" and restore share value. Despite a rating agency revising its outlook on Noble from "stable" to "negative," Elman appealed to shareholders and staff to be patient. This comes after Noble's annual general meeting in April. The company's volatile trading has been a concern, but Elman's comments have provided some relief to investors.

site_title: Customers' trust about personal data can't be bought
summary: US customers' trust in personal data cannot be bought, according to a recent survey of over 900 consumers. Most respondents want to prevent government and financial institutions from sharing their data, while retailers and airlines are viewed as less trustworthy. Companies can earn trust by asking for permission in a clear way, doubling the number of consumers willing to share data. The reluctance to trade data for compensation applies to all users, regardless of online sophistication. Companies must prioritize trust to build loyalty and avoid reputational harm.

site_title: Reelpolitik
summary: The OPEN festival in Singapore is showcasing a strong slate of 14 award-winning films that explore the impact of governments and regimes on ordinary people. The films, from countries including Russia, Germany, and Indonesia, examine devastating moments in their respective histories. The screenings, which include award-winning features and documentaries, offer an unflinching look at the consequences of political systems on individuals and communities. The films are part of the pre-festival of the Singapore International Festival of Arts (SIFA).

images.alt_text: Helmi Yusof
Post Mortem, part of the Pablo Larrain trilogy that includes Tony Manero, looks at the chilling legacy of Pinochet.

site_title: Huationg Holdings strikes partnership with Mitsui
summary: Huationg Holdings has entered a strategic partnership with Mitsui & Co and JA Mitsui Leasing, with the latter two purchasing a 49% stake in the heavy lifting and haulage player for 3.5 billion yen (about S$38.2 million). The deal will help Huationg redefine its expansion throughout the Asia-Pacific region, with plans to establish itself as a market leader in the industry. The partnership is seen as a key step in Huationg's growth and expansion into the Indonesian market, where it hopes to acquire local businesses.

images.alt_text: Mindy Tan

site_title: History takes a spin in the rabbit hole
summary: Singaporean authors Sonny Liew and Mohamed Latiff Mohamed have released novels that borrow historical moments to tell their stories. "The Art Of Charlie Chan Hock Chye" by Liew and "The Widower" by Latiff Mohamed, both published by Epigram Books, take creative liberties with significant events in Singapore's past. The authors' reinterpretations have sparked controversy, with the authorities taking issue with one of the works. The novels' use of dramatic license raises questions about the boundaries between fiction and history.

images.alt_text: Helmi Yusof

site_title: Washi goes from bombs to clothes
summary: For 1,300 years, Japanese paper from Ogawa has served various purposes, including Buddhist scriptures and balloon bombs. However, as Japan marks the 70th anniversary of its defeat in World War II, Ogawa-washi is being repurposed as a fabric for clothes. The traditional washi-making process was inscribed on Unesco's list of Intangible Cultural Heritage, sparking hopes for tourism. A local designer has created western-style clothes from washi, blending the ancient and modern. The delicate fabric is said to be light, breathable, and durable, offering a unique textile option.

images.alt_text: Senior craftsman Teizo Takano working at his papermaking studio in Ogawa (above);
Former craftsman Kaihei Kasahara (above) used to make paper balloon bombs during World War II.

site_title: Albedo to acquire majority stake in Taiwan firm
summary: Albedo Limited, a Singapore-based steel trader, agreed to acquire a 51% stake in China iMyth Company Pte Ltd, a Taiwanese aesthetic medicine group, for S$18.9 million. The acquisition aims to diversify Albedo's business and create value for shareholders. The deal includes a payment of S$12 million in cash and 550 million shares, as well as the issuance of warrants to new investors. The acquisition is expected to enhance Albedo's long-term viability and use the net proceeds for working capital and growth.

site_title: Mers-CoV: A brief breakdown
summary: The Middle East respiratory coronavirus (Mers-CoV) is a respiratory illness that has spread globally, particularly in the Middle East and South Korea, with 38% of known cases resulting in death. It is transmitted through infected person's droplets and can cause mild to severe illness. The disease is not yet considered highly contagious, and Singapore has designated Tan Tock Seng Hospital to handle cases. The incubation period is 2-14 days, similar to Sars-CoV. Measures have been put in place to handle the pandemic, and experts believe that isolation and early identification can reduce human-to-human transmissions.

images.alt_text: The Middle East respiratory coronavirus (Mers-CoV) is a respiratory illness which has spread globally recently, particularly in the Middle East and South Korea.

site_title: Wall Street rally helps STI rise 22 pts
summary: The Straits Times Index (STI) rose 22 points, or 0.67%, to 3,347.67, its second consecutive day of gains, after a Wall Street rally on Wednesday. The index had recovered its losses from the previous four sessions. Noble Group's shares rebounded after its chairman asked for patience, while Singtel and YuuZoo also saw gains. The STI's technical indicators had entered oversold territory, according to UBS Investment Research, which advised investors to buy.

site_title: Google dives into business of improving urban life
summary: Google is launching Sidewalk Labs, an independent company focused on developing technologies to improve urban life. Led by Daniel Doctoroff, the startup will cut pollution, curb energy use, and streamline transportation, with Google investing a significant amount. Sidewalk Labs aims to build technology platforms that residents can plug into, rather than embedding itself in city infrastructure. The company's goal is to reduce the cost of city living and improve quality of life, with a focus on the "huge space between civic hackers and traditional big technology companies".

site_title: China's 'New Silk Road' plan offers investment opportunities in Mid-East
summary: China's "One Belt, One Road" initiative aims to rejuvenate ancient silk routes connecting China with Central Asia, Russia, Europe, South-east Asia, India, and Africa. The Middle East, particularly the Gulf Cooperation Council (GCC) states, is a key region in this plan, with China using the region for infrastructure upgrades and large-scale developmental projects. The yuan, increasingly used in international trade and investment, is also playing a role in creating opportunities for Middle Eastern businesses and investors. However, the US dollar remains the region's premier currency, and the upcoming International Monetary Fund (IMF) approval vote could see China's currency awarded official reserve currency status, potentially impacting global trade and investment.

site_title: Singapore fintech startup gets accredited by Malaysia regulator
summary: Singapore-based Crowdonomic, a crowdfunding platform, has been accredited by Malaysia's Securities Commission as a registered equity crowdfunding (ECF) platform. This is the first and only homegrown platform in South-east Asia to receive this status. The accreditation allows businesses to raise up to RM3 million (S$1 million) within a 12-month period, and microfunds can raise unlimited amounts via an ECF platform. The move aims to democratize finance and provide market-based financing to SMEs and startups in Malaysia.

site_title: Harness interests of the rich to help fight inflation: Berkeley don
summary: A visiting economist from the University of California, Berkeley, Professor Andrew Rose, suggests that the interests of the wealthy can be harnessed to help countries fight inflation. He found that countries with a domestic currency bond market experienced lower inflation rates, with consumer price index inflation 2.9 percentage points lower and gross domestic product inflation 4.4 percentage points lower. This is because bondholders, who are typically wealthy individuals and institutions, lose out if inflation erodes their coupons, leading them to lobby for tighter monetary policy.

site_title: US: Wall St opens higher after retail sales data
summary: US stocks opened higher on Thursday after better-than-expected retail sales data, indicating a growing momentum in the US economy. The Dow Jones industrial average rose 0.17%, the S&P 500 gained 0.16%, and the Nasdaq Composite added 0.22%. This marks the latest sign of a recovering economy, despite ongoing trade uncertainty and tariff concerns.

site_title: Abu Dhabi to issue rules on regulating real estate sector
summary: Abu Dhabi's ruler has issued a decree to regulate and improve transparency in the emirate's real estate sector. The decree requires brokers and developers to be licensed, introduces rules to protect buyers of unfinished projects, and mandates registration of all real estate developments. Unfinished projects will have payments held in a separate account, while brokers will not be allowed to represent multiple parties in a single transaction. The new rules aim to increase transparency and protect buyers, but no specific implementation date has been specified.

site_title: Albedo to buy majority stake in Taiwanese aesthetic medicine group for S$18.9m
summary: Albedo Limited has agreed to acquire a 51% stake in China iMyth Company Pte Ltd for S$18.9 million, expanding into China's healthcare market. The acquisition, worth S$12 million in cash and 550 million shares, will be used as a "springboard" for Albedo's diversification. Albedo CEO Tai Kok Chuan sees the deal as creating value for shareholders and enhancing the company's long-term viability. Chung Yih-Chen, Taiwan's plastic surgeon expert, retains a 49% stake in China iMyth.

site_title: City buzz
summary: The Deep, an exhibition at the ArtScience Museum, showcases creatures from the abyss, with over 40 deep-sea creatures and 67 images of sea fauna and bioluminescent creatures. The exhibit features interactive installations and preserved creatures suspended in tanks. Meanwhile, the Singapore Dance Theatre celebrates its 20th edition of Ballet Under The Stars with performances of Balanchine and Goh Choo San's works. The December Rains musical will also launch a new CD with a mini concert, and Antoinette offers a Nordic-inspired seafood "cake" for Father's Day. Comedian Ronny Chieng will perform at a comedy show.

site_title: Dim Sum Dollies' hysterical history lesson
summary: The Dim Sum Dollies' revue "The History of Singapore Part 1" has been staged, poking fun at Singaporean culture and history in a comedic manner. The show, which has been performed twice before, features a mix of jokes, dialect, and satire, making it a unique and entertaining experience. With its irreverent style, the Dollies have established themselves as a local comic institution, mercilessly ridiculing everything Singaporean. The show's updated gags, including political barbs, have been well-received, making it a must-see for Singaporeans looking for a lighthearted take on their country's history.

images.alt_text: Dylan Tan

site_title: IMF says no progress in Greece talks, deal far off
summary: The International Monetary Fund (IMF) stated that Greece and its creditors have made no recent progress in resolving their differences, with major differences still existing in key areas. Despite Greek Prime Minister Alexis Tsipras' talks with German Chancellor Angela Merkel and French leader Francois Hollande on a possible new bailout deal, the IMF says an agreement is far off.

site_title: Consumer confidence in US falls for a record ninth straight week
summary: US consumer confidence dropped to a seven-month low, falling for a record ninth straight week, as Americans' views of the buying climate deteriorated. The Bloomberg Consumer Comfort Index decreased to 40.1, the weakest since November, amid rising gasoline prices and a decline in the comfort index's buying climate gauge. However, wage gains and higher stock prices helped households feel better about their finances, with average pay for civilian workers rising 4.2% in the first quarter.

site_title: US office landlord ups the ante by offering free concierge service
summary: US office landlord Rick Caruso is introducing a unique concierge service for employees, offering perks such as car washing, grocery shopping, and party planning. Tenants will pay for their own expenses, but the services are included in the rent. This innovative approach aims to improve work-life balance, as the "second shift" of household duties is often left to working parents. Experts say this concept plays into the growing trend of employees expecting quality and help in their personal lives, and could be a game-changer for office landlords.

site_title: Brokers' take
summary: Singtel aims to grow its data business by increasing fibre and tiered data plan customers, despite muted earnings growth outlook. OUE Commercial Reit has entered a conditional sale and purchase agreement to acquire an indirect interest in One Raffles Place. Ho Bee Land's London properties are expected to contribute significantly to recurring income, potentially leading to a commercial Reit spin-off. These companies have been given buy ratings, with targets of S$4.50 for Singtel, S$0.88 for OUE Commercial Reit, and S$2.86 for Ho Bee Land.

site_title: EU parliament urges Blatter to quit Fifa job immediately
summary: The European Parliament has called on FIFA president Sepp Blatter to step down immediately, citing a need for urgent reforms in the governing body. The resolution, which is not legally binding, comes after a massive corruption scandal led to Blatter's resignation in June, which won't take effect until December. Parliament urges FIFA to select an interim leader to replace Blatter, allowing for reforms to begin. The move is seen as a show of pressure to address the credibility crisis in FIFA.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares close weaker on Thursday
summary: Malaysia's shares closed weaker on Thursday, with the Kuala Lumpur Composite Index slipping 2 points to 1,730. 1.4 billion lots were traded, with losers outnumbering gainers 468 to 289.

site_title: Europe tries to compete with China's influence in Latin America
summary: Europe is attempting to counter China's growing influence in Latin America by offering new trade deals, visa-free travel, and deeper ties. Despite China's $250 billion investment pledge, the EU lacks fresh cash and instead relies on its trade influence. EU leaders, including German Chancellor Angela Merkel, emphasized the need for increased trade between Europe and Latin America. The EU agreed to re-examine talks with Mercosur, deepen trade agreements with Mexico and Chile, and implement a free-trade accord with Ecuador.

site_title: Mindset shift needed at Noble Group
summary: Noble Group's shares have plummeted 42% in four months due to mounting public scrutiny of its accounting practices, particularly its classification of Yancoal as an associate instead of an investment. Critics, including self-proclaimed whistle-blower Iceberg Research, short-seller Muddy Waters, and retired investment banker Michael Dee, have raised concerns about the company's governance and transparency. Chairman Richard Elman has sent a letter to shareholders and staff, but the company's lack of transparency and failure to address concerns have raised doubts about its ability to win back market confidence. Privatization is a possible solution, but a more direct approach, such as addressing accounting-related questions, may be more effective.

images.alt_text: Shares in commodities firm Noble Group may have enjoyed some respite from their recent weakness when they bounced S$0.06 from a six-year low to close at S$0.705 on Thursday after its chairman Richard Elman sent a letter to shareholders and staff to reassure them that management is working hard behind the scenes.

site_title: Tales of two nations brought to life
summary: Wild Rice's "Another Country" theatre production brings to life over 60 texts from both sides of the Singapore-Malaysia Causeway, exploring the significance of Singapore's 50th anniversary. The show features excerpts from notable literature and writings by authors from both countries, engaging the audience for three hours. The production showcases excellent acting and brings the audience through a dramatized romp through the stories and histories of both nations. The event highlights the importance of Singapore's separation from Malaysia in achieving the country's 50th anniversary milestone.

images.alt_text: The Malaysia cast's portrayal of Han Suyin's And the Rain my Drink.
The Singapore cast performing the Malaysian section of the two-part play.

site_title: Plum Central Boulevard white site draws interest
summary: A 1.12-ha site at Central Boulevard in Singapore has drawn significant interest from developers, with Hongkong Land already expressing keen interest in acquiring the plot. The site, which can yield about 1.2 million square feet of commercial space and 375 residential units, is considered prime due to its location near key landmarks such as Marina Bay and Downtown MRT station. The Urban Redevelopment Authority (URA) plans to release the site for application around December, and experts believe it will be the most likely plot to be triggered for sale due to its high demand and limited supply of CBD sites until 2020.

images.alt_text: People crossing the road at Central Boulevard next to Marina Bay Financial Centre (MBFC). A Plum site at Central Boulevard, straddling the old Shenton Way financial district and the new Marina Bay downtown, has caught the market's attention more than any other site on the reserve list, with one developer already signalling potential interest.

site_title: Europe: Stocks pare gain as IMF says fails to make Greek progress
summary: European stocks pared gains after the International Monetary Fund (IMF) said its team negotiating with Greece left Brussels without making progress on a debt deal. The IMF cited "major differences" for the withdrawal, despite leaving the door open for further talks. Greek Prime Minister Alexis Tsipras promised to step up efforts to find a package of reforms and budget fixes to release financial aid. Despite lingering concerns, European Central Bank stimulus is providing a floor to drops, and stocks are seen as a good value, with investors expecting a higher end-of-year performance.

site_title: Twitter to more than double its staff at Asia-Pacific office
summary: Twitter is expanding its Asia-Pacific operations with the opening of its regional headquarters in Singapore, aiming to more than double its staff in the region. The company plans to add over 100 new jobs and establish a hub for live, digital innovations. The new office will house various business functions, including sales, partnerships, and marketing, and will feature a #RealTimeLab for live Twitter campaigns and analytics. Twitter's CEO, Dick Costolo, noted that the Asia-Pacific region is a vital market for the company, with 77% of Twitter accounts outside the US.

site_title: The winding road of Marco Polo
summary: Spanish composer-conductor Luis Serrano Alarcon has completed the third part of "Marco Polo - The Trilogy," a 90-minute composition performed by 60-strong amateur wind orchestra The Philharmonic Winds in Singapore. The trilogy, which includes "The Silk Road," "The Cathay Years," and "The Book of India," features unusual instruments and was conducted by different people for each part. Alarcon, 42, completed the trilogy after 30 years of childhood dreams, praising the orchestra's professionalism and passion for good music.

images.alt_text: The Philharmonic Winds (above) will perform Spanish composer-conductor Luis Serrano Alarcon's three-part piece about Marco Polo's travels
The Philharmonic Winds will perform Spanish composer-conductor Luis Serrano Alarcon's three-part piece about Marco Polo's travels

site_title: Rupert Murdoch sets 21st Century Fox transition: CNBC
summary: Rupert Murdoch is set to step down as CEO of 21st Century Fox and hand the job to his son James, 42, with his other son Lachlan as co-chairman. Murdoch, 84, will remain executive chairman, and the transition is expected to occur this year or early 2016. James Murdoch will take over day-to-day management at Fox, working with Lachlan and his father. The move follows the split of News Corp from 21st Century Fox two years ago, with the Murdoch family maintaining control of both companies.

site_title: EU energy boss seeks to make Mediterranean 'major gas marketplace'
summary: EU Climate Action and Energy Commissioner Miguel Arias Canete launched a plan to turn the Mediterranean region into a "major gas marketplace" as part of EU efforts to reduce dependency on Russia. This is the first of a series of energy platforms, including one for electricity and green energy, to be set up across the 28 EU nations and beyond. The goal is to accelerate progress on the creation of an energy union with improved cross-border infrastructure.

site_title: New Zealand dollar hits five-year low on rate cut
summary: The New Zealand dollar dropped 2.6% to a five-year low against the US dollar after the Reserve Bank of New Zealand cut interest rates, potentially paving the way for further easing. The move was a surprise, taking a toll on the kiwi. The US dollar rose against other currencies ahead of US retail sales data release, while a Singapore public offer by NTT DC Reit was oversubscribed 9.8 times.

site_title: US retail sales jump in May, brighten growth outlook
summary: US retail sales surged 1.2% in May, exceeding economists' forecasts, as households boosted purchases of autos and other goods despite higher gasoline costs. This data suggests the economy is gaining momentum after a slow start in the second quarter. Solid retail sales and robust job growth also keep the Federal Reserve on track to raise interest rates this year, with consumer spending expected to remain strong in the coming months.

site_title: US business inventories post largest gain in nearly a year
summary: US business inventories rose 0.4% in April, the largest gain in nearly a year, beating economists' forecasts. This increase, combined with a 0.6% rise in retail inventories, is expected to boost second-quarter GDP growth estimates. The Commerce Department reported a 0.6% increase in retail inventories, the largest since November 2013. The uptick in inventories suggests the economy may not have contracted in the first quarter as previously estimated, potentially altering GDP growth expectations.

site_title: Caution warranted on China stocks, despite inclusion in major indices
summary: China's stock markets have seen a boost due to the potential inclusion in major global indices, such as MSCI and FTSE. Analysts predict significant inflows of $400 billion from pension funds and $50 billion from passive assets if China A shares are included. However, MSCI has delayed inclusion until "important issues related to market accessibility" are resolved. FTSE expects to complete its review in September, and HSBC predicts partial inclusion could see a 23% representation in the MSCI Emerging Markets Index and $5 billion in passive inflows.

images.alt_text: The prospect of inclusion in major global indices is arguably one of several factors that have helped buoy China's stock markets over the past year. MSCI and FTSE have had the domestic China A-share market on their radar for some time.

site_title: US import prices rise as petroleum posts biggest gain since 2009
summary: US import prices rose 1.3% in May, the largest gain since March 2012, driven by a 12.7% surge in petroleum prices, the biggest increase since June 2009. Despite this, a strong dollar continued to curb underlying imported inflation pressures. Import prices excluding petroleum were unchanged, while imported food prices rose 0.3% and export prices rose 0.6%. The 12-month decline in import prices was 9.6%, while export prices declined 5.9% over the same period.

site_title: Nine banks to issue China's first certificates of deposit on Monday
summary: Nine Chinese banks, including the "Big Four" state lenders, will issue China's first large-scale certificates of deposit (CDs) on June 15, following guidelines released by the People's Bank of China. The CDs will have terms of one year or shorter, with individual subscription thresholds of 300,000 yuan and institutional thresholds of 10 million yuan. This move paves the way for full interest rate liberalization, allowing individual and institutional investors to access CDs.

site_title: Update: IMF quits Greek talks; EU tells Tsipras: stop gambling
summary: The International Monetary Fund (IMF) abruptly ended negotiations with Greece, citing major disagreements on key areas such as pensions, taxes, and financing. The EU has urged Greek Prime Minister Alexis Tsipras to take decisive action to avert a devastating default and potential exit from the eurozone. The IMF's departure raises concerns about the likelihood of a deal, with the EU and IMF experts doubting Greece's ability to meet proposed reforms. Greece needs a deal by the end of the month to unlock aid and avoid a default, which could trigger capital controls and unpredictable economic consequences.

site_title: ECB's Draghi defends private meetings after criticism of hedge-fund dinner
summary: European Central Bank President Mario Draghi has defended private meetings with hedge funds, saying they are essential for the ECB's transparency policy. Last month, Draghi discussed plans for money printing with a group of hedge funds, academics, and bankers, sparking criticism from the EU's top watchdog and investors. Draghi stated that the meetings did not disclose sensitive or confidential information and that the ECB would take steps to improve transparency of communication. The decision was welcomed by the European Ombudsman but others criticized the ECB for not informing all parties on an equal basis.

site_title: Amazon probed for e-books as EU widens scrutiny of US tech
summary: Amazon.com Inc is under probe by the European Commission for allegedly squeezing out rival e-book distributors by insisting on better terms with publishers. The EU's antitrust watchdog claims Amazon requires publishers to inform the company about more favorable terms offered to competitors and to ensure Amazon is offered terms at least as good as those for competitors. Amazon has stated its agreements with publishers are legal and in the best interests of readers, but the EU will analyze whether the clauses limit competition between different e-book distributors.

site_title: Boeing sees budget airlines driving jet market to US$5.6t
summary: Boeing predicts a surge in commercial aircraft sales to US$5.6 trillion over the next 20 years, driven by booming demand from budget airlines. Single-aisle jets, such as the 737, are expected to be the fastest-growing part of the global fleet, with sales totaling US$2.8 trillion by 2034. Four-engine jumbos, on the other hand, are predicted to see shrinking demand. Boeing's forecast points to a doubling of the global fleet to 43,560 planes by 2034.

site_title: S&P cuts Noble Group rating outlook to negative from stable
summary: Standard & Poor's revised the rating outlook on commodities trader Noble Group to negative from stable, citing a weakened trading risk position and potential earnings volatility. The agency affirmed Noble's BBB-minus rating, the lowest investment grade rating. This change is due to Noble's long-term commodity contracts, which create a mismatch between profit recognition and cash realization. A downgrade would take the company's rating into the junk category.

site_title: Fifa spokesman De Gregorio quits post at soccer governing body
summary: Fifa communications director Walter De Gregorio has quit his post as director of Communications & Public Affairs, effective immediately. He will serve as a consultant until the end of the year. The move comes as the soccer governing body deals with investigations in the US and Switzerland. Deputy Nicolas Maingot will take over the role on an interim basis.

site_title: US jobless claims up marginally, but jobs market firming
summary: US jobless claims rose slightly to 279,000 in the week ending June 6, but remained below the 300,000 threshold, indicating a firming labor market. This marks the 14th straight week claims held below 300,000. The four-week moving average of claims increased to 278,750. Nonfarm payrolls rose 280,000 in May, following a 221,000 increase in April.

images.alt_text: The number of Americans filing new claims for unemployment benefits rose slightly more than expected last week, but remained in territory consistent with a strengthening labour market.

site_title: Swee Hong sells rights to foreign workers' dormitory to Crest Capital for S$30m
summary: Swee Hong Limited has agreed to sell the rights to its foreign workers' dormitory, North Coast Lodge, to Crest Capital Asia for S$30 million. The dormitory, built on a 49,684.9 sq m site, has a capacity of 9,000 beds and was initially sub-leased from the Building & Construction Authority for a three-year term. The sale marks a significant move for Swee Hong, which had faced opposition from shareholders over a similar agreement with S11 Capital Investments. The transaction is expected to provide a financial boost to the company.

site_title: Singapore: Wall Street's rally helps STI add 22 points
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) rose 22 points, finishing at 3,347.67, following Wall Street's rally. Noble Group's shares rebounded after the company's chairman sought to reassure investors, while Singtel gained 0.03 dollars. The index has recovered 52 points in two days, ending a four-session slump. Market volume reached 1.5 billion units worth S$1.3 billion.

site_title: Singapore eDevelopment warns of expected loss for half-year ending June 30
summary: Singapore eDevelopment Limited has issued a profit warning, expecting a loss for the half-year ending June 30, 2015, due to low revenue from its property division and the lack of revenue from its mobile application, HotApp. The company will disclose further details on August 14. This follows a preliminary review of its unaudited financial results.

site_title: EU tells Greece's Tsipras: time's up, no more gambling
summary: The European Union has warned Greek Prime Minister Alexis Tsipras that time is running out to avoid a devastating default, with EU leaders urging him to take crucial decisions to avert a eurozone exit. The EU's Donald Tusk said there's no more time for "gambling" and that Greece needs to offer alternative savings and tax measures to deliver a modest fiscal surplus. The deadline for a deal is June 18, with Greece facing a possible default at the end of the month if fresh funds are not secured.

images.alt_text: The European Union bluntly warned Greek Prime Minister Alexis Tsipras on Thursday that time was up and he should stop playing with his cash-strapped country's future and instead take crucial decisions to avoid a devastating default.

site_title: Three parties sign MOU on energy storage systems integration in S'pore
summary: Singapore's Centre for Energy Research and Technology (CERT) has signed a memorandum of understanding with the Singapore Institute of Power and Gas (SIPG) and Singapore Test Services (STS) to integrate energy storage systems (ESS) with the country's power grid. The goal is to mitigate the impact of solar energy's intermittency and ensure a stable power grid. The three parties will collaborate on training and technical standards for ESS, with STS leading the development of product standards. This move aims to enhance Singapore's expertise in ESS and support the country's growing adoption of renewable energy.

site_title: Fifa gives Swiss authorities 2018, 2022 World Cup bidding data
summary: FIFA has handed over electronic data from the 2018 and 2022 World Cup bidding processes to Swiss authorities as part of an investigation into alleged corruption. The data transfer was made in accordance with a procedure initiated by FIFA in 2014. Swiss prosecutors have opened a probe into the awarding of the tournaments to Russia and Qatar, with officials in both countries denying any wrongdoing. FIFA officials were previously arrested and indicted on charges including racketeering and money laundering.

site_title: TIH to pump US$5m into vehicle to invest in Thailand real estate deal
summary: TIH Limited has entered into a shareholders' agreement to invest US$22 million in Chang Chun Road Limited (CCRL) for a real estate deal in Thailand. TIH's share of the investment is US$5 million, representing 22.73% interest in CCRL. This represents 6.79% of TIH's latest audited net tangible asset value. The deal marks a significant investment by TIH in the Thai real estate market.

site_title: EU pushes Greece for deal as protests erupt
summary: The European Union is pushing Greece for a debt deal, with EU Commission chief Jean-Claude Juncker urging Prime Minister Alexis Tsipras for a breakthrough after talks with German and French leaders failed to produce a deal. Protests erupted in Athens as Greece's creditors demand tougher reforms in exchange for the remaining €7.2 billion bailout. A default could send Greece crashing out of the euro, with the EU and IMF warning of economic contagion. The Greek government is discussing a possible extension of the bailout until March 2016, but time is running out for a deal as finance ministers from the eurozone meet on June 18.

site_title: Swatch plans to start selling sunglasses to boost product lineup
summary: Swatch Group AG plans to sell sunglasses under its namesake brand, Swatch Eyes, starting this year. The Italian-made collection will be sold in 900 locations, including Swatch shops and Asian retailers. This diversification comes as the Swiss watch industry faces challenges, including Apple's smartwatch introduction and a surge in the Swiss franc against the euro. Despite this, Swatch is still hiring in Switzerland, adding 770 jobs last year. The new sunglasses line aims to boost Swatch's product lineup and counter the industry's decline.

site_title: iPhone maker Foxconn in talks to build first Apple plant in India
summary: Foxconn Technology is in talks with the Indian government to build its first Apple plant in India, aiming to lower production costs and mitigate accelerating wage inflation in China. The move could help Foxconn keep hold of Apple orders amid intensifying competition. Foxconn plans to develop 10-12 facilities in India by 2020, including factories and data centers, and is looking to manufacture iPhones, iPads, and iPods for both domestic and global sales. A successful venture would be a major victory for India, which seeks to reboot manufacturing and turn its tech boom into a manufacturing and employment boost.

site_title: Hong Kong's SARS scars fuel MERS jitters as virus plan starts
summary: Hong Kong is implementing an extensive infectious disease response program after a suspected MERS case sparked panic and stock market fluctuations. Despite the patient testing negative for the virus, the city has put measures in place, including immediate testing, fever screening, and quarantine camps, as a precautionary measure. The city's experience with SARS in 2003 has shaped its response, with residents and investors showing cooperation with the government's tough measures. Hong Kong has no confirmed cases of MERS, and stocks rebounded after the government confirmed no cases.

site_title: Chinese developer Kaisa appoints new CEO, two directors quit
summary: Kaisa Group Holdings Ltd has appointed 34-year-old Zheng Yi as new CEO, effective immediately, following a management reshuffle. Two directors, Ye Lieli and Jin Zhigang, have resigned to focus on other business commitments. The move comes two weeks after a rival takeover bid was withdrawn, renewing investor uncertainty over Kaisa's debt repayment. Despite a liquidity crisis warning in March, analysts suggest the scrapped deal may indicate improvement in Kaisa's finances since authorities lifted a sales ban and reinstated a shareholder and founding chairman.

site_title: US testing Nestle's Maggi noodles after India recall
summary: The US Food and Drug Administration (FDA) is testing samples of Nestle's Maggi instant noodles after India recalled the product due to reports of excess lead. Nestle, the world's largest food company, is seeking to defend its reputation in India following the recall. The FDA is looking into the issue, but it's unclear if US products are affected. Nestle does not import, market, or distribute Maggi noodles in the US, and any products in US stores are sourced by retailers or imported through third parties.

site_title: Don't underestimate Greece contagion risks, warns Bundesbank
summary: German Bundesbank chief Jens Weidmann warned that Greece's contagion risks should not be underestimated, citing increasing daily risks of insolvency. Weidmann emphasized that Greece must meet its reform commitments to receive eurozone partner support, and that an erosion of monetary union principles would have consequences for the entire union. He also expressed concerns about the ECB's quantitative easing program, suggesting it could undermine central bank independence and hinder sustainable growth.

site_title: South Korea says Mers patient dies, 10th fatality in outbreak
summary: A South Korean man with terminal lung cancer died from the Middle East Respiratory Syndrome (Mers) virus, marking the 10th fatality in the country's outbreak since last month. The 65-year-old man, hospitalized since June 7, had been in the same ward as another Mers patient. This development highlights the severity of the outbreak in South Korea.

site_title: China to start cross-border payment system to boost yuan usage
summary: China is launching a cross-border payment system for the yuan, called China International Payment System (CIPS), by the end of the year to promote its global use. The system will facilitate cross-border trade settlement, direct investments, and other yuan deals in Asia, Oceania, and Europe. China aims to boost the yuan's global use to increase its inclusion in the International Monetary Fund's Special Drawing Rights basket, which currently includes the dollar, euro, yen, and pound. The move is seen as a vital step for the yuan's internationalization and a key part of China's efforts to increase its global economic influence.

site_title: Solar Impulse now fixed but waiting on weather: team
summary: Solar Impulse 2, a solar-powered plane, has been repaired and is ready to fly again after becoming stuck in Japan due to a cold front. The plane was damaged during a strong wind storm while on the ground, but repairs were completed. The team is now waiting for favorable weather conditions to continue its record-breaking attempt to circumnavigate the globe. The plane's pilot, Andre Borschberg, will attempt to find a "good weather window" to fly from Nagoya to Hawaii, a journey expected to take five days and nights.

site_title: Noble Group surges as chairman pledges to 'right the damage'
summary: Noble Group's stock surged 9.3% to 70.5 Singapore cents after Chairman Richard Elman pledged to "right the damage" caused by accounting concerns and negative market sentiment.
