The company had slumped 43% this year, with brokerages downgrading recommendations and lowering price targets. Elman's letter denied rumors and inaccuracies, and the company plans to work behind the scenes to regain market confidence. Standard & Poor's revised Noble's credit rating outlook to negative, citing earnings volatility, and the company aims to meet certain criteria over the next 9-12 months.

site_title: Good chance of a deal with Greece next week-senior EU official
summary: Greece and its creditors are close to reaching a deal in their cash-for-reforms talks, with a potential agreement possible by the next eurozone finance ministers meeting on June 18, a senior EU official stated. Discussions will focus on Greek pension reforms, value added tax rates, and primary surplus targets. The official expressed optimism, saying "I think there is a good chance that next week will bring an agreement that can be endorsed by the Eurogroup."

site_title: Oceanus unveils details of MOU with BioValence for China JV
summary: Oceanus Group Limited has unveiled details of its memorandum of understanding (MOU) with BioValence Sdn Bhd to set up a joint-venture company in China to distribute shrimp. The parties have concluded feasibility studies and initiated discussions on implementation plans, aiming to finalize the definitive agreement in early 2016. The MOU, signed in January, outlines a one-year timeline for incorporating a China special purpose vehicle and executing the definitive agreement.

site_title: Oil falls as IEA says price-rally under threat amid Opec boost
summary: Oil prices fell by as much as 0.8% after the International Energy Agency stated that Opec's record oil production, particularly by Saudi Arabia, Iraq, and the UAE, threatens this year's price rally. The IEA also raised its forecast for global demand growth by 0.3 percentage points. The increased supply outweighs the initial boost from the demand growth revision, leaving oil prices under threat.

images.alt_text: A shake-up of Saudi Arabia's oil leadership by King Salman has introduced a new element of unpredictability to its energy policymaking at a moment when Riyadh is grappling with slumping crude prices and its war in neighbouring Yemen.

site_title: Europe: Stocks open with losses
summary: Europe's main stock markets fell on Thursday, with London's FTSE 100 down 0.30% to 6,809.57 points, and Frankfurt's DAX 30 dropping 0.20% to 11,242.87 points. This follows a rise in stocks on Wednesday as investors sought bargain shares amid concerns over a Greek default and euro exit.

site_title: No need to be industry number one, says Spotify founder
summary: Spotify founder Daniel Ek stated that the music streaming industry is big enough for multiple players, and his company doesn't need to be number one. Ek expressed his ambition to maintain Spotify's current position as the leading music streaming service. He said being among the top three is sufficient, but his priority is to keep Spotify at the top. This comes after Apple launched its own music streaming service, adding to the growing competition in the industry.

site_title: China's May bank loans, money supply growth quicken
summary: China's banks made 900.8 billion yuan (S$195.6 billion) in new loans in May, exceeding expectations. Broad money supply growth accelerated to 10.8% year-over-year, up from 10.1% in April. Outstanding loan growth was 14%, slightly above expectations. The central bank's easing measures, including interest rate cuts, have yet to show significant effects on the economy, which faces pressure from a property market downturn and factory overcapacity.

site_title: Greece's jobless rate rises to 26.6 percent in first quarter
summary: Greece's jobless rate rose to 26.6% in the first quarter of 2015, with 71.6% of the 1.27 million unemployed being long-term unemployed. The rate is the highest since 2014, driven by the debt crisis and austerity measures imposed by the EU/IMF lenders. Greece's economy is expected to expand by 0.5% this year, but had dipped into recession in the first quarter after a fragile recovery last year.

site_title: Taiwan finance minister seeks fiscal stimulus for 2016 to support growth
summary: Taiwan's finance minister, Chang Sheng-ford, proposed increasing government investment spending in 2016 to boost economic growth amid a global slowdown. The economy grew 3.37% in the first quarter, its slowest pace since 2013, due to weak government consumption. The central bank is expected to keep interest rates on hold, maintaining a steady policy stance. The proposal aims to support Taiwan's export-reliant economy, which remains resilient despite sluggish growth in Europe and Asia.

site_title: Indonesia removes luxury tax for most goods: finance minister
summary: Indonesia's finance minister announced the removal of a luxury tax for most goods to boost household consumption and revive economic growth, which has slowed to its most sluggish pace since 2009. The move aims to address the country's weak consumption, which accounts for 55% of GDP. The decision comes amid a slow Ramadan and expectations of a slow retail season. The move is part of efforts to stimulate the economy and increase disposable incomes.

images.alt_text: Indonesia is exempting most goods from a luxury tax in a bid to boost household consumption and revive faltering economic growth, the finance minister said on Thursday.

site_title: Nestle challenges noodles ban in Indian court
summary: Nestle is challenging a ban on its Maggi instant noodles brand in India's high court after tests showed excessive levels of lead. The company, which has sold the noodles for over three decades, had already pulled the product from sale. Nestle claims the noodles are safe to eat, but the Food Safety and Standards Authority of India (FSSAI) banned the product after tests found lead levels above statutory limits. Shares in Nestle India fell 9% on the Bombay Stock Exchange due to the controversy.

site_title: Switzerland will dodge deep slump, government economist says
summary: Switzerland's economy is expected to avoid a deep slump due to domestic demand counteracting pressure on exports from the stronger Swiss franc, according to government economist Eric Scheidegger. Despite a predicted contraction in the second quarter, the government forecasts 0.9% growth this year, with expansion accelerating to 1.8% next year. A strong construction industry and buoyant private consumption are helping to offset weak trade. Scheidegger cites a better global environment, with the US and euro area central banks normalizing policies, as a reason for optimism.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks end 0.83% higher
summary: Hong Kong stocks rose 0.83% to close at 26,907.85 on Thursday, following a regional rally and a strong lead from Wall Street. The benchmark Hang Seng Index added 220.21 points, while the Shanghai Composite Index gained 0.32%. The Shenzhen Composite Index also rose 1.48%. The rally comes despite US-EU trade talks and ongoing tariff uncertainty, with investors remaining positive.

site_title: Singapore Wrap Thursday
summary: Singapore government to sell 17 sites in 2H 2015, yielding 7,825 private residential units and 277,580 square meters of commercial space. Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong says it's a "matter of time" before Singapore sees its first MERS case. Meanwhile, other news includes a surprise response from Vietnam to US tariff announcement, Malaysia seizing RM3 billion of Daim Zainuddin's assets, and China's GDP growth expected to slow.

site_title: Malaysia April factory output up 4.0% y-o-y, in line with forecast
summary: Malaysia's factory output rose 4.0% in April from the previous year, in line with market expectations. The March index was revised upwards to 7.1%, from 6.9%. This growth contrasts with the decline in exports, which fell 8.8% from a year ago due to lower gas prices affecting shipments. The results are consistent with market forecasts, despite the weaker-than-expected export data.

site_title: Opec's biggest pump record oil with rally in jeopardy: IEA
summary: OPEC's largest members, Saudi Arabia, Iraq, and the UAE, have pumped record amounts of crude oil, threatening the current 45% rally in oil prices. Despite OPEC's decision to maintain output quotas, the International Energy Agency (IEA) warns that disruptions to oil products and refinery projects may ease supply imbalances, curbing price gains. Global oil supply is about 96 million barrels, with OPEC's output about 1.3 million barrels above its target of 30 million barrels a day.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks close 1.68% higher after four days of losses
summary: Tokyo stocks rose 1.68% on Thursday, reversing four days of losses, with the Nikkei 225 index closing at 20,382.97 and the Topix index at 1,648.88. The gains come despite global market uncertainty, including US-EU trade talks and tariff concerns. In other markets, Singapore stocks notched a 5-day rally, and the S&P 500 and Nasdaq in the US edged to fresh records.

site_title: China's industrial output gains in sign economy is stabilising
summary: China's industrial production grew 6.1% in May, beating expectations, while retail sales and fixed-asset investment also showed stabilization. This marks a counterpoint to earlier data on sluggish domestic growth, suggesting the economy may be pulling out of its weakest growth since the 2009 global recession. Economists believe pro-growth policies could improve the economic situation in the third quarter, with some indicators already showing signs of stabilization.

site_title: PM: 'Matter of time' before Singapore sees first Mers case
summary: Singapore Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong stated that it's only a matter of time before the country detects its first case of Middle East respiratory syndrome (Mers). He made the comment during a visit to Tan Tock Seng Hospital, Singapore's designated isolation center for Mers patients. The visit aimed to observe emergency preparedness measures.

site_title: Hot stock: Noble slides as OCBC cuts target price to S$0.61
summary: Noble Group shares fell after OCBC cut its target price to S$0.61, citing uncertainty over the company's accounting practices and a weaker outlook for commodities. The stock hit a high of 66 cents earlier in the day, but retreated as the bank trimmed its valuation from 13.5 times earnings to 8 times earnings. OCBC maintained its "hold" rating and attributed the pullback to a "new normal" for China's slower economic growth and volatile crude oil prices.

site_title: Water test begins for wider Panama Canal
summary: Crews have begun flooding part of the widened Panama Canal for its first operational tests, a five-day process to fill the new Agua Fria locks with 5 million cubic meters of water. The test, expected to take several months, is part of a $5.25 billion upgrade to the canal's system of locks, allowing for ships carrying up to 14,000 containers. The project, originally scheduled for completion in 2014, has seen repeated delays since work began in 2007.

images.alt_text: Crews began flooding part of the widened Panama Canal for its first operational tests, the group responsible for the massive project said.

site_title: Taiwan: Stocks flat; semiconductors rise
summary: Taiwan's stocks remained steady, with the main TAIEX index rising 6.6 points to 9,303.13. The electronics subindex was boosted by a 1.27% increase in semiconductors, which received support from the Philadelphia Semiconductor Index's 1.31% overnight gain. This helped keep Taiwan's domestic microchip industry afloat.

site_title: Australia: Shares jump the most in 7 weeks following surprise jobs data
summary: Australian shares surged 1.3% to their highest gain in seven weeks, driven by better-than-expected employment data and optimism over a Greek debt crisis solution. The S&P/ASX 200 index rose 70.7 points, led by banks, miners, and energy stocks. The unemployment rate fell, and the Reserve Bank of New Zealand cut interest rates, further boosting the market.

site_title: Twitter to more than double Asia-Pac HQ staff over next few years
summary: Twitter plans to add over 100 jobs to its Asia-Pacific headquarters in Singapore, more than doubling its current staff, to meet growing demand from users, partners, and advertisers. The new regional headquarters at CapitaGreen Building will accommodate technical staff, including data analytics professionals, engineers, and product specialists. Twitter vice-president Shailesh Rao sees the Asia-Pacific region as a key growth area, with potential to show the value of its platform to users, partners, and advertisers across Japan, India, and Australia.

images.alt_text: Christopher Lim
Twitter's new Asia-Pacific headquarters in Singapore will give it the space and facilities to grow to meet the demands of users, partners and advertisers in the region.

site_title: China's Jan-May property investment growth slows to 5.1% y-o-y
summary: China's real estate investment growth slowed to 5.1% in the first five months of 2015, down from 6% in the first four months. The floor area of property sold dropped 0.2% from the year-earlier period, while home sales have picked up recently in bigger cities. Economists say the sector will continue to drag on broader growth until high inventories of unsold homes are cleared and investment resumes, with construction expected to pick up once inventories are reduced. This slowdown is attributed to a cooling property market.

site_title: Hong Kong stock exchange chief sees China MSCI inclusion as inevitable
summary: Hong Kong Stock Exchange Chief Charles Li believes that China's 'A' shares will be included in the MSCI Emerging Markets Index, despite a one-year delay. MSCI requires China to further liberalize its capital markets before inclusion. Li expects the inclusion to happen, with a possible 5% initial weighting for 'A' shares. The imminent launch of a trading link with Shenzhen is seen as a step towards inclusion, and Li believes trading quotas can be lifted or eased to facilitate it.

site_title: China central bank researcher warns of "debt trap" for firms
summary: China's central bank researcher warns that non-financial firms risk a "debt trap" due to high interest borrowing. To address this, the researcher suggests banks exchange company debt for preferred shares to help firms deleverage. This move was recommended by Yao Yudong, director of the Research Institute of Finance, and Jin Hainian, chief research officer at Noah Holding Ltd. The proposal aims to alleviate debt concerns and support China's economic growth.

site_title: Gold firm after 3-day rally on sluggish dollar, Greek worries
summary: Gold prices held steady near a one-week high on Thursday, boosted by a weaker dollar and safe-haven bids amid the Greek debt crisis. The metal rose 0.8% on Wednesday after reaching US$1,192.10, with spot gold remaining at US$1,185.75 per ounce. A softer dollar makes gold cheaper for holders of other currencies, increasing its safe-haven appeal. However, traders expect downside bias due to prospects of higher US interest rates, and gains may be short-lived.

site_title: Oil prices down in Asian trade
summary: Oil prices in Asia declined Thursday following a mixed US energy report, with West Texas Intermediate falling 27 cents to $61.16 and Brent easing 19 cents to $65.51. Crude reserves fell 6.8 million barrels, but output reached a record high of 9.61 million barrels per day. Analysts expect a potential drawdown of US reserves and a slowdown in shale output to reduce global supplies, but the market is closely monitoring the possible return of Iranian oil supplies if a nuclear deal is reached by June 30.

site_title: Quick takes: Singapore's cut in land supply for residential development largely expected
summary: Singapore's Government Land Sales (GLS) Programme for the second half of 2015 was released, offering 17 sites that could yield over 7,800 private residential units. The confirmed list includes four sites, while 13 are on the reserve list. Real estate experts expect the cut in land supply to impact the market, although the exact impact is largely anticipated. The government's decision is largely seen as expected, with the supply of land for residential development expected to remain relatively stable.

images.alt_text: Angela Tan

site_title: Asia: Stocks mostly higher after Wall Street rally
summary: Asian markets rallied on Thursday, following a strong close on Wall Street, with Tokyo up 1.44%, Hong Kong 0.94%, Sydney 1.23%, and Seoul 0.23%. The Dow and S&P 500 also rose, snapping a four-day sell-off, amid hopes for a Greek debt deal and optimism over a potential EU-Latin America summit. Analysts remain nervous, however, warning that a decision on Greece could lead to a continued selloff in equities if it defaults.

site_title: Jakarta's ill-famed traffic grief to residents but boon for some
summary: Jakarta's notorious traffic congestion affects 10 million residents, causing significant productivity loss and economic costs. However, entrepreneurs have capitalized on this issue, with apps like GO-JEK and Waze offering innovative solutions. Since its launch, GO-JEK has seen a tenfold increase in distinctive drivers and nearly 400,000 downloads, while Waze has 800,000 users in the city. Despite efforts to improve public transport, officials acknowledge that infrastructure challenges and urbanization will continue to pose a significant challenge to Jakarta's economic growth.

site_title: Noble chairman seeks 'confidence and patience' from shareholders
summary: Noble Group chairman Richard Elman has asked shareholders and colleagues for "confidence and patience" as the commodity company seeks to recover share value. In a letter, Elman criticized "rumors, gossip, inaccurate statements" from outsiders, claiming they have no knowledge of the company. The letter was published on Noble's website but not announced through the Singapore Exchange, where S&P has cut the company's rating outlook to negative from stable.

site_title: RBS stake sale by UK government to begin in coming months
summary: UK Chancellor George Osborne announced plans to start selling Royal Bank of Scotland Group's shares in the coming months, marking the beginning of returning the bank to private ownership. The government will initially sell shares to institutional investors, with a retail offering to follow later. The sale is expected to take several years, but Osborne believes it will allow for a higher price to be achieved. The decision is supported by Bank of England Governor Mark Carney and aims to reduce the UK's stake in the bank, which has been bailed out since 2008.

site_title: ICBC and Citic Trust locked in spat over failed trust products
summary: China's ICBC and Citic Trust are arguing over accountability for two failed high-yield trust products, totaling 500 million yuan (S$108.3 million) owed to investors. The products, marketed by ICBC and sold by Citic Trust, were issued to finance a struggling mining company. The banks claim the other party should bear responsibility, with ICBC stating it was just an intermediary and Citic Trust saying ICBC passed the buck. The dispute highlights the risks of China's shadow banking system, which is marked by opacity and lack of accountability.

site_title: On final day, climate talks seek exit from text mire
summary: UN climate talks in Bonn conclude with no agreement on a draft text, six months before the Paris conference where 195 countries are expected to forge a post-2020 accord to limit global warming to 2 degrees Celsius. The draft text remains 80-90 pages long, with issues such as pledging reductions, climate aid, and the accord's legal status still undecided. Negotiators are seeking a way to streamline the text, with options to mandate the co-chairmen to create a draft or provide different options for political choices.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks open 0.94% higher
summary: Hong Kong stocks rose 0.94% in the opening exchanges on Thursday, following a strong lead from Wall Street. The Hang Seng Index increased 250.51 points to 26,938.15, while the Shanghai Composite Index eased 0.07%. The Shenzhen Composite Index also edged up 0.19%. The rally came despite ongoing trade uncertainty and mixed views on the Federal Reserve's policy.

site_title: 3 parties sign MOU on energy storage systems integration in Singapore
summary: Singapore's Centre for Energy Research and Technology (CERT), Singapore Institute of Power and Gas (SIPG), and Singapore Test Services (STS) signed a memorandum of understanding (MOU) to integrate energy storage systems (ESS) into the country's power grid. The three parties aim to create platforms and training opportunities for ESS integration, enhance local expertise, and establish product technical standards for grid-scale ESS. This initiative aims to support the deployment of intermittent generation sources, such as solar energy, and reduce demand during peak periods. The collaboration is seen as a timely initiative for Singapore's energy sustainability efforts.

images.alt_text: Professor Lee Jim Yang, director of CERT, and head of the chemical & biomolecular engineering department at NUS Engineering, said that the MOU is a "timely initiative", as Singapore steps up its efforts towards energy sustainability.

site_title: Modi's solar embrace in India is leaving wind power in shade
summary: India is set to surpass wind power for the first time, with solar installations projected to exceed 2,500 megawatts by March 2016, according to the Ministry of New and Renewable Energy. This shift is part of Prime Minister Narendra Modi's goal to scale up clean energy in India fivefold by 2022. Solar power has become more competitive, with costs expected to be lower than wind power, and companies like Suzlon Energy and ReNew Power Ventures are diversifying into solar projects. The government aims to invest $200 billion in clean energy and has pledged investment from companies like Adani Enterprises and Reliance Power.

site_title: Japan growth strategy sets sights on shift to IT: draft
summary: Japan's government has released a draft of its growth strategy, aiming to encourage companies to focus on cutting-edge IT such as big data and artificial intelligence. The plan also promotes start-ups and investment in the "Internet of Things." Industrial robots will continue to be promoted, with the government planning to add more details to the plan before its final version is released at the end of the month. This shift is part of Prime Minister Shinzo Abe's efforts to boost Japan's economy.

site_title: Google launches company to tackle city life woes
summary: Google has launched Sidewalk Labs, a company focused on solving urban problems such as affordable housing and traffic congestion. Headed by Dan Doctoroff, Sidewalk aims to develop technology that improves city life for everyone. The company will focus on cost of living, efficient transportation, and energy usage, with a mission to develop urban technologies at scale. Sidewalk is described as an "urban innovation" firm, with Larry Page comparing it to Google's X lab, known for "moonshots" like self-driving cars.

site_title: Singapore's Crowdonomic registered as equity crowdfunding platform in M'sia
summary: Singapore-based crowdfunding platform Crowdonomic has been registered as an equity crowdfunding (ECF) platform in Malaysia by the Securities Commission Malaysia. This marks the first and only homegrown platform in the region to receive this registration. ECF allows investors to invest in companies in exchange for shares, and Malaysia's regulations allow for participation by angel and retail investors, with a maximum raise of RM3 million within a 12-month period. Crowdonomic's registration demonstrates the country's commitment to fintech and its exportable business models.

site_title: Japan messaging app Line launches music streaming business
summary: Japan's messaging app Line Corp has launched its music streaming service, Line Music, in Japan, aiming to reverse the declining market for digital music. The service offers unlimited access to 1.5 million songs for 1,000 yen (S$10.90) per month, with plans to expand the library to 5 million songs by the end of this year and 30 million next year. This move follows Apple's launch of Apple Music, and Line aims to capitalize on the growing global market for streaming music.

site_title: Nestle India faces wake-up call to wean itself off noodles
summary: Nestle India's prepared foods division, largely composed of Maggi instant noodles, saw sales volumes grow last year, but the nationwide recall of Maggi noodles due to high lead content has raised concerns about the company's diversification. The recall has led to a decline in sales of milk products, chocolates, and coffee, accounting for 70% of the company's revenue. The company's stock has slumped 9% this month, and analysts predict a loss of nearly $3 billion in sales if the product remains off shelves.

site_title: China May investment up 11.4% y-o-y, surprisingly weak
summary: China's fixed-asset investment grew 11.4% in the first five months of 2015, slower than expected and not seen since 2000, indicating a possible need for increased policy support to avoid a deeper economic downturn. Meanwhile, factory output and retail sales steadied, with factory output growing 6.1% and retail sales growing 10.1% in May. The disappointing investment data follows weaker-than-expected import growth figures earlier this week, strengthening calls for policymakers to act sooner to revive growth.

images.alt_text: China's fixed-asset investment grew more slowly than expected in May and at a rate not seen since 2000, even as growth in retail sales and factory output steadied, arguing for Beijing to increase policy support to avert a deeper downturn.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open 0.68% higher
summary: Tokyo stocks opened 0.68% higher on Thursday, following a four-day losing streak, with the Nikkei 225 index rising 137.25 points to 20,183.61. The gains were backed by Wall Street's positive performance and a breather in the yen's rally. The rally is seen as a positive lead from Wall Street, and investors are cautiously optimistic despite tariff uncertainty.

site_title: Singapore: STI follows US momentum to open 0.6% higher
summary: Singapore shares opened 0.6% higher on Thursday, following a US market rally. The Straits Times Index rose 21.18 points to 3,346.95, driven by bank gains, including DBS Group Holdings and OCBC Bank. Noble Group was the most active stock, with 10.9 million shares traded. Gainers outnumbered losers 103 to 44, as investors remained positive despite tariff uncertainty and split views on the Fed.

site_title: US should ditch 'outdated' oil export ban: Harvard
summary: A Harvard Business School study recommends the US lift its 40-year-old oil export ban to capitalize on the hydraulic fracturing boom. The ban would add $23 billion to the economy by 2030, create tens of thousands of jobs, and boost US influence abroad. The study suggests easing restrictions on liquefied natural gas export terminals and addressing concerns about air and water pollution. The move comes amid debate in Washington, with Republicans pushing to reverse the ban, while Democrats have expressed concerns over potential price increases.

site_title: Twitter looks at on-phone apps to target new pitches
summary: Twitter has launched "installed app category targeting," a tool that helps advertisers target pitches for other mini-programs based on the apps people already have on their smartphones or tablets. This feature can be combined with other ad-targeting approaches and provides analysis and reporting to help marketers orchestrate ad campaigns. The tool is part of Twitter's efforts to ramp up revenue and win more users amid investors' concerns about its profitability and ability to grow.

site_title: HSBC joins Citigroup, SocGen in Brazil foreign-bank graveyard
summary: HSBC Holdings Plc has joined Citigroup Inc and Societe General SA in abandoning or scaling back its operations in Brazil, leaving the country with just two foreign retail banks. The move follows a wave of acquisitions since 2002, with HSBC spending $951 million on its Brazilian unit before selling it to Banco Santander Brasil SA. Foreign banks have struggled to adapt to local culture and regulatory requirements, with their share of Brazil's credit market falling to 14.5% from 22% in 2007. The departure of HSBC marks the third foreign bank to leave the market in two years.

site_title: Australian jobless rate unexpectedly declines; currency surges
summary: Australian jobless rate unexpectedly dropped to 6% in May, the lowest in a year, with 42,000 new jobs created. The decline is attributed to improved business confidence and increased hiring in the housing construction sector. The Australian dollar surged to 77.71 US cents. Despite the positive employment data, central bank Governor Glenn Stevens remains open to reducing the interest rate to support the economy's transition.

site_title: EMA launches framework to meet Singapore power sector's manpower needs
summary: The Energy Market Authority (EMA) of Singapore has launched a National Energy Competency Framework (NECF) to address manpower needs in the power sector. The framework outlines career progression pathways for 26 technical and non-technical job families, prioritizing 14 key areas. The NECF aims to enhance the power sector's workforce capabilities and career prospects, and will serve as a reference for human resource policies. The framework is now available online and will guide institutions in aligning their curriculum for power sector training.

site_title: Seoul: Shares rise, won eases slightly after BOK rate cut
summary: South Korean shares rose 0.5% on Thursday after the Bank of Korea cut its policy rate by 25 basis points to a record-low 1.50%, easing concerns over export markets. The won currency also eased slightly. Analysts expect no further rate cuts, citing limited market impact. Carmakers gained, including Hyundai Motor Co and Kia Motors Corp, as the stronger yen boosted exports. Greek news also eased market uncertainties, with a potential deal with creditors potentially bolstering the euro and South Korean exports.

site_title: Stocks to watch: GLP, Petra, Auric Pacific, China New Town
summary: Global Logistic Properties (GLP) denied reports of a potential US$4.5 billion warehouse deal. Petra Foods Limited sold its loss-making Singapore distribution business to Auric Pacific Group by June 30. China New Town Development Company (CNTD) shares plummeted after executive director Shi Jian was taken into custody in China.

site_title: Woman tests negative for Mers after panic in Hong Kong
summary: A woman in Hong Kong tested negative for the Mers virus after seeking treatment for symptoms after returning from a trip to South Korea, where an outbreak has triggered alarm. The area was cordoned off and health officials wore protective gear. Despite 31 negative test results, two cases were still pending, and Hong Kong authorities issued a "red" alert advising against non-essential travel to South Korea. The Mers virus, considered deadlier but less infectious than Sars, has a 35% fatality rate and no vaccine or cure.

site_title: Yangtze capsize ship insurance payout estimated at US$14.9m: Xinhua
summary: China's insurance regulator estimates a payout of around 92.5 million yuan (US$14.9 million) for the fatal Yangtze cruise ship capsizing, which killed over 400 people. Insurance firms underwrote 340 contracts for parties involved in the accident, including shipowners, travel agencies, and passengers. The ship, owned by Chongqing Eastern Shipping Corporation, was insured for 15.7 million yuan by the People's Insurance Company of China.

site_title: GLP says no deal yet after reports of interest in US$4.5b of US warehouses
summary: Global Logistic Properties (GLP) has not entered into a binding contract to buy over 200 US warehouses valued at approximately US$4.5 billion, despite initial talks with the owner, Industrial Income Trust Inc. GLP has been reviewing potential investment opportunities, including acquisitions, to strengthen its financial performance. The company made its US industrial market debut in February after purchasing IndCor Properties Inc for US$8.1 billion. No deal is currently expected, with negotiations reportedly not leading to a conclusion.

site_title: Singapore government to sell 17 sites in 2H 2015
summary: The Singapore government will sell 17 sites in the second half of 2015, yielding about 7,825 private residential units and 277,580 square meters of commercial space. Four sites are on the Confirmed List, including one executive condominium site, and 13 are on the Reserve List. The sales are part of the Government Land Sales programme, which aims to meet the existing pipeline supply of 84,000 private residential units.

site_title: Canada agency warns institutions to keep eye on transactions
summary: Canada's Financial Transactions and Reports Analysis Centre (Fintrac) has issued guidelines to financial institutions to identify signs of terrorism funding following deadly attacks in October 2014. The guidelines include monitoring clients who pay down debt, show transactions or travel plans to conflict zones, or sell property. Institutions are urged to increase customer scrutiny and flag suspicious cases to Fintrac, with a focus on transactions below the C$10,000 threshold. The guidelines follow a jump in suspicious transactions reported by Fintrac after the attacks, which saw 337 cases of terrorism financing studied and referred to law enforcement in 2014-2015.

site_title: Japan big manufacturers turn pessimistic in Q2, expect rebound in Q3: govt survey
summary: Japan's big manufacturers turned pessimistic in Q2, with a business survey index of minus 6.0, but expect a rebound in Q3 with a sentiment index of plus 13.2. They plan to raise capital spending by 5.9% in the current business year, a 2% increase from the previous poll. The improvement in business conditions suggests a patchy recovery in the economy.

site_title: UK house prices set to rise further, sellers absent: RICS
summary: UK house prices are expected to rise further, with the Royal Institution of Chartered Surveyors' monthly index reaching its highest level since August 2014. Despite a surprise election victory for Prime Minister David Cameron's Conservatives, the number of people looking to sell houses remains low, contributing to continued price growth. The index rose to +34 in May, indicating a quarter of price increases over the next five years, making property increasingly unaffordable.

site_title: EMAS Offshore secures charter contract worth more than US$30m
summary: EMAS Offshore secured a charter contract worth more than US$30 million from EMAS AMC, a subsidiary of 75.5% shareholder Ezra Holdings. The contract, awarded through a competitive tender process, involves four marine vessels with an average duration of 1.3 years, including options. The work is part of a larger project awarded to EMAS AMC by an oil major in West Africa.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open higher on Thursday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rose 9.14 points to 1744.77, driven by a 123-22 gain-to-lose ratio. Volume reached 39.7 million lots worth RM11.23 million.

site_title: London's financial job vacancies fell 20% in May, survey says
summary: London's financial job vacancies fell 20% in May, with 8,340 available positions, down from 10,458 in April, according to Morgan McKinley's survey. This decline was attributed to public holidays and uncertainty surrounding the UK election results. Meanwhile, those securing new jobs saw a 18% average salary increase. The decline comes as banks like HSBC and Deutsche Bank assess potential moves away from London due to Brexit uncertainty, citing significant costs and risks involved.

site_title: NZ central bank cuts rates, sees chance of more easing
summary: New Zealand's central bank cut its benchmark cash rate for the first time in four years to 3.25%, citing low inflationary pressures and weakening demand. The move is seen as a sign of the bank's willingness to ease monetary policy. Economists had expected the rate to remain unchanged, but the cut is expected to boost the New Zealand dollar and potentially lead to further rate cuts. The Reserve Bank of New Zealand forecasts inflation to return to its 1-3% target range by the March 2016 quarter.

site_title: S&P cuts Greece rating after IMF payment delay
summary: Standard & Poor's cut Greece's junk rating to "CCC" after a delayed debt payment to the IMF, citing the government's prioritization of domestic spending over debt service obligations. The rating agency warns that Greece's debt is unsustainable without a turnaround in the economy and deep public-sector reform. S&P predicts a default on commercial debt within the next 12 months and considers the possibility of capital controls and issuing a separate currency to pay domestic bills. The downgrade increases pressure on the Greek government to reach a new deal with creditors to release 7.2 billion euros in bailout funding.

site_title: City day care lets Paris moms work, first female mayor says
summary: Paris Mayor Anne Hidalgo credits the city's affordable and widely available child care as a key factor in attracting women to the workforce, with 87% of working-age women employed. The city's 45% preschool enrollment rate in municipal day-care centers is higher than the national average. France's nationwide 83% female workforce participation rate is also higher than the US, where only 75% of women in the same age group are employed. Hidalgo's administration aims to expand day-care capacity to 39,000 by 2020, supporting the economy and promoting women's employment.

site_title: Britain to get tougher on rogue finance
summary: Britain's Bank of England recommended tougher measures to end market abuses and longer prison sentences for those who break the law, following a series of financial scandals. The Fair and Effective Markets Review calls for extended market abuse rules and maximum prison terms of up to 10 years. Bank of England Governor Mark Carney stated that the "age of irresponsibility is over," and Finance Minister George Osborne agreed that individuals who commit financial crimes should be treated as criminals. The reforms aim to strengthen trust in markets and maintain London's global leadership position.

site_title: South Korea central bank cuts rates to record low 1.50% after Mers outbreak
summary: South Korea's central bank cut its policy rate by 25 basis points to a record-low 1.50% in response to the Middle East Respiratory Syndrome (MERS) outbreak, which has caused public anxiety and hit spending. This is the fourth rate cut in less than a year and the seventh since the current easing cycle began. The decision aims to offset any potentially harmful economic effects from the outbreak, which has resulted in nine deaths and thousands in quarantine.

images.alt_text: South Korea's central bank cut its policy rate by 25 basis points to a record-low 1.50 per cent on Thursday to offset any potentially harmful economic effects from an outbreak of the Middle East Respiratory Syndrome (MERS).

site_title: Central America seeks US$20b to revitalise troubled region
summary: Central American countries El Salvador, Honduras, and Guatemala have proposed a US$20 billion plan to revitalize their economies through new infrastructure and education, aiming to curb illegal migration into the US. The plan seeks to boost growth by 3.5% and create 600,000 jobs. Foreign ministers will meet with US officials in Washington on June 16 to discuss the proposal, which was presented to US President Barack Obama at a Panama City summit. The goal is to address poverty and violence in the region, which is considered one of the poorest and most dangerous in the world.

site_title: Japan Post in talks over asset management joint venture: sources
summary: Japan Post Holdings Co Ltd is in talks to establish an asset management joint venture with Sumitomo Mitsui Trust Bank and Nomura Holdings Inc. to sell mutual fund products at post offices. The state-owned postal giant's banking unit aims to develop and sell financial products for retail customers at post offices. Details have not been finalized, with Nomura stating that nothing has been decided and a Sumitomo Mitsui Trust spokesman declining to comment.

site_title: US: Stocks surge as tech, banking sectors lead
summary: US stocks surged 1.3% on Wednesday, led by a broad-based rally in technology and banking sectors. The Dow Jones Industrial Average rose 236.36 points to 18,000.40, while the S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite Index gained 1.20% and 1.25% respectively. The rally followed a week of anemic trade and was attributed to buyers stepping in to take advantage of oversold conditions. Large tech stocks, including Microsoft, Facebook, and Apple, rose 2.1%, 1.9%, and 1.2% respectively, while banking shares, such as JPMorgan Chase and Goldman Sachs, jumped 1.6% and 2.0%.

site_title: Oil prices rise as US inventories fall
summary: US oil prices rose for a second day, increasing $1.29 to $61.43 a barrel on the New York Mercantile Exchange. Crude and gasoline inventories declined, contributing to the price surge. European benchmark brent oil also rose, advancing 82 cents to $65.70 a barrel. The price increase follows a bearish outlook from US President Trump's tariff announcements.

site_title: South Korea reports 14 new Mers cases, takes total to 122
summary: South Korea reported 14 new cases of Middle East Respiratory Syndrome (Mers), bringing the total to 122, the largest outbreak outside Saudi Arabia. A pregnant woman, who contracted the virus at a Seoul hospital linked to previous cases, was reported to be in stable condition.

site_title: Auric to acquire Petra's S'pore distribution business
summary: Auric Pacific Group has agreed to acquire Petra Foods Limited's loss-making Singapore distribution business by the end of June. The acquisition includes the existing brand agencies portfolio of Delfi Singapore, a wholly-owned subsidiary of Petra Foods. The deal marks a significant move by Petra Foods to divest its underperforming business. Financial terms of the deal were not disclosed.

site_title: S&P confirms US credit rating at AA+
summary: Standard & Poor's confirmed the US credit rating at AA+, citing the return of the US economy and efforts to reduce debt levels. However, debt levels remain high at 80% of GDP, expected to remain through 2018 before rising again. This marks a four-year recovery since the country's triple-A rating was cut in 2011.

site_title: Yen surges following Bank of Japan comments
summary: The Japanese yen surged against the dollar and euro after Bank of Japan Governor Haruhiko Kuroda stated that a further decline in the currency was "unlikely". This move was seen as a surprise, catching the market off guard. Kuroda's comments also suggested concern over potential upheaval to domestic markets if the currency weakens further. Meanwhile, the dollar dipped against the euro as European bond yields rose to multi-month highs.

site_title: Otto Marine wins US$27m charter contract
summary: Otto Marine subsidiary Swordfish 1 has secured a US$27 million long-term bareboat charter contract for a 238-men work maintenance vessel in Southeast Asia. The vessel is expected to be delivered in the third quarter and will positively impact earnings and net tangible assets for the 2015 financial year. This contract will contribute to Otto Marine's financial performance, with the company's shares trading at 3 Singapore cents prior to the announcement.

site_title: Greece's Tsipras in last-ditch talks with European leaders
summary: Greek Prime Minister Alexis Tsipras held last-ditch talks with European leaders in Brussels, seeking a breakthrough to prevent Athens from going bankrupt by the end of the month. Tsipras met with European Commission chief Jean-Claude Juncker and will hold three-way talks with German Chancellor Angela Merkel and French President Francois Hollande. Greece signaled its readiness to discuss key reform concessions and extend its EU-IMF bailout until March 2016, in a bid to unlock the last €7.2 billion tranche and avoid default and a possible euro exit.

site_title: PM Modi goes private to woo investment in infrastructure
summary: Indian Prime Minister Narendra Modi is establishing the National Investment and Infrastructure Corp (NIIC) to attract investment in infrastructure, with a 200 billion rupee (S$4.2 billion) government investment. The company will buy shares in existing infrastructure lenders and provide debt to selected projects, aiming to boost infrastructure investment and eliminate bottlenecks. This move is seen as a step to increase private participation in Indian infrastructure, which fell 84% in the first half of 2014.

site_title: World Bank warns emerging economies to 'fasten seatbelts'
summary: The World Bank has warned emerging economies to "fasten seatbelts" due to a rocky road ahead as the US tightens monetary policy and the dollar strengthens. The World Bank trimmed its forecast for 2015 to 2.8% and urged the US Federal Reserve to delay rate hikes until next year to give more breathing room to the slow-growing global economy. Emerging economies face increased challenges due to low commodity prices, capital outflows, and a stronger dollar, which may lead to more volatility in global markets and weaker economies suffering.

site_title: Europe: Shares snap losing streak
summary: European shares ended a six-day losing streak on Wednesday, rebounding as traders deemed the recent sell-off excessive. German equities, which had hit a low since February, rose in response to a Bloomberg report suggesting Germany might consider a staggered aid deal to Greece. The German government stated it would only accept a cash-for-reform deal approved by all three lending institutions.

site_title: Tianjin port unit freezes iron ore stocks after finding illegal release from warehouse
summary: A subsidiary of China's Tianjin port, Tianjin Port No 5 Stevedoring Co Ltd, has frozen iron ore stocks after discovering an undisclosed agent and trading firm had released the commodities without authority. The move is linked to a larger concern about irregularities at Chinese ports, following a scandal at Qingdao port last year. The port company has initiated legal proceedings and is investigating the matter, while affected customers are checking on the fate of their stored iron ore holdings.

images.alt_text: New examples of irregularities at ports will raise fresh concerns about the risks of storing commodities in China and commodity financing, traders say.

site_title: Glencore buys over 1m tonnes of fuel oil in Singapore as premiums slump
summary: Glencore has bought over 1 million tonnes of fuel oil in Singapore in June, taking advantage of plummeting prices. The company purchased at least 925,000 tonnes of 380-centistoke fuel oil and 140,000 tonnes of 180-centistoke grade. This accounts for about 36% of the total 2.95 million tonnes transacted on the Platts window. The purchase comes as fuel oil prices tumble from a record premium in the world's biggest bunker market.

site_title: Former financial controller of ST Marine to plead guilty in graft case
summary: A former financial controller of ST Marine, Patrick Lee Swee Ching, has indicated his intention to plead guilty in a graft case involving bribing agents of the company's customers between 2004 and 2010. Lee faces 38 counts of abetting false entries for entertainment expenses worth over S$126,000. Analysts downplay the impact on parent company ST Engineering, stating it's a non-event, as the executives involved are no longer employees. Lee's case will be heard on July 1.

site_title: US tech industry urges Obama to keep hands off encryption
summary: US tech companies, including Apple, Google, and Microsoft, have urged President Barack Obama to keep hands off encryption, warning that weakening encryption systems could compromise consumer privacy and security. The Information Technology Industry Council and Software and Information Industry Association sent a strongly worded letter to Obama, opposing any policy actions that would undermine encryption. The move comes as the Obama administration seeks to expand its powers to access encrypted data, amid growing concerns about terrorism and cyber threats.

site_title: Computer data seized at Fifa headquarters
summary: FIFA has handed over computer data to Swiss police investigating corruption surrounding the 2018 and 2022 World Cup votes. The data includes records from the Zurich headquarters, and Swiss authorities are investigating the 2010 vote that awarded the 2018 World Cup to Russia and the 2022 tournament to Qatar. FIFA has suspended bidding for the 2026 tournament due to the ongoing investigation. Brazilian legend Zico has declared himself a candidate to take over FIFA from Sepp Blatter, who resigned amid the corruption scandal.

site_title: D'oh! Homer and Marge to split on The Simpsons
summary: Homer and Marge Simpson are set to separate after 25 years together on The Simpsons, according to the show's executive producer Al Jean. The decision will be revealed in the show's 27th season premiere in September, citing the strain of Homer's newly diagnosed narcolepsy on their marriage. The revelation will mark a significant change in the long-running sitcom, which has followed the couple's relationship since its debut.

site_title: Japan's April core machinery orders up
summary: Japan's core machinery orders rose 3.8% in April, the fastest pace in four months, indicating companies are becoming more optimistic about capital spending. This follows a 2.9% increase in March and surpasses the median estimate of a 2% annual decline. The data suggests improving business confidence and record corporate profits, which could drive a virtuous cycle of economic growth.

site_title: Indonesia looks to new roadmap for Islamic finance boost
summary: Indonesia's financial services authority, OJK, has published a five-year strategy to boost the Islamic finance sector, aiming to increase Islamic banks' market share to 15% by 2023. The roadmap includes reducing fees on Syariah-compliant products, developing training programs, and expanding education and promotion activities. Low financial literacy among the public and lack of coordination among government bodies are seen as major obstacles to the sector's growth, but experts consider the new developments as positive for the industry.

site_title: Venezuela demands Guyana halt 'imperial' oil exploration
summary: Venezuela has demanded Guyana halt oil exploration in a disputed offshore territory, citing a 1966 treaty and a 1899 international tribunal ruling. The dispute centers on the Essequibo region, which Guyana claims as part of its territory. Venezuela claims the territory is still in dispute and accuses Guyana of being "imperial" and backed by Exxon Mobil. The dispute escalates tensions between the two South American nations, with Venezuela's President Nicolas Maduro blaming Exxon Mobil for the situation. Exxon Mobil found oil off Guyana's coast last month, sparking the dispute.

site_title: Jokowi breaks tradition in picking new military chief
summary: Indonesian President Joko Widodo has broken tradition by appointing Gen Gatot Nurmantyo, the army chief of staff, as the new military chief, instead of rotating the position between branches of the armed forces. This decision is likely to cement the army's dominant role and inflame rivalry within the armed forces. Analysts say it's a way for the army to stay relevant as Widodo beefs up the navy and air force to pursue maritime goals. The decision has been submitted to Parliament for approval.

site_title: Pimco cuts US govt-related debt holdings
summary: Pimco, a German investment firm, significantly reduced its US government-related debt holdings in its flagship Pimco Total Return Fund by nearly two-thirds in May, from 23.4% to 8.5%, amid expectations of a potential Federal Reserve interest rate hike. The move comes as investors have priced in low interest rates, making it "perfectly plausible" that borrowing costs could rise above the neutral rate. The fund now holds 8.5% of US government-related debt, down from 35.3% in February.

site_title: Yen soars after BOJ head says currency 'very weak'
summary: The Japanese yen surged to a two-week high against the dollar after Bank of Japan head Haruhiko Kuroda stated the currency is "very weak" and unlikely to fall further, prompting investors to trim bets against the yen. This lifted the yen to 122.82, its weakest since May 27, and led to a decline in the dollar against a basket of major currencies. Analysts suggest the BOJ may be preparing the market for reduced monetary stimulus, potentially leading to a slowdown in the dollar's rise.

site_title: PSA makes foray into China's south-west
summary: PSA International has launched a joint venture with Beibu Gulf Port Group and Pacific International Lines to operate a new container terminal in Qinzhou, Guangxi province, China. The Beibu Gulf-PSA International Container Terminal, which can handle up to three million TEUs per year, aims to support container trade growth in the region and connect to key shipping routes. The terminal is expected to begin operations in the fourth quarter of 2015, marking PSA's entry into China's south-western region. The venture is seen as a strategic move to boost economic growth in the area.

site_title: S Korea's duty free shop sales take a hit from Mers
summary: South Korea's duty-free shop sales are expected to decline due to the spread of Middle East respiratory syndrome (Mers), with LOTTE Duty Free reporting a potential 10% drop in revenue this month. The decline is attributed to decreased visitor arrivals from China, with some tourists cutting short their trips. This is the latest challenge facing the country's tourism industry, which is already feeling the impact of the virus.

images.alt_text: Large numbers of overseas visitors are cancelling trips to South Korea as Mers has killed nine people there and the number of confirmed cases rose to 108.

site_title: Australand secures Ceva Logistics as tenant in Melbourne
summary: Australand, a subsidiary of Frasers Centrepoint, secured Ceva Logistics as a tenant for its 90,000 sqm warehouse and office facility in Melbourne. This deal is one of the largest in Australia, adding to Australand's 200,000 sqm of industrial space transacted over six months, valued at around A$200 million.

site_title: Tenants' market seen extending into '16 as condo rents dip in May
summary: Rentals for condominiums and private apartments in Singapore dipped 0.6% in May, affirming the trend of a tenants' market. Analysts attribute this to new supply outweighing demand, particularly in suburban areas. This trend may extend into 2016, with SLP International's Nicholas Mak stating that more project completions will lead to higher competition for tenants.

site_title: Swiss chemicals firm Clariant launches consumer-care competence centre here
summary: Swiss chemicals firm Clariant has launched a consumer-care competence centre in Singapore, its fifth application development centre in the Asia-Pacific region. The centre focuses on sensorial testing for personal and home-care products, helping partners find claims for future trends. Located at The Synergy, it is part of Clariant's 160-man-strong team in Singapore and demonstrates the company's investment in the country's chemicals industry and growing consumer-care sector.

site_title: New standard size unveiled for carry-on luggage
summary: The International Air Transport Association (IATA) has unveiled a new standard size for carry-on luggage, aiming to reduce anxiety among passengers and give airlines assurance that compliant bags can board the plane. The new size is 21.5 inches by 13.5 inches by 7.5 inches, slightly smaller than current standards. IATA is working with major luggage brands to produce compliant bags, which will carry an "IATA Cabin OK" tag and a unique tracking number. Several airlines, including Azul, Lufthansa, and Qatar Airways, have already expressed interest in adopting the standard, which is voluntary and expected to become available in stores later this year.

site_title: Nike settles with 3 designers it accused of stealing secrets
summary: Nike has settled a lawsuit against three former shoe designers, Denis Dekovic, Marc Dolce, and Mark Miner, who it accused of stealing its commercial secrets and taking them to Adidas. The designers had worked for Nike before consulting for Adidas and opening a design studio in Brooklyn. The settlement, reached through a confidential agreement, resolves a lawsuit filed by Nike in December, alleging damages of at least $10 million. Adidas had denied any knowledge of the non-compete agreements and claimed that the designers' idea for the design studio was not based on Nike's confidential information.

site_title: London luxury home sales stall over record prices
summary: London luxury home sales have stalled due to record prices, with buyers resisting further increases. Despite the Conservative Party's victory, which ended plans for a mansion tax, prices in prime districts like Knightsbridge and Chelsea have slowed. Knight Frank reported a 2.3% year-over-year growth in May, the slowest since 2009. Realtors attribute the slowdown to buyers' reluctance to pay higher valuations, exacerbated by tax increases and a "wall of money" not being spent.

site_title: Brokers' take
summary: OCBC's share price is expected to re-rate due to its enhanced growth prospects in wealth management, retail & commercial banking, and insurance in Greater China. Venture Corp's next growth wave is likely from its Test & Measurement, Medical & Life Science, and Others segments, with a steady and meaningful growth from the medical & life sciences segment. Vard Holdings' recent contract for a diving support vessel is seen as a positive, but its valuations are considered rich due to macroeconomic headwinds.

site_title: A US$3.7 trillion traffic jam looming in credit
summary: A US$3.7 trillion traffic jam is looming in the US corporate-bond market, where nearly all growth is concentrated in the hands of three types of buyers: mutual funds, foreign investors, and insurance companies. As interest rates are set to rise for the first time since 2006, this concentration of buyers may lead to more selling than the market can absorb. Experts warn that a liquidity crisis could exacerbate the selloff, and diversifying positions by buying less liquid assets may help investors weather volatility.

site_title: Wall Street courts startups it once may have ignored
summary: Wall Street banks are shifting their focus from traditional in-house development to partnering with startups, recognizing that many of the best young talents are moving to Silicon Valley. Goldman Sachs, for example, has invested in data analytics company Kensho, alongside Bank of America and Bloomberg. This trend is driven by the growing pace of venture capital investing in financial technology and the need for banks to adapt to changing talent pools. By partnering with startups, banks aim to co-opt innovation and talent, rather than building it themselves.

site_title: Disputed painting is declared a Rembrandt
summary: The Mauritshuis Royal Picture Gallery in The Hague, Netherlands, has declared a disputed painting, "Saul and David", to be an authentic work by Rembrandt. The painting, which was sliced down the middle in the 19th century and later sutured back together, was initially discredited as a Rembrandt work in 1969. However, after eight years of examination and restoration, the museum's conservators and researchers have concluded that the painting was indeed created by Rembrandt's own hand in two stages. The museum has now reclaimed the painting as one of more than 300 surviving Rembrandt works, with the exhibition "Rembrandt? The Case of Saul and David" set to open soon.

site_title: Rare WWI patriotic posters up for auction
summary: A collection of approximately 2,000 World War I era posters, amassed by a US Army officer over a decade, will be sold at auction on June 30 and July 1. The collection, considered one of the world's finest, features patriotic posters from the US and over 15 countries, including works by prominent illustrators like JC Leyendecker and Howard Chandler Christy. The collection, which includes rare and previously unseen posters, is expected to fetch between $200 and $5,000 per piece, with the largest poster valued at a significant amount.

site_title: Defusing Greek crisis would require creditors to change mindset
summary: Greece's eurozone crisis is nearing a critical juncture, with the EU's bailout program set to expire in June. Greece must secure an agreement with its creditors, including the European Commission, ECB, and IMF, to avoid capital controls, a banking system collapse, and potential "Grexit." Critics argue the creditors' approach of demanding austerity measures has failed, and a new strategy focusing on debt relief, growth, and reform is needed. A failure to reach an agreement could lead to a catastrophic impact on the eurozone and EU's economic integration project.

site_title: Creditors press Greece for more concessions
summary: Greece and its creditors are on the brink of a deal, with leaders from Germany, France, and the European Commission holding back meetings with Prime Minister Alexis Tsipras to press for more concessions. Greece has proposed ideas to address its budget and implement reforms, but creditors say these are inadequate. Without a deal by the end of the month, Greece risks defaulting on a 1.6 billion euro repayment, potentially leading to severe economic consequences and the risk of leaving the eurozone.

images.alt_text: German Chancellor Angela Merkel (left) shakes hands with Greek Prime Minister Alexis Tsipras (right) at the start of an EU-CELAC Latin America summit in Brussels, Belgium on June 10, 2015.

site_title: State Bank of India chief urges more action on default policy
summary: State Bank of India (SBI) Chairman Arundhati Bhattacharya urged the government to expedite the creation of a commercial court system to handle defaulting companies. The RBI has rewritten rules to help lenders recover loans from defaulting companies, allowing them to convert loans into equity and take control of stressed companies. However, bankers are awaiting a national code to resolve bankruptcies and recover debts, which will require more time due to India's complex legal framework. Bhattacharya believes a commercial court system will improve judgment quality and decision-making speed.

site_title: A global-governance challenge for China
summary: China is shifting its development finance focus from domestic stability to global leadership, amid a transformation of its worldview. The country's "China Dream" under Xi Jinping emphasizes its emerging role as a global leader, presenting daunting challenges in developing a sustainable strategy. As a member of the AIIB, China has an opportunity to establish new standards and shape infrastructure investment, potentially influencing global governance. This move reflects China's outward-facing focus, contrasting with its inward focus on domestic stability.

site_title: Wanted - accelerators to help cleantech startups
summary: SPRING Singapore is seeking up to five accelerators to support 40 startups in clean technology and advanced manufacturing and engineering sectors. The accelerators will jointly nurture startups and invest up to S$4 million in each. The sectors have immense growth potential but require support, according to Edwin Chow, group director for industry development and innovation.

site_title: Four Singapore urban planning, development firms complete mergers
summary: Four Singapore urban planning and development firms, Ascendas, Singbridge Group, Jurong International Holdings, and Surbana International Consultants, have completed mergers. The merged entities, Ascendas-Singbridge and Surbana-JIH, are jointly owned by Temasek Holdings and JTC Corporation in a 51-49 partnership. The mergers aim to drive economic and social development in urbanising cities, and the companies expect to offer complete value chain services to the development industry, creating high-value jobs and exploring co-investment opportunities.

site_title: European cloud firms play up roots, privacy credentials
summary: US-based cloud computing startup Zettabox is unveiling its service, touting its European roots and commitment to data privacy, as the European Union prepares to complete its long-awaited data-protection reforms. The company, which has received less than $10 million in funding, will store data within Europe, where privacy laws are stricter, and allow individuals and companies to retain information in specific European countries. This move aims to compete with US rivals like Google and Microsoft, which have faced criticism for handling sensitive data.

site_title: All eyes on Malaysia's debt rating review
summary: Malaysia's debt rating is set to be reviewed by Fitch Ratings by the end of June, with a 50:50 chance of a downgrade. A downgrade could cut deep, making it difficult for the country to climb back up after years of hard work. The review comes as Malaysia faces economic challenges, including lower commodity prices and capital outflows. Analysts expect a short-lived reaction if the rating is downgraded, but warn that a downgrade could impact the country's currency, bond, and equity markets. Fitch's decision could also shift attention to other rating agencies, Standard & Poor's and Moody's, which have a stable and positive outlook on Malaysia's sovereign rating.

images.alt_text: Anita Gabriel
If the rating slips by one notch to BBB+, Malaysia's ringgit and bond and equity markets could suffer a further hit.

site_title: EY poll finds S'pore firms' ethical business practices wanting
summary: A recent EY survey of 1,508 Asia-Pacific employees found that Singapore companies' ethical business practices are lacking in effectiveness, despite having policies in place. Over a third of respondents believe anti-bribery/anti-corruption policies are irrelevant and ineffective, while nearly 40% of employees are hesitant to use whistleblowing hotlines due to fear of retribution. The survey highlights the need for more proactive compliance monitoring and integrity systems to combat graft and corruption.

site_title: Yen surges as analysts expect volatility in currency, share prices
summary: The yen surged against the dollar after Bank of Japan (BOJ) Governor Haruhiko Kuroda and Policy Board member Takehiro Sato criticized the central bank's monetary easing policy. Kuroda described the yen as "very weak" and suggested it would not weaken further, while Sato warned of potential difficulties in buying government bonds at current pace. The yen jumped to its highest level in two weeks, reversing earlier gains in Tokyo stock prices, amid growing concerns about currency-market volatility and potential interest rate hikes by the US Federal Reserve.

images.alt_text: The yen jumped from a 13-year low of 124.63 to the dollar to 122.7 - its highest level in two weeks, reversing earlier gains in Tokyo stock prices and pointing to further volatility ahead for both the yen and Tokyo share prices, dealers said.

site_title: STI bounces on MSCI's 'A' share decision
summary: The Straits Times Index (STI) rebounded 30.64 points or 0.93% to 3,325.77 after MSCI announced it won't include China "A" shares in its Emerging Markets (EM) index, alleviating concerns that Singapore's weighting would be reduced. The market had fallen 98 points from May 29 due to speculation about the "A" share inclusion. Analysts described the bounce as a "relief" move, with the market relieved that Singapore's weighting won't be cut.

site_title: Ireland to tackle strict abortion laws following gay marriage vote triumph
summary: Ireland's strict abortion laws, which were not changed by the recent same-sex marriage referendum, are set to be re-examined. Despite the country's shift towards a more liberal society, the laws remain among the most restrictive in the world, with around 4,000 Irish women traveling to the UK each year for abortions. Activists are calling for the abolition of the eighth amendment of the constitution, which enshrines the equal right to life of the mother and her unborn child.

site_title: Rousseff seeks 198.4b reais in infrastructure investment
summary: Brazilian President Dilma Rousseff has unveiled a plan to draw 198.4 billion reais (S$86.3 billion) in private investment to upgrade and operate the country's infrastructure, aiming to boost the economy and improve her popularity. The plan, which could be implemented in the coming years, aims to restore growth and alleviate issues such as high inflation and unemployment. The move is seen as a potential solution to the country's economic woes, although the outcome is uncertain.

site_title: US mortgage applications rise 8.4%: industry body
summary: US mortgage applications increased 8.4% in the week ended June 5, according to the Mortgage Bankers Association. Refinancing applications rose 7.0%, while home purchase demand increased 9.7%. The rebound in mortgage activity follows the Memorial Day holiday, with strong job gains and initial signs of wage growth supporting the purchase market. The refinance share of total mortgage activity remained unchanged at 49%.

site_title: Talent and knowledge are 'key to success for countries today'
summary: Ambassador-at-Large Tommy Koh stated that countries that succeed in today's world prioritize talent and knowledge, as seen in Singapore's numerous think tanks and international organizations. Over 100 people from 10 organizations attended an event celebrating SG50, highlighting the importance of knowledge and connections to the region and the world. Think tanks and international organizations help countries gain a better understanding of key regions and facilitate trade and growth. Koh emphasized that connections to other parts of the world, such as Europe, are crucial for Singapore's economic success.

images.alt_text: Nisha Ramchandani

site_title: New US Embassy in London is object of debate
summary: The US Embassy in London is relocating from its historic site in Grosvenor Square to a new site in Nine Elms on the South Bank of the Thames due to security concerns. Critics have panned the new design, calling it a "corporate office block" and a "fortress" that separates Americans from their host community. However, supporters argue that the new embassy will be safer, more sustainable, and will spark development in the area. The $1 billion project, financed by Qatar's Sovereign Wealth Fund, will feature a public plaza, walkways, and seating areas, and will be designed by KieranTimberlake.

site_title: The return of a frostier Cold War
summary: A new Cold War has emerged between Russia and the West, following Russia's military intervention in Ukraine and annexation of Crimea. This marks a return to the era of the First Cold War, which began in 1946 and ended in 1991 after the collapse of the Soviet Union. Russia's assertiveness is perceived as a new Soviet-style expansionist empire, straining diplomatic relations with the West.

site_title: Japan firms start boosting capex at home
summary: Japan's companies are boosting capital expenditure amid pressure from Prime Minister Shinzo Abe to share record profits and address obsolescent equipment. A recent report showed orders for machines rose for the fifth time in six months in April, suggesting a positive start to the second quarter. Abe's campaign aims to encourage companies to invest in automation and robotics, particularly among small and medium-sized companies, to boost productivity. However, the government faces challenges in convincing companies to invest, especially with a shrinking population and stagnant consumer prices.

site_title: MSCI postpones including China A shares in index
summary: US index provider MSCI Inc has postponed including China A shares in one of its key benchmark indexes due to outstanding market accessibility issues. The decision was seen as a setback for China's efforts to promote its yuan currency globally and attract foreign capital through financial reforms. MSCI expects China A shares to be included once these issues are resolved, but for now, it will focus on resolving the market accessibility concerns.

site_title: Drug switch study bolsters case for using copies of biotech medicine
summary: A Finnish study found that patients with rheumatic diseases can safely switch from original-brand biotech medicine to cheaper biosimilar copies, with comparable clinical effectiveness and safety. The study involved 39 patients who switched from Merck and Johnson & Johnson's Remicade to a biosimilar, with no loss of effectiveness or unexpected side effects. The results bolster the case for using biosimilars, which could reduce healthcare spending and threaten the business of companies reliant on biotech drugs. The study's findings are expected to improve doctors' confidence in switching to biosimilars.

site_title: Strategy mistakes a key reason for HSBC's Brazil exit
summary: HSBC's Brazilian unit is being sold due to strategy mistakes, including prioritizing relationships with corporate clients over profitability, keeping branches overstaffed, and failing to protect profits from a deteriorating economy. The sale, which could fetch between $3 billion and $4 billion, comes as part of a broader trend of consolidation in the local banking industry. HSBC Brasil's poor performance, including negative return on equity and high expense growth, led to the decision to slash nearly one in five jobs worldwide and fix operations saddled with compliance costs and low interest rates.

site_title: MNCs' days of tax avoidance are all but over
summary: Multinational corporations, led by US companies like Apple and Google, are largely dismantling tax avoidance structures, according to Pascal Saint-Amans, the top tax official at the OECD. This marks the end of "very aggressive tax planning" and comes as part of an international crackdown on avoidance. The move is seen as a significant shift, with Saint-Amans stating that the days of tax avoidance are "all but over". This change aims to increase tax revenue and promote fair competition among companies.

site_title: Bidding for 2026 World Cup to be postponed: Fifa official
summary: FIFA secretary general Jerome Valcke has announced the postponement of bidding for the 2026 World Cup due to the ongoing corruption investigation. The decision comes as the FBI investigates bribery and corruption in the organization, including the 2018 and 2022 hosting rights. Valcke denied allegations of wrongdoing over $10 million in bank transactions and claimed he had no role in the payments. The investigation has led to a delay in the decision on who will host the 2026 finals, originally due to be made in 2017.

site_title: Carlyle weighing US real estate expansion, says co-founder
summary: Carlyle Group LP, the world's second-largest manager of alternatives to stocks and bonds, is considering expanding its US real estate offerings with a core-plus strategy targeting 9-11% returns. Co-founder David Rubenstein stated that this business is likely to be a great growth opportunity, particularly in the US. The move comes as alternative-asset managers are increasingly shifting into traditional asset management to generate steadier fees.

site_title: BOAML highlights potential for currency mismatches
summary: Bank of America Merrill Lynch (BOAML) has flagged rising foreign-currency public debt issuance in Malaysia and Indonesia, warning of currency mismatches and implications for financial stability and macroeconomic policy. The surge in local bond yields and diminishing foreign interest have led governments to opt for foreign-currency debt financing, similar to the 1997-98 Asian financial crisis. This could exacerbate currency misalignments, posing a risk to financial stability and macroeconomic policy. BOAML's warning highlights the need for policymakers to address these potential issues.

site_title: One man's struggle with 'green dream' condo
summary: A former New York City developer, Colin Rath, recounts his struggles with his $1.6 million condo project at 123 W 15th St in his self-published book, "It Is What It Is." The project, meant to be a luxury eco-friendly building, was plagued by issues including nine standing tenants, demolition problems, and a collapsed foundation. Rath spent two years fighting creditors and was eventually forced to surrender the property to the lender. He lost millions, but managed to sell his condo for $3.1 million, and is now sailing around the world with his family.

site_title: El Nino dims Australia wheat harvest outlook
summary: Australia reduced its wheat production outlook due to the El Nino weather event, which may curb yields in the country's east. The harvest is now forecast at 23.6 million tonnes, down from 24.4 million tonnes in March. El Nino is expected to cut global wheat output by 1.4% and has already raised concerns about global supplies. Australia's wheat yields typically fall well below trend during El Nino years, and dry conditions are likely to continue through the country's growing season.

images.alt_text: Farmers in New South Wales, the second-biggest wheat grower, may harvest 6.2 million tonnes from 6.3 million tonnes a year ago, Abares said.

site_title: Beijing okays second batch of debt swaps, doubling size to 2 trillion yuan
summary: China's finance ministry approved a second batch of debt swaps worth 1 trillion yuan, doubling the existing program to 2 trillion yuan. The move aims to rationalize local government spending without damaging growth and investment. The swaps, announced in March, cover 2015 maturing debt and have eased restrictions on local government financing vehicles. Despite concerns, sovereign bond yields have risen, but the government's support for projects under development by these vehicles suggests a policy dilemma.

site_title: Thailand holds key rate, sees gradual gains for economy
summary: Thailand's central bank left its benchmark interest rate steady at 1.50% after two surprise cuts, citing a projected gradual economic improvement. The Monetary Policy Committee voted unanimously, despite 19 of 22 economists predicting no change. The economy has struggled with weak domestic consumption and slow exports, and forecasts for this year have been trimmed. The baht has weakened following rate cuts, and the central bank warned that exports could contract again this year. Economists say the hold doesn't necessarily mean the rate won't be cut again later due to the fragile economic state.

site_title: HSBC aims to be the leading international bank in Singapore
summary: HSBC aims to become the leading international financial services provider in Singapore, focusing on Financial Institutions Group (FIG) clients and large corporates. The bank plans to increase its presence in South-east Asia and China's Pearl River Delta within the next 10 years, driven by significant growth in loans and advances in the region.
