HSBC has already opened two local branches in Singapore and has a loan market share of 3.6 per cent, and expects "significant growth opportunity" in South-east Asia, with wealth creation projected to grow 3.6 times by 2030.

site_title: Poorly performing family firms more likely to improve governance
summary: A recent study found that poorly performing family firms in Singapore are more likely to improve their governance practices, contrary to the assumption that well-performing firms have good governance. The study of 421 family firms revealed that those experiencing financial difficulties disclosed more about their governance, while those performing well with family control on the board showed no improvement in disclosure. This suggests that family owners are motivated to improve corporate governance during times of poor performance, providing a useful insight for minority shareholders and regulators.

site_title: Rich, poor divide a factor in emissions scheme talks
summary: Diplomats working to reduce carbon emissions from passenger planes globally are considering options that give developing countries more leeway to meet new rules. The International Air Transport Association (IATA) is discussing a market-based system and global emission standard, with varying stringency and time frames for different countries. This approach aims to ease tension between emerging economies and richer states, which has hindered ICAO's efforts to develop a global plan. A decision is expected by next September, with a working paper suggesting that some countries may be able to "preserve their leading positions" in aviation.

site_title: N America packaged-food M&As hit 6-year high
summary: Campbell Soup Co's purchase of Garden Fresh Gourmet pushed North American packaged-food M&A to a 6-year high of $66.3 billion in 2015. The deal, valued at $231 million, follows other acquisitions by Hormel Foods and General Mills to gain up-to-date products and reinvigorate sales. Analysts expect more M&A activity, citing undervalued companies like WhiteWave Foods and Boulder Brands, which offer popular products in the organic and natural food sectors. Acquisitions are seen as necessary to grow sales in a competitive market.

site_title: Rise in Spain's home prices lags increase in purchases due to glut
summary: Spanish home prices rose 1.5% in the first quarter of 2015, but purchases increased by 9.4% due to a lingering glut of empty homes. The market faces long-term challenges, including an estimated one million empty homes and a decline in the number of people between 25-35 years old, a typical source of first-time home buyers. Experts predict slower price growth due to harsh fundamentals, including households wary of poor labor market conditions.

site_title: SMCP expanding in HK despite soft retail sector
summary: French fashion chain SMCP plans to expand its presence in Hong Kong and Macau despite the city's slumping retail market. The company will open five new outlets in Hong Kong over the next year, doubling its stores in Macau, and aims to capitalize on the growing demand for affordable luxury brands among Chinese consumers. Sales in the Greater China region rose in the high double-digits in 2014, driven by a wealthier Chinese middle class willing to pay premium prices for quality products.

site_title: Oil stocks fall most since July as refineries lift output: EIA
summary: US crude oil stocks fell 6.8 million barrels in the last week, the largest decline since July, as refineries increased output by 169,000 barrels per day. Gasoline stocks decreased by 2.9 million barrels, while distillate inventories rose 865,000 barrels. Refinery utilization rates also rose 1.4 percentage points. This marks a reversal of the previous week's decline, when crude imports fell 750,000 barrels per day.

site_title: Target affirms dividend boost after statement is posted online by mistake
summary: Target Corp reiterated a 7.7% increase in its dividend to 56 US cents and a US$5 billion boost to its stock buyback plan after an initial announcement was posted on its website by mistake. The error occurred less than 25 minutes before the company's board made a final decision. As a result, Target's stock rose 3.9% in the year. The incident followed a similar fake bid incident at Avon Products earlier this year.

site_title: OUE C-Reit to buy majority stake in One Raffles Place for S$1b
summary: OUE Commercial Reit (OUE C-Reit) has agreed to acquire a majority stake in One Raffles Place for S$1-1.1 billion, resulting in an effective stake of 61.16-67.95%. The acquisition will be done through an indirect purchase of OUB Centre Limited, with the Reit's assets under management expected to more than double to S$3.4 billion. The deal is OUE C-Reit's first major acquisition since its IPO in 2014, and is expected to strengthen its position in the Singapore office market and enhance its income diversification and tenant base.

site_title: ISIS's funding sources: mafia-like taxes, drug cartel-like extortions
summary: ISIS, a self-proclaimed extremist group, has proven to be financially resilient despite US airstrikes and has emerged as the world's richest and most feared terrorist force. The group has seized an estimated $675 million from banks, $145 million in oil sales, and tens of millions from other commercial enterprises through taxes, extortion, and looting. Despite cut oil revenue, ISIS has shifted to demanding higher taxes and fees from people and businesses, plundering resources and antiquities, and confiscating property and land. The group's financial situation is complex, with US officials estimating its revenue but unable to accurately determine its spending.

site_title: American Air, Qantas step up their alliance
summary: Qantas and American Airlines have strengthened their alliance with the addition of direct flights from Los Angeles to Sydney and the resumption of flights from Sydney to San Francisco. The new flights, set to begin in December, will increase air capacity between Australia and the US by around 9%. Qantas expects a boom in the tech industry in Silicon Valley to drive demand, while American Airlines sees the partnership as a way to strengthen its global competitiveness. The airlines will ask for antitrust immunity for the new service.

site_title: China New Town shares dive
summary: China New Town Development Company (CNTD) shares plummeted 10.1% in Singapore and 13.5% in Hong Kong after the company's executive director and vice-chairman Shi Jian was taken into custody by Chinese authorities. The move, which occurred without explanation, led investors to question the reasons behind the detention. Despite assurances that the situation won't impact the group's operations, CNTD's shares continued to fall. The company's shares were also affected by recent speculation and a surge in the Chinese market, which saw property prices rise due to reduced down-payment requirements for home loans.

site_title: Indonesian bonds an opportunity amid rout: BOAML
summary: Bank of America Merrill Lynch predicts Indonesian 10-year government bonds could be an opportunity amid a potential rout in Asian currencies, which may depreciate 5-9% in the next 12 months. The bank's co-head of Asia FX and rates strategy, Claudio Piron, expects the rupiah to hit 13,800 to the US dollar by the end of the year and 14,500 by the end of next year. Meanwhile, Indian 10-year government bonds are seen as a stable option, with yields expected to head down to 7% from around 7.8%.

site_title: UK's NIESR estimates economy grew 0.6% in three months to May
summary: Britain's economy grew 0.6% in the three months to May, the fastest growth rate since January, according to estimates by the National Institute for Economic and Social Research. This rebounded from a 0.3% growth rate in the first quarter of 2015. The growth rate is consistent with a second-quarter rebound and forecasts the UK's economy to grow 2.5% this year, slightly above its long-run average.

site_title: Wages in US increased in first quarter by most since 2006
summary: US wages rose 4.2% in the first quarter, the largest increase since 2006, according to the Labour Department's Employer Costs for Employee Compensation report. Average pay for all civilian workers climbed to $22.88 an hour, and total compensation increased 4.9% in the same period. This growth surpasses the 4% year-over-year gain in the fourth quarter and is the strongest since 2006. The data suggests a strengthening labour market, with the ECEC providing a more accurate measure of worker compensation than the fixed-weight ECI.

site_title: US consumers spent 0.4% less on health care in first quarter
summary: US consumers spent 0.4% less on health care in the first quarter, according to a Commerce Department report. The figure is not adjusted for inflation or seasonal variations. The data will be used to revise gross domestic product data for the first three months of the year. This marks the first decline in healthcare spending since 2009.

site_title: SGX unveils LNG price index
summary: Singapore Exchange (SGX) has unveiled its LNG price index, the FOB Singapore SLInG, to increase transparency in physical spot trading of liquefied natural gas in Asia. The index is based on averaged submissions from international LNG players and aims to maintain a balanced portfolio of net buyers and sellers. The debut index is the result of a joint initiative between SGX, Pavilion Energy, and IE Singapore, with 13 LNG players currently participating and 10 more expected to join. The index is seen as a potential benchmark for the region's LNG market, which currently lacks a clear price benchmark, and could lead to the launch of derivatives and over-the-counter swap products.

site_title: Shringgit
summary: Singapore stocks have recorded a 5-day rally ahead of the release of GDP data. Meanwhile, Popiah king Sam Goi has made a mandatory offer for the remaining shares of PSC at S$0.40 per share. In the Asia market, traders are shrugging off US President-elect Donald Trump's threats to extend the stock rally. In the US, the S&P 500 and Nasdaq reached fresh records despite ongoing trade tensions with the EU. Key stocks to watch include Singtel, Sinarmas Land, and Cordlife, as well as companies involved in mining, healthcare, and trade negotiations.

site_title: Using technology to redefine education for employment
summary: A 2014 labor survey found that 65% of new job postings for executive secretaries and executive assistants require a bachelor's degree, despite only 19% of those in these roles having one. This highlights the issue of employers' increasing demand for a bachelor's degree as a job-qualifying badge, despite its irrelevance or lack of capturing someone's true capabilities. Experts, including Senator Mark Warner, are calling for a shift towards using Big Data and online talent platforms to nurture talent in the workforce and make university curricula more relevant to changing workforce needs.

site_title: US mortgage applications rise; rates at highest since Nov
summary: US mortgage applications increased 8.4% last week, while interest rates rose to 4.17% for 30-year fixed mortgages, the highest since November 2014. Refinancing applications rose 7.0%, and home purchase demand increased 9.7%. Strong job gains and initial signs of wage growth are supporting the purchase market, according to the Mortgage Bankers Association.

site_title: US services data suggest upward revision to Q1 GDP
summary: US services data suggest a revision to Q1 GDP, potentially bumping it up to a 0.2% contraction rate, compared to the initial 0.7% decline. This is due to stronger-than-estimated consumer spending, including healthcare, and revisions to construction, trade, and inventory data.

site_title: UK clamps down on markets after trader scandals
summary: The UK has announced plans to tighten regulations in financial markets after a string of scandals, costing banks $19 billion in fines. The proposals include extending criminal penalties for insider trading to FICC markets, increasing jail sentences to 10 years, and holding managers accountable for staff misconduct. The move aims to prevent market abuse and ensure accountability, with Bank of England Governor Mark Carney emphasizing the need for real markets that guarantee prosperity. The UK's review has influenced the European Union's consideration of similar laws, with regulators worldwide expected to follow suit.

site_title: JPMorgan warns Brexit could trigger Scottish independence vote
summary: JPMorgan warns that a Brexit vote in the UK could trigger a Scottish independence vote, as the country's fifth-largest economy navigates EU exit. The bank's analysts believe the SNP would claim the EU exit decision should prompt another independence referendum. A 2015 note stated that if the UK votes to leave the EU, economic uncertainty could hurt the economy and business sentiment, with substantial transitional costs. The prospect of another referendum on Scottish independence adds to UK uncertainties following a Brexit vote.

site_title: OUE C-Reit to buy majority stake in One Raffles Place for S$1b-S$1.1b
summary: OUE Commercial Reit (OUE C-Reit) is acquiring a majority stake in One Raffles Place for S$1 billion-S$1.1 billion from its sponsor OUE Limited. The acquisition, through an indirect purchase of OUB Centre Limited, will give OUE C-Reit a portfolio exceeding S$3 billion. The sale and purchase agreement was signed between the Reit's trustee and the sponsor, marking a significant expansion for the company.

site_title: China's economy forecast to pick up in H2 2015
summary: China's central bank economists have lowered their 2015 inflation forecast to 1.4%, from 2.2%, citing stabilizing home prices and firmer foreign demand. Despite this, they remain cautiously optimistic about the economy's outlook, predicting a 7.0% growth rate for 2015. The forecast also shows a sharp revision in producer price expectations, with a 4.2% decline anticipated. The economists attribute these changes to looser monetary policy conditions and the expected recovery in the world economy.

site_title: Petra Foods to cease distribution business in Singapore
summary: Petra Foods Limited has decided to cease its loss-making distribution business in Singapore, selling its agency brands portfolio to Auric Pacific Marketing. The distribution business, operated by Delfi Singapore, has not been profitable for years due to its small scale. Despite this, Petra Foods plans to continue growing its Delfi brand of chocolate confectionery in Singapore through Auric Pacific as distributor. The transaction is expected to have minimal impact on Petra Foods' financials.

site_title: US should ditch 'outdated' oil export ban: Harvard
summary: A Harvard Business School study suggests the US should lift its 40-year-old oil export ban to capitalize on the hydraulic fracturing boom. The ban could add $23 billion to the economy by 2030, create tens of thousands of jobs, and enhance the country's geopolitical influence. The study's authors argue that the ban is "outdated" and restricts market opportunities for US producers. The move comes amid debate in Washington, with Republicans introducing bills to reverse the ban, while Democrats cite concerns over domestic energy prices.

site_title: Indonesia's state banks to halve small business lending rates: Bloomberg
summary: Indonesia's state-owned banks will halve lending rates to small businesses, reducing rates from 22-24% to 12%, to stimulate the economy. Vice President Jusuf Kalla announced the move as part of efforts to boost economic growth, which has slowed to 2009 levels. The government will subsidize interest payments and provide cheaper funding to state banks to lend to small firms, aiming to stimulate demand and counter inflation. The move aims to support President Joko Widodo's economic stimulus plans, which include raising the income tax threshold and relaxing lending rules.

site_title: US: Wall St opens slightly higher
summary: US stocks opened slightly higher on Wednesday, with the Dow Jones industrial average rising 54.12 points, or 0.3%, to 17,818.16. The S&P 500 gained 6.76 points, or 0.32%, to 2,086.91, and the Nasdaq Composite added 15.14 points, or 0.3%, to 5,029.01. The gains followed a flat market the previous day.

site_title: ECB raises emergency funding for Greek banks by 2.3 bln euros: sources
summary: The European Central Bank (ECB) has raised the cap on emergency liquidity assistance for Greek banks by 2.3 billion euros, increasing the ceiling to 83.0 billion euros. This move aims to keep pressure on Athens to agree on economic reforms required to unlock remaining bailout aid. The ECB has raised the cap in increments, following a 500 million euro increase last week. The move aims to support Greek banks and prevent bankruptcy.

site_title: Bodies of teens from Germanwings crash arrive in hometown
summary: The bodies of 44 German schoolchildren and two teachers, killed in a Germanwings plane crash in the French Alps, arrived in their hometown of Haltern, Germany. The victims were returning from a trip to Spain when the plane was intentionally crashed by co-pilot Andreas Lubitz. Lubitz, who had a history of severe depression, intentionally downed the plane, killing everyone on board. The remains were repatriated to Germany from Duesseldorf, with more victims expected to arrive in the coming weeks. The crash's aftermath has raised concerns about the handling of logistical and bureaucratic issues by Lufthansa.

site_title: Oil prices jump on US stock draw, easing production
summary: US oil prices rose as crude inventories fell 6.81 million barrels to 470.6 million last week, exceeding forecasted drawdown of 1.72 million barrels. This confirms a bullish report from the American Petroleum Institute and suggests the US oil market is rebalancing after months of large surpluses. Brent crude prices rose $1.48 to a two-week high of $66.36 a barrel, while US light crude was up 90 cents at $61.04, following a prediction that domestic oil production would fall more strongly and for longer than expected.

site_title: SIA to waive cancellation fees for flights to Seoul due to Mers
summary: Singapore Airlines (SIA) will waive cancellation fees and admin fees for flights to Seoul's Incheon International Airport due to the Mers outbreak. The waiver is valid for tickets issued on or before June 9 for travel until June 22. Passengers holding confirmed tickets can rebook, re-route, or receive refunds without incurring additional fees.

images.alt_text: Nisha Ramchandani

site_title: TeliaSonera buys 1.4 per cent stake in music streamer Spotify
summary: TeliaSonera, a Nordic telecom operator, has acquired a 1.4% stake in music streaming service Spotify, valuing the company at over $8.2 billion. The investment, worth $115 million, is part of Spotify's $526-million fundraising round. The deal allows Spotify to top $1 billion in revenue since its creation in 2008. TeliaSonera and Spotify will collaborate on innovation, including media distribution, data analytics, and advertising, with TeliaSonera being the first to publicly disclose its stake.

site_title: Dubai's financial free zone aims to triple number of firms by 2024
summary: Dubai International Financial Centre (DIFC) aims to triple the number of finance firms in the free zone by 2024, solidifying its position as the Middle East's leading banking hub. The growth will come from emerging markets, including India and China, as well as expanding existing activities such as investment banking and asset management. DIFC governor Essa Kazim stated that half of the growth will target the 'south-south trade corridor' and the other half will focus on family-owned investment offices. The strategy aims to entrench DIFC's position in the global finance industry.

site_title: Microsoft offers Monster Surface for conferencing: Just $20,000
summary: Microsoft is launching the Surface Hub, a 84-inch touch-screen flat-panel computer designed for conferencing, priced at $20,000. The device, available in 55-inch and 84-inch models, will connect to phones and tablets, offering a unique alternative to traditional teleconference setups. This product is part of Microsoft's focus on hardware projects, leveraging its 2012 acquisition of Perceptive Pixel Inc. to produce large, precise touch screens. The Surface Hub is set to be delivered in September and is expected to be more cost-effective than comparable teleconference setups.

site_title: India's Jan-March current acc deficit narrows to 0.2% of GDP
summary: India's current account deficit narrowed to 0.2% of GDP in the January-March quarter, its lowest in a year, due to a slump in global oil prices. The deficit fell to $1.3 billion, from $8.3 billion in the previous quarter. Foreign investments remained robust, with a surge of $12.9 billion in the January-March period. Analysts expressed disappointment, however, as the deficit prevented a current account surplus, and warned that the deficit could widen if US interest rates rise.

site_title: UK's Cameron faces calls to issue impact analysis on possible EU exit
summary: British Prime Minister David Cameron is facing calls to provide an independent analysis of the financial impact of a possible UK exit from the European Union ahead of a potential referendum by the end of 2017. The Labour Party demands such analysis by the Bank of England and independent economic forecasters at least 10 weeks before the vote. The Bank of England has already announced plans to conduct research on the topic, and Cameron has stated that he will reshape Britain's ties with the EU before the referendum, but has not ruled out an exit if his demands are not met.

site_title: PSA expands into south-western China with new container terminal JV
summary: PSA International has partnered with Beibu Gulf Port Group and Pacific International Lines to establish a new container terminal in Qinzhou, Guangxi province, China. The Beibu Gulf-PSA International Container Terminal will support container trade growth in the region, connecting it to key shipping routes in South-east Asia, East Africa, and the Mediterranean. The terminal is expected to begin operations in the fourth quarter of 2015, capitalizing on Guangxi's rapid economic growth and extensive hinterland. The partnership aims to boost economic growth in the region through PSA's management expertise and operational efficiency.

site_title: Opec says oil market oversupply to ease, but raises output again
summary: OPEC reported that the oil market's excess supply is expected to ease in the coming quarters as demand picks up and supply growth slows from non-OPEC producers. The group's strategy of letting prices fall appears to be working, with supply from rival producers anticipated to decline in the second half of the year. World oil demand is forecast to grow faster than in 2014, according to OPEC's in-house economists.

site_title: Tokio Marine buys US's HCC for US$7.5b in its biggest takeover
summary: Tokio Marine Holdings Inc agreed to buy HCC Insurance Holdings Inc for approximately US$7.5 billion, its largest acquisition. The deal is a 37.6% premium to HCC's latest closing price and marks Japanese insurers' efforts to expand overseas amid stagnant home markets. Tokio Marine will pay US$78 in cash per share for HCC, adding to its US$8.8 billion in North American purchases. The acquisition follows Japanese insurers' US$27.5 billion in acquisitions over the past five years.

images.alt_text: Tokio Marine Holdings Inc agreed to buy HCC Insurance Holdings Inc for about US$7.5 billion in the biggest acquisition by a Japanese insurer, stepping up an overseas expansion.

site_title: Fifa suspends 2026 World Cup bidding
summary: Fifa has suspended the bidding process for the 2026 World Cup due to the ongoing corruption probes within the organization. The decision was made to halt the administrative process, with further discussions to be held by the Fifa Executive Committee at a later date. This move comes amid growing concerns and furore surrounding corruption allegations.

site_title: Malaysia's palm oil reserves climb to six-month high on output
summary: Malaysia's palm oil reserves reached a six-month high in May, climbing 2.5% to 2.24 million metric tons, according to the Malaysian Palm Oil Board. Production rose 6.9% to 1.81 million tons, the highest since October, and exports jumped 37% to 1.61 million tons. This surge in output may curb a rally in futures, which reached a three-month high this week, and is expected to drop 7-10% in June due to increased imports ahead of the Ramadan festival.

site_title: Qatar faces first budget deficit for 15 years
summary: Qatar is set to face a budget deficit of 4.9% of GDP in 2016, its first in 15 years, due to the oil price slump. Despite this, the country plans to proceed with its massive infrastructure projects worth $200 billion, including a new metro system and port, linked to the 2022 World Cup. The government expects a 7.3% economic growth in 2015, but forecasts tapering growth in 2016 and 2017. Qatar's minister for development planning stated that the country's financial reserves will provide a buffer against the deficit.

site_title: EU rejects Greek plan as Tsipras-Merkel meeting in doubt
summary: The European Union (EU) rejected Greece's new bailout reform plan, casting doubt on a meeting between Greek Prime Minister Alexis Tsipras and German Chancellor Angela Merkel, French President Francois Hollande, and European Commission President Jean-Claude Juncker. The EU dismissed the proposals, which included tough reforms, as not reflecting the state of discussions between Juncker and Tsipras. The EU's refusal has raised concerns that Greece may default on payments to the IMF and European Central Bank, potentially leading to a messy exit from the eurozone.

site_title: Greek PM to meet EU's Tusk in Brussels shortly: PM's office
summary: Greek Prime Minister Alexis Tsipras is set to meet European Council President Donald Tusk in Brussels on Wednesday, amid efforts to agree on a cash-for-reforms deal for Greece. The meeting comes as time runs out for an agreement, with EU officials expressing concerns that Greece's latest offer had not gone far enough. Tsipras had previously met with German Chancellor Angela Merkel and French President Francois Hollande in Brussels. The outcome of the meeting is uncertain, with the European Union seeking more concessions from Greece.

site_title: Raffles United to pay S$7.98m for 51% stake in seven Lavender Street shophouses
summary: Raffles United Holdings agreed to pay S$7.98 million for a 51% stake in seven two-storey shophouses along Lavender Street, Singapore. The units have a freehold tenure and total land area of 1,217.7 square meters. The purchase price, based on arm's length negotiations, accounts for market conditions and valuation reports that valued the properties at S$30 million. The acquisition aligns with Raffles United's strategy to expand into property investment, taking advantage of Singapore's scarcity of freehold commercial properties and the shophouses' proximity to the city and transport links.

site_title: Singapore Wrap Wednesday
summary: Singapore's stocks showed a 'relief bounce' after MSCI announced it would not include China's emerging markets index, boosting the Straits Times Index (STI) by 30.64 points to 3,325.77. However, concerns about corruption and unethical business practices persist, with five former ST Marine executives charged in a graft case. Meanwhile, Singapore companies continue to focus on emerging sectors, with Spring Singapore seeking up to five accelerators to invest in startups. Property market trends showed condo rents dipping 0.6% in May, while HDB rents remained flat.

site_title: Singapore: STI enjoys 'relief bounce' after MSCI news
summary: The Straits Times Index (STI) in Singapore bounced 30.64 points to 3,325.77 after news that MSCI will not include China 'A' shares in its emerging markets index. This decision alleviated concerns that Singapore's weighting would be reduced, causing a relief bounce rather than a rally. The STI had fallen 98 points since MSCI's announcement on May 29. Turnover on Wednesday was 1.2 billion units worth S$1.1 billion, with banks, Jardine group, and shares of Q&M Dental and Silverlake Axis rebounding.

site_title: Spring to appoint accelerators for cleantech, advanced manufacturing, engineering
summary: SPRING Singapore plans to appoint up to five accelerators to support startups in emerging sectors, including clean technology, advanced manufacturing, and engineering. The accelerators will jointly invest up to S$4 million each in these sectors, which have immense growth potential. The initiative aims to foster innovation and entrepreneurship in these areas.

site_title: Samsung battle escalates as Lee family ally increases stake
summary: Samsung's battle for control escalated as KCC Corp increased its stake in the Samsung Group to support the founding Lee family's plan. KCC will buy 8.99 million shares, valued at 674.3 billion won, to secure a close shareholder for the merger between Samsung C&T and Cheil Industries. This move counters Elliott Associates LP's efforts to block the merger, citing it isn't in shareholders' best interests. The merger aims to boost control of South Korea's biggest conglomerate, with the Lee family seeking to use it as part of their strategy.

site_title: German Instagram rival EyeEm seeks to expand photo marketplace
summary: EyeEm, a German photo-sharing app, plans to expand its marketplace globally, introducing its 50 million-image library to the UK, Germany, Indonesia, South Korea, Japan, Turkey, and Brazil over the next 12 months. The app, which attracts 13 million users, allows photographers to sell their work to companies, with a scalable business model that splits revenue 50-50 with the photographer. EyeEm has sold photos to clients in 40 countries, including Uber and Mercedes Benz, and has received $18 million in funding from investors.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares end higher
summary: Malaysian shares closed higher on Wednesday, with the Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rising 6.58 points to 1,735.63. A total of 1.22 billion lots worth RM1.55 billion were traded, with 357 gains and 417 losses.

site_title: China approves US$19.3b of airport, rail projects
summary: China's National Development and Reform Commission approved over 120 billion yuan worth of airport and railway projects, including a 14.5 billion yuan airport expansion on Hainan island and a 96.1 billion yuan railway track connecting Anhui and Hangzhou. The approvals come as China's economy faces its weakest pace in six years, with economists shaving their forecast for 2015 growth to 7.0 per cent. This follows recent infrastructure approvals, including 250 billion yuan of railway subway projects in mid-May, aimed at averting a sharp slowdown.

site_title: Rolls-Royce forms gearbox production JV with Germany's Liebherr-Aerospace
summary: Rolls-Royce has formed a joint venture with Liebherr-Aerospace to develop manufacturing facilities for a new gearbox for the Ultrafan engine, which could be 25% more fuel-efficient. The joint venture will be based in Friedrichshafen, Germany, and will initially produce components in existing facilities, with plans to build a new factory as production volumes rise. This move is part of Rolls-Royce's cost-cutting program to boost aero-engine profitability, which has lagged behind rival General Electric.

site_title: New StanChart boss Winters says bank needs to strengthen finances
summary: Standard Chartered's new CEO, Bill Winters, has emphasized the need to strengthen the bank's finances by simplifying and restructuring operations to achieve better returns. He prioritizes capital strength, aiming to raise at least $5 billion through a rights issue and cut dividends. Winters also plans to rebuild confidence, improve efficiency, and enhance the bank's ethical standards to combat financial crime. He aims to announce the leadership team by the summer and provide broader plans by the end of the year.

site_title: French April industry output falls, countering rise forecasts
summary: France's industrial sector output fell 0.9% in April, contrary to forecasted 0.4% rise, due to dips in aerospace, automobiles, and textiles. The temporary refinery closure contributed to the decline. This marks a notable reversal of the economy's recovery, casting doubt on its strength. The unexpected drop may impact the overall economic outlook, prompting policymakers to reassess their strategies.

site_title: Fifa official Valcke hits back over $10 mln transactions
summary: Fifa Secretary General Jerome Valcke has denied allegations of wrongdoing over $10 million in bank transactions under investigation by US authorities. Valcke stated there were no grounds to blame him or Fifa over the funds' use, and claimed he had not been questioned by Swiss prosecutors or police. The transactions are central to a US bribery investigation against soccer's governing body. Valcke's comments came during an emotional appearance in Samara, Russia, a venue for the 2018 World Cup finals.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks end 1.12% down
summary: Hong Kong shares ended 1.12% lower on Wednesday, following a tepid lead from Wall Street. The Hang Seng Index closed at 26,687.64, while the Shanghai Composite Index edged down 0.15%. The decline was attributed to news that Chinese A shares would not yet be included in a global benchmark index of equities.

site_title: Glencore in Singapore fuel oil spree as cargo premium slumps
summary: Glencore has purchased over 1 million metric tons of fuel oil in Singapore this month, taking advantage of a slump in cargo premiums. The company bought 925,000 tons of 380-centistoke fuel oil and 140,000 tons of 180-centistoke fuel oil, accounting for about 36% of total transacted volume. The fuel oil inventory in Singapore has reached a record, and the market's attention is drawn to the high volume of cargoes traded recently, indicating ample supplies.

site_title: Petrobras says it's the victim as investor bribery suits mount
summary: Petrobras faces mounting US investor lawsuits over a multibillion-dollar bribery scheme that allegedly knocked US$60 billion off its stock value. The company claims it was a victim of corruption, citing a "criminal cartel" of Brazilian construction firms. Petrobras has asked a US judge to throw out the suits, arguing it didn't pay bribes and lost less than investors claim. A US District Judge will hear arguments on June 25, and experts say the company's defense may not absolve it from liability.

site_title: Woman isolated in Hong Kong hospital over Mers
summary: A 22-year-old woman in Hong Kong was isolated in a hospital after returning from a trip to South Korea, where an Mers virus outbreak has occurred, resulting in 9 deaths and 108 infections. The woman presented with a runny nose and fever after returning, and is in stable condition. This marks the first suspected case in Hong Kong, following the country's previous quarantine of 19 people and isolation of suspected cases. The Mers virus has a 35% fatality rate and no vaccine or cure is available.

site_title: BOJ survey shows less concern about bond market functioning
summary: The Bank of Japan (BOJ) conducted a survey of 39 financial institutions, showing a decrease in concerns about the bond market's functioning and liquidity. The diffusion index improved to minus 5 in May from minus 25 in February, indicating fewer firms are worried about liquidity and widening spreads. The BOJ's massive debt purchases under quantitative easing have eased strain on the market, with some firms reporting an improvement in trading flows.

images.alt_text: Japanese government bond dealers are growing less concerned about the overall functioning of the bond market and liquidity, a Bank of Japan survey showed on Wednesday, suggesting easing strain from quantitative easing.

site_title: China: Stocks decline after MSCI defers adding stocks to indexes
summary: China's stocks declined for a second day after MSCI Inc deferred adding mainland shares to its benchmark indexes. The Shanghai Composite Index slipped 0.2% to 5,106.04, while the Hang Seng Index fell 1.1%. Industrial companies retreated, with CRRC Corp slumping 9% and Huaneng Power International Inc dropping 2.7%. MSCI cited obstacles to inclusion, but said a decision may come at any time, potentially hurting A-share sentiment and triggering profit-taking.

site_title: Bank breakup bill set for key EU talks as nations seek deal
summary: European Union nations are set to reach agreement on a bill to tackle "too-big-to-fail" banks by the end of June, with the aim of sending the legislation to finance ministers for approval in Luxembourg. The draft law, known as the bank structure regulation, sets ground rules for measuring risk-taking at banks and separating derivatives transactions from consumer services. The proposal has been met with criticism from the finance industry, which fears it could lead to reduced market-making capacity and higher costs for European borrowers. Negotiations are ongoing, with the EU's rotating presidency, Latvia, seeking a deal before handing over to Luxembourg on July 1.

site_title: China central bank economists lower 2015 GDP forecast, cite growth pressure
summary: China's central bank economists lowered their 2015 GDP forecast to 7.0% from 7.1%, citing downward pressure on activity. They also lowered trade growth forecasts, stating their estimates were personal views and not official. This change reflects concerns about economic growth, which may put pressure on policymakers.

images.alt_text: Economists at China's central bank have lowered their 2015 growth forecast for the Chinese economy to 7.0 per cent, from 7.1 per cent, citing increased downward pressure on activity.

site_title: Undercooked US economy risks overheating as demand tops supply
summary: The US economy is at risk of overheating as demand surpasses supply for the first time in 15 years, according to Wells Capital Management Inc. Demand growth is outpacing supply due to weak labor supply and low productivity, leading to heightened inflation pressure, narrowing profit margins, and higher borrowing costs. Chief investment strategist Jim Paulsen warns of potential market fluctuations and recommends diversifying into foreign markets and minimizing exposure to bonds, citing historical examples of demand-led recoveries leading to financial market volatility.

site_title: Europe: Stocks weaken at open
summary: Europe's stock markets declined in opening trade on Wednesday, with London's FTSE 100 down 0.19%, Frankfurt's DAX 30 down 0.28%, and Paris's CAC 40 down 0.40%. The decline follows stalled Greek debt talks and a bank overhaul. Greek Prime Minister Alexis Tsipras is set to meet with Angela Merkel in Brussels, where a potential breakthrough bailout deal could be imminent.

site_title: Singapore still has room for improvement in ethical business practices: survey
summary: A survey by EY found that while Singapore companies have set up codes of conduct, training, and anti-bribery policies, their effectiveness is lacking. 84% of respondents reported increasing efforts to combat fraud and bribery, but 40% believe these policies have little impact on employee behavior. Whistleblowing hotlines are underused due to concerns about retaliation, with 67% of companies having them in place but 62% of employees willing to use them. The survey suggests that more needs to be done to demonstrate and communicate about ethical behavior in Singapore companies.

site_title: Indonesia to halve lending rates to small business amid slowdown
summary: Indonesia's state-owned banks will halve lending rates to small businesses to revive economic growth from a five-year low. The rates will be lowered to 12% from 22-24%, with the government subsidizing interest payments and providing cheaper funding to state-owned banks to lend to small firms. This move aims to address a mismatch in banking principles, with small business loans having higher interest rates than bigger loans. The decision comes as Indonesia's economy expanded 4.71% in the first quarter, the least since 2009, amid inflation accelerating to 7.15% in May.

site_title: China tech giant Baidu to develop driverless car: media
summary: China's Baidu plans to develop a driverless car by the end of 2015, following in the footsteps of Google. The company will work with an unknown auto manufacturer on the project. Baidu has previously collaborated with BMW on "semi-autonomous" cars. Other Chinese tech firms, including Alibaba and Tencent, are also working on Internet-connected cars. However, analysts believe details of these plans are vague, and commercial production is unlikely due to scandals surrounding Baidu, including a cheating scandal and anti-corruption investigations.

site_title: Airbus says A400M to fly at Paris airshow
summary: Airbus announced that its A400M military aircraft will perform a flying display at the Paris airshow, despite a fatal crash in Spain just over a month ago. The crash, which killed four people, was attributed to a technical bug in the plane's engine control units. An analysis of the black boxes found that three of the four engines failed, but there was no structural fault. The incident has led to a global grounding of A400M planes, with several countries, including Spain, Britain, and Germany, suspending operations. Airbus maintains confidence in the aircraft's safety.

site_title: Airlines struggle to please the modern passenger
summary: Airlines struggle to meet the evolving demands of modern air travelers, with 55% of industry representatives surveyed stating they are not satisfied with current services. Industry experts suggest airlines should focus on personalizing experiences, managing expectations, and offering tailored information to passengers' needs. New initiatives include a standardized carry-on bag size and an air travel app that provides advice on jet lag and healthy flying habits. Airlines are also exploring innovative services such as free Wi-Fi, wearable devices, and personalized shopping opportunities to improve the passenger experience.

site_title: Fifa to elect Blatter successor on Dec 16
summary: FIFA is set to elect a new president on December 16, following Sepp Blatter's resignation amidst corruption charges. Representatives from 209 member associations will vote in the emergency meeting, with Jordan's Prince Ali Bin Al Hussein and South Korea's Chung Mong-joon reportedly considering bids. FIFA's executive committee will meet in July to finalize the date for the full presidential vote.

site_title: Qatar faces first budget deficit in 15 years
summary: Qatar is predicted to run its first budget deficit in 15 years in 2016, with a 4.9% fiscal deficit expected, down from a 7.7% deficit in 2015. The country's economy is forecast to grow 7.3% next year. Despite the anticipated deficit, Qatar plans to proceed with its $200 billion infrastructure investment program, including a new metro system and port, ahead of hosting the 2022 World Cup. The country's financial reserves will provide a buffer against lower oil prices.

site_title: Bayer to Sell diabetes unit to Panasonic for US$1.15 billion
summary: Bayer AG agreed to sell its diabetes devices business to Panasonic Healthcare Co, a joint venture backed by KKR & Co, for approximately $1.15 billion. The diabetes unit, which includes blood-glucose monitoring systems, will be sold to focus on more lucrative life-sciences operations. The transaction is expected to be completed in the first quarter of 2026, after regulatory review. This sale marks Bayer's second peripheral unit disposal, following the listing of its plastics unit on the stock market in the coming months.

site_title: China says Taiwan opposition leader needs to explain China policy
summary: China has urged Taiwan's opposition leader Tsai Ing-Wen to explain her policy towards China and how she intends to maintain peace between the two sides. Tsai, the Democratic Progressive Party's presidential hopeful, completed a visit to the US, where she reiterated her support for the "status quo" with China. China's Taiwan Affairs Office spokesman Ma Xiaoguang stated that Tsai's comments opposing Taiwan independence and upholding the "1992 consensus" are crucial for peaceful cross-strait relations. Tsai's party has a strong chance of retaking power in January's presidential election.

site_title: Stung by weak dairy prices, NZ's Fonterra plans job cuts
summary: New Zealand's Fonterra, the world's largest dairy exporter, plans to cut jobs due to weak dairy prices, which have fallen to their lowest level in nearly six years. The company aims to improve sales in the face of declining demand in China and other countries. Fonterra plans a company-wide review, with the results to be announced in coming months, and has already slowed spending on expansion if demand remains sluggish. CEO Theo Spierings said the company must adapt to changing market conditions, including volatile dairy prices.

site_title: Indonesian president breaks tradition in picking new military chief
summary: Indonesian President Joko Widodo has broken tradition by choosing General Gatot Nurmantyo as the new military chief, rather than rotating the position between the branches of the armed forces. The decision is expected to cement the army's dominant role and may inflame rivalry within the military. Widodo's choice is seen as a way to strengthen the military in response to regional geopolitical changes. The move has been defended by the presidential spokesman as a legitimate use of the president's authority, with parliamentary approval required. The decision comes amid a shift in Indonesia's military strategy under Widodo's presidency.

site_title: Taiwan's top 2 carriers to temporarily cut flights to South Korea on Mers
summary: Taiwan's top two airlines, China Airlines and EVA Airways, are temporarily cutting their flights to South Korea by nearly half due to the Middle East Respiratory Syndrome (Mers) outbreak. China Airlines will cut flights to 27 per week from 42, while EVA Airways will cut flights to seven from 20. The cut will run from mid-June to end of July. The move comes after 15% of reservations to South Korea were canceled, and Taiwanese health authorities have widened their travel alert to cover all of South Korea.

site_title: Another casualty of Mers: South Korea's duty free shop sales
summary: South Korea's largest duty-free shop operator, Lotte Duty Free, expects a 10% decline in revenue this month due to the spread of Middle East respiratory syndrome (Mers), which has killed nine people and infected 108. The decline is attributed to a drop in visitor arrivals, particularly from China, where most of the 54,400 tourists who have cancelled travel plans are from. This is affecting not only duty-free operators but also tour agencies and other retailers, with some analysts predicting a bad month for the industry.

site_title: Sabah quake: Bodies of missing Tanjong Katong Primary pupil and teacher found
summary: The bodies of missing Tanjong Katong Primary pupil Navdeep Singh Jaryal and teacher Mohammad Ghazi Bin Mohamed have been identified by the Malaysian authorities in Kota Kinabalu. The Ministry of Education confirmed the news, stating that the two individuals were among those who perished in the earthquake. The tragic incident has left the community in shock.

site_title: El Nino seen hurting Australian wheat; Japan warns it will intensify
summary: Australia's wheat crop outlook has been downgraded due to the first El Nino since 2010, which threatens to curb yields. The country's wheat harvest is expected to total 23.6 million metric tons in 2015-2016, down from a previous forecast of 24.4 million. Global wheat output is predicted to decline 1.4% due to the El Nino, with impacts also felt in India and other regions. The event is expected to intensify and persist through 2015, affecting global food production.

site_title: Oil prices rise on US stock draw, improved world demand outlook
summary: Oil prices rose on Wednesday due to a US stock draw and improved world demand outlook. US crude and gasoline inventories are expected to drop, with the Energy Information Administration raising its 2015 oil demand growth forecast by 20,000 barrels per day. Brent crude futures rose 44 cents to $65.32 a barrel, while US crude climbed 72 cents to $60.86 a barrel. Despite rallies, analysts expect big further gains to be unlikely due to continued oversupply and a stronger US dollar.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks open slightly higher
summary: Hong Kong stocks opened flat on Wednesday, edging up 3.09 points to 26,992.61, following a weak lead from Wall Street. This marks a slight increase from the previous day's close.

site_title: Australia: Shares in 7th straight decline on broad economic concerns
summary: Australia's shares fell for a seventh consecutive session, down 0.1% to 5467.1, amid concerns over consumer sentiment and the impact of recent rate cuts on the economy. Higher oil prices failed to offset worries about a lack of catalysts and neutral macroeconomic backdrop. Bank stocks also declined due to concerns over reduced dividend yields. The benchmark has lost nearly 6% since May 29.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open higher on Wednesday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index opened higher on Wednesday, rising 1.89 points to 1730.94. Gainers outnumbered losers 94 to 56, with a total of 23.3 million lots traded worth RM6.9 million.

site_title: IMF official calls for growth-friendly fiscal policy in Asia
summary: A senior IMF official, Mitsuhiro Furusawa, urged Asian policymakers to adopt "growth-friendly" fiscal policies to counter demographic changes that may slow economic growth. Aging populations and shrinking labor forces in Asia pose challenges, requiring increased spending on the elderly and shrinking tax bases. Furusawa also noted that global growth remains modest, with medium-term prospects less optimistic for some economies, particularly emerging markets.

site_title: Alibaba's Ma, visiting New York, says not in America to compete
summary: Alibaba's Executive Chairman Jack Ma stated during a visit to New York that the company does not aim to compete in the US market, instead focusing on helping small US businesses sell more goods in China. Ma emphasized Alibaba's global strategy, which involves investing in various sectors abroad, despite generating the majority of its revenue from its domestic online marketplaces.

site_title: EU business confidence in China at new low: survey
summary: European companies have lost confidence in China's economy, with only 28% of firms polled by the European Chamber of Commerce in China saying they are "optimistic" about their profitability. The number of respondents planning to expand operations in China fell to 56% from nearly 90% two years ago, and nearly two-thirds plan to lay off staff. China's economy grew 7.4% last year, its slowest pace in 24 years, and companies cite an "unpredictable legal environment," slow internet speeds, and online censorship as obstacles to business.

site_title: Australia's central bank open to further easing, with caveats
summary: Australia's central bank, Reserve Bank of Australia (RBA), Governor Glenn Stevens stated the bank is "open to the possibility" of further interest rate cuts if beneficial for sustainable growth. Stevens warned that monetary policy alone cannot deliver everything needed and that heavily indebted households have limited scope to use borrowing for spending. He emphasized the need for infrastructure spending and public investment to drive growth and confidence, suggesting that a long-term pipeline of infrastructure projects could be a confidence-enhancing measure.

site_title: Yuan gets early warning on IMF ambition as MSCI defers on stocks
summary: China's efforts to obtain reserve status for the yuan received an early warning from MSCI's decision to defer adding yuan-denominated stocks to an emerging-market benchmark. MSCI cited investor concerns about accessibility and capital mobility. Chinese officials have called for the International Monetary Fund to include the yuan in its basket of reserve currencies in a review in October. The yuan needs more policy changes, including easing restrictions on fund flows, to be considered for inclusion.

site_title: Chided by Abe, Japan Inc starts boosting investment at home
summary: Japan's companies, under pressure from Prime Minister Shinzo Abe, are boosting investment spending to counter record profits and outdated equipment. This move is part of the Abe administration's public campaign to encourage companies to increase wages and revive capital spending. The success of this strategy will determine the strength of Japan's recovery in the remainder of the year.

images.alt_text: Pressured by Prime Minister Shinzo Abe to share some of their record profits, and by increasingly obsolescent equipment, Japan's companies are starting to boost their investment spending.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks fall 0.25% as yen jumps
summary: Tokyo stocks closed 0.25% lower on Wednesday, despite early gains, as the yen surged after the central bank's head stated a further decline in the currency was "unlikely". The Nikkei 225 index dropped 49.94 points to 20,046.36, while the Topix index fell 0.38% to 1,628.23. The yen's appreciation countered the market's initial rally.

site_title: Swiber redeems maturing S$95m bond, easing investor concerns
summary: Swiber Holdings has redeemed its S$95 million 6.25% three-year bond, easing investor concerns over the company's ability to meet principal repayment obligations. The redemption will not impact Swiber's net tangible assets or earnings per share for the 2015 financial year. The move also addresses concerns over Swiber's 9.75% perpetual bonds due in September. The company's actions demonstrate its commitment to repaying debts and alleviating investor worries.

site_title: Thailand holds benchmark interest rate after two unexpected cuts
summary: Thailand's central bank held its benchmark interest rate at 1.5% after two unexpected cuts, defying government signals that borrowing costs may be low enough. The decision was unanimous among monetary policy committee members. The Bank of Thailand will wait for pass-through effects of previous rate cuts on the economy before making further moves, according to economists. The government has pledged to accelerate spending to boost consumption and counter falling exports, but the central bank may reassess its economic growth forecast. The decision follows a weaker Thai baht, which reduced pressure on additional rate cuts.

site_title: Barry Callebaut picks Unilever's Saint-Affrique as new chief
summary: Barry Callebaut AG, the world's largest bulk chocolate maker, appointed Unilever's head of food, Antoine de Saint-Affrique, as its new CEO, effective October 1. De Saint-Affrique will replace Juergen Steinemann, who will become vice chairman. The appointment comes after Unilever's CFO Jean-Marc Huet and head of hair-care business Michel Dallemagne left the company. De Saint-Affrique's experience in consumer markets and international business made him the right candidate for the position, according to Chairman Andreas Jacobs.

site_title: Singapore condo rents dip 0.6% in May, HDB rents stay flat: SRX
summary: Singapore condo rents decreased 0.6% in May, with city fringe and suburbs experiencing a 0.6% and 1.5% drop, respectively. Rents in the prime central area rose 0.2%. Year-over-year, rents fell 6% and from their peak in January 2013, 11.7%.

site_title: Asia: Markets mostly higher, US reports lift dollar
summary: Asian markets mostly rose on Wednesday, with Tokyo and Hong Kong gaining 0.36% and 0.35%, respectively. The dollar strengthened against the yen after two upbeat US reports, fueling expectations of a Federal Reserve interest rate hike. Shanghai sank 1.25% as MSCI Inc delayed including it in its global benchmarks. Greece's bailout reform talks continued to impact foreign exchange markets, with the euro edging up to $1.1300. US markets ended largely unchanged, and oil prices inched higher on expectations of a decline in US crude stockpiles.

site_title: Greek PM to meet Merkel as bailout deal nears
summary: Greek Prime Minister Alexis Tsipras is set to meet with German Chancellor Angela Merkel in Brussels as a breakthrough bailout deal for Greece is expected to be reached "within days." Greece has submitted new proposals to end a standoff with the EU and IMF, which demand tough reforms in exchange for the final 7.2 billion euros of bailout funds. The meeting comes as a deadline for the current bailout package expires at the end of the month, and Greece desperately needs the cash to avoid a default.

site_title: Former ST Marine financial controller is fifth exec to be charged in graft case
summary: Former ST Marine financial controller Patrick Lee Swee Ching has become the fifth senior executive to be charged in a graft case involving bribes to secure ship repair contracts. Lee faces 38 counts of abetting bogus entertainment expenses worth over S$126,000. He is the fifth former executive to plead guilty, while four others are at the pre-trial conference stage. The scandal involves alleged bribes to customers' agents between 2004 and 2010, and Lee's case is set to be heard on July 1.

site_title: South Korea reports 13 new Mers cases, 2 more deaths
summary: South Korea's Middle East Respiratory Syndrome (Mers) outbreak has reported 13 new cases and 2 more deaths, bringing the total to 108 fatalities. The deaths were of individuals with pre-existing serious ailments, and all new cases were traced to hospitals. The health ministry emphasized that the virus was spreading in healthcare settings.

site_title: Gold steadies on softer dollar, but fund outflows continue
summary: Gold steadied at $1,175.63 an ounce on Wednesday, despite a softer dollar, due to ongoing investor concerns over a potential US interest rate hike. The metal fell to an 11-week low on Friday after a strong US nonfarm payrolls report. Fund outflows continued, limiting gains, and the dollar's losses were not enough to push up gold significantly.

site_title: Singapore: Stocks open marginally higher on Wednesday
summary: Singapore shares opened 0.2% higher on Wednesday, with the Straits Times Index rising 8.07 points to 3,303.2. The gain was attributed to Singapore Telecommunications' 0.24% increase. The most actively traded stock was Loyz Energy, which rose 0.011 to S$0.130. Gainers outnumbered losers 76 to 69, with an average unit price of S$1.05 per share.

site_title: MSCI to give investors at least a year to prepare for China 'A' shares
summary: MSCI, a US index provider, announced it will give investors at least 12 months to prepare for China 'A' shares to be included in its benchmark indexes. The decision comes after resolving outstanding market accessibility issues. MSCI may consider including China 'A' shares as early as June 2016, pending further review.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open 0.15% higher
summary: Tokyo stocks opened 0.15% higher on Wednesday, reversing three days of losses, amid a stable dollar and positive US job vacancy reports. The dollar rose to 124.37 yen, while US stocks edged to fresh records despite tariff uncertainty. Analysts expect the Federal Reserve to raise interest rates due to the surge in job vacancies. Meanwhile, stalled Greek debt talks continued, with Athens submitting new proposals to end the standoff.

site_title: Stocks to watch: Soilbuild, Loyz
summary: Two stocks are making headlines: Loyz Energy, which agreed to a reverse takeover deal with Primeline Energy Holdings, and Soilbuild Construction Group, which won a contract to build a luxury condominium in Yangon, Myanmar, valued at US$50.4 million. The Loyz deal will give Primeline listed status in Singapore, while Soilbuild's project marks its first full-fledged construction project in Myanmar.

images.alt_text: It said on Tuesday that it has been awarded a contract worth US$50.4 million to design and build Rosehill Residences, a 24-storey, 176-unit condo along Kabar Aye Pagoda Road, near the city's Shwedagon Pagoda. The condo also has four levels of semi-basement. The project is scheduled to start in the third quarter of 2015, and will be completed in 40 months.

site_title: MSCI delays including China 'A' shares' in benchmark index
summary: MSCI has delayed including China's "A" shares in its benchmark index due to outstanding market accessibility issues. The decision was made despite China's efforts to promote its yuan currency globally and attract foreign capital through financial reforms. MSCI cited restrictions on capital mobility, settlement risks, and investment quotas as reasons for the delay. The decision may fall outside of its regular review schedule and could have injected an estimated $400 billion into mainland China's equity markets if included.

site_title: Messenger app tops a billion downloads at Google Play
summary: Facebook's Messenger app has reached a milestone, topping a billion downloads on the Google Play store. The Android version of the app was downloaded more than a billion times, making it the second app to achieve this feat after Google. The high download count is attributed to Facebook spinning off Messenger from its main application, allowing users to download the app separately. The app now boasts over 600 million users and offers features such as video calling and peer-to-peer payments, setting the stage for potential monetization and e-commerce integration.

site_title: Short 'last' film of Amelia Earhart surfaces
summary: A 3.5-minute film, shot by photographer John Bresnik in 1937, has surfaced, showing Amelia Earhart boarding her Lockheed 10 Electra at Burbank airfield the day before her ill-fated around-the-globe flight. The grainy black-and-white footage, believed to have been taken by Earhart's official photographer, captures Earhart looking "coquettish" and self-confident. The film, released by author Douglas Westfall, provides a rare glimpse into Earhart's preparations before her disappearance over the Pacific in 1937.

site_title: China: Stocks open down after MSCI decision to not include A shares in benchmark
summary: China stocks opened lower on June 10, 2015, after MSCI Inc decided not to include China-listed shares in its key benchmark indexes due to market accessibility issues. The CSI300 index fell 1.2% and the Shanghai Composite Index lost 1.3%, with investors bracing for a new wave of initial public offerings. MSCI's decision showed global asset managers' reservations about China's capital market openness, with the result seen as within market expectations.

site_title: Tesla CFO Deepak Ahuja to retire, help find replacement
summary: Tesla CFO Deepak Ahuja to retire later this year, but will remain to find his successor. CEO Elon Musk also announced an early release of Tesla's Autopilot self-driving program for the Model S by the end of June. Musk confirmed deliveries of the Model X crossover will begin in 3-4 months, with a new battery factory in Nevada expected to start production by mid-2016 and reach full production in 3-4 years.

site_title: MSCI cushions China A-shares delay with regulator working group
summary: MSCI has formed a working group with China's regulator to discuss global investors' concerns about mainland China's A-share market, accelerating the timeline for adding these stocks to global benchmark indexes. The group aims to address barriers such as investment quotas, capital lockups, and ownership rights. MSCI will be more transparent in its decision-making process, and the working group is expected to resolve issues within 12 months. This collaboration is seen as a step towards including China's A-shares in MSCI's indexes, which could boost the yuan's role in global finance.

site_title: Thatcher policies failed UK as productivity weakness persists
summary: A study at the University of Cambridge found that Margaret Thatcher's economic policies failed the UK, leaving the country with long-term structural shortcomings. Productivity growth "clearly slowed" after 1979, and liberalization had little positive impact. The decline of manufacturing and rise of services industry, driven by Thatcher's policies, has proven challenging for current Prime Minister David Cameron. The research suggests that the UK's economic weaknesses persist, hindering efforts to sustainably increase living standards.

site_title: Gas Malaysia to raise gas price by 10.3% from July 1
summary: Gas Malaysia will raise gas prices by an average of 10.3% starting July 1, with the tariff increasing to 21.80 ringgit per million British thermal units (mmBtu) in Peninsular Malaysia. The price hike is due to higher procurement costs from Petroliam Nasional Bhd, and is not applicable to households using liquefied petroleum gas. This is the second price revision in 7 months, as part of the government's plan to reduce subsidies and cut its budget deficit.

site_title: Dozens of US airport workers linked to terror: official
summary: A report by the Homeland Security Inspector General found that the Transportation Security Agency (TSA) failed to detect at least 73 people with terror links who were hired by US airports. The TSA had limited oversight over the hiring process, allowing individuals with ties to terrorism to be employed. The agency is also criticized for its PreCheck program, which some say is too easily accessible. The TSA is reeling after a recent report found that investigators could sneak fake bombs and weaponry through security with a 95% success rate.

site_title: Japan April core machinery orders up 3.8% m-o-m
summary: Japan's core machinery orders rose 3.8% in April from the previous month, surpassing economists' expectations of a 2.0% decrease. This marks the second consecutive month of growth, with orders increasing 2.9% in March. The data suggests capital expenditure is gaining strength, with orders rising 3.0% compared to the previous year's decline. The Cabinet Office has raised its assessment of machinery orders, indicating a recovery in the sector.

site_title: South Korea's Park postpones US trip as Mers cases rise
summary: South Korean President Park Geun Hye postponed a US trip to supervise the handling of the MERS outbreak, which has seen 2 additional deaths and 13 new cases, bringing the total to 108 patients. The outbreak has fueled public anxiety, with thousands in quarantine and schools closing. Park's office described the coming week as a "watershed" for the country's response to the disease, which has led to widespread anxiety and disruptions to daily life.

images.alt_text: South Korean President Park Geun Hye postponed a US visit on Wednesday to supervise the handling of an outbreak of Middle East Respiratory Syndrome (MERS), as two more people died and 13 new cases were reported, lifting the total number of patients to 108.

site_title: House passes bill curbing CFTC's power as Obama threatens veto
summary: The US House of Representatives passed a bill curbing the Commodity Futures Trading Commission's (CFTC) power, renewing its responsibilities while limiting its ability to regulate Wall Street banks' overseas trades. The measure, which Obama threatened to veto, would also require cost analysis of CFTC rules. The bill's passage sends it to the US Senate, where it needs at least six additional Republican votes to pass. The legislation aims to ease rules for agricultural and energy traders, but Democrats object to its potential impact on the agency's ability to police trading.

site_title: Taiwan: Stocks rebound; TSMC gains, HTC recovers
summary: Taiwan's stocks rebounded 1% on Wednesday, with TSMC leading the gain after the company's chairman expressed optimism for the second half of the year. HTC, a struggling smartphone maker, also recovered 1% after forecasting losses in the second quarter. Financial stocks and the Taiwan dollar also gained. The main TAIEX index rose to 9,283.76 points, ending its nearly five-month low.

site_title: 'Crazy' Auckland house prices leave central bank chief in a bind
summary: New Zealand's central bank governor, Graeme Wheeler, faces a dilemma in addressing near-zero inflation risks and stoking a housing bubble in Auckland. Mortgage broker John Bolton reports a surge in loan volumes since Wheeler's interest rate hint, with his business doubling since March. This boom highlights Wheeler's challenge in balancing economic stability with responding to market signals.

site_title: Australia consumer confidence falls sharply in June: survey
summary: Australia's consumer confidence fell sharply in June, with a 6.9% seasonally adjusted decline in a survey of 1,200 people. The index reading of 95.3 was the weakest since the start of the year, reversing May's 6.4% increase. Several factors, including falls in the share market and concerns about the economy, contributed to the decline. The Reserve Bank of Australia's latest rate cut did not have a lasting impact on consumer sentiment, and the government's budget was also cited as a factor. Consumer confidence is now at its lowest since the start of 2020.

site_title: FCL's Australand secures deals worth S$200m in Melbourne
summary: Frasers Centrepoint's Australand unit secured deals worth S$200 million in Melbourne's industrial space over the past six months. The latest deal involves a 90,000 sq m campus-style warehouse and office facility for CEVA Logistics at its West Park Industrial Estate. This follows previous deals totaling 200,000 sq m of industrial space, also valued at S$200 million. The news comes as Frasers Centrepoint shares closed at S$1.785 on Tuesday.

site_title: New effort to ease air travel anxiety: assuring your bag fits in bin
summary: The International Air Transport Association (IATA) has announced an "optimal size" standard for carry-on bags to ease air travel anxiety. The new size, 55cm by 35cm by 20cm, is slightly smaller than current standards and will be marked with an "IATA Cabin OK" tag. Airlines that sign on to the standard will guarantee that compliant bags can board the plane without questions. Several major airlines, including Azul, Lufthansa, Emirates, and Qatar Airways, have expressed interest in adopting the new standard, which is expected to become available this year.

site_title: US: Stocks little changed as GE sells finance assets
summary: US stocks finished little-changed on Tuesday, offsetting worries about spiking US treasury yields. General Electric's sale of finance assets to the Canada Pension Plan Investment Board for $12 billion boosted the Dow Jones Industrial Average. Despite this, the S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite Index remained stable, with the Nasdaq edging above its session lows. Market experts expressed concern over rising US treasury yields, which could impact stock performance.

site_title: Britain approves world's first tidal lagoon power project
summary: Britain has approved the world's first tidal lagoon power project in Wales, a 1 billion pound project capable of generating enough electricity to power 155,000 homes. The 9.5-km sea wall will capture tidal power, producing 320 megawatts of electricity. The project, developed by Tidal Lagoon Power, still needs government subsidy approval under the Contract for Difference scheme. The UK aims to cut emissions by 80% by 2050 and has embarked on electricity market reforms to spur low-carbon investment.

site_title: First Germanwings crash victims' bodies repatriated
summary: The first 44 bodies of victims from the Germanwings plane crash in the French Alps were repatriated to Germany on a Lufthansa cargo plane. The victims, mostly Germans, were among the 150 on board when the plane crashed on March 24. The remains were transported from Marseille to Duesseldorf, with the French prosecutor meeting with relatives to discuss identification and repatriation. The repatriation is part of a process that will see the transfer of the remaining victims to their home countries in the coming weeks, with Lufthansa working closely with relatives to ensure the transfer is carried out according to their wishes.

site_title: Oil prices surge ahead of US supply data
summary: Oil prices surged on Tuesday, with US benchmark West Texas Intermediate rising $2 to $60.14 a barrel and European benchmark Brent North Sea crude adding $2.19 to $64.88 a barrel. Analysts expect a lower US crude storage report, signaling a tighter market, and the US Department of Energy forecasted a decline in US oil production through early 2016. The rise is attributed to weak Chinese inflation data, which may prompt more monetary stimulus, and a lack of OPEC production cuts.

site_title: Europe: Shares hit 3-1/2-month low on US rate hike worries
summary: European shares hit a 3-1/2-month low on Tuesday, falling 0.4% to 1,522.29 points, amid concerns over a US rate hike cycle from September. The sell-off followed a decline in US and Asian shares, following stronger-than-expected US jobs data. Spain's Amadeus led the decline, while Deutsche Bank fell 2.5% after its offices were searched by German prosecutors. Negotiations between Greece and its creditors also sparked investor concern.

site_title: Microsoft beefs up Xbox ahead of major E3 event
summary: Microsoft has released an Xbox One console with 1TB of storage space, set to hit the market before the Electronic Entertainment Expo (E3) event. The new console, priced at $399, will appeal to players who prefer digital downloads over physical disks. The updated model features improved storage and a new controller. Microsoft also plans to release a $25 adapter allowing Xbox controllers to be used on Windows 10-powered PCs. The company promises a strong lineup of Xbox games at E3 next week, following rumors of a potential one-terabyte PlayStation 4 from Sony.

site_title: Dollar edges higher on euro
summary: The US dollar edged higher against the euro, reaching US$1.1280 per euro, as key labor market indicators and surging Treasury yields indicated strength in the greenback. A surge in job vacancies and hiring by small businesses in the US also pressured the Federal Reserve to raise interest rates. Despite hopes of a Greek bailout agreement, EU Vice President Valdis Dombrovskis urged Greece to focus on substance over tactics. The ten-year Treasury yield jumped to 2.44%, its highest level in eight months.

site_title: Turkey cabinet resigns after polls blow
summary: Turkey's ruling Justice and Development Party (AKP) has lost its parliamentary majority for the first time since 2002, leading to the resignation of the cabinet. President Recep Tayyip Erdogan has asked Prime Minister Ahmet Davutoglu to stay on until a new government is formed. A coalition government or snap elections are possible, with the opposition parties denouncing the AKP's failure. Erdogan has remained silent since the election, and the country faces uncertainty and potential unrest.

site_title: S&P lowers ratings of Barclays, Deutsche and RBS
summary: Standard & Poor's downgraded several major banks, including Deutsche Bank, Barclays, and Royal Bank of Scotland, citing uncertain government support. Deutsche Bank was downgraded to "BBB positive" and Barclays to "A negative", while Royal Bank of Scotland was downgraded to "stable". The agency attributed the downgrades to regulatory and legal issues affecting Deutsche Bank and tarnished image concerns. Ratings on Lloyds Bank and HSBC were affirmed, with stable outlooks. The downgrades come amid broader economic concerns, including China's slowing GDP growth and pressure on policymakers.

images.alt_text: Ratings agency Standard & Poor's downgraded several UK and German banks, including Deutsche Bank AG and Barclays Plc, saying it considers government support for these banks to be uncertain.

site_title: GM's Barra brushes off Fiat merger talk
summary: General Motors CEO Mary Barra dismissed talk of a merger with Fiat Chrysler Automobiles, saying the company has scale and can achieve growth through its own internal plan. Despite receiving an email from FCA head Sergio Marchionne proposing talks, Barra confirmed the proposal was vetted with management and the board. GM is open to partnerships with other automakers, but Barra emphasized the company's focus on its own strategy and generating returns for shareholders.

site_title: American Airlines, Qantas to launch US-Australia flights
summary: Qantas Airways Ltd and American Airlines Group Inc have announced a joint venture to launch direct flights from Los Angeles to Sydney and resume flights from Sydney to San Francisco, effective December 2015. The new flights will increase air capacity between Australia and the US by 9%. This marks a shift from their four-year-old joint venture to a revenue-sharing agreement, boosting travel options between the two countries.

images.alt_text: Qantas Airways Ltd and American Airlines Group Inc are stepping up their alliance, announcing on Tuesday that the US carrier will operate a direct flight from Los Angeles to Sydney for the first time.

site_title: Australia delves deeper into illegal home buying by foreigners
summary: Australia's Treasurer Joe Hockey is widening an investigation into 191 foreign property purchases that allegedly breached investment rules. The probe focuses on foreign buyers, particularly from China, who have contributed to the surge in residential real estate prices in cities like Sydney and Melbourne. The investigation aims to curb the influence of foreign investors in the Australian market.

site_title: EU parliament delays vote on US trade deal
summary: The European Parliament has delayed its vote on the Transatlantic Trade and Investment Partnership (TTIP) deal with the US due to disagreements over proposed amendments. The deal's dispute mechanism, which campaigners fear could allow companies to bypass national courts, was a major point of contention. Despite efforts to reach a compromise, the socialist group in the parliament insisted on excluding the mechanism, leading to the postponement of the vote. Hundreds of demonstrations against the deal were held across Europe in April, with leaders vowing to press through the agreement by next year.

site_title: Scrapping UK air travel tax would boost economy, airlines say
summary: British Airways and easyJet claim scrapping the UK's air travel tax could boost the economy by 1.7% by 2020, citing a study that found it would lift gross domestic product by 0.5% in the first year. The airlines, which have already benefited from a government concession on the tax, are calling on the government to abolish the tax entirely, arguing it would support tourism, investment, and business activity. The move comes ahead of finance minister George Osborne's budget in July and amid concerns of different APD regimes within the UK borders.

images.alt_text: Abolishing its tax on air travel could boost Britain's economy by 1.7 per cent by 2020, British Airways and easyJet said on Wednesday, calling on the government to go beyond recent concessions on the duty.

site_title: HSBC continues to wind back the clock
