summary: Hong Kong stocks opened marginally lower, edging down 20.40 points to 27,295.88, following losses on Wall Street due to the prospect of an early interest rate hike by the Federal Reserve.

site_title: HSBC to eliminate up to 50,000 jobs in Gulliver push to cut cost
summary: HSBC Holdings Plc plans to cut up to 50,000 jobs globally by 2017 as part of its strategy to reduce costs by $5 billion. The bank aims to cut 22,000-25,000 full-time employees, primarily in Europe, and sell its Turkey and Brazil operations. The move is part of CEO Stuart Gulliver's efforts to restore investor confidence and improve profitability. Gulliver has already announced over 87,000 job cuts since taking over in 2011, and the bank is targeting a return on equity of over 10% by 2017.

site_title: Hong Kong: Shares end at 2-month low amid policy uncertainty
summary: Hong Kong's Hang Seng index fell 1.2% to 26,989.52, its lowest close in two months, amid policy uncertainty and concerns over a possible US interest rate rise. Analysts attribute the market's weakness to a possible inclusion of mainland shares into MSCI's global indexes and reduced Hong Kong stock weightings. The China Enterprises Index also lost 1.8%. A plan for 2017 leaders to be elected by universal suffrage faces opposition from Hong Kong's democrats, while the territory's top newspaper, the People's Daily, supports a Beijing-proposed election blueprint.

site_title: Qatar fund buys $1.2 billion stake in Li's Hong Kong utility
summary: Qatar's sovereign wealth fund, Qatar Investment Authority, has agreed to pay HK$9.3 billion (S$1.62 billion) to acquire a 19.9% stake in Hong Kong utility HK Electric Investments & HK Electric Investments Ltd, controlled by Li Ka-shing. The deal, valued at $1.2 billion, allows Power Assets to retain control of the utility and pursue acquisitions. Qatar plans to invest up to $20 billion in Asia over the next five years and has set up a $10 billion investment venture with China's Citic Group.

site_title: Hong Kong to issue "red alert" travel alert to South Korea as Mers spreads
summary: Hong Kong is issuing a red alert travel warning to South Korea due to the Middle East Respiratory Syndrome (Mers) outbreak, which has reported 95 cases with seven fatalities. The alert advises people to adjust travel plans and avoid non-essential travel. The World Health Organization is reviewing South Korea's response to the outbreak, and thousands of tourists have cancelled plans to visit the country. The red alert follows a sharp drop in new cases reported on Tuesday, bringing the total to 95 with seven fatalities, and seven reported deaths.

site_title: Australia: Shares cautiously higher as banks find some reprieve
summary: Australian shares rose 0.2% to 5,509.3, rebounding from a four-month low, as banks showed some improvement. The S&P/ASX 200 index slid nearly 5% last week, its biggest weekly drop since May 2012. Despite this, Westpac and Commonwealth Bank shares climbed 1.1% and 0.5%, respectively. Meanwhile, Nine Entertainment's shares plummeted 15% after a profit warning, while New Zealand's benchmark NZX50 index eased 0.5%.

site_title: Fifa scandal: Australia denies it paid bribes in 2022 World Cup bid
summary: Australia's Football Federation chairman Frank Lowy denied the country paid bribes to secure its bid for the 2022 World Cup, which it ultimately lost to Qatar. Despite investing A$43 million, Australia secured only one vote. Lowy stated he "never stood a chance" in the bid and urged FIFA President Sepp Blatter to step aside due to the organization's corrupt culture. A police investigation is ongoing into corruption claims surrounding the issue, with Lowy sharing what he knows with authorities.

site_title: Indonesia central bank says rupiah won't be part of any global currency war
summary: Indonesia's central bank has stated that the rupiah will not be involved in a potential global currency war, despite being the worst-performing emerging Asian currency this year. The rupiah has lost 7.5% against the dollar year-to-date, with Bank Indonesia Governor Agus Martowardojo warning of a global currency war in the next three years due to rising US interest rates. The bank will maintain the exchange rate to reflect the fundamentals of the Southeast Asian economy, aiming to keep volatility within an acceptable range. The rupiah's value has reached 17-year lows.

site_title: Four people killed, five wounded in China "mass shooting": CCTV
summary: A mass shooting in China's Hebei province resulted in the deaths of four people, including two police officers, and injured five others. The 55-year-old suspect, who had a history of bipolar disorder, was among the victims. The attack occurred in a village early Tuesday morning. This incident is rare in China, where gun violence is uncommon due to strict firearm control laws. The case remains under investigation.

site_title: Banks sidestep negative rates in Europe with bond price buffers
summary: Europe's banks have sidestepped negative interest rates by issuing bonds with higher upfront costs. In the past six months, banks issued 5.1 billion euros of floating-rate notes priced at a premium, the highest since 2011. This allows them to keep interest payments above zero, avoiding time-consuming discussions with investors. The move follows the European Central Bank's efforts to stimulate the economy, which has led to record-low benchmark euro rates. By pricing bonds at a premium, banks can maintain profitability despite negative interest rates.

site_title: UBS transfers assets to Swiss unit to meet regulatory demands
summary: UBS plans to transfer assets and operations to a new Swiss unit on June 14 to meet regulatory demands, making the company easier to break up in a crisis. The Swiss unit, UBS Switzerland AG, will house the bank's retail, corporate, and wealth management businesses booked in Switzerland. The transfer aims to prevent UBS from needing another bailout, following a 2008 government bailout. The new structure will have joint liability for assets and obligations, and neither unit will bear liability for new obligations incurred after the asset transfer date.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open flat on Tuesday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index opened flat on Tuesday at 1737.53, down 0.77 points. Gainers outnumbered losers 82 to 67, with a trading volume of 36.4 million lots worth RM14.5 million.

site_title: PropertyGuru receives S$175m from TPG, Emtek, Square Peg
summary: PropertyGuru Group has received S$175 million from investors TPG, Emtek Group, and Square Peg Capital. Scout24, a minority shareholder, will exit to focus on its European businesses. The transaction is expected to close in mid-June. This funding will support PropertyGuru's growth, with the online portal drawing 11 million monthly consumer visits in Singapore, Thailand, and Indonesia. Representatives from the new investors will join the board of directors.

site_title: Modi's plan to wean India off gold: trading God's gift for cash
summary: India's Prime Minister Narendra Modi plans to encourage citizens to lend their gold to banks, which will then melt it down to boost domestic supply and curb the country's trade deficit. The gold, currently valued at about $360,000, will be offered to temples and homes in exchange for cash, with interest paid to the banks. The goal is to reduce India's reliance on imported gold, but critics argue that it will be a tough sell due to cultural and religious ties to the metal. The plan aims to increase the country's gold holdings, which are currently at 8,133.5 tons, but its success is uncertain.

site_title: Gold edges up on weaker dollar, but US rate outlook caps gains
summary: Gold prices rose 0.1% to $1,174.95 an ounce, driven by a weaker US dollar, but remained near an 11-week low due to concerns over a potential US interest rate hike. The metal had fallen to its lowest since March 19 after robust US payrolls data bolstered expectations of a rate rise. Uncertainty over the Greek debt crisis also provided some support, but investor positioning remained bearish, with holdings of gold-backed ETFs at their lowest since January.

site_title: Junma Tyre Cord to delist from Catalist on June 10
summary: Junma Tyre Cord Company will delist from the Catalist board at 9am on June 10, 2015, following an exit offer by Ultimative that was accepted by 7.96 million shares, representing 10.8% of the company's total shares. The offer price was 20 Singapore cents in cash.

images.alt_text: Angela Tan

site_title: Australia job vacancies flat in May: ANZ
summary: Australia's job vacancies remained flat in May, with 144,767 job advertisements per week on average, according to a survey by ANZ. Annual growth in ads increased to 14.1% from 7.3% in April. The official employment report for May is expected to show an increase of around 11,000, with the jobless rate remaining at 6.2%.

site_title: China's Industrial Bank cooperates with authorities on probe into illegal fund-raising
summary: China's Industrial Bank is cooperating with authorities on a probe into 3 billion yuan (S$654 million) allegedly raised illegally by a former employee, Su Yu, who deceived over 2,000 customers. Su, a former corporate finance account manager, is under investigation for raising funds without lending contracts. The bank's capital is not affected, and Su voluntarily resigned in March. The incident has raised concerns about China's banking regulations and the impact on customers.

site_title: Seoul: Shares barely move ahead of MSCI decision; won up
summary: Seoul shares remained steady on Tuesday, with the Korea Composite Stock Price Index (KOSPI) holding at 2,066.65 points. Market heavyweight Samsung Electronics fell 2.4% due to concerns over its earnings, while Hyundai Motor Co rose 0.4%. The MSCI decision on China shares, scheduled for later in the day, is expected to influence fund flows on the Seoul stock markets. The won edged up 0.3% against the dollar, despite dollar demand from local importers, following a broader weakening of the dollar.

site_title: Distrust between South Korea, Japan sky high: poll
summary: A record-high 73% of Japanese people and 85% of South Koreans express distrust in each other, according to a joint survey, amid bitter disputes over historical grievances and territory. Only 4% of South Koreans believe Japanese prime ministerial apologies are enough, while 94% say they are not. Japan views South Korea's demands for repeated apologies as an attempt to bolster their own popularity, while Seoul insists the window for genuine contrition is closing. Relations between the two countries remain strained, with 61% of Japanese and 74% of South Koreans believing their countries' current "bad relationship" is inevitable.

images.alt_text: Former South Korean Foreign Minister Yu Myung-hwan (right) and former Japanese Chief Cabinet Secretary Takeo Kawamura hold a joint press conference at a Seoul hotel, South Korea, on June 1, 2015.

site_title: Coffee farmers in Vietnam hoarding most robusta since 2010
summary: Vietnamese coffee farmers are holding the largest unsold robusta inventory in at least five years, with 35% of this year's 1.56 million metric tons output stockpiled as of May. The surplus is due to low local prices, which have fallen to a 16-month low, and farmers preferring to hold back sales. This may reduce the impact of El Nino's expected impact on the next harvest, which is forecast to reach 1.72 million tons, matching the record in 2013-2014.

site_title: Not seen since 1997: El Nino event strengthens, Australia says
summary: Australia's Bureau of Meteorology reports that the El Nino event is strengthening, with sea-surface temperatures exceeding thresholds for the remainder of the year. The current event bears similarities to the 1997-1998 El Nino, the strongest on record, which caused severe weather patterns in Asia, crimped hurricane seasons, and brought cooler summers to the US. All five Nino indices are at least plus 1.2 degrees Celsius above-normal, a pattern not seen since 1997-1998.

images.alt_text: The El Nino developing in the Pacific keeps sending signs reminiscent of the most severe event in 1997-1998, according to Australia's Bureau of Meteorology, which said recent data point toward a pattern that'll last all year.

site_title: HSBC to cut as many as 25,000 jobs as Gulliver tackles costs
summary: HSBC plans to cut up to 25,000 jobs, approximately 10% of its staff, through 2017 as part of its cost-cutting efforts. The bank aims to achieve annual cost savings of $4.5 billion to $5 billion by 2017, while also selling businesses in Turkey and Brazil. This move comes as CEO Stuart Gulliver seeks to reverse profit declines and improve the bank's financial performance.

images.alt_text: HSBC Holdings Plc will eliminate as many as 25,000 jobs in cost-cutting through 2017 as Chief Executive Officer Stuart Gulliver seeks to reverse profit declines.

site_title: HSBC lowers return targets, to shrink asset base by US$290 billion
summary: HSBC announced plans to reduce its asset base by $290 billion, sell units in Brazil and Turkey, and shrink its investment bank to cut costs and improve performance. The bank aims to shrink its global banking and markets division to less than one-third of its $2.6 billion balance sheet. HSBC also lowered its return on equity target to greater than 10% by 2017, down from 12-15% by 2016. The move is part of the bank's second major strategic plan under CEO Stuart Gulliver.

site_title: Non-landed private home resale prices flat in May: SRX
summary: Resale prices for Singapore non-landed private residences remained flat in May at 167.3, unchanged from April and down 2.8% year-on-year. Volumes increased 4.2% from April and 33.1% from the year-ago volume. Core central region prices fell 1.2% month-on-month, while the rest of central region and outside central region saw price increases of 0.8% and 0.3%, respectively.

site_title: Australia business confidence rises to 9-mth high: NAB
summary: Australia's business confidence rose to a nine-month high in May, according to National Australia Bank's survey, driven by improved sales and profits. The index of business conditions rose 3 points to +7, and business confidence climbed 4 points to +7, its highest reading since August last year. The improvement was attributed to record-low interest rates and a well-received government budget. This boost in confidence is welcomed by the Reserve Bank of Australia, which has been seeking signs of business "animal spirits."

site_title: Singapore's WorkRight programme wins UN Public Service Award
summary: Singapore's WorkRight programme, launched in 2012, has won the UN Public Service Award for promoting whole-of-government approaches in the Asia-Pacific. The initiative, involving the government, unions, businesses, and community groups, has benefited over 42,000 workers, with compliance rates increasing to nine out of 10 in sectors such as food and beverage and retail. Minister for Manpower Lim Swee Say credited the programme's success to collaborative efforts and vowed to continue improving service delivery and public engagement. The programme aims to ensure workers, especially lower-wage employees, enjoy their basic employment rights.

site_title: Taiwan: Stocks fall; HTC slumps 10% again
summary: Taiwan's stocks fell 0.5% on Tuesday, with HTC Corp experiencing a 10% drop, its second consecutive day of decline, due to a loss forecast for the second quarter. The TAIEX index slid to 9,320.00 points. The Taiwan dollar rose 0.655% to T$31.070 to the US dollar. This decline follows HTC's previous 20% drop this week, amidst concerns over the struggling smartphone maker's financial performance.

site_title: Diamond industry unites to match 20th century's best ad line
summary: The diamond industry has formed the Diamond Producers Association to promote diamonds as the ultimate luxury and expression of romance, targeting millennials as they continue to see diamonds as a symbol of love. The association aims to increase demand for diamonds in the US market, which is under pressure from growing demand for other luxury goods. With a $18 million budget, the association will focus on advertising to younger demographics, expecting significant growth as more industry players contribute. The move aims to revive diamonds as a symbol of luxury and romance.

images.alt_text: Challenged by Michael Kors handbags, iPads and vintage Bordeaux, gem producers including De Beers, Rio Tinto Group and Russia's OAO Alrosa last month formed the Diamond Producers Association to ensure a new generation views the jewels as the ultimate luxury and expression of romance.

site_title: Singapore shares slip 0.1% at open; Jardine group eases
summary: Singapore shares opened 0.1% lower, with the Straits Times Index down 4.08 points to 3,316.25, following overnight US market declines. The Jardine group of companies, including Jardine Matheson Holdings and Jardine Strategic Holdings, were lower, dragging the index down. Losers outnumbered gainers 67 to 59, with about 62 million shares changing hands.

site_title: Asia: Markets mostly down, euro picks up
summary: Asian markets declined Tuesday, with Shanghai and Hong Kong experiencing losses, while Tokyo slipped 0.70% due to a yen pickup. The euro gained support from upbeat German trade data, which showed a widening trade surplus. US markets also fell, with the Dow, S&P 500, and Nasdaq losing ground. China's consumer price index fell to 1.2% in May, raising concerns about deflation. The euro remains fragile due to stalled debt reform talks between Greece and its creditors.

site_title: Qatar Airways CEO sees no need for concessions to US airlines
summary: Qatar Airways CEO Akbar Al Baker stated that Middle Eastern governments have no reason to make concessions to US airlines amid allegations of unfair competition from Gulf carriers. He referenced an agreement between mature governments, which is being implemented, and expressed confidence in Qatar Airways' ability to compete.

site_title: Dollar steadies after pullback against euro
summary: The US dollar steadied against major counterparts after a sharp drop against the euro due to solid German data and higher Bund yields. The euro fell 0.1% to US$1.1281, while the dollar index remained steady at 95.289. Greek officials met with EU Economics Commissioner Pierre Moscovici, but no new proposal was agreed upon. The euro's rise was capped due to Greece's small influence on the eurozone economy. The dollar edged up 0.1% to 124.65 yen, despite expectations of a potential US interest rate hike in September.

site_title: China to have 'veto power' over infrastructure bank: report
summary: China will have "veto power" over major decisions of the Asian Infrastructure Investment Bank (AIIB), with its largest shareholder status granting it control over the voting structure. The AIIB, led by Beijing, has 57 prospective members, excluding the US and Japan, which have declined to join. This arrangement effectively gives China significant influence over the bank's major decisions, despite its relatively small economic size compared to the US and Japan.

images.alt_text: China's President Xi Jinping (front, centre) guides guests at the Asian Infrastructure Investment Bank launch ceremony at the Great Hall of the People in Beijing in this Oct 24, 2014, file photo.

site_title: Oil prices rise on hopes for China stimulus
summary: Oil prices rose on Tuesday on hopes for economic stimulus in China, with front-month US crude climbing 31 cents to $58.45 a barrel and Brent rising 24 cents to $62.93 a barrel. China's consumer inflation weakened to 1.2% year-on-year in May, raising concerns about deflationary pressures. Meanwhile, OPEC agreed to maintain unconstrained output, and Iran is expected to increase oil exports if sanctions are lifted. Oil production declines from major US shale plays are forecast to deepen, while investors are monitoring supply and demand.

site_title: Stocks to watch: Sinarmas Land, SGX, Linc Energy
summary: Sinarmas Land agreed to take a strategic stake in KaiLong China Real Estate Investment Trust, a first Chinese Reit to be listed in Singapore. Singapore Exchange (SGX) named Loh Boon Chye as its next CEO, replacing Magnus Bocker on June 30. Linc Energy made changes to its board of directors, including appointing Ong Tiong Soon as non-executive director and reducing salaries by 20% for a year.

site_title: Most Chinese stocks fall amid prices data as MSCI decision looms
summary: Most Chinese stocks fell due to weaker-than-expected inflation data, with the Shanghai Composite Index slipping 0.5% to 5,106.37. Material and industrial companies declined, led by Aluminum Corp of China Ltd and China Railway Construction Corp. The consumer-price index rose 1.2% and the producer-price index fell 4.6%, exceeding forecasts. MSCI is set to decide on Tuesday whether to add mainland securities to its global indexes, weighing on traders' sentiment.

site_title: Linc names new director, cuts directors' pay
summary: Linc Energy has appointed Genting Bhd's energy chief executive Ong Tiong Soon as non-executive director, while the company's chairman, CEO, and other non-executive directors have agreed to a 20% reduction in their salaries for a year starting July 1. The pay cut will be reviewed after a year. Additionally, the company has decided to merge its nominating and remuneration committees from July 1.

site_title: Compensation fund for Bangladesh factory victims reaches US$30m target
summary: A compensation fund for Bangladesh factory victims has reached its US$30-million target, exceeding the initial estimate by $3 million. The fund was established after the 2013 Rana Plaza factory collapse, which killed over 1,100 garment workers and injured 1,500 others. The fund has secured all funding, and the last families awaiting payment will receive their money in the coming weeks. The milestone was welcomed by the International Labour Organisation, which chairs the Rana Plaza Coordination Committee, and calls for further action to prevent similar accidents and establish a national employment injury insurance scheme.

site_title: South Korea's May department store sales at 3-month high, Mers a worry
summary: South Korea's department store sales rose 3.6% in May, the highest in three months, driven by private consumption growth. However, the government is concerned about the recent outbreak of the Mers virus, which threatens the country's economic recovery. Sales at major discount stores rebounded 0.3% in May, while the finance ministry plans to stabilize markets in case of external shocks. The government has also confirmed 95 cases of Mers, with 8 new cases reported, and will "aggressively respond" to counter the economic impact of the virus.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open 0.80% lower
summary: Tokyo stocks opened 0.80% lower on Tuesday, following a negative lead from Wall Street, where US stocks dropped due to large declines in technology and airline shares. The Dow Jones Industrial Average fell 0.46%, while the S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite Index fell 0.65% and 0.92%, respectively. The stronger yen also weighed on the market. Investors continue to monitor the US Federal Reserve's interest rate hike plans and the Greek debt situation.

site_title: Nasa tests 'flying saucer' device for future Mars landings
summary: NASA successfully tested a "flying saucer" device, known as the Low-Density Supersonic Decelerator, to aid in future Mars landings. The 3,088kg device, attached to a helium balloon, reached supersonic speeds before deploying a 30m-diameter parachute to slow its descent. The test, the second of its kind, aims to develop technology for landing heavier spacecraft on Mars, potentially enabling human missions in the 2030s. The parachute successfully slowed the entry vehicle, achieving the desired subsonic speeds, paving the way for more advanced Mars landing technologies.

site_title: HSBC boss prepares to axe jobs, businesses in strategy refresh
summary: HSBC is set to cut thousands of staff, exit businesses in Brazil and Turkey, and shrink its investment bank as part of its second major strategic plan. CEO Stuart Gulliver aims to simplify the bank and improve financial performance. The measures could see over 10,000 jobs lost, with restructuring planned for the US and Mexico. The bank may also consider moving its headquarters from London to Asia and separating its UK retail banking operation. The move aims to address the bank's complexity and compliance issues following a series of scandals.

site_title: Malaysia Air CEO shuns 'terminator' label amid turnaround push
summary: Malaysia Airlines CEO Christoph Mueller is pushing for a turnaround, eliminating about 6,000 jobs and restructuring efforts to restore profit. He aims to create 12 subsidiaries and target break-even results by 2018, with a 20% cost reduction. Mueller, dubbed "The Terminator" by the media, disputes the nickname, saying it's "totally made up." He expects revenue to recover in at least a year and plans to make temporary contracts permanent if the turnaround is successful.

site_title: Alibaba's Jack Ma visits US to lure businesses into China
summary: Alibaba Chairman Jack Ma visits the US to lure businesses into China, seeking to increase revenue beyond the country's slowing economy. Ma aims to position Alibaba as a cross-border e-commerce solution, enabling China's 557 million internet users to buy from anywhere in the world. He plans to meet with US business leaders and entrepreneurs to promote cross-border sales and exports to China, with a goal of raising international revenue to 50% of the company's total revenue. This visit coincides with new policies and successful trial programs on Alibaba's platforms, competing with Amazon and JD.com to introduce Western brands into China.

site_title: Obama tells Greeks it's time to make tough decisions
summary: US President Barack Obama urged Greeks to make tough decisions to resolve their economic crisis, warning that a default could trigger a messy euro exit. Obama emphasized the need for Athens to implement reforms and for creditors to show flexibility. German Chancellor Angela Merkel and French President Francois Hollande also urged Greece to speed up talks on a loan deal. The Greek government, led by Prime Minister Alexis Tsipras, remains committed to reaching an agreement despite disagreements with creditors.

site_title: US$ retreats after near 13-year high against yen
summary: The US dollar retreated from near 13-year highs against the yen after a Bloomberg report quoted an unnamed French official as saying US President Barack Obama was uncomfortable with the strong dollar. This prompted some traders to trim their bets on the greenback. The report came ahead of the second day of the G-7 summit, where French President Francois Hollande met with a group of French reporters. The dollar's decline followed a media report that a strong dollar was a problem, according to the French official.

site_title: UBS boss says negative interest rates a major challenge
summary: UBS chairman Axel Weber stated that negative interest rates pose a significant challenge to Swiss banks, particularly in defending profit margins. Introduced in January, the rates have forced banks to adjust their wealth management strategies, including longer-term investments. The Swiss National Bank's decision to lower interest rates further aims to curb the strong franc, but has led to institutional investors seeking alternative investments, including higher-risk options. Despite this, the Swiss financial sector remains active, with 300 banks remaining operational, according to Finma.

site_title: 'Flying has never been safer,' says air industry chief
summary: Air industry chief Tony Tyler says flying is safer than ever, with a rate of one jet hull loss for every 4.4 million flights in 2014. Despite recent disasters, including Malaysia Airlines flights 370 and 17, and Germanwings 9525, Tyler attributes the decline in aviation safety to improved tracking standards, emerging technology, and proposed new practices. The industry is working to ensure that civilian aircraft are not targeted by weapons of war and to better share security information.

site_title: US Army website hacked: officials
summary: The US Army's official website was hacked on Monday, with hackers posting messages criticizing the training of rebel fighters in Syria. The website was temporarily shut down, but no sensitive data was stolen. The messages, which included claims that commanders admit to sending soldiers to die, were deemed non-credible by officials. The Army cited the website's design as a factor in the vulnerability, stating it does not contain classified or personal data.

site_title: South Korea reports 8 more Mers cases, seventh death in outbreak
summary: South Korea reported 8 new Mers cases, bringing the total to 95, with a 7th death confirmed. The cases are mainly from healthcare facilities, with 37 out of 95 cases reported at one hospital. Authorities have put 2,500 people under quarantine, tracking those who violate quarantine using mobile phones. Globally, the Mers outbreak has reached 1,244 cases with 446 related deaths. South Korea's President Park Geun-hye has called for a national effort to eradicate the outbreak, which has been spreading since May.

site_title: Top Chinese officer pays visit to US: Pentagon
summary: Top Chinese General General Fan Changlong began a six-day US visit, starting in San Diego, amid rising tensions over the South China Sea. He met with US Defence Secretary Ashton Carter at the Pentagon on Thursday, following stops at the USS Ronald Reagan aircraft carrier and US Army bases in Texas. The visit aims to build a dialogue between the US and Chinese armed forces to defuse tensions. The visit comes after US officials criticized China's land reclamation efforts in the disputed waters, with Defence Secretary Carter calling for an immediate end to such activities.

site_title: Apple aims to become online music powerhouse
summary: Apple has launched its new music streaming service, Apple Music, which will allow users to stream songs, listen to playlists, and connect with performers. The service, available for $9.99/month or $14.99 for up to six people, will initially be available to Apple device users and later to Android users. The service includes a live radio station, curated playlists, and a social music network, and is seen as a major rival to online services like Spotify and Pandora.

site_title: UK retail sales recover in May, helped by housing market
summary: UK retail sales rose 1.1% in May compared to the same month last year, driven by a recovery in the housing market. Furniture sales were the strongest since July 2023, while clothing and footwear sales fell due to cool weather. Food sales stabilized after a weak six-month period. On a like-for-like basis, retail spending remained unchanged in May, despite a 2.4% annual fall in April. The recovery in the housing market is expected to continue, supporting consumer spending.

site_title: Iceland moves on capital controls, to tax money outflows
summary: Iceland has proposed a 39% tax on creditors who want to withdraw assets from the country's banks, a step towards lifting capital controls and rejoining the international financial community. The tax is conditional on creditors meeting "stability" conditions by the end of the year. This move aims to compensate the state for the 2008 financial meltdown, which left Iceland facing significant economic hardship and billions of dollars in debt for European countries. The government's plan marks a key step in Iceland's recovery.

site_title: It's time to wake Chemical Industries from its long slumber
summary: Chemical Industries (Far East) is a Singapore Exchange-listed company with a core business in industrial chemicals and valuable properties. However, it has been undervalued, making it a "value trap." The company's management is criticized for not maximizing shareholder value, prompting the author, a long-time shareholder, to attend the upcoming Annual General Meeting (AGM) to raise concerns and ask questions. The author hopes to bring attention to the company's issues and encourage other shareholders to attend the AGM.

site_title: Oil prices dip as market weighs Opec, Iran talks
summary: Oil prices fell on Monday as investors weighed the outcome of last week's Opec meeting and the prospects for a breakthrough in nuclear talks with Iran. US benchmark West Texas Intermediate dropped 99 cents to $58.14 a barrel, while European benchmark Brent oil lost 62 cents to $62.69 a barrel. Analysts expect oil prices to remain stuck in a range of $55-$63 a barrel until a clearer catalyst emerges, such as a surprise drop in oil production or major progress on Iran. A potential deal to curb Iran's nuclear ambitions could trigger downward movement of crude prices.

images.alt_text: Oil prices fell on Monday as the market weighed last week's Opec meeting and the prospects for a breakthrough in upcoming nuclear talks with Iran.

site_title: Swiss government defends central bank against currency complaints
summary: The Swiss government defended the central bank against criticism that it has failed to shield the economy from the surge in the value of the franc currency. Economy Minister Johann Schneider-Ammann stated that the Swiss National Bank's autonomy in setting monetary policy is beyond question, and the government will not interfere. The SNB has been criticized for its decision to stop defending the franc cap, which has led to a decline in Swiss exports and job losses. Schneider-Ammann acknowledged intense debates with the SNB but emphasized the bank's independence and commitment to safeguarding the economy.

site_title: China rail merger forges industrial giant second only to GE
summary: China has formed the world's second-largest industrial company, CRRC Corp, through the merger of state-owned rail equipment makers CSR Corp and China CNR Corp. The $130 billion company aims to compete with global giants like GE and Siemens, targeting emerging markets and high-profile contracts in the developed world. With its massive scale and government backing, CRRC is set to project China's political influence abroad, potentially disrupting the global rail industry.

site_title: Dalian Wanda to launch crowdfunding for malls
summary: Dalian Wanda Group, China's largest commercial property developer, plans to launch a crowdfunding initiative to finance its new shopping malls, aiming to raise "at least several billion yuan" with investors receiving 12% annualized returns. This is part of the company's "asset-light" strategy, seeking outside investment and selling malls after 5-7 years. The crowdfunding product has a 1,000 yuan investment threshold, making it accessible to a wide range of investors. This move follows other Chinese developers tapping into internet financing, amid a sluggish property market.

site_title: Chinese deferring car purchases for stocks
summary: Chinese consumers, such as Tom Zhang, are deferring car purchases to invest in the stock market, which has more than doubled in value over the past year. This trend is slowing car demand in China, the world's largest market, with sales rising at the slowest pace in over two years. Carmakers, including General Motors and Volkswagen, have cut prices to encourage sales, but investors remain focused on the stock market, with the industry unlikely to recover until the market "gets back to its senses".

site_title: Jobs outlook better elsewhere in region than S'pore
summary: The job outlook in Singapore for the next three months is relatively stable, with a net employment outlook of 13%, slightly better than Australia and New Zealand. However, employers remain cautious about hiring due to economic uncertainty. The services sector is expected to see the strongest job growth, with a net employment outlook of 24%, followed by finance and real estate. Manufacturing is expected to underperform, with a net employment outlook of 11%. The wholesale trade and retail trade sectors are tipped for a decline in jobs, with a net employment outlook of minus 1%.

site_title: US: Tech shares, airlines lead US stocks lower
summary: US stocks declined on Monday, led by technology shares and airline stocks. The Dow Jones Industrial Average fell 82.91 points (0.46%) to 17,766.55, while the S&P 500 dropped 13.55 (0.65%) to 2,079.28. The Nasdaq Composite Index fell 46.83 (0.92%) to 5,021.63. The declines were attributed to a weak market open, with investors awaiting the US Federal Reserve's decision on monetary policy.

site_title: Airbus faces A380 sales snag as used planes hit the market
summary: Airbus faces a sales challenge for its A380 superjumbo, with used planes hitting the market. The company needs to sell around 30 A380s annually to break even, but has not won a new customer in almost three years. Used A380s, which can be purchased at a fraction of the plane's list price, are likely to attract customers who would otherwise opt for smaller planes like the Boeing 777. The lack of new sales could lead to empty production slots for Airbus from 2018.

site_title: Europe: Stocks fall; Turkish market plunges
summary: European stocks fell on Monday, with the CAC 40 in Paris losing 1.28% and Frankfurt's DAX 30 dropping 1.18%. The euro rose to $1.1214 against the dollar, while the Turkish lira plunged to a record low against the dollar due to political and economic uncertainty in Turkey. Greece's debt talks with the EU continued, with investors awaiting a deal to secure $10.8 billion in aid. The US dollar rallied ahead of the weekend, leading to profit taking and lower stock prices, including the Dow Jones Industrial Average and S&P 500.

site_title: South Korea govt ready to counter economic impact of Mers
summary: South Korea's government is prepared to counter the economic impact of the Middle East Respiratory Syndrome (Mers) outbreak, with President Park Geun-hye and Finance Minister Choi Kyung-hwan expressing concerns over private consumption and investment sentiment. The government plans to take swift measures, including monetary and fiscal stimulus, to mitigate the effects of the outbreak, which has resulted in 87 infections and six deaths. A funding package worth 84.1 billion won for small-to-medium-sized businesses in Gyeonggi Province has also been announced.

site_title: New UK code will hold bankers to account for misconduct
summary: UK Chancellor George Osborne and Bank of England Governor Mark Carney are set to unveil the Fair and Effective Markets Review, a new regulatory framework aimed at holding bankers accountable for misconduct. The review will introduce rules on pay, management structures, and boards, and is expected to extend to asset managers and investment funds. The move is seen as a shift towards personal accountability and is part of a broader regulatory overhaul. The review is due to be released on Wednesday and is expected to have significant implications for the financial industry.

site_title: German exports, industrial output up in April
summary: Germany's exports and industrial output rose more sharply than expected in April, with exports increasing 1.9% and industrial production rising 0.9%. This data suggests a strong start to the second quarter, with the country's trade surplus widening to 22.3 billion euros. The boost is attributed to a recovery in the euro area and accelerating growth at home, benefiting German manufacturers. This news follows the Bundesbank's forecast boost for the domestic economy and counters the Organisation for Economic Cooperation and Development's reduced world growth outlook.

site_title: Greece willing to compromise with EU, IMF
summary: Greece is willing to compromise with its EU-IMF creditors to reach a deal acceptable to both sides. The government, led by Prime Minister Alexis Tsipras, is open to negotiations until the end of June to secure a bailout extension and release remaining funds. Despite initial rejection of creditors' terms, the Greek government is willing to make concessions, and Finance Minister Yanis Varoufakis has called for an end to finger-pointing in debt talks. A deal is seen as crucial to meet debt repayments by the end of June.

site_title: HackerOne proves hackers are not all bad
summary: HackerOne, a San Francisco-based tech startup, is changing the way hackers report security flaws by turning vulnerability hunting into a legitimate, lucrative venture. The company connects "white hat" hackers with companies willing to pay a bounty for their finds, rather than exploiting them. Since its founding in 2011, HackerOne has persuaded major tech companies like Yahoo, Square, and Twitter to work with its service, and has convinced venture capitalists of its potential for profitability. The company aims to persuade hackers to responsibly report security flaws, rather than selling them to criminals or governments, and has already convinced some companies to adopt its moderated bug bounty programs.

site_title: Leadership lessons from fairy tales
summary: Leadership lessons can be found in fairy tales, which teach executives about universal truths of human behavior and illustrate the dangers of leadership. Fairy tales help children navigate reality and survive in a world full of ambiguities and dangers. Executives can learn from the hero's journey, where protagonists face challenges and develop their potential, and from stories like "The Emperor's New Clothes" and "Snow White," which highlight the dangers of hubris and generational envy. By analyzing fairy tales, leaders can recognize the five deadly dangers of leadership: lack of self-knowledge, hubris, inability to get the best out of people, inability to create well-functioning teams, and creating an organisational gulag.

site_title: Blackstone targets Brazil buys as property values tumble
summary: Blackstone Group LP is expanding its presence in Brazil's real estate market, targeting the country's struggling property values. The US-based firm, which has tripled its money on big US real estate bets, is opening a Sao Paulo office and investing in a new global real estate fund of over $15 billion. Blackstone is joining forces with Brookfield Asset Management and JPMorgan Chase to take advantage of attractive prices in a market hit by a corruption scandal and recession. Property values have dropped 20% in parts of Sao Paulo, with a glut of empty buildings and falling rents.

site_title: Clinton downplays personal ties in discussing US overdose deaths
summary: Hillary Clinton has downplayed her personal ties to addressing the US overdose death epidemic, stating she's "surprised" to be discussing the issue. Prescription painkiller overdoses kill an average of 44 people daily, according to the federal government. Clinton's remarks come as several presidential rivals plan to address the issue if elected in November 2016.

site_title: Amazon, Google race to get DNA into the cloud
summary: Amazon and Google are racing to store and analyze human DNA data in the cloud, with the potential to revolutionize personalized medicine. The cloud computing market for genomics is expected to grow to $1 billion by 2018, driven by the need for large datasets to identify genetic responses to treatments. Both companies are offering analytical functions to help scientists make sense of DNA data, with Amazon charging around $4-5 per month to store one full human genome and Google charging around $3-5 per month. The cloud services are also pitched as more secure and cost-effective than on-premises solutions.

site_title: Vogue editor Wintour helps Tony stars scorch the red carpet
summary: Vogue editor Anna Wintour helped Tony Award stars shine on the red carpet, a year after criticizing the event's fashion. Nominees showcased diverse outfits, including Elisabeth Moss's bold, sleeveless Oscar de la Renta gown with colorful embroidery. Hemlines and colors varied, with metallics and floral fabrics also present. The event aimed to elevate the Tony Awards' fashion standards, with Wintour's guidance.

site_title: Bond market playing a risky game over Fed rate rise bets
summary: Investors in the global bond market are taking a riskier stance on the Federal Reserve's potential interest rate hikes, downplaying the likelihood of a quick rate rise despite the potential for significant losses for bondholders. Despite a stronger-than-expected jobs report, analysts and investors are betting the Fed will keep rates low to avoid harming the economy. Yields on US 10-year Treasuries have surged, but many forecasters still expect rates to remain low, with some predicting they won't exceed 1.25% by the end of 2016.

site_title: BlackRock puts Asia Square's Tower 1 up for sale
summary: BlackRock is selling Asia Square Tower 1 in Singapore for S$4 billion, or S$3,200 per square foot of net lettable area. The 43-storey tower has 1.2 million square feet of offices and 40,000 sq ft of retail space. BlackRock is also open to selling the rest of its space in the Asia Square development, worth S$2.5 billion, if the sale of Tower 1 is unsuccessful. The sale is expected to be concluded by the end of the year.

images.alt_text: Kalpana Rashiwala

site_title: Dutch central bank sees output back to pre-crisis levels in '15
summary: The Dutch central bank revised its economic growth forecasts, predicting output will return to pre-crisis levels by the end of 2015 in real terms. Domestic consumption is expected to grow substantially for the first time since the 2008 credit crisis, driven by exports. This marks a significant improvement from previous years of sluggish growth.

site_title: Brokers' take
summary: Brokerages assess Singapore stocks after recent market fluctuations. Ezra Holdings' rights issue is seen as a potential buying opportunity, with a target price of S$0.34. Lippo Malls Indonesia Retail Trust is recommended to hold due to solid retail sales momentum in Indonesia. City Developments (CDL) is a buy, despite a potential downward bias following its removal from the FTSE EPRA/NAREIT Global Real Estate Index Series.

site_title: Singapore's productivity imperative: The three missing pieces
summary: Singapore's productivity growth has slowed, with the country needing to increase output per worker by 2.6 times faster than its historical pace to maintain its economic growth. To achieve this, the government must focus on three key areas: improving managerial quality, supporting behavioural change, and ensuring vigorous competition in domestic sectors. Currently, Singaporean firms perform well in some areas but lag behind multinational firms and struggle with poor management and inefficient business practices. A more comprehensive approach to productivity improvement is necessary to maintain Singapore's economic success and avoid a slowdown.

site_title: Turkey investors take fright at post-poll uncertainty
summary: Turkish investors are on edge following the country's legislative elections, with shares plummeting 6.2% and the lira hitting a record low against the dollar. The Justice and Development Party (AKP) won the most votes but fell short of a majority, creating uncertainty about the formation of a new government. The central bank intervened, reducing interest rates to alleviate the lira's depreciation. Analysts predict a prolonged period of political uncertainty, with possible outcomes including a coalition, early elections, or a minority government, which may impact the country's economic stability.

images.alt_text: The AKP won the biggest portion of the vote in Sunday's legislative poll but came well short of a parliamentary absolute majority.

site_title: The evolution of oil as a weapon
summary: The US has been employing financial warfare as a weapon, particularly targeting countries reliant on oil exports. The practice began in 1965 with Egypt's nationalization of the Suez Canal, leading to a US-Saudi alliance to secure a steady oil supply. This agreement, made in 1976, ensured the US would receive unlimited oil at discounted prices in exchange for protection from rival countries and a guarantee of Saudi oil fields' security. The US and Saudi Arabia have since used financial sanctions to influence global events, including the collapse of the USSR in the 1980s, and have continued to employ this tactic against countries like Iran and Russia.

site_title: New CEO of Deutsche Bank has to make his mark this month
summary: Deutsche Bank's new CEO, John Cryan, will have to make his mark within days of taking the role. Cryan, a 54-year-old Briton, previously worked at UBS as head of global financial institutions advisory group and chief financial officer of the Swiss bank during the 2008 financial crisis. His appointment comes as he will be putting his ideas into practice, with the global banking landscape facing pressure from policymakers and economic uncertainty. Cryan's strategy will be crucial in navigating the challenges facing the industry.

site_title: Striving for Digital Organisation 4.0
summary: Companies must adopt digital technology to stay ahead, with 75% of executives having a digital strategy but only 15% believing they have the capabilities to implement it. A digital transformation is likely to be a phased process for non-technology industries, and effective leadership, including a chief digital officer, is crucial for innovation and cross-functional collaborations. The impact of digital technology will continue to grow, with 30% of companies having successful leadership factors and 70% having a dedicated CDO, and new roles like the chief connectivity officer may emerge to optimize productivity and connectivity.

site_title: Guangzhou eases home downpayment rules
summary: Guangzhou, China has relaxed downpayment rules for first and second homebuyers, reducing the downpayment ratio for apartments under 144 square meters to 20% and 30% respectively. This move aims to stimulate the local housing market, which has been recovering slowly. The city also eased mortgage borrowing rules for non-permanent residents, making it cheaper to borrow loans. The move is expected to help stabilize and improve the property market, which has been a drag on the broader economy.

site_title: Japan's Q1 growth revised to 3.9% on increased capex
summary: Japan's gross domestic product (GDP) expanded 3.9% in the first quarter, exceeding initial estimates of 2.4%, driven by increased corporate capital investment. The upgrade suggests economic revival, but concerns over rising import costs and potential backlash in currency markets temper optimism. Despite strong business investment, private consumption remains cautious due to sluggish wage growth, with some economists predicting GDP growth may slow to 1.7% in the next quarter.

site_title: Oil prices not as well-anchored as Opec claims
summary: OPEC ministers claimed their strategy to stabilize oil prices is working, but uncertainties have grown, including US oil industry performance, Iran's return to oil markets, China's demand growth, and a possible return of a political oil risk premium. The US oil industry's response to declining prices has been mixed, with some predicting a deep production decline and others suggesting it will continue to adapt to lower prices. Additionally, China's demand growth and Iran's potential return to the market pose significant risks to OPEC's efforts to stabilize prices.

site_title: Financial market risks rising, spreading, says IMF deputy MD
summary: IMF deputy MD Mitsuhiro Furusawa warns of growing financial market risks, including "fire sales" of assets and contagion, as monetary policy normalizes in the US and elsewhere. He notes asynchronous monetary policies have spurred dollar appreciation, volatility, and capital outflows, potentially triggering disorderly rebalancing of investment portfolios. The risk of negative spillovers and contagion is higher due to increased correlation among asset classes, with emerging markets particularly vulnerable to potential shocks.

site_title: Spackman diversifies into variety show production
summary: Spackman Entertainment Group, a CATALIST-listed company, has acquired a majority stake in Delmedia, a Korean variety show production company, for US$1.48 million. Spackman's associated company, Spackman Media Group (SMG), acquired 88.89% of Delmedia's shares through a share subscription agreement. This move expands Spackman's presence in the variety show production sector. The deal was funded by proceeds from a recent share placement and capital injection, with SMG holding an effective interest of 44.45% in Delmedia.

site_title: Traipsing from margins to mainstream to bag a Tony
summary: The Tony Awards ceremony honored Best New Musical Fun Home, a poignant exploration of family, memory, and sexuality, which won the award over An American in Paris and other nominees. The show, adapted from Alison Bechdel's graphic memoir, was praised for its emotional power and haunting lyricism. Michael Cerveris won Best Actor for his portrayal of a closeted gay father, while Kelli O'Hara took home Best Actress for her role in The King and I. The ceremony also recognized a record-breaking number of awards for women, including Jeanine Tesori and Lisa Kron, who won for Best Score and Best Book, respectively.

site_title: Nestle noodle crisis shows long road for India's food safety
summary: India's food safety crisis, sparked by a Nestle instant noodle recall, highlights the country's lack of resources for widespread inspections. A team in Uttar Pradesh found lead levels in Nestle's Maggi noodles exceeded limits, prompting a national recall and import bans. Authorities blame a manpower shortage, with one vacancy open for three years. India's food regulator, the FSSAI, is seen as still evolving, and the government is urged to establish a credible regulator to attract investment in the food processing industry, which is growing at 12% annually.

site_title: Hilton planning host of corporate manoeuvres
summary: Hilton Worldwide Holdings is planning various corporate maneuvers, including paying a modest dividend to shareholders, repurchasing its stock, and potentially spinning off its timeshare business. The company aims to increase its global room count by 240,000 in the next three to five years. Hilton's bullish stock performance and strengthening hospitality sector have led to a decrease in Blackstone's ownership stake, making the company eligible for inclusion in the S&P 500 and potentially earning an investment-grade credit rating.

site_title: QE - currency market intervention by another name
summary: Quantitative easing (QE) has become a global phenomenon, with leading central banks engaging in competitive currency market intervention. This practice distorts the playing field for both advanced and emerging economies, leading to market turbulence and capital flows reacting to interest rate differentials. Bank of Japan governor Haruhiko Kuroda has acknowledged the global spillover effects of diverging monetary policies, warning that uncoordinated strategies hurt emerging markets. Critics argue that QE is a covert form of currency market intervention, sacrificing international monetary policy and exchange rate cooperation for expediency, which will likely lead to a painful financial market correction.

site_title: Keeping tabs on the cloud (Amended)
summary: Singapore-based cloud-tagging startup veriTAG has developed an innovative approach to asset management and food trade by integrating a cloud platform that enables the tagging of various assets and devices. The company's cloud platform allows for the storage of unlimited information and applications, and provides a secure access to the cloud database through NFC or QR code tags. This technology helps prevent counterfeits and ensures the integrity of the system, with features such as serialised QR tags and rule engines to detect discrepancies. veriTAG has partnered with Chashan Eco-food Hub and Shanghai Nongken Agricultural Technology, and aims to hit S$1 million in revenue by end-2015.

images.alt_text: Jason Lim, CEO of two-year-old Singapore-based startup veriTAG, has found a way to integrate the myriad components of the Quick Response code into one complete solution.
Prisca Ang

site_title: Indonesia to review coal mining licences
summary: Indonesia plans to review and revoke over 4,000 coal mining licenses, citing low coal prices and the need for consolidation in the sector. The move aims to increase domestic coal production to feed growing power demand and squeeze more revenue from the sector. The review will only apply to newer mining licenses, while larger, older-generation firms will be unaffected. The government also plans to build 70 gigawatts of new power stations by the end of the decade.

site_title: Big challenge for smart cars is steering around human behaviour
summary: Smart cars face a significant challenge in steering around human behavior, despite advanced technology. A recent incident involving a Volvo employee demonstrated this issue, where the driver unintentionally ran into pedestrians due to a misunderstanding of the car's safety features. This incident highlights the limitations of autonomous vehicles in handling unpredictable human behavior on the road. The problem persists despite the soundness of the technology, emphasizing the need for further research and development to improve safety and reliability.

site_title: SWFs now better placed to manage oil-related funding concerns: report
summary: A new report by Invesco suggests that sovereign wealth funds are better equipped to manage funding concerns linked to falling oil prices due to improved liquidity objectives and governance frameworks. The study found that 42% of sovereigns with high oil exposure expect a decrease in funding, but this is a lower proportion than expected. Meanwhile, 43% of central banks are interested in investing in the yuan, a currency that has historically been used by some sovereign investors.

site_title: One-year US inflation expectations rebound: NY Fed survey
summary: US inflation expectations rebounded to 3% for the next year, according to the New York Fed's consumer expectations survey, its highest level so far this year. This rise comes as the central bank considers raising interest rates later this year. The survey also showed that three-year ahead expectations remained at 3%. The news follows a jump in wages in the May jobs report, which may influence the central bank's decision.

site_title: China Life Insurance opens first Singapore office (Amended)
summary: China Life Insurance has opened its first Singapore office, marking its first venture outside mainland China. The subsidiary, China Life Insurance Singapore, will offer health insurance and renminbi wealth management services. The move is seen as part of China's "One Belt, One Road" strategy, aiming to link countries across the Eurasian region.

site_title: San Francisco startup spins laboratory-grown silk
summary: A San Francisco startup, Bolt Threads, has developed a synthetic alternative to spider silk by engineering proteins identical to the natural threads. The company has raised $40 million to commercialize its technology and produce high-performance fabrics for athletic clothing, medical equipment, and other applications. By genetically modifying yeast to produce silk-like proteins, Bolt Threads aims to create fabrics that are soft, durable, and machine-washable. The company expects to launch products by late next year, targeting the market for high-performance apparel such as sports shirts and bras.

site_title: Europe: Stocks decline as Germany's DAX index enters correction
summary: European stocks fell for the fifth consecutive day, with Germany's DAX index retreating 10% from its April peak. The Stoxx Europe 600 Index lost 0.9% to 385.68. Key sectors declined, including automakers and commodity producers, while food- and-beverage companies posted a gain. The decline was attributed to concerns over Greece and the euro's strengthening. German Chancellor Angela Merkel demanded urgent action from the Greek government to maintain its single currency membership.

site_title: Greek minister changes tone, calls Schaeuble meeting "very helpful"
summary: Greek Finance Minister Yanis Varoufakis met with German Finance Minister Wolfgang Schaeuble in Berlin, calling the meeting "very helpful" to find a final solution to the cash-for-reforms deal. This comes after Prime Minister Alexis Tsipras' rejection of a proposal from international lenders, prompting an angry response from European Commission President Jean-Claude Juncker. Varoufakis did not provide further details on the meeting's outcome.

site_title: ECB's Noyer: QE seems to be working, boosting growth prospects
summary: The European Central Bank's quantitative easing program has boosted European growth prospects, with ECB governing council member Christian Noyer predicting a 1.5% growth rate for the eurozone this year. Noyer stated that the program is working, but European governments need to speed up their structural reforms, which have historically been slow and timid.

site_title: Darkest before the dawn
summary: Singapore's stock market has been facing challenges since the global financial crisis, with many stocks being inactive and daily trading values halving to under $1 billion. The new CEO, Loh Boon Chye, aims to internationalize and attract bigger listings to the market. However, the traditional securities business still lags behind the derivatives business, which has seen a significant increase in revenue. The market's lack of excitement and accessibility to retail investors is a major issue, with Singapore being too small to benefit from asset allocation flows. Despite this, experts believe that the market will come back with a vengeance when attention snaps back.

site_title: Corrupt or not, Russia and Qatar should remain World Cup hosts
summary: Russia and Qatar are facing the possibility of having their World Cup hosting rights revoked due to corruption allegations. Domenico Scala, Fifa's head of audit and compliance, warned that new evidence could lead to the annulment of the 2018 and 2022 tournaments. Both countries have invested heavily in infrastructure and preparations, making it difficult to find a replacement host. While there's a moral and ethical issue, removing Russia and Qatar as hosts would be unfair to innocent fans and would be a major step back for Fifa's reform process.

images.alt_text: The Al-Wakrah football stadium, one of Qatar's 2022 World Cup stadiums, is still under construction.
Lee U-Wen

site_title: 1MDB settles Deutsche Bank-led syndicated loan of US$975m
summary: 1MDB, a debt-ridden Malaysian state investment company, has repaid a US$975 million syndicated loan led by Deutsche Bank, settling the loan early as part of its plan to wind down operations. The repayment is funded by Abu Dhabi's state-owned IPIC, which will also pay US$1 billion to 1MDB by June 4. This move aims to reduce 1MDB's debt levels, which have reached RM41.9 billion, and comes as the company seeks to address its financial struggles.

site_title: Russia, Qatar could lose right to host World Cup 'if bribery found'
summary: Russia and Qatar could lose the right to host the 2018 and 2022 World Cups if evidence of corruption is found in the bidding process, according to a Fifa official. The comments come as bribery claims mount against Jack Warner, the man at the center of the scandal engulfing football's world body. The Fifa auditing and compliance committee's comments suggest that both Russia and Qatar could face consequences if corruption is proven, potentially stripping them of their hosting rights.

site_title: Bigger isn't always better in business
summary: A study by Bain & Company found that scale alone is not enough to confer real economic leadership in business. Only 26% of scale leaders achieved a positive return on capital, while 36% failed. The best-performing companies, however, shared four critical attributes: valuable assets, superior capabilities, attractive customers, and the benefits of scope. These companies outperformed scale leaders by developing ambitious strategies that target higher performance. Challengers can succeed by using differentiated capabilities, hijacking the industry profit pool, or changing the rules of the game entirely. The study highlights that scale is valuable, but companies that achieve high leadership economics think and act beyond scale.

site_title: Nathaniel Rothschild sells Asia Resource Minerals stake
summary: Nathaniel Rothschild, a financier and member of the banking dynasty, is selling his stake in Asia Resource Minerals (Arms), a coal industry investment in Indonesia. He secured an improved offer from Asian group Coal Energy Ventures, ending his involvement in the troubled investment. Rothschild co-founded one of Arms' predecessor companies in 2010 and partnered with Indonesia's Bakrie family to tap demand from the country's infrastructure plans.

site_title: Plight of the NEETs - a global phenomenon
summary: The NEETs (Neither Employed Nor in Education or Training) phenomenon is a global issue affecting 39 million young people in 33 advanced industrial countries, according to the OECD. This group faces significant challenges, including heavy student loans, delayed life milestones, and reduced employability due to prolonged unemployment. The OECD warns that prolonged joblessness can erode confidence, undermine relationships, and lead to social instability. While there are potential solutions, such as digital job services and a gradual global economic recovery, the issue remains a pressing concern for many countries, with half of NEETs not even looking for work.

site_title: Ringgit hits 9-year low
summary: The Malaysian ringgit has hit a 9-year low of 3.767 to the US dollar, following stronger-than-anticipated US employment data and speculation of an impending Federal Reserve rate hike. The currency has lost nearly 8% against the greenback this year, and experts predict it may reach a forecast 4.00 by year-end. The country's sovereign rating has been downgraded to BBB by Fitch Ratings, and the economy is expected to face tough quarters due to a contracting trade surplus and softening demand in key markets.

site_title: G-7 pledges to speed up work on transatlantic free trade pact
summary: Leaders of the G-7 pledged to speed up work on a transatlantic trade and investment partnership (TTIP) deal, aiming to finalize understandings on the outline of an agreement by the end of this year. US President Barack Obama needs to receive fast track authority from Congress to conclude talks quickly, according to German Chancellor Angela Merkel. The G-7 communique emphasized accelerating work on all TTIP issues to ensure progress on the negotiations.

site_title: Greek exit would not be problem for eurozone: ECB's Noyer
summary: European Central Bank governing council member Christian Noyer stated that Greece's exit from the eurozone would not be a problem for the currency bloc, but rather for Greece itself. Noyer emphasized the urgency of Greece reaching a settlement with its creditors, warning that any late-June agreement would need approval from European legislatures. He also downplayed concerns over the euro's exchange rate with the US dollar, attributing it to differences in economic conditions between the two regions.

site_title: Sinarmas Land takes stake in Chinese Reit
summary: Sinarmas Land has entered into a heads of agreement to take a strategic stake in KaiLong Holdings Ltd's proposed Chinese Reit to be listed on the Singapore Exchange. This could be the first Chinese Reit to list on the SGX. The agreement was signed following an invitation to participate in the listing and offering of units. The terms of the agreement have not been disclosed, but it is expected to precede a negotiated contract.

site_title: SGX names veteran banker Loh Boon Chye as its new CEO
summary: The Singapore Exchange (SGX) has appointed Loh Boon Chye, former head of Bank of America Merrill Lynch's global markets in the Asia-Pacific, as its new CEO, effective July 14. This marks a departure from the traditional equities stronghold and brings in experience beyond the market operator's usual focus. The search for a new CEO lasted 3 1/2 months.

site_title: Keong Hong launches S$50m medium term notes
summary: Keong Hong Holdings Limited has launched and priced its S$50 million medium term notes (Series 1 Notes) at 100 per cent of their principal amount, bearing a 6 per cent fixed interest per annum. The notes, part of its S$150 million multicurrency medium term note programme, are expected to mature on June 15, 2018. The Hongkong and Shanghai Banking Corporation Limited has been appointed as sole bookrunner and lead manager for the Series 1 Notes, set to be issued on June 15.

site_title: Malaysia's 1MDB repays US$975 million loan: statement
summary: Malaysia's state investment fund 1MDB has repaid a $975 million loan to international banks, reducing its debt levels as part of a rationalization plan. The move comes amid controversy over the fund's nearly $15 billion in debts and alleged financial mismanagement. Malaysia's central bank launched a formal inquiry into 1MDB on June 3, seeking to establish if there were any rule violations. This repayment is seen as a step towards addressing the fund's financial issues.

site_title: Shares of Deutsche Bank jump on management purge
summary: Deutsche Bank's shares rose 8% after John Cryan was appointed as CEO, seen as a more credible contender to revive the bank's fortunes. Cryan faces a challenging task to move the bank beyond regulatory and legal probes, and execute a strategic overhaul. His predecessor, Anshu Jain, had unveiled a cost-cutting drive but faced investor skepticism due to a lack of detail and poor meeting targets. Cryan's experience steering UBS through the financial crisis has raised hopes that he can take a more radical approach to revamp the bank.

site_title: OCBC to launch venture debt
summary: OCBC Bank plans to launch venture debt, a debt financing option for startups that have raised capital from venture capitalists. The product is aimed at helping fast-growing companies with limited capital, typically taking 2.5 years to reach S$10 million in sales turnover. Venture debt providers will combine loans with warrants or equity rights to compensate for higher risk. OCBC's venture debt offering is sector-agnostic and will be available to startups and growth companies that typically do not have positive cash flows or significant assets.

images.alt_text: "Today, we continue to be a leading banker in the SME segment. Over 40 per cent of SMEs in Singapore have a banking relationship with OCBC, and every one in two new businesses formed every year bank with us. In fact, we were the first bank to introduce dedicated products and services to meet the needs of these emerging businesses in 2006." - Tan Chor Sen, OCBC's head of international, global commercial banking

site_title: China's island creation will lead to what it dreads - containment
summary: China's construction of artificial islands in the South China Sea is escalating tensions with neighboring countries and potentially limiting global shipping routes. China claims sovereignty over 3.5 million sq km of the sea, but the US and Japan are working together to contain Beijing's growing military presence. The US has already flown unarmed spy planes over disputed islands, but it's unclear if this will be enough to stop China's leaders, who are unlikely to back down due to nationalist sentiment. The situation may lead to a prolonged game of attrition, with the US and Japan seeking to militarily link up with other nations to counter China's growing power.

site_title: IATA hikes 2015 global airline profit forecast to US$29b
summary: Global airlines have raised their 2015 profit forecast to $29.3 billion, a 17% increase from last year. Lower oil prices are the main factor, but the industry's profits are not uniform, with many airlines still facing challenges. The industry's average net profit margin is expected to almost double to 4% from 2.2% last year. Airlines are also expected to fly fuller than ever before, with a record high load factor of 80.2%.

site_title: Alibaba's Jack Ma visiting US to lure businesses into China
summary: Alibaba Group Holding Ltd Chairman Jack Ma is visiting the US to lure businesses into China, seeking revenue beyond the nation's slowest economy growth since 1990. Ma aims to position Alibaba as a cross-border e-commerce solution, enabling China's 557 million Internet users to buy products worldwide. He plans to meet with US business leaders, including American Express CEO Ken Chenault, and aims to raise Alibaba's international revenue to 50% from 4%. This push coincides with new policies making it cheaper for Chinese residents to import overseas goods and successful trial programs selling Western brands on Alibaba's TMall.com.

site_title: Nightmare not over for HTC: analyst
summary: HTC Corp has slashed its quarterly sales forecast by as much as 35% and announced a one-time writedown on assets, prompting a significant stock drop. Analyst Calvin Huang predicts the company's "nightmare" is far from over, with HTC expected to continue losing share in the smartphone market and incur losses in the coming quarters. The stock has declined 41% this year, and HTC is being squeezed by larger competitors and cheaper prices offered by Chinese brands. Huang has cut his price target to NT$53, indicating a potential 37% further decline.

site_title: China trade continues sliding; surplus soars in May
summary: China's trade continued to slide in May, with exports dipping 2.8% and imports falling 17.6% for a record $59.49 billion surplus. Despite stimulus measures, domestic demand remains weak, with imports and investment growth sluggish. Analysts predict a stabilisation of commodity prices and easing policies will drive up imports in the coming months, but the export outlook remains weak due to a strong currency and weak overseas conditions. China's economy is bracing for its slowest growth in 25 years, with policymakers facing pressure to support growth or push through reforms.

site_title: India central bank announces new measures on debt restructuring by lenders
summary: The Reserve Bank of India (RBI) has announced new measures on debt restructuring by lenders, including a requirement for lenders to hold 51% equity after debt-for-share conversion under the strategic debt restructuring (SDR) scheme. The RBI also allows lenders to convert debt to equity within 30 days and exempts lenders from making an open offer when acquiring shares of a listed company. These measures will apply to all company accounts, effective immediately.

site_title: G7 pledges to speed work on transatlantic free trade pact
summary: Leaders of the Group of Seven (G7) pledged to accelerate work on the transatlantic trade and investment partnership (TTIP) deal, aiming to finalize understandings on the outline of an agreement by the end of 2015. German Chancellor Angela Merkel emphasized the need for the US President to receive fast track authority from Congress to conclude the talks quickly. This move comes as the deal has faced fierce opposition on both sides of the Atlantic.

site_title: Obama says global economy not performing at full potential
summary: US President Barack Obama stated that the global economy is expanding but not performing at its full potential. This was during a G7 summit in Germany. The US is a major source of strength in the global economy, but other nations are facing challenges such as higher US tariffs and slowing GDP growth in China. The global economy's growth is expected to be affected by these factors, with some predicting a slowdown in 2026.

site_title: US: Wall St opens lower as rate hike worries weigh
summary: US stocks opened lower on Monday due to concerns about a potential Federal Reserve interest rate hike as soon as September. The Dow Jones industrial average fell 0.05%, the S&P 500 dropped 0.1%, and the Nasdaq Composite fell 0.08% at the open. Despite a strong jobs report on Friday, investors worried about the impact of a rate hike on the economy.

site_title: SGX names ex-BofAML banker Loh Boon Chye as next CEO
summary: The Singapore Exchange (SGX) has appointed Loh Boon Chye, former head of Bank of America Merrill Lynch's global markets in Asia Pacific, as its next CEO, effective July 14. Loh, 51, will replace Magnus Bocker, who is leaving after his contract ends on June 30. Loh brings extensive experience in capital markets, having previously worked at the Monetary Authority of Singapore and Deutsche Bank, and has previously been involved with SGX. The appointment comes as SGX shares closed lower before the announcement.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks inch lower despite upbeat Japan growth
summary: Tokyo stocks fell on Monday, despite Japan's economic growth data showing a positive outlook. The Nikkei 225 index declined 0.02%, finishing at 20,457.19, while the Topix index lost 0.30%. The upbeat data failed to drive stocks higher, with investors instead focusing on global economic uncertainty.

site_title: Sinarmas Land signs non-binding agreement to participate in KaiLong China Reit
summary: SINARMAS Land has entered into a non-binding agreement to participate in the proposed listing and offering of units in KaiLong China Reit, a Reit to be set up in Singapore and listed on the Singapore Exchange. KaiLong China Reit will have an initial portfolio of eight properties in China, with KaiLong Holdings Limited serving as the sponsor. The deal is subject to further negotiation and approval.

site_title: UBS increases stake in Chinese joint venture
summary: UBS has increased its stake in its Chinese joint venture, UBS Securities, to nearly 25% by buying an additional 4.99% of the company. This move comes as Western banks have been exiting their ventures in China, with Standard Chartered and Royal Bank of Scotland Group preparing to withdraw from their Asian businesses. Despite this trend, UBS has maintained management control through a consortium of Chinese state-affiliated firms, with Beijing Guoxiang Property Management Co Ltd remaining the largest shareholder.

site_title: Greece ready to negotiate for EU/IMF deal till end-June
summary: Greece is ready to negotiate with its EU/IMF creditors until the end of June to reach a deal, according to government spokesman Gabriel Sakellaridis. The bailout program's deadline is set to expire at the end of the month, and Greece is determined to have a positive outcome. The country's options for extending the program are open, with discussions ongoing.

site_title: TTJ Holdings Q3 net profit slumps 74%
summary: TTJ Holdings reported a 74% slump in Q3 net profit to S$1.6 million, driven by lower sales and margins. Group revenue declined 56% to S$14.8 million, mainly due to lower structural steel work. The company's gross profit margin slipped to 24.9%, with an orderbook of S$106 million expected to be substantially completed between FY2015 and FY2017. TTJ will monitor costs and enhance productivity to remain competitive.

site_title: India to seek damages from Nestle over 'unsafe noodles'
