site_title: Big US data breaches offer treasure trove for hackers
summary: A massive breach of US federal computer networks at the Office of Personnel Management (OPM) has compromised the records of up to 4 million current and former federal employees, with suspected Chinese hackers believed to be behind the attack. The breach, disclosed last week, is the latest in a series of attacks on government and private computers by Chinese hackers. US officials have linked the attacks to earlier breaches at Anthem Inc and Premera Blue Cross, and warned of a growing threat from China and Russia.

site_title: New toys for flash boys in China's fledgling derivatives trade
summary: China's derivatives market has attracted "flash boys" who employ complex trading strategies to gain quick profits, generating risk and contributing to the country's runaway stock boom. Brokerages and fund managers invest in mathematics whizzes and hardware to gain precious microseconds in trading new options and futures contracts, helping the CSI300 index become the world's most traded equity futures contract.

site_title: Buying by directors high, no sales
summary: Buyback activity was high in Singapore with 16 companies posting 43 repurchases worth S$38.8 million in the first week of June. This includes rare acquisitions in Silverlake Axis and insider buys in Boustead Projects, GuocoLand, and GSS Energy. On the other hand, there were fund manager sales in healthcare plays Raffles Medical Group and Religare Health Trust. The recent buybacks by directors have seen Silverlake Axis' stock rise by 64% six months after the group bought shares, while Boustead Projects' stock closed at 90.5 cents on Friday.

site_title: Sabah quake: 11 dead, 8 missing on Malaysian peak, says official
summary: A 6.0-magnitude earthquake struck Mount Kinabalu in Malaysia, killing at least 11 people and leaving 8 missing. The quake, one of the strongest in decades, caused landslides and damage to trails, trapping 137 hikers for up to 18 hours. Malaysian rescuers safely evacuated the hikers, but no major damage has been reported outside of the mountain. The official update stated 11 bodies recovered, 8 still missing, as of noon on Saturday.

site_title: Sabah quake toll reaches 13 dead, 6 missing: police
summary: A 6.0-magnitude earthquake struck Mount Kinabalu in Malaysia, resulting in 13 deaths and 6 missing. The quake damaged trails and triggered landslides, forcing the evacuation of 137 hikers. Climbing has been suspended for at least three weeks to allow for repairs. Authorities have reported no major damage or casualties outside of those on the mountain, and no reports of major damage to the local rainforests, wild rivers, or coral reefs.

site_title: June 8 declared Day of National Remembrance for victims of Sabah quake
summary: June 8 has been declared a Day of National Remembrance in Singapore for victims of the Sabah earthquake that occurred on Friday, resulting in 7 deaths, including 6 students and 1 teacher. The Prime Minister's Office has announced that state flags will be flown at half-mast and a minute of silence will be observed at the beginning of the day at all SEA Games venues. The Prime Minister has expressed condolences to the families of the victims and thanked those involved in the search, rescue, and recovery efforts.

site_title: US auto safety agency plans more aggressive enforcement after GM recall
summary: The US National Highway Traffic Safety Administration (NHTSA) has announced plans for more aggressive enforcement against future car safety problems after acknowledging shortfalls in its probe of a deadly General Motors (GM) ignition switch defect. The regulator admitted it misunderstood the technology and failed to demand clear information from GM, resulting in 109 deaths and over 200 injuries. NHTSA Administrator Mark Rosekind vows to reform the agency, introducing new teams of experts and programs to cut bureaucratic barriers and enhance collaboration with plaintiffs' attorneys and parts suppliers.

site_title: US tech giants giving big bond funds a run for their money
summary: US tech giants, including Apple and Oracle, are increasingly investing in corporate bonds, snapping up as much as half of some bond issues. This is a departure from traditional investors like Pacific Investment Management Co and BlackRock, and is driven by the need to juice returns in a low-interest-rate environment. The trend is cutting into traditional investors' access to new issues, and is expected to continue as tech companies, with over $500 billion in cash and marketable securities, seek to bring their funds back to the US.

site_title: From blue to gold
summary: Singapore stocks experienced a 5-day rally ahead of GDP data, with key players including Singtel, Sinarmas Land, and PSC. Popiah king Sam Goi made a mandatory offer for PSC at S$0.40 per share. The rally was attributed to traders brushing off US President Trump's new threats, with Asian markets extending their gains. Meanwhile, European shares were boosted by mining and healthcare stocks, while US markets edged to fresh records despite ongoing trade tensions.

site_title: Sabah quake: Family members of missing pupils fly to Kota Kinabalu
summary: A group of family members and officials from Singapore left for Kota Kinabalu on a Republic of Singapore Airforce aircraft to search for missing pupils and teachers in Sabah following a 2015 earthquake. The team includes counsellors and representatives from the police, Singapore Civil Defence Force, and Ministry of Transport. The search efforts were initiated in response to the initial news of missing individuals.

site_title: Gold at 11-week low after US data, set for 3rd weekly fall
summary: Gold prices hit an 11-week low, falling 1.2% to $1,162.35 per ounce, after US employment data showed a 280,000 increase in non-farm payrolls, boosting prospects for an interest rate increase this year. The dollar rallied 1.5% versus a basket of currencies, making dollar-denominated gold more expensive. Investors also eyed Greece's delayed debt payment. Gold is set for a third weekly decline, the biggest since April.

site_title: Hell's Angels paradise
summary: MEATliquor, a trendy burger chain in Singapore, has opened its latest outpost on Duxton Road. The restaurant's in-your-face psychedelic art, blasting music, and cramped atmosphere evoke a "bear-hugged by a heavily tattooed, burly rig worker" vibe. The menu features straightforward, deep-fried options like burgers, fries, and fried chicken, with bold sauces and seasonings. The food is a deliberate assault on the senses, but the execution is praised for its quality. The restaurant offers a playful atmosphere, including a game of dice to win free meals. Rating: 6.

site_title: Walmart names another founding family member as chairman
summary: Walmart has named Greg Penner, the grandson-in-law of founder Sam Walton, as its new chairman, replacing Rob Walton. This move has sparked concerns about nepotism, with critics arguing that the board may prioritize the family's interests over those of other shareholders. Despite steps taken to add outsiders to the board, the appointment has been met with criticism from labour groups and investors. Penner, who has industry experience, was elected unanimously by the board, but the move is seen as a continuation of Walmart's family-run business model, which Americans tend to be skeptical of.

site_title: Hackers are next on government-spyware company's list of targets
summary: Verint Systems Inc, a government-spyware company, is now targeting corporate America with its cybersecurity expertise. The company, which sifts through communications to combat terrorism and crime, plans to unveil new cybersecurity products for corporations at a conference in Las Vegas. Despite the US government's efforts to balance security with citizen privacy, demand for cybersecurity intelligence remains high, and Verint is betting its skill in helping governments will give it an edge in the competition for private-sector contracts.

images.alt_text: A company that helps governments monitor their citizens is now peddling its expertise to corporate America.

site_title: IMF plans US$833m in emergency aid to Iraq
summary: The International Monetary Fund (IMF) plans to provide $833 million in emergency aid to Iraq to help the country cope with the economic impact of the Islamic State insurgency. The aid, under the IMF's Rapid Financing Instrument programme, is subject to approval and likely to be finalized in July. Iraq's economy contracted 2.1% last year due to violence and is expected to grow only 0.5% this year. The country's foreign earnings have been significantly impacted by the crash in oil prices, widening the government's budget shortfall.

site_title: Russian, Dutch ministers discuss prosecuting MH17 culprits
summary: Russian Foreign Minister Sergei Lavrov met with Dutch counterpart Bert Koenders to discuss prosecuting those responsible for shooting down Malaysia Airlines Flight 17 over Ukraine last year. Lavrov emphasized the need for a comprehensive, global, and independent investigation. The two ministers also discussed the situation in the Middle East, North Africa, and the Ukraine crisis. Russia wants to cooperate with the Netherlands to uncover the truth behind the 2014 plane crash.

site_title: Singaporean Trafigura executive arrested in China
summary: A senior executive, Bo Li, of Trafigura Beheer BV, has been arrested in China as part of a probe into gasoline trading. Li, a Singaporean, was detained at Beijing airport on Monday evening while preparing to depart on a business trip to Singapore. The Singaporean government has confirmed the arrest and is providing consular assistance to Li and his family. The reasons behind Li's detention are not yet clear, but it is linked to gasoline trading, according to people familiar with the matter.

site_title: US: Stocks mostly down as market weighs good jobs data
summary: US stocks ended mostly lower on Friday, despite a strong jobs report that showed the US economy added 280,000 jobs in May, beating expectations. The Dow Jones shed 56.12 points, while the S&P 500 dropped 3.01 points. The jobs data sparked concerns about the Federal Reserve raising interest rates, which boosted large banks like Bank of America and JPMorgan Chase. Other sectors, including technology and telecommunications, also saw gains, while petroleum-related stocks rose on higher oil prices.

site_title: South Korea reports nine new Mers cases, one recovers and leaves hospital
summary: South Korea reported 9 new Mers cases, bringing the total to 50, with one patient recovering and being discharged from hospital. The outbreak, first reported on May 20, has claimed 4 lives and raised public fear over the government's response. The new cases were linked to the initial patient, and there has been no sustained human-to-human transmission. The virus has a 38% death rate, higher than SARS, and global cases total around 1,194 with at least 443 deaths.

site_title: US rig count seen bottoming out soon, recovering towards year-end
summary: US drilling-rig count is expected to bottom out soon, recovering in the Permian and Eagle Ford shale plays by year-end. After OPEC agreed to maintain unconstrained output for six months, oil prices are likely to hold at current levels. This stability is expected to encourage drilling in US shale basins, mainly in Texas. Analysts anticipate a recovery in the second half of the year.

site_title: Greece close to EU-IMF deal but creditors must drop 'absurd' demands: PM
summary: Greek Prime Minister Alexis Tsipras said the country is close to a default-saving reform deal with EU-IMF creditors, but creditors must drop "absurd" demands for further austerity cuts. Tsipras insisted that any agreement must include debt relief to be a definitive solution to the Greek crisis, rejecting proposals made by international creditors.

site_title: China's cancer epidemic driving investment in healthcare
summary: China's rising affluent population is driving investment in healthcare, particularly in cancer treatment. Cities like Datong, plagued by pollution, are experiencing soaring cancer rates, with cancer accounting for a third of deaths in 2012. To address this, a privately run, radiotherapy-equipped cancer hospital is being built in Datong by Concord Medical Services Holdings Ltd. This investment is part of a growing trend of businesses catering to China's growing demand for healthcare services, particularly among the affluent population willing to pay for premium medical care.

images.alt_text: Coal constitutes 65 per cent of China's energy mix. In Datong, one of China's coal capitals, cancer rates are soaring despite efforts to vanquish the smog, and the disease accounted for a third of deaths in 2012.

site_title: South Africa leadership 'approved' World Cup payment
summary: South African officials, including then-president Thabo Mbeki and foreign minister Nkosazana Dlamini-Zuma, allegedly approved a $10-million payment to FIFA in 2008, which US investigators suspect was a bribe to secure the 2010 World Cup bid. The payment was made through FIFA and went to an account controlled by Jack Warner, a former FIFA vice president wanted by US authorities. South African authorities claim the payment was for a legitimate development project in the Caribbean, but the allegations have sparked fresh pressure on FIFA amid a corruption scandal.

site_title: Ukraine and creditors lock horns over debt writedown
summary: Ukraine's finance ministry and creditors, led by Franklin Templeton, failed to reach a debt restructuring deal, with Kiev dismissing the offer as unacceptable. The disagreement occurred after a teleconference aimed at resolving a US$40 billion bailout package led by the International Monetary Fund. Ukrainian sovereign bond prices rose before the talks, fueled by hopes of a smaller loss than previously expected. The deadlock has raised concerns about Ukraine's ability to meet its bailout targets.

site_title: Oil up 2 per cent after early swings on dollar
summary: Oil prices rose 2% on Friday, reversing a three-day decline, despite warnings of increased supply due to OPEC's decision to keep pumping without restraint. The decision was made at a meeting in Vienna, where producers agreed to stick to unconstrained output for six months. The US dollar's surge on a stronger-than-expected jobs report initially depressed oil prices, but a late rally pushed Brent and US crude futures up. The price of Brent settled at $63.31 a barrel, while US crude rose to $59.13 a barrel.

site_title: Bond turmoil scary as hell: Bill Gross
summary: Treasury prices have fallen 7.4% since March, driven by a global selloff led by German bunds, largely due to liquidity issues. Legendary investor Bill Gross expressed concern but believes a bear bond market is unlikely. Gross attributes the market's volatility to minute-by-minute fluctuations and fears for liquidity problems, but remains optimistic about the market's trajectory. Despite the decline, Gross doesn't predict a bear market, citing the ongoing upward trend in the S&P 500.

site_title: Google puts India PM in criminal search line-up
summary: Google apologized for serving India's Prime Minister Narendra Modi alongside notorious US mobster Al Capone in search results for "Top 10 Criminals". The error was attributed to references to "criminal" in image captions or unseen data. Google is continually working to improve its algorithms to prevent such unexpected results. This incident follows previous issues with Google Maps, including racist language searches pointing to the White House and crowd-sourced editing mistakes. Google is re-evaluating its user-edited online map system to prevent similar incidents.

site_title: Walmart blends in-store and online grocery shopping experience
summary: Walmart has introduced a new tool that streamlines the in-store and online grocery shopping experience at Sam's Club. The feature, which debuted at the company's annual shareholders meeting, allows customers to check in when they're ready to pick up their order, and workers will assemble frozen items with the rest of the order, ensuring it's ready on time. This move aims to improve the customer experience and make online shopping more appealing, particularly for groceries, which are often considered the most mundane and essential retail purchases.

site_title: Argentina must pay "me-too" claims for US$5.4b: US judge
summary: A US judge ruled that Argentina must pay US$5.4 billion to over 500 "me-too" holders of defaulted debt before paying the majority of its creditors. This is the latest legal defeat for Argentina, which defaulted on US$100 billion in 2002 and again in 2014 after refusing to honor orders to pay the "me-too" debtors. The decision comes after Argentina refused to honor US District Judge Thomas Griesa's orders to pay US$1.33 billion plus interest to these debtholders.

site_title: Italy's Berlusconi agrees sale of AC Milan stake to Thai businessman
summary: Berlusconi agrees to sell 48% of AC Milan to Thai businessman Bee Taechaubol, ending his three-decade ownership. The deal aims to relaunch the team in Asia and boost revenues. Berlusconi will remain chairman, and Taechaubol and he will collaborate on a business and sports plan to revive AC Milan, a seven-time European champion.

site_title: Japan state firm to auction stake in platinum mine
summary: Japan's state-run Japan Oil, Gas and Metals National Corp (Jogmec) will auction its 28% stake in a promising platinum mine in South Africa, potentially to Japanese trading houses. The Waterberg deposit, with layers 30 times thicker than typical, is expected to become the world's third-biggest platinum and palladium mine. The sale comes as South African supply nears exhaustion, and the car industry, accounting for 40% of global platinum demand, drives demand for the metal. The auction is expected to occur by April.

site_title: Greece postpones repayment of 300m euro loan from IMF
summary: Greece has postponed repayment of a 300 million euro IMF loan, delaying a payment of 1.6 billion euros owed to the lender in June. The move, taken just hours after Prime Minister Alexis Tsipras was presented with a compromise deal from lenders, has triggered fury in the ruling Syriza party. The decision may lead to snap elections, as the party seeks public legitimacy for difficult decisions to secure more cash. A bailout expires at the end of June, and default would likely occur if no cash-for-reforms deal is reached, potentially pushing Greece out of the eurozone.

site_title: Deutsche Bank probes US$6b suspected money laundering: source
summary: Deutsche Bank is investigating possible money laundering transactions by Russian clients, potentially exceeding US$6 billion. The transactions, conducted over several years, involve "relatively simple" transactions in the dollar and rouble currencies. The bank has suspended a small number of traders in Moscow and is conducting an internal review. The European Central Bank, German regulator BaFin, and UK's Financial Conduct Authority have been informed of the investigation. Up to three staff have been laid off, and the bank has pledged to uphold high standards in combating suspicious activities.

site_title: Data hacked from federal government dates back to 1985: US official
summary: US officials revealed that data stolen from federal government computers by suspected Chinese hackers in 2015 included security clearance information and background checks dating back to 1985, affecting up to 4 million current and former federal employees. The breach, attributed to Chinese hackers, could strain US-China relations, particularly amid tensions over territorial claims in the South China Sea. The Office of Personnel Management was targeted, highlighting the scope of the cyber attack. The breach's implications for national security and government trust remain unclear.

images.alt_text: Data stolen from US government computers by suspected Chinese hackers included security clearance information and background checks dating back three decades, US officials said on Friday, underlining the scope of one of the largest known cyber attacks on federal networks.

site_title: India, Bangladesh to seal border pact as Modi visits
summary: India's Prime Minister Narendra Modi visited Bangladesh to seal a land pact allowing tens of thousands of people living in border enclaves to choose their nationality. The agreement, which has been decades in the making, will remove a thorn in relations between the two countries since Bangladesh's 1971 war of secession. Under the deal, the countries will exchange territories and people living in the enclaves will have the option to choose citizenship in the newly designated territories. The pact is seen as a significant milestone in strengthening ties between the two nations, with Modi comparing it to the dismantling of the Berlin Wall.

site_title: Europe: Shares fall as debt woes hit Greek stocks
summary: European shares dropped on Friday, weighed down by Greece's delayed debt payment, which slid the Athens stock market to one-month lows. Greece's benchmark index tumbled 5% as Prime Minister Alexis Tsipras demanded changes to international creditors' terms. Despite economic stimulus measures from the European Central Bank, traders viewed the Greek impasse as an opportunity to sell European stocks, which have had a good run in 2015. The lingering uncertainty over Greece pressured European stock markets, overshadowing solid US employment data and a potential September interest rate hike from the US Federal Reserve.

site_title: A trade body's Singapore story
summary: The Singapore International Chamber of Commerce (SICC) has been a vital part of Singapore's business community since its founding in 1837. As the country's longest-serving, wholly independent voice of the private sector, SICC aims to promote a vibrant economy and has been a constant supporter of Singapore's post-independence governments. With a diverse membership representing over 20 industry sectors and 40 nationalities, SICC has played a key role in shaping Singapore's economic policies and has worked closely with the government to build and maintain a thriving economy.

site_title: HDB calls for largest solar leasing tender
summary: The Housing & Development Board (HDB) in Singapore has issued the largest solar leasing tender, worth 40 megawatt-peak (MWp) capacity, for public and private sectors. Eight Ministry of Home Affairs and Public Utilities Board sites, and approximately 900 HDB blocks, will receive solar photovoltaic (PV) systems. The installations are expected to be completed by end-2017 and will contribute to Singapore's goal of 350 MWp of solar power by 2020, equivalent to 5% of peak energy consumption.

site_title: Takata, US regulator can't say how many cars may have faulty air bags
summary: US regulators and Takata Corp cannot determine how many vehicles may still contain defective air bag inflators, despite identifying nearly 34 million potentially faulty parts. At least 400,000 replacement parts need to be replaced again, while 500,000 appear safe, leaving over three million in question. The National Highway Traffic Safety Administration (NHTSA) and carmakers are working to determine which parts need to be replaced, with Honda Motor Co providing some guidance on the issue. The exact number of vehicles with defective inflators remains unclear, adding to the confusion.

site_title: SMRT drops telco venture bid
summary: SMRT, Singapore's main train operator, has decided not to invest in OMGtel, a telco firm bidding for Singapore's fourth wireless telecommunications carrier licence. This decision comes after facing criticism over potential distraction from its core public transport business. SMRT cited reviewing capital allocation priorities and focusing on other business areas, such as rail engineering. The move is unlikely to impact OMGtel's chances, with analysts stating that both firms lack expertise in running a nationwide mobile network.

site_title: Revamped Shaw Centre fails to pull in shoppers, tenants unhappy
summary: The Shaw Centre shopping mall in Singapore is struggling to attract shoppers, with low occupancy rates and footfall despite its recent refurbishment. Tenants are unhappy with the lack of marketing efforts and cohesive concept in the retail tenant mix. The landlord has offered rental rebates and some marketing initiatives, but tenants want more. The mall's management claims to be working closely with tenants to address concerns, and some tenants have reported an increase in footfall following video advertisements and marketing efforts. The mall's occupancy rate is expected to hit 75% with the arrival of new tenants, but it remains to be seen if the mall can turn its fortunes around.

site_title: Singapore startup Mesitis bags US$3m in Series A funding
summary: Singaporean fintech startup Mesitis secured US$3 million in Series A funding to expand its personal financial data aggregation platform, Canopy, to other markets. The platform, which costs US$299 a month, aggregates financial data from various sources and provides a comprehensive view of users' portfolios. Meanwhile, homegrown startup Call Levels launched the world's first real-time investment alert app for Apple Watch, offering premium market assistance technology to the average consumer for free.

site_title: Foreigners find gems in high-end condos
summary: Foreigners have been attracted to high-end condos in Singapore, with notable buyers including Alibaba co-founder Sun Tongyu, who paid S$51 million for a penthouse, and a regional executive at Facebook, who bought a nearly 4,700 sq ft unit for S$11.3 million. Other international buyers, such as Chinese citizens and Taiwanese investors, have also snapped up luxury condos. According to Savills Singapore research head Alan Cheong, well-heeled buyers find Singapore's luxury condo market "very compelling" compared to Hong Kong and London, with prices averaging S$2,400-2,800 psf.

site_title: What Fifa and AIIB tell us about the world order
summary: The article highlights the shift in global power dynamics and the limits of US influence. The ousting of FIFA President Sepp Blatter and the China-led Asian Infrastructure Investment Bank (AIIB) illustrate the decline of Western patronage and the rise of emerging markets. International cooperation and competition are emphasized as key factors in promoting good governance and accountability. The article concludes that the world order is changing, with the US, UK, and other Western countries adapting to a new reality, while China becomes a more prominent player, leveraging its influence to promote its own interests.

site_title: The art of selling artefacts
summary: D Brent Pogue, a 50-year-old coin collector, is selling his collection of 680 coins, valued at over $200 million. The collection, which took 40 years to build, includes rare coins such as the 1822 Half Eagle gold piece. To sell the collection, Pogue worked with specialty auction house Stack's Bowers, which spaced out the sales over seven auctions. A strategy is key to selling a collection, and Pogue's coins vary in quality and auction value. The sale is expected to bring in $30 million per auction, with some pieces potentially fetching over $10 million.

site_title: Indonesia joins queue for Iran oil amid talks to rejoin Opec
summary: Indonesia is seeking a long-term oil supply deal with Iran amid talks to rejoin Opec. Resources Minister Sudirman Said discussed potential crude supply and investments with Iran during an Opec meeting in Vienna. Indonesia, where domestic demand exceeds production, joins European oil majors in expressing interest in Iran's energy resources. The deal would curb Iran's nuclear program in exchange for easing sanctions. Indonesia is also exploring potential deals with the UAE and has signed a memorandum of understanding with Iran for long-term crude supply. Rejoining Opec would strengthen ties between producers and consumers.

site_title: Lifting of ABSD: too soon to tell
summary: The Singapore government will continue to monitor the property market and adjust its cooling measures as necessary to promote a stable and sustainable market. This decision comes amid rising global property prices and market trends. The government aims to balance demand and supply, and its actions will be guided by market conditions and economic stability.

images.alt_text: Prisca Ang

site_title: German economy shifting into higher gear: Bundesbank
summary: The German economy has seen a shift into higher gear, according to the Bundesbank. Germany's GDP is expected to expand by 1.7% in 2015, 1.8% in 2016, and 1.5% in 2017, driven by low unemployment, higher wages, and the weak euro. This upgrade in growth expectations marks a positive outlook for the European economy.

site_title: High Speed luxury
summary: The Bentley Mulsanne Speed is the latest luxury variant of the ultra-luxury saloon, boasting massive torque and super speed. Weighing 2.7 tonnes, the 5.6-metre long car delivers sybaritic comfort with truck-like torque, thanks to its 6.75-litre twin turbo V8 producing 537 hp and 1,100 Nm. The Mulsanne Speed features a refined and tactile interior, while its exterior styling remains unchanged, with minor tweaks to the headlamps and bumper grilles. It accelerates from 0-100kmh in 4.9 seconds and has a top speed of 305kmh.

site_title: China tightens Communist Party leadership at SOEs
summary: Chinese President Xi Jinping called for strengthening Communist Party leadership at state-owned enterprises (SOEs) during a top-level meeting. Documents related to SOE reform and preventing loss of state assets were approved. Premier Li Keqiang and other government officials attended the meeting. This move comes as the government prepares sweeping reforms to overhaul state industry.

site_title: wine&dinewith BTWeekend
summary: Singapore's dining scene offers various events and promotions this month. The Rice Dumpling Festival at Peach Blossoms and Mikuni at Fairmont Singapore feature unique culinary experiences. Oyster Occasions returns at 10 at Claymore, Pan Pacific Orchard, with unlimited servings of six oyster varieties. Serenity Spanish Restaurant offers authentic Spanish cuisine in its new outlet at Ngee Ann City. Meanwhile, Plate is launching an SG50-themed dinner buffet every Thursday and Friday, featuring local favorites and a famous Chilli Crab dish.

site_title: Pocket Rocket
summary: The latest Mini John Cooper Works (JCW) model has debuted with several "firsts". The third-generation JCW features a bodykit with large air intakes to optimize cooling of its 2-litre, four-cylinder turbocharged engine and brakes. The exterior also includes aerodynamic air ducts in the lower front apron and a distinctive roof spoiler at the back. These design elements aim to enhance performance and handling.

site_title: Flamboyant Aussie businessman Alan Bond dies at 77
summary: Alan Bond, a flamboyant Australian businessman, died at 77 after a triple-bypass operation. He had never regained consciousness. Bond was known for funding Australia II's 1983 America's Cup victory, earning international acclaim. He built a fortune through various business ventures but faced financial struggles, including a 7-year prison sentence and A$622 million bankruptcy. Despite rebuilding part of his fortune, Bond's net worth was estimated at A$265 million by 2008.

site_title: Chinese equities: Will it all end in tears?
summary: China's equity bubble may be deflating, with local brokers potentially restricting or removing funds for stock margin lending. This could lead to a sharp sell-down in the markets, as seen when Golden Sun Securities Co removed ChiNext Index stocks from its list, triggering an immediate 5% drop in the Shanghai Composite Index. The regulator's blanket restriction on margin trading could also have a crippling effect on the rally. As the stock SEARAINBOW Holdings Corp trades at 10,000X earnings, its valuation is unsustainable, and the potential for a bubble top is growing.

images.alt_text: Clearly it is a product of the bubble in Chinese equities. The thing is though, that even when this stock was trading at a PE of 5000X a little while back, it would have been classified as expensive. Yet it continued on, managing to double in valuation over a short time.

site_title: A spectacular SEA Games opening!
summary: The 28th SEA Games opened in Singapore with a spectacular ceremony that drew cheers from a 40,000-strong crowd and millions watching on TV. The two-hour show featured over 5,000 performers and volunteers, utilizing the world's largest projection system in any sporting event. The event was a high-tech display of Singapore's capabilities, promising a memorable experience for the athletes and spectators alike.

site_title: Smart Nation know-how the focus of premier ICT show
summary: The CommunicAsia, EnterpriseIT and BroadcastAsia 2015 ICT show in Singapore focused on connectivity and Smart Nation initiatives, attracting 48,000 attendees from 101 countries. Exhibitors showcased various smart nation technologies, including Intelligent Aggregation Gateway, intelligent robots, and EEG brainwave headgear. Industry leaders discussed ICT trends, broadcasting economics, and digital media challenges. Major brands like Panasonic, Dell, Samsung, and Sony launched new products, including 4K broadcast and video capture equipment, IoT gateways, and low-temperature video walls. The event highlighted Singapore's Smart Nation initiative and its efforts to become a hyper-connected digital world.

images.alt_text: Connectivity and Smart Nation - these were the twin themes underlying all that was showcased and discussed at this year's CommunicAsia, EnterpriseIT and BroadcastAsia 2015, which closed on Friday.

site_title: Mers outbreak ups pressure for rate cuts in S Korea
summary: A deadly respiratory disease outbreak in South Korea is putting pressure on the nation's central bank to cut interest rates as early as next week. The outbreak, which could hurt consumer spending and tourism, is expected to deal a damaging blow to the struggling economy. A Bank of Korea official stated that the outbreak increases the pressure for a rate cut, citing the potential impact on consumer spending and tourism. The official's comments come ahead of the central bank's policy committee meeting on June 11.

site_title: Trading value spikes up but STI now in red zone
summary: The Singapore Stock Exchange (STI) ended the week in the red, with a 1.8% decline, despite a spike in trading value. The Straits Times Index (STI) fell 60 points to 3,333.67, driven by weakness in prices and concerns over MSCI's potential introduction of China 'A' shares in its emerging market indices. The market is expected to trade sideways with a downward bias until MSCI's announcement on June 9.

site_title: An enthralling final on the cards
summary: Barcelona and Juventus are set to face off in the Uefa Champions League final on Saturday, with the stakes high for both teams. Barcelona, the reigning La Liga and King's Cup champions, is the hot favourite to lift the trophy, while Juventus, the Italian Cup champion, is looking to win European club football's top prize for the first time since 1996. The match is expected to attract a massive TV audience of 350 million viewers worldwide, with Heineken, a major sponsor of the tournament, gearing up for the big day.

images.alt_text: Lee U-Wen

site_title: Q&M dives on vendor share sale plan
summary: Shares in Q&M Dental Group plummeted 9.6% on Friday after substantial shareholders announced a vendor share sale plan. Quan Min Holdings and Heritas Helios Investments, which own over 3/5 of the dental group, plan to sell up to 46 million shares, or 8.18%, as part of a partial lifting of a moratorium. The move aims to allow the shareholders to monetize their investments and align their interests with the company's long-term future. Q&M's CEO and other executives abstained from voting on the decision.

site_title: Taiwan approves property gains tax
summary: Taiwan's lawmakers approved a property gains tax of up to 45% to curb speculative transactions in the real estate market. The tax will be calculated based on market prices, with exemptions for qualified home sellers with gains of less than NT$4 million. The measure aims to address concerns about unaffordable housing, following a 12-year surge in residential real estate prices in Taipei. The tax will apply to properties bought after January 1, 2016, and is expected to promote stable and healthy development in the long run.

site_title: Queensland's golden produce
summary: Queensland's Sunshine State is home to numerous small farms producing world-class products, showcasing the state's mild climate. The region, particularly the Sunshine Coast, is renowned for its tropical produce, including sugar cane, ginger, and exotic fruits. Local farmers offer farm tours, allowing visitors to sample their products. Notable producers include Maleny Dairies, Gourmet Afrika, Woombye Cheese, Cedar Creek Farm Bush Foods, Cedar Street Cheeserie, Farmer & Sun Shop, CC's Kitchen, and Garnisha Curries. The Sunshine Coast hosts the Noosa International Food and Wine Festival, drawing 30,000 attendees annually, and the Real Food Festival, which brings together local producers and industry professionals.

images.alt_text: Tay Suan Chiang

site_title: Is online no longer on-trend?
summary: E-commerce in Singapore is facing a saturation point, with new online stores and traditional retailers launching digital platforms every month. To stand out, e-tailers are turning to offline stores and localizing merchandise. Companies like Formasian Label and Inverted Edge are incorporating technology into their shopping experiences, using business intelligence software to analyze consumer behavior and transactions. Omnichannel retailers are using data to fine-tune their retail therapy, and independent retailers like The Label Monster are leveraging e-commerce data to improve their performance. Localization is key to success in the competitive Southeast Asian market, according to Zalora's managing director.

site_title: Unwind in stylish seclusion
summary: Sri Panwa, a luxury resort in Phuket, Thailand, offers a tranquil escape from city life. The resort, set on 40 acres of tropical rainforest, features private villas with infinity pools, a spa with tailored treatments based on blood type, and a relaxed atmosphere. Guests can enjoy dining options, including Thai classics and Japanese cuisine, and explore the surrounding area on foot or in converted tuk-tuks. While the location is secluded, the friendly staff and natural beauty of the area create a blissful experience.

site_title: Brokers' take
summary: Singapore stocks recorded a 5-day rally ahead of the release of GDP data, with the STI up 0.4% on Thursday. Investors remained optimistic despite tariff uncertainty and split Fed views. The rally was driven by gains in mining and healthcare stocks. Meanwhile, Q&M Dental Group's shares rose after the company's broker, Maybank Kim Eng, upgraded its rating to "buy". The STI is expected to be influenced by the GDP data, with analysts closely watching the market's response to the economic figures.

site_title: Who needs IMF when you can sell bad debts online?
summary: China's state-owned loan restructurer, China Cinda Asset Management, has partnered with Alibaba Group Holding to dispose of over 4 billion yuan (S$869 million) of non-performing assets on its online shopping platform Taobao. This marks a shift from traditional global development banks to tapping into the internet billionaire Jack Ma's platform to clean up bad debts. The move aims to maximize value, but experts note that the supply of bad loans outpaces demand, leading to lower prices, and that the online auction platform may have limitations due to legal complexities.

site_title: US govt agencies come under big cyber attack
summary: US government agencies, including the Office of Personnel Management, were targeted in a massive cyber attack believed to be carried out by Chinese hackers. The breach may have compromised the personal data of four million current and former federal employees, including healthcare records. The FBI is investigating the attack, which is part of a larger effort by Chinese hackers to obtain healthcare records and personal information. The US government has long raised concerns about cyber spying and theft emanating from China, and officials are urging Beijing to take action to curb the problem.

site_title: Sturdy jobs report boosts chances of Fed rate hike
summary: US job growth accelerated sharply in May, with non-farm payrolls increasing 280,000, the largest gain since December. Wages also picked up, with average hourly earnings rising 2.3% year-over-year, bolstering prospects for an interest rate hike in September. The unemployment rate rose to 5.5% due to more people entering the labor force, but this was not a sign of weakness in the jobs market. The Fed is likely to consider tightening monetary policy this year.

site_title: Gibraltar woos Asian funds with lure of European exposure
summary: Gibraltar is attracting Asian funds with its European exposure, aiming to capitalize on the growing two-way interest between the regions. The territory's tax-friendly environment, new stock exchange, and EU membership offer a gateway for Asian funds to access European investors. Set-up times in Gibraltar are significantly shorter than in other EU markets, with estimated costs being a fraction of the usual expenses. This move is expected to increase visibility for new funds in Europe, allowing them to compete with established players. Gibraltar aims to become the Asian gateway to the European Union.

site_title: Challenger emerges for Eurogroup presidency
summary: Spanish Economy Minister Luis de Guindos is challenging Dutch Finance Minister Jeroen Dijsselbloem for the Eurogroup presidency, a position that has gained importance during Europe's debt crisis. Dijsselbloem, seen as the favourite, has been handling the Greece crisis well but faces uncertain domestic positions. Germany's Chancellor Angela Merkel has not publicly backed either candidate, and both ministers' futures are uncertain. Applications for the 1.5-year term are due next week, with the new chairman serving from July.

site_title: China's online lending boom spurs investment and risk
summary: China's online lending market has seen a significant boom, with at least $32.5 billion in Internet loans given out last year, quadruple the rest of the world combined. This growth is attracting big-name investors, including Tiger Global and Alibaba Group, and is testing China's state-dominated banking system. Regulatory scrutiny is underway, with the government considering rules to maintain oversight of the sector. Despite risks, peer-to-peer lending offers higher interest rates and lower risk than traditional banking options, drawing Chinese investors.

site_title: Cardinal to buy private generic drug distributor for US$1.12 billion
summary: Cardinal Health Inc plans to acquire privately held generic drug distributor Harvard Drug Group for $1.12 billion. The deal is expected to add 15-17 US cents per share to adjusted earnings from 2016 to 2017, according to Cardinal Health. The acquisition aims to expand Cardinal Health's presence in the generic pharmaceutical market.

site_title: Robotics seen drawing venture capitalists back to Japan
summary: Japan is attracting venture capitalists with its development of new robot technology featuring artificial intelligence, according to consultant Koichi Hori. Japan's strengths in engineering play to its advantage in this area, and robotics innovation could be the next phase of technological progress. This shift could help Japan's economy, despite its limited digital media growth.

site_title: The young and the daring
summary: Young chefs in their 20s are opening high-end food stalls in coffeeshops, bridging the gap between fine dining and hawker food. Immanuel Tee, 28, launched his second stall, By The Fire, in Katong, serving Western grilled food like scotch eggs and grilled octopus. His business partner, Alexander Chong, 29, shares similar ambitions, while Shaun Gian, 23, plans to expand his cafe, The Betterfield, by opening three stalls in hawker centers. These entrepreneurs aim to offer high-quality food at affordable prices, with plans to eventually open their own restaurants.

site_title: US job growth surges, wages push higher in May
summary: US job growth surged in May with a 280,000 increase, the largest gain since December, and wages rose 2.3% year-over-year, the largest rise since August 2013. The unemployment rate rose to 5.5% due to more people entering the labor force, but payrolls for March and April were revised to show 32,000 more jobs created. This data suggests a September interest rate hike from the Federal Reserve may be possible, putting pressure on the economy's sluggish growth.

site_title: Get out of the fixed income comfort zone: Amundi
summary: Amundi's head of product specialists, Adrian Bender, advises investors seeking stable income to venture out of their comfort zones due to the current low-yield environment. The firm advocates a relative value approach, investing in high-yield, emerging debt, and currencies. Investors' tolerance for loss has decreased, making it challenging for fund managers to absorb negative performance. Amundi's Bond Global Aggregate Fund seeks to outperform the Barclays Global Aggregate Index by 3.5 percentage points, using strategic and arbitrage strategies to mitigate risk.

images.alt_text: Genevieve Cua

site_title: Telin Singapore starts work on S$155m data hub
summary: Construction on Telin Singapore's S$155 million, 20,000-square-metre data centre, Telin-3, has begun at the newly opened Data Centre Park in Jurong. The facility is expected to be completed in 2016 and will serve as a strategic hub for the group's operations in Southeast Asia. The project is part of Singapore's efforts to solidify its position as an infocomm and media hub, with the government aiming to equip Singaporeans with the right capabilities and develop strong infrastructure.

images.alt_text: ALTOGETHER NOW: (From left) Telin Singapore CEO Septika N Widyasrini; Ms Soemarno; Mr Lee; Ridwan Hassan, deputy chief of mission at the Indonesian embassy in Singapore; and Mr Sinaga at the official groundbreaking ceremony of Telin Singapore Data Centre and Telecommunication Hub on Friday

site_title: Sell and do good
summary: Three Singaporean pop-up shops, Megafash, Be Movement, and 100 Good Things, are selling ethically sourced products for the greater good. Megafash features wood and bamboo items from environmentally friendly brands, while Be Movement showcases artisanal products from social enterprises. 100 Good Things sells sustainably sourced items such as raw forest honey and silk protein soap. The shops aim to promote socially conscious shopping and educate customers about the importance of being environmentally and ethically responsible.

site_title: New technology may end drunk driving
summary: Federal officials announced a technological breakthrough that could virtually eliminate drunken driving, which kills 10,000 Americans annually. A set of sensors or touch-sensitive contact points will register alcohol levels before a driver can start the car, preventing them from driving if the limit is exceeded. The technology, expected to be in cars in five years, is estimated to cost $150-200 per vehicle and will not require drivers to blow into a tube. Researchers have developed passive sensors and touch-based devices, with the goal of producing a device that reacts in less than a second and functions without maintenance for 10 years or 157,000 miles.

site_title: Nestle pulls Maggi noodles from India stores
summary: Nestle has withdrawn Maggi instant noodles from Indian stores due to concerns over excess lead in some packs, despite the product being deemed safe by the company. The move follows weeks of damaging headlines and bans by at least six states, major retailers, and even the Indian army. Nestle's decision comes after criticism of its slow response to the issue and the firm's statement that it will continue to sell the product in other countries.

site_title: US: Wall St opens lower after jobs data
summary: US stocks opened lower on Friday after better-than-expected jobs data, with the Dow Jones industrial average falling 0.18% to 17,873.05. Nonfarm payrolls increased 280,000 last month, beating economists' expectations, and average hourly earnings grew by 8 cents. The jobs data revived the possibility of a rate hike in September.

site_title: EU ruling removes threat of higher costs for insurance sector
summary: The European Union has endorsed insurance rules used in the US, Switzerland, and five other countries as equivalent to its own, allowing insurers to operate in each other's markets without duplicating costs. The decision aims to increase choice and competition for European consumers and enable European insurers to compete more effectively overseas. The new capital rules, Solvency II, will be introduced in January, providing legal certainty for the sector.

site_title: Canada, Mexico push WTO for US$3b sanctions against US
summary: Canada and Mexico are seeking World Trade Organization (WTO) authorization to impose over $3 billion in sanctions against US exports in retaliation against US meat-labelling laws. The laws, enacted in 2009, require labels to indicate the country of origin, making Canadian and Mexican meat products more expensive. The WTO upheld a ruling in May that the US laws discriminate against imported livestock from Canada and Mexico, allowing the two countries to impose trade sanctions. Mexico is seeking $653 million in punitive measures, while Canada is targeting over $3 billion in US exports.

site_title: Indonesian tax drone takes off
summary: Indonesia has launched a tax drone program to catch cheats who underreport the size of their plantations or mineral extraction. The program, which began in April, uses Chinese-made drones to map out areas and gather data on plantations, allowing for more precise tax collection. The government aims to increase tax revenue, which currently stands at 11% of GDP, and is considering a tax amnesty to encourage Indonesians to repatriate overseas funds. The program is seen as a step towards tackling corruption and improving tax collection, but economists warn that achieving the government's ambitious targets will be challenging.

site_title: Food fest with a difference
summary: Chef Ryan Clift, owner of the Tippling Club, praises the Noosa International Food and Wine Festival for its unique atmosphere, describing it as a "laid-back and fun vibe" that sets it apart from other food congresses. The festival, held in a park with live bands, evokes a relaxed atmosphere that Chef Clift finds unmatched. He was invited by festival director Jim Berardo to attend the event, which took place last month.

images.alt_text: Tay Suan Chiang

site_title: Sylvia Lim: MND has 'misrepresented' AHPETC's request for govt grants
summary: The Aljunied-Hougang-Punggol East Town Council (AHPETC), run by the opposition Workers' Party, claims that the Ministry of National Development (MND) has misrepresented its request for government grants without conditions and accountability. AHPETC chairman Sylvia Lim says the town council had agreed to most of the conditions proposed by MND, but MND is now seeking to expedite an appeal against a High Court decision not to appoint independent accountants. MND claims AHPETC has ignored its offers and refuses to answer questions for public accountability. The case will be provisionally heard on August 3.

site_title: Fed seen raising rates in October as job market firms
summary: US Federal Reserve traders now expect a potential interest rate hike as early as October, with a 52% chance of a rate increase at the Fed's second-to-last meeting of the year. The job market showed strength in May, with 280,000 new payrolls and a 2.3% rise in hourly wages, but still below the Fed's target of 3-4% wage gains. This shift in expectations comes after the May jobs report, which initially suggested a delay in rate hikes until December or next year.

site_title: UK may speed up RBS sale to avoid clash with Lloyds exit: sources
summary: Britain may accelerate plans to sell Royal Bank of Scotland shares in September to avoid a conflict with Lloyds Banking Group's full privatization in March 2026. Government officials are examining a possible 3-5 billion pound sale, and bankers consider it a viable option. However, no decisions have been made, according to sources.

site_title: ECB's Smets says no plans to end bond buying programme prematurely
summary: European Central Bank (ECB) governing council member Jan Smets stated that there are no plans to prematurely end the ECB's bond buying programme. Smets mentioned that the programme has shown positive impacts in recent months, but did not provide a specific timeline for its conclusion.

site_title: SingTel rolls out cloud-based network management service
summary: SingTel has launched a cloud-based network management service called ConnectPlus Software-Defined Wide Area Network (SD-WAN), in partnership with Viptela Inc. The service simplifies and centralizes network provisioning and policy management, enabling enterprises to adapt and program their network operations in real-time. With a global reach and market-leading network services, SingTel ConnectPlus customers can easily change their network requirements, reducing operating costs. Multiple Global 2000 enterprise customers are participating in pilot deployments, and the service is supported by over 200 Points-of-Presence worldwide.

site_title: More Greeks want EU/IMF deal accepted than those who do not
summary: A recent Greek opinion poll indicates that nearly half of Greeks want Prime Minister Alexis Tsipras to accept a proposal by international lenders on a cash-for-reforms deal, while 35% believe it should be rejected. The poll also shows that 60% of Greeks support their government's hardline strategy in negotiations with EU/IMF lenders.

site_title: AEC 'a big step, but not end of cooperation'
summary: Singapore Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong stated that the formation of the Asean Economic Community (AEC) by the end of the year is a significant step, but it does not signify the end of cooperation among Asean member states. He noted that outstanding issues, such as the South China Sea dispute, will require continued negotiation and cooperation. Lee emphasized the need for Asean to address regional integration and cooperation, including narrowing the development gap between countries. He also highlighted the importance of addressing pressing global issues, such as the Rohingya refugee crisis, and the role of the opposition in parliament.

site_title: Craft Print completes incorporation of new unit
summary: Craft Print International has completed the incorporation of its new subsidiary, Orient-Salt Chemicals (OSC), a 51-49 joint venture with Jiang Hao. OSC will engage in investment holding, chemicals manufacturing, and trading. This move follows Craft Print's announcement to venture into new business activities, including chemicals manufacturing and distribution, and property investments. Sam Kok Yin, executive director of Craft Print, has been appointed as a director of OSC.

site_title: Greek economy may contract in 2015: European Commission's Dombrovskis
summary: The European Commission's Valdis Dombrovskis warned that Greece's economy may contract in 2015 if it fails to reach a deal with international creditors and restore financial stability. The Commission cut its growth forecast for Greece to 0.5% from 2.5%, citing substantial downside risks. Greece's bailout expires at the end of June, and if it defaults on its debts, the risk of a "Grexit" from the eurozone will rise sharply. The country's economy shrank by 0.2% in the first quarter of 2015, raising concerns about a potential recession.

site_title: SMRT won't exercise option to subscribe for shares in OMG
summary: SMRT Corporation announced it will not exercise its option to subscribe for shares in OMG, a telco company vying for the fourth licence in Singapore. SMRT had agreed to work exclusively with OMG in April and was offered the opportunity to invest up to S$34.5 million. The company decided to allocate its investment focus to rail engineering instead, citing a review of capital allocation priorities. The decision is subject to OMG obtaining the telco licence and executing definitive agreements with SMRT.

site_title: Watchmakers race Apple to introduce smartwatches in Switzerland
summary: Swiss watchmakers are racing against Apple to introduce smartwatches in Switzerland, with several brands, including Montblanc, Frederique Constant, and Movado, set to launch their products in the coming weeks. Montblanc's "e-Strap" allows for mobile payments and tracking physical activity, while Frederique Constant's smartwatch will be available next week. Other brands, such as TAG Heuer and IWC, are also planning to introduce smartwatches later this year. The move is seen as a challenge to Apple's Apple Watch, which enters the market in Switzerland on June 26.

site_title: UK consumers' inflation expectations rise back above 2%
summary: UK consumers' inflation expectations have risen back above 2% to 2.2% in the Bank of England's May Inflation Attitudes survey, up from 1.9% in February. The survey also showed 42% expect interest rates to remain steady, while 38% predict a rise. The Monetary Policy Committee maintained its record-low 0.5% interest rate, citing temporary inflation weakness that will unwind later in the year.

site_title: Singapore Wrap Friday
summary: The Housing & Development Board (HDB) in Singapore has called for the largest solar leasing tender, at 40 megawatt-peak (MWp), in the country's public and private sectors. Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong stated that the Asean Economic Community will be formed by the end of this year, but issues will not be fully resolved. New rules require developers to disclose discounts and perks in the housing market, leading to homebuyers seeking bargains. Investment funds have bought more Noble Group shares after the stock fell to a six-year low.

images.alt_text: The Housing & Development Board (HDB) has called for the first multi-agency solar leasing tender in Singapore, which at 40 megawatt-peak (MWp) is the largest to date in both the public and private sectors in Singapore.

site_title: Shanghai to spend US$3.2 billion to expand city's airport capacity
summary: Shanghai International Airport Co plans to spend $3.2 billion to expand its facilities, including adding passenger and baggage handling capacity, constructing a new apron, and setting up 10 new aerobridges. The upgrade aims to increase the airport's capacity to 80 million passengers per year, from 60 million this year. This expansion is part of China's efforts to address growing air travel demand, which is expected to make the nation the world's largest air-travel market within two decades. The project is set to start in November.

site_title: Helping to open people's minds
summary: Award-winning architect Sou Fujimoto, 44, says his role is to propose new ways for people to live and behave, rather than changing the world. He believes his designs help open people's minds to the idea that architecture can be comfortable and transcendent. Fujimoto's projects, such as the Serpentine Gallery Pavilion and his residential design L'Arbre Blanc, feature light structures and permeable enclosures that reconcile nature and architecture. He hopes his proposals will be developed by architects and lead to a more diverse and flexible approach to architecture in the future.

site_title: Greece postpones IMF payment; snap elections possible
summary: Greece postponed a 300 million euro IMF loan repayment, citing an impasse with lenders that could push the country into bankruptcy and out of the euro. The move, a highly unusual step, raised investor concerns and led to a decline in European stocks. Greek bond yields surged. The delay does not signal a formal default, but a deputy minister hinted at the possibility of snap elections to break the impasse, further escalating tensions in the country's negotiations with creditors.

images.alt_text: Greece delayed repayment of an IMF loan on Friday and a deputy minister said Athens might call snap elections to break an impasse with lenders that threatens to push the country into bankruptcy and out of the euro.

site_title: Najib slammed for failing to face critics on scandal
summary: Malaysia's Prime Minister Najib Razak faced intense criticism for failing to attend a public forum to defend himself against a scandal surrounding the state-owned development company 1Malaysia Development Bhd (1MDB). The event was shut down by police citing "public order and national harmony" concerns, with critics accusing Najib of engineering the cancellation to avoid facing his main accuser, former Prime Minister Mahathir Mohamad. The scandal has led to allegations of billions of dollars in debt and possible mismanagement, with Najib and 1MDB denying wrongdoing.

site_title: Latest earnings
summary: NTT DC Reit's Singapore public offer received 9.8 times oversubscription. Creative Technology warned H2 revenue may be below target, with similar operating loss to H1. London's Heathrow plans to increase fees for its £10 billion upgrade. Indonesia detained a Trafigura employee in a 285 trillion rupiah graft case. OCBC's incoming CEO is Tan Teck Long, a former DBS veteran. MAS and PBOC agreed to deepen cooperation in green and transition finance. Singapore stocks rose for a 5-day rally ahead of GDP data.

site_title: Asean Economic Community a 'big step', but there are next steps in regional cooperation: PM Lee
summary: Singaporean Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong stated that the Asean Economic Community will be formed by the end of 2015, marking a significant step in regional cooperation. However, he noted that this is not the end of the process, with more agenda items to be addressed, including the South China Sea dispute and regional integration. A high-level task force is working on these issues, and Lee expressed optimism about the potential for narrowing development gaps and promoting economic growth through human resource development and trade.

site_title: Malaysia: Stocks end 3.85 points higher
summary: Malaysia's Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rose 3.85 points to 1,745.330 on Friday, with 1.17 billion lots valued at RM1.31 billion traded. Losers outnumbered gainers 412 to 345.

site_title: Update: Opec welcomes back Indonesia
summary: Indonesia has gained approval from all Opec members to rejoin the oil exporters group, with Saudi Arabia's Oil Minister Ali al-Naimi expressing support for the decision. Indonesia's Energy Minister Sudirman Said stated that Indonesia is one of the founders of Opec and Saudi Arabia appreciates the decision, citing Indonesia as a top crude supplier. This move comes after Indonesia's energy ministry submitted a plan to rejoin Opec, marking a significant development in the country's energy sector.

site_title: Oil prices rise after Opec keeps low output target
summary: Oil prices rose on Friday after Opec ministers agreed to maintain their oil production target at 30 million barrels per day for another six months. The decision came despite a Reuters survey showing Opec has been pumping over 31.2 million barrels per day. Brent crude oil rose 80 cents to $62.83, while US crude futures were up 30 cents to $58.30. The market saw the decision as a sigh of relief, but analysts noted the decision did not change the current oversupplied market situation.

site_title: Opec agrees to maintain oil output: delegates
summary: The Organization of the Petroleum Exporting Countries (Opec) agreed to maintain its oil output ceiling, sticking with its plan to tolerate lower prices to defend market share. The decision comes after Brent crude rebounded by over $20 a barrel from January lows and global demand accelerated. Opec's move was widely expected, following its resistance to cutting production in November despite tumbling oil prices. The group aims to balance the market and maintain its influence despite lower prices.

site_title: AHPETC case: Why MND has 'no choice' but to apply to High Court for swift resolution on its appeal
summary: The Ministry of National Development (MND) has decided to apply to the High Court for a swift resolution on its appeal against the non-appointment of independent accountants at Aljunied-Hougang-Punggol East Town Council (AHPETC). MND claims AHPETC has ignored its offers to disburse S&CC grants with safeguards and to appoint independent accountants. AHPETC had requested the entire grant be placed in its sinking funds, a move MND considers unusual. The High Court Judge previously found no basis for AHPETC's objection to the proposed appointment of PwC as Independent Accountants.

site_title: Quake strands about 160 climbers on Malaysian peak
summary: A 6.0-magnitude earthquake struck Mount Kinabalu in Malaysian Borneo, stranding about 160 climbers, including some injured, on the mountain's summit. The quake triggered rockfalls and cut off a main trail, making it difficult for authorities to reach the stranded climbers. Despite some reports of injuries, no deaths have been reported. Authorities are working to deliver supplies, including food and warm clothing, to the climbers as night temperatures are expected to drop. The mountain, a popular tourist destination, has been closed until further notice.

site_title: GP Batteries responds to SGX query
summary: GP Batteries reported a decrease in "bank loans and overdrafts" from S$149.81 million to S$124.93 million for the financial year ended March 31, 2015. The decrease was mainly due to the repayment of borrowings with positive cash flow generated by operating activities and property sales. GP Batteries attributed the decrease to short-term borrowings such as trade finance and money market loans.

site_title: All Singapore primary schools support POSB savings campaign
summary: All 190 primary schools in Singapore have joined POSB's National School Savings Campaign, encouraging students to save their pocket money by buying stamps and pasting them onto a card. Some schools have also requested bank accounts for their students to monitor and manage their finances.

site_title: Brunei withdraw from hosting 2019 SEA Games
summary: Brunei has withdrawn from hosting the 2019 Southeast Asian Games due to lack of government backing, citing insufficient sports facilities, accommodation, and preparation for athletes. The Philippines, set to host the games in 2025, is willing to step in at short notice. The 28th SEA Games will proceed in Singapore with the opening ceremony on Friday, with Malaysia hosting the 2017 event.

site_title: Update: India bans Nestle instant noodles after safety scare
summary: India's Food Safety and Standards Authority has banned the sale and production of Nestle's Maggi instant noodles due to excessive lead levels found in tests. The ban follows a growing scandal after at least six states temporarily banned the product. Nestle, which claims the lead content is below India's legal limit, has already withdrawn the product from sale. The regulator cited risks of kidney and nervous system damage from high lead levels. The ban affects 80% of India's instant noodle market, with widespread outrage on social media.

site_title: Luxembourg to vote on giving foreigners a say in state
summary: Luxembourg is set to vote on extending voting rights to foreigners, a move that could expand the electorate by up to 50% and make it the first EU country to grant equal voting rights to all foreigners. The referendum, backed by liberal Prime Minister Xavier Bettel, aims to modernize the country's voting system, including lowering the voting age to 16 and introducing term limits for ministers. However, recent polls suggest the "No" campaign, backed by Juncker's party, may have an edge, citing concerns over long-time foreign residents seeking citizenship.

site_title: Lloyds fined US$180m for PPI complaints failings
summary: Lloyds Banking Group has been fined £117 million (US$180 million) for failings in handling complaints about the mis-selling of loan insurance between 2012 and 2013. The fine is in addition to £12 billion already set aside to compensate affected customers. Lloyds will also reduce staff bonuses by £30 million in 2015. The bank apologized to customers and acknowledged its failings in handling PPI complaints.

site_title: South Koreans squabble over MERS as more cases appear
summary: South Korea is struggling to contain the Middle East Respiratory Syndrome (MERS) outbreak, with a fourth death reported and five new cases confirmed. The government is at odds with city officials over information sharing and handling of the crisis, fueling public fear and concern. With 41 cases reported, South Korea has the most MERS infections outside the Middle East, where the disease has claimed 440 fatalities. The World Health Organization has not recommended travel restrictions, but many countries have cancelled trips to South Korea.

site_title: India to tighten screws on banks' "window dressing" of accounts
summary: India's government plans to overhaul annual targets for public sector lenders to focus on efficiency, including return on assets and controlling bad debts. The move aims to curb "window dressing" of state banks' financial accounts at year-end, where billions of dollars in loans and deposits are inflated before reversing in the next month. The practice threatens financial stability and obscures the real state of India's financial sector. The government may consider punitive action to back up its push and change the incentive structure for banks.

site_title: Tokyo: Nikkei edges down as market focuses on US jobs data
summary: Japan's Nikkei share average fell 0.1% to 20,460.90 points, ending a three-week winning streak, as investors grew cautious ahead of US jobs data that may signal an increase in US interest rates. The Nikkei 225 shed 0.5% for the week, moving away from a 15-year high. The broader Topix and JPX-Nikkei Index 400 also declined 0.4% each.

site_title: Malaysian jungle graves add to Obama's trade pact headache in Congress
summary: US lawmakers are re-examining President Barack Obama's Trans-Pacific Partnership (TPP) trade deal amid the discovery of 139 graves in Malaysian jungle camps used by suspected smugglers and traffickers of Rohingya Muslims. The graves cast a shadow over the deal, with Democratic Senator Robert Menendez saying he no longer supports a compromise that would allow Malaysia to participate in fast-tracked trade deals despite its Tier 3 ranking on human trafficking. The stricter language could condemn the TPP to a laborious congressional approval process.

site_title: Update: Lloyds CEO bonus reduced after record fine by regulator
summary: Lloyds Banking Group CEO Antonio Horta-Osorio will forfeit £350,000 in bonuses after the bank was fined £117 million for mishandling complaints about mis-sold loan insurance. The Financial Conduct Authority found Lloyds unfairly rejected a significant number of claims between 2012 and 2013. The bank has already set aside £12 billion to compensate customers and has reduced staff bonuses by £30 million. Horta-Osorio's 2014 pay package will also be reduced by £2.65 million, as part of the penalty.

site_title: AXA sets up new units in Singapore, Shanghai, HK
summary: AXA is establishing three units in Singapore, Shanghai, and Hong Kong to strengthen its ties with Asian entrepreneurs and talents. The new units will focus on data analytics and research and development, leveraging the "data revolution" to enhance its products and services. The Singapore unit, called a "Data Innovation Lab," aims to process large volumes of data using advanced technologies. This move is part of AXA's efforts to stay competitive in the rapidly evolving Asian insurance market.

site_title: AirAsia founder's Tune Group considers selling insurance holding
summary: Tune Group, backed by AirAsia founder Tony Fernandes, is considering selling its 16.6% stake in Malaysian insurance venture Tune Ins Holdings Bhd for about US$62 million. The company is working with Credit Suisse on the potential sale and has also discussed the review with an international investment bank. Tune Group regularly assesses its shareholdings and invests in new ventures, and will continue to participate in Tune Ins through AirAsia, which owns 13.7% of the company. The decision is at a preliminary stage and no timeline has been set.

site_title: Taiwan approves 45% property gains tax to rid speculation
summary: Taiwan's lawmakers approved a 45% property gains tax to curb speculation in the real estate market. The tax will apply to property bought after January 1, 2016, and domestic individual sellers will pay between 15% to 45% based on market prices. Qualified sellers with gains of less than NT$4 million (US$130,000) will be exempted. The move aims to address concerns about unaffordable property prices, which have tripled in Taipei over the past 12 years. The tax will be calculated based on market prices, not government-assessed values.

site_title: Hong Kong: Shares slip on uncertainty about Greek aid deal, US jobs data
summary: Hong Kong stocks fell 1.1% to 27,260.16, following global market weakness due to uncertainty over a Greece aid deal and US jobs report. Energy and IT stocks led the decline, while China Enterprises Index lost 1.5%. The Hang Seng index fell 0.6% for the week, contrasting with mainland indexes' 8% gains.

site_title: Lenovo parent Legend gets HK approval for up to US$2b IPO: sources
summary: Legend Holdings Corp, parent of Lenovo Group Ltd, has received Hong Kong stock exchange approval for an initial public offering (IPO) worth up to $2 billion, the largest IPO in the city since 2014. The IPO comes amid a boom in capital markets activity, with $41 billion raised in Hong Kong this year. Legend will start gauging investor interest on Monday and take orders in a roadshow starting the week after. China International Capital Corp and UBS AG were hired as joint sponsors for the IPO.

site_title: Nestle Singapore says its products meet safety standards
summary: Nestle Singapore has reassured consumers that its products meet safety standards, following Singapore authorities' suspension of Maggi instant noodles sales in India due to high lead levels. Nestle's products are manufactured under strict conditions and undergo comprehensive testing to ensure compliance with local and international standards. Although a small amount of Maggi noodles produced in India was imported into Singapore, the Agri-Food and Veterinary Authority has advised importers to stop sales until tests are completed. Nestle prioritizes consumer trust and product safety.

images.alt_text: NESTLE Singapore has moved to reassure consumers of the safety standards of its products after Singapore authorities ordered importers to suspend sales of the Maggi brand instant noodles produced in India.

site_title: AHPETC chairman responds to MND's statement
summary: AHPETC chairman Sylvia Lim has responded to the Ministry of National Development's (MND) statement, calling it a "gross misrepresentation" that the council wants government grants without conditions and accountability. Lim stated that AHPETC had accepted most of MND's proposed conditions for grant disbursement and only two issues remain, including the identity of external accountants and AHPETC's request for grant placement in sinking funds. AHPETC is willing to expedite an appeal to resolve the issues and move forward, but disagrees with MND's reasons for the expedited appeal.

site_title: Indonesia courts Iran over oil supply amid talks to rejoin Opec
summary: Indonesia is seeking a long-term crude oil supply deal with Iran if trade sanctions are lifted, as it talks to Opec on rejoining the group. Indonesia, a net oil importer, is discussing crude supply and investments with the UAE during meetings in Vienna. The country's state oil and gas company, PT Pertamina, is also exploring the possibility of entering the upstream business as operator or shareholder. Iran plans to build a refinery and increase oil exports to Indonesia if sanctions are lifted, and the country needs $200 billion of investment in its oil industry.

site_title: Europe: Stocks drop at open
summary: European stock markets fell at the start of trading Friday, with the FTSE 100 losing 0.44% and the DAX 30 sliding 0.87%. Greece delayed a debt repayment to the IMF, bundling four payments into one, while the IMF cut US growth forecasts to 2.5% due to economic challenges. The US Federal Reserve was urged to refrain from raising interest rates this year by IMF head Christine Lagarde. The markets await the release of US jobs growth data for May, which guides the Fed's rate policy, and an OPEC meeting to determine oil production levels.

site_title: German industrial orders surprisingly strong in April
summary: German industrial orders rose 1.4% in April, exceeding expectations, driven by a 5.5% increase in foreign demand, particularly from the eurozone. Domestic demand fell 3.8% during the same period. The Bundesbank lifted its growth forecast for Germany, expecting the economy to expand by 1.7% in 2015 and 1.8% in 2016. The strong industrial orders have brightened the outlook for the second quarter, with analysts predicting a 0.5% growth.

site_title: Update: US confirms data on 4 million govt staff hacked
summary: The US government has confirmed that hackers accessed the personal data of at least 4 million current and former federal employees in a suspected Chinese cyber-attack. The breach, uncovered in April, may have originated from Chinese hackers, but the Chinese embassy denied any involvement. The Office of Personnel Management will notify affected parties and offer identity theft protection services at no cost. This is the latest in a series of major breaches affecting the federal government, including a Russian hack on the White House and State Department last year.

site_title: Singapore: Week sees STI drop into the red for the year, but volume rises
summary: The Straits Times Index (STI) dropped 1.8% over the week, marking the first time it's in the red for 2015, with a total decline of 60 points. Despite a rise in trading volume, mainly driven by a large sell-off in bond markets, the market experienced weakness in prices. The STI opened the week at 3,333.67 and closed at 3,272.89.

site_title: Gold near 5-week low ahead of US jobs data, eyes 3rd weekly drop
summary: Gold prices near a 5-week low ahead of US jobs data, with a possible third weekly decline. The metal is down 1% for the week at US$1,177.80 an ounce. Strong US economic data and expectations of an interest rate hike bolstered expectations of lower demand for gold. The nonfarm payrolls report, due later, may dictate gold's near-term price direction, with a lower-than-expected number seen as positive for gold.

site_title: Nestle withdraws Maggi noodles in India after food scare
