summary: Nestle has withdrawn Maggi noodles in India due to "an environment of confusion for consumers" following high lead levels found in some packets in Uttar Pradesh. The company stated that despite the product being safe, recent developments and unfounded concerns led to the withdrawal. This decision aims to restore consumer trust and safety.

site_title: Colourful Australian businessman Alan Bond dies
summary: Australian businessman Alan Bond, 77, died Friday after complications from open heart surgery. He was a former America's Cup hero who led Australia II to a historic win in 1983, but was later convicted of swindling Aus$1.2 billion in 1996. Bond, who emigrated from Britain at 11, was bankrupted and served three years in jail for corporate fraud. His children announced his death outside a Perth hospital, stating he never regained consciousness after surgery.

site_title: Myanmar's Suu Kyi to make first visit to China
summary: Myanmar's opposition leader Aung San Suu Kyi will visit China from June 10-14, meeting President Xi Jinping and Premier Li Keqiang. The trip comes amid strained relations between the two countries, as Myanmar seeks to reduce its dependence on China. Suu Kyi's National League for Democracy party is expected to perform well in the upcoming general election in November, increasing her power and influence. The visit is seen as a strategic move by Suu Kyi to strengthen ties with China, despite international criticism of her silence on the Rohingya minority's treatment.

site_title: Broker's Take: OCBC upgrades Ezra to 'hold'
summary: OCBC Investment Research has upgraded its rating for offshore marine services firm Ezra to "hold" after a recent price correction. The stock fell 22% following the announcement of a rights issue and convertible bonds to raise US$300 million. The analysts expect the group to raise US$150 million from the rights issue if shareholders approve it. With the share price corrected to S$0.305, the rating is raised to "hold" due to the group's ability to repay debt and maintain financial stability.

site_title: Massive cyber attack hits US federal workers, probe focuses on China
summary: A massive cyber attack hit US federal workers, possibly compromising the personal data of 4 million current and former employees. The breach occurred at the Office of Personnel Management, which handles employee records and security clearances. Investigators believe a "foreign entity or government," possibly based in China, was behind the attack. The US government has long raised concerns about cyber spying and theft emanating from China, and authorities are probing the incident. The FBI has launched a probe, and the agencies involved are implementing additional security precautions for their networks.

site_title: Alibaba puts in new application to invest in Taiwan: regulator
summary: Alibaba Group Holding Ltd, a Chinese e-commerce giant, has submitted a new application to invest in Taiwan under rules for mainland-backed companies. The application is currently being reviewed by Taiwan's Investment Commission, which has previously fined Alibaba and its online marketplace Taobao for violating investment rules. This is the second application submitted by Alibaba, with a six-month deadline set for Taobao's online operations in Taiwan. Chinese investments in Taiwan are strictly regulated due to the sensitive political relationship between China and Taiwan.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open 0.44% lower
summary: Tokyo stocks opened 0.44% lower on June 5, 2015, due to concerns over the US economy and Greece's debt issues. The IMF cut its US growth forecast to 2.5% and urged the Federal Reserve to hold off on a rate hike. Greece removed a debt repayment block, but investors await the May US jobs report and OPEC policy announcement, both scheduled for Friday.

site_title: HDB calls for largest solar leasing tender in Singapore
summary: The Housing & Development Board (HDB) in Singapore has called for the largest solar leasing tender in the country, worth 40 megawatt-peak (MWp), to power 900 HDB blocks and 8 government sites. The tender, under the government-led SolarNova program, aims to spur the growth of the solar industry in Singapore and contribute 350 MWp of solar power to the system by 2020. The installation is expected to be completed by the end of this month, with a total of about 2,000 HDB blocks to be powered by solar energy by then.

site_title: Singapore's homebuyers to seek bargains on discounts disclosure
summary: Singapore homebuyers will have more bargaining power as the Urban Redevelopment Authority starts publishing weekly net prices of home transactions, accounting for discounts and incentives. The move aims to improve transparency in the already depressed housing market. Homebuyers can now use this information to negotiate better prices, with brokers expecting more buyers to drive harder bargains. The new rules follow a S$181 million lawsuit over hefty furniture rebates in the luxury Marina Collection. The move is expected to give buyers additional leverage in negotiations.

site_title: Singapore-based fintech startup Mesitis raises US$3m
summary: Singapore-based fintech startup Mesitis has raised US$3 million in Series A Funding to expand its account aggregation platform, Canopy. The platform, launched in late 2014, aggregates financial data from various banks and asset classes. Mesitis' customers include wealth managers, family offices, and private banks, with the platform currently managing over S$1.1 billion in assets. The funding was raised from individuals and employees, with CEO Tanmai Sharma describing it as a "great vote of confidence" in the company.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks open marginally lower
summary: Hong Kong stocks opened marginally lower on Friday, edging 13.83 points down to 27,538.06, following losses on Wall Street ahead of a key US jobs report.

site_title: Malaysian ringgit drops most in Asia this week as crude declines
summary: Malaysia's ringgit dropped 1.2% from May 29 and 0.4% on Friday to 3.7132 a dollar, its third week of losses, due to a 5.2% drop in Brent crude and concerns over US interest rate hikes. The country's energy-related revenue and exports contracted in April, while the trade surplus narrowed. The decline in oil prices has made Malaysia the most exposed to lower commodity prices, particularly oil.

site_title: Record property loans drive Japan real estate recovery
summary: Japan's property market is experiencing a strong recovery, driven by record property lending, with loans reaching 3.82 trillion yen ($31 billion) in the first quarter. Land prices in major metropolitan areas are rising for the second year, and condominium prices have increased by 26.5% compared to a decade ago. The Bank of Japan's efforts to end deflation are bearing fruit, but policymakers are flagging risks of increased risk-taking and inflows of money.

site_title: Taiwan: Stocks stabilise; TSMC leads techs lower
summary: Taiwan's stocks fell 0.2% on Friday, with TSMC leading tech stocks lower, closing at 4-1/2-month lows. TSMC slid 1% to T$139.5, weighing on electronics shares. Banks rose 0.2%, while the Taiwan dollar strengthened to T$30.899 to the US dollar.

site_title: Damage, some injuries as quake jolts Malaysia's Borneo
summary: A 6.0-magnitude earthquake struck near Malaysia's Mount Kinabalu on Borneo, injuring at least four climbers and causing damage to roads and buildings. The quake, which lasted around 15 seconds, also snapped off a rock outcropping from the mountain's summit. Climbing activities have been halted until further notice, and authorities are working to bring down the injured climbers using helicopters. No tsunami warning was issued, and there were no initial reports of major damage, but social media users uploaded photos showing damaged infrastructure.

site_title: Hot stock: Q&M plunges on vendor sale announcement
summary: Q&M Dental Group shares plummeted 7.4% in early trade on Friday after substantial shareholders Quan Min Holdings and Heritas Helios Investments announced plans to undertake a vendor sale. The stock opened at S$0.90 and traded at S$0.87, with 52.3 million shares changing hands. The sale is the second most traded stock on the Singapore Exchange.

site_title: LTA seeks ideas to harness self-driving vehicles technology
summary: The Land Transport Authority (LTA) of Singapore is seeking proposals on harnessing self-driving vehicle technology for land transport planning. The proposals could include autonomous buses and a network of demand-responsive cars to reduce reliance on private cars. LTA aims to create an open platform in one-north for joint Proof-of-Concept trials, with shortlisted proposers allowed to test their concepts at a six-km long AV testbed. The RFI proposals are expected to be concluded by the third quarter of this year, with the goal of leveraging AV technology to optimize road capacity and facilitate efficient vehicle sharing.

site_title: Malaysia's April exports fall more than expected on lower gas prices
summary: Malaysia's exports declined 8.8% in April from a year earlier, exceeding expectations, due to lower gas prices. Imports also fell 8.8% from a year earlier, driven by weakened consumer spending after the implementation of a 6% GST on April 1. Analysts had forecast a 6.2% decline in exports and flat imports. The weaker-than-expected exports data may pose a challenge for the country's economic growth.

site_title: CityDev falls 3.6% on removal from FTSE EPRA/NAREIT Global Developed Index
summary: City Developments fell 3.6% after being removed from the FTSE EPRA/NAREIT Global Developed Index, effective June 22, 2015. The company's share price dropped to S$9.70 before rebounding to S$9.85. The removal was announced following the quarterly review for the Asia region. Over 3 million shares changed hands in early trade.

images.alt_text: Angela Tan

site_title: Saudi oil minister 100% comfortable with market: Saudi-owned al-Hayat newspaper
summary: Saudi Arabia's oil minister Ali al-Naimi expressed confidence in the oil market, stating he is 100% comfortable with current prices. Ahead of an Opec meeting, al-Naimi attributed rising demand and a slight improvement in global growth to the current market conditions. He defended Opec's decision not to cut production in November, citing accurate predictions. Al-Naimi also downplayed concerns about the price level, saying it's determined by market forces and can fluctuate daily.

site_title: Death toll climbs to 97 as China rights capsized ship
summary: A Chinese cruise ship capsized on the Yangtze River, killing 97 people, with 14 survivors found, including the captain. Rescuers worked through the night to right the ship and recover bodies, with over 200 divers searching the vessel. Authorities have faced criticism from distraught families for lack of information and handling of the disaster. Police have detained the captain and chief engineer for questioning, and the government has pledged a thorough investigation. The incident has sparked anger and calls for greater transparency, with relatives demanding to know why the ship did not dock in the storm and how survivors managed to put on life vests.

images.alt_text: The death toll from a Chinese cruise ship that capsized on the Yangtze River climbed to 97 on Friday as authorities righted the battered vessel and turned their efforts to recovering bodies still on board amid simmering anger from distraught families.

site_title: Australia: Shares shaky, on track for worst week in three years
summary: Australian shares fell to their lowest in over four months, with the S&P/ASX 200 index down nearly 5.0% on the week, its worst performance in three years. Bank stocks, particularly Westpac, led the decline, with the bank's stock reaching a low not seen since February 2014. Despite some bargain hunting, the market remains cautious, with smaller stocks offering significant price action. The decline is partly driven by renewed weakness in the banking sector, following disappointing earnings and forecasts.

site_title: Navis said to buy Singapore's Super Peking Duck restaurant chain
summary: Navis Capital Partners Ltd has agreed to buy a majority stake in Imperial Treasure Restaurant Group Pte, the Singapore company behind the popular "Super Peking Duck" eateries, for S$60 million to S$80 million. Founder Alfred Leung will retain his stake and remain involved in the business, which aims to accelerate expansion in China and fine-dining cuisine. The investment will help Imperial Treasure expand its presence in both countries.

site_title: Police chief orders Najib dialogue to be cancelled
summary: Malaysia's scheduled "Nothing2Hide" dialogue between Prime Minister Datuk Seri Najib Tun Razak and NGOs on the 1MDB scandal has been cancelled due to public safety concerns raised by the Inspector General of Police, Tan Sri Khalid Abu Bakar, in a Twitter message.

site_title: Stocks to watch: KTL Global, Noble
summary: KTL Global acquired a 20% stake in Korean rigging equipment firm Dae Kwang for $5 million, aiming to expand into the Korean offshore and marine industry. Investment funds purchased Noble Group shares after the stock hit a six-year low, with its founder buying more shares despite the decline.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open higher on Friday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index opened higher on Friday, up 2.06 points to 1743.16. The index saw 31.1 million lots traded worth RM13.7 million, with 101 gainers outnumbering 97 losers.

site_title: Asia: Stocks mostly down, euro sinks as Greece delays payment
summary: Asian markets declined on Friday, following a lower US stock market and concerns over Greece's debt repayments. The IMF cut its US growth outlook, and the euro fell against the dollar and yen. Tokyo, Hong Kong, and Seoul fell, while Shanghai rose 1.54%. The delay in Greece's debt payments gives Athens until the end of the month to reach an agreement with creditors. The delay has raised concerns that stumbling blocks remain, impacting global markets.

site_title: Disenchanted Chinese tech companies plot escape from New York
summary: Chinese tech companies are planning to drop their New York listings and return to China, seeking higher share valuations and avoiding foreign shareholder control restrictions. The move follows China's relaxation of profitability requirements and easing of regulatory hurdles. Analysts expect dozens of lesser-known companies to follow, and Chinese investment firms are lining up to assist the repatriation. The trend is seen as a shift in favor of Chinese companies, with China's tech-driven ChiNext composite index gaining nearly 180% this year, eclipsing the 30% rise in the Nasdaq OMX China Technology Index.

site_title: China: Shanghai Composite Index tops 5,000 for first time since 2008
summary: China's Shanghai Composite Index reached a 7-year high, surpassing 5,000 points for the first time since 2008. The index rose 2% to 5,046.04, driven by gains in Bank of China Ltd and PetroChina Co. The rally has added over $4 trillion to China's market capitalization, fueled by record margin debt and government efforts to boost faltering growth.

site_title: Philippine May inflation slows to weakest in at least 9 years
summary: The Philippine economy experienced its slowest annual inflation in at least 9 years in May, with a 1.6% rise from last year, below analyst predictions. This decline in inflation gives the central bank more flexibility to lower interest rates to stimulate growth. Core inflation, which excludes volatile food and fuel prices, remained at 2.2%. On a month-on-month basis, prices fell 0.1% in May, the first decline in three months.

site_title: Oil prices edge up in cautious trading ahead of Opec meeting
summary: Oil prices rose in cautious trading ahead of an OPEC meeting, stabilizing after a 5% drop in the previous two sessions. Traders are wary of a surprise outcome, which could impact crude markets. Iraq's expected 5% increase in oil exports in June is also contributing to the market's volatility. Despite fundamentals remaining unchanged, some traders expect a decrease in US rig activity to lead to lower production. The OPEC meeting is expected to maintain the global oversupply, potentially keeping prices stable.

images.alt_text: Oil markets stabilised in cautious trading on Friday ahead of an OPEC decision that is likely to keep the market oversupplied and sets aside warnings of a second lurch lower in prices as some members like Iraq and Iran look to ramp up exports.

site_title: NYC building that houses American Girl store going on market
summary: SL Green Realty Corp is preparing to market 609 Fifth Ave, a 156,000-square-foot Manhattan office and retail building housing the American Girl Place toy store. The building, which is 81% occupied, may fetch around $600 million, reflecting demand for high-rent retail properties in the area. The lease with American Girl expires in early 2018, offering a buyer the opportunity to boost rents. The sale is part of SL Green's plan to complete its $2.29 billion acquisition of 11 Madison Ave and capitalize on rising real estate values along Fifth Avenue.

images.alt_text: People arrive at an Apple store on Fifth Avenue in New York on April 9, 2015.

site_title: Strong 6.0-magnitude quake strikes Malaysia's Borneo
summary: A 6.0-magnitude earthquake struck Malaysia's Borneo island, specifically the district of Sabah, on June 5, 2015. The quake, at a depth of 10km, was located 19km from Ranau and 54km from Kota Kinabalu. There were no reports of damage or a tsunami warning issued. Malaysia is outside the Ring of Fire, a region prone to seismic activity.

site_title: Singapore: Shares open weaker on Friday
summary: The Singapore market opened weaker on Friday, June 5, 2015, amid uncertainty over Greece's payment to the International Monetary Fund. The Straits Times Index declined 7.38 points, or 0.22%, to 3,337.62 points. Trading volume was 107.4 million shares worth S$148.1 million.

site_title: Chinese premier encourages start-up firms to list locally
summary: Chinese Premier Li Keqiang announced plans to promote domestic listings of start-up firms with special ownership structures, aiming to encourage innovation and boost funding for productive sectors. The government will also develop the venture capital industry and provide tax incentives to start-up firms and angel investors. This move is part of China's efforts to relax rules for domestic listings and develop over-the-counter equity markets, giving start-up firms easier access to funding, despite some firms currently using the variable interest entity (VIE) structure to meet overseas regulatory requirements.

site_title: Europe: Shares pare losses as yields and euro ease on US data
summary: European shares closed down 0.9% at 1,557.25 points, pausing losses after US unemployment benefit claims data showed a resilient labor market, boosting the dollar and easing euro yields. The euro also rallied, aiding euro zone shares and government bonds.

site_title: NSA expands online spying in search for hackers: report
summary: The NSA has been granted wider powers to spy on internet traffic in search of computer hacking by foreign governments or others, according to classified documents. The Justice Department permitted the agency to track addresses and patterns linked to foreign governments, as well as spy on online targets as long as they are linked to "malicious cyber activity". The move aims to counter a growing cyber threat, but critics argue it could push the agency into areas traditionally reserved for domestic law enforcement.

site_title: South Korea reports fourth death from Mers outbreak
summary: South Korea reported its fourth death from the Mers virus outbreak, a 76-year-old patient who died after testing positive on May 21. The health ministry confirmed five new cases, bringing the total number of diagnosed cases to 41. This is the largest outbreak of Mers outside Saudi Arabia, with hundreds of schools closed and thousands of travel plans canceled.

site_title: US says 4 million current, former federal employees affected by data breach
summary: The US Office of Personnel Management (OPM) disclosed that a cyberattack compromised the data of approximately 4 million current and former federal employees. The breach is suspected to have originated in China, and the FBI is investigating. OPM has implemented additional security measures and will notify the affected individuals, offering credit monitoring and identity theft services. This is the second cyberattack to target the agency, following a previous incident in 2014.

site_title: Thai factory output set to rebound in second half: ministry
summary: Thai factory output is expected to rebound in the second half of 2015, driven by revived private and public investment and a improving global economy. The industrial sector accounts for 40% of Thailand's economy, with manufacturing production index falling every month except February over the past two years. The recovery is attributed to the sector's resilience and the Thai government's efforts to stimulate growth.

site_title: Oil prices move little in cautious trading ahead of Opec meeting
summary: Oil prices remained relatively stable in cautious trading ahead of an Opec meeting, with Brent futures trading at $62.08 per barrel and US crude futures at $57.95. The meeting is expected to maintain the existing output ceiling, supporting Saudi Arabia and continuing to oversupply the market. Despite oil prices rebounding by over 30% since hitting a six-year low in January, traders are wary of taking big positions due to potential surprise outcomes. Opec's decision is seen as keeping the market oversupplied, with Iraq's exports expected to rise 5% in June.

site_title: Pace of UK hiring slows in May: REC recruiters group
summary: The UK job market experienced a slowdown in May, with the rate of expansion in permanent staff placements at a four-month low, according to a survey by the Recruitment and Employment Confederation (REC) and KPMG. Vacancies rose at the slowest rate in 2015, while starting salaries for permanent jobs grew but at a slower pace. The Bank of England is closely monitoring the labour market as it considers raising interest rates. This slowdown is attributed to the outcome of national elections in May, which led to uncertainty and a delay in business decisions.

site_title: Invesco follows other funds to buy more of Noble after stock dives
summary: Investment fund Invesco has acquired 1.18 million shares of Noble Group, increasing its stake to 5.01% after the company's stock fell to a six-year low. Noble's shares have declined over 35% this year amid criticism of its accounting practices and lack of transparency. The company's founder, Richard Elman, has also been buying shares to try to stabilize the stock price. Other investors, such as Prudential, have increased their stakes, with Prudential holding 7.2% of the company.

site_title: Greece delays IMF payment, PM to brief angry parliament
summary: Greece has delayed a key debt payment to the International Monetary Fund due on June 30, with Prime Minister Alexis Tsipras postponing four payments into a single 1.6 billion euro lump sum. The delay comes as talks with international creditors on a cash-for-reforms deal are still far from reaching an agreement, with Tsipras rejecting pension cuts and a tax rise on electricity. The delay highlights the risk of a revolt in Tsipras' Syriza party if he accepts a deal crossing the party's "red lines."

site_title: Dish, T-Mobile US talk merger, wireless spectrum a key factor
summary: T-Mobile US Inc and Dish Network Corp are in talks to merge, with Dish providing T-Mobile with its spectrum holdings to become the second-largest wireless carrier in the US. The deal would give T-Mobile access to mid-band frequency spectrum and low-frequency airwaves, allowing it to leapfrog rivals Verizon and AT&T. The merger is seen as a strategic move to strengthen T-Mobile's US business, and regulators are unlikely to raise substantial antitrust concerns. The deal would also follow a similar structure to a pending merger between AT&T and Dish's rival DirecTV.

site_title: Yahoo to shut down Maps, some other services June 4
summary: Yahoo Inc is shutting down Yahoo Maps by the end of June 2015, citing intense competition from Google's Maps service. The service will still be supported through Yahoo's search and other services, including Flickr. The move is part of Yahoo's realignment to focus on search and digital content.

site_title: Fed doves' ranks may be growing, possibly pushing hike into 2016
summary: Federal Reserve Chair Janet Yellen initially predicted a rate hike in 2015, but some of her colleagues are now suggesting a delay until late 2015 or 2016 due to international economic concerns and US consumer reluctance. The May job numbers, expected to show a 225,000 gain, could influence the dovish camp. A disappointing reading could strengthen the argument for a delay, potentially pushing the rate hike into 2016.

site_title: Virgin America pilots vote for unionisation
summary: Virgin America pilots voted to be represented by the Air Line Pilots Association, International (ALPA), with 75.3% of eligible pilots supporting unionization. This marks the end of Virgin America's run as the last major US carrier without collective representation for pilots. The airline currently employs 612 pilots and has been partly owned by Richard Branson.

site_title: BNP Paribas to cut costs in investment banking: Les Echos
summary: French bank BNP Paribas plans to cut costs by 20% and increase revenue by 7% in its investment banking business to achieve a 20% return on notional equity (RONE) by 2019, according to Les Echos. The bank aims to boost revenue while reducing expenses, as part of a strategy to improve its investment banking performance.

site_title: Fracking not a 'widespread risk' to drinking water: US EPA
summary: The US Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) has released a draft report stating that fracking for shale oil and gas does not pose a widespread risk to drinking water, despite some isolated cases of contamination. The study found that the mechanisms leading to contamination are rare and that the number of identified cases is small compared to the number of hydraulically fractured wells. However, the report acknowledges potential risks and notes that other factors, such as inadequately cased or cemented wells, could also contaminate drinking water.

site_title: Poland's Swiss franc mortgages seen as 'ticking bomb'
summary: Poland's central bank governor Marek Belka has warned that Swiss franc-denominated mortgages, totaling 144 billion zlotys (S$52.6 billion), pose a "ticking bomb" due to the potential for the Swiss franc to strengthen against the zloty, making loan repayments more difficult. Belka urged banks to convert the loans into zlotys, potentially at their own expense, to avoid a costly conversion. The central bank maintains its interest rate stance unchanged, citing robust economic growth and expected inflation.

site_title: Exploring the relationship between 2 lands through objects
summary: Malaysian-born artist Ahmad Abu Bakar explores the relationship between his two lands through objects in his exhibition "Tanah Ini Ku Punya II - Siri Objek & Objektif" at Chan Hampe Galleries in Singapore. The show features ceramic vessels with geometric forms and organic extensions, representing his experience living in Singapore and combining structure with raw, organic elements. The tension and harmony in his works reference his dual identity and relationship with Malaysia, reflecting his journey of belonging to two lands.

site_title: Alarm grows as S Korea reports third Mers death
summary: South Korea reported its third death from Middle East Respiratory Syndrome (Mers), a virus outbreak that has spread to over 1,600 people, mostly in hospitals. The 82-year-old man, who had asthma and bacterial pneumonia, died after sharing a room with others infected with Mers. This brings the total number of confirmed Mers infections in South Korea to 36. The outbreak, which began two weeks ago, has prompted the government to close over 1,100 schools and consider border checks with North Korea.

site_title: US: Wall St drops before jobs report; Greece worries linger
summary: US stocks fell on Thursday ahead of the jobs report, weighed by declining oil and gold prices and lingering Greece aid uncertainty. The S&P 500 declined 0.86%, while the Dow Jones industrial average fell 0.94%. The jobs report is expected to show a 225,000 gain in non-farm payrolls, with some investors hoping for a strong number that could prompt the Federal Reserve to raise interest rates sooner. Greece delayed a debt payment and German Chancellor Merkel expressed concerns over a cash-for-reforms deal.

site_title: Apple's challenge is getting China users to pay for apps
summary: Apple has successfully persuaded developers in China to create apps for the iPhone, making the country the largest market for downloads last quarter. However, the challenge now lies in getting Chinese users to pay for software, as downloads outpaced revenue. Apple's CEO Tim Cook aims to encourage Chinese programmers and developers, with over 5,000 attendees at the upcoming developer conference. The company estimates 1.5 million jobs have been created in China due to iOS apps, with Chinese developers paid $3.4 billion since the App Store's introduction.

site_title: US Fed's bond-buying: Welfare for the wealthy?
summary: The Federal Reserve's massive bond-buying program, worth over $3 trillion, has sparked debate about its impact on economic inequality. While some argue it benefited the wealthy, a Brookings Institution conference concluded that the program may have helped the middle class and poor more than the upper class. Research by economists Josh Bivens and Susan Lund found that younger households experienced gains, while older households suffered losses. However, a former Fed chairman, Ben Bernanke, echoed Bivens's conclusions that the program promoted equality. The Fed should focus on its core goals of stable prices and maximum employment, leaving distributional issues to elected officials.

site_title: Gold hits 5-week low as US data offsets weaker dollar
summary: Gold prices fell 0.8% to a five-week low of $1,175.53 an ounce due to robust US economic data, which may prompt the Federal Reserve to raise interest rates this year. The US dollar initially weakened but recovered, offsetting the impact on gold prices. Traders will closely watch Friday's non-farm payrolls data for further guidance.

images.alt_text: Gold prices fell on Thursday, shrugging off early weakness in the US dollar and hitting five-week lows as robust US economic data fed expectations that the Federal Reserve could raise interest rates this year.

site_title: AsiaMedic soars as new stakeholder emerges
summary: AsiaMedic's shares surged 18.2% on Thursday, closing at 13 Singapore cents, following the emergence of a new controlling stakeholder. The company's shares jumped 64% the previous day after the announcement.

images.alt_text: Prisca Ang

site_title: Songs about death and sorrow laced with hope and love
summary: Sufjan Stevens releases album 'Carrie & Lowell' after his mother's death in 2012. The album features songs about death, sorrow, and hope, with Lowell Brams, Stevens' stepfather, co-producing the record. Stevens' music is compared to that of Bob Dylan and James Taylor, known for resonating with unexpected audiences. The album marks a personal and emotional journey for Stevens, reflecting on his relationship with his mother and stepfather.

images.alt_text: Christopher Lim

site_title: Greek PM to plot next move as talks stalemate persists
summary: Greek Prime Minister Alexis Tsipras will convene his inner circle to plot the next move in the standoff with international creditors after talks with European leaders and the International Monetary Fund failed to yield a breakthrough. Tsipras stuck to his position that any basis for an accord must be a Greek proposal, rejecting creditor demands for spending cuts and tax increases. Greece faces four payments to the IMF totaling over 1.5 billion euros by June, while its euro-area-backed bailout also expires this month, and Tsipras has signaled that Greece will meet the first payment.

site_title: Bank Indonesia relaxes derivatives rules to rein in rupiah
summary: Bank Indonesia has relaxed rules on derivatives to rein in the rupiah's volatility, aiming to double the role of derivatives in the onshore foreign exchange market by 2020. The central bank has allowed cross-currency swaps, erased a 30-minute net position requirement, and shortened contract durations to increase liquidity and hedge against exchange-rate swings. The changes are expected to boost demand for derivative products, particularly among local companies with foreign currency debt, as the US prepares to raise borrowing costs. The rupiah's one-month implied volatility stands at 10.5%, the highest among Asia's emerging-market currencies.

site_title: Alibaba fluffs first rule of being a movie villain
summary: Alibaba Pictures is raising HK$12.2 billion, diluting existing shareholders and leaving the company as a loss-making cash shell. The company's acquisition war chest will account for 90% of its pro-forma assets, valued at around four times face value. The new capital raising was done at an 18.9% discount to the previous share price, resulting in a US$200 million paper profit for new investors. Minority investors remain optimistic about the company's potential to become China's answer to a global production studio, despite the lack of explanation of its strategy.

site_title: Fewer bosses give low-wage staff a raise as their numbers dip
summary: Singapore's low-wage workers saw a 14.2% average pay rise in 2014, but fewer employers gave raises, with 59% of companies with low-wage workers increasing pay, down from 77% in 2013. Total wage growth eased to 4.9%, while real wages increased 3.9% due to lower inflation. Labour productivity growth lagged behind real wages, and the economy grew at a slower pace, with 2.9% growth in 2014, down from 4.4% in 2013.

site_title: Malaysia tries to convince Fitch that economy is resilient
summary: Malaysia is seeking to convince Fitch Ratings that its economy is resilient ahead of a sovereign rating decision. Despite efforts by the finance ministry to demonstrate its commitment to a managed float system and fiscal consolidation plans, concerns over the 1MDB scandal and the country's reliance on petroleum-related earnings may still lead to a downgrade of its sovereign ratings. Fitch has indicated a 50% chance of a downgrade, citing the government's explicit guarantees on a substantial portion of 1MDB's debts.

site_title: Bank of Singapore stays upbeat on equities market: CIO
summary: Bank of Singapore's Chief Investment Officer Hou Wey Fook remains optimistic about the equities market, despite a global reflation cycle. He noted that different regions are at varying stages of the cycle.

site_title: Ku De Ta nightclub is now Ce La Vi
summary: Ku De Ta nightclub in Singapore has been rebranded as Ce La Vi, following a court ruling that allowed the entertainment entity to stop using the Ku De Ta name after a five-year legal battle. L Capital, the controlling stakeholder, unveiled the new brand with plans for a Ce La Vi outlet in Hong Kong and a significant renovation of the Singapore outlet. The company aims to establish Ce La Vi as "the international titan of lifestyle and sophisticated hedonism" with a five-year expansion plan to open new venues globally.

site_title: Start the morning with a bang
summary: Zespri, a kiwifruit marketer, is hosting "Zespri Golden Mornings" in London from June 8-12, promoting a healthier lifestyle through early morning activities such as indoor cycling, Vinyasa yoga, and a pre-work party. The events, organized in collaboration with local fitness studios and clubs, aim to encourage a positive approach to fitness and healthy living. The activities are free, but spaces are limited, and participants can register online. The events will culminate in a unique morning party, featuring healthy food and drinks, and are designed to be fun and refreshing ways to start the day.

site_title: MAS: Covered bond structure a commercial decision
summary: The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) stated that the proposed covered bond structure, including an alternative ring-fencing declaration of trust (DoT) structure, is a commercial decision by the issuing bank. The proposed amendments to Notice 648 on covered bond issuance aim to provide operational flexibility to banks seeking to issue covered bonds in Singapore. This decision follows feedback on the proposed amendments, which were detailed in a January consultation paper. The MAS is refining the regulatory framework to support the issuance of covered bonds in Singapore.

site_title: Daim's son sued over debt to buy LionGold shares
summary: Maybank Kim Eng Securities filed a S$2.6 million lawsuit against LionGold deputy chairman Md Wira Dani Abdul Daim, son of Malaysia's former finance minister Daim Zainuddin, for unpaid debts related to leveraged LionGold shares. The debt is part of a broader wave of legal actions by banks and broking firms to recover tens of millions of dollars from affected directors following the 2013 share price plunge. LionGold's financial struggles continue, with a loss of S$52 million for the year ended March 2015.

images.alt_text: Anita Gabriel

site_title: EDB unit backs cybersecurity company CounterTack
summary: EDBI, the Singapore Economic Development Board's investment arm, has invested US$15 million in Series C funding for US cybersecurity company CounterTack. The investment, led by TenEleven Ventures, aims to help CounterTack expand in Singapore and Asia. CounterTack's Sentinel platform uses big data to detect threat patterns and anticipate online attacks, providing a comprehensive approach to endpoint detection and response. The investment will support the company's go-to-market strategy and deliver scalable next-generation EDR technology to its customers.

site_title: India boss finds there's no such thing as a free lunch after all
summary: Indian steelmaker Jindal Steel & Power Ltd has faced significant financial losses after the nation reversed its policy on coal, which had been a key factor in the company's growth. The company, once valued at nearly $15 billion, now has a market value of $1.7 billion after the government cancelled permits for coal blocks and ordered companies to pay a levy of 295 rupees a tonne for the coal they extracted. The company's shares have fallen 45% since the Supreme Court's ruling in September, and it is fighting a court investigation into alleged irregularities in winning rights to a coal block in eastern India.

site_title: Asian-Americans a key factor in US electoral politics and TPP deal
summary: US immigration data shows China has surpassed Mexico as the top country of origin for immigrants, with a growing trend of immigration from Asia. Asian-Americans now comprise 5% of the US population and are the fastest-growing, highest-income, and best-educated racial group. However, neither Democrats nor Republicans have effectively tapped into their electoral power, with many Asian-Americans identifying as independents and holding non-ideological views. Republicans may need to reassess their anti-immigration stance to win over Asian-American voters, while Democrats' opposition to the TPP trade deal could lead to anti-Asian sentiments.

site_title: 40 New York restaurants win wine magazine's top awards
summary: Forty New York restaurants have won the top three-star award in the 2015 World of Fine Wine's Best Wine List Awards, making the city the best globally for wining while dining. Eleven Madison Park in Manhattan took the top spot as the best overall list, beating out Vienna's Palais Coburg. The US accounted for 116 three-star winners, with 34 countries represented.

site_title: Crafting songs out of her own heartaches
summary: Singer-songwriter Rachael Yamagata performed a 100-minute show in Singapore, playing a selection of 15 songs from her three critically acclaimed studio albums. Despite experiencing jet lag and struggling to remember song lyrics, Yamagata turned the situation to her advantage, delivering a soul-stirring acapella version of the song "Elephants." Her intimate and personal ballads, often based on her own failed relationships, showcased her ability to craft songs out of her own heartaches, captivating the audience in the full Esplanade Concert Hall.

images.alt_text: Dylan Tan

site_title: Lenovo's 4b yuan bonds snapped up, largest offshore RMB issue in 2015
summary: Lenovo Group's 4 billion-yuan bonds (S$800 million) were snapped up in the largest offshore renminbi (RMB) sale in 2015, with a 5-year benchmark deal paying 4.95% coupon. This is one of the two largest non-bank, corporate offshore RMB issues since the offshore RMB bond market opened in 2010. The deal was oversubscribed, marking a significant milestone for the offshore RMB market.

site_title: Some Opec members moot US$80 as new 'fair' oil price
summary: Some Opec members, including Iraq, Venezuela, and Angola, have expressed support for an "equitable" oil price of around $75-$80 per barrel, citing this as a "fair" price for producers and consumers. However, Saudi Arabia, a key Opec member, has not indicated its support for this view. Analysts caution that finding a balance between meeting demand and preventing price volatility will be tricky, with Iran needing higher prices to balance its budget and the US shale industry posing a threat to competition.

site_title: Berlin airports brace for deluge of Champions League fans
summary: Berlin's Schoenefeld airport is preparing for an influx of 25,000 soccer fans for the Uefa Champions League final between Barcelona and Juventus, with over 370 extra commercial flights scheduled. Temporary check-in and security areas will be set up to handle the increased traffic, while special flights will be available at Tegel airport for the teams and VIPs. The airport faces strain due to its lack of world-class capacity, with Flughafen Berlin Brandenburg GmbH employing additional staff to manage the increased demand.

site_title: China tycoon sees bubble in chip industry
summary: China's semiconductor industry is facing a "serious bubble" according to tycoon Zhao Weiguo, chairman of Tsinghua Unigroup. The industry's valuations have surged, with many chipmakers trading at over 100 times profit, making them unaffordable. Zhao, who has invested $4.7 billion in the industry, says he sees few good companies worth buying and that most chip companies are barely making money. The government's support for acquisitions in the industry, including state-backed funding, has driven the boom, but Zhao believes it is unsustainable.

images.alt_text: Mr Zhao has tapped connections at Tsinghua University to make acquisitions and amass a fortune of at least US$2 billion.

site_title: ST Teleport extends satellite communications coverage
summary: ST Teleport, a Singapore-based satellite communications provider, has formed a strategic partnership with Telespazio, a global satellite services provider, to establish a global Ku-band communications network for maritime oil and gas customers. The partnership will provide previously unavailable global Ku-band coverage, fast data transmission, and technical support to customers across seven continents. ST Teleport will be Telespazio's preferred partner in the Asia-Pacific region, expanding its reach and ability to provide seamless solutions to customers.

site_title: Amazon debuts free shipping for small goods, no minimum order
summary: Amazon is introducing free shipping for thousands of small, popular items with no minimum order requirement, targeting cost-conscious shoppers. The program, dubbed "Fulfillment by Amazon Small and Light", covers items weighing 230g or less and usually costing $10 or less. Delivery will take 4-8 business days from a new shipping hub in Kentucky. The move aims to gain market share from competitors like Walmart and Target, but won't necessarily boost Amazon's profitability.

site_title: SoftBank's stake in Coupang said to value firm at 5.5t won
summary: SoftBank Corp is set to invest US$1 billion in South Korean online retailer Coupang, valuing the company at approximately 5.5 trillion won (S$6.7 billion). The deal is expected to close at the start of July, according to SoftBank. This valuation comes after SoftBank's agreement to invest in Coupang.

site_title: Junta boss happy to stay in power, if Thais want him
summary: Thai General Prayuth Chan-ocha expressed willingness to stay in power if given a mandate at the 2016 general election, calling on Thais to "protect" him. He denied having political aspirations and promised to give Thailand "true democracy" as fast as possible. The junta expects the election to pass a new constitution, but critics accuse Prayuth of undemocratic tactics, including using military courts and threatening opponents. Prayuth thrives on criticism, saying it motivates him to stay in power.

site_title: A muddled, misguided effort
summary: Cameron Crowe's film "Aloha" is met with disappointment due to its muddled and misguided effort. The movie attempts to cover themes of Hawaiian folklore, family, and national identity, but loses its way early on. Despite providing insight into military life and the complexities between the military and indigenous peoples, the film's various plot threads are not examined in detail, leaving viewers with more questions than answers. The film's messiness and choppy editing are also notable drawbacks.

site_title: Rupiah hits 17-year low, BI to intervene if needed
summary: Indonesia's rupiah hit a 17-year low against the US dollar, falling 0.4% to 13,281, due to slowing economic growth and high inflation. Bank Indonesia is ready to intervene in the foreign exchange and bond markets to ensure stability. The rupiah is the worst performer among emerging Asian economies this year, having lost over 6%. The central bank has taken steps to stabilize the currency, but analysts believe it may allow for gradual depreciation to support the rebalancing of the economy.

site_title: Casino ban fails to deter John Keells' Sri Lanka mixed-development project
summary: Sri Lanka's largest conglomerate, John Keells Holdings, is moving forward with a $850 million mixed-development project in Colombo despite a ban on casinos. The project, which includes malls, commercial and residential space, and convention halls, will drive growth for the company. Lenders are committed to the project, and while the casino ban may affect rental premiums, it's expected to drive footfall and spending. The project is expected to account for 26% of the group's valuation, according to analysts. The ban on casinos, which reversed a previous administration's decision, was prompted by the withdrawal of an Australian company, Crown Resorts, from a $400 million resort project.

images.alt_text: The Colombo-based group, which is into banking to property and port terminals, is expanding its leisure business to tap rising demand as the US$67 billion economy rebounds after the war ended in 2009.

site_title: Mapletree offers Sing50 tickets in charity drive
summary: Mapletree Investments Pte Ltd has launched a charity ticket drive for Sing50, a golden jubilee concert in Singapore, to raise S$100,000 for two charities supporting underprivileged children and youth. The charity tickets, priced at a minimum donation of S$20, will be available at VivoCity shopping mall. The concert, featuring local artists, will be held on August 7 at the new National Stadium. The ticket drive will run until June 28, and proceeds will benefit The Straits Times School Pocket Money Fund and The Business Times Budding Artists Fund.

site_title: Return of Singa-Pop
summary: Singa-pop, a genre of local music in Singapore, experienced a golden age in the 1960s. After declining over the decades, it has seen a revival in recent years due to the digital era. In 2015, a dozen homegrown acts released new music, with major labels signing artists like Gentle Bones and The Sam Willows. Two compilations and a concert this weekend celebrate the resurgence, offering insight into the local music scene past, present, and future. This revival is expected to continue with more new releases.

images.alt_text: Dylan Tan

site_title: 2015 'probably best year ever' to start a covered bond market
summary: Ralf Grossmann, head of covered bond origination at Societe Generale, says 2015 is "probably the best year ever" for a new covered bond market to start in Singapore due to a large investor base, demand, and tight spreads. Covered bonds, which are secured by residential mortgages, are seen as safer than mortgage-backed securities and offer investors "double recourse" in the event of default. Singapore banks are exploring issuing covered bonds, which could diversify their investor base and provide cheap funding.

site_title: COE premiums remain flat
summary: COE premiums in Singapore remained flat in the first June bidding exercise, with only one category, Category A, showing a tiny increase. Category A fell to S$66,000, while Cat B and Cat E categories dropped to S$75,000 and S$75,801, respectively. This suggests a wait-and-see attitude among buyers, awaiting a larger quota in the coming months.

site_title: Bank of England keeps rates on hold, watches for recovery rebound
summary: The Bank of England maintained interest rates at a record low of 0.5% as it awaited a recovery in Britain's economy from a sharp slowdown earlier this year. The decision was made after a quarterly economic growth rate of 0.3% in the first three months of the year, and amid low oil prices which took Britain's inflation rate below zero. Investors expect the BoE to keep rates on hold until 2016, following a unanimous decision by the Monetary Policy Committee to maintain rates at their current level.

site_title: Italian brokers cheer home price drop as a path to recovery
summary: Italian home prices declined 16.3% in Q1, extending a 2008 high drop, but brokers see the decline as a path to recovery, with easier credit conditions and lower mortgage costs matching supply and demand. Transactions are expected to increase by a quarter this year to 500,000, with prices needing to fall another 5-10% to spark a sustainable recovery. Experts say regulatory uncertainty, slow economic recovery, and high unemployment curb the supply and demand for home-acquisition loans.

site_title: Lessons from Jones the Grocer's collapse
summary: Jones the Grocer, a Singapore-based private grocery store chain, filed for insolvency in 2014. Private equity firm L Capital Asia is working to rebuild the brand and open new stores. Managing partner Ravi Thakran views the collapse as an opportunity to learn from experience, stating "we learn from every experience and many times the not-so-successful ones teach you more than the successful ones." Despite the challenges, L Capital Asia is committed to revitalizing the brand.

site_title: Blackstone seeks US$1.5b for two Boston office buildings
summary: Blackstone Group LP is seeking approximately US$1.5 billion for two Boston office buildings acquired in 2007 as part of its purchase of Equity Office Properties Trust. The buildings, at 500 Boylston St and 222 Berkeley St, occupy the same block and share a garage, with total square footage of around 1.3 million square feet. This sale is part of Blackstone's efforts to sell assets amid a recovery in office occupancies and demand for prime real estate in coastal markets.

site_title: Punters big on women's healthcare company
summary: Singapore O&G (SOG), a women's healthcare company, made its Catalist debut, with its shares opening at 45.5 Singapore cents, a 82% hike from the IPO price. The shares peaked at 63.5 cents, with 88.8 million units changing hands, making it the second most active stock on the exchange. The company plans to expand its physical presence, reach out to medical tourists, and venture into overseas markets, with a focus on healthcare professionals. Analysts note that the high demand may put pressure on management to deliver, but the sector's overall trend suggests a positive outlook.

images.alt_text: Prisca Ang

site_title: Why winning the Emerging Enterprise Award goes beyond bragging rights . . .
summary: The Emerging Enterprise Award in Singapore has been recognizing outstanding young enterprises for excellence in innovation and business practices since its eighth year. Past winners have seen significant growth, with one in three reaching S$10 million turnover within a year and over 40% establishing a presence overseas. This year's prize package is worth up to S$1.47 million, with up to three winners receiving S$200,000 in interest-free business overdraft facilities. The award aims to encourage entrepreneurship and contribute to the building of a vibrant ecosystem in Singapore.

site_title: Accor to open booking website to independent hoteliers
summary: Accor, the world's fourth-largest hotel group, will allow independent hoteliers to list their rooms on its booking website, starting in July. The move aims to increase the number of hotels available on the site to 10,000 by 2018 and boost profit margins against online travel agents such as Expedia and Booking.com. Accor will charge a 30-50% lower booking commission than rivals, and will select hotels based on their rating, size, and location. The investment of 22 million euros is part of Accor's 225 million euro digital business expansion plan.

site_title: 'Free pizza for life' helps close Portland home deal
summary: A Portland homeowner, Donna DiNicola, offered free pizza for life to her son as a unique selling point in the competitive real estate market. The offer, made for a 900-square-foot house, was accepted, allowing her son to secure the property. The unconventional tactic worked, and DiNicola attributed it to her son's charm. The unusual offer has sparked interest in the local real estate market, highlighting the creative strategies buyers are using to stand out in the competitive Portland housing scene.

site_title: China - where a new passion for Rover barks up big business
summary: China's pet care industry is experiencing rapid growth, with sales expected to increase by over 50% to 15.8 billion yuan (S$3.5 billion) by 2019, surpassing the US market. Pet owners are spending more on luxury items, such as gourmet dog food, grooming services, and high-end accessories. The industry's growth is driven by higher disposable incomes and the desire for pets as a symbol of financial success. Multinationals like Nestle, Procter & Gamble, and Mars are capitalizing on the trend, with sales of dog food and other pet products expected to triple by 2019.

site_title: Otto unit redeems preference shares; Vallianz raising US$10m
summary: Otto Marine's unit, GO Marine Investments, has redeemed S$12 million of preference shares issued in 2013. Meanwhile, Vallianz Holdings is raising US$10 million from a fund owned by United Overseas Bank and Japan's Orix Corp. to grow its fleet and expand working capital. Analysts had previously raised concerns about Otto's ability to pay creditors, but the redemption of preference shares appears to alleviate those concerns. Vallianz plans to use the funds to grow its fleet and increase its stake in the company if the investor converts the preference shares into ordinary shares.

site_title: From a dark past, soulful songs emerge
summary: The Black Arm Band, an Australian music collective, performs at the Singapore International Festival of Arts with their captivating music that deals with struggles and resistance of the Aboriginal people. Their songs, sung in near-extinct Aboriginal languages, highlight social equality and unite people to drive social change. Formed in response to Australia's dismissal of the 'black armband view of history', the band creates music that draws from Aboriginal Australian and contemporary genres, raising awareness and telling the stories of their marred history and dispossession.

images.alt_text: Helmi Yusof

site_title: City buzz
summary: Local events and activities are taking place in Singapore. The Singapore Lyric Opera's "Opera In The Park" will feature opera songs from movies, with conductor Wong Kah Chun making his debut. An exhibition, "The Tools that Built Singapore", showcases everyday tools used in various trades from the 1940s to the 1960s. The comic revue "Dim Sum Dollies" tells the history of Singapore in a unique and entertaining way. Meanwhile, a large-scale escape room game, "Real Escape Game (REG) in Singapore Vol. 9: Escape from The Conspiracy", is taking place across the country, and a new beer growler service has been introduced by Amber Nectar.

site_title: Key to global water crisis is management
summary: The world is not facing a water crisis due to scarcity, but rather due to improper management of this renewable resource. Despite having enough water for all uses, the global population's increasing needs and unsustainable practices are degrading water quality. Agriculture, industry, and urbanization are major contributors to water pollution, with many rivers and lakes becoming "trickle streams" by the time they reach the sea. The lack of proper pricing, management, and institutional weaknesses have hindered efforts to manage water resources efficiently, resulting in serious environmental and health problems.

images.alt_text: In India, the Supreme Court, in October 2014, slammed the failures of central and state Pollution Control Boards at all levels for the continued pollution of the Ganga, considered to be the holiest river of the country.

site_title: Euro pauses after biggest gains in six years
summary: The euro paused after its biggest two-day gain in over six years, edging down 0.1% to $1.12595. The eurozone's inflation returned, and the European Central Bank played down the impact of bond market volatility. The Australian dollar fell 1% to $0.7708, while the US dollar index slid to a near two-week low of 95.415. The closely watched US nonfarm payrolls report on Friday will provide a gauge of employment conditions and possible interest rate hike timing.

site_title: America's good trade intentions go bad as it keeps TPP details a secret
summary: The US government is keeping the details of the Trans-Pacific Partnership (TPP) free-trade agreement secret, sparking controversy over the lack of transparency. Despite claims that the agreement will boost US exports and jobs, critics argue that the US already has tariff-lowering agreements with many participating countries, rendering the TPP unnecessary. The administration's emphasis on fast-track procedures to negotiate the agreement has led to concerns that legitimate concerns about the TPP's contents are being stifled, with those who raise objections being labeled "protectionist".

site_title: Celebrating Singapore with pop-up art
summary: American artist Charles Fazzino's solo exhibition in Singapore celebrates the nation's 50th anniversary with a 1.45-meter map of Singapore featuring iconic sights and landmarks. The intricate artwork, created with silk-screen printing and layered details, took a team of 50 people six months to complete. Fazzino, who has worked on major events like the Super Bowl and Emmy award ceremonies, aims to capture the essence of his subject and evoke emotions, stating that his goal is to make people happy and remember special things. The exhibition, "The Colors of Singapore: A 3-Dimensional Artwork," is on display at Bruno Gallery in Singapore until June 14.

site_title: More signs of HDB resale market stabilising
summary: Singapore's HDB resale market appears to be stabilizing, with SRX flash estimates showing a 2.2% decline in transactions in May compared to April, but a 19.3% year-on-year increase in resale volume. The HDB resale flat price index remained unchanged in May, and median transaction over X-value (TOX) remained at negative S$2,000. Experts predict a less than 5% fall in HDB resale prices for 2015, but note that demand remains restrained due to the 30% MSR cap and rising interest rates.

images.alt_text: Kalpana Rashiwala

site_title: Tackling market concerns should be priority for new SGX CEO
summary: Singapore Exchange's new CEO faces challenges in balancing shareholder demands for growth and profits with stakeholder expectations, including retail investors' demand for stronger regulation, local companies' need for good valuations, and trading representatives' desire for better working conditions. The exchange must also address low liquidity and volatility in regional markets due to concerns over rising interest rates, slowing growth, and the impact of China's growing market on local benchmark indices.

site_title: Peter Lim invests in TheEdge owner's new property portal
summary: Singapore billionaire Peter Lim has invested in Malaysian entrepreneur Tong Kooi Ong's new property portal, TheEdgeProperty.com, taking a 20% stake. This marks Lim's first foray into the technology sector, as he previously invested in various industries such as football, healthcare, and sports. The business model is deemed scalable and revenue-generating, with immediate prospects. Lim and Tong previously collaborated in 2012, with Tong becoming the chairman and CEO of UPP Holdings, a firm part-owned by Lim.

images.alt_text: Anita Gabriel

site_title: New career progression pathway for engineers launched
summary: The National Trades Union Congress (NTUC) and its partner The Institution of Engineers, Singapore (IES) launched a new career progression pathway for engineers, offering a three-tiered scheme to enhance leadership skills and technology management expertise. The pathway includes the Young Engineers Leadership (YEL) programme for recent hires and the Advanced Engineering Leadership (AEL) and Global Engineering Leadership (GEL) programmes for senior engineers. The initiative aims to create long-term career development for engineers, raise engineering standards, and groom a strong pipeline of engineering leaders.

images.alt_text: Fiona Lam

site_title: IMF urges Fed to postpone rate liftoff to first half of 2016
summary: The International Monetary Fund (IMF) has urged the Federal Reserve to postpone interest rate hikes until the first half of 2016, citing a moderately overvalued dollar that could harm further appreciation. The IMF also cut its US growth forecast for the second time in three months, citing economic uncertainty. The lender's annual checkup of the US economy stated that the US growth forecast has decreased due to various factors, including the strong dollar. This recommendation may impact the Fed's decision-making process on interest rates and economic policies.

site_title: Bond rout wipes out 2015 gains as traders stay glued to screens
summary: The global bond market has experienced a significant downturn, erasing all 2015 gains, as investors shift away from debt securities with yields below zero. The Bank of America Merrill Lynch Global Broad Market Index is now down 0.4% for the year. European Central Bank President Mario Draghi's warning of continued market volatility has also contributed to the sell-off. The ECB's heightened volatility signals that investors should expect further market fluctuations, leaving little incentive to own debt securities.

site_title: US: Wall St opens lower as global bond rout weighs
summary: US stocks opened lower on Thursday, weighed down by a global bond rout. Despite better-than-expected US jobless claims data, the Dow Jones industrial average fell 0.47%, the S&P 500 lost 0.45%, and the Nasdaq Composite dropped 0.5%. The decline overshadowed a strong performance by Singapore stocks, which notched a 5-day rally ahead of GDP data.

site_title: Philippines unveils plan to boost car output
summary: The Philippines has launched a $600 million incentive plan to boost its tiny car industry, aiming to lift production and catch up with regional rivals. The scheme, which will run for six years, is a response to the sector's struggles, with Japanese car makers such as Toyota and Mitsubishi expressing concerns about shifting manufacturing to cheaper neighboring countries. The move is expected to provide much-needed support to the country's shrinking car output.

site_title: Missed power plant deadline belies Jakarta's optimism
summary: Indonesian President Joko Widodo's government has missed a deadline to start construction on a $4 billion power plant in Batang, despite optimistic claims. The project, which has been delayed since 2012, is now expected to begin this month, with coordinating minister Sofyan Djalil attributing the delay to "chasing all the details." The project is seen as a test case for the government's ability to cut through bureaucracy and stimulate growth in the country, which has seen economic growth slow to 4.7% in the first quarter.

site_title: Air travel demand up 5.9% in April: IATA
summary: Global air travel demand rose 5.9% in April, according to the International Air Transport Association. Despite low oil prices, the strong US dollar may impact demand in some regions. Capacity increased 6.1% and load factors fell 0.1 percentage points to 79.4%. The association's annual meeting will provide an updated forecast for airline profitability on Monday.

site_title: Global air freight momentum slowing: IATA
summary: Global air freight growth is slowing due to weakening world trade, according to IATA. In April, air cargo volumes rose 3.3% compared to 5.3% in the first three months of the year, with only Asia-Pacific and Middle East regions reporting growth. Capacity increased 5.5% in April, leading to a load factor of 44.7%. IATA Director General Tony Tyler stated that the market is settling down and momentum in air freight growth is being lost.

site_title: MND stresses urgency in ironing out issue of independent accountants in AHPETC
summary: The Ministry of National Development (MND) in Singapore is urging the High Court to expedite its appeal against a decision not to appoint independent accountants at the Aljunied-Hougang-Punggol East Town Council (AHPETC). The MND claims an "urgency for the matter to be resolved quickly". The decision is related to the AHPETC, which is run by the Workers' Party (WP), and the MND wants to address concerns about the council's financial management. The outcome of the appeal could have significant implications for the council and the WP.

site_title: World's biggest gold ETF loses place in US top 10
summary: The world's largest gold-backed exchange-traded fund, SPDR Gold Shares (GLD), has fallen to its lowest value and gold holdings since mid-January, losing its spot as one of the top 10 US-listed ETFs by value. The fund's value dwindled to $27.148 billion, and its gold holdings fell to 709.9 tonnes. A 12-year rally in gold prices came to an end in 2013, and the metal has struggled to find direction, trading within a $50 range since mid-February. Expectations of the Federal Reserve raising interest rates later this year are contributing to the decline.

site_title: Index loses grip on early gains
summary: The Straits Times Index (STI) fell 4.84 points to 3,345, marking its 20th point loss of the year, due to weak trading. European and US bond yields rose, causing pressure on stocks. However, Singtel's 8.6-point gain helped the index initially rise, but a sell-off in the final hour pushed it into negative territory. The index's largest contributors were Singtel, DBS, and UOB, while Noble and Singapore Exchange dropped. The SGX's CEO is set to leave in June, and analysts expect the index to remain volatile until a successor is appointed.

site_title: Passengers' families march to China shipwreck site as survivor hopes fade
summary: Dozens of family members of passengers on the sunken Eastern Star cruise ship in China marched towards the disaster site, demanding news of missing relatives. Rescuers have recovered 29 bodies and 14 survivors since the ship capsized on Monday with 456 people on board. Premier Li Keqiang oversees rescue efforts, but hopes of finding more survivors are fading. Relatives questioned the government's handling of the disaster, including why most rescued crew members were released and why the captain and crew wore life vests but failed to sound the alarm.

site_title: US jobless claims fall; continuing claims lowest since 2000
summary: US jobless claims fell to 276,000 for the week ended May 30, the lowest since 2000, according to the Labour Department. This marks the 13th consecutive week of claims below 300,000, indicating a resilient labour market despite moderate economic growth. The four-week moving average of claims increased to 274,750, and continuing claims fell 30,000 to 2.20 million, also the lowest since 2000. Economists expect solid job growth, with a Reuters survey predicting a 225,000 increase in nonfarm payrolls last month.

site_title: Jeb Bush to announce White House bid on June 15: campaign website
summary: Former Florida Governor Jeb Bush will announce his bid for the Republican presidential nomination on June 15 in Miami, following a week-long trip to Germany, Poland, and Estonia. Bush's announcement comes after polls showed his front-runner status had diminished and amid criticism about his delay in announcing. His campaign will be based in Miami, with the Right to Rise superpac organization led by strategist Mike Murphy. Bush faces challenges from conservative voters and a home-state challenge from Senator Marco Rubio, who has called for a new generation of leaders in the party.

site_title: Oil tumbles again before Opec; worry over spiking European yields
summary: Crude oil prices tumbled 2% on Thursday, marking the second consecutive day of decline, ahead of an OPEC meeting in Vienna. The Organization of the Petroleum Exporting Countries is expected to reaffirm its 30 million barrels-per-day output target, despite calls to cut supply. European bond yields rose to eight-month highs, raising concerns about a tighter credit environment that could choke off growth and speculative money in the oil market. Brent crude fell to $62.35 a barrel, and US crude futures dropped to $58.34.

site_title: Turkey's knife-edge election
summary: Turkey's general election on June 7 could significantly impact the country's future, potentially allowing President Recep Tayyip Erdogan to consolidate power and resolve the Kurdish separation issue. However, the poll's outcome is expected to lead to acrimony and coalition-building, which may negatively affect the Turkish economy, already vulnerable to capital outflows due to a 4.2% current account deficit. The IMF warns that Turkey must lower growth to curb the deficit, which has been a concern since Erdogan's economic miracle began to fade in 2012-14.

site_title: Indonesia hopes to rejoin Opec by year-end
summary: Indonesia is hopeful to rejoin Opec by year-end, with Energy Minister Sudirman Said stating the country's President Joko Widodo has agreed to a plan for Indonesia to rejoin the Organization of the Petroleum Exporting Countries. Indonesia left Opec in 2009 due to rising domestic demand and falling production, but there is no requirement for Opec members to be net oil exporters to be a member. Indonesia aims to "bridge the gap" between oil producing and consuming nations by rejoining the group and develop resources in Opec countries, while also focusing on renewable energy.

site_title: Detention of Singapore ships down in 2014
summary: Singapore's ship detention rate fell to 47 in 2014, down from 68 in 2011. The Maritime and Port Authority of Singapore reported that Singapore-flagged ships had a relatively low detention rate, with 1.14% for the Tokyo MOU regime and 0.85% for the Paris MOU regime. This is in line with Singapore's goal to maintain a low detention record with major port state control regimes. Two Singapore-flagged ships were detained in Indonesia for alleged paperwork issues, but the MPA aims to encourage sustainability and integrated reporting in the maritime industry.

site_title: Consumer comfort in US falls to lowest level since November
summary: Consumer confidence in the US fell to a six-month low in May, with the Bloomberg Consumer Comfort Index dropping to 40.5 from 40.9. The decline was attributed to weakened views of the buying climate, driven by higher gasoline prices and weak wage growth. Employment opportunities and housing market gains may help underpin spending, but uncertainty over interest rate hikes by the Federal Reserve also contributed to the decline. The confidence survey's buying climate gauge fell to 34.2, the lowest level since mid-November, and sentiment improved only among the poorest households.

site_title: An old TV series' irrelevance, magnified on the big screen
summary: The movie adaptation of the HBO TV series Entourage, released in 2015, fails to recapture the magic of its predecessor. The film, loosely based on Mark Wahlberg's experiences as a rising film star, is a reminder of the series' decline in quality. The movie's opening scene, featuring the main characters on a luxury speedboat, sets the tone for a lackluster viewing experience. Critics argue that the film's attempt to revive the series' irreverent humor falls flat, leaving audiences disappointed. The movie's poor reception is a testament to the series' irrelevance on the big screen.

images.alt_text: The cast from the TV series, which ended its run in 2011, reprise their roles for the movie version, which dishes out a larger-than-normal dose of Hollywood-style excess.

site_title: IMF warns US Federal Reserve should delay rate hike until 2016
summary: The International Monetary Fund (IMF) recommends that the US Federal Reserve delay a rate hike until the first half of 2016, citing mixed US data and a lack of signs of a sustained recovery. The IMF forecasts that the Fed's inflation target will not be reached until mid-2017, and delaying rate hikes could provide insurance against disinflation and policy reversal.

site_title: Singapore Wrap Thursday
summary: Singapore's private sector wages rose at a slower rate in 2014, with total wages increasing by 3.8% compared to 4.1% in 2013. However, real wages for employees grew more due to lower inflation. COE (Certified Emission Reduction) premiums remained flat in Singapore, with buyers waiting to see how the market will react.

site_title: UK to start selling remaining Royal Mail shares: Osborne
summary: British finance minister George Osborne announced the UK government will sell its remaining 30% stake in Royal Mail, valued at around 1.5 billion pounds, to generate 4.5 billion pounds for the public coffers. The sale comes after the government found extra savings in the current financial year.

site_title: Brokers' take
summary: ISOTeam has proposed a placement of up to 9 million new shares at S$0.58 per share, raising net proceeds of up to S$5 million. The company secured S$24.8 million worth of contracts, bringing total contracts secured for FY15 to S$78.1 million. Despite rising cost pressures, ISOTeam maintained its gross profit margins at 22% for H2FY14 and H1FY15, which are expected to be sustainable due to cost savings and ability to pass on costs to customers.

site_title: US productivity plunges in Q1; unit labour costs surge
summary: US nonfarm productivity declined at a 3.1% annual rate in Q1, surpassing the previously reported 1.9% rate. This drop led to a surge in unit labour costs, potentially sparking inflation. It was the first back-to-back fall in productivity since 2006, and economists had expected a 2.9% rate. The decline in productivity may have implications for the US economy, particularly in terms of inflation and growth.

site_title: Govt and govt-linked companies up the ante to woo engineers
summary: Singapore's government and government-linked companies are implementing measures to attract and retain engineering talent amid a shortage. They are offering professional development, career progression, and competitive salaries. Companies such as SMRT Corporation, PUB, and ST Engineering are providing post-graduate degree courses, industry attachments, and mentorship. Scholarships, internships, and overseas project opportunities are also being offered. The Public Service Division is working to build engineering capabilities in the public sector, with a focus on civil, electrical, geo-technical, and environmental engineering. The goal is to increase the employability of engineers and reduce attrition rates.

images.alt_text: Fiona Lam

site_title: Thai factory output set to rebound in second half: ministry
summary: Thai factory output is expected to rebound in the second half of 2015 due to revived private and public investment and improved global economic conditions. The industrial sector, accounting for 40% of Thailand's economy, has seen a decline in manufacturing production over the past two years. With industrial goods making up the bulk of exports, the country's efforts to revive the economy are hindered by weak exports and subdued domestic demand.

site_title: Bloated oil market fed more crude from unwinding sea storage plays
summary: The global oil market is experiencing a decrease in speculative storage, with trade houses selling millions of barrels of oil stored on tankers at sea. This reduction in supply is putting pressure on the market, leading to a build-up of unsold oil in the West African, North Sea, and Mediterranean regions. The drop in storage volumes is expected to weaken the market structure and add to the oversupply of crude oil, making it more challenging for producers to sell their oil.

site_title: HSBC to pay 40m Swiss francs in Geneva money laundering probe
summary: HSBC agreed to pay 40 million Swiss francs (S$57.54 million) to settle an investigation into allegations of aggravated money laundering at its Swiss private bank in Geneva. The payment, made to local authorities, is compensation for past organizational failings, and no criminal charges will be filed. The bank's Swiss office was searched in February as part of the probe, following allegations of money laundering.

site_title: EPL's income dwarfs other European leagues by a mile
summary: The English Premier League (EPL) has generated record revenues of £3.26 billion (S$6.74 billion) in the 2013-14 season, surpassing other European leagues by a significant margin. Manchester United tops the table with £433 million in revenues and £117 million in operating profit. The league's broadcast revenue increased by 48% year-on-year, driven by a new three-year domestic TV deal, and is expected to continue growing. The EPL's profitability has marked a turning point in football finance, with 15 of the 20 clubs posting a profit, and the league's overall pre-tax profit reaching £187 million.

images.alt_text: Lee U-Wen

site_title: Greek left vents fury at creditors as Tsipras nears deal
summary: Greek Prime Minister Alexis Tsipras rejected proposed conditions by creditors, including pension cuts and a tax rise on electricity, for a last-ditch deal to stave off bankruptcy.
