Despite European officials expressing confidence in an agreement, Tsipras' left-wing party vented fury at the terms, with some lawmakers threatening to call early elections or a referendum. A deal is reportedly near, with the IMF seeking a primary surplus of 1% this year and 2% next year, and Tsipras aiming to wrap up talks by June 14.

images.alt_text: Leftists in Prime Minister Alexis Tsipras' party vented fury on Thursday at terms proposed by Greece's creditors for a last-ditch deal to stave off bankruptcy, but European officials voiced confidence that an agreement was near.

site_title: China Sports responds to SGX queries on results announcement
summary: China Sports International responded to Singapore Exchange queries regarding its unaudited first quarter results, ending March 31, 2015. The company clarified its usage of placement proceeds for its online shopping platform, stating it generated less than 5% of total revenue. It also reported a 23.4% increase in trade receivables, with 75% related to royalty fees for breathable shoes, but noted it had yet to make any payment of the royalty fees. The company will continue to develop its e-commerce platforms, reflecting the growing trend of online shopping.

site_title: UK regulator poised to fine Lloyds £100m
summary: The UK's Financial Conduct Authority is set to fine Lloyds Banking Group £100m over its handling of customer complaints related to payment-protection insurance (PPI). This penalty follows Lloyds' £12 billion provision for PPI-related costs, the largest among British lenders. The fine may be announced as soon as Friday.

site_title: Saudi Arabia raises benchmark oil price to Asia
summary: Saudi Arabia has raised its benchmark oil price for Asia to $65.50 a barrel in July, up 60 cents from June, in response to robust demand and higher consumption at home during the summer. This move sets the price at parity with the Oman/Dubai average. The state oil company, Saudi Aramco, has cut its price to Northwest Europe but maintained the US sales price unchanged. The decision aims to balance the demand and supply in the Asian market.

site_title: South Korea confirms death of third MERS patient
summary: South Korea confirmed the death of a third patient infected with Middle East Respiratory Syndrome (MERS), bringing the total fatalities to three and the infected cases to 36. The 82-year-old man, who had asthma and bacterial pneumonia, died while sharing a room with others suffering from MERS. The outbreak remains the largest outside the Middle East.

images.alt_text: South Korea confirmed on Thursday that a man who died a day earlier was infected with Middle East Respiratory Syndrome (MERS), marking the third fatality in an outbreak of the often-deadly virus.

site_title: KTL Global buys 20% stake in Korean rigging equipment firm
summary: KTL Global, a mainboard-listed oil and gas company, has acquired a 20% stake in Korean rigging equipment firm Dae Kwang for US$5 million. The move aims to accelerate KTL Global's push into the Korean offshore and marine industry by leveraging Dae Kwang's network and customer base. The acquisition is expected to provide higher gross margins through the provision of heavy lift slings and managed services, and will also enable KTL Global to take on larger-scale projects with Dae Kwang's new facility set to be completed by end-2015.

site_title: EU/IMF lenders demand asset sales, pension cuts in Greek proposal
summary: Greek Prime Minister Alexis Tsipras has been presented with a proposal by EU/IMF lenders requiring Athens to sell state assets, implement 1% pension cuts, and raise taxes to 11-23%. The proposal also includes scrapping a low-income pension benefit, increasing healthcare contributions, and saving 800 million euros by 2016. These demands would cross Greece's "red lines" and force Tsipras to violate his pledge to avoid new pension cuts. The proposal's release is seen as a challenge to Tsipras' government and its ability to implement austerity measures.

site_title: Indonesia's chief econ minister says does not want rupiah to be too weak
summary: Indonesia's coordinating minister for economics, Sofyan Djalil, expressed concerns over the country's currency, the rupiah, which slid to a 17-year low against the dollar. The rupiah closed at 13,279 to the dollar, its weakest since 1998. Djalil stated that the government will accelerate spending to improve the fiscal side, while Bank Indonesia will manage the monetary side to stabilize the currency. Despite the weakening, Djalil reassured that the exchange rate is still safe.

site_title: Britain sees "very strong" case for re-running World Cup bids if process corrupt: sports minister
summary: Britain's sports minister John Whittingdale says there's a "very strong" case for re-running the 2018 and 2022 World Cup bids if corruption is found in the process. An FBI investigation and Swiss prosecutors' inquiry are ongoing, scrutinizing the awarding of tournaments to Russia and Qatar. If Qatar is stripped of the 2022 World Cup, England may be asked to host instead, as it has the necessary facilities.

site_title: HSBC seen making investment banking cuts, with equities at risk
summary: HSBC Holdings Plc is set to announce deeper investment banking cuts, with equities trading at risk. The plan, to be presented by CEO Stuart Gulliver, prioritizes foreign exchange and rates trading for higher returns and to service corporate clients globally. In contrast, the equities division has the lowest returns and is likely to be the first to face cuts. The move comes after annual earnings fell 17% and the lender cut its profitability targets. Gulliver previously vowed to implement "extreme solutions" for underperforming businesses.

site_title: Apple to launch watch in Singapore and six more countries from June 26
summary: Apple is set to launch its watch in seven additional countries, including Italy, Mexico, and South Korea, from June 26, as demand surpasses expectations. The watch will also be launched in Singapore, Switzerland, and Taiwan, in addition to its current availability in the US, Australia, Canada, China, France, Germany, Hong Kong, Japan, and the UK. The company has not provided sales figures for the Apple Watch since its release in April, but has consistently stated that demand is outstripping supply.

site_title: Brent to face pressure from weakening European diesel: Goldman
summary: Goldman Sachs predicts a weakening European diesel market, driven by abundant supply and strong demand growth. Despite a 7.2% annual growth in diesel demand in the first quarter, Goldman expects demand to grow by 3.5% for the rest of 2015. This will put pressure on refining margins and Brent crude prices.

site_title: ST Index constituents to stay unchanged
summary: The Straits Times Index (STI) constituents will remain unchanged following the quarterly review. The reserve list, comprising the top 5 non-constituents by market capitalization, includes UOL Group, Yangzijiang Shipbuilding Holdings, CapitaLand Commercial Trust, Suntec Reit, and Genting Hong Kong. Changes will take effect on June 22, with the next review scheduled for September 3.

site_title: China orders sunken ship operator to check safety as toll mounts
summary: China has ordered the operator of the sunken river cruise ship, Chongqing Dongfang Lunchuan Co, to conduct a safety check amid mounting death toll from the disaster. 14 people have been rescued and 75 confirmed dead after the ferry capsized on the Yangtze River in poor weather. The ship's operator must suspend operating another vessel of the same make. Chinese President Xi Jinping has called for a "serious investigation" into the accident, and the ship's captain and chief engineer have been detained for questioning.

site_title: NTUC, IES launch career progression pathway for engineers
summary: The National Trades Union Congress (NTUC) and The Institution of Engineers, Singapore (IES) have launched a three-tiered career progression pathway for engineers, aiming to equip them with leadership skills and technology management expertise. The initiative also marks a broader effort to develop career and skills progression pathways for professionals, managers, and executives in other sectors. This move is part of NTUC's sectoral development efforts through collaborations with its U Associate partners.

images.alt_text: Fiona Lam

site_title: Fifa scandal spreads around the globe
summary: A global corruption scandal involving FIFA has escalated, with new allegations emerging about World Cup bribes and FIFA President Sepp Blatter. Whistleblower Chuck Blazer, battling cancer, testified that FIFA executives conspired to accept bribes for the 1998 and 2010 World Cups. Other suspects, including former FIFA official Jack Warner, have promised to reveal "avalanches" of secrets. Investigations are underway in South Africa, Australia, and Venezuela, and US prosecutors have charged seven FIFA officials with over $150 million in bribes. The scandal has sparked a search for a new FIFA president, with a vote expected in December.

site_title: Greece aims to meet all debt obligations, Varoufakis says
summary: Greece's finance minister Yanis Varoufakis stated the country aims to meet all its debt obligations, including a 300 million-euro payment to the International Monetary Fund due on Friday. Greece is also set to pay approximately 1.5 billion euros to the IMF in June in four installments. Varoufakis opposed the privatization of the country's dominant power utility PPC, which was halted after the leftist government took power in January.

site_title: COE premiums flat as buyers wait and see
summary: COE premiums in Singapore remained flat in the first June bidding exercise, with only Category A seeing a small increase. Category B slipped S$2, while Category E dropped S$2,200. Category C for goods vehicles fell S$1,101, and Category D for motorcycles rose S$8. The flat premiums reflect a wait-and-see attitude among buyers, anticipating a larger quota in the coming months.

site_title: Food commodity prices fall in May to near six-year low: FAO
summary: The world's major food commodity prices fell to a near six-year low in May, averaging 166.8 points, a 1.4% decline from April and 20.7% from last year, according to the Food and Agriculture Organisation. The decline was driven by a 3.8% drop in cereal prices, 2.9% in dairy prices, and 1% in meat prices. FAO upgraded its forecast for global cereal production in 2015, citing larger harvests in China, Mexico, Africa, and North America, reinforcing stable cereal markets.

site_title: Malaysia: Stocks end the day lower
summary: Malaysia's stocks closed lower on Tuesday, with the Kuala Lumpur Composite Index dropping 7.69 points to 1,741.480. Trading volume reached 1.36 billion lots valued at RM1.68 billion, with losers outnumbering gainers 434 to 377.

site_title: Tokyo: Shares inch higher at close after two days of losses
summary: Tokyo stocks rose on Thursday, ending two days of losses, as exporters benefited from a weak yen. The Nikkei 225 index gained 0.07% to 20,488.19, while the Topix index added 0.23% to 1,673.89. This follows a 0.04% gain on Wednesday. The positive move was attributed to the weak yen, supporting exporters.

site_title: Junta boss happy to stay in power, if Thais want him
summary: Thai General Prayuth Chan-ocha expressed willingness to stay in power as leader if given a mandate at the next year's general election. He warned that Thais must "protect" him from both domestic and international criticism. Prayuth, who led the 2014 coup, has been criticized for his undemocratic rise and zero-tolerance approach to dissent. He promised to give Thailand "true democracy" and has denied having political aspirations. A general election is expected in August 2016, allowing for a referendum on a new constitution.

site_title: Russia seeks US$140b reserves boost
summary: Russia aims to boost central bank reserves by $140 billion over the next few years to reach $500 billion, a level before it annexed Ukraine's Crimea. The goal is to cover two to three years of capital outflows, with gradual increases to avoid inflation. The reserves fell by a quarter in 2014 due to declining oil prices and US sanctions. The Bank of Russia has eased monetary policy, cutting interest rates to 12.5% and plans to buy $200 million daily to replenish reserves.

site_title: EDB arm invests in US cyber security firm
summary: EDB's investment arm, EDBI, has invested US$15 million in US cyber security firm CounterTack through a Series C funding round led by TenEleven Ventures. The investment aims to help CounterTack expand in Singapore and Asia, utilizing its Sentinel platform to deliver endpoint detection and response to targeted cyber threats. CounterTack's unique technology uses big data to detect threat patterns and anticipate attacks, enhancing security teams' approaches to endpoint detection and response.

site_title: Shanghai Free Trade Zone has not become channel for hot money: central bank official
summary: China's Shanghai Free Trade Zone has not become a channel for hot money outflows or arbitrage, according to a central bank official. Vice Director Zhang Xin stated the zone has achieved full convertibility of the yuan and has not been exploited by corrupt officials or currency arbitrage. His comments address concerns raised by analysts about the zone's liberalization of the capital account.

images.alt_text: China's Shanghai Free Trade Zone has not become a channel for hot money outflows or arbitrage, a central bank official said on Thursday.

site_title: HK bank regulator calls for more anti-money laundering efforts
summary: Hong Kong's banking regulator has urged banks to step up anti-money laundering efforts following the Fifa bribery scandal, in which more than a dozen banks were implicated. The regulator warned that it will take action against banks that fail to detect dirty money, citing a US Department of Justice indictment involving $150 million in bribes. The Hong Kong Monetary Authority stated that meeting anti-money laundering expectations remains a challenge for some banks, particularly with higher-risk customers.

site_title: Najib to answer questions at 'Nothing2Hide' dialogue
summary: Prime Minister Najib Razak is scheduled to answer questions at an open townhall dialogue, 'Nothing2Hide', at the Putra World Trade Centre on Friday, moderated by the Malaysian Volunteer Lawyers Association.

site_title: Lenovo's four billion-yuan bonds snapped up; largest offshore RMB issue in 2015 to date
summary: Lenovo Group sold 4 billion-yuan (S$800 million) bonds, the largest offshore RMB issue in 2015. The five-year, 4.95% coupon bond was oversubscribed, with orders exceeding 20 billion yuan. Initial guidance was 5.375%, but pricing tightened to 4.95% after trading above 101. The bond, sold at par 100, was quoted between 101.105 and 101.283. Joint global coordinators and lead managers included Agricultural Bank of China, Citi, and DBS Bank.

site_title: Tight oil is here to stay, Conoco CEO tells Opec
summary: Conoco CEO Ryan Lance stated that the US tight-oil boom is here to stay due to technological breakthroughs that have reduced costs by 15-30%. This comes despite low crude prices, as Opec chose not to cut production to tackle a global glut. Lance's comments were made during a seminar organized by Opec, highlighting the long-term viability of tight oil reservoirs.

site_title: Singapore fuel oil stocks hit all-time high, exports slower
summary: Singapore's fuel oil stocks reached an all-time high of 27.603 million barrels, or 4.3 million tonnes, in the week to June 3, driven by weaker exports. Shipments fell by 35% to a two-week low of 535,000 tonnes, with key destinations including South Korea, Hong Kong, and Taiwan. The surge in inventory has raised concerns that demand may not be keeping pace with rising inflows, fueling worries about the region's fuel oil market.

site_title: IMF calls for simpler EU budget rules, focus on debt
summary: The International Monetary Fund (IMF) has called for simpler EU budget rules to limit discretion in their application and focus on reducing public debt. The current rules, according to IMF head Vitor Gaspar, are complex and allow for significant discretion, resulting in weak compliance. The IMF aims to simplify the rules to prioritize debt reduction, addressing concerns about the EU's debt burden.

site_title: Top EU court rules German nuclear fuel tax is legal
summary: The European Union's top court has ruled that Germany's nuclear fuel tax is legal, dealing a blow to energy utilities E.ON, RWE, and EnBW, who have demanded a refund of around $5.7 billion. The tax, which has been paid by the utilities, aims to cover the cost of storing radioactive waste. The court's decision, which came after an adviser backed the tax in a previous case, means the utilities' hopes for a refund have been dashed. A related lawsuit filed with Germany's Constitutional Court is still pending, but a decision is expected later this year.

site_title: Dirty money has outsized impact on world's poorest, data shows
summary: A new study by Global Financial Integrity found that illicit financial flows have a significant impact on the world's poorest countries, exacerbating poverty and economic inequality. Data from 2008-2012 showed that countries with high illicit outflows, such as Liberia (61.6% of GDP) and Togo (76.3% of GDP), experienced higher poverty rates and lower development. The study estimates that nearly $1 trillion in illicit finance is lost annually, equivalent to funding a country's health budget four and a half times. World leaders are discussing ways to address tax evasion and illicit financial flows at the G7 summit.

site_title: Indonesia seeks partners to get AIIB voting right, official says
summary: Indonesia seeks partners to gain voting rights in the China-led Asian Infrastructure Investment Bank (AIIB), aiming for a 4% share. The country is trying to form a constituency with a combined 6% share with other member countries like the Maldives. Indonesia is negotiating with countries having shares below 6%, seeking partners with 2.5% or 2% shares. This move is part of Asia's emerging economies seeking a bigger voice in the multi-nation lender, which is part of China's efforts to boost its influence in the region.

site_title: Europe: Shares led lower by weaker utility stocks
summary: European shares fell 0.6% on Thursday, led by weaker utility stocks due to rising bond yields. German 10-year Bund yields reached 2015 highs, impacting utility stocks such as Gas Natural and Red Electrica. However, Swiss agrochemicals group Syngenta rose 1.8% after reports of a potential bid from BASF. The FTSEurofirst 300 index declined, while Germany's DAX weakened 0.5%.

site_title: Alibaba to invest US$194m in financial media firm CBN
summary: Alibaba Group Holding Ltd has agreed to invest US$194 million in China Business News (CBN), a domestic financial media firm. The deal will involve setting up a financial data and information platform targeting China's growing investment community. Alibaba's stake will bolster Executive Chairman Jack Ma's holdings in China's financial sector, aiming to build an array of online services to challenge state-owned banks and financial institutions. This investment further solidifies Alibaba's growing presence in financial services, expanding its reach in China's financial sector.

site_title: Viva Industrial Trust to raise up to S$65m through private placement
summary: Viva Industrial Trust plans to raise up to S$65 million through a private placement, issuing 50.96 million new stapled securities at S$0.785 each. The funds will be used to finance asset enhancement works at Technopark@Chai Chee, aiming to attract creditworthy tenants and negotiate better rental rates. The placement, not underwritten, is expected to reduce the trust's total leverage from 43.4% to 40.6% and increase its free float from 17.4% to 27%.

site_title: Thai baht could get weaker: Deputy PM
summary: Deputy Prime Minister Pridiyathorn Devakula warned that Thailand's baht could get weaker following the central bank's recent measures to spur capital outflows. The baht has depreciated and weakened over 2% against the dollar this year, with its lowest level in over five years. The measures aim to hold down the baht to boost exports, which are crucial to Thailand's trade-dependent economy. The baht stood at 33.69/71 to the dollar at 0830 GMT.

site_title: Nippon Life in early talks to buy NAB insurance business
summary: Japan's Nippon Life Insurance Co is in preliminary discussions to buy National Australia Bank's insurance business for up to $2.4 billion. The deal, if completed, would be Nippon Life's largest overseas acquisition. NAB has been underperforming and is selling non-core assets due to new global capital rules and a new CEO's focus on core businesses. The life insurance business, valued between $1.6 billion and $2.4 billion, was acquired by NAB in 2000 as part of its wealth management division MLC.

site_title: Q&M to buy majority stakes in 3 dental clinics in Liaoning, China
summary: Q&M Dental Group is acquiring majority stakes in three dental clinics in Liaoning, China for 12.2 million yuan (S$2.65 million). The acquisition includes two clinics in Panjin City and one in Gaizhou City, with recorded revenues of 4 million yuan and 835,000 yuan in 2014. The deal includes a profit guarantee of at least 20.33 million yuan and dividend payments of at least 14.81 million yuan over 12 years.

site_title: Peter Lim buys 20% stake in new property portal
summary: Singapore tycoon investor Peter Lim has bought a 20% stake in TheEdgeProperty.com, a new property portal launched by Malaysia's The Edge Media Group. The portal, set to debut in Singapore on July 25, aims to strengthen existing stakeholders in the property industry. Lim, who has previously invested in various sectors, sees growth prospects and immediate revenue generation due to its scalable business model. This marks his first investment in the technology sector.

site_title: IKEA pledges US$1.13b to help slow climate change
summary: IKEA has pledged US$1.13 billion to invest in renewable energy and climate change mitigation efforts, aiming to become energy independent. The investment will include 600 million euros in wind and solar power, in addition to the 1.5 billion euros already invested since 2009. CEO Peter Agnefjall stated that the move will be "win, win, win" for customers, the climate, and IKEA. This commitment underscores companies' growing role in addressing climate change, surpassing governments in efforts to combat global warming.

site_title: SoftBank's stake in Coupang said to value firm at US$5b
summary: SoftBank Corp is investing $1 billion in South Korean online retailer Coupang, valuing the firm at approximately $5 billion. The deal, set to close in July, follows SoftBank's strategy to replicate its successful Alibaba Group Holding Ltd investment, now worth $72 billion. Analysts see the move as a key step in SoftBank's goal to become the world's No. 1 internet company, with increasing e-commerce consumption globally.

site_title: Slower increase in Singapore's private sector wages in 2014
summary: Singapore's private sector wages increased 4.9% in 2014, slightly lower than the 5.3% increase in 2013. However, real total wages rose 3.9% last year, up from 2.9% in 2013. This growth was largely driven by lower inflation. Nearly three in five companies with low-paying employees (S$1,000/month) gave wage increases, similar to 2012's rate. The proportion of employers adopting flexible wage systems was also at its highest in a decade.

site_title: Bond rout wipes out 2015 gain
summary: The global bond market has experienced a significant selloff, erasing all of 2015's gains, due to improved economic outlooks in the euro zone and increased volatility. The Bank of America Merrill Lynch Global Broad Market Index of bonds with a total face value of $41 trillion is now down 0.4% for the year. European Central Bank President Mario Draghi attributed the rout to heightened volatility, improved economic and inflation outlooks, and a lack of market liquidity. The selloff has been exacerbated by quantitative easing, which has made investors overly sensitive to interest rates.

site_title: GM sales slump deepens in China despite discounts
summary: General Motors reported a 4% decline in May sales in China, its largest market, to 252,567 vehicles. Despite cutting prices on 40 models across its Buick, Chevrolet, and Cadillac brands, the decline was mainly due to a changeover and phasing out of older models. The company still expects annual growth of 6-8% in China, with Cadillac sales rising 11% and low-cost Baojun brand sales jumping almost fourfold. Foreign automakers face pressure from slowing economic growth and local brands offering cheaper SUVs.

site_title: Malaysia islamic asset growth to rebound on deposit transparency
summary: Malaysia's Islamic banking assets are expected to rebound to 20% growth due to increased transparency for depositors, following a two-year effort to improve deposit transparency. The nation's Shariah-compliant banking industry slowed to 13% growth in the past three years, but is expected to rise to high-teens in the near to medium term. The growth is driven by increased demand from the retail consumer market and the introduction of a new Shariah-compliant investment option by the Employees Provident Fund, set to become the world's largest such fund.

images.alt_text: "We expect the growth to go back to the high-teens if not in the low twenties in the near to medium term," said Kuala Lumpur-based Badlisyah, who is also the chief executive officer of CIMB Islamic Bank Bhd.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks close 0.38% down
summary: Hong Kong stocks closed 0.38% lower on Thursday, despite a positive lead from Wall Street. The Hang Seng Index slipped to 27,551.89 on turnover of HK$195.23 billion. In contrast, the Shanghai Composite Index rose 0.76% to 4,947.10, its highest level since January 2008. The Shenzhen Composite Index fell 0.58%. The market's volatility was attributed to ongoing US-China trade tensions and uncertainty.

site_title: Ku De Ta nightclub renamed Ce La Vi , new outlet in HK planned
summary: Ku De Ta nightclub in Singapore has been renamed Ce La Vi, following a court ruling that ordered the club to stop using the name due to a five-year legal battle. The new outlet in Hong Kong's California Tower will open next month, with plans to expand to other cities including Dubai and Taipei. Ce La Vi aims to become an international lifestyle and hedonism brand, featuring Asian-inspired design, modern cuisine, and entertainment. A renovation is underway in Singapore's Marina Bay Sands Skypark, with a five-year expansion plan to establish the brand as a global presence.

site_title: Malaysia's ethical sukuk adds to market width but depth elusive
summary: Malaysia's sovereign wealth fund Khazanah Nasional has launched the country's first sustainable and responsible investment (SRI) sukuk, aiming to develop the Islamic finance market. Despite efforts to innovate, sukuk issuance remains dominated by government-related issuers, with only $13.5 billion issued by corporate issuers in 2014. The new SRI sukuk aims to appeal to first-time issuers, but complexity and costs may deter private-sector firms from issuing their own versions. Further expansion will require greater buy-in from the private sector.

site_title: Hedge fund boss Paulson gives Harvard record US$400m
summary: Harvard University has received a record-breaking $400 million donation from hedge fund investor John Paulson, a 1980 Harvard Business School graduate. The gift, made to the School of Engineering and Applied Sciences, will help place Boston at the center of US innovation. This is the third record-sized gift Harvard has received from an alumnus in the past year, contributing to the university's $6.5 billion fundraising campaign, which has already surpassed $5 billion.

site_title: Indonesian c.bank says 'always' in the forex market to calm fluctuations
summary: Indonesia's central bank vows to intervene in the foreign exchange and bond markets to calm fluctuations, following the rupiah's 17-year low against the dollar. The rupiah weakened due to the strengthening of the euro, trading at 13,240 per dollar. The bank's spokesman, Peter Jacobs, stated that Bank Indonesia will "always" be in the market to monitor and stabilize exchange rates and bond prices. The bond yield rose to 8.198% on Thursday morning.

site_title: Dish in talks to merge with T-Mobile
summary: Dish Network Corp is in talks to merge with T-Mobile US Inc, with the two sides agreeing on the combined company's structure. However, a purchase price and the mix of cash and stock for the deal remain unresolved. The Wall Street Journal reported the talks, citing people familiar with the matter. Dish and T-Mobile declined to comment after regular business hours.

site_title: GE said to hire banks to start sale on US$20b assets
summary: General Electric Co has hired banks to sell US$20 billion of assets from its health-care, railcar, and franchise finance divisions. The company is working with JPMorgan Chase & Co, Deutsche Bank AG, and Barclays Plc to find buyers. The sales process is accelerating GE's plan to divest US$200 billion of its GE Capital operations by 2016, a year earlier than initially planned. The move aims to refocus GE on industrial manufacturing.

site_title: Blackstone seeking US$1.5b for Boston Office buildings
summary: Blackstone Group LP is seeking approximately US$1.5 billion for two Boston office buildings acquired in 2007. The properties, at 500 Boylston St. and 222 Berkeley St., occupy the same block and have a combined 1.311 million square feet. Blackstone is selling assets amid a recovery in office occupancies and demand for prime real estate in coastal markets, following previous sales of Northern California properties and development parcels.

site_title: O&G? More like OMG
summary: Singapore O&G's first day of trading saw its stock price jump 132% from 25 Singapore cents to 58 cents, making it a profitable IPO for investors who purchased the stock. However, the company may have priced its offering too low, as it could have raised more capital or executed a less dilutive IPO. The IPO manager, Hong Leong Finance, may bear responsibility for the low price, as it has a history of underestimating market demand for healthcare stocks, with an average first-day gain of 109%.

site_title: Drones target tax cheats in Indonesia's palm oil plantations
summary: Indonesia's government is using drones to target tax cheats in palm oil plantations and tin mines. The drones, launched from a football field, map out vast areas in just an hour, providing precise data on plantation sizes and tree ages. The program aims to increase tax revenue, which has been below the Asia-Pacific average, and fund a $400 billion infrastructure program. The government has also raised pay for collectors and offered to exempt citizens from penalties if they settle unpaid taxes.

site_title: China: Stocks slump as technology firms sink on valuation concern
summary: China's stocks fell 1.8% to 4,822.42 due to a 3.6% decline in technology shares, amid concerns about rapid gains and a potential flood of new equity sales. The country's second-largest nuclear power operator, China National Nuclear Power Co., raised 1.69 trillion yuan (S$367.7 billion) in bids for its IPO. This is the first mentioned article in the provided content.

site_title: Massive Tiananmen vigil expected in divided Hong Kong
summary: Tens of thousands of people in Hong Kong are expected to attend a candlelit vigil on Thursday to commemorate the 26th anniversary of China's Tiananmen Square crackdown. The event marks the military's brutal suppression of pro-democracy protests in 1989, resulting in hundreds, possibly over a thousand, deaths. Hong Kong is the only location where a major commemoration takes place on Chinese soil, amid a divided city preparing for a vote on its next leader. The event is a significant moment for the city, highlighting the ongoing struggle for democratic reforms.

site_title: Alarm spreads as South Korea reports more MERS cases
summary: South Korea reported five new cases of Middle East Respiratory Syndrome (MERS), bringing the total to 35, with two deaths. The outbreak, caused by a coronavirus, has led to 1,600 people being quarantined. Authorities have demanded measures to halt the spread, while North Korea has called for border checks. The disease has a higher death rate than SARS but spreads less swiftly. Over 700 schools were closed, and the global total of MERS cases reached 1,180, with at least 442 related deaths.

site_title: Australia: Shares fall as disappointing retail sales add to economy fears
summary: Australian shares fell for a fourth consecutive session due to weak retail sales and trade data, fueling concerns about the economy. Retail sales were flat, missing forecasts, while the balance of goods and services showed a bigger deficit than expected. The Reserve Bank of Australia kept its policy rate on hold, indicating no near future easing. This decision suggests the governor has limited room for further rate cuts.

site_title: Australian banks 'appalling behaviour' towards rate probe: watchdog
summary: Australia's corporate watchdog, ASIC, has described the behavior of major banks towards a rate probe as "absolutely appalling" and demanded more cooperation. The investigation, focusing on interbank lending practices from 2007 to 2013, comes after US and British regulators fined six major global banks nearly $6 billion for rigging the foreign exchange market and Libor. ASIC is seeking more cooperation from the banks, following a similar approach taken by US and British regulators.

images.alt_text: Australia's corporate watchdog has described the behaviour of the country's biggest banks towards an investigation into possible rigging of the benchmark interest rate as "absolutely appalling" and demanded more cooperation.

site_title: China may free up bank deposit rates soon: central bank official
summary: China's central bank official, Sheng Songcheng, suggests that the bank deposit rates may be freed up soon, rather than increasing the cap again. This move would mark a landmark reform allowing market forces to determine credit costs, helping to rebalance the economy. Analysts expect the central bank to cut interest rates and banks' reserve requirements to boost demand for credit and increase money supply, stabilizing economic growth. The move aims to avoid wasteful investment funded by artificially cheap credit and promote sustainable growth.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks open flat
summary: Hong Kong stocks opened flat on Thursday, with the Hang Seng Index easing 12.11 points to 27,645.36. Profit-taking after the previous day's gains offset a positive lead from New York and Europe.

site_title: Free pizza for life helps close Portland real estate deal
summary: A Portland homeowner accepted a unique offer from a buyer, Donna DiNicola, who offered free pizza every month for life in exchange for purchasing a 900 square foot home. The offer, which included a $275,000 price tag and two months of free rent, stood out among dozens of other bids in the competitive real estate market. The seller, Holly Marsh, described the offer as "compelling" and "hilarious," and may even take up the pizza offer for their son's birthday dinner.

images.alt_text: In Portland's hot real estate market where some homes are getting dozens of offers and bidding wars have sent prices skyrocketing, one buyer found a way to stand out among the rest: Offer free pizza every month for life.

site_title: Singapore: STI opens 0.3% lower on Thursday
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) fell 9.91 points or 0.3% to 3,339.93 points on Thursday, despite a positive lead in US and Tokyo markets. The decline comes after Wall Street stocks rose on Wednesday following positive US data and the European Central Bank's monetary stimulus commitment. Trading volumes were high, with 86.9 million shares changing hands worth S$198.8 million.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open lower on Thursday morning
summary: Malaysia's shares opened lower on Thursday morning, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index falling 8.13 points to 1,741.04 points. Volume was 21.8 million lots worth RM18.46 million. Gainers outnumbered losers 114 to 72.

site_title: Stocks to watch: YuuZoo, CapitaLand, Vallianz
summary: YuuZoo Corporation formed a new e-sport joint venture in China, aiming for 5 million active paying users and 1.5 million yuan in revenue. CapitaLand Limited reached its goal of 40,000 serviced residence units, aiming to double to 80,000 by 2020. Vallianz Holdings secured S$10 million through the issue of convertible preference shares to expand its fleet and working capital.

site_title: Kuroda urges vigilance on spillovers of diverging Fed, ECB, BOJ policies
summary: Bank of Japan Governor Haruhiko Kuroda urged policymakers to consider the global impact of diverging monetary policies on emerging economies. He noted the importance of accurately measuring inflation expectations and managing international capital flows. Kuroda warned that emerging economies may face challenges from the Federal Reserve's proposed interest rate hikes, which could trigger capital outflows. The BOJ has expanded its stimulus to prevent deflation, and Kuroda emphasized the need for better understanding of inflation expectations to evaluate the effectiveness of unconventional monetary policies.

site_title: Oil prices dip as crude glut overshadows strong fuel demand
summary: Oil prices dipped on Thursday, with front-month Brent futures falling 16 cents to $63.64 per barrel, as a large crude glut overshadowed strong global fuel demand. Despite a sliding dollar, the oversupply of crude is expected to persist, with the Organization of the Petroleum Exporting Countries (Opec) likely to maintain its production levels. However, strong fuel demand in Europe and Asia, particularly in China and North America, has curbed declines in prices, with Goldman Sachs forecasting Brent to average $60 in 2015 and $70 in 2016.

site_title: Nestle faces brand crisis in India over lead in iconic noodles
summary: Nestle's Maggi instant noodles in India face a crisis after a routine test revealed excessive lead levels, 7 times the permissible limit. The product, a staple comfort food for decades, has jolted the nation, prompting officials in six states to order independent testing and criminal complaints against the company and its ambassadors. Shares of Nestle's Indian unit have plummeted, and the food minister has threatened to consider class action suits, amid concerns over the metal's link to learning difficulties and death.

site_title: Alibaba joins share-sale frenzy with offering for pictures unit
summary: Alibaba Pictures Group Ltd, a unit of Alibaba Group Holding Ltd, plans to raise HK$12.2 billion (S$2.15 billion) by selling new shares in Hong Kong to finance potential acquisitions. The sale of 4.2 billion shares will increase the number of outstanding shares by 20%, leading to a 11% drop in the company's shares. This offering adds to the US$21.9 billion raised through share sales in Hong Kong this year, as the Greater China region experiences a surge in stock market activity, with over 380 companies announcing deals exceeding US$130 billion in 2015.

site_title: Japan's Rakuten says to raise US$1.5b by issuing new shares
summary: Japan's Rakuten Inc plans to issue new shares worth approximately S$2 billion to raise funds for debt repayment. The company will issue 100 million new shares, boosting its shares by 7.5%. The new shares will be used 90% for debt repayment, with the remaining 10% for other purposes. Shares in Rakuten were down 6% in early morning trade following the announcement.

site_title: Australia shoppers shut wallets in blow to growth hopes
summary: Australian retail sales remained flat in April, defying forecasts of a 0.4% increase, and the country's trade deficit tripled to A$3.89 billion, a record high. Falling commodity prices and weak wages growth are attributed to the decline. The local dollar slid, and interest rate cuts are seen as possible, with a 60% chance of a move by Christmas. The flat retail sales and trade deficit will be a disappointment to the Reserve Bank of Australia, which had previously hinted at a revival in consumer demand.

site_title: Apple's China challenge is getting users to pay for downloads
summary: Apple has successfully convinced developers in China to create apps for the iPhone, making the country the largest market for downloads last quarter. However, the challenge now is getting Chinese users to pay for software, as revenue from downloads in China trailed behind the US. Apple is working to change this by promoting its ecosystem and encouraging developers to create apps with value and meaning. The company estimates that 1.5 million jobs have been created in China due to iOS apps, and it plans to double the number of retail stores in the country by mid-2016.

site_title: Hot stock: Singapore O&G doubles on trading debut
summary: Singapore O&G (SOG), a healthcare firm specializing in women's healthcare, more than doubled on its trading debut on the Catalist board, reaching S$0.555 after opening at S$0.455. The counter surged 122% above its initial public offer price of S$0.25, with 31.4 million shares changing hands. SOG plans to use the net proceeds of S$9.2 million to invest in healthcare professionals and synergistic businesses. The firm's 2014 net profit rose to S$4.25 million, up from S$3.12 million in 2013.

site_title: Tallest Seattle Tower said to sell to Gaw for over US$700m
summary: A group led by Gaw Capital Partners agreed to buy Columbia Center, Seattle's tallest tower, for over $700 million. The 76-story building, completed in 1985, has about 1.5 million square feet of space and an occupancy rate of 87%. The sale, a record for an individual office building in the city, follows a period of increased foreign investment in US real estate. Columbia Center, the second-tallest US building west of Chicago, was previously occupied by Amazon before it left for a new headquarters campus in 2010.

site_title: Taiwan: Stocks down slightly on caution ahead of inflation, trade data
summary: Taiwan's stocks fell 0.1% to 9,545.85 on Thursday, marking the fourth consecutive session of decline, ahead of inflation and trade data for May. Exports were expected to show a fourth consecutive month of decline, while inflation is expected to have contracted. The Consumer Price Index (CPI) will be issued on Friday, while trade data is due on Monday.

site_title: Asia: Stocks higher, euro holds up as Greek talks plod
summary: Asian markets rose as investors took a positive cue from Wall Street and Europe, with the euro holding steady amid Greek bailout talks. The eurozone inflation is projected to reach 0.3% in 2015, while the euro was at US$1.1262 and 140.13 yen on Thursday. Asian markets including Hong Kong, Shanghai, and Tokyo gained ground, while Sydney fell 0.46 percent. The US dollar edged up following upbeat economic reports, and equity buying was supported by comments from European Central Bank chief Mario Draghi.

site_title: Brazil hikes interest rates to 13.75% as expected
summary: Brazil's central bank raised interest rates to 13.75% from 13.25% in a unanimous vote, marking the fifth consecutive rate hike. The move was expected by most economists and traders, despite concerns it could deepen the country's recession. The bank made no changes to the decision statement, sticking to its previous wording.

site_title: Sandberg gets personal in note on mourning husband
summary: Facebook COO Sheryl Sandberg shared a personal note on mourning her husband David Goldberg, who died suddenly in Mexico. In the post, Sandberg expressed her sorrow and newfound wisdom, stating she's become "thirty years sadder" but also "thirty years wiser." She credited her mother for helping her understand the pain of losing a loved one, noting the anguish she feels is both her own and her children's. Sandberg's emotional post has resonated with fans, offering a glimpse into her grief and personal growth.

site_title: Google buying Twitter an 'instant fit,' investor Sacca says
summary: Longtime Twitter investor Chris Sacca said Google buying Twitter would be a "fantastic use of Google's cash" and an "instant fit" due to Twitter's unique social features. Sacca believes Twitter should improve its products and services to lure more users and advertisers, or risk being acquired by Google, Microsoft, or Facebook. In a blog post, Sacca outlined suggestions for Twitter to broaden its appeal, including highlighting live events and popular discussions, in an effort to remain independent.

site_title: Otto Marine redeems preference shares for S$12m
summary: Otto Marine has fully redeemed S$12 million in preference shares from a Singapore private equity firm. The private equity firm had subscribed for S$10 million redeemable preference shares in Go Marine Investments Pte Ltd in 2013. The transaction is not expected to impact Otto Marine's net tangible assets or earnings for the current financial year.

site_title: Greece still rejects some of creditors' proposals: Tsipras
summary: Greece's Prime Minister Alexis Tsipras said the country still rejects some of its creditors' proposals, but is willing to reach a deal in coming days. Tsipras stated that there are "points that no one would consider as a base for discussion" and expressed a willingness to find a mutually acceptable solution. European Commission officials and Eurogroup chief Jeroen Dijsselbloem expressed progress in talks, with a meeting to continue in the coming days.

images.alt_text: Greece still rejects some of the reform plans put forward by its EU-IMF creditors but sees a willingness to reach a deal in coming days, Prime Minister Alexis Tsipras said Thursday after crunch bailout talks in Brussels.

site_title: China's hot IPO market lures US$273b to US$2b offering
summary: China's initial public offerings (IPOs) have attracted significant investor interest, with a company's US$2 billion offering receiving total bids of almost US$273 billion. This is equivalent to the annual economic output of Hong Kong. Investors are drawn to mainland Chinese IPOs, which tend to surge in initial trading, partly due to regulators discouraging high valuations. This trend is fueling China's hot IPO market, with investors seeking to capitalize on the potential for growth.

images.alt_text: China's initial public offerings are such hot commodities that a company seeking to raise US$2 billion attracted total bids for an amount almost equaling the entire annual economic output of Hong Kong.

site_title: Pyongyang Bling: The rise of North Korea's consumer comrades
summary: North Korea is witnessing a rise in consumerism, with nail salons, massage parlors, and cafes emerging in the country. The demand for Western-style products such as cosmetics, smartphones, and foreign clothes is increasing among North Koreans earning money in the unofficial economy. This shift is a departure from the country's rigidly controlled socialist model, where conspicuous consumption was discouraged. The growing middle class is driving this change, with residents and visitors noting the shift in consumer behavior.

site_title: US stock market reform has wrong focus, outgoing regulator says
summary: US Securities and Exchange Commissioner Daniel Gallagher says the piecemeal approach to regulating the stock market is unlikely to lead to major changes, calling for a more dramatic overhaul. The SEC plans a comprehensive market review, but Gallagher believes relying on a new advisory committee may not yield significant results. Recent initiatives, such as testing increased trading increments for small public companies, are expected to produce results in four years, suggesting a status quo approach for the time being.

site_title: Showtime to offer streaming service
summary: Showtime to launch a streaming service in July, offering movies, original series, and sports programming without cable subscriptions. The service will be available on desktop computers and Apple devices for $11 monthly. This move follows HBO's launch of a standalone online TV service, appealing to "cord cutters" looking to ditch costly cable subscriptions. The streaming service will compete with existing platforms such as Netflix, Roku, and Amazon Fire.

images.alt_text: The announcement by Showtime, which is owned by CBS, came a few months after HBO launched a standalone online TV service via Apple's streaming media player - appealing to "cord cutters" ready to ditch their costly cable subscriptions.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open 0.32% higher
summary: Tokyo stocks opened 0.32% higher on Thursday, driven by gains on Wall Street and a weak yen. The Nikkei 225 index rose 66.43 points to 20,539.94, backed by the European Central Bank's commitment to stimulus policies. The dollar strengthened against the yen, making Japanese exporters more competitive abroad. The ECB kept interest rates unchanged and President Mario Draghi dismissed talk of ending early monetary stimulus plans, supporting the market.

site_title: Death toll from capsized China ship rises to 65, families demand answers
summary: A ship capsized on China's Yangtze River, killing 65 people and leaving 370 missing. The vessel, carrying 456 people, including elderly tourists, sank in a freak tornado on Monday night. Despite a police cordon, over 80 family members marched to the site to demand answers, breaching the security. Rescuers plan to cut a hole in the ship's hull to search for survivors, with 14 people, including the captain, already found. Authorities are facing criticism for the slow response and lack of information.

site_title: HDB resale prices flat in May, transaction volume dips 2.2%: SRX
summary: HDB resale prices in Singapore remained flat in May, unchanged from April, according to SRX Property's flash estimates. The transaction volume fell 2.2% to 1,575 units, with a 19.3% year-on-year increase. The median transaction over X-value (TOX) remained at negative S$2,000, indicating that buyers are overpaying or underpaying. Prices of flats in mature estates declined 3.9% year-on-year, while non-mature estates saw a 6% drop. Overall, the market shows signs of stabilization, but buyers are still facing challenges.

images.alt_text: Kalpana Rashiwala
Resale prices of Housing & Development Board (HDB) flats remained unchanged in May compared with April, according to SRX Property's flash estimates released on Thursday.

site_title: Greek crisis talks end without breakthrough
summary: Greece and its creditors failed to reach a breakthrough in Brussels talks, leaving Greece to face a critical payment to the International Monetary Fund on Friday. The four-hour meeting between Prime Minister Alexis Tsipras and European Commission chief Jean-Claude Juncker did not yield an agreement on a reform plan to unlock the final €7.2 billion bailout tranche. Talks will resume soon, but Greece remains at risk of a possible euro exit without a deal.

site_title: IEA sees slower rise in global gas demand as Asian markets weaken
summary: The International Energy Agency (IEA) forecasts a slower rise in global natural gas demand, averaging 2% per year over the next five years, due to weaker Asian markets. This marks a deceleration from the 2.3% growth rate over the past decade, with global demand expected to reach 3,926 billion cubic meters by 2020. The decline is attributed to the rise of cheap coal and falling costs for renewables, making gas less competitive in the market.

site_title: YuuZoo forms e-sport joint venture in China
summary: YuuZoo Corporation has formed a joint venture with XG AMA in China, aiming to capture 5 million active paying users and 1.5 million yuan in revenue within the first 12 months. The e-sport joint venture, YuuGames, will target 146,000 internet gaming bars in China, leveraging XG AMA's existing agreements with 3,000 bars. The app will facilitate online and offline gaming interactions, shopping, and events, further expanding YuuZoo's presence in the rapidly growing Chinese gaming market.

site_title: Ascott achieves goal of 40,000 units ahead of schedule
summary: THE Ascott Limited has exceeded its goal of 40,000 units globally ahead of schedule, adding 18 properties and opening eight in the past five months. The serviced residence owner and operator now has over 41,000 units in 25 countries, with a target to double its portfolio to 80,000 by 2020. CEO Lee Chee Koon attributes the success to expansion through investments and strategic alliances, aiming to reap operational efficiencies and cost savings. China is expected to be a key market, with a quarter of units located there by 2020.

site_title: US: Stocks rise on data, dovish ECB meeting
summary: US stocks rose on Wednesday, driven by solid economic data and a dovish European Central Bank meeting. The Dow Jones Industrial Average gained 64.33 points, while the S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite Indexes rose 4.47 and 22.71 points respectively. The US trade deficit dropped in April, and new private-sector jobs were added in May. The ECB confirmed its ultra-easy money policies, with ECB President Mario Draghi stating there were no plans to end them sooner.

site_title: Vallianz raises S$10m through convertible preference share issue
summary: Vallianz Holdings, an offshore marine solutions provider, has raised S$10 million through the issue of 10 million convertible preference shares to United Orient Capital (UOC) at US$1 each. The net proceeds will be used for fleet expansion and general working capital. UOC will receive a cumulative preferential dividend of 4% for the first four years, with the option to convert shares at a premium. The investment signals confidence in Vallianz's business model and growth prospects, despite the uncertain offshore oil and gas industry.

site_title: G-7's role as actor in international security under-appreciated
summary: The G-7 summit in Dresden, Germany, will focus on the Greek crisis and its potential exit from the Eurozone, as well as other geopolitical issues such as Ukraine and energy security. The summit comes at a time of growing international alarm over the crisis, and the G-7 will discuss ways to manage the situation. Russia will not be participating in the meeting due to its annexation of Crimea, but may rejoin if it changes its course. The G-7 will also address issues of tax evasion and cross-border coordination on terrorist funding.

site_title: Japan's economy is still recovering so Abe shouldn't overreach
summary: Japan's economy, still recovering from two decades of stagnation and deflation, is not ready for Prime Minister Shinzo Abe's ambitious plans for increased overseas military projection and grandiose investments. Despite efforts by Abe and Bank of Japan governor Haruhiko Kuroda to boost the economy, Japan's huge debt, shrinking domestic tax base, and aging population pose significant challenges. The government's debt-to-GDP ratio is over twice the level of other developed economies, and interest rates are expected to rise, further increasing the burden of servicing the debt. Abe should prioritize economic recovery and structural reforms before pursuing his ambitious plans.

site_title: Pin and shop on Pinterest with 'buyable pins'
summary: Pinterest is introducing "buyable pins" that allow users to purchase items directly from the platform. The feature, launching on iPhones and iPads in the US later this month, will use Apple Pay or credit cards for payments. The move aims to enable users to buy products they see on Pinterest without leaving the platform. Pinterest has partnered with Shopify to facilitate the service, and it will be free for buyers and sellers. The company has raised $367 million in new capital, valuing it at $11 billion, and plans to expand globally with the new feature.

site_title: Europe: Shares fall from highs, turn lower after ECB
summary: European shares fell, mirroring a selloff in German bonds, after the European Central Bank raised its inflation forecasts and signaled it would maintain a steady policy. Despite this, some national indexes remained positive, with Germany's DAX and France's CAC falling back from intraday highs. The euro rose broadly, and German Bund yields soared, with investors expressing disappointment in ECB President Mario Draghi's comments. Market support came from merger talks between Ahold and Delhaize, which could create a top 20 global retailer.

site_title: Opec moots US$80 as new 'fair' oil price - but will it stick?
summary: Opec ministers from Iraq, Venezuela, and Angola suggest a new "fair" oil price of $75-$80 per barrel, barely above the current market rate. This comes as the group maintains its current production levels, defying efforts to push prices back up into the $70s. Saudi Arabia has not indicated support for this view, and finding a balance between meeting demand and preventing US shale production from resuming its rapid growth will be challenging. Opec's role as a swing supplier has fallen to shale drillers, adding to market uncertainty.

site_title: Euro gains on higher ECB inflation forecast
summary: The euro strengthened against the dollar and other currencies after the European Central Bank (ECB) confirmed its easy money policies and forecast higher near-term inflation, reaching 0.3% in 2015. The ECB kept interest rates unchanged, with President Mario Draghi dismissing talk of ending early monetary stimulus plans. The dollar fell against the euro, but rose against the yen and pound, weighed down by mixed US economic data ahead of the May jobs report.

site_title: DirectTV deal: AT&T may abide by new net neutrality rules
summary: AT&T is expected to accept aspects of the new net neutrality rules as a condition for its US$49 billion purchase of DirecTV. The company may agree to abide by the FCC's ban on slowing websites, blocking websites, and taking payments from website operators to speed up content. This commitment would bind AT&T to the rules for the duration of the agreement, regardless of the outcome of its industry coalition's lawsuit to roll back the net neutrality rules. The FCC may approve the deal by mid-month, pending negotiations.

site_title: US economy grew in April-May after Q1 stall: Federal Reserve's Beige Book
summary: The US economy showed modest-to-moderate growth in April and May after stalling in Q1, according to the Federal Reserve's Beige Book survey. Consumer spending, construction, and travel increased in most districts, driven by lower gasoline prices. However, the oil industry was negatively impacted, contributing to slower growth in the Dallas and Kansas City districts. The economy rebounded after contracting 0.7% in Q1 due to harsh winter weather and port slowdowns, but the growth was not as strong as expected, with manufacturing activity and job gains remaining slight.

site_title: Fifa probe: Blazer details corruption in 1998, 2010 World Cup host bids
summary: Chuck Blazer, a former FIFA official, admitted to conspiring with fellow executives to accept bribes during the 1998 and 2010 World Cup host bids. Blazer pleaded guilty to racketeering and other charges, describing how he and others on the FIFA executive committee accepted bribes for hosting the 1998 World Cup in France and the 2010 World Cup in South Africa. The US investigation into FIFA's corruption has led to a "Racketeering Influenced Corrupt Organisation" designation, with Blazer awaiting sentencing.

site_title: Greek PM meets EU's Juncker as debt drama nears climax
summary: Greek Prime Minister Alexis Tsipras met with European Commission chief Jean-Claude Juncker in Brussels, seeking a bailout deal to end a four-month standoff. Tsipras presented a reform plan to unlock the final €7.2 billion tranche of Greece's international rescue package. However, creditors were skeptical and insisted Tsipras work from their tougher proposal to avoid a possible default on Friday's IMF payment. A deal is crucial to prevent Greece from defaulting on its debt obligations.

site_title: Qatar outlook trumps World Cup risk as stocks pare sell-off
summary: Qatar's stocks closed little changed after a 3.2% drop, the largest in two months, amid concerns over the country's hosting of the 2022 World Cup following FIFA president Sepp Blatter's resignation. Despite the controversy, Qatar's economic growth outlook remains solid, with an estimated 6% growth per year until 2017. The country is spending $200 billion on infrastructure, and investors believe the long-term story for Qatar remains intact. The QE Index closed at 12,182.09, with the largest decline in Ezdan Holding Group and the smallest increase in Qatar National Bank.

site_title: Digiland acquires 65% of S'pore software maker
summary: Digiland International has acquired 65% of Singapore software maker iBase Technology International for S$26,000. The joint venture will develop and market real-time enterprise solutions to support global e-Government initiatives, focusing on areas such as accounting and claims management, human resource management, and real estate management. The suite of solutions, UBERIQ, is currently used by several government agencies and will be marketed globally starting from July, with interest from government-affiliated parties in Indonesia and Africa.

site_title: Oil prices fall as US output edges higher
summary: US crude oil prices fell, with West Texas Intermediate dropping $1.62 to $59.64 a barrel, and Brent crude losing $1.69 to $63.80 a barrel. The US Energy Department reported a 20,000-barrel-a-day increase in US output, despite low prices and a global oil glut. The Saudi-led OPEC cartel plans to maintain production levels, and Iran's potential nuclear deal could add another 1 million barrels a day to the market. US production reached nearly 9.6 million barrels a day, a 1.2 million-barrel-a-day increase from last year.

images.alt_text: Crude oil prices fell on Wednesday after the weekly US oil report showed a rise in US crude output, against expectations that producers were pulling back.

site_title: Modi's income insurance plan may not ease rural distress
summary: Indian Prime Minister Narendra Modi plans to introduce an income insurance plan for farmers, but experts say it may not alleviate rural distress due to bureaucracy and limited coverage for small farmers. The scheme aims to provide a guaranteed income by covering losses from weather and price slumps, but its effectiveness is uncertain due to outdated methods for assessing crop damage. The plan is expected to benefit mainly large farmers, and the government is working to improve access to banking services to increase the number of farmers who can receive payouts.

site_title: PCRD urged to make 'truly fair' bid in the event of privatisation
summary: A Singapore institutional investor has urged Pacific Century Regional Developments (PCRD) to make a "truly fair" bid if the company is to be privatised, as vehicles controlled by Richard Li top 86% of the stake. PCRD has clarified it was not aware of any privatisation proposal. The company's share price has risen to a near 13-year high, with a delisting threshold of 90% expected. Minority shareholders are calling for a fair offer to be made in the event of a delisting.

site_title: Brokers' take
summary: Ezra Holdings proposes a renounceable rights issue of up to 2.02 billion new shares and an issue of fixed rate convertible bonds, totaling estimated net proceeds of US$289.5 million. OCBC Investment Research downgrades the company to "sell" due to dilutive effect on fair value estimate. Meanwhile, Cache Logistics Trust divests a warehouse to JTC for S$9.7 million, citing the need to streamline its portfolio and focus on large-scale warehouses.

site_title: S'pore ranks 7th among top 10 destination cities
summary: Singapore ranks 7th among the world's top 10 destination cities, attracting 11.88 million international overnight visitors in 2015, down from 6th place in 2014. London topped the index with 18.82 million visitors, while Bangkok followed closely with 18.24 million. Despite the decline, Singapore remains a magnet for tourist spending, ranking 5th internationally with $14.7 billion in expected visitor spending. The city's resilience and continued growth in the tourism sector are attributed to innovation and partnerships that draw tourists to stay longer and spend in Singapore.

site_title: MAS plans to strengthen OTC derivatives market
summary: The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) has proposed measures to strengthen oversight of capital markets intermediaries dealing in over-the-counter (OTC) derivatives and refine rules governing financial advisory services. The financial watchdog invites comments on the proposed changes, aiming to enhance regulatory framework and improve financial advisory services. This move aims to increase transparency and protect investors in the OTC derivatives market.

site_title: EPL to leave its mark at National Stadium
summary: The English Premier League (EPL) has chosen Singapore to host its Barclays Asia Trophy tournament, with top premier league stars set to participate. The decision was made two years ago, following the availability of the new National Stadium in Kallang. The EPL director of sales and marketing, Richard Masters, stated that Singapore was the "overwhelming favourite" due to the stadium's availability. The tournament is scheduled to take place in Singapore, marking the EPL's mark at the National Stadium.

images.alt_text: Lee U-Wen

site_title: Interpol puts two former officials on 'red notice' wanted list
summary: Interpol has issued a "red notice" for two former top FIFA officials, following a US investigation into corruption at the soccer governing body. The request was made at the request of US authorities. South Africa denied allegations it bribed a soccer official with $10 million meant for the 2010 World Cup. The payment was claimed to be for a legitimate purpose, contradicting US prosecutors' allegations.

site_title: Mega deals send merged companies up the ranks of world's largest
summary: The world's largest companies are getting bigger through mega deals and organic growth, according to a PwC study. 15 new entries joined the global top 100 companies by market value this year, with five joining through mergers and acquisitions or a stock market listing. US companies dominate the list, taking seven of the top 10 spots, with Apple maintaining its crown as the highest-valued company. The study highlights the importance of strategic acquisitions in driving growth, with energy firms experiencing significant drops in market value due to falling oil prices.

site_title: Trialling of Smart Nation services progressing well: IDA
summary: Singapore's Smart Nation drive is progressing well, with the Infocomm Development Authority of Singapore (IDA) leading the effort to prototype various technologies and services. IDA's executive deputy chairman, Steve Leonard, noted that trialling the HetNet in the Jurong Lake District is on track. The Smart Nation initiative aims to create an environment that fosters new growth and market opportunities for firms, highlighting the country's commitment to innovation and technological advancement.

site_title: Global economy in danger of stalling: OECD
summary: The Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development (OECD) has given the global economy a B-minus grade for its performance, warning that a failing grade is possible if policy reforms are not implemented. The OECD attributes the weak recovery from the 2008 financial crisis to low levels of public and private investment, disappointing productivity growth, and subdued demand. The report projects that global growth will strengthen gradually to approach its past average pace by late 2016, with some economies expected to grow faster than others.

site_title: Singapore to boost Islamic finance regime
summary: Singapore's central bank will continue to strengthen its Islamic finance regime to support growth in cross-border Islamic finance and infrastructure projects in Asia and the Middle East. The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) aims to enhance the bankability of infrastructure projects and involve more capital market participants. This will complement the growing global Islamic finance industry, which has seen total assets exceed $2 trillion in the past decade, with most demand stemming from Asia and the Middle East.

images.alt_text: With cross-border Islamic finance set to grow further, Singapore's central bank will continue to strengthen its Islamic finance regime and capabilities, said Jacqueline Loh, deputy managing director of the Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS).
Fiona Lam

site_title: Renewed interest in Irish trophy homes
summary: Wealthy buyers are returning to Ireland, sparking renewed interest in trophy homes, nearly a decade after the 2008 property bubble burst. In the Dublin suburb of Howth, developer Joe Cosgrave is overseeing the construction of Ireland's first luxury home development since 2008. The project features granite-framed doorways and vast walk-in wardrobes, catering to high-end buyers. This resurgence marks a shift towards a more optimistic market, with demand for luxury properties on the rise.

site_title: No homes are too luxurious for Manhattan super-rich
summary: Record prices in Manhattan's luxury real estate market have crossed the US$100 million threshold for a single apartment, with agents customizing buildings for billionaires. A duplex at a 43-storey tower near the UN is on offer for US$70 million, featuring an infinity pool, private elevator, and spectacular views. This trend is driven by the growing demand for ultra-luxurious living spaces among the super-rich.

site_title: Government seen maintaining supply of private housing land in H2
summary: Singapore's Ministry of National Development (MND) is expected to maintain the supply of private housing land in the second half of 2015, or trim it slightly, to balance the substantial pipeline of new homes with developers' appetite for land at state tenders. Property consultants forecast a non-EC private residential land supply of 2,000 to 2,500 units on the confirmed list and 5,000 to 5,500 units on the reserve list, while EC supply is expected to remain low. The government is unlikely to release any predominantly office sites on the confirmed list, maintaining the strategy adopted in the current GLS Programme.

images.alt_text: Kalpana Rashiwala

site_title: IDA programme to support young tech firms bears results
summary: Singapore's Infocomm Development Authority (IDA) programme, Accreditation @ IDA, has seen two young tech firms win government projects worth over S$1 million. KAI Square and Inspire-Tech, both with annual revenues under S$10 million, secured the contracts after participating in the programme. The initiative aims to support Singapore-based tech companies by providing assurance to potential buyers and improving product quality. With the success of these five projects, the programme has helped develop over 100 potential projects worth millions of dollars.

site_title: Saudi family sweetens offer to creditors
summary: Saudi Arabian company AHMAD Hamad Algosaibi & Brothers Co has proposed to pay creditors at least 28 cents on the dollar for its $6 billion debt, an improvement from a previous offer made in 2014. The company, which defaulted on $15.7 billion in 2009, aims to recover assets worth 2.7 billion Saudi riyals and 3.4 billion Saudi riyals of real estate assets. The proposal, made to over 80 banks, builds on a previous offer and includes the disclosure of personal assets by the company's 19 partners to increase transparency.

site_title: New lenders jump on commercial property bandwagon
summary: New lenders are entering the UK commercial property market at a rapid pace, with 46 institutions offering debt for the first time in the past 12 months. This surge in competition has led to increased syndication of loans, with foreign lenders seeking better returns than corporate bonds and government debt. The value of new commercial property loans rose 51% last year, with senior property debt returns exceeding 3.5%, outpacing corporate bonds and government debt. This trend is expected to continue, with lenders offering loans at loan-to-value ratios of up to 80%.

site_title: Opec finds oil output consensus: 'Don't rock the boat'
summary: OPEC has agreed to maintain its oil production ceiling of 30 million barrels per day, citing stabilized prices and reduced competition. The decision comes after last year's market therapy revived moribund demand and knocked back growing competition. OPEC members, including Gulf countries, are reluctant to modify production limits, with some analysts suggesting a possible increase in output. The decision is seen as a cautious approach, with Iran's gradual return to the oil market expected to take months or a year to recover.

site_title: Game-changer in the 'Future-Ready' Age
summary: Singapore is embracing the "Future-Ready" Age, where organisations and individuals must prepare for a constantly changing economy. The key to success lies in developing "future-ready leadership" that combines traditional values with new principles. This includes personal branding, where individuals acknowledge their strengths and value, and resilience, which enables them to adapt to uncertainty. The "challenger mindset" is also crucial, encouraging innovation and evolution in the workplace. To stay ahead, professionals, managers, and executives (PMEs) must be able to anticipate change, capitalise on new opportunities, and drive resilience.

site_title: More pain than gain seen for China economy
summary: China's economic growth slowed to 7.4% in 2014, its weakest in decades, and is expected to worsen before improving. The IMF predicts 6.8% growth this year and 6.25% in 2016. Beijing needs to implement more reforms to stimulate a sustainable turnaround, but the current pace of liberalizing reforms is partly responsible for the slowdown. The country's debt overhang and weak customer demand are hindering productive investment, and policymakers fear that China may be stuck in the "middle-income country trap."

images.alt_text: China's debt overhang has made it hard to stimulate productive investment. Private firms, facing stubbornly weak customer demand and high real interest rates, prefer to repay debt than invest in new capacity.

site_title: M'sia Airlines set to refresh staff lineup with 3,000 hires
summary: Malaysia Airlines plans to hire nearly 3,000 staff over the next two years to "refresh" its staff lineup following a 6,000-employee layoff. The new hires will include "specialists in critical areas" and foreigners, with the airline's new boss, Christoph Mueller, expected to handpick top management. The move is part of a turnaround strategy aimed at returning the airline to profitability in three years. The airline's recruitment spree may have already begun, with some positions already advertised on its website.

images.alt_text: Anita Gabriel

site_title: Living it up in the 'village in the city'
summary: TWENTY hotels in Singapore have been designated as official hotels of the 28th South East Asia (Sea) Games, with over 500 rooms booked to accommodate nearly 1,200 athletes and officials. The three M&C group properties - Grand Copthorne Waterfront Hotel, Copthorne King's Singapore, and M Hotel Singapore - will provide accommodations for the event.

images.alt_text: Lee U-Wen

site_title: Report says Savings Bonds will hurt economy, but few agree
summary: A Bank of America Merrill Lynch report warns that Singapore's upcoming Savings Bonds program could be contractionary in a slowing economy, potentially pressuring interest rates higher and hitting the economy at an inconvenient time. However, most other economists disagree, citing the program's limited impact and the government's measures to mitigate its effects, such as capping individual holdings and using proceeds for liquidity management. The program is expected to be worth around S$30 billion in five years, with most economists believing it will not significantly crowd out available loanable funds.

site_title: Chinese investors flock to Hong Kong to buy stocks they could get at home
summary: Mainland Chinese investors are increasingly flocking to Hong Kong to buy stocks, taking advantage of lower trading commissions and margin-finance charges. Thousands of investors are setting up accounts in Hong Kong to trade Chinese stocks, then returning to China through the city's stock connect with Shanghai. This trend is driven by the discounts offered by Hong Kong's securities firms compared to those on the mainland.

site_title: Time running out for Greece to strike a deal
summary: Greece is at risk of missing a loan repayment to the IMF on June 5, potentially leading to default. The country needs an aid package to avoid the deadline. Prime Minister Alexis Tsipras will meet with European officials in Brussels on Wednesday to discuss a plan, including economic reforms, to secure funds. The IMF has threatened to cut off aid if Greece fails to meet the repayment.

site_title: Russia continues preparations for 2018 World Cup
summary: Russia continues preparations for the 2018 World Cup despite the resignation of FIFA boss Sepp Blatter due to a corruption scandal. President Vladimir Putin's spokesman, Dmitry Peskov, stated that all plans are being implemented and work is underway. The Kremlin remains unaware of the reason for Blatter's resignation, but the 2018 World Cup is expected to proceed as scheduled. The Kremlin has invested heavily in hosting international sporting events to boost Putin's image, and there is no indication that the World Cup will be reconsidered.

site_title: S'pore leads the way in S-E Asia in lowering emissions: report
summary: Singapore is the only South-east Asian country to have made improvements in lowering carbon emissions on a per capita basis, according to a new economic report by the Institute of Chartered Accountants in England and Wales. Since 1994, Singapore has seen a sustained drop in emissions, while other Asean member countries such as Indonesia and Malaysia only experience periodic lower emissions when their GDP shrinks. Singapore's transition to a high-value-added international services hub has contributed to this reduction, but the country still needs to focus on renewable energy sources to achieve its goals.

images.alt_text: Lee U-Wen

site_title: BASF's Wintershall keen on more Russia investments
summary: BASF's oil and gas subsidiary Wintershall is committed to investing in Russia despite strained relations between Moscow and Europe. The company's new CEO, Mario Mehren, stated that Russia remains its most important focus region and that it will continue to invest around 500 million euros in existing projects. This investment supports gas production of 28 billion cubic meters per year, meeting a third of Germany's annual demand. Mehren emphasized the importance of Russia for gas supplies in the EU, citing a projected shift in purchasing power towards China by 2035.
