Pinterest's buyable pins are expected to allow users to buy products in-the-moment, with no fees charged to buyers or sellers.

site_title: Global commodity supply glut to persist: BHP Billiton
summary: BHP Billiton, the world's largest mining company, warns that a global commodity supply glut is likely to persist due to newly installed low-cost supply. Despite a collapse in prices, the oversupply may take longer to absorb, and prices may remain lower than sustainable levels. The company's iron ore division remains steady at 17% of the seaborne market share, despite major investments. The price of iron ore has dropped as low as $46.70 in April, but has rebounded slightly since. The global oversupply may lead to prolonged pressure on commodity prices.

site_title: Chinese economy faces more pain than gain this year: economists
summary: China's economic growth is expected to worsen before improving, with economists predicting a 6.8% growth rate this year and 6.25% in 2016. The country's GDP growth slowed to 7.4% last year, its weakest since 1990, due to liberalizing reforms. Despite efforts to stimulate the economy through interest rate cuts and increased lending, economists believe the reforms are partly responsible for the slowdown. A sustainable turnaround is expected to take time, with some economists warning that the country needs to make further structural adjustments to boost growth.

site_title: Stocks to watch: Jason, Sino Construction, GLP, SPH
summary: Several Singapore companies made announcements that may impact trading. Jason Holdings resumed trading after suspending due to a query, while a Sino Construction subsidiary received approval to start micro power plant operations in Korea. Global Logistics Properties leased 146,000 sq m of facilities to logistics providers in China. Meanwhile, a Singapore Press Holdings subsidiary acquired a 40% stake in Beerfest Asia for S$580,000. These developments may have varying impacts on the companies' earnings and results in the current financial year.

site_title: Tsipras to meet EU's Juncker as Greece debt deadline looms
summary: Greek Prime Minister Alexis Tsipras is set to meet European Commission President Jean-Claude Juncker on Wednesday for make-or-break bailout talks, with a Friday repayment deadline looming for Athens. Greece and creditors have exchanged proposals, but talks have been deadlocked over reforms, with creditors pushing for greater changes. The Eurogroup's head, Jeroen Dijsselbloem, expressed disappointment with the progress, while Tsipras has defended his government's determination to bolster labour rights and implement reforms. A deal remains uncertain, with fears of a Greek default and potential eurozone exit.

site_title: Disney unveils wearable marvel toys with Iron Man Repulsor
summary: Disney unveiled wearable Marvel toys, the Iron Man "Repulsor," which use radio waves, infrared light, and Bluetooth technology to interact with other products and characters. The toys, designed by Disney, will be available in October starting at $120 for a five-piece starter pack. The company aims to promote active play among children, as parents have been seeking a combination of technology and traditional play. Additional Marvel toys, including Hulk hands, will be released in November, with Star Wars and Frozen products to follow in subsequent years.

images.alt_text: Walt Disney Co unveiled a line of wearable toys that interact with each other and other products, starting with its Marvel comic-book characters.

site_title: Modi's income insurance idea may not win over angry Indian farmers
summary: Indian Prime Minister Narendra Modi plans to provide income insurance to millions of farmers, but it may not alleviate rural distress due to limited success of a similar scheme in his home state of Gujarat. The new plan aims to ensure a guaranteed income for farmers by covering crop price fluctuations, but its effectiveness is hindered by outdated methods for assessing damage and limited access to satellite technology. The scheme may benefit big farmers over smallholders, who make up 260 million of India's 263 million farmers, and face bureaucratic hurdles.

site_title: Singapore's STI edges higher on Wednesday morning
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) rose 5.09 points, or 0.15%, to 3,345.84 on Wednesday, despite losses on global markets. The index fell 51.36 points on Tuesday, taking it into the red for the year. Stocks like Sino Construction gained 11.8% after receiving approval for micro power plants in Korea, while Singtel and Noble continued their slide. As of 9:04am, 100.4 million shares valued at S$260.3 million changed hands, with gainers outnumbering losers 74 to 68.

site_title: Singapore vehicle sales expected to grow fastest in Asean: BMI
summary: Singapore is expected to see the fastest rise in vehicle sales in Asean with a 20% average annual growth rate from 2015 to 2016, according to BMI Research. This growth is driven by the replacement of vehicles due for deregistration after seven years, resulting in a 30% growth rate from 2015 to 2019. Mass brands, including Japanese cars, are expected to benefit from the weak yen and increased COE availability, while premium models will also see growth. This contrasts with Indonesia and Malaysia, which face weaker markets due to high interest rates and economic conditions.

images.alt_text: Singapore will see the fastest rise in vehicle sales in Asean with an average annual growth rate of 20 per cent till 2016.

site_title: New York Stock Exchange appoints Stacey Cunningham as COO
summary: The New York Stock Exchange (NYSE) has appointed Stacey Cunningham as its new chief operating officer (COO), replacing Adam Sodowick. Cunningham will oversee cash equities markets, relationship management, and product management. The appointment aims to enhance the exchange's customer connectivity and ease of use with its integrated trading platform. Cunningham, who was previously president of governance services, will focus on several NYSE Group initiatives, while Sodowick will take over as president of the unit.

site_title: Deutsche Boerse plans to start Singapore Exchange in 2016
summary: Deutsche Boerse plans to launch Eurex Exchange Asia, a derivatives exchange in Singapore, in the second quarter of 2016. The Frankfurt-based company has applied for an exchange license with the Monetary Authority of Singapore and received "in principle" approval for a Singapore clearinghouse. This move follows Intercontinental Exchange Inc.'s efforts to establish a Singapore futures market, which has been delayed multiple times. The expansion aims to increase Deutsche Boerse's Asian footprint and compete with other market operators.

images.alt_text: Deutsche Boerse AG is planning to open a derivatives exchange in Singapore next year, joining other market operators in expanding their Asian footprint.

site_title: Microsoft buys German start-up behind Wunderlist app
summary: Microsoft has acquired 6Wunderkinder GmbH, the German startup behind the popular Wunderlist to-do list app, in a deal valued at $100-200 million. The acquisition aims to enhance Microsoft's productivity offerings in a mobile-first, cloud-first world. Financial details were not disclosed, but the move is seen as a strategic expansion of Microsoft's presence in the Berlin tech scene. The Wunderlist team will join Microsoft, marking a significant addition to the company's product portfolio.

site_title: Singapore sees role for sukuk in infrastructure financing: MAS
summary: Singapore's Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) sees potential for sukuk financing in infrastructure projects, complementing the country's efforts to enhance the bankability of infrastructure projects in the region. MAS deputy managing director Jacqueline Loh stated that the central bank is working to provide clarity and certainty for Shariah-compliant financing structures. The MAS has already offered S$600 million under its sukuk facility since 2009, and industry players are exploring pre-approved standardised templates to speed up sukuk issuance. This development aims to facilitate Islamic finance activities in the region.

images.alt_text: Sukuk financing is ideal for infrastructure projects and will complement ongoing work by Singapore to enhance the bankability of infrastructure projects in the region, a Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) official said Wednesday morning.

site_title: Toys 'R' Us hires former Domino's chief as next CEO
summary: Toys "R" Us has appointed David Brandon, former CEO of Domino's Pizza, as its new CEO, effective July 1. Brandon, 63, aims to revive the toy retailer's turnaround attempt, which includes cost-cutting, investing in its online business, and improving stores. The company has posted revenue declines and net losses, but its adjusted earnings have improved. Brandon's tenure at Domino's was marked by pushing the pizza chain into the digital age, but revenue growth was modest. He will replace outgoing CEO Antonio Urcelay.

site_title: Russians bid to end bond isolation for US$117b repayments
summary: Russian companies are preparing to return to the Eurobond market after a half-year absence, with some issuing bonds in the coming months. Companies like OAO Koks and Metalloinvest plan to refinance debt, while others, like Bank FC Otkritie, are meeting investors in Europe to gauge interest. Despite a 20-40 basis point yield premium being offered, some companies, like Inter RAO UES, remain cautious due to ongoing sanctions. The return to the market is seen as a response to the cease-fire in Ukraine and rising oil prices, with foreign bondholders seeking higher yields.

site_title: Oil up on dollar drop; poll calls for US stocks decline
summary: Oil prices rose on Tuesday due to a weak dollar and expectations of a fifth consecutive week of US crude supply declines. However, the American Petroleum Institute reported a 1.8 million barrel inventory build, paring earlier gains. Analysts had forecast a 1.7 million barrel decline. The report contradicted expectations of a decline in US crude inventories, leading to a mixed market reaction.

site_title: Fitbit IPO could top US$500m
summary: Fitbit plans to raise more than $500 million in its initial public offering, with shares priced between $14 and $16 each. The company expects to sell around 33.7 million shares, giving it a market value of $2.9-3.3 billion. Fitbit, a pioneer in wearable devices, has sold over 20.8 million devices and reported a profit of $131.8 million last year. The IPO, pending regulatory approval, would be one of the largest in the US technology sector.

site_title: Greece's creditors draft deal to unlock aid
summary: Greece's creditors have drafted a deal to provide aid to the cash-strapped country, following four months of negotiations. The agreement, to be discussed with Greek Prime Minister Alexis Tsipras, outlines key policy areas and terms for a cash-for-reforms deal. The European Commission, European Central Bank, and International Monetary Fund collaborated to bridge lender differences. German Chancellor Angela Merkel and French President Francois Hollande will present the plan to Tsipras by phone to secure his acceptance, potentially unlocking aid before Greece runs out of money.

site_title: Problem with analysing the 'Obama Doctrine'
summary: US presidential foreign policy strategies, known as "doctrines," have been widely studied. Critics argue President Barack Obama lacked a coherent doctrine, instead relying on recycled elements of the Bush Doctrine. Political scientists define a doctrine as a unique foreign policy strategy reflecting a president's vision and goals. However, critics have yet to provide a clear alternative strategy, instead reusing parts of the Bush Doctrine. This raises questions about the validity of Obama's foreign policy approach and its effectiveness in addressing global challenges.

site_title: Voya lifts profit target, announces US$750m buyback
summary: Voya Financial Inc, a US insurer and investment manager, announced a $750 million share buyback and increased its 2018 operating return on equity target to 13.5-14.5%. CEO Rodney Martin aims to boost profitability through investments, focusing on growth in investment-management and retirement operations. The company plans to spend $350 million on data and analytics, IT simplification, and other initiatives, with the largest share allocated to 2016.

site_title: US auto sales hit best pace since 2005
summary: US auto sales accelerated in May to their fastest pace since 2005, with a 1.6% increase compared to May 2014. The sales pace reached an adjusted annualized rate of 17.9 million vehicles, surpassing the previous record of 16.5 million in April. Easy credit and low fuel prices drove the surge, marking a significant improvement from the pre-2005 pace.

site_title: Chevron deploys robots to see damage at Big Foot site
summary: Chevron has deployed robots to assess damage from six giant tendons that sank at its Big Foot deepwater oil project in the Gulf of Mexico, delaying production by indefinitely. The 225-mile site was expected to produce 75,000 barrels of oil per day. The tendons, designed to be buoyant, failed to stay in place, and it's unclear if they can be salvaged or if new ones need to be built. Chevron will update its production timeline during its July earnings conference call.

site_title: British press cheer Blatter's resignation from Fifa
summary: British newspapers celebrated Sepp Blatter's resignation as FIFA president on their front pages, hailing it as a long-awaited victory for critics. The Sun's headline read "GOT HIM" while The Guardian's featured a large image of Blatter walking away, describing the reaction as "joy, disbelief and anger." Blatter's resignation follows a tumultuous period for FIFA, with widespread criticism of his leadership and corruption allegations.

site_title: New Jersey's Christie steps up criticism of Federal Reserve's 'easy money' policy
summary: New Jersey Governor Chris Christie has intensified his criticism of the US Federal Reserve's "easy money" policy, warning that it could destabilize the global economy. Christie, a Republican presidential contender, believes the Fed's crisis-era interest rate slashing will cause problems as the economy moves forward. He has released policy proposals to address these concerns, but his momentum in the crowded field remains uncertain. Christie's comments reflect his growing unease with the Fed's monetary policies, which he believes are fueling inflation and economic instability.

site_title: Boeing begins production on single-aisle 737 MAX plane
summary: Boeing has started production on the 737 MAX, a single-aisle aircraft, with over 2,700 orders. The company has begun building the wings for the first 737 MAX, scheduled for flight-testing in its Renton, Washington plant. This milestone marks the success of the 737 design and Boeing's integrated design-and-build team.

site_title: Takata still searching for 'root cause' of deadly airbags
summary: Takata, a Japanese auto parts maker, is still searching for the main cause of deadly airbag explosions. The company's US arm, TK Holdings, has focused on the instability of ammonium nitrate propellant in certain conditions but has not found the definitive root cause. The company is recalling 34 million cars in the US to replace faulty inflators, with some still using the explosive chemical, which appears to become unstable after years of exposure in hot and humid climates. Research suggests ammonium nitrate is a factor, but other factors, such as desiccant and detonator shape, also play a role.

site_title: Euro rises on higher eurozone inflation
summary: The euro rose against the dollar and other major currencies after data showed eurozone inflation climbed to 0.3% in May, the first rise in five months. This lifted hopes of economic recovery in Europe. Analysts believe the European Central Bank's bond-buying program is working, but it's too early for the ECB to turn hawkish. The euro surge could be boosted if ECB Chief Mario Draghi suggests an earlier-than-planned end to the program. Meanwhile, Greece faces a Friday deadline to repay over 300 million euros to the International Monetary Fund.

site_title: Mortgage approvals in UK soar
summary: UK mortgage approvals rose to 68,076 in April, the highest level in over a year, according to the Bank of England. This is a 6,131 increase from March, the largest since February 2009. The increase is seen as a sign of a strengthening housing market, following the Conservative victory in the May 7 general election. Economists also reported a boost in construction industry confidence, with a measure of building activity reaching its highest in almost a decade in May.

site_title: Most Brits want to stay in EU: poll
summary: A majority of young Brits (69%) want to remain in the EU, according to a Pew Research Centre poll, as the euro crisis fades and support for European integration rebounds. The poll found 61% of people in six EU countries, including Britain, favouring EU membership, up 9 points from 2013. The results could provide comfort for newly re-elected British Prime Minister David Cameron as he prepares to hold a referendum on the country's EU membership by 2017.

site_title: Sponsors urge Fifa to 'win back trust' after Blatter's resignation
summary: Global football sponsors urge Fifa to regain public trust after Sepp Blatter's resignation, citing a need for urgent action to address corruption issues. Coca-Cola and Visa, among others, welcome Blatter's decision, but emphasize that more work is needed to rebuild trust. The sponsors, who pay an estimated $60 million annually to be official Fifa partners, have been critical of the organization's handling of corruption allegations. They call for swift and immediate steps to address issues and restore the reputation of the games for fans worldwide.

site_title: Ortega overtakes Buffett to become world's second richest person
summary: Amancio Ortega has surpassed Warren Buffett to become the world's second-richest person, with a net worth of US$71.5 billion. Ortega's wealth has increased 17% this year, driven by Inditex's rising profit and sales. The Spanish magnate's company, Inditex, operates over 6,600 stores worldwide under brands such as Zara, Massimo Dutti, and Pull&Bear. Ortega's strategic approach to growth, including keeping production facilities close to headquarters and focusing on trendy shopping areas, has contributed to his success.

images.alt_text: Amancio Ortega, the Spanish magnate who pioneered fast-fashion retail, passed investor Warren Buffett (above) to become the world's second-richest person.

site_title: Europe: Stocks fall to two-week low amid Greece debt standoff
summary: European stocks fell to a two-week low amid Greece's debt standoff, with the Stoxx Europe 600 Index declining 1% to 396.45. Greece's prime minister submitted a new plan to creditors, while European leaders and IMF officials gathered in Berlin to discuss a potential agreement. The euro strengthened, causing exporters to decline, and shares of companies such as Volkswagen and Aryzta fell. The Greek government faces four payments to the IMF this month, and its aid package expires at the end of June.

site_title: Blatter quits as Fifa corruption storm grows
summary: Sepp Blatter resigned as FIFA president on June 2, 2015, amid corruption scandals threatening the governing body. Blatter, 79, cited a lack of mandate from the entire world of football, despite winning a fifth term just four days earlier. The move comes as seven FIFA officials were arrested in a luxury Zurich hotel and amid an FBI investigation. Blatter vowed to pursue reforms until a special congress can choose a new leader, scheduled to take place between December 2015 and March 2016.

site_title: US dollar hits more than 12-year high against yen
summary: The US dollar reached a 12-year high against the yen, briefly hitting 125.05 yen on June 2, 2015, due to upbeat US data sparking interest rate hike speculation. The dollar settled at 124.59 yen, its strongest level since December 2002.

site_title: Landed property sales 'buoyed by pent-up demand'
summary: Landed property sales in Singapore have seen a surge in recent months, with RealStar Premier Group reporting a 20% increase in transactions this year compared to 2012. The group attributes this growth to pent-up demand and anticipated changes in the additional buyer's stamp duty (ABSD), which could increase the affordability of properties for second-time home buyers. With over $400 million in transaction sales so far this year, RealStar's landed property sales are expected to continue to climb, driven by buyers targeting smaller units and developers looking to capitalize on the market.

images.alt_text: Prisca Ang

site_title: Sino Construction gets nod to start micro power plants in Korea
summary: Sino Construction's subsidiary, Magnum Modular Power Generation, has received approval to start operations at its micro power plants in Korea. The company completed its first plant on April 29 and is building a second, expected to be ready by July. The modular systems incorporate advanced biofuel technologies, enabling immediate power generation.

site_title: Moody's sees Fed spoiling record US$ sukuk sales
summary: The US Federal Reserve's expected interest-rate hike may spoil Asia's record quarter for dollar-denominated Islamic bond sales, known as sukuk. Despite global yields being below a four-year average, sales of dollar sukuk have risen to $5.27 billion this year, with issuers taking advantage of the low yields. However, experts predict that sales will taper off after the Fed's move, with many issuers likely to refinance through the local market. Average yields on global sukuk have dropped 22 basis points this year to 2.83%, making funding markets still attractive for issuers.

site_title: Taiwan president warns over stalled China trade deals
summary: Taiwan President Ma Ying-jeou warned that stalled trade deals with China could damage the Taiwanese economy due to mass protests. The agreements, which have been under deliberation, are seen as a result of increased Chinese influence on the island. Ma expressed concern over the situation during the Computex tech fair in Taipei, emphasizing the need for the legislature to pass the deals. The stalled agreements are a result of ongoing tensions between Taiwan and China, highlighting the ongoing challenges in their relationship.

site_title: EU beaching ban would be counterproductive
summary: The European Commission is considering banning beaching as a method of scrapping ships, a practice widely used in South Asian ship-recycling yards. GMS, the world's largest buyer of ships, argues that a ban would be counterproductive, discouraging improvements in the industry and limiting options for EU-flagged ships. A ban would force owners to flag vessels in non-EU countries, potentially reducing the value of commercial ships. The EU's policy would also undermine the International Maritime Organization's Hong Kong Convention, aimed at improving safety and environmental standards in shipbreaking yards.

site_title: Analysts cut M'sian earnings growth forecasts for '15
summary: Malaysian corporate earnings growth forecasts for 2015 have been trimmed to 5.5% year-on-year due to a dismal first quarter performance, marked by slower consumer spending and depressed commodity prices. Analysts attribute the decline to factors such as a new consumption tax and political uncertainties. Other sectors, including automotive, aviation, and chemicals, also underperformed, contributing to the disappointing quarter.

site_title: Rural Japan cities rebrand themselves as urban alternatives
summary: Rural Japanese towns are rebranding themselves as urban alternatives, attracting younger residents and tech firms to combat the country's shrinking population. Kamiyama, a village on the island of Shikoku, is a prime example, boasting a mix of wood-fired pizza, tech start-ups, and young people. The town is practicing "creative depopulation," offering a unique lifestyle with co-working spaces, outdoor activities, and a welcoming community. Other towns, such as Iketani and Amacho, are also experiencing revitalization efforts. These initiatives aim to create jobs, raise families, and reverse the trend of depopulation in rural Japan.

site_title: Focus on startups as Taiwan seeks new tech identity
summary: Taiwan is shifting focus to startups as the country faces intense competition from China. To boost its tech credentials, the island is highlighting nine niche startups at the upcoming Computex trade show, providing them with a special exhibition area for the first time. The government is also being urged to support fledgling firms, with difficulties in raising capital and marketing hindering innovation. Taiwanese firms like Asus and TSMC have benefited from the country's tech industry, but smaller companies need help to tap international markets and develop long-term branding strategies.

site_title: US online shoppers get perks as tech competition heats up
summary: US online shoppers are receiving perks as tech giants intensify competition. Amazon introduced same-day delivery in 14 metro areas, while Google launched "Android Pay" for mobile payments. Apple partnered with Postmates for same-day delivery and added a "buy button" to web pages. Walmart is testing a $50 membership program for free three-day shipping, and Jet is launching a $49 annual membership for low prices. These moves reflect the growing competition in online shopping, with internet sales growing 13.8% over the Christmas holidays.

site_title: RHB research head quits to start own fund
summary: RHB Research head Terence Wong is leaving the firm to set up his own South-east Asia-focused equity fund after June 5. Wong, known for his expertise in small-cap companies, will be replaced by Ong Kian Lin, a current real estate analyst. Wong has been with RHB since 2007 and has led the research team to numerous awards, including Asiamoney's best small-cap analyst in 2014. He cited opportunities in Singapore and the desire to focus on stock picking as reasons for his departure.

site_title: US: Wall St ends lower
summary: US stocks fell on Tuesday, with the Dow Jones industrial average down 28.43 points, or 0.16%, to 18,011.94. The S&P 500 lost 2.13 points, or 0.1%, to 2,109.6, and the Nasdaq Composite dropped 6.40 points, or 0.13%, to 5,076.52. Energy shares gained, but utilities and other dividend-paying shares declined after US long-dated Treasury debt yields rose. Greece's creditors drafted a potential agreement with the Greek government, limiting losses.

site_title: New York's hotel growth causes pause in bond market
summary: New York's hotel construction boom is causing concerns in the bond market, as increased competition and lower prices may lead to reduced hotel valuations and lower returns for investors. This growth in hotel construction is a welcome development for visitors, but it may have negative implications for the city's real estate market, particularly in terms of bond investments.

site_title: GSS Energy gets a foot into oil trading
summary: GSS Energy has entered the oil trading market by partnering with AFCO Energy, a Dutch firm, to invest in a joint venture (JV) that will market and distribute mineral oil and crude oil products in Indonesia. The JV, GSS-AFCO, will be equally owned by both companies and aims to capitalize on the growing demand for energy products in Indonesia. This move marks GSS Energy's first foray into energy trading, expanding its business scope beyond its traditional focus on renewable energy.

site_title: S'pore PMI back in expansion mode, but economists not swayed
summary: Singapore's manufacturing sector has returned to expansion mode, with the PMI rising to 50.2 in May, up from 49.4 in April. The growth was driven by new domestic orders, production output, and inventory, but economists remain cautious due to weak electronics and exports across Asia, citing concerns over global demand. Despite the turnaround, the PMI still lags behind the pre-pandemic level of 52.3, indicating a fragile recovery.

site_title: China's home sales pick up in May
summary: China's housing sales in major cities jumped 37.4% in May from a year earlier, driven by government stimulus policies and developers' efforts to clear inventories. Home sales rose 14.7% from April, with prices increasing 0.05% in May, the first rise in 14 months. Moody's changed its outlook on the China property sector to stable from negative, forecasting a 0-5% growth in property sales value until June 2016. The government is set to publish May property sales and investment figures on June 11.

site_title: Takata to stop making inflater linked to airbag defect
summary: Takata, a Japanese vehicle supplier, announced it will stop producing driver-side inflaters linked to a US airbag defect. The company agreed to recall almost 34 million vehicles in the US, the largest such action in US history, following violent bursts of metal that could harm passengers. Despite this, Takata plans to continue using a potentially dangerous airbag propellant. The company's move comes ahead of a US congressional hearing on the issue.

site_title: Over 450 tourists, crew missing after ship capsizes in China
summary: Rescuers in China are searching for over 400 missing tourists and crew after the Eastern Star ship capsized on the Yangtze River in a storm. The ship, carrying 458 people, was likely China's worst shipping disaster in nearly 70 years. Five people were found trapped in the ship's upturned hull, but many elderly Chinese tourists remain unaccounted for. The search is ongoing despite bad weather.

site_title: Euro now more closely linked to crude oil prices
summary: The euro-dollar rate has become closely linked to crude oil prices, with a 120-day correlation of 0.4, the highest since April 2013. The European Central Bank's focus on inflation, which includes energy prices, has led to a stronger correlation with oil prices compared to the Federal Reserve's approach. Analysts predict a decline in oil prices, which could support a fall in the euro against the dollar, with some forecasting parity by December. The ECB is expected to keep its benchmark rate unchanged, while the US Federal Reserve is poised to raise borrowing costs later this year.

site_title: Trade associations key to helping SMEs thrive: Lim Hng Kiang
summary: The Singapore government has awarded $7 million in funding to six trade associations and chambers (TACs) to support their Local Enterprise and Association Development (LEAD) programmes. The funding aims to help small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) develop and grow through industry development and internationalisation projects. TACs will play a key role in guiding businesses to tap government assistance and build competitive advantage. The LEAD programmes have benefited over 38,000 SMEs since its founding in 2005.

images.alt_text: Mr Lim said it was important to help local companies internationalise ahead of the debut of the Asean Economic Community in end 2015.

site_title: Times will be as tough as what S'pore pioneers endured: Heng
summary: Singapore must adopt a pioneering spirit to tackle global competition and adapt to changing circumstances, said Education Minister Heng Swee Keat. The country faces accelerating economic competition, demographic changes, and international safety threats, which are as demanding as the challenges faced by the pioneer generation in the early years of independence. To succeed, Singapore must move faster to seize good jobs and business opportunities, and be prepared to adapt to an uncertain future.

images.alt_text: Lee U-Wen

site_title: Concern over quality of Indian pilots' training
summary: Indian pilots' training certificates have been found to show inflated flying hours, with some pilots claiming to have logged hundreds of hours despite only spending a few minutes in the air. A court investigation found that flying schools in India often falsify data, and regulators are taking steps to address the issue. Despite the concerns, many budget airlines in India continue to hire pilots with minimal flying experience, citing the high demand for pilots and the need for cost-effective training. The Indian government has made efforts to improve safety, but under-trained pilots remain a risk to passenger safety.

site_title: Heavy selling hits STI
summary: The Singapore stock market experienced a significant decline on Tuesday, with the Straits Times Index (STI) falling 51.36 points or 1.5% to 3,340.75, entering negative territory for the year. The decline was attributed to various factors, including an impending change to the liquidity rules of the STI and concerns over the performance of blue-chip companies such as Jardine Matheson, Singtel, and the banks. Turnover was high, with 1.5 billion units traded worth S$1.74 billion.

site_title: Seoul reports first two deaths from MERS
summary: South Korea reported its first two deaths from Middle East Respiratory Syndrome (MERS), a coronavirus with a 38% death rate, as the outbreak infected 25 people. The first death was a 57-year-old woman who died of acute respiratory failure, followed by a 71-year-old man. The World Health Organization (WHO) has not recommended trade or travel restrictions, but South Korea has isolated over 700 people and banned overseas travel for those with possible infection. The government has come under criticism for not naming the hospitals where patients were treated, fueling speculation.

site_title: Your birthplace determines your wealth
summary: Economist Branko Milanovic found that a person's birthplace significantly determines their wealth, with more than half of earnings attributed to the country of origin. Richer countries can afford to pay more for similar work, and this is reflected in the varying McWages across countries. For example, McDonald's workers in the US earn significantly more than those in India. While immigration can help the economy, excessive immigration could lead to decreased wages for existing residents, highlighting the importance of balancing economic growth with social considerations.

site_title: Greece, creditors line up rival reform proposals to unlock aid
summary: Greece's creditors are close to finalizing a draft agreement to release aid for the cash-strapped country, with Greek Prime Minister Alexis Tsipras submitting his own proposal to lenders. The draft includes pension and labor market reforms, fiscal targets, and the size of the civil service. A failure to reach an agreement by the end of the month could trigger a Greek default and potential exit from the euro zone, dealing a blow to Europe's single currency. Talks are ongoing, with EU leaders urging a deal to be reached to prevent economic instability.

site_title: Global Invacom buys US satellite maker Skyware Global
summary: Global Invacom Group, a Singapore-based satellite equipment specialist, has acquired US satellite terminal manufacturer Skyware Global for up to $11.6 million. The acquisition will boost Global Invacom's presence in China, Israel, Malaysia, and the UK, and position it as a world leader in satellite communications equipment. The deal aims to integrate Skyware's plant with Global Invacom's global network, introducing its VSAT technology for Asian markets and increasing efficiency in manufacturing and logistics. The acquisition is expected to return Skyware to profitability through synergies and cross-selling.

site_title: HSBC set to axe thousands in strategy overhaul
summary: HSBC Holdings Plc is set to cut thousands of jobs, with estimates suggesting between 10,000 to 20,000 positions will be eliminated, primarily from its investment bank. The move is part of a strategy overhaul aimed at reducing costs and reversing a decline in profit. The bank has faced pressure to address a year marked by fines for currency market manipulation and a tax-avoidance scandal. CEO Stuart Gulliver will announce the plan on June 9, with the restructuring expected to include closures of underperforming business lines.

site_title: The US oil fracker's dilemma: crouch or pounce?
summary: US shale oil producers face a dilemma: whether to add rigs and risk contributing to another global market slump, or stay in a defensive crouch after slashing their fleets in response to a 60% price plunge. Despite a 40% rebound since March, US crude remains below $100 a barrel, but costs have fallen 15-25% and productivity gains have helped break-even levels decrease. Analysts predict the rig count may pick up in the third quarter and gain momentum in the fourth quarter, but the timing and pace of new wells replacing lost output are uncertain.

site_title: Tokyo fund closes with Straits Trading unit as key sponsor
summary: Cordea Savills has announced the first closing of its Greater Tokyo Office Fund, with Straits Trading's real estate arm, Straits Real Estate, committing 4.9 billion yen (S$52.3 million) as a key sponsor. The fund targets an internal rate of return of mid-teens, focusing on buying office assets in the Greater Tokyo area. Straits Real Estate, a real estate investment firm, sees this investment approach as ideal given Japan's market realities. The fund's first close capital was sourced from Asian investors, with Cordea Savills' team utilizing their long-standing relationships to acquire office assets in Tokyo.

site_title: Top 50 list mired in controversy - again
summary: The World's 50 Best Restaurants list has faced controversy over its voting process, with some restaurants dropping out of the top 50 and new entries from Chile, Peru, and Mexico. Critics argue that the list is influenced by cronyism, "flip a coin" voting, and geopolitical influence, with some chefs claiming that voters are not required to pay for meals at the restaurants they vote for. The Occupy 50 Best movement, which has collected over 400 signatures, is calling for more transparency in the voting process. Despite this, the guide's organizers claim that the list is based on the personal choices of nearly 1,000 independent experts.

site_title: New manpower minister to stay the course on foreign-worker policy
summary: Singapore's new Manpower Minister Lim Swee Say will not relax the foreign-worker policy, despite calls from some employers to ease the labour market. Instead, he wants businesses to focus on making the economy manpower-lean, boosting the local core workforce, and upgrading existing foreign workers. The government will provide support to businesses that align with these goals, and Lim believes that just a few companies can take the lead in achieving the desired outcomes. He emphasizes the need for decisive action and Tripartism among government, employers, and unions to address the manpower challenge.

site_title: RBI cuts rates for third time this year to support India's growth
summary: The Reserve Bank of India (RBI) cut interest rates for a third time this year to 7.25%, citing subdued inflation and the need to support the economy despite impressive growth numbers. The rate cut, which was predicted by 35 of 48 analysts, also left room for further cuts later this year, despite forecasts of a below-average monsoon season. RBI Governor Raghuram Rajan warned that the economy still needs "policy support" and that the rate cut is part of a "disinflationary path" aimed at containing inflation, which is expected to rise to 6% in January 2016.

site_title: China should swiftly ink code of conduct with Asean
summary: China and the US appeared close to war over the South China Sea, but at the Shangri-La Dialogue, both sides adopted a less hawkish stance. The US demanded China halt land reclamation, but China countered that its work is justified and reasonable. China and ASEAN agreed to conclude a code of conduct on the South China Sea, but Beijing appears reluctant to sign. The US seems to lack a strategy to deal with China, and the US Congress is urging a more assertive response. The situation remains tense, with the US presidential campaign season looming and China seeking to exercise diplomacy by moving to conclude a code of conduct with ASEAN.

site_title: Racial integration a reason for S'pore's success: Obama
summary: US President Barack Obama stated that Singapore's success is partly due to its ability to integrate people from different racial backgrounds, emphasizing the importance of leadership and government principles. This sentiment was shared during his speech to 75 emerging leaders from the Association of South-east Asian Nations (Asean). Obama's comments highlight the significance of racial integration in Singapore's economic and social development.

site_title: Noble plunges amid market sell-off
summary: Noble Group, a Singapore-listed commodity firm, plummeted 6.3% to 74.5 cents amid a general market sell-off, with the Straits Times Index falling 1.5%. The company reported a 29.6% decline in net profit to US$107 million for the first quarter, citing a 7.3% fall in revenue. Investment banker Michael Dee criticized the group's lack of transparency, recommending clarity in financial statements and a focus on generating positive free cash flow. Noble also embarked on a share buyback exercise of three million shares.

images.alt_text: Mindy Tan

site_title: US factory orders down in April, demand broadly soft
summary: US factory orders fell 0.4% in April, the first decline in eight months, as demand weakened due to a strong dollar and spending cuts in the energy sector. Orders for transportation equipment and consumer goods declined, while non-defence capital goods orders excluding aircraft rose 0.5%. Economists had forecast flat orders, but a report showed factory activity rising in May for the first time in seven months. The dollar's rally may be nearing its end, and business spending outside the energy sector is picking up, suggesting the downturn could be nearing its end.

site_title: German labour market strong with unemployment at 24-year low
summary: Germany's unemployment rate hit a 24-year low of 6.4% in May, with 2.786 million people registered as unemployed, a decrease of 6,000 from the previous month. This is the lowest level since West and East Germany reunited in 1990. Strong domestic demand and a positive labor market trend are expected to continue, with analysts predicting a job market boom in 2015.

site_title: OECD redefines itself as go-to resource for economic analysis
summary: The Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development (OECD) has redefined itself as a go-to resource for economic analysis, shifting from a consultative body to a more proactive institution. Under the leadership of Secretary-General Angel Gurria, who has been unanimously re-elected for his third six-year term, the OECD has become more relevant and influential, providing research and recommendations to governments. The institution has expanded its membership to include emerging economies and has become a virtual recruiting agency for consultants. However, the OECD has also faced criticism for its methods and biases, particularly regarding its Programme for International Student Assessment (PISA) evaluations and its approach to tax reform.

site_title: Microsoft escalates dispute with US tax agency
summary: Microsoft has filed a federal lawsuit against the US tax agency, the IRS, over an ongoing audit that seeks to hire David Boies, the lawyer who won an antitrust case against Microsoft in 2000. The lawsuit claims the IRS is trying to "subpoena" Boies, who would then reveal confidential information about Microsoft's corporate income, which the IRS claims totals "tens of billions of dollars." The dispute marks the latest in a series of legal battles between Microsoft and the IRS.

site_title: Smart Nation makes headway with 3 more projects
summary: Singapore has entered the "build phase" of its Smart Nation initiative, with three new projects announced to showcase the latest in smart technologies. The projects include Smart Logistics, a cargo tracking platform; the Video Analytics Smart Nation Tech Challenge, which aims to co-create technologies with the government; and the Smart Health-Assist pilot in the Jurong Lake District, which will deploy sensors to monitor the health of the elderly. These initiatives aim to leverage technology to improve living and create new opportunities, with the government calling on global industry partners and local startups to help develop these solutions.

site_title: Australian banks rein in loans to property investors amid stern warnings
summary: Australian banks have begun tightening lending to property investors, with stricter criteria and higher deposit requirements, amid stern warnings from regulators about the risk of a housing bubble in Sydney. The measures aim to prevent the financial system from destabilizing, following a 40% surge in home prices in three years. The major banks are expected to raise A$22-41 billion in capital reserves, impacting earnings and investor returns. Regulatory filings show that home loans to investors now account for a third of the A$1.5 trillion home loan market.

site_title: Reserve Bank of Australia keeps rates on hold at 2%
summary: The Reserve Bank of Australia kept interest rates at 2% for the second consecutive month, maintaining a record low. This decision aims to support the economy, which is struggling with soft business spending and a slowdown in China's GDP growth. The bank also called for a weaker currency to boost exports and counter the sluggish economy.

site_title: Optimism for Singapore as Asia's LNG hub
summary: Singapore's position as Asia's LNG hub may be strengthened by the sharp decline in the spot price of liquefied natural gas in Asia, which has dropped to multi-year lows of US$6.2 per mmbtu. Lower demand from Asian economies and greater use of coal in some markets are contributing to the price drop. Structural changes to supply and demand could keep Asian LNG prices soft until 2020, potentially solidifying Singapore's position as the region's LNG hub.

site_title: Turnaround for Malaysia Airlines ambitious but achievable
summary: Malaysia Airlines has embarked on a RM6 billion (S$2.12 billion) 12-pronged overhaul plan to rescue the struggling airline. The plan, which includes addressing lucrative procurement contracts and a bloated payroll, has led to the axing of 6,000 employees, with 14,000 retained in the new Malaysia Airlines Bhd. New CEO Christoph Mueller aims to return the carrier to profitability in three years, with a focus on full-service international flights and maintaining its global brand reputation. The overhaul is seen as achievable, with Mueller stating that the airline cannot have lower ambitions than its past achievements.

images.alt_text: Much has happened at struggling carrier Malaysia Airlines since its sole owner, Khazanah Nasional, revealed a RM6 billion (S$2.12 billion) 12-pronged "complete overhaul" plan to rescue the tragedy-struck airline some nine months ago.

site_title: Fifa should become a listed company to ensure transparency
summary: FIFA's alleged corruption and bribery have led to calls for the organization to become a publicly listed company to ensure transparency. As a non-profit, FIFA's lack of transparency has hindered efforts to combat corruption and has diverted revenue from developing the sport. If listed, shareholders would be in revolt over the alleged wrongdoing, potentially driving change. The organization's current model has allowed corruption to thrive, with billions of dollars siphoned off for personal gain, ultimately harming the sport. Public listing could bring accountability and transparency, but its feasibility remains uncertain.

site_title: Fed can't get caught up in inequality debate: Bernanke
summary: Former Federal Reserve Chairman Ben Bernanke has acknowledged that his bond-buying campaigns may have increased economic inequality, but argues that the stimulus was justified regardless of its impact on inequality. Bernanke wrote in a blog post that monetary policy is a blunt tool that affects the distribution of income and wealth, but the net effect on inequality is unclear. He also suggested that the impact on inequality should be offset by fiscal policy. Current Fed officials agree that the stimulus worked, but some critics argue that the wealthy have benefited disproportionately.

site_title: Air France faces new safety probe after freighter scare
summary: Air France faces a new safety probe after pilots recovered from a mid-takeoff incident on a Boeing 777 freighter at Paris Charles de Gaulle airport on May 22, where they entered the wrong data into the plane's computer. The mistake caused the plane to accelerate too slowly on the runway. This is Air France's second safety investigation in as many weeks, following a previous incident on a commercial airliner. The cause of the mistake is still under investigation, but it has raised concerns about the airline's safety protocols.

site_title: Millennials drive new industry based on sharing or renting
summary: Millennials are driving a new industry based on sharing or renting, disrupting traditional retailers. The "no ownership" trend, fueled by student loan debt and the Great Recession, has led to the emergence of businesses like Kidizen and Yerdle, which allow customers to swap or buy smaller-ticket items. This shift is driven by millennials' emphasis on sharing, bartering, and trading, as well as environmental concerns. Many established retailers, such as Patagonia and Rent the Runway, have taken note and are incorporating sharing and reuse into their business models.

site_title: Market strategy working: Saudi Arabia
summary: Saudi Arabia's oil minister, Ali al-Naimi, says the country's market strategy is working, with demand picking up and supply slowing ahead of the Opec meeting. The strategy, which prioritized defending market share over cutting production, has led to a 40% rebound in oil prices from a six-year low. Saudi Arabia expanded its share of China's oil market in April, and global oil consumption is expected to rise 1.1 million barrels a day this year. The Opec meeting on June 5 may maintain its collective quota at 30 million barrels a day.

site_title: Niche car brands may miss out on riding the COE boom
summary: Niche car brands in Singapore may not benefit from the growing quota of COEs due to changing market conditions. Despite sluggish sales, mass-market brands like Daihatsu, Fiat, and Chrysler have seen single-digit registrations in the first four months of 2015. Niche brands like Skoda and Chery have not registered any cars this year, suggesting buyers now prefer established brands. This shift may limit the market share of niche car brands that fail to debut new models to excite the market.

site_title: Merkel's flexible line is rooted in history
summary: German Chancellor Angela Merkel signaled a willingness to renegotiate the UK's EU membership, acknowledging that curtailing free movement of people is "not impossible" and that she wants Germany to be a "constructive partner" for Britain. This stance is rooted in history, as Merkel understands the economics and geopolitics of the situation, and her country has long maintained a close rapport with Britain due to shared values and interests. Merkel's approach reflects a long-standing "Silent Alliance" between Germany and Britain, with a history of cooperation on issues like free markets and European integration.

site_title: Supply-side lift could inject US$1.5t to global growth
summary: Global economies need a "Plan B" to revive the sluggish world economy, as governments consider boosting productivity and competitiveness to drive growth. A supply-side lift could add $1.5 trillion to global growth, surpassing the European Central Bank's current bond-buying program. Strategists, including Martin Malone, advocate for reforms in areas such as trade, women's participation in labor forces, and infrastructure investment to achieve this goal. The shift in tone among Group of Seven leaders and promises of structural reforms offer a glimmer of hope for economic revival.

site_title: Neither growth nor reasonable price
summary: The P/E-to-growth gap, a key indicator used by Peter Lynch, has reached its widest since 1995, with the S&P 500 Index's price/earnings (P/E) multiples about 1.7 times higher than analysts' expected growth over the next five years. This suggests that stocks are overvalued, with the index's P/E at 17 times forecast earnings, 15% above its average in the past two decades. Analysts predict earnings will rise only 1.4% in 2015, down from 15% a year since 2009, leading some to express concern about the market's prospects.

site_title: Intel makes bid for rival semiconductor maker Altera
summary: Intel has agreed to pay $16.7 billion for chip company Altera, aiming to expand its presence in large data centers and the Internet of Things. The deal, part of a trend of consolidation in the semiconductor industry, follows a series of large mergers, including Avago's $37 billion acquisition of Broadcom. Intel hopes to gain flexibility, customers, and manufacturing capabilities from Altera, which was losing profitability due to high development and sales costs. The acquisition is driven by economics, as building and maintaining chip fabrication facilities has become prohibitively expensive for most companies.

site_title: Fiat Chrysler puts off redesign or release of a dozen vehicles
summary: Fiat Chrysler Automobiles (FCA) has delayed the redesign or release of at least a dozen vehicles in North America, including high-margin models such as the Ram 1500 pick-up and Jeep Wrangler, due to a search for a partner. This delay may allow the company to defer billions of dollars in investment. FCA's cash and marketable securities have fallen, and its net debt has risen. The company is accelerating development of certain vehicles, including Alfa Romeo models, as part of its five-year, $50 billion strategy to boost global sales to 7 million by 2018.

site_title: Head of TSA reassigned after tests reveal flaws
summary: The US Department of Homeland Security has reassigned the acting director of the Transportation Security Administration (TSA) after a covert test revealed that screeners failed to detect prohibited items 95% of the time. Undercover agents were able to get prohibited items through security checkpoints in 67 of 70 instances. The TSA has been ordered to revise its security procedures, retrain airport security officers, and increase covert testing. The agency's acting administrator, Melvin Carraway, has been replaced by Mark Hatfield, and Vice Admiral Peter Neffenger is expected to be confirmed as the new administrator.

site_title: Sophia Road residential site up for collective sale
summary: A 15-unit residential development, Fairhaven, along Sophia Road, has been launched for collective sale by public tender with a minimum offer of S$45 million, translating to S$1,169 per square foot per plot ratio. This comes amid other en bloc sales tenders, including Amber Park and Thong Sia Building, amid a generally quiet market. Analysts predict that successful collective sales will be few and far between due to high expectations from owners. The tender for Fairhaven closes on July 1.

site_title: US fund managers raise bets on healthcare even amid high prices
summary: US fund managers are increasing their bets on the healthcare sector despite high prices, with some analysts warning of a potential bubble similar to the tech bubble of the late 1990s. Fund managers like Graham Tanaka and Randy Gwirtzman have seen significant gains in healthcare stocks, with some funds beating the S&P 500 by 13 percentage points or more. However, analysts such as Tobias Levkovich caution that the sector's high valuations could lead to a sharp pullback if the rally continues. Despite this, healthcare is expected to continue growing as a larger part of the economy, with health spending projected to rise to 19.9% of US GDP by 2022.

site_title: Fifa denies that Blatter's aide approved US$10m payment
summary: FIFA has denied that Jerome Valcke, its former secretary general, was involved in a $10 million payment to Jack Warner, a disgraced football official facing US corruption charges. The payment was authorized by Julio Grondona, a former finance chief who died last year. FIFA claims the payment was for a World Cup legacy project to support the African diaspora in Caribbean countries. The US has charged 14 people, including Warner, with bribing officials to secure the 2010 World Cup.

site_title: China debt markets show more stress
summary: China's debt markets show increased stress as Zhong'ao Holdings Group Co, a smoked duck processor, defaults on bank loans due to difficulty in getting credit. The company owes banks 295.96 million yuan and must repay 200 million yuan of notes on June 12. This comes amid a trend of defaults by smaller companies, with banks becoming more cautious and reducing lending. China's junk bonds were also rattled last week after a bottle maker defaulted, and officials warn of more defaults among small and medium-sized enterprises.

site_title: ST Index drops 1.5% in the biggest sell-off in five months
summary: The Straits Times Index (STI) plummeted 1.5% to 3,340.75 on Tuesday, marking its worst sell-off in five months. The index is now 25 points or 0.7% in the red for 2015, with a cumulative loss of almost 200 points or 5.6% in six weeks. The market's weakness is attributed to months of non-performance, with some analysts speculating that funds may be exiting the market. The decline also reflects concerns over the Jardine group's possible removal from the STI and the impact of the new liquidity requirement.

site_title: Chinese ETFs come with volatility
summary: US investors are pouring money into Chinese exchange-traded funds (ETFs), with $1.1 billion in new money over the past month as the Shanghai Composite Index reached a seven-year high. The iShares China Large-Cap fund attracted $732 million, the largest inflow since 2012. However, foreign buyers must navigate market volatility, the highest in five years, due to the Chinese market's unpredictability. This surge in ETF inflows may be driven by dollar asset diversification and the desire for exposure to the growing Chinese economy.

site_title: Behavioural economics exposes just how irrational people are
summary: Behavioral economics, pioneered by Richard Thaler, challenges traditional economic theory by highlighting human irrationality. Thaler's work, as chronicled in his memoir "Misbehaving," showcases how people make systematic mistakes despite available data. His experiments, such as asking students to pay for a hypothetical antidote to a rare disease, reveal wildly different answers. This field, which also includes Amos Tversky and Daniel Kahneman's work, acknowledges that humans are not rational optimizers but rather prone to predictable biases. Thaler's rise to prominence, including his presidency of the American Economic Association, is a testament to the power of human misjudgment and the disruptive potential of behavioral economics.

site_title: Fund manager Ashburton sees spark in India
summary: Fund manager Ashburton Investments Ltd is betting on India's equities, citing a 16% discount between India's S&P BSE Sensex index and the Shanghai Composite Index. India's economy grew 7.5% in the first quarter, beating China's 7% expansion, and is expected to outpace China in the current fiscal year. Ashburton's India equity fund has returned 79% since its launch three years ago, while foreign investors have pulled a net $429 million from Indian shares in May, the largest outflows since 2013.

site_title: Eurogroup chief says 'not enough' progress in Greek debt talks
summary: Eurogroup chief Jeroen Dijsselbloem expressed disappointment with the progress made in debt talks with Greece, stating "there is some progress, but it's really not enough" as Athens submitted a "realistic" plan to creditors. The talks aim to unlock 7.2 billion euros in remaining bailout funds, with a Friday deadline to repay over 300 million euros to the IMF. Dijsselbloem warned that time is pressing and no half-way compromises will be accepted, as creditors push for greater reforms.

site_title: Manchester Airport earmarks £1b to lure long-haul airlines
summary: Manchester Airport is investing £1 billion over 10 years to upgrade its facilities and broaden its appeal to long-haul airlines. The upgrades include expanding Terminal 2, establishing a US customs facility, and improving road links. The changes aim to future-proof the airport, meet the demands of carriers such as Emirates and Ryanair, and tap into government plans to rebalance the UK economy. The investment is expected to boost passenger numbers, with the airport already having more routes than Gatwick and aiming to add new destinations such as Beijing and Mumbai.

site_title: Ado plans IPO to raise 400m euros
summary: ADO Properties SA, a Berlin-based residential real estate investor, plans to raise at least 400 million euros through an initial public offering (IPO) on the Frankfurt exchange. The company, which owns 13,700 homes and 700 commercial properties, aims to use the funds to buy more properties and improve existing homes. Demand for German property stocks is rising, driven by increasing home values in Europe's largest economy, with Berlin apartment prices climbing 50% in three years and rents gaining 30%. The IPO will be managed by Kempen & Co NV and UBS Group AG.

site_title: Entertainment, media industry to ride S'pore's mobile, Net edge
summary: Singapore's entertainment and media industry is expected to grow at a 5.4% compound annual growth rate (CAGR) from 2014 to 2019, driven by the country's high-quality mobile and broadband network. Despite having a high digital consumption rate, Singapore has one of the lowest proportions of digital media spend among developed countries. The industry is expected to see growth in internet advertising, video advertising, and online TV advertising, with total internet advertising revenue projected to reach US$609 million by 2019. Traditional media, such as newspapers and TV, will also continue to grow, but at a slower pace.

site_title: US flights face bomb threats, no explosives found: media reports
summary: US Airways flight 648 from San Diego to Philadelphia received a bomb threat upon landing at Philadelphia International Airport, prompting an evacuation and search. No explosives were found, according to an airline official. Similar threats were reported on other US commercial flights, including a United Airlines flight to Chicago and a Delta Air Lines flight to Atlanta. The Federal Bureau of Investigation was notified, but officials were unavailable for comment. Passengers were deplaned, and the planes were searched, with all flights landing safely.

site_title: Hyundai shares tumble to five-year low
summary: Hyundai shares plummeted 10% on Tuesday to a five-year low of 138,500 won, marking the worst performance among major carmakers in the past year. The decline is attributed to unfavorable exchange rates and foreign brands gaining traction in South Korea. Domestic sales fell 8.2% in May, while overseas sales dropped 6.1%. Analysts' 12-month target price has dropped from over 300,000 won to 207,868 won, indicating a significant decline in investor confidence.

site_title: Euro-area consumer prices up in relief for ECB after deflation scare
summary: Euro-area consumer prices rose 0.3% in May, exceeding forecast of 0.2%, with core inflation accelerating to 0.9% - the fastest in nine months. The increase is largely due to a rebound in oil prices. Despite this, inflation remains below the ECB's goal of 2%, and policymakers will assess the data when they meet in Frankfurt this week. The ECB's trillion-euro stimulus program is ongoing until at least September 2016, aiming to boost inflation to 1.8% by 2017.

images.alt_text: The central bank's latest projections foresee an average inflation rate of zero this year, rising to 1.8 per cent by 2017.

site_title: Singapore fuel oil trade volume highest in at least 5 years: traders
summary: Singapore experienced its highest daily fuel oil trade volume in at least 5 years, with 620,000 tonnes traded on Tuesday. The majority of this volume was 380-centistoke grade, accounting for nearly a third of the monthly volume. This record-breaking trade volume was facilitated by Platts, a unit of McGraw Hill Financial, during the Asia's pricing process.

site_title: Opec hopes for further oil price recovery despite glut
summary: OPEC officials, including Angola's oil minister, are optimistic about oil price recovery, expecting it to reach $80 per barrel. Despite a global oil glut, OPEC is expected to maintain its production policy at its upcoming meeting. The group's decision last November to defend market share contributed to the supply surplus, which has been exacerbated by booming US oil output. OPEC officials hope for a price increase, but acknowledge it's not easy to achieve.

site_title: South Korea's inflation speeds up for first time in 7 months
summary: South Korea's inflation rate accelerated for the first time in 7 months in May, rising 0.5% from a year earlier, according to Statistics Korea data. The increase was attributed to higher farm product prices and slower declines in oil product prices. Despite the rise, annual inflation remains below the central bank's target of 2.5-3.5%, and economists predict the Bank of Korea may cut interest rates again to boost the economy. A rate cut could occur before the US Federal Reserve raises interest rates later this year.

site_title: CDL's 'green' condo gets global recognition
summary: CDL's Tree House condominium has received international recognition for its eco-inspired design and green features. The property won the Sustainable Development category at the FIABCI World Prix d'Excellence Awards 2015, taking home the World Gold award. The condominium features a 24-storey vertical garden that provides natural insulation and filters pollutants, reducing energy needed to cool indoor spaces by 98,000 kWh/year. This innovative design aims to promote sustainable development amidst rapid urbanization and population growth.

site_title: Microsoft fine said to be on shipping lines' minds in EU probe
summary: The European Union is drafting a possible deal with shipping lines, including AP Moeller-Maersk A/S, to avoid initial fines in a case over possible collusion on prices. The deal, worth 561 million euros, would allow Maersk Line and its rivals to avoid fines for breaking a promise made to Microsoft. Microsoft was fined for breaching a promise not to favor certain shipping lines. The EU has been investigating the matter since 2013.

site_title: PBOC injects cheap funds using long-term lending tool
summary: China's central bank, the People's Bank of China (PBOC), has injected cheap funds into the banking system using a long-term lending tool to combat rising municipal debt issuance and long-term yields. This move, dubbed "Operation Twist," aims to encourage lending and bond purchases. The yield on 10-year sovereign bonds has risen 29 basis points since April, despite cuts in interest rates and reserve requirements. The PBOC provided funds to banks through the Pledged Supplementary Lending programme at 3.1% to boost financing and stimulate investment and demand for homes.

site_title: Fed's Brainard says US economic slowdown may be more than temporary
summary: Federal Reserve board member Lael Brainard suggests the US economic slowdown may be more than temporary, citing weak consumer spending, low investment, and a high dollar as factors. Brainard indicates a rate hike may still be a ways off, but warns of a more significant drag on the economy, citing a mixed picture of data and a recovery that has been marked by "fits and starts." The Fed's policy setting committee may consider an interest rate increase in June, but Brainard's comments add to concerns that overseas troubles may delay the move.

site_title: Singapore ranks 9th for rule of law
summary: Singapore ranked 9th worldwide in the 2015 World Justice Project (WJP) Rule of Law Index, up from last year. It ranked first in regulatory enforcement and second in the East Asia and Pacific region. The index evaluates countries based on 47 indicators across eight categories, with Singapore excelling in formal and procedural rules. Despite ranking high, Singapore remains a "work in progress" in open government and fundamental rights. The WJP emphasizes that a strong rule of law can combat corruption, poverty, and disease, and protect people from injustices.

site_title: US: Stocks drop as Greece fears hover over eurozone
summary: US stocks dropped on Tuesday as European markets declined due to concerns over a possible Greek debt default. The Dow Jones Industrial Average fell 47.51 points, the S&P 500 dropped 6.32 points, and the Nasdaq Composite Index lost 18.85 points. The eurozone's deadline for Greece to repay over $328 million to the IMF looms on Friday, with official creditors pushing for tougher reforms than those accepted by Greece's government. Despite a "realistic" reform plan submitted by Greece, markets remain uncertain.

site_title: Ezra falls amid plan for rights issue
summary: Ezra shares plummeted to their lowest level since January 2005, shedding 12.8% to close at S$0.34 on the first trading day after the oilfield services group announced plans to refinance its debt. The 5-cent drop occurred on a day when 18.8 million shares changed hands, marking the steepest daily decline since January 2014. Analysts downplayed the drop, citing the company's plans to raise funds.

site_title: Brokers' take
summary: NTT DC Reit's Singapore public offer was oversubscribed 9.8 times, exceeding expectations. US stocks opened lower as the US imposed fresh tariffs on Canada. Creative Technology warned of potential revenue shortfall in H2, with similar operating loss to H1. London's Heathrow plans to increase fees for a £10 billion upgrade. Indonesia detained an employee in a 285 trillion rupiah graft case. Singapore stocks rallied for the 5th consecutive day ahead of GDP data release.

site_title: HSBC must face US lawsuits over mortgage debt losses
summary: HSBC Holdings plc has been ordered to face three US lawsuits over mortgage debt losses, totaling over $34 billion, stemming from its role as a trustee in residential mortgage-backed securities during the global financial crisis. The lawsuits, filed by investors including BlackRock Inc and Allianz SE, accuse HSBC of breaching its duties and concealing defects in mortgage loans. US District Judge Shira Scheindlin allowed the plaintiffs to pursue claims of breach of contract and concealment of defects in 283 trusts.

site_title: Apple to give developers tools to speed up slow-load watch apps
summary: Apple plans to unveil new tools for developers to speed up slow-load watch apps, addressing criticism that the Apple Watch's performance issues could harm sales. The upgrade will be a key highlight of the company's annual conference for 5,000-plus software developers in San Francisco. The new software development kit will allow engineers to write programs on the watch and access its sensors, enabling faster app loading times and potentially boosting app development for the device.

site_title: Big Oil promoting gas as successor to coal
summary: Big Oil companies, including Royal Dutch Shell and Total, are promoting natural gas as a cleaner alternative to coal, with a focus on reducing carbon emissions. The move comes as almost 200 nations prepare to agree on a binding pact on carbon emissions in December. Fossil-fuel companies are refocusing on gas as a cleaner option, with Exxon Mobil Corp's output rising to 47% of total production last year. However, critics argue that the shift to gas may not be enough to combat global warming, citing the economics of coal and the abundance of the fuel in fast-growing Asia.

site_title: Singapore Wrap Tuesday
summary: Singapore's Manpower Ministry announced no changes to its foreign-worker policy, maintaining a labour-lean economy. At a tech showcase, the new Minister reiterated Smart Nation goals, highlighting advancements in infocomm technologies. Global Invacom acquired US satellite terminal maker Skyware, and GSS Energy expanded into energy trading through a joint venture. The Straits Times Index (STI) plummeted 1.5% due to liquidity rule changes and other unknown factors.

site_title: Indian automaker Mahindra to fit Google's Android technology in SUVs
summary: Mahindra, India's top-selling utility vehicle maker, plans to integrate Google's Android Auto technology into its SUVs, including the XUV 500 and Scorpio. Android Auto aims to make driving safer and easier by allowing voice command access to applications like maps through the steering wheel. This integration is part of Mahindra's partnership with the Open Automotive Alliance, a global group of automakers and technology companies working to bring the Android platform to cars. The technology will be made available after successful integration, but a timeline has not been committed.

site_title: Kingsmen Creatives to acquire the rest of Kingsmen (North Asia) Ltd
summary: Kingsmen Creatives Ltd has entered into a sale and purchase agreement to acquire 117,000 ordinary shares of Kingsmen (North Asia) Ltd for S$3.17 million. The deal will increase Kingsmen's shareholding in KNA from 92.2% to 100%. S$1.8 million will be satisfied by new shares, while the remaining S$1.37 million will be paid in cash.

site_title: Shipping giant Maersk orders 11 'mega' container ships
summary: Maersk, the world's largest container transporter, has agreed to buy 11 "mega" container ships for $1.8 billion. The 400-meter-long vessels will be capable of carrying over 19,000 containers and are set to be deployed between April 2017 and May 2018. The purchase is part of Maersk's strategy to stay competitive in the Asia-Europe trade and grow with the market. The new ships will replace smaller vessels, allowing Maersk to maintain its market performance despite the sector's overcapacity.

site_title: SPH's Sphere Exhibits buys another 40% of Beerfest for S$580,000
summary: Sphere Exhibits, a subsidiary of Singapore Press Holdings, has purchased 40% of Beerfest Asia for S$580,000, increasing its stake to 80%. Timbre Group sold its remaining 20% shares, which are held by individuals. The acquisition is expected to have no material impact on SPH's net tangible assets per share or earnings per share for the current financial year.

site_title: Lufthansa seeks to take more control over ticket sales
summary: Lufthansa plans to introduce a 16-euro ($18) surcharge on ticket sales not booked through its own websites, aiming to regain control over ticket sales and boost revenue. The airline's revenue from ticket sales has been decreasing, with costs to use global distribution systems (GDSs) reaching over 100 million euros annually. This move is part of a broader trend among airlines to unbundling services and charge passengers separately for amenities.

site_title: Samsung Elec sold 6m Galaxy S6 devices by end-April: Counterpoint
summary: Samsung Electronics Co Ltd sold 6 million Galaxy S6 smartphones by end-April, surpassing initial expectations. The devices became the world's most popular, behind Apple's iPhones, according to research firm Counterpoint. Sales are expected to reach 50 million by year-end, setting a new record for the Galaxy S series. This achievement was less than a month after the devices' launch.

site_title: Oil up ahead of Opec meeting as dollar slips
summary: Oil prices rose due to a weaker dollar, making oil cheaper for consumers, and expectations that Opec will maintain its production target. Brent crude oil rose 40 cents to $65.28 a barrel, while US crude rose 60 cents to $60.80 a barrel. Opec ministers meet on Friday to decide on production policy for the next six months, with analysts expecting demand to pick up and supply to decrease, helping to balance the market. Most investors expect no change in Opec's official target, despite some analysts suggesting a potential increase.

site_title: Singapore manufacturing PMI returns to growth in May, but electronics still in contraction
summary: Singapore's manufacturing sector showed signs of growth in May, with the purchasing managers' index (PMI) rising to 50.2 from 49.4 in April. However, the electronics PMI remained below the 50-point threshold, indicating contraction. Improvements in new orders, production, and inventory contributed to the growth, but new export orders and employment continued to decline. The electronics sector saw production and imports return to growth, but new orders from domestic and foreign markets declined. Overall, the data suggests a potential turning point for Singapore's manufacturing sector.

site_title: Fear and confusion in S.Korea amid secrecy over MERS hospitals
summary: Fear and confusion spread in South Korea as the country grappled with its first MERS (Middle East Respiratory Syndrome) deaths, with two confirmed cases and over 700 in isolation. The government refused to name the hospitals treating infected patients, fueling speculation and rumors. Despite the lack of transparency, life in Seoul appeared normal, with few taking precautions. Experts warned of the risks of group visits to hospitals, citing cases of exposure, and called for a shift in cultural norms to prioritize patient recovery.

site_title: US factory orders decline, demand broadly soft
summary: US factory orders declined 0.4% in April, falling for the eighth consecutive month, as demand for transportation equipment and other goods weakened. The decline was unexpected, contrary to economists' forecasts of flat orders. Excluding the volatile transport component, orders remained unchanged for a second straight month. The decline is attributed to a strong dollar and spending cuts in the energy sector, suggesting manufacturing remains constrained.

images.alt_text: New orders for US factory goods unexpectedly fell in April as demand for transportation equipment and a range of other goods weakened, suggesting that manufacturing remained constrained by a strong dollar and spending cuts in the energy sector.

site_title: Bank managers knew about Libor fixing, Hayes told Citigroup HR
summary: Citigroup manager Thomas Hayes claimed in a 2010 letter that senior management at Citigroup Global Markets Japan was aware of his attempts to manipulate benchmark interest rates, the London interbank offered rate (Libor), and that he was not told his actions constituted wrongdoing. Hayes, a 35-year-old former trader, is accused of eight counts of conspiracy to manipulate Libor from 2006 to 2010. The letter, written after his dismissal, contradicts prosecutors' claims that Hayes acted alone, suggesting higher levels of involvement than previously thought.

site_title: US housing market seen withstanding Fed's interest rate hikes
summary: The US housing market is expected to withstand the Federal Reserve's interest rate hikes, with 28 out of 32 economists surveyed predicting stronger house price gains this year. Home prices are forecast to rise 5.0% this year and 4.5% in 2016.
