Sales of previously owned homes are expected to average 5.10 million units in the second quarter and 5.20 million units in the third quarter. The median forecasters believe interest rate hikes will be gradual, maintaining a relatively accommodative environment.

site_title: Singapore: STI plunges 1.5% on heavy selling
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) plummeted 1.5% on Tuesday, falling to 3,340.75, due to heavy selling. The decline was attributed to an impending change in liquidity rules and unexplained falls in Singtel and banks. The STI is now 25 points or 0.7% down for 2015. Turnover reached 1.5 billion units worth S$1.74 billion, with 135 rises and 340 falls. The Jardine stable and other components also fell significantly.

site_title: China's Xiaomi launches online store in US, Europe
summary: Xiaomi, a leading Chinese smartphone maker, has launched an online store in the US and major European countries, including France, Britain, and Germany. The move marks the brand's entry into established Western markets. The online store, mi.com, initially offers accessories such as fitness bands, headphones, and battery cells at competitive prices. Xiaomi aims to expand its product offerings to consumers in the US and Europe in the future, building on its success in China, where it has become the world's number three smartphone vendor.

site_title: Malaysia's Anwar in hospital with "serious" health problems: wife
summary: Malaysia's jailed ex-opposition leader Anwar Ibrahim was hospitalized with "serious" health problems, including erratic blood pressure, according to his wife Wan Azizah Wan Ismail. The prison authorities were criticized for allegedly delaying Anwar's request for treatment and tests. Wan Azizah described Anwar's condition as "serious" and called for immediate medical attention.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares end lower
summary: Malaysia's shares ended lower on Tuesday, closing at 1,741.37 after a 2.04-point drop. A total of 1.73 billion lots worth RM2.15 billion were traded, with 571 gainers and 262 losers.

site_title: Facebook opens new artificial intelligence lab in Paris
summary: Facebook has opened a new artificial intelligence lab in Paris, expanding its efforts to make its online social network smarter and more profitable. The lab, which will double in size by the end of the year, will focus on improving image recognition and interpretation, as well as eliminating spam and violent content. With over 350 million photos uploaded daily, Facebook aims to better mine these images for advertising opportunities. The lab, led by Yann LeCun, will be the largest AI research facility in France and continental Europe.

site_title: China central bank issues guidelines for banks to issue large certificates of deposit
summary: China's central bank, the People's Bank of China (PBOC), has issued guidelines for banks to issue large certificates of deposit (CDs), paving the way for full interest rate liberalization. The CDs will be covered by the deposit insurance program and can be issued to individuals, non-financial firms, or institutional investors with varying minimum thresholds. Floating rates for the CDs will be based on the Shanghai Interbank Offered Rate (SHIBOR). This move aims to free the flow of capital within China's financial system and market-determined interest rates.

images.alt_text: China's central bank on Tuesday issued rules governing the transfer of large-scale certificates of deposit (CDs), saying they will pave the way for full interest rate liberalisation.

site_title: GLP leases logistics facilities to six customers in China
summary: GLP leases 146,000 sq m of logistics facilities to six Chinese customers, including repeat clients Best Logistics and Deppon Logistics. The agreements cater to domestic consumption across various industries, including e-commerce and home appliances. GLP's US$28 billion portfolio comprises 41 million sq m of logistics facilities in China, Japan, Brazil, and the US. The company expects to support its customers as they expand across China, driven by growing domestic consumption.

site_title: Chipmaker Intel said to be planning debut European bond offering
summary: Intel Corp plans to sell its first European bonds, offering notes in euros, pounds, or both, according to a person familiar with the matter. Barclays Plc and JPMorgan Chase & Co are arranging investor meetings. The move is Intel's first foray into the European bond market, marking a significant step in its global expansion efforts. Details of the bond offering, including the size and interest rate, have not been disclosed.

images.alt_text: Intel Corp is planning to sell its first bonds in Europe, according to a person familiar with the matter.

site_title: Opec is winning the oil price war
summary: OPEC is winning the oil price war as the organization's production strategy continues to influence global oil markets. In November, OPEC left production unchanged, causing oil prices to collapse to a six-year low. The strategy aims to flood the market and force higher-cost producers to scale back, ultimately pushing prices back up. This approach has been successful, with OPEC announcing plans to trim oil demand for the next four years. The organization's strategy has given it significant control over the global oil market, with OPEC's decisions having a direct impact on oil prices.

site_title: Deutsche Boerse to open Asia derivatives exchange
summary: Deutsche Boerse plans to open a derivatives exchange in Singapore, with operations expected to begin in the second quarter of 2026. The move is part of the German exchange operator's effort to expand its business in Asia. Following the approval of a clearing house in Singapore earlier this year, the new derivatives exchange will be the exchange's second Asian presence. This expansion aims to increase Deutsche Boerse's presence in the growing Asian market.

site_title: ECB study highlights credit crunch for Greek companies
summary: The European Central Bank's biannual survey highlights stark differences in credit availability across the eurozone, with Greek companies struggling to secure funding despite an overall improvement in credit conditions. Greek companies face a drastic situation, with tumbling profits and reduced access to credit as the government navigates European debt concerns. In contrast, companies in Spain and Germany find it easier to borrow.

site_title: India interest rate cut shows economy needs support: finmin adviser
summary: The Reserve Bank of India (RBI) cut interest rates for a third time this year, citing subdued inflation to boost the economy. Chief Economic Adviser Arvind Subramanian stated the economy needs support, despite impressive growth numbers. The government aims to contain inflationary risks if summer monsoon rains turn out to be weak.

site_title: Bernanke says Yuan approaching fair value after Lew urges gains
summary: Former Federal Reserve Chairman Ben Bernanke stated that the yuan is approaching fair value, supporting China's claim of a market-driven exchange rate. The yuan has strengthened against 30 of 31 major currencies since China removed its dollar peg in 2015, with a 34% jump against the US dollar. This trend contrasts with significant declines in other emerging economies, such as Brazil, Russia, and India.

images.alt_text: Former Federal Reserve Chairman Ben Bernanke said the yuan is heading toward fair value, lending weight to China's claim that its exchange rate is largely determined by market forces.

site_title: Manpower Ministry making changes for a labour-lean economy
summary: Singapore's new Manpower Minister Lim Swee Say is shifting focus from relaxing foreign-worker policies to making the economy "manpower-lean" to boost the local core workforce and upgrade foreign workers. He aims for a more competitive economy, beneficial for businesses seeking higher profits and Singaporeans seeking a fruitful career path. The government will work with businesses and unions to achieve this goal, rather than increasing foreign worker quotas or reducing levies. This approach is expected to benefit the economy in the long run, but details of the plan are still unclear.

site_title: Greece calls on lenders to accept "realistic" plan sent on Monday
summary: Greece has sent a "comprehensive" and "realistic" package of reforms to EU and IMF lenders, calling on Europe to accept it to end the crisis. The proposal was submitted to lenders just in time for a late-night meeting in Berlin to discuss Greece's fate. Greek Prime Minister Alexis Tsipras stated that the plan aims to help Greece exit the crisis, and he urged Europe to put aside divisions to accept it. The meeting in Berlin will discuss Greece's future, but no further details on the proposal's contents have been disclosed.

site_title: Growth in UK construction picks up, optimism surges after election: Markit
summary: Optimism among British construction firms surged to a nine-year high in May, driven by Prime Minister David Cameron's election victory. The Markit/CIPS UK Construction Purchasing Managers' Index (PMI) rebounded to 55.9, beating forecasts and marking the first growth since April 2013. Firms took on staff at the fastest rate in five months, but it's unclear if the boost in confidence will translate to increased output volumes. The survey contrasts with weaker official data showing a 1.1% contraction in construction output in the first three months of 2015.

site_title: US small-business borrowing hit record in April: PayNet
summary: US small businesses boosted borrowing to record levels in April, with the Thomson Reuters/PayNet Small Business Lending Index rising to 141.5. This marks a 13% increase from the same period last year, and a decline in delinquency rates, suggesting improved financial health. The trend is seen as a positive sign for economic growth, tracking ahead of US GDP growth by two to five months, which fell at a 0.7% annual rate in the first quarter.

site_title: Eurozone inflation higher than expected in May
summary: Eurozone inflation rose 0.3% year-over-year in May, beating market expectations of a 0.2% increase. This rebound, despite a strong drag from cheaper energy, could indicate the effectiveness of the European Central Bank's sovereign bond buying program. Consumer prices excluding energy and unprocessed food rose 1.0% and 0.9% respectively, accelerating from April's 0.7% and 0.7% readings.

site_title: German jobless rate stays at record low in May
summary: Germany's unemployment rate remained at a record low in May, standing at 2.786 million, according to the Labour Office. This was in line with the consensus forecast and the lowest since German reunification in 1990. The number of people out of work decreased by 6,000 on a seasonally-adjusted basis, slightly smaller than the forecasted 10,000 drop. The low unemployment rate suggests private consumption will propel growth in Germany this year.

site_title: Prudential sells Korean drugmakers after shares almost double
summary: Prudential Plc's South Korean unit is selling its holdings in the nation's pharmaceutical companies due to valuations that have surged to three times the benchmark index. The Korean pharmaceutical stocks have rallied 82% this year, outperforming the broader Kospi index. The decision to sell is attributed to investors buying into "future stories" that are difficult to guarantee, rather than the companies' current earnings.

site_title: Toyota's billionaire partner sees Philippines sales doubling
summary: Toyota's partner, Carmelo Bautista, predicts the company's Philippine sales will double by 2020, driven by rising personal incomes. Deliveries are expected to grow 20% annually, with sales reaching 134,220 vehicles by then. The growth is attributed to the country's growing middle class and President Aquino's executive order offering tax breaks for carmakers. Toyota is set to expand its dealerships to 60 and add another production line, capitalizing on the country's growing car market.

site_title: Japan's oil use may fall 33% by 2030: ministry
summary: Japan's oil use is projected to fall by 33% by 2030 to around 2.5 million barrels per day, a 1.9% annual decline, driven by a return to nuclear power and increased renewable energy use. Oil will remain the largest component of Japan's primary energy supply at 30% in 2030, down from 40% in 2014. The country aims to increase nuclear power generation to 20-22% and renewable energy output, raising self-sufficiency to 25% by 2030 from 6% currently.

site_title: MH370 disappearance suit settled out-of-court in Malaysia
summary: The Malaysian government and Malaysia Airlines have reached an out-of-court settlement with the family of Jee Jing Hang, a passenger on the missing Flight MH370, in a lawsuit claiming breach of contract and negligence. The settlement, reached in October, allows the family to drop their claims, but terms remain undisclosed. The move may trigger similar legal actions from other affected families. An Australian-led search for MH370's wreckage continues in the southern Indian Ocean, with no debris found since the flight's disappearance in 2014.

site_title: One-third of investors see Greek Euro exit, GAM survey shows
summary: A survey by Swiss asset manager GAM Holding AG found that one-third of investors expect Greece to exit the euro area within the next 12 months due to the country's talks with creditors over a bailout package expiring this month. In contrast, only 9% predicted the UK leaving the EU. Investors cited geopolitical risk, economic recovery reversals, and interest rate movements as key concerns. The survey also found that 78% of pension fund managers believe they will fail to meet long-term investment targets due to regulatory restrictions.

site_title: Hong Kong: Shares close down as investors wait for stimulus
summary: Hong Kong stocks fell 0.5% on Tuesday, with the Hang Seng index closing at 27,466.72, due to investors waiting for mainland policies to guide money into the city's market. The market lacks direction, and investors are also watching the US Federal Reserve's interest rate hike timing, which could potentially draw money away from Hong Kong. Mainland China's market posted solid gains, but Hong Kong's shares were unaffected.

site_title: Greek factory activity shrinks in May, exports orders decline: PMI
summary: Greek manufacturing activity declined for the ninth consecutive month in May, with a PMI of 48, down from 46.5 in April. Export orders and production led to job cuts. The economy contracted 0.2% in the first quarter, and factory output was scaled back for the fifth consecutive month. The weak euro drove up costs, but manufacturers struggled to attract demand due to uncertainty over Greece's bailout aid.

site_title: Fifa acknowledges US$10 million transfer
summary: Fifa acknowledged a US$10 million transfer from South Africa to Jack Warner, the then president of the North, Central America and Caribbean football confederation, in 2007. The transfer was facilitated by Fifa, which claimed it was to support the African diaspora in Caribbean countries. Fifa denied that its secretary general, Jerome Valcke, was involved in the transfer, stating it was an intermediary between South Africa and the project. This admission comes as Warner is one of 14 people charged with involvement in more than US$150 million of bribes to soccer officials.

images.alt_text: Fifa on Tuesday admitted that it had processed a US$10 million payment from South Africa to football official Jack Warner but denied that the world body's secretary general Jerome Valcke was involved.

site_title: Myanmar navy escorting boat with 727 migrants to Bangladesh waters: minister
summary: Myanmar's navy is escorting a boat carrying 727 abandoned migrants to Bangladesh waters, four days after intercepting it in the Andaman Sea. The migrants, who wanted to go to Bangladesh rather than Myanmar, will receive assistance, including water, food, and other necessities, according to the country's information minister. The navy's cooperation is based on the migrants' wishes to reach Bangladesh.

site_title: Craft Print ventures into chemicals, proposes name change
summary: Craft Print International, a loss-making printing business, is diversifying into chemicals through a joint venture company Orient-Salt Chemicals (OSC). Craft Print will hold a 51% stake in OSC, which will manufacture and trade chemicals. The company plans to transfer its printing business to a wholly-owned subsidiary and change its name to Abundance International Limited to reflect the new business line. Craft Print will also change its financial year-end to December 31 and grant put and call options to Jiang Hao, who will eventually hold control of OSC.

site_title: Europe: Stocks advance at open
summary: European stocks rose at the opening bell on Tuesday, with the CAC 40 in Paris gaining 0.52% to 5,051.68 points, and the DAX 30 in Frankfurt rising 0.27% to 11,467.07 points. The rally was driven by hopes of a deal on bailout funds for Greece. In other markets, London's FTSE 100 index inched up 0.04% to 6,955.87 points, while Singapore's STI index rose 0.4% on Thursday despite tariff uncertainty.

site_title: Australia: Shares post sharpest fall in 4 weeks as central bank holds rates
summary: Australian shares fell 1.7% to their largest decline in four weeks, closing at 5636.0, due to tumbling commodity prices and the Reserve Bank of Australia's decision not to cut interest rates. This was the biggest one-day drop since May 6. In contrast, New Zealand's benchmark index rose 0.3% to 5863.7.

site_title: Microsoft to buy German start-up behind Wunderlist app: report
summary: Microsoft has agreed to acquire 6Wunderkinder GmbH, the German start-up behind the popular Wunderlist to-do list app, for between $100-200 million. The acquisition is part of Microsoft's efforts to enhance its mobile app line. 6Wunderkinder was created in 2010 and allows users to manage tasks on multiple devices. The deal is the latest move by Microsoft to bolster its mobile presence, following its acquisition of LiveLoop in March.

images.alt_text: Microsoft has agreed to acquire 6Wunderkinder GmbH, a Berlin-based startup behind the Wunderlist to-do list app, for between US$100-200 million, the Wall Street Journal reported on Tuesday.

site_title: 'Serious progress' in Greece talks but 'work to do': commissioner
summary: Greece's debt crisis talks have made "serious progress," according to EU Commissioner Pierre Moscovici, but more work needs to be done. A late-night meeting in Berlin involving the International Monetary Fund, European Central Bank, and European leaders resulted in an agreement to intensify talks and present a final proposal to Athens. The talks aim to prevent a potential Greek default, which could lead to the country's exit from the eurozone, and a key repayment deadline of 300 million euros to the IMF looms on Friday.

site_title: Islamic finance looks to jump on Asia's infrastructure bandwagon
summary: Islamic finance is looking to expand into infrastructure projects in Asia, with governments and bankers planning a new organization to handle deals. The Asian Development Bank estimates $800 billion in infrastructure financing is needed annually in Asia over the next decade. An Islamic infrastructure bank, backed by Indonesia and Turkey, is being launched to address technical and legal issues. The use of sukuk, Islamic bonds, is seen as ideal for infrastructure projects, with Malaysia's recent 30-year sukuk sale setting a pricing benchmark for future deals. However, complexities in sukuk structures and regulatory hurdles remain obstacles to their widespread adoption.

site_title: Copper trades near US$6,000 amid signs of slowing in US, China
summary: Copper prices traded near $6,000 a metric ton amid signs of slowing US and Chinese economies. US manufacturing new orders dropped 0.1% in May, while China's economy has slowed below its 7% target rate. Analysts predict a global copper surplus this year, with China's new low-voltage cable standards potentially accelerating a switch to aluminum alloy. Copper prices have fallen for a sixth day, extending May's 5.1% decline, their first monthly loss since January.

site_title: Hyundai Motor falls to lowest since 2010 after sales slump
summary: Hyundai Motor Co fell to its lowest level in nearly five years, closing at 138,500 won after its domestic sales declined for the second month in a row. Domestic sales dropped 8.2% and overseas sales declined 6.1% in May. The company failed to boost deliveries despite offering price cuts and interest-free loans. Hyundai's market share sank to 32% in January, its lowest in at least 15 years, amid rising competition from foreign brands.

site_title: Lupin, Cipla said to bid for UCB's $1b US generics unit
summary: Indian pharmaceutical companies Lupin Ltd and Cipla Ltd have submitted first-round bids for UCB SA's US generics business, valued at approximately $1 billion. This follows a previous $1.5 billion sale attempt that fell apart in November. The companies aim to expand their presence in the US market, competing with market leader Sun Pharmaceutical Industries Ltd. UCB is selling the US generics business as it focuses on central nervous system illnesses and immunology. The outcome of the bidding process is uncertain, with no assurance that Lupin and Cipla will proceed to the next round.

site_title: Hot stock: SGX says not aware of any info on unusual trading of its stock
summary: The Singapore Exchange (SGX) stated it is unaware of information explaining the unusual trading activity in its stock, which has fallen over 6% since May 27. As of Tuesday, the stock was trading at S$8.17, down 3.1% from Friday's close. The SGX confirmed the company is in compliance with listing rules and did not disclose any internal information that might cause the unusual trading.

site_title: Singapore' STI down 0.83% on Tuesday morning
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) fell 0.83% on Tuesday, down 28.15 points to 3,363.96, following mixed sentiment in US and European trading. Key stocks like Keppel Corp, Singtel, and Noble Corp. declined. The session saw 136.6 million shares change hands, with 113 losers outweighing 74 gainers.

site_title: Greece will make June 5 IMF payment if deal with lenders reached: official
summary: Greece will make a 300 million-euro payment to the International Monetary Fund on June 5 if a deal with its lenders is reached by then, a Greek government official stated. The payment is part of four 1.6 billion-euro payments scheduled for June, and Athens may not be able to pay without new loans from European and IMF creditors. The official confirmed that a preliminary agreement would be made, but not necessarily approved at a Eurogroup meeting.

site_title: Frontier to buy US$1.3b of Airbus jets featuring more seats
summary: Frontier Airlines Inc has agreed to purchase 12 Airbus jets valued at $1.3 billion to replace its smallest planes with larger models featuring more seats. The aircraft, consisting of 10 A321s and 2 A320s, will help the airline accelerate its fleet growth and reduce expenses by increasing the number of seats on each plane. The move is part of Frontier's shift to becoming an ultra-low-cost carrier, with CEO Barry Biffle stating that the goal is to be the lowest-cost carrier in the US.

site_title: SHC Capital to buy Tong Da Medical Device in reverse takeover
summary: SHC Capital is set to acquire Tong Da Medical Device in a reverse takeover, transforming into a medical device business. The acquisition will be funded by the issuance of shares at S$0.07 apiece, totaling S$120 million. Tong Da produces and sells medical equipment in China, with a net profit of S$10.3 million in 2014. The deal faces conditions, including meeting Singapore Exchange requirements for a new listing within 12 months, or risk being removed from the Catalist board.

site_title: Crocodile-skin handbag sells for a record US$222,912
summary: A fuchsia-coloured crocodile-skin Hermes bag broke the record for the most expensive handbag sold at auction, selling for US$222,912 at a Christie's auction in Hong Kong. The bag was sold to an Asian phone bidder in a fast-paced auction, with a final price around 15% more than the estimated US$190,000.

site_title: US tightens airport security after screeners fail undercover tests
summary: Homeland Security Secretary Jeh Johnson has ordered improved security at US airports following a report that 95% of undercover tests found airport screeners failed to detect mock explosives and weapons. In 70 tests, screeners missed banned items in 67 instances, with some failing to find devices taped to undercover agents. Johnson directed the TSA to revise screening procedures, order training for all officers, and test screening equipment. He also promised more random covert testing at checkpoints, citing the need to continually evolve aviation security as threats evolve.

site_title: Minister reiterates Singapore's Smart Nation goals at tech showcase
summary: Singapore Minister for Communications and Information Yaacob Ibrahim reiterated the country's Smart Nation goals at a tech showcase. The Infocomm Media Business eXchange featured over 2,000 exhibitors showcasing various smart technologies, including video analytics and smart logistics. The government announced the Video Analytics Smart Nation Tech Challenge and Smart Logistics platform, aiming to boost public safety, resource utilization, and situation awareness. The Smart Nation and Infocomm Media Masterplan will be launched later this year, with the goal of creating a key infrastructure enabler for Singapore's Smart Nation initiative.

site_title: Asian stocks retreat as copper slips with oil
summary: Asian stocks retreated as copper prices slipped and oil fell, with the MSCI Asia Pacific Index down 0.5% by Tuesday. The yen weakened to a 12 1/2-year low, while Australia's dollar rallied ahead of an interest-rate review. The Shanghai Composite Index jumped 4.7% on Monday, but the Hang Seng Index and Kospi index fell 0.4% and 1.1% respectively. China's central bank is expected to hold interest rates steady, while India is forecast to cut rates amid an uneven global recovery.

site_title: Sophia Road residential property up for sale
summary: A 15-unit freehold residential development at Sophia Road in Singapore is up for public tender with owners seeking offers of more than S$45 million, or S$1,169 per sq ft. The development, known as Fairhaven, has about 16,660 sq ft of land area and is zoned for residential use. The tender closes on July 1, and potential buyers can consider building small apartments to capitalize on its location and limited supply of one-bedroom units.

site_title: Indian central bank makes third 25-basis point rate cut this year
summary: India's central bank cut its policy interest rate by a quarter percentage point to 7.25% for the third time this year, as policymakers aim to stabilize the improving economy. The move was widely expected and aligns with analyst predictions. The rate cut is seen as a response to the country's strong Q1 GDP growth of 7.5%, although some economists question the accuracy of the data.

site_title: Stimulus policies boost China's home sales jump in May
summary: China's housing sales in major cities jumped 37.4% in May from a year earlier, driven by government stimulus policies and developers' efforts to clear inventories. This increase follows a 21.8% rise in April and a 14.7% rise from April. Moody's changed its outlook on the China property sector to stable from negative, citing improved expectations. China cut interest rates for the third time in six months to stimulate the economy. Home prices rose 0.05% in May, with first-tier cities experiencing a 2.2% increase, but remained 1.61% lower than a year ago.

site_title: Australian banks rein in investor property loans
summary: Australian banks have tightened lending standards for investor property loans amid warnings from regulators about a potential housing bubble in Sydney. The four major banks have increased criteria for investor loans, raised deposits to up to 20%, and reduced interest rate discounts. This shift aims to prevent destabilizing the financial system, which has seen home prices surge 40% in three years. The banks are expected to raise A$22-41 billion to boost capital reserves, with regulators warning of "heightened risk" to the financial system.

site_title: GSS Energy expands into energy trading with AFCO tie-up
summary: GSS Energy has entered the energy trading market through a joint venture with AFCO Energy. The partnership will market and distribute mineral oil and crude oil products in Indonesia, leveraging AFCO's expertise in oil storage, trading, and distribution. GSS Energy CEO Sydney Yeung stated that the venture will complement and create synergy with their existing oil production, fueling future growth. The partnership expands GSS Energy's investment in Indonesia's oil energy sector, enhancing shareholder value.

site_title: Australia: Shares fall on weak commodity prices
summary: Australian shares fell sharply on Tuesday as tumbling commodity prices and expectations of a rate cut held investors back. Despite a lower Australian dollar, foreign investors remained cautious, and a bounce in iron ore prices failed to stem losses in resource stocks. The Reserve Bank of Australia is expected to keep interest rates on hold, further weighing on investors. The market's decline was attributed to weak commodity prices and concerns over the central bank's monetary policy.

site_title: Takata will change design for certain air bag inflators
summary: Takata Corp will continue producing air bags with ammonium nitrate propellant, but will change the design of driver-side air bag inflators. The company is working with automakers to transition to newer versions of inflators without ammonium nitrate. Despite concerns over the volatility and safety of ammonium nitrate, Takata claims replacement inflators made by the company are safe when properly engineered and manufactured. The company has linked defective inflators to six deaths and hundreds of injuries since 2003, and plans to replace existing replacement parts with newer designs.

site_title: Japan real wages positive for the first time in 2 yrs
summary: Japan's inflation-adjusted real wages rose 0.1% in April, the first increase in two years, according to government data. This marks a positive trend for the country's labor market, with regular pay increasing 0.6% and total cash earnings rising 0.9%. The rise in wages is seen as a victory for Prime Minister Shinzo Abe's reflationary policies, which aim to boost consumer spending and stimulate economic growth. However, overtime pay remains a concern, falling 2.3% from the previous year.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks open lower
summary: Hong Kong stocks opened lower on Tuesday, falling 0.45% in the first few minutes of trade, despite a positive lead from Wall Street. The Hang Seng Index lost 123.71 points to 27,473.45. This move followed a 5-day rally in Singapore stocks, which are expected to be impacted by GDP data. Meanwhile, US stocks continued to edge towards fresh records, with the S&P 500 and Nasdaq reaching new highs despite tariff uncertainty.

site_title: Aso tight-lipped on fresh yen losses
summary: Japanese Finance Minister Taro Aso declined to comment on the yen's recent decline, despite previous warnings. The dollar reached a 12-1/2-year high of 125 yen, fueled by investors' expectations of US interest rate hikes. The yen's slide has raised concerns about its impact on Japan's export-reliant economy, with some policymakers worried about increased import costs and eroding consumers' purchasing power. Aso reiterated that the government will continue to monitor currency movements closely.

site_title: Sharapova dethroned at French Open
summary: Maria Sharapova was defeated by Lucie Safarova in the French Open semifinals, 7-6 (7-3), 6-4. The loss marks the first time Sharapova won't be playing in the final of the French Open in four years. The win opens up the bottom half of the women's draw, with Serena Williams advancing to the quarterfinals after dropping the first set to Sloane Stephens. Williams is now set to face Sara Errani in the quarterfinals.

images.alt_text: For the first time in four years, Maria Sharapova won't be playing in the final of the French Open tennis tournament.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open 0.17% higher
summary: Tokyo stocks opened 0.17% higher on Tuesday, marking a 12th consecutive day of upward trend, the longest since 1988. The Nikkei 225 index rose 34.80 points to 20,604.67. This follows a positive lead on Wall Street, with the S&P 500 and Nasdaq reaching fresh records despite tariff uncertainty.

site_title: Spackman subsidiary raises US$7m, turns associate
summary: A Spackman Entertainment Group subsidiary, Spackman Media Group, raised US$7 million through a share placement and became an associate, selling six million shares for US$6 million and 999,999 shares for US$999,999. The funds will be used to diversify the group's exposure in the Korean entertainment sector, according to group executive chairman Charles Spackman.

site_title: Australia dollar jumps after RBA omits strong easing bias
summary: The Australian dollar rose over 1% after the Reserve Bank of Australia (RBA) kept interest rates at 2% and did not indicate a clear bias to ease policy, contrary to market expectations. This led to a short squeeze, with the currency reaching a peak of US$0.7693. The RBA cited sub-standard economic growth, a high currency, and tame inflation as reasons for maintaining stimulative policy. The currency's gains are now being tested at US$0.7730, with support found at a seven-week low of around 76 US cents.

site_title: Australia keeps key rate unchanged
summary: Australia's central bank left its key interest rate unchanged at 2% as predicted, citing a weaker currency's relief on companies and anticipation of a US rate hike. This decision comes amid a decade-long mining boom's decline and weak wage growth, leading businesses to cut investment plans for the next 12 months. The central bank relies on the Australian dollar's recent 3.3% drop in May to stimulate the economy.

images.alt_text: Australia left its key interest rate unchanged as a weaker currency relieves competitive pressure on companies and the central bank awaits the impact of two rate cuts in the first half of the year.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks end longest rally since 1988
summary: Tokyo's benchmark Nikkei 225 index ended a 12-day winning streak, losing 0.13% to 20,543.19, marking its longest losing streak since 1988. The broader Topix index also fell 0.26% to 1,674.21. The end of the rally comes after a prolonged period of market gains, with the Nikkei 225 rising 5.6% in the past month. The loss is attributed to a decline in investor sentiment, possibly due to ongoing global economic uncertainty and trade tensions.

site_title: South Korea announces first two MERS deaths
summary: South Korea reported its first two fatalities from Middle East Respiratory Syndrome (MERS) on June 2, 2015. A 58-year-old woman and a 71-year-old man died from the virus, bringing the total infected to 25. The country's health ministry has quarantined or put under special observation 682 people who were exposed to the virus, and Acting Prime Minister Choi Kyung-Hwan vowed to curb the spread of the virus and ease growing public alarm.

site_title: IMF, ECB chiefs join Merkel, Hollande, Juncker for Greek debt talks
summary: IMF Chief Christine Lagarde and ECB President Mario Draghi joined German Chancellor Angela Merkel, French President Francois Hollande, and European Commission Head Jean-Claude Juncker in Berlin for talks on Greece's debt crisis. The aim was to come up with a final proposal to present to Athens, with the group agreeing to work together intensely in the coming days. Greece remains locked in negotiations with creditors to release 7.2 billion euros in remaining bailout funds, with a key deadline of repaying 300 million euros to the IMF on Friday.

site_title: Yellen urged to steer global regulators from too-big-to-fail Tag
summary: US Federal Reserve Chair Janet Yellen and the Investment Company Institute urge global regulators to reconsider designating individual asset managers and investment funds as "too-big-to-fail" due to potential misalignment with risk reduction. The proposal, made by the Financial Stability Board, focuses on size rather than risk. Industry leaders argue it won't effectively reduce systemic risk. Yellen and the ICI will use their FSB role to redirect the proposal, citing its misguided focus. This move aims to avoid unnecessary oversight and protect the financial system from excessive regulation.

site_title: Greece's Tsipras attacks creditors over 'absurd' reforms
summary: Greece's Prime Minister Alexis Tsipras criticized creditors for pushing for "absurd" reforms, which he said have hindered negotiations for a bailout deal. The IMF, ECB, and European Commission are demanding greater reforms in exchange for €7.2 billion in bailout funds. Tsipras' government has made concessions, including privatizations and tax reforms, but insists on raising revenues rather than further austerity. A meeting between European leaders and creditors was held in Berlin, with a proposal to present to Athens. The outcome remains uncertain, with Tsipras warning that Europe is at a crossroads between integration and division.

site_title: Chevron sells NZ petrol station network for US$785m
summary: Chevron is selling its 74 petrol stations in New Zealand to Z Energy Limited for US$785 million, as part of its US$15 billion divestment program. The sale is in response to falling oil prices and is expected to be completed by the end of the year. Chevron's focus remains on its Asia-Pacific operations, where it aims to meet growing energy demand.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open lower
summary: Malaysia's shares opened lower on Tuesday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index down 3.19 points to 1,740.22. The market saw a 150-104 gain-to-lose ratio, indicating a relatively balanced trading day.

site_title: Stocks to watch: Ezra, Hyflux, Spackman, Cache Logistics Trust
summary: Ezra Holdings plans to raise up to US$300 million through a rights issue and convertible bonds to repay debt. Hyflux wins a US$48 million contract to build a desalination plant in Saudi Arabia. Spackman Entertainment Group's subsidiary raises US$7 million through a share placement to invest in entertainment-related businesses. Cache Logistics Trust sells a warehouse to JTC for S$9.7 million to recycle capital and reduce debt. These announcements may affect trading on Tuesday.

site_title: Ezra plans US$300m rights, convertible bonds issues
summary: Ezra Holdings plans to raise up to $300 million through a rights issue and convertible bonds to repay debt and secure long-term growth. The company will issue up to 2.03 billion new shares, with 200 rights shares offered for every 100 existing shares held by eligible shareholders. The funds will mainly go towards redeeming fixed-rate notes. The issue is expected to generate high interest from investors and provide opportunities to broaden the investor base and reduce debt financing costs. The company also plans to explore other financing options, including sale and leaseback transactions.

site_title: Oil holds near US$60 as Saudis back market share before Opec meets
summary: Oil prices remain near US$60 a barrel ahead of the OPEC meeting, as Saudi Arabia's efforts to focus on market share appear to be working. Demand is increasing and supply is slowing, according to Oil Minister Ali al-Naimi. The Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries is expected to maintain a collective quota of 30 million barrels a day. Despite a six-year low, oil prices are stalling amid concerns of a global glut and rising US output. The OPEC meeting is scheduled for June 5.

site_title: UK's Manchester Airport to get £1b upgrade
summary: The owners of Manchester Airport plan to invest £1 billion over 10 years to upgrade the airport, aiming to compete with Heathrow for passengers. The upgrade will help Manchester Airport develop as a global gateway for the UK, following its expansion of long-haul routes. The investment will focus on improving the airport's facilities and services to attract more passengers.

images.alt_text: The owners of Manchester Airport plan to invest £1 billion (US$1.5 billion) over 10 years to upgrade Britain's third largest airport and help it compete harder with Heathrow for passengers.

site_title: Etihad says US carriers want to stifle airline competition
summary: Etihad Airways denies US carriers' allegations of flooding the skies with unfairly subsidized flights, saying the US rivals aim to stifle competition that benefits consumers. The airline claims the US carriers' effort to have the US government discuss the Gulf airlines' finances is disingenuous and aimed at eliminating the US-UAE Air Services Agreement. Etihad asserts its state sponsor, Abu Dhabi, has provided $14.3 billion in allowable shareholder equity and loans since 2003, and the US carriers' claims are based on a lack of evidence.

site_title: Warren Buffett charity lunch already fetching US$1m at auction
summary: Warren Buffett's annual charity auction for Glide, a San Francisco charity, has started with a top bid of over $1 million, surpassing the seventh-highest amount ever paid in 2013. The auction, which began on Sunday, has raised $17.8 million in 15 prior years. This year's winner can bring up to seven friends to dine with Buffett at a Manhattan steakhouse, with the auction set to end on Friday. Buffett's involvement has helped raise funds for the charity, which provides food, healthcare, and rehabilitation services to the poor and homeless.

site_title: Hyflux clinches US$48m contract from Saudi Arabia
summary: Hyflux clinches a US$48 million contract from Saudi Arabia to build a desalination system for the Yanbu Desalination Plant on the Red Sea coast. The containerized system, comprising 10 modular units, will boost the plant's capacity to supply water to Yanbu and Medina. The project is expected to be completed in eight months and contribute to Hyflux's results for the current financial year. The system uses Hyflux's proprietary Kristal ultrafiltration membrane technology for pre-treatment and will increase the plant's capacity to supply water to the region.

site_title: South Korea struggles to contain MERS outbreak; 3 more cases confirmed
summary: South Korea is struggling to contain an outbreak of Middle East Respiratory Syndrome (MERS), with 18 cases confirmed in just over 10 days. The cases are linked to a 68-year-old man who returned from Bahrain via Qatar on May 20. The World Health Organization (WHO) has not recommended screening of passengers or travel restrictions, but South Korea's public health authorities are considering a ban on overseas travel for nearly 700 people isolated for possible infection. The country's Health Ministry is also investigating the cause of death of a 58-year-old woman who had contact with the first patient.

site_title: Google's workforce diversity little changed in past year
summary: Google's workforce diversity remained largely unchanged in the past year, with women making up 30% of its workforce and whites and Asians comprising 91% of the employee base. Blacks and Hispanics make up about 5%. Despite this, Google reported a 1% increase in the number of women in technical jobs, and the company expressed encouragement for the ongoing discussion on workforce diversity. Google's data is the latest from a growing number of tech companies to report on their ethnic and gender makeup, highlighting the industry's predominantly male and white/Asian composition.

site_title: Gold heads for biggest gain in two weeks on easing rate concerns
summary: Gold prices rose 0.9% to $1,200.10 an ounce, the largest gain in two weeks, after signs of slowing US economic growth eased concerns of a Federal Reserve rate hike. US consumer purchases unexpectedly stalled in April, and Fed Bank of Boston President Eric Rosengren stated that growth is too slow to warrant rate increases. This move helped gold prices move higher, as traders seek higher-yielding assets amidst weak economic data.

site_title: HSBC preparing job cuts that may target 20,000 workers
summary: HSBC Holdings, Europe's largest bank, plans to cut 10,000 to 20,000 jobs as part of its cost-cutting strategy. The job-cutting target will exclude the impact of selling businesses in Brazil and Turkey. The bank's CEO, Stuart Gulliver, will disclose the plan to shareholders on June 9. The move is aimed at reducing costs and boosting earnings, amid tough regulations and tax increases in the UK.

images.alt_text: HSBC Holdings, Europe's largest bank, will announce a plan next week to cut thousands of jobs, Sky News reported, citing unidentified people close to the matter.

site_title: Cache Logistics Trust sells warehouse to JTC for S$9.7m
summary: Cache Logistics Trust sold its single-storey warehouse at 4 Penjuru Lane in Jurong industrial estate to JTC Corporation for S$9.7 million. The property was valued at about S$9 million as of Dec 31, 2014, and was the smallest in the Reit's portfolio. The sale proceeds will be used to reduce debt and distribute to unitholders. After the divestment, Cache owns 16 logistics warehouse properties in Singapore, Australia, and China, with a total value of S$1.2 billion and gross floor area of 6.7 million sq ft.

site_title: Global Invacom buys US satellite terminal maker Skyware
summary: Global Invacom Group has acquired US satellite terminal manufacturer Skyware Global for up to $11.6 million. The deal will position Global Invacom as a world leader in satellite communications, with revenue-based earn-out payments up to $5 million. The consideration includes $6.6 million in treasury shares and $5 million in cash, with the earn-out model paying 0.5554 times revenue over $52.3 million between June 1, 2015, and May 31, 2016.

images.alt_text: Satellite equipment specialist Global Invacom Group is buying US satellite terminal manufacturer Skyware Global for up to US$11.6 million, in what the mainboard-listed group said will position it as a world leader in satellite communications.

site_title: BofA to pay almost US$11m over SEC short-sale violations
summary: Bank of America has agreed to pay almost $11 million to the US Securities and Exchange Commission (SEC) to resolve claims that its Merrill Lynch unit used inaccurate data when executing short-sale orders. The brokerage used outdated "easy-to-borrow" lists, violating securities laws. Bank of America admitted wrongdoing and agreed to retain an independent compliance consultant and pay a $9 million penalty, $1.6 million in disgorgement, and $335,000 in prejudgement interest. The firm acknowledged that its systems need to incorporate knowledge of stocks no longer considered easy to borrow.

site_title: National Highway Traffic Safety Administration needs more funding
summary: The National Highway Traffic Safety Administration (NHTSA) is seeking increased funding to address safety risks, citing a 23% budget reduction since 2005. Administrator Mark Rosekind will testify before a congressional subcommittee, highlighting the need for resources to tackle emerging technologies. The agency has saved 39,866 lives with front-seat air bags since 1987, but Rosekind notes that NHTSA's lack of resources poses a known risk, particularly in addressing the Takata air bag recall affecting 34 million vehicles in the US.

site_title: AIG to sell US$2.4b of AerCap stock in public offering
summary: AerCap Holdings NV announced that American International Group Inc plans to sell 50 million shares of the aircraft leasing company in a public offering valued at approximately US$2.4 billion. This represents 51% of AIG's stake in AerCap. The sale is part of AIG's efforts to dispose of assets and repay a bailout, with funds from the sale expected to provide "substantial flexibility for capital deployment over time."

site_title: AngloGold in exclusive talks with Newmont on Colorado mine-sources
summary: Newmont Mining Corp is in exclusive talks with AngloGold Ashanti Ltd to buy its Cripple Creek & Victor gold mine in Colorado for a price likely below $1 billion, sources say. The sale could be finalized soon, with a possible price range of $700 million to $800 million. AngloGold is looking to reduce its $3.1 billion debt pile by at least $1 billion over the next one to three years. The deal could be finalized soon, with other players, including Iamgold, Kinross, and Goldcorp, potentially re-entering the fray if Newmont fails to strike a deal.

site_title: RBI rate cuts lose sway as India bond traders scan rain clouds
summary: The Reserve Bank of India (RBI) is set to review monetary policy, with economists predicting a potential interest rate cut to 7.25% but some warning of a pause. The yield on 10-year sovereign notes has risen four basis points, driven by concerns over India's inflation and weak monsoon. The RBI will consider factors including the "likely strength" of monsoons when making its decision. Despite some predictions of a rate cut, others believe the RBI may hold rates due to resilient oil prices and El Nino conditions.

site_title: Google's solar-fuelled cyber drone crashes at test site
summary: Google's solar-powered drone, Solara 50, crashed at a New Mexico test site on May 1, destroying the prototype. The incident occurred shortly after take-off and no one was injured. The US National Transportation Safety Board is investigating the accident. The drone was part of Google's plan to deliver internet services from the sky.

site_title: China new home prices up in May: survey
summary: China's new home prices increased by 0.5% in May, the first rise in four months, according to a survey by the China Index Academy. The average price rose to 10,569 yuan (S$2,305) per square meter, reversing a four-month decline. The increase is attributed to Beijing's loosening policies to boost the market, which include cutting benchmark interest rates and easing mortgage policies. Despite the rise, the property market remains fragile, with some cities experiencing inventory pressures and tense supply and demand.

site_title: State-owned traders take on established houses
summary: State-owned traders are emerging as a new force in global commodity markets, bypassing traditional oil and grain traders. Azerbaijan's Socar Trading SA acquired Phibro LLC in 2015, while Saudi Arabia, China, Oman, Thailand, and Russia are also building or expanding government-owned firms to procure and market commodities directly. These state traders have deep pockets and ambitions, potentially damaging the business model of established houses. They face challenges in accepting trading losses and acting quickly, but their growth is driven by national interest and control of commodities.

site_title: Making sense of the Middle Income Trap
summary: The Middle Income Trap (MIT) refers to countries that reach a certain per capita income level but struggle to transition to more skill-intensive and sophisticated activities, leading to stagnation. Since 1960, only 13 out of 103 middle-income countries have achieved high-income status. Experts debate the best institutional and policy settings to enable middle-income countries to grow past the "easy" phase of economic growth. Research suggests that countries that have successfully escaped the MIT have developed industrial sectors, invested in human capital, maintained low inequality, and improved institutional quality. A public forum will be held on June 3 to discuss the concept and its implications for middle-income countries.

site_title: Biggest property agencies holding up in cheerless market
summary: Singapore's largest real estate agencies, such as ERA Realty and PropNex, weathered the dismal market better than smaller firms by cutting costs, streamlining operations, and focusing on higher-margin deals. These agencies reported profits of 4-5% and 3.8%, respectively, despite revenue drops. In contrast, smaller agencies, like OrangeTee, recorded net losses, while SLP Realty and SLP Scotia saw a surge in revenue but a significant decline in net profit. The market's commission structure, favoring larger agencies, makes it challenging for smaller firms to remain profitable, with only a few "mega" agencies able to sustain business.

site_title: US: Stocks edge up after recent losses, mixed data
summary: US stocks closed with modest gains on Monday, recovering part of last week's losses. The Dow Jones industrial average rose 0.16%, the S&P 500 gained 0.21%, and the Nasdaq Composite added 0.25%. Economic data showed a rise in manufacturing growth, but construction spending surged while consumer spending remained flat. Investors are weighing data to predict when the Federal Reserve might raise interest rates, with Boston Fed President Eric Rosengren stating the Fed is unlikely to raise rates until evidence of a rebound emerges.

site_title: Mixed views about direction of market in June
summary: The Straits Times Index (STI) lost 2.7% in May, bringing its 2015 performance to 27 points in the black, with many attributing the weakness to a bursting equity bubble in China and Hong Kong, and uncertainty over US interest rate hikes. Despite this, some optimists believe that the market will rebound in June, citing improved liquidity and the potential for a bottom to be near.

site_title: UOB: Now's the right time for bank's digital revamp
summary: UOB is relaunching its online and mobile banking services in July, aiming to compete in the mobile space and leapfrog rivals. The bank is focusing on contactless payments, credit cards, and digital banking, with plans to issue credit cards to mobile users and deliver credit facilities instantly. UOB is also exploring opportunities in the retail market and wealth management, with a new suite of income-building funds and plans to target affluent customers with tailored services. The bank's strategy is to utilize its cost advantages and mature online banking segment to drive growth.

site_title: Sydney in grip of housing bubble, says Treasury
summary: The Australian government's Treasury Secretary, John Fraser, has warned that Sydney is experiencing a housing bubble. In a parliamentary committee testimony, Fraser stated that the housing price bubble is "unequivocally" the case in Sydney, citing casual observation of the data. Despite this, Fraser does not believe the housing bubble poses a major risk to the financial sector.

site_title: Sharing means profit but not without risk
summary: The sharing economy is expected to reach £9 billion in the UK by 2025, with significant growth in sectors such as P2P finance, online staffing, and car sharing. However, this innovative economy also poses new risks, including dependency on trust between parties, privacy issues, and dispute resolution. To address these concerns, the insurance industry is working on solutions to mitigate risks, while businesses are adopting measures to build awareness and engage with market participants. A collaborative approach from all stakeholders is required to ensure the sharing economy prospers.

site_title: The China Circle and its implications for US
summary: The US has yet to respond officially to China's "One Belt, One Road" initiative, also known as the China Circle, which marks a significant shift in China's economic diplomacy. The initiative, launched by Chinese President Xi Jinping in 2013, aims to create a comprehensive network of infrastructure projects across Eurasia and beyond. With nearly 60 countries committed to the project, the US has an opportunity to engage with China in a constructive manner, particularly through the new Silk Road network, which could offer a chance for collaboration and cooperation.

images.alt_text: The China Circle has the potential to be a renminbi circle, allowing China to optimise use of its foreign reserves and accelerate internationalisation of the currency.

site_title: Startup develops premium, Internet-connected e-scooter
summary: A startup in Beijing, led by former CTO Li Yinan, has developed a premium, internet-connected e-scooter called Niu. The scooter features a design similar to the Vespa and is powered by lithium-ion batteries, similar to the Tesla Model S. It will come equipped with remote monitoring and anti-theft location services. The company plans to export the scooter to Europe, aiming to transform the e-scooter from a low-end mode of transportation to a high-tech luxury option.

site_title: Think positive
summary: Wealth experts are focusing on the unwinding of the negative-rate environment and identifying profitable opportunities. US weekly jobless claims fell unexpectedly, while China urges Southeast Asia to support openness amid US tariffs. Chinese property shares surged on unverified reports of a meeting to revive the sector. Reliance Jio, led by Ambani, has delayed its India IPO beyond this year. China also introduced new steps to aid employment amid trade tensions.

site_title: The world's coming broadband divide
summary: The world is experiencing a broadband divide, where some places will be left out of the growing demand for fast internet speeds. The Federal Communications Commission (FCC) has proposed a $1.7 billion program to subsidize broadband services to 12 million US households, highlighting the importance of fast internet in modern life. With more work shifting online and the rise of freelance gigs, people are increasingly dependent on high-speed internet. However, some countries, including Latin America, the Middle East, and Africa, are expected to have slower speeds, potentially leaving them behind in the global economy.

site_title: Top Fifa aide linked to money transfer key to indictment
summary: US authorities believe Fifa Secretary General Jerome Valcke transferred $10 million in 2008 to Jack Warner, a former Fifa vice president, in bribes related to the 2010 World Cup. This is a key element of the indictment accusing Warner of taking a bribe in exchange for helping South Africa secure the right to host the tournament. The alleged involvement of Valcke raises questions about what Fifa President Sepp Blatter knew about the money transfer, despite Blatter's claim that the US timing of the charges is an attempt to undermine his re-election.

site_title: The smart investor's way
summary: A venture capitalist approach is being taken by the Chen Yet-Sen Family Foundation, led by James Chen, to do good. The foundation is focusing on investments and philanthropy. Meanwhile, China urges South-east Asian countries to support openness amid US tariffs, while Chinese property shares surge on unverified reports of a meeting to revive the sector. In the US, weekly jobless claims fell unexpectedly, and Reliance Jio's India IPO has been delayed beyond this year. China has also unveiled new steps to aid employment amid trade tensions.

site_title: M1 offers free services over National Day weekend
summary: M1, a Singaporean telco, is offering free voice calls, SMS, and local mobile data usage to its customers from Aug 7-10, 2015, to commemorate Singapore's 50th National Day. This promotion is similar to Singtel's offering last year. The gesture is part of a growing list of companies celebrating the occasion, including insurance provider Great Eastern, DBS Bank, and SMRT, which have launched various campaigns and offers.

site_title: Digging deep for dividends
summary: A low-profile property trust has made a data centre gambit, raising interest in the sector. US weekly jobless claims fell unexpectedly, and China urged Southeast Asian nations to support openness amid looming US tariffs. Chinese property shares surged on unverified reports of a meeting to revive the sector. Reliance Jio, backed by Ambani, has delayed its India IPO beyond this year. China unveiled new steps to aid employment amid trade tensions, while a Myanmar election was deemed non-priority by Asean, with Malaysia in agreement.

site_title: Saudi Arabia keeps oil output up despite lower prices
summary: Saudi Arabia is increasing its oil production despite lower global prices, focusing on delivering fuel to its growing economy rather than price stabilization. The country's daily production has nearly reached record levels in 1980, with Kuwait and the UAE also drilling at record rates. This shift has reduced the pressure to cut production, as oil prices have stabilized above $60 a barrel. Saudi Arabia's new leadership, led by King Salman, prioritizes domestic consumption growth over price control, with energy subsidies and a focus on refining and petrochemicals driving demand.

site_title: France, Germany voice concerns over EU migrant redistribution plan
summary: France and Germany have expressed concerns over the European Commission's plan to redistribute 40,000 Syrian and Eritrean asylum-seekers throughout the EU, citing efforts already made by member states to help asylum-seekers. The two countries, which would take nearly 40% of the migrants, called for a fair distribution mechanism that takes into account their existing efforts. The EU faces a tough fight on how to share out the migrants amid rising anti-immigration sentiments and economic problems in southern European states.

site_title: Golden Agri's Liberia unit under sustainability fire
summary: Violent protests erupted at Golden Veroleum Liberia's (GVL) plantations in Liberia, sparked by a local group seeking more jobs for the community. The protests were preceded by criticisms of GVL's sustainability efforts, including a letter from the Butaw Youth Association, which accused the company of taking land without community consent. The incident has raised concerns about the company's commitment to sustainability, following recent setbacks, including a suspension by The Forest Trust and a ruling by the Roundtable for Sustainable Palm Oil.

site_title: Tide is turning
summary: Market analysts predict a multi-year trend of European equity outperformance, shifting from the US dominance. The US reported a decrease in weekly jobless claims, while China urged South-east Asian countries to support openness amidst US tariffs. Chinese property shares surged on unverified reports of a meeting to revive the sector. Reliance Jio's India IPO has been delayed beyond this year. China also unveiled new steps to aid employment amid trade tensions, but these moves are seen as insufficient to address the ongoing economic challenges.

site_title: Europe: Shares end steady as oil stocks offset real estate rally
summary: European equities steadied at close on Monday, with real estate and healthcare stocks rising 1.3% and 1% respectively, offsetting a 0.8% drop in energy stocks due to a 1% decline in crude oil prices. The FTSEurofirst 300 index ended 0.06% higher at 1,587.29 points, despite concerns over Greece's debt crisis and a downgrade of Vestas Wind to "sell".

site_title: Thinking out of the white box
summary: Young art collectors in China are finding innovative ways to share their passion for art, marking a shift in the country's art scene. China urges South-east Asia to support openness amid US tariffs looming, while Chinese property shares surge on unverified reports of a meeting to revive the sector. The country also unveils new steps to aid employment amid trade tensions, and US weekly jobless claims fall unexpectedly.

site_title: Indonesia's central bank officials head to the farms to fight inflation
summary: Indonesia's central bank officials, led by head Rosmaya Hadi, are visiting farms to tackle the country's 7.15% inflation rate, the highest in Asia. The effort focuses on improving agricultural yields and reducing supply chain disruptions. Through initiatives like training farmers and providing them with rain shelters and washing machines, the central bank aims to stabilize prices. The project aims to increase food security and support President Joko Widodo's goal of achieving self-sufficiency in key crops by 2018.

site_title: Motorola Mobility's antitrust suit could have broader implications
summary: Motorola Mobility filed a civil antitrust suit against AU Optronics and other companies for their role in a cartel that price-fixed liquid-crystal display screens used in computers and cellphones. The US Supreme Court will decide whether the company's overseas subsidiaries can reap the benefits of America's antitrust laws. A federal appeals court previously ruled that Motorola's overseas subsidiaries are not bound by US antitrust laws, citing the company's global corporate structure and the fact that it repatriated profits from foreign subsidiaries. Motorola is seeking a total award of $3.5 billion, but the defendants claim the amount is exorbitantly inflated.

site_title: Shanghai Tang CEO prudent on China, looks to expand overseas
summary: Shanghai Tang CEO Raphael le Masne de Chermont remains cautious about expanding his brand in China due to the country's economic slowdown. Despite suffering less than other luxury brands, he is not planning to open new stores on the mainland. Instead, he is focusing on expanding to Asia, Europe, and the US, where 50% of his customers currently reside. De Chermont believes Shanghai Tang's niche and premium positioning will help it thrive in the changing Chinese luxury market, where consumers are seeking more discreet and affordable brands.

site_title: New StanChart boss faces cash call, dividend squeeze
summary: Standard Chartered's new CEO Bill Winters is expected to raise capital and cut the bank's dividend later this year, potentially forced by a tough stress test of its Asian loans. Investors and analysts estimate the bank needs $5-10 billion to boost its capital strength, with some suggesting a $5 billion raise. Winters may opt for a quicker share sale or cost cuts to avoid a lengthy and complex rights issue, but analysts warn that failure to act could crimp strategic choices for two years and strain profits.

site_title: Fast credit may be seismic faultline for China's economy
summary: Morgan Stanley MD Ruchir Sharma predicts China's economy will slow down due to an explosion of credit and debt since 2009, a phenomenon historically linked to financial crises. China's credit to GDP ratio has soared from 140% in 2010 to over 200% now, exceeding three standard deviations above the norm. Sharma estimates China's growth will slow to 4-5% by 2018, impacting other emerging markets and global growth. He warns of a potential global recession made in China, which could also affect commodity prices, particularly oil, and notes that South-east Asia, particularly the Philippines and Indonesia, are relatively less exposed to the risks.

site_title: Look East
summary: Asia's credit investors continue to favor bonds, despite global economic uncertainty. China urges Southeast Asian nations to support openness amid US tariffs, while China also unveils new measures to aid employment. Chinese property shares surge on unverified reports of a meeting to revive the sector. Reliance Jio, led by Mukesh Ambani, delays its India IPO beyond this year. US weekly jobless claims unexpectedly fall, offering a glimmer of hope for the US economy.

site_title: Wealth and the family office
summary: Veteran fund manager Stephen Diggle emphasizes that becoming wealthy is not the primary goal for him. He is featured in a Wealth and the Family Office article, likely discussing his approach to wealth management and family offices.

site_title: Anger at paucity of prosecutions of bankers responsible for misdeeds
summary: UK MPs, British press, and consumer associations are frustrated over the lack of prosecutions of bankers responsible for estimated $235 billion in misdeeds over seven years. Despite heavy penalties, directors receive fat bonuses for presiding over misconduct, and CEOs or senior figures have not resigned. Experts and regulators, including Lord Mayor of the City of London, argue that bankers need to behave properly and be disciplined and punished for wrongdoing. However, prosecutors face challenges in connecting wrongdoing, and few bankers have been jailed for their part in the 2008 financial collapse.

site_title: Greenback steady despite weak US GDP data
summary: The US dollar remained steady despite a contraction in the US economy, with the greenback buying 124.08 yen in Tokyo afternoon trading. Investors await US jobs data for clues about the economy, while a weak euro and Greece's debt crisis dominated markets. The euro weakened to US$1.0960 and 135.94 yen, and Greece faces a debt repayment deadline on June 5.

site_title: Nostalgic Russians spur demand for Stalinist art
summary: Demand for Stalinist art, a style promoted by Joseph Stalin in the 1930s, has surged in Russia, driven by a resurgence of patriotism and nostalgia. Sales at London auctions have reached a 7-year high, with some works selling for tens of millions of dollars. Transport tycoon Andrey Filatov has amassed a collection worth $500 million, and prices for Soviet paintings can now produce a "ten-fold" return. Experts predict the market will continue to grow, with rare pieces from the Stalinist era selling for record-breaking prices, including a Georgy Nissky painting that broke a post-war Soviet art record.

site_title: Messaging app LINE lures Singapore firms
summary: LINE, a messaging app, is targeting Singaporean businesses, particularly small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs), with its affordable business offerings for marketing, advertising, e-commerce, sales, and branding. The app has seen success in Japan, with 100,000 LINE@ accounts opened in the first month. LINE aims to expand its services to help Singaporean companies tap into its platform, leveraging its global user base and innovative features.

site_title: Euro area shocks less pronounced than in Japan's case
summary: The euro area's economic growth has underperformed Japan's over the past seven years, despite having less severe shocks. However, specific factors unique to the euro area pose greater challenges, including constrained fiscal policy, coordination difficulties between fiscal and monetary policies, and the impact of rising debt and cross-border liabilities. The euro area's aging population also presents a moderate challenge compared to Japan. The region's ability to return to a sustainable growth path is uncertain, and the question is whether it can catch up with Japan's performance.

site_title: BOJ faces decision over property trusts
summary: The Bank of Japan is considering whether to continue its purchases of shares in real estate investment trusts (Reits), which have helped revive Japan's moribund property industry. The central bank's purchases, which began in 2010, have doubled the value of the Tokyo Stock Exchange Reit Index and driven up land prices in major cities. As the BOJ runs out of securities to buy, analysts expect the central bank to consider buying J-Reits with lower credit ratings or maintaining its current pace of purchases.

site_title: China PMIs remain subdued, suggest more easing to come
summary: China's official Purchasing Managers Index (PMI) edged up to 50.2 in May, while HSBC and Markit data showed 49.2. Despite recent monetary support, the PMIs remain subdued, suggesting more policy easing is expected. Analysts predict the central bank will cut banks' reserve requirement ratio by another 50 basis points to support China's slowest economic growth in 25 years. The government's growth target of 7% for this year may not be reached due to overcapacity, low inflation, and lagging demand.

site_title: Macau's casino revenue falls for 12th straight month
summary: Macau's casino revenue fell 37.1% in May, marking the 12th consecutive month of decline, due to China's anti-graft efforts and a slowing economy. The city's economy also suffered, with a 24.5% contraction in the first quarter. Casino analysts have cut their forecasts for Macau's gambling revenue, expecting a 21% slump this year, and warn that new casino openings may not stimulate demand by year's end. The decline has wiped out over US$24 billion in market value from Macau's six operators.

site_title: Oil hit by strong dollar, jitters over supply glut
summary: Oil prices fell to one-month lows due to a strong dollar and concerns over a global supply glut. London Brent oil dropped to a six-week low and US crude to a four-week trough. The Organization of the Petroleum Exporting Countries (Opec) meets on June 5, with market expectations that it will maintain its output levels. The US Department of Energy reported a decline in crude oil and petrol reserves, but also a rise in output, which could exacerbate the global oversupply.

site_title: Consumer spending flat, inflation pressures muted
summary: US consumer spending was flat in April, with households cutting back on purchases and boosting savings, indicating a struggling economy. Inflation pressures were muted, with a price index for consumer spending recording its smallest gain since late 2009. The data suggests the Federal Reserve may not raise interest rates before the end of the year. The economy is slowly rebounding from a first-quarter slump, with output held down by temporary factors.

site_title: The tentative American economy
summary: The American economy continues to experience a "tentative" growth, with job creation being a positive aspect but other aspects, such as business investment and consumer spending, being less impressive. The economy's slow recovery is attributed to the aftermath of the 2008-09 financial crisis, which changed economic psychology and led to increased saving and hoarding. Companies are adopting flexible pricing strategies, resulting in reduced job security for workers. The economic recovery remains uncertain, with forecasts of stronger growth repeatedly being disappointed.

site_title: In a changing Brooklyn, shop owners decide to call it quits
summary: Brooklyn shop owners, John and Richard Zawisny, are selling their 35-year-old Polish sausage and craft-beer emporium, Eagle Provisions, due to rising rents and changing neighborhood dynamics. The Zawisnys, who own their building, are not cashing out but are instead bowing to pressure from younger customers and new developments. Similar mom-and-pop businesses in Manhattan and Brooklyn have shut down or sold in recent years, citing hypergentrification and unaffordable rents. The owners are looking forward to retirement and spending time with their family, as the city continues to evolve and lose its unique character.

site_title: Editor's note
summary: Wealth can be a blessing or a curse, and ensuring it benefits future generations is a challenge. The article discusses various global economic and financial issues, including a low-profile property trust's data centre gambit, US weekly jobless claims, and Chinese property shares surging on unverified reports of a meeting to revive the sector.
