site_title: Modi govt's 'vision thing' proves to be a challenge for his aides
summary: The Modi government's efforts to balance pro-business and pro-poor policies have led to communication struggles, affecting both groups in India. Finance Minister Arun Jaitley's statement on tax demands on foreign funds sparked a stock sell-off, wiping $10 billion off investor wealth. The incident highlights the administration's challenge in articulating a clear vision, which is crucial for capitalizing on renewed optimism since Modi's election win. This misstep may have long-term implications for investor confidence and the economy.

site_title: Eurozone relief from deflation offset by unsolved Greece crisis
summary: The European Central Bank (ECB) can take comfort in a rising inflation rate in the eurozone, forecast to be 0.2% in May, marking the first price increase in six months. However, Greece's debt crisis remains unresolved, with the country set to make four payments totaling 1.6 billion euros to the IMF this month. ECB policymakers will gather to assess emergency liquidity requests and restrict conditions for Greek banks, as talks between Greece and its creditors missed another deadline. The ECB's quantitative easing program remains dependent on its full implementation.

site_title: UN climate deal in Paris may be graveyard for 2 degree goal
summary: The UN's Paris climate conference may fail to meet its goal of limiting global warming to 2 degrees Celsius above pre-industrial levels, despite efforts by governments to reduce greenhouse gas emissions. Despite record-high emissions, some officials believe new mechanisms and technologies could hit the 2C mark, but experts say it's unlikely and that the goal is becoming increasingly unfeasible. The 2C cap has been a driving force for climate negotiators, but its feasibility is being questioned, and some countries are advocating for even more ambitious targets, such as 1.5C.

site_title: Eurozone banks adapt to their new demanding and hands-on supervisor
summary: The European Central Bank (ECB) is intensifying its supervision of eurozone banks, demanding more data and frequent on-site visits. The ECB's balance-sheet assessment has led to a year-long review, and now a more in-depth look at banks' businesses, resulting in thousands of data points and frequent requests. Banks are working overtime to comply, with some hiring more staff and others working late into the night. The ECB aims to keep the burden on banks low, but critics argue the system is cumbersome and decisions can take time, potentially hindering crisis management.

site_title: Developers look to top-floor attractions to maximize revenues
summary: Developers in New York City are capitalizing on the popularity of rooftop attractions by offering unique views and dining experiences. The Empire State Building's deck raked in $82.5 million last year, and other properties are following suit with rooftop bars, restaurants, and observatories. However, real estate experts warn that the market may be nearing a "view glut" with the addition of new observatories, including the One World Trade Center's 102nd-floor observation deck. Despite this, rooftop spaces remain popular, with many developers citing the unique views and increased foot traffic as reasons to invest.

site_title: Three US spy programmes expire amid Senate stand-off over extension
summary: Three US spy programmes aimed at stopping terrorists expired early on Monday, amid a Senate stand-off over legislation to renew them. The programmes, which allowed for monitoring communications and seizing records for counter-terrorism investigations, expired due to procedural obstacles raised by Senator Rand Paul, who says the bill doesn't do enough to limit spying. The Senate is expected to vote on the USA Freedom Act by Wednesday, which would limit government spying and require investigators to get a court warrant to obtain individual phone records. The programmes' expiration has raised tensions among lawmakers and exposed rifts in the Republican Party over national security policy.

site_title: M1 offers customers free services on National Day weekend
summary: M1, a Singaporean telco, is offering free voice calls, SMS, and local mobile data usage to its customers from Aug 7 to 10, 2015, to commemorate Singapore's 50th birthday. Both post-paid and pre-paid customers will automatically receive the offer. M1's chief marketing officer said the company aims to allow customers to freely share their wishes for the nation.

site_title: The US needs a coherent security strategy, especially in light of ISIS
summary: US President Barack Obama's foreign policy has faced criticism for its perceived ineffectiveness in addressing global threats, particularly from ISIS. The recent losses of Ramadi and Palmyra to the Islamic State have raised concerns about US control in the region. Critics blame Obama for failing to anticipate and counter ISIS, while others argue that his strategy of retrenching abroad has led to a lack of guiding assumptions. Obama's administration has been accused of muddling through international crises with grandiose rhetoric and a lack of strategic thinking, but some argue that his caution is necessary given budgetary constraints.

site_title: New venture for the founder of Men's Wearhouse
summary: George Zimmer, the founder of Men's Wearhouse, has launched a new company, zTailors, which connects customers with on-demand tailors for in-home alterations. The app and website allow customers to schedule a tailor to measure and refit garments for a set price, with altered items returned in a few days. Zimmer aims to double the income of tailors, who currently make around $38,000 a year, and has already partnered with 600 tailors. The company takes a 35% fee from each purchase, with plans to expand to all 50 states by the end of the year.

images.alt_text: Zimmer, whose net worth has been estimated to be US$150 million to US$800 million, is the chairman and the financial force behind zTailors.

site_title: NSA lends a hand in new privacy app
summary: The National Security Agency (NSA) has developed a secure communication app called Scrambl3, which creates a "dark Internet tunnel" to thwart snooping on voice calls and messages. The app uses a technology from the NSA's "Fishbowl" project and adds an extra layer of encryption, making it difficult for the NSA to access. The app is designed to provide private and secure mobile communications, and USMobile plans to offer it for Android devices at a monthly fee of around $10. The app does not store voice mails or messages on its servers and cannot be sold to countries with a history of terrorist activity.

site_title: US factory activity growth slows slightly in May: Markit
summary: US factory activity growth slowed slightly in May, with a deceleration in new orders offsetting an improvement in employment, according to Markit. The manufacturing sector's Purchasing Managers' Index rose to 54.0, a slight increase from April. The new order component fell to 54.3, its lowest since January 2014, while employment rose to its highest level since November. The strong dollar is hurting the economy, and the extent of the second quarter recovery remains uncertain.

summary: Singapore entrepreneurs face challenges in growing their businesses, prompting a need to explore alternative financing options. Banks are cautious due to a surge in non-performing loans, which have reached 982.5 billion yuan, and rising bad loans, making them hesitant to package higher-quality assets into debt securities. Policymakers have expanded the securitization quota to free up space for lending, but the market still faces challenges, including low yields and liquidity issues.

VW's goal is to more than double US sales to 800,000 vehicles by 2018 and become the world's largest carmaker by overtaking Toyota.

site_title: US: Stocks open higher as Intel buys Altera for US$16.7b

The new indices will compete with major indices such as Frankfurt's DAX, Madrid's IBEX, and Milan's FTSE Mib.

This follows a surge in Opec supply in May, which reached its highest in over two years.

site_title: US manufacturing growth accelerates in May as employment rebounds: ISM
summary: US manufacturing growth accelerated in May, rebounding from its slowest pace in almost two years, according to the Institute for Supply Management. The index of national factory activity rose to 52.8, exceeding expectations, and marked the 30th consecutive month of expansion. Employment rebounded, rising to 51.7, while new orders and prices paid indices also improved, with the new orders index reaching its best month since December. This rebound is a positive sign for the US economy.

site_title: Breaking hearts, breaking chains: Paris removes 'love locks'

The city official Bruno Julliard stated that nearly one million padlocks will be removed, weighing 45 tonnes. The trend, which originated in 2008, has spread globally, with similar locks found in European capitals and other cities. Authorities had previously warned of the dangers, but tourists continued to attach locks, prompting the city to take drastic measures to restore its iconic bridges.

site_title: BNP fined US$1.4m in Hong Kong for unreported cross trades

The firm failed to provide sufficient resources to dealers, leading to "particularly serious" failures over an extended period. BNP stated it strengthened internal controls to prevent similar issues in the future and seeks to maintain regulatory compliance.

site_title: India's April infrastructure output shrinks 0.4% yr-on-yr: government
summary: India's infrastructure output declined 0.4% year-over-year in April, its second consecutive contraction, due to lower production of electricity, crude oil, and cement. The decline is attributed to a decline in production of key infrastructure components, suggesting a slowdown in India's economic growth.

site_title: OCBC takes big stake in micro-loan market
summary: OCBC Bank has taken a significant market share in the micro-loan market in Singapore, with over 50% market share under the government-backed Micro Loan Programme. OCBC sees double-digit growth in this segment and aims to provide financing to companies with varying levels of maturity, including those as young as six months. The bank's long history in the business segment and risk-sharing approach with the government enable it to assess the viability of new businesses.

site_title: EU watchdog warns of QE pressure on insurers
summary: The European Insurance and Occupational Pensions Authority (EIOPA) warns that the European Central Bank's quantitative easing program is putting additional pressure on insurance companies and pension funds due to low interest rates. The program has lowered the 'risk-free rate,' increasing the value of future liabilities and cutting the value of assets on insurers' and pension funds' books. This may lead to a negative impact on solvency, with smaller players at risk of financial strain, while larger companies like Allianz and Axa are seen as more resilient.

site_title: South Korea fights to contain MERS outbreak, considers tough measures
summary: South Korea is struggling to contain an outbreak of Middle East Respiratory Syndrome (MERS), with 18 cases reported in over 10 days, including three new cases on Monday. Authorities are considering a ban on overseas travel for nearly 700 people isolated for possible infection. The cases are linked to a 68-year-old man who returned from Bahrain, and the World Health Organization has not recommended screening of passengers or travel restrictions. The government is under pressure to find the reason for the high rate of transmission, with the President calling for a thorough investigation.

site_title: EU urges Fifa to reform after corruption scandal
summary: The European Union has urged FIFA to reform quickly amid a corruption scandal, citing the sport's integrity as at stake. Millions of fans worldwide have lost patience and deserve better, she added, while declining to comment on Sepp Blatter's re-election as FIFA head.

summary: Hong Kong-based investment bank Reorient Group Ltd. saw its shares surge 152% after a private-equity fund backed by e-commerce billionaire Jack Ma agreed to invest in the company. site_title: China central bank provides pledged supplementary lending to select banks: sources
summary: China's central bank provided Pledged Supplementary Lending (PSL) to select banks at 3.10% to support longer-term investment amid a slowing economy. Analysts say much of China's new lending is still dominated by short-term loans, implying credit is being used for speculation or to roll over existing debt, rather than funding fresh investment. The central bank has not commented on the matter.

site_title: Hermes Birkin Handbag sells for record US$223,000 in Hong Kong

site_title: Opec seen holding oil output to defend market share

Opec members, led by Saudi Arabia, are resisting calls to cut output to support prices, which could weigh on demand and economic growth. The cartel's decision is seen as a tactical move to boost demand and hurt non-Opec producers.

site_title: Eurozone factory growth stumbles as core struggles: PMI

summary: China's Financial Futures Exchange has denied rumors that Goldman Sachs and other foreign investors are shorting China's stock market using index futures. This comes amid concerns over two weeks of panic selling in China's stock market, which saw main indexes drop over 20%.

site_title: Swiss industry shows signs of recovery in May, order books expand
summary: Switzerland's manufacturing sector showed signs of recovery in May, with the Swiss Purchasing Manager's Index (PMI) rising to 49.4 points, above the contraction threshold of 50.0. This follows the removal of the Swiss franc cap by the Swiss National Bank in January, which exposed the export-reliant economy to a surge in the franc. Order books expanded for the first time since the cap's removal, with the subindex for employment falling to 40.7 points, its lowest since the financial crisis. The recovery suggests the economy may hold up better than expected despite a strong franc.

site_title: French manufacturing better but still shrinking in May: PMI
summary: French manufacturing sector showed improvement in May with a rise in new export orders to 50.5, its highest in a year. The Purchasing Managers Index rose to 49.4, above the 48.0 mark in April, but still below the 50-point threshold for expansion. The sector remains in recession, with output falling throughout the past year. Job cuts were made as manufacturers scaled back staffing levels.

site_title: Euro seen remaining 'undervalued' by Standard Life on ECB policy
summary: The euro is seen as undervalued by Standard Life, with a 9.8% drop against the dollar this year, according to investment director Ken Dickson. The European Central Bank (ECB) would prefer the euro to trade below fair value for some time, and Dickson expects it to remain undervalued. The ECB's stimulus measures and the Federal Reserve's policy contrast are contributing factors. Dickson estimates fair value to be around $1.24, and believes the dollar still has further to rise. The euro currently trades at $1.0918.

site_title: Affordable luxury
summary: Luxury watch brands are shifting their focus from exclusivity and high prices to making high-quality timepieces more accessible to a wider audience. This change is attributed to the 2007 global recession and China's anti-corruption drive, which have led to a purge of excesses in the industry. As a result, luxury watch brands are now turning to more affordable pricing strategies to attract customers.

site_title: Hong Kong: Shares rise, but gains far smaller than in China
summary: Hong Kong stocks rose 0.6% on Monday, following a surge in Chinese shares that jumped nearly 5% due to market-friendly commentary and positive PMI data. However, gains were capped by Friday's US market slump after disappointing economic data. Most Hong Kong sectors were firmer, with industrial and materials stocks leading, while consumer services shares lost 0.8%. Shares in Huatai Securities Co Ltd rose 5% on its Hong Kong debut, driven by expectations of continued growth in China's stock markets.

site_title: UK manufacturing index edges off seven-month low: PMI
summary: The UK manufacturing index rose to 52.0 in May, edging off a seven-month low in April, but weak exports and strong domestic demand offset the increase. Hiring slowed to its lowest in over two years, casting doubt on a broad rebound in UK economic growth. The sector is hit by a combination of a strong pound and weak business investment, with factory output rising just 0.1% in the first three months of 2015. This news contrasts with other sectors of the economy experiencing growth, and raises concerns about the UK economy's trajectory.

site_title: New StanChart boss faces cash call, dividend squeeze
summary: Standard Chartered's new CEO, Bill Winters, is expected to raise capital and cut the bank's dividend later this year to address its Asian loan exposure and capital strength issues. The bank needs to raise $5.25 billion to meet the 12-13% common equity tier 1 ratio expected by shareholders. A stress test by the Prudential Regulation Authority could force Winters to act, potentially limiting his strategic choices for at least two years. Analysts estimate the bank needs between $5 billion and $10 billion in capital to strengthen its balance sheet.

images.alt_text: Standard Chartered's incoming Chief Executive Bill Winters is expected to raise capital and cut the bank's dividend later this year, potentially forced to act by a tough stress test of its Asian loans, investors and analysts said.

site_title: Indonesia's central bank relaxes forex rules to bolster domestic market
summary: Indonesia's central bank, Bank Indonesia, relaxed foreign exchange regulations to bolster its domestic market. The changes include a reduction in the frequency of monitoring net foreign exchange exposure and the removal of a minimum period for foreign investors to hedge against volatility. The bank also expanded its definition of derivatives to include cross currency swaps, requiring banks to have at least 1 trillion rupiah in capital. The moves aim to deepen the foreign exchange market and mitigate risks associated with the country's growing foreign currency debt.

site_title: Alibaba Group in talks to buy stake in India's Paytm: sources
summary: Alibaba Group's financial arm Ant Financial is in advanced talks to invest around $600 million in Indian online payment platform Paytm, potentially increasing its stake to 40%. This deal would mark a significant investment by Alibaba in the Indian market. Ant Financial already holds a 25% stake in Paytm's parent company, and the new deal would further solidify Alibaba's presence in the Indian e-commerce and online payments sector.

site_title: Schaeuble says Greek 'no' vote would not mean Grexit: German lawmaker
summary: German Finance Minister Wolfgang Schaeuble stated that a 'no' vote in Greece's bailout package referendum on Sunday would not result in Greece leaving the eurozone. This contradicts previous concerns about a potential "Grexit." Schaeuble's comments were made during a meeting with lawmakers, who reported his statement as accurate.

site_title: Quick takes: Private home prices in Singapore seen easing by 4-6% in 2015
summary: Singapore's private residential prices slid 0.9% in the second quarter, marking a seventh consecutive quarter of decline. Experts predict a 4-6% overall decline in 2015, with prices easing in the Core Central Region and Rest of Central Region, but potentially worsening in the Outside Central Region. Developers are expected to take a restrained stance on new launches, and buyers are adopting a wait-and-see attitude due to the substantial supply of unsold units.

images.alt_text: Angela Tan

site_title: German manufacturing sector growth slows to three-month low
summary: Germany's manufacturing sector growth slowed to a three-month low in May, with the Markit purchasing managers index dropping to 51.1 from 52.1 in April. This is the slowest pace of growth since February, suggesting the sector is losing momentum. Companies continued to hire new staff but at a more modest pace, while backlogs rose, indicating ongoing pressure on capacity. The weak euro and raw material shortages also pushed input prices to a 37-month high, hinting at inflationary pressures.

site_title: Mutual funds buy more Singapore stocks
summary: Global mutual funds increased their net purchases of Singapore stocks to S$1.3 billion in the three months to June 24, with S$212.7 million in Reits. The top buys were Capitaland Mall Trust and top sells were Suntec Real Estate Investment Trust. This trend suggests fund managers are focusing on Singapore's property market, which may be driven by dollar asset diversification. The data is based on ShareInvestor and Ipreo, but alternative investors and institutional money managers may also be trading without disclosure.

site_title: Buying retreats as sellers step in
summary: Singapore's stock market saw a rebound in buying activity and a decline in selling activity in the fourth week of June. Buyers outweighed sellers with 18 companies recording 29 purchases worth S$1.86 million, while four firms made 7 disposals worth S$0.83 million. Several significant buyback and director trades were reported, including Keong Hong Holdings' first buyback since October 2014, and directors' purchases in Mencast Holdings, Japfa Ltd, CEI Contract Manufacturing, and Oxley Holdings. Conversely, directors sold shares in Saizen Reit, Riverstone Holdings, and ComfortDelGro Corporation. BlackRock Inc reported a purchase-related filing, boosting its deemed stake to 128.764 million shares or 6 per cent.

site_title: US investigating terror attacks for evidence of links
summary: US and UK authorities are investigating potential links between terror attacks in France, Kuwait, Tunisia, and Somalia, with Islamic State militants possibly using online communications to inspire attacks outside their territory. Islamic State's spokesman urged Muslims to "embark and hasten toward jihad" in an audio message. Authorities are analyzing intercepted communications and data to determine if there's coordination among the attacks, with no clear evidence found so far.

site_title: Microsoft readies windows 10 for next month in PC, tablet push
summary: Microsoft is preparing to release Windows 10 on July 29, aiming to boost the ailing PC market and revive its mobile device fortunes. The operating system will be available as a free upgrade for Windows 7 and 8.1 users, or on new devices. Windows 10 will feature a blended design, Microsoft Edge browser, Cortana voice assistant, and touch-enabled Office applications. Despite optimism, market research firm IDC predicts a 6.2% drop in PC shipments this year due to a corporate purchasing cycle. Microsoft expects a billion users in the first two to three years.

site_title: Australian city home prices jump anew in June: RPData
summary: Australian home prices surged 2.1% in June, with Sydney leading the way with a 16.2% annual growth, followed by Melbourne with a 9.8% increase. This marks a rebound from May's decline, fueling concerns of a housing bubble. The Reserve Bank of Australia is cautious, as speculation in housing investment could lead to a price slump. Regulators have tightened lending standards, and banks are slowing mortgage growth, amid a backdrop of strong economic conditions and migration in New South Wales and Victoria.

site_title: PM Lee takes the stand at hearing to assess damages payable by Roy Ngerng for defamation
summary: Singapore Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong took the stand at a three-day hearing to assess damages payable by blogger Roy Ngerng for defamation, stemming from Ngerng's claim that Lee misappropriated Central Provident Fund savings. Justice Lee Seiu Kin previously ruled Ngerng defamed Lee. The hearing aims to determine the amount of damages Ngerng must pay.

site_title: Brokers' take
summary: UOB and Cache Logistics Trust are analyzed by DBS Group Research and Maybank Kim Eng, respectively. UOB is recommended to hold due to its conservative growth and regionalization efforts, despite a potential lack of fee income differentiation and a stronger Singapore-centric focus. Cache Logistics Trust is recommended to buy due to its active debt management and favorable tenant-expiry profile, with a target price of S$1.37. Both companies face challenges in the short term, with UOB's loan growth and credit costs expected to remain higher than peers, and Cache's revenue exposure to the multi-tenanted market.

site_title: Prices of completed non-landed private homes slip 0.6% in May
summary: Prices of completed non-landed private homes in Singapore decreased 0.6% in May, according to the National University of Singapore's Residential Price Index. The largest drop was among shoebox units, which fell 1.3%. Excluding small units, non-landed private homes in the central region declined 1%. Only 15 of the 430 homes transacted in May were shoebox units.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares end higher
summary: Malaysia's Kuala Lumpur Composite Index closed higher at 1,731.68, with a 4.82-point gain. The index saw 1.79 billion lots traded, valued at RM1.89 billion. Gainers outnumbered losers 443 to 353. This follows a global stocks rally, despite US-EU trade talks and uncertainty.

site_title: Qatar Petroleum sets sights on overseas expansion
summary: Qatar Petroleum, the world's largest liquefied natural gas producer, plans to expand overseas after a restructuring. The company, led by CEO Saad Sherida al-Kaabi, aims to focus on upstream energy production and manage Qatar's oil output slump. Qatar aims to avoid depleting its oil and gas deposits by limiting opportunities for foreign companies. The restructuring includes the takeover of Qatar Petroleum International and the firing of some workers, as well as stricter conditions for foreign partners. QP will prioritize international expansion over downstream activities.

site_title: More than star power needed to revive old franchise
summary: Arnold Schwarzenegger's return in the fifth Terminator film, Terminator Genisys, is crucial to reviving the franchise. The movie's time-travel plot, which includes multiple timelines, is confusing and gimmicky. Despite impressive special effects, the 31-year-old franchise starts to show its age. Director Alan Taylor's attempt to reboot the series falls short, with Schwarzenegger's stiff acting being the only redeeming quality. The film's reliance on alternate timelines and over-reliance on action sequences make it feel like a cosmetic makeover rather than a fresh upgrade.

site_title: Noble continues share buyback
summary: NOBLE Group announced it has purchased 14 million of its own shares at S$0.69445 apiece, totaling S$9.75 million, as part of its share buyback program. The firm now holds 119.71 million shares, equivalent to 1.78% of equity. This is the sixth share buyback transaction in June 2015, following a purchase of 3 million shares on Monday at S$0.69529 apiece. Yu Xubo (Patrick) has been appointed as a non-executive director, replacing Li Rongrong.

images.alt_text: Mindy Tan

site_title: The unassuming leader
summary: Towers Watson CEO John Haley has led the human resource and risk management firm to a 75-fold increase in market value since 1998, driven by historic mergers and acquisitions. The firm's market value more than doubled after the 2012 acquisition of Extend Health, but plummeted before that due to a significant expenditure on the acquisition. Today, the exchange solutions segment is its main growth driver. With 100 offices across 38 countries, Towers Watson manages companies' human resources and provides investment consulting services.

site_title: Alibaba sells US e-commerce website 11Main to rival OpenSky
summary: Alibaba Group Holding Ltd will sell its US e-commerce website 11 Main to rival online marketplace OpenSky, with Alibaba holding a "significant" stake in the combined entity. The deal aims to help over 50,000 brands, marking a shift in Alibaba's strategy towards niche e-commerce. This move highlights the challenges of cracking the US e-commerce market, dominated by Amazon.com Inc and eBay Inc.

site_title: Foreign policy success could be high point of Obama's legacy
summary: US President Barack Obama's second term may be defined by his foreign policy success, particularly with a historic nuclear deal with Iran and passage of trade agreements like the Trans-Pacific Partnership (TPP) and Transatlantic Trade and Investment Partnership (TTIP). The Iran deal, set to expire on June 30, has the potential to transform the Middle East geopolitics and enhance global nuclear security. The TPP and TTIP could cement US influence in Asia-Pacific and Europe, respectively, and become a key part of his presidential legacy.

site_title: Greece and the moral hazard dilemma
summary: Greece's potential departure from the eurozone has sparked extreme worry, despite being a possibility for years. Markets are inefficient due to moral hazard, a situation where one party takes on risk knowing they'll be protected, and another will incur the cost. This is exemplified by Greece's repeated bailouts and extensions, which removed financial risk and distorted price discovery. The European Central Bank's refusal to increase emergency lending to Greece has snapped back the "elastic band" of monetary policy, making risk a factor to be reckoned with.

images.alt_text: So Greece might very well default on its payments, reject its creditors' demands, declare itself bankrupt and exit the eurozone.

site_title: Qingjian Realty launches one-stop services portal for its homeowners
summary: Qingjian Realty launched HiLife, a mobile app providing one-stop services for its homeowners, including booking facilities, yoga classes, and home services. The app is available to residents of Riversound Residence, the first to use it. This marks Qingjian as the first developer in Singapore to extend its relationship with homeowners beyond sales transactions. HiLife is a key project by Qingjian's wholly owned subsidiary, HiLife Interactive, established in April 2015.

images.alt_text: Fiona Lam

site_title: Brokers' take
summary: Singapore stocks notched a 5-day rally ahead of GDP data, with the STI up 0.4% on Thursday. Investors remained positive despite tariff uncertainty and split views on the Fed's next move. The rally was also influenced by a mandatory offer for the rest of PSC by Popiah king Sam Goi at S$0.40 a share. Meanwhile, eSIM platform Airalo raised US$220 million in new funding, lifting its valuation past US$1 billion, and US stocks edged to fresh records despite tariff concerns.

site_title: Women joining company boards but few chair them: Deloitte Global survey
summary: Women now hold 12% of boardroom seats worldwide, but only 4% are chairing boards, according to Deloitte Global's survey. In Singapore, 9% of board seats are held by women, with 7% being female chairmen. The energy & resources industry has the highest percentage of women on boards, with 14%. European countries lead in gender diversity, with Norway at 36.7%, while the Asia-Pacific and Americas have made the least progress, with 4% of board chairs. Deloitte attributes the gap to traditional barriers and insufficient family support.

images.alt_text: Mindy Tan

site_title: Medical tourism expertise helps Thailand cope with Mers
summary: Thailand's medical tourism industry may be helping contain the spread of Middle East Respiratory Syndrome (Mers), after confirming its first case of the virus. The 75-year-old man from Oman, who had traveled to Bangkok for treatment, was the first reported case in Thailand. With an average of 1.4 million medical tourists annually, Thailand's healthcare system may be more equipped to handle infectious diseases. The country's tourism sector, which accounts for 10% of the economy, could play a crucial role in mitigating the spread of Mers.

site_title: Ascott Reit acquiring 7 assets in Australia, Japan for S$298.3m
summary: Ascott Residence Trust (Ascott Reit) is acquiring 7 assets in Australia and Japan for S$298.3 million, with an Ebitda yield of 5.1%. The acquisitions include three serviced residences and four rental housing properties, expanding the Reit's portfolio and diversifying its geography. The deal is expected to raise FY2014 distribution income by S$3.9 million and distribution per unit by 2.9%. Ascott Reit aims to finance the acquisitions with debt financing and perpetual securities, with the target of reaching S$6 billion by 2017.

site_title: No need for Greek govt measures on banks at this stage: official
summary: A Greek official stated that the country's banking system is not facing an imminent threat to its stability, ruling out the need for government measures at this stage. The official, speaking in Brussels, emphasized the close collaboration between the Greek government and the European Central Bank. The remarks come after positive signs from European leaders regarding a potential deal to release vital bailout funds, easing pressure on the financial system.

site_title: Paris enters race for 2024 Olympic Games hosting
summary: Paris officially announced its bid to host the 2024 Olympic and Paralympic Games, marking the start of a two-year selection process. The city, which last hosted the Games in 1924, will face competition from Rome and other cities. The French National Olympic Committee (CNOSF) sees Paris 2024 as a feasible and flexible Games concept, promising a return to the French capital after a 100-year absence.

site_title: LionGold restructures US$17m convertible bonds due last month
summary: LionGold Corp has restructured US$17 million of existing convertible bonds due last month, with a plan to issue up to S$100 million of redeemable convertible bonds due 2018. The company will make an upfront repayment of US$2 million and repay the balance over 24 months. The proposed issue aims to reduce debt burden and provide financial stability, with net proceeds to be used for debt repayment, working capital, and investments. The new bonds have a minimum conversion price of 0.3 Singapore cent.

images.alt_text: Kalpana Rashiwala

site_title: Germany leads the way in car sharing
summary: Germany leads the way in car sharing, with 140 operators and 1.04 million registered users, accounting for half of Europe's total car-sharing offer. The country's success in car sharing is attributed to its extensive network, public transport systems, and the involvement of carmakers like BMW and Daimler. With 45% of households in Berlin not owning a car, car sharing has become a convenient alternative, with the number of users predicted to rise to 2 million in the next five years.

site_title: Singapore shares close 0.7% higher on Tuesday
summary: Singapore shares rose 0.7% on Tuesday, with the Straits Times Index (STI) closing at 3339.78 points, driven by gains in Global Logistic Properties and banks. This optimism followed a potential debt reform deal in Greece, which may avert a default. The STI was offset by a 0.7% drop in Singtel. Total shares traded were 1.05 billion worth S$917 million, averaging S$0.87 per share.

site_title: Obama's Pacific trade pact progresses on US Senate vote
summary: The US Senate voted 60-37 to limit debate on a bill granting President Barack Obama "fast-track" negotiating authority for a Pacific Rim trade deal, moving the agreement closer to completion. The bill's approval is seen as a win for Obama and a defeat for labor unions. A final vote on the fast-track measure is likely to occur on Wednesday. However, a related hurdle in the House of Representatives remains. The trade package's progress brings US ties with Asia closer to strengthening.

site_title: Curbs on crop prices boost odds of India rate cut
summary: India's Prime Minister Narendra Modi's government has limited gains in guaranteed prices for rice and lentils, boosting the odds of a rate cut by the Reserve Bank of India. The move, which keeps prices at levels not seen since 2006, is seen as a positive signal by central bank governor Raghuram Rajan, who has stressed the correlation between inflation and agricultural purchase prices. Economists expect the RBI to cut the benchmark repurchase rate to 6.5% by March, potentially lowering the yield on the 10-year sovereign bond to 6.5%.

images.alt_text: The government sets agricultural prices twice a year to cover two harvests and more than 20 food crops.

site_title: Nokia said to prefer German carmakers as buyer for maps unit
summary: Nokia is leaning towards selling its maps business, HERE, to a group of German carmakers including Audi, BMW, and Daimler, with a potential valuation of US$4 billion. The company aims to pressure the carmakers to increase their offer by continuing to entertain bids from other bidders. Several private-equity firms, including Apax Partners, have dropped out of the race, and Baidu Inc may now join the carmakers to expand its mapping business in China.

site_title: China's celebrity economist
summary: Dr. Justin Lin Yifu, a Taiwanese-born economist and former World Bank chief economist, discusses his economic philosophy and prescriptions for China. He advocates for an activist industrial policy, where governments "pick winners" and channel resources to desired areas. Lin believes China's economic slowdown is mainly external and cyclical, driven by weak growth in major export markets, rather than structural issues. He argues that China can sustain high investment rates as long as investments are made in productive areas, and consumption will increase as incomes rise. Lin also sees potential for China-India economic relations, with China providing investment in India's infrastructural bottlenecks and foreign direct investment in industrial sectors.

site_title: Norway wealth fund to avoid high-frequency trading in Asia
summary: Norway's US$890 billion wealth fund is taking steps to avoid high-frequency trading (HFT) in Asia, where the practice is gaining momentum. The fund has already reduced its use of algorithmic trading to dodge HFT traders and is now looking at individual markets in Japan. The fund's head of asset strategies, Oeyvind Schanke, expressed concerns about the impact of HFT on institutional investors and the need for trading venues to focus on their needs rather than catering to high-frequency traders. The fund holds significant assets in Asian stocks and is seeking to minimize transaction costs.

site_title: Amazon defends beyond-line-of- sight drone use
summary: Amazon has defended its plan to use drones beyond the line of sight for 30-minute parcel delivery, despite the Federal Aviation Administration's concerns about safety. The company's vice-president, Paul Misener, told lawmakers that flying drones beyond line of sight is not a major safety concern and should be assessed through performance-based operating permissions. Amazon has proposed significant changes to the proposed US drone regulations before introducing Prime Air operations. The FAA is expected to miss its September deadline for finalizing rules governing civilian drones, prompting industry fears that the US is falling behind other countries in developing high-value UAV technology.

site_title: Hershey trims FY sales forecast, announces 300 job cuts
summary: Hershey Co trimmed its full-year sales forecast to 4-5% growth due to weak sales in China and announced 300 job cuts. The company cited a new productivity program expected to result in $65-75 million in pretax savings. Its shares fell 3% in premarket trading. This move follows the company's prior estimate of 6-7% growth.

site_title: Chip off the old wok
summary: Singaporean chefs Lee Tong Kuon and Adrian, and Sam Leong and Joe, are preserving their family's culinary traditions by joining the family business. Chef Lee Tong Kuon, 68, returned to the kitchen at Tao Seafood Asia after retiring, while his son Adrian, 37, took over the front-of-house duties. Chef Sam Leong, 49, presented his son Joe with options, advising him to learn dim sum or pastry making before entering the culinary industry. Joe, 22, trained under his father and worked at various hotels, eventually becoming the demi-chef for pastry at the InterContinental Singapore. The Leong family is set to collaborate on a cookbook featuring their recipes.

images.alt_text: Tay Suan Chiang

site_title: US: Nasdaq at record as Wall St runs on strong data; Greece eyed
summary: US stocks surged, with the Nasdaq Composite reaching a record intraday high of 5,143.316, as strong economic data boosted the market. The Dow Jones industrial average rose 180.1 points, and the S&P 500 gained 20.8 points, while the Nasdaq Composite added 68.07 points. Consumer prices increased, jobless claims fell, and factory activity accelerated, supporting equities. The US Federal Reserve's perceived dovishness also contributed to the rally.

images.alt_text: The Nasdaq Composite on Thursday erased its last standing milestone from the dot-com era as it set a record intraday high, with stocks on Wall Street in rally mode boosted by strong economic data.

site_title: Thailand to seek review by UN aviation body after safety downgrade
summary: Thailand's civil aviation body has been downgraded to Category 2 by the United Nations' International Civil Aviation Authority (ICAO) due to missing a 90-day deadline to resolve significant safety concerns. The country will invite the ICAO to carry out a new inspection in October or November. Thailand will take steps to improve flight safety conditions, including a training program for 25 aviation officials, before the re-audit. The downgrade has resulted in flight bans for some Thai airlines, including NokScoot and Thai AirAsia X, and has led to a call for quick improvements from the national carrier Thai Airways International.

site_title: Singapore civil servants to get special SG50 Bonus of S$500
summary: Singapore civil servants will receive a special one-off payment of S$500 in July, in addition to their usual mid-year bonus of 0.5-month, as a recognition of their contribution towards nation-building. This move signals the government's commitment to raise the salaries of low-wage civil servants, with about 2,500 Division 4 officers benefiting from a built-in monthly wage increase of S$30. The government will decide on the year-end AVC payment after considering Singapore's economic performance in the second half of 2015.

images.alt_text: Lee U-Wen

site_title: IBM makes huge bet on open source software for big data analysis
summary: IBM is investing hundreds of millions of dollars in Apache Spark, an open-source project for real-time data analysis, to strengthen its position in the big data software market. The move is seen as a strategic endorsement of the technology, which promises speed and efficiency in processing vast volumes of data. IBM will contribute developers, technology, and education programs, and embed Spark in its data analysis and commerce software. The investment aims to attract developers and strengthen IBM's ecosystem, as the company primarily makes its living selling tailored applications to individual companies.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks down 0.20% at open
summary: Hong Kong stocks fell 0.20% in the first minutes of trade on Tuesday, following losses on Wall Street amid Greece's debt reform deal struggles. The Hang Seng Index eased 54.14 points to 26,807.67.

site_title: Parkson Retail Asia subsidiary to dispose about 30% equity interest in Parkson Hanoi
summary: Parkson Retail Asia's subsidiary Parkson Vietnam Co will dispose of about 30% equity interest in Parkson Hanoi Co to Hoang Manh Cuong for US$5,000. This deal is aimed at facilitating the closure of Parkson Hanoi's Landmark 72 store, which ceased operations in January 2015. Parkson Vietnam will manage the stores, which have been loss-making, with Parkson Vietnam's stake reduced to 45.5%. The disposal is expected to be completed by June 30 and will not impact Parkson Retail Asia's financials.

site_title: China developers turn to online financing
summary: Chinese real estate developers are turning to online financing as traditional sources of funding dry up. The market is expected to more than triple to over 350 billion yuan this year, with developers using peer-to-peer lending and crowdfunding to raise funds. Despite concerns about information asymmetry and inadequate risk management, the industry is expected to introduce regulation this year. Developers see online financing as a way to secure cheap capital and tap into the wealth of Chinese high-net-worth individuals, with some platforms offering better investment returns for lenders who also buy properties.

site_title: US: Wall St opens lower after Greece talks fall through
summary: US stocks plummeted at the open on Monday, with the Dow Jones falling 108.87 points (0.61%) to 17,789.97, the S&P 500 losing 13.76 points (0.66%) to 2,080.35, and the Nasdaq Composite dropping 44.43 points (0.88%) to 5,006.67. The decline comes as Greece's debt talks with international creditors collapsed, raising concerns of a potential default. The market's reaction to US President Trump's recent threats is also being closely watched.

site_title: Living in the now
summary: A 5.9-magnitude earthquake struck Mount Kinabalu on June 5, killing a 29-year-old teacher, Terrence Sebastian Loo, who helped save 12 students from the mountain. Loo, known for his supportive and playful nature, had graduated with a degree in real estate but found teaching to be his true calling. He died trying to protect his students, and his family and friends remember him as a brave and selfless individual. The article concludes that Loo's death serves as a reminder to appreciate the present moment and live life to the fullest, embracing spontaneity, adventure, and the pursuit of one's passions.

site_title: Asia's biggest hospital operator IHH Healthcare faces currency losses on lira
summary: IHH Healthcare, Asia's largest hospital operator, expects its Turkish unit, Acibadem, to post currency losses due to the slump in the lira. The company's CFO, Tan See Haw, stated that the losses are accounting in nature and unrealized, with no impact on cash flow. IHH does not hedge against such accounting translations and plans to conserve hard currency received from medical tourism customers. The company expects the strengthening of the Singapore dollar to boost its net assets and results, while the weaker lira will have an opposite effect.

site_title: UK revises up GDP as construction data changes kick in
summary: Britain's economic growth rate was revised upwards to 3.1% in 2014, up from 2.8%, according to the Office for National Statistics. The revision was due to changes in the construction sector's price calculations and seasonal adjustments. Construction output fell 0.2% in Q1 2015, but rose 1.5% year-over-year. The revised data reflects the impact of the May 7 UK national elections, which led to a weaker construction sector and slower economic growth.

The analysts' recommendations and target prices are based on their analysis of market trends and industry developments.

site_title: Malaysia's Felda shares hit record low on Eagle High bid
summary: Malaysia's Felda Global Ventures Holdings Bhd shares plummeted to a record low after the company announced a plan to spend around US$680 million to acquire a 37% stake in Indonesia's PT Eagle High Plantations Tbk and a 95% stake in a sugar project for US$67 million. Analysts deemed the deal expensive, citing Felda's limited financial resources. The move has raised concerns about the company's financial sustainability.

site_title: Xi moves into uncharted territory with purge
summary: Chinese President Xi Jinping has taken the country into uncharted territory with the conviction and life imprisonment of former chief of domestic security Zhou Yongkang, the most senior leader to be jailed for corruption in over 65 years of Communist rule. Zhou was found guilty of abuse of power, accepting bribes, and revealing state secrets, and his downfall marks a significant crackdown on corruption within the ruling Communist Party. The verdict follows the purge of other high-ranking officials and raises questions about Xi's ultimate goal: to cleanse the party of corruption or consolidate his hold on power.

site_title: Out of patience, IMF flexes muscles in Greek debt crisis
summary: The International Monetary Fund (IMF) has increased pressure on Greece to meet its bailout demands, citing a lack of progress in negotiations. The IMF, led by Managing Director Christine Lagarde, has publicly stated its frustration with European partners and Athens' intransigence, calling for "difficult decisions" to be made to lighten Greece's debt burden. The IMF's actions come as Greece faces a looming debt payment and a potential default, which could impact Lagarde's bid to renew her job. The Fund has warned that if an agreement is not reached, it will lose credibility and resources.

site_title: EU opens anti-trust probe into Amazon e-book business
summary: The EU's anti-trust regulator has opened a formal investigation into Amazon's e-book distribution business, targeting the company's arrangements with publishers. Competition Commissioner Margrethe Vestager stated her duty to ensure Amazon's practices are not harmful to consumers. The investigation aims to determine if Amazon's business practices are justified. This is the latest Brussels inquiry to target Amazon, following previous probes into the company's dominance in various markets. The outcome of the investigation is yet to be determined.

site_title: China inbound tourism on road to recovery
summary: China's inbound tourism to Singapore appears to be recovering, with anecdotal accounts from travel operators and hospitality players indicating a 20% increase in business for the first half of 2015. Despite a 40% drop in Chinese visitors in the second half of 2014, some hotels have seen a steady increase in Chinese travelers, with Royal Plaza on Scotts reporting a 6% increase since 2011. The Singapore Tourism Board has introduced new visa measures and marketing campaigns to accelerate the growth of Chinese visitors, with a focus on peak travel periods and strategic advertising.

site_title: Roxy-Pacific sets up S$500m multi-currency debt issuance programme
summary: Roxy-Pacific Holdings Limited has established a S$500 million multi-currency debt issuance programme, allowing for the issuance of notes and perpetual securities in various currencies and tenures. United Overseas Bank Limited has been appointed as the sole arranger and dealer. Net proceeds will be used for general corporate purposes, including repayment or refinancing of existing borrowings and financing investments.

site_title: Felda said to seek buyer for US$150 million North American assets
summary: Felda Global Ventures Holdings Bhd, the world's largest producer of crude palm oil, is seeking a buyer for its US$150 million North American assets, including crushing and refining businesses in the US and Canada. The company has invited offers for these operations, which could fetch about US$150 million, as it seeks to increase its core palm oil plantation business and expand trading operations. This move comes after the company's shares have dropped 12% this year.

site_title: Asian jet fuel refining profits could weaken on Mers outbreak
summary: Asian jet fuel refining profits are expected to weaken further due to a drop in flight bookings and a deadly respiratory disease outbreak in South Korea. The Middle East Respiratory Syndrome has caused dozens of suspected cases in Hong Kong and thousands of cancelled trips, affecting demand from Europe. Regional inventory is set to build, leading to jet fuel storage or blending into gasoil. Despite a 10% rise in Indonesia's jet fuel demand during Ramadan, losses in margins are anticipated, particularly in the June-July period.

site_title: China May industrial output up 6.1% y-o-y, meets forecast
summary: China's industrial production rose 6.1% year-on-year in May, meeting forecasts, while retail sales increased 10.1% and fixed asset investment expanded 11.4% in the January-May period. This marks a three-month high for industrial output, amid China's slowing economy, which grew 7.0% in the first quarter. Authorities are trying to engineer a controlled slowdown to transform the growth model, but fear too fast a deceleration. The data suggests the economy remains on track for a slowdown, putting pressure on policymakers.

site_title: Living in the moment
summary: Twitter CEO Dick Costolo is stepping down on July 1, 2015, after six years leading the company. He likens Twitter to a town square where people gather to exchange information and connect with others. Costolo believes the platform's spontaneity and 140-character limit foster creativity and wit. Despite Wall Street's disapproval, Costolo remains a well-liked leader among Twitter employees. He emphasizes the importance of Twitter's public, real-time, conversational, and widely distributed nature. Costolo also highlights the company's potential for social good, citing examples of how Twitter helped during natural disasters and global events. He will be replaced by Jack Dorsey, who will take over as interim CEO.

site_title: PropertyGuru secures S$175m from 3 investors
summary: PropertyGuru secures S$175 million in funding from TPG, Emtek Group, and Square Peg Capital, with the investment expected to be completed by mid-June. The funding will support the company's growth in existing markets in Singapore, Malaysia, Thailand, and Indonesia, with a focus on product innovation, branding, and marketing. PropertyGuru's co-founder and CEO Steve Melhuish stated that the company is considering an IPO and will prioritize strengthening its presence in its existing markets rather than expanding rapidly.

site_title: China May inflation cools to 1.2% y-o-y, weaker than forecast
summary: China's consumer inflation eased to 1.2% year-on-year in May, lower than forecast, raising concerns about growing deflationary pressures. The producer price index remained unchanged at minus 4.6% for the 38th consecutive month. This marks a weakening economy, which may put pressure on policymakers. The decline in inflation and producer prices indicates a cooling economy.

site_title: Long ER waits aggravate spread of virus in Seoul
summary: A 35-year-old man in South Korea waited two-and-a-half days in an emergency ward for a bed at the Samsung Medical Center, where nearly 900 people, including 55 infected with Middle East respiratory syndrome (Mers), had passed through before his diagnosis on May 30. The hospital's wait times and family visits are blamed for spreading the virus, prompting calls for change. South Korea's Health Ministry has promised to address emergency room bottlenecks. The outbreak has infected 122 people, with 10 dead, and highlights gaps in the country's healthcare system despite having a sophisticated healthcare system and universal insurance.

site_title: Park seeks to prevent Mers crisis overshadowing US trip
summary: South Korean President Park Geun Hye is facing pressure to contain the spread of the Middle East respiratory syndrome (Mers) outbreak, which has claimed nine lives and infected 108 people. The outbreak threatens to overshadow her upcoming trip to meet President Barack Obama, with her approval rating at a near all-time low. Acting Prime Minister Choi Kyung Hwan vowed to end the crisis by the end of the week, but the government's handling of the outbreak has been criticized for being slow and inadequate. The Mers outbreak is expected to hurt consumer spending and economic growth, with Goldman Sachs cutting its 2015 economic growth forecast.

site_title: South Korea finance minister: concerned about Mers impact on economy
summary: South Korea's finance minister, Choi Kyung-hwan, expressed concern over the impact of Middle East Respiratory Syndrome (Mers) on the country's economy, citing potential negative effects on private consumption and investment sentiment. The finance minister stated that the government will take swift countermeasures to mitigate the economic impact and asked South Koreans to cooperate to avoid hindering economic activity. Following the report of 23 new infections and six deaths, the government has yet to announce specific measures to stimulate the economy.

site_title: Nanyang Polytechnic appoints new principal and CEO
summary: Nanyang Polytechnic has appointed Liew Jeanne as its new principal and CEO, replacing Chan Lee Mun, effective July 1. Liew, a 23-year NYP veteran, brings experience as deputy principal and registrar of Singapore Polytechnic. Chan, who served for 23 years, spearheaded strategic plans and initiatives in PET, CET, innovation, and internationalization.

images.alt_text: Prisca Ang

site_title: Koyo unit bags two contracts worth S$17.3m
summary: KOYO International's subsidiary, Koyo Engineering (SE Asia), secured two contracts worth approximately S$17.3 million, increasing its gross order book to S$41 million. The contracts involve mechanical, electrical, and plumbing services at a polytechnic campus and school zone maintenance under the Ministry of Education. The deals are expected to positively contribute to the group's earnings for the next four financial years.

site_title: S$ falls against greenback on strong US jobs data
summary: The Singapore dollar (SGD) fell 1% against the US dollar on Monday following stronger-than-expected US monthly jobs data and a hike in US interest rates. The Malaysian ringgit also slid 1.3% against the US dollar, reaching a nine-year low, as investors focus on the impact of the US Federal Reserve's taper tantrums on emerging markets. The SGD's decline was attributed to pressure from the Malaysian ringgit, with the currency managed against a trade-weighted basket of currencies.

site_title: Greece hasn't agreed to a 1 per cent primary surplus this year: finance minister
summary: Greece's Finance Minister Yanis Varoufakis stated that the country has not agreed to a 1% primary surplus for this year, contradicting earlier reports. The surplus target, excluding debt payments, has been a point of contention in negotiations with European leaders. Greece aims for a 0.6-0.85% surplus, but time is running out to avoid a default by the end of June. Varoufakis expressed concerns that a 1% target is "part of the problem and not the solution."

images.alt_text: Greece has not agreed to meet a primary budget surplus of 1 per cent for this year, Finance Minister Yanis Varoufakis told parliament on Thursday, amid talks between the Greek premier and European leaders over a cash-for-reforms deal in Brussels.

site_title: Too big to succeed? Investors want 'radical surgery' at HSBC
summary: HSBC shareholders are urging the bank's CEO Stuart Gulliver and chairman Douglas Flint to announce radical measures to restore profitability, citing the bank's high costs and compliance issues. The bank has paid around $8.6 billion in fines for compliance failures and faces allegations of tax evasion. Investors believe HSBC's global reach is becoming too expensive and are considering a break-up. A strategy day on June 9 is expected to reveal the bank's plans to increase profitability, with analysts predicting potential job losses and a restructure of the bank's global operations.

site_title: Death toll from China ship disaster reaches 331
summary: A Chinese cruise ship capsized during a storm in the Yangtze River, resulting in 331 confirmed deaths and over 100 still missing. The Eastern Star, carrying 456 passengers, overturned on Monday night, with 14 survivors found, including the captain. The ship operator, Eastern Star, apologized and cooperated with investigations, while police detained the captain and chief engineer. An initial investigation found no evidence of overloading or life vest shortage. Relatives of missing passengers expressed frustration at a lack of information from the government.

site_title: EasyJet to use drones to inspect jets, mulling 3D-printed parts
summary: EasyJet plans to use drones to inspect jets on the ground starting next year, aiming to trim maintenance downtime and costs. The airline has already successfully used a drone to inspect a plane and will roll out the technology at engineering bases over the next 12 months. Additionally, EasyJet is experimenting with 3D-printed parts, such as cabin components, to reduce repair times and storage needs. The goal is to minimize delays caused by mechanical failures, which can cost up to 15,000 pounds per overnight delay.

site_title: Iceland parliament summoned for capital controls vote
summary: Iceland's parliament is set to vote late on a bill to tighten capital controls, which were introduced in 2008 following the collapse of three major banks. The controls, aimed at preventing a run on the currency, will be unwound as part of a plan to restore investment and stabilize the economy. The government plans to impose a tax on recovered debt from the failed banks to stem outflows and reduce the risk of a currency plunge. The vote comes ahead of the planned abolition of capital controls, which are expected to be announced on Monday.

site_title: CityDev shares hit by news of removal from an index
summary: City Developments (CDL), a Singapore property and hotel conglomerate, saw its stock plummet 5.4% after being removed from the FTSE EPRA NAREIT Global Developed index due to not meeting the income criterion. The stock price dropped to S$9.77, its largest daily decline since 2013. CDL cited a potential issue with the index's definition of 'relevant real estate activities' as the reason for the removal, which will take effect on June 22. Despite the decline, analysts remain upbeat on CDL, viewing it as a good buying opportunity.

site_title: Chief Justice to hear MND application for expedited appeal hearing on AHPETC case
summary: Chief Justice Sundaresh Menon will hear the Ministry of National Development's application to expedite its appeal against a High Court decision not to appoint independent accountants at the Workers' Party-run town council. The hearing is scheduled for Thursday. The MND's appeal seeks to challenge the court's decision, which denied its request for independent accountants at the town council. The Chief Justice will decide whether the case warrants an expedited hearing.

site_title: US consumer spending flat, inflation pressures muted
summary: US consumer spending was flat in April, with households cutting back on purchases and boosting savings. The economy is expected to grow moderately in the second quarter. Inflation pressures were muted, with a price index for consumer spending recording its smallest gain since 2009. The economy is slowly rebounding from its first-quarter slump, despite a strong dollar and deep spending cuts in the energy sector.

site_title: Indian Ivy League graduates flock to technology boom back home
summary: Thousands of Indian Ivy League graduates are returning to their home country, drawn by the booming technology industry with more green-field opportunities than Silicon Valley. Many left the US due to US immigration barriers, while others chose to stay in India to capitalize on the country's growing tech sector. Indian startups such as Snapdeal and Flipkart are attracting top talent, with venture capitalists and hedge funds investing heavily in the sector. The trend is a shift from the 1980s and 1990s, when US education and employment were the brass rings for engineers, with India now offering similar opportunities.

site_title: Berlin landlords up in arms over new law
summary: Berlin has implemented a new law limiting rent increases to 10% above the area average, known as the Mietspiegel, in an effort to keep housing affordable. The law, which applies to new leases, has sparked opposition from landlords, who claim the index is statistically flawed and will curb their income expectations. Critics argue that the Mietspiegel, which only considers 10,000 apartments out of Berlin's two million, does not accurately reflect market conditions. The move is part of a broader effort by the German government to address rising housing costs, with some landlords already suing the city over the new rules.

site_title: External woes continue to weigh on STI
summary: The Straits Times Index (STI) fell 13.34 points to 3,320.33, marking a soft Monday session with low trading volume and minimal action in blue chips or penny stocks. External factors such as Greece's debt problems, US interest rate uncertainty, and China's slowing economy have contributed to the local market's downturn. The exception is Hong Kong, which has seen increased interest and volume following its link to the Shanghai exchange.

site_title: Changing as conditions shift
summary: Artradis, Singapore's largest hedge fund in 2008, made a significant amount of money due to trading volatility. However, no further information is provided about the current status or events following this peak.

site_title: Oil prices edge up as firm demand counters oversupply
summary: Oil prices edged up on Tuesday due to firm demand, despite expectations of OPEC not cutting output at its meeting this week. Crude oil futures rose to $65 per barrel, with US crude up 15 cents to $60.35. Saudi oil minister Ali al-Naimi stated that demand would pick up in the second half of the year, while firm refinery demand also supported prices. However, the contrasting views among OPEC members, with Saudi Arabia favoring high output and others seeking cuts, may lead to a rebalancing of the market.

site_title: South Korea bent on stopping any further spread of Mers
summary: South Korea confirmed five more Mers cases, bringing the total to 30, with two deaths reported. The country has taken measures to prevent further spread, including shutting over 200 schools and quarantining 1,300 people. Samsung has postponed a staff conference due to public safety concerns. The World Health Organization has reported 1,161 Mers cases globally, with 436 related deaths, mostly in the Middle East. South Korea has banned overseas travel for isolated individuals, and pressure is growing for the government to disclose the names of hospitals treating infected patients.

site_title: London's future residential hotspots
summary: London's future residential hotspots are being identified as areas with high demand and limited supply, such as Camden, Hackney, and Greenwich. These areas are expected to outperform in the new-build market, with prices rising due to gentrification and urbanization. Experts predict that London's property market will continue to thrive, driven by investment and tourism. However, concerns over affordability and Brexit uncertainty remain. The areas with potential for growth are expected to be in the central and eastern parts of the city, with a focus on regeneration and urban renewal projects.

site_title: 'Amazing' results seen for IDA accredited tech companies (Amended)
summary: Singapore's IDA programme Accreditation@IDA has seen "amazing" results, with two out of eight supported tech companies winning government projects worth over S$1 million. The initiative provides assurance to potential buyers on Singapore-based tech products, helping companies win projects by government agencies and large companies. The two winning companies, KAI Square and Inspire-Tech, offer innovative video analytics solutions and file-sharing systems. IDA executive deputy chairman Steve Leonard attributed the success to the accreditation process, which has improved the quality of products and business structures for participating companies.

site_title: Intel buys Altera for US$16.7b as chip deals accelerate
summary: Intel has agreed to buy Altera Corp for $16.7 billion, adding to a record year of chip industry consolidation. Intel will pay $54 per share in stock and cash, a 56% premium over Altera's closing share price. The deal aims to mitigate slowing growth and rising costs for Intel, the world's largest chipmaker. This is the largest deal in the US$300 billion semiconductor business, following Avago Technologies' $37 billion acquisition of Broadcom Corp last week.

site_title: Saudi to post massive budget deficit: IMF
summary: Saudi Arabia is forecast to post a budget deficit of 20% of gross domestic product in 2015 due to a sharp decline in oil revenues, according to the IMF. The projected deficit translates to around $130 billion, despite Riyadh's own projection of a $39 billion shortfall. The decline in oil prices has resulted in a substantial decrease in revenues, but strong public spending has limited the impact on the rest of the economy, with growth projected at 3.5% this year and 2.7% in 2016.

site_title: The lessons of crises
summary: Former US Treasury and IMF official Charles Dallara, a renowned expert in financial crisis management, warns that seeds of crises are being planted. He attributes the causes of financial crises to a sudden break of confidence, citing examples from the Greek debt crisis and the 2008 global financial crisis. Dallara emphasizes the need for global financial institutions to have greater authority to prevent or deal with crises, and for nation states to cede some authority to these institutions. He also stresses the importance of pragmatic solutions, close and open dialogue, and being trustworthy in crisis situations. Dallara suggests that a global super-agency is needed, but one that is jointly owned by the public and private sectors, to handle crises at the capital market and banking levels.

site_title: UK mortgage approvals stage biggest jump in over six years
summary: UK mortgage approvals surged to 68,076 in April, the highest level in 14 months and the largest jump in over six years. This marks a reversal of the decline in mortgage approvals that occurred throughout most of 2014. Strong consumer demand, fueled by household spending, has driven the economic recovery, despite weak wage growth. Net mortgage lending rose to 1.735 billion pounds, while consumer credit grew to 1.173 billion pounds in April. This growth contrasts with a weaker outlook for British manufacturers.

site_title: Westpac splits retail and business banking division
summary: Westpac Banking Corp, Australia's No 2 lender, has split its retail and business banking division into two separate divisions: consumer banking and commercial and business banking. The move aims to simplify the organization and improve accountability and customer service. Analysts say the restructuring should lead to greater focus and earnings upside. The retail and business banking division, which accounted for 36% of group cash earnings, will be led by new executives, with George Frazis taking over consumer banking and David Lindberg leading commercial and business banking.

site_title: HK group to buy Seattle's Columbia Center: report
summary: A group led by Gaw Capital Partners has agreed to buy Columbia Center in Seattle for over $700 million, a record price for an individual office building in the city. The 76-storey building, once home to Amazon, will be acquired by Hong Kong-based Gaw Capital and other Asian investors. The sale marks a significant move by foreign investors seeking higher returns on US real estate, with Seattle's tech industry driving demand. The building, built in 1985, has 87% occupancy and features an observatory and private club.

site_title: Update: China May exports fall less than expected, but imports tumble
summary: China's exports in May fell 2.5% from a year ago, less than expected, while imports dropped 17.6%, a double-digit decline. The country's trade surplus reached a near-record $59.49 billion. Despite a slightly improved export figure, analysts predict the economy remains sluggish due to weak overseas demand and rising labor costs. The government is expected to release further stimulus measures to stabilize the economy, which is on track for its worst year in a quarter of a century.

images.alt_text: China's exports in May fell less than expected but a double-digit drop in imports will likely keep the pressure on Beijing for more stimulus to avert a sharper economic slowdown.

site_title: Singapore: Weakness in bond markets drags STI lower
summary: The Straits Times Index (STI) fell 4.84 points to 3,345, marking its 20th point loss of the year, due to a weak trading session with 140 rises and 298 falls. Pressure on European and US bonds, causing yields to rise sharply, was cited as the main factor. Notable movers on the STI included Singtel, DBS, and UOB on the upside, while Noble and the Singapore Exchange (SGX) fell. The index's year-to-date loss increased to 0.6%.

site_title: Singapore banks lure investors betting on Fed rate rise
summary: Singaporean banks, including DBS Group Holdings, Oversea-Chinese Banking Corp, and United Overseas Bank, have seen their shares rise as investors bet on a US interest-rate hike this year. The banks' borrowing costs and loan volumes have dropped, making them attractive to investors. Analysts expect the Federal Reserve to raise its benchmark rate in December, which will boost interest income and margins at the banks. The mean price-book ratio of the banks has slid to 1.25 times, the lowest since February 2014, presenting a buying opportunity for investors.

images.alt_text: Singaporean bank stocks are priced near the cheapest valuations in 16 months as the city's borrowing costs and loan volumes drop, presenting an opportunity to investors betting on a US interest-rate hike this year.
